--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., gosd123 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > CHRIS, > > what the heck have you done to this forum?????????????????/ > > > thanks for letting people know!!! you just messed this whole thing up > and all the messages have disappeared!!! > > > thanks for letting people know and thanks =for giving us the > opportunity to save messages etc... > > > NOT! > > danG Hey Chill Dan! In fact, there has been a banner at the top of the club for 6 months or so, warning that clubs and groups are merging. It's quite likely that Chis himself is in for a shock cos he probably doesn't know yet! If you want to moan at someone, moan at Yahoo! But good luck!

luck :)

15. Help on reading this notation.
From: "moditha" <moditha@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Mar 2002 00:35:56 -0000

Hi

I want to learn speedng methods in rubiks cube, so I found the
following link which has last layer moves

http://www.ssie.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/orient.html

Now the problem is even though I identify the pattern and do the
correct algorithm, it doesn't seem to work.

I hold the last layer on top position when doing this. I think that
is the way to follow those algos. am i right ?

So why it doesnt work? May be I do not understand the folloing
notations.

O7a) (13,13,11,4) Rs U'B'U B U B U B'U'Ls
07b) (12,18,9,6) R² U²B F'L'B²F²R'D²R²B F'

can any body decypher it to me please?

to my understanding move 7a means

Rs = RL' = Right layer clockwise 90 degrees and Left layer counter
clockwise 90 degrees ?

the rest also the same right ?

Any help will be appreciated.

Regards
KK

19. Re: Help on reading this notation.
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Mar 2002 03:00:26 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "moditha" <moditha@y...> wrote: > Hi > > I want to learn speedng methods in rubiks cube, so I found the > following link which has last layer moves > > http://www.ssie.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/orient.html > > Now the problem is even though I identify the pattern and do the > correct algorithm, it doesn't seem to work. > > I hold the last layer on top position when doing this. I think that > is the way to follow those algos. am i right ? > > So why it doesnt work? May be I do not understand the folloing > notations. > > O7a) (13,13,11,4) Rs U'B'U B U B U B'U'Ls > 07b) (12,18,9,6) R² U²B F'L'B²F²R'D²R²B F' > > can any body decypher it to me please? > > to my understanding move 7a means > > Rs = RL' = Right layer clockwise 90 degrees and Left layer counter > clockwise 90 degrees ? > > the rest also the same right ? > > Any help will be appreciated. > > Regards > KK About the only thing i can tell you is to make sure your holding the cube in the right position, and make sure you turn the correct sides the correct direction,(i used to get confused on B and B') so maybe its a problem similar to that. And make sure you keep the front side as the front and don't let yourself accidentially turn the cube and turn the wrong side..... well i think thats about it -Heath

23. A New Forum!
From: the_phantom_cuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Mar 2002 05:53:51 -0000

Hi gang, Hi Jess,

I had the same idea than Jess: build a real forum for the community,
the new Yahoo! Group is really awful, slow and ad-full.

That's why yesterday I installed on my site a complete forum (phpBB)

Try it here:
http://ulysse.iie.cnam.fr/formet/phpBB
(the URL is likely to change in the future)

This forum is powerful and easy to use, with a lot of features:
(here are the main ones)
-registered members, moderators
-several categories and sub-forums
-HTML code and/or BBCode in posts, smileys, images
-new posts indicator
-themes, languages support
-user preferences
-private messages
-powerful search engine
-answers notification by email
-... and much more

and everything is configurable, just ask, (the color theme may
change soon)

The different categories and sub-forums are not created yet (it will
be done today, you can suggest a hierarchy), but you can already
test it.

So, what do you think about it?

To better replace this yahoo group, I can also create a chatroom and
a place for files and photos.

I think everything is said, I'm waiting for your reactions.
I hope you will like the idea.

Benoit

31. New forum and new chat!
From: cubomaniac70 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Mar 2002 22:38:49 -0000

Hi everybody,

A lot of guys here seems to like Benoit Formet's forum and have
already posted on it.
It will probably become the successor of this Yahoo group which is
slow and now has some bothering advertisements.
I remind you that the address of this new forum is http://www-
eleves.iie.cnam.fr/formet/phpBB (this address is liable to change,
but for the moment it works at this address)

If everybody moves to this new forum, which seems to be the case
gradually, a new chat is also necessary.
So Benoit has installed two chats on his page : there are available
at http://www-eleves.iie.cnam.fr/formet/chat/ and http://www-
eleves.iie.cnam.fr/formet/chat.html
I suggest that you try both of them, and we'll decided which one will
be used in the future.
The first one's great advantage is that messages are kept during 96
hours. So you can access them be recalling the history.
The second one is similar to the actual Yahoo chat, and it can also
be accessed by irc.
It will soon be available from the forum with a link, but for now
just try them at the urls I gave above.


If you have any suggestions or questions, post them on Benoit's forum.



32. New forum and new chat!

Date: Fri, 29 Mar 2002 22:39:19 -0000

Hi everybody,

A lot of guys here seems to like Benoit Formet's forum and have
already posted on it.
It will probably become the successor of this Yahoo group which is
slow and now has some bothering advertisements.
I remind you that the address of this new forum is http://www-
eleves.iie.cnam.fr/formet/phpBB (this address is liable to change,
but for the moment it works at this address)

If everybody moves to this new forum, which seems to be the case
gradually, a new chat is also necessary.
So Benoit has installed two chats on his page : there are available
at http://www-eleves.iie.cnam.fr/formet/chat/ (please select the
Rubik's cube room, or an error will occur. For the moment this is
only a test period) and http://www-eleves.iie.cnam.fr/formet/chat.html
I suggest that you try both of them, and we'll decided which one will
be used in the future.
The first one's great advantage is that messages are kept during 96
hours. So you can access them be recalling the history.
The second one is similar to the actual Yahoo chat, and it can also
be accessed by irc.
It will soon be available from the forum with a link, but for now
just try them at the urls I gave above.


If you have any suggestions or questions, post them on Benoit's forum.

36. beginner needs some advice
From: "afoxesq" <afox@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 04 Apr 2002 16:08:11 -0000

I am using the method to solve the cube where you make the cross on
the bottom, then get the middle edges and bottom pieces in the
correct spot, leaving you with one "working corner" and one "working
edge". I have followed the instructions faithfully, but since my
working corner is not adjacent to my working edge, going to the next
step in the directions messes up my cube further rather than fixing
it. Can someone tell me what I am doing wrong? The directions I am
following are located at:

http://www.puzzlesolver.com/seqential/rubik/cube/index.shtml

Thanks
Anna

I've looked at various directions on the 'net and these seem the
easiest to follow - Does anyone have other suggestions?? THANKS - I'd
like to get it right and then work on my speed.




37. Re: beginner needs some advice
From: bobbit_at_mac_dot_com <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 04 Apr 2002 18:02:29 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "afoxesq" <afox@i...> wrote: > I am using the method to solve the cube where you make the cross on > the bottom, then get the middle edges and bottom pieces in the > correct spot, leaving you with one "working corner" and one "working > edge". I have followed the instructions faithfully, but since my > working corner is not adjacent to my working edge, going to the next > step in the directions messes up my cube further rather than fixing > it. Can someone tell me what I am doing wrong? The directions I am > following are located at: > > http://www.puzzlesolver.com/seqential/rubik/cube/index.shtml > > Thanks > Anna > > I've looked at various directions on the 'net and these seem the > easiest to follow - Does anyone have other suggestions?? THANKS - I'd > like to get it right and then work on my speed. Hello Anna, There is another forum you could ask at: http://www-eleves.iie.cnam.fr/formet/phpBB At that forum, pictures can be placed in messages, it makes it easier to follow peoples suggestions. I use the same method you are using and if I follow where your problem is, I think I understand. It probably doesn't matter which corner and edge are your working pieces. Turn them so they are together, even if the slices end up being a different colour. Will you be using one alg (an F2L alg) to get both pieces in at once? Or are you following a simpler two step alg to get the pieces in separately? I usually use two algs, unless the pieces are in a position that I happen to know the single alg for.
38. Re: beginner needs some advice
From: bobbit_at_mac_dot_com <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 04 Apr 2002 18:01:46 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "afoxesq" <afox@i...> wrote: > I am using the method to solve the cube where you make the cross on > the bottom, then get the middle edges and bottom pieces in the > correct spot, leaving you with one "working corner" and one "working > edge". I have followed the instructions faithfully, but since my > working corner is not adjacent to my working edge, going to the next > step in the directions messes up my cube further rather than fixing > it. Can someone tell me what I am doing wrong? The directions I am > following are located at: > > http://www.puzzlesolver.com/seqential/rubik/cube/index.shtml > > Thanks > Anna > > I've looked at various directions on the 'net and these seem the > easiest to follow - Does anyone have other suggestions?? THANKS - I'd > like to get it right and then work on my speed. Hello Anna, There is another forum you could ask at: http://www-eleves.iie.cnam.fr/formet/phpBB At that forum, pictures can be placed in messages, it makes it easier to follow peoples suggestions. I use the same method you are using and if I follow where your problem is, I think I understand. It probably doesn't matter which corner and edge are your working pieces. Turn them so they are together, even if the slices end up being a different colour. Will you be using one alg (an F2L alg) to get both pieces in at once? Or are you following a simpler two step alg to get the pieces in separately? I usually use two algs, unless the pieces are in a position that I happen to know the single alg for.
39. Re: beginner needs some advice
From: bobbit_at_mac_dot_com <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 04 Apr 2002 18:07:47 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "afoxesq" <afox@i...> wrote: > I am using the method to solve the cube where you make the cross on > the bottom, then get the middle edges and bottom pieces in the > correct spot, leaving you with one "working corner" and one "working > edge". I have followed the instructions faithfully, but since my > working corner is not adjacent to my working edge, going to the next > step in the directions messes up my cube further rather than fixing > it. Can someone tell me what I am doing wrong? The directions I am > following are located at: > > http://www.puzzlesolver.com/seqential/rubik/cube/index.shtml > > Thanks > Anna > > I've looked at various directions on the 'net and these seem the > easiest to follow - Does anyone have other suggestions?? THANKS - I'd > like to get it right and then work on my speed. Hello Anna, There is another forum you could ask at: http://www-eleves.iie.cnam.fr/formet/phpBB At that forum, pictures can be placed in messages, it makes it easier to follow peoples suggestions. I use the same method you are using and if I follow where your problem is, I think I understand. It probably doesn't matter which corner and edge are your working pieces. Turn them so they are together, even if the slices end up being a different colour. Will you be using one alg (an F2L alg) to get both pieces in at once? Or are you following a simpler two step alg to get the pieces in separately? I usually use two algs, unless the pieces are in a position that I happen to know the single alg for. I use Dan Knights instructions which are very easy to understand (they needed to be for me!) see http://benjerry.middlebury.edu/~knights/CubeInfo.html
40. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] beginner needs some advice
From: john blade <justinhak@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 4 Apr 2002 10:26:07 -0800 (PST)

Hi Anna I read that you've got some problems solving
the cube. I must say that the method you are trying to
master isn't a very fast one. It's a decent method but
it isn't fast. if you want to do speedcubing avoid all
the layer methods, except one. The method I'm talking
about is called the Lars Petrus method.

Lars Petrus was the Swedish champion and he gained the
fourth place at the World Championchips in 1982. He
did this with his method.

The Lars Petrus method isn't very easy but with some
practice I'm sure you can master it.
This is the site with the method.

http://ng.netgate.net/~mette/lars/cubedude/index.html

If you get stuck while trying to solve it tell me and
I will help you.




__________________________________________________
Do You Yahoo!?
Yahoo! Tax Center - online filing with TurboTax
http://taxes.yahoo.com/


41. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] beginner needs some advice
From: bobbit_at_mac_dot_com <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 04 Apr 2002 19:12:44 -0000

Blade, I disagree with you. As we have discussed on here
before, all methods if learnt to an advanced level will yield
averages of less than 20 seconds. A layer by layer method is a
good way to learn and when the time is right it is easy to learn a
full blown Jessica method. I agree that the Petrus method is
worth a look but it is not necessarily the best method for
everyone, it's really down to the individual. I leant the method I
was most comfotable with.

Sorry my last post went through 3 times, I was having finger
trouble along with being impatient with this damn yahooey site. I
wrote that I learnt from Dan Knights page. Having looked at his
site again, I realised I don't think I did learn from there, I've
forgotten where I learnt from. Try this instead:

http://www.cubeland.fr.st/

It's pretty much the method I use, I average 45 seconds and I'm
getting better still. All I have to do now is learn some more
specialised algs so I can do the Jessica method properly and
average 17 seconds! (honest)

48. Preparation for permutation algorithms
From: ilovemycube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 06 Apr 2002 11:31:49 -0000

Hi friendz,

Maybe I am old-fashioned, but for the time being I stay with this
forum.

I made some cubing videos to see where I can still improve. I
sometimes lose valuable time during the preparation for the
permutation algorithm.

These small steps are done after doing the orientation algorithm:
A) move the upper layer to get to a position in which you are able to
recognize which permutation situation the cube is in
B) recognize which permutation algorithm to use
C) move upper layer to get to starting position of the permutation
algorithm
D) execute the permutation algorithm
E) do a correction move of the upper layer to solve the cube

You can skip step A, if you are able to recognize each situation from
any angle.

It should be possible to do steps A and B during the end of the
execution of the orientation algorithm, at least for some cases.

For step C it would be good if you have alternative algorithms,
depending on the angle of the upper layer. On page
http://www.speedcubing.com/final_layer_permutation.html there is an
overview of the algorithms, and f.i. for cases P6 and P7 I can
execute the algorithms for the situation on the image, and for the
situation where the cube is rotated 180 degrees.

Step D is all about finding the fastest move sequences and short cuts
for your fingers. Guys like Katsu, Pejave and Kyubeman helped me a
lot to improve this step.

You need to do step E statistically in 75 percent of the cases. But
there are some ways to improve that percentage.

Here comes my observation. I noticed that for some cases (P1, P2, P3,
P4, P8, P10 [depending on the algorithm I use], P18 and P21) I first
move the upper layer or bottom two layers, to get to the angle where
I do not need to execute step E anymore after step D. Doing this I
lose a lot of time, maybe 1 to 2 seconds, because I always do
consecutive U' moves. So it sometimes takes 3 U' moves and some
thinking time before I can get started.
For all other cases I do not care about the angle, so I just execute
the algorithm, and then do step E.

The reason for this is probably that for the above cases, the used
permutation algorithm does not end with a correction move of the
upper layer. In other cases because they end up with an easy to do
step E. For most algorithms step E is just a small move with the left
or right index finger (or even a thumb). But for other algorithms,
especially those where the cube is rotated during the algorithm, I
lose valuable time to do the last step E move.

My questions to you are: Do you recognize this behavior? How do you
handle these situations? Do you have any hints on how to improve?

Please join the chatroom during the weekends. It is fun, and you can
learn a lot from other fast/desperate/hooked/novice/Jim Courier look-
alike/MASTER guys.

Thanks,

Ron
http://www.speedcubing.com




49. JustinHak Re: beginner needs some advice
From: texasgrape <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

50. Sunday contest April 7th.
From: jess_bonde <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 06 Apr 2002 14:18:58 -0000

Her are the algs. for April 7th.

1: B´ R F´ B´ R´ F L´ U2 L B F´ U´ B´ R´ U L´ R´ B´ R´ U´ B U´ R´ L´
F´
2: D´ L´ B2 D´ B2 L D R´ L2 D2 B F´ L2 U2 R L´ F´ R L B´ L´ U´ R´ U
L2
3: B´ R´ B2 U R´ F D R´ U2 L2 F2 R´ U2 R´ D´ L´ D2 L2 R U´ L´ D2 R´
U´ F´
4: R2 D U2 F´ D U´ R2 D2 R D U´ L´ U B L´ B2 F2 U´ B´ L2 F L2 B U´ F´
5: L R2 B R2 L2 U F D2 L´ R´ B R´ F´ L2 B R´ D´ B2 L2 U F´ L´ F2 D´
B´
6: D2 U2 B U B´ U´ R´ F B´ L´ D2 L F´ R´ L´ B2 F´ R´ B2 R2 L U F U´
D´
7: F2 D L´ U´ D´ R2 L´ U´ R2 U2 L2 U2 D´ R´ F´ L2 F D´ B´ F´ U B´ L´
U D´
8: R´ U´ D L R2 D´ U L´ F2 U´ L´ D2 R´ U´ F´ R2 D U2 F´ D U´ R2 D2 R
D
9: U´ L´ U B L´ B2 F2 U´ B´ L2 F L2 B U´ F´ B D B´ L2 U2 B L´ F2 L´
B´
10: F´ D2 F2 D2 B2 R2 D´ F R L´ D B´ D´ B´ R´ F´ D´ R B2 L D´ F2 L2
U´ R´
11: B´ R2 B U´ D2 B2 L D´ R´ U2 R U´ R´ F2 D´ L2 U2 R2 F L´ R´ U F´
U´ F´
12: D2 R´ F´ B D´ R´ L2 U2 F L´ R F R2 D2 F2 R´ F´ L2 R B´ F´ R´ B´
D´ L

13: D F´ U2 F2 R F´ R2 B2 L´ R´ B2 D´ R´ F´ L2 F2 L U L´ B´ R2 B U´
D´ R´

You can print the algs. at:
http://www.rubiks.dk in the 'info & rules' section.

Jess.

the fact that it was the weekend of Easter.

following ones.

Henceforth the Sunday contest news will be mainly posted on the new
forum:

http://ulysse.iie.cnam.fr/formet/phpBB

Moreover I made little improvements to this forum. Amongst other
things I added several color themes (look at your preferences).
I also added to the site a page where you can share files or photos
and one other page of bookmarks (still empty for the moment, I'm
waiting for your submission (a form will follow)), in addition to
the chatroom.
And I added a Navigation bar on the homepage of the forum, to gather
all these pages at a same place.

Benoit Formet



53. Receive the posts of the forum by email
From: the_phantom_cuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Apr 2002 02:05:42 -0000

Hello,

I just added a new feature to the new forum, now you can receive all
the posts by email.

To do that go to your preferences page, and choose the forums of
which you want to receive the posts, and you will receive new topics
and replies at the email address you specified in your user profile.

In the mail body you will find the message (with poster name and post
time) and a direct link to view the whole topic or reply.

I remember the URL of the forum:
http://ulysse.iie.cnam.fr/formet/phpBB

So Don't hesitate anymore to try it and register in this forum.

and webmasters, please add a link to it on your site to make it known.
Thanks

--
Benoit Formet

hi everyone!
i've just joined this group and am surprised (and thrilled!) to see
so many fans of the rubik's cube...i've hardly met anyone who shares
the same passion for the cube (and all other rubiks puzzles) as i do!
all you people must be participating in the 2003 competition right? I
can solve the cube in appx 3.5 mins...is that good bad or ugly? i
have no idea of what the record time is ...maybe someone could help
me here! Also is anyone interested in discussing the puzzle Square 1?
(Although i don't know what we'll talk about coz i have no idea about
algorithms, etc...excuse me...i am a biology student..math was never
my forte!)
looking forward to some replies!
ps---when do you people chat online??? i never seem to find anyone
whenever i log on

60. Re: New Members/Slow Cubers :-)
From: texasgrape <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Apr 2002 02:19:38 -0000

I've seen a couple of posts about "slow times". Everyone's time
used to be slow, even the sub 20ists! So, whether your time is 30
seconds, or 30 minutes, got to www.speedcubing.com and click on
Unofficial World Records, then 3x3x3. There is a personal best
record page, and an avg. of 10 page. Once there, you can see how
to properly score your avg of 10. (Thanks Chris/Ron for maintaining
this page.)

No matter what your time is, it is fun to be ranked in with everyone
else and to watch your time improve. This is a very good site.

Texasgrape

PS I'm slow too, but having fun. Used to be at 3 minutes too,
then 2, and now 1:42 avg of 10, and improving every week.

Smiles,

J.

66. Re: New Members/Slow Cubers :-)
From: texasgrape <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 10 Apr 2002 03:03:20 -0000

Chris (or Ron) usually update the Unofficial page pretty quick.
I've sent in a couple of times and they are usually there within a
day or two. I'd resend it if it has been two weeks.

:-)



67. New cubes
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 11 Apr 2002 17:20:49 -0000

My favourite old racing cube has been looking a bit worse for wear
for a while. The edges of most stickers have chipped bits and 2 of
the stickers keep falling off -- not from ever having pealed them
off, of course, because we all know this would be sacrilege, but just
from years and years of racing. (If only I had a dollar for everytime
someone has seen me solve the cube and said "I had a cube when I was
younger. I used to peal the stickers off." People who desecrate cubes
like this don't deserve to have them!!)

Anyway, I digress... I bought a new cube, but it's just not the same.
The old cube is like an old pair of jeans which may be faded and have
holes, but are just so comfortable and you feel so at home with. The
new cube is all pristine and lacks the same character, but what is
worse is that it's sooo stiff. I reckon I'd have trouble getting
under 1.5 minutes, let alone down to 50 seconds (which is a decent
time for me with my old cube).

I saw a variety of cubes in the shops but I bought a Rubik's brand
one (not a cheap clone) which was more expensive but I was after
quality. I'm sure I'll get used to it with time, but for now it's
just sitting on my shelf... :/

Date: Thu, 11 Apr 2002 17:02:35 -0000

71. Re: New cubes
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 11 Apr 2002 21:58:47 -0000

Hey, I too got a new Rubik's cube, like you said it turns sooo
stiff. But I spent one day squirting silicon spray into the cube,
then worked it in, sprayed some more, squirt, work, etc. And now the
cube turns great. I suggest that you get a can of silicon spray at
your nearest hardware store. It helps a lot!!!



72. Re: New cubes
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 11 Apr 2002 23:19:33 -0000

Thanks for the advice re silicon spray for new cubes. Looks like I'll
be maing a visit to the hardware shop.



73. Re: i just saw
From: texasgrape <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 12 Apr 2002 11:52:24 -0000

You shouldn't judge; I'm the dummy! I am a collector of games. You
cannot find an UNOPENED Ideal tub Made in Hungary for $50.00. You
can find them opened, but not Mint in Tub UNOPENED. If you have one
Mint and unopened, and made in Hungary, and you want to sell it to
me for 50.00, let me know. I'll buy it! Also, the Buvos Kocka, in
the blue paper box from Hungary, (Pre-Ideal) circa 1978-79, goes for
around a thousand.

Texasgrape

PS. Although I have not rec'd the cube yet, I no longer own it. I
just sold it to another collector who wanted it more than I. :-)
Have a nice day.

76. Re: i just saw
From: "moocowbob2000" <sum1else@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 12 Apr 2002 18:56:58 -0000

Honestly,

I get the "circa 79 cubes" for $7.50 new in box.
I know of someone who has TONS of cubes, sealed. Including rubiks
mate, 3x3 hungarian, 4x4, snakes, and many more.

In regard to Silver and Brass cubes.
My brass cube auction never went above 125.00 (I had a 150 reserve)
The recent silver cube auction didnt get a single bid at $1100.00

There are no cubes i think to be worth $200,
however for a dogic, i paid it. $255...
All other rare puzzles i have ever had, or still have i traded
for/bought for under US150 (2 dino cubes, 2 dominos, brass cube,
octahedron)

82. Gosd's apology and $$ for vintage cubes
From: texasgrape <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 14 Apr 2002 22:55:30 -0000

GosD: Your apology is accepted. You have irritated the hell out of
me more than once with your bluntness, rudeness, and mis-stated
facts. However, you have my respect because of your accomplishments
and for the help you have given me in the past, and for the
sincerity of your note. Anyone can have a bad day.

In your last post you asked for facts; here they are.

You should learn more about a subject before speaking rudely about
it to someone. If a person's intent is to get the best cube he can
for speedcubing, you go through them and test them as you have done
through the years. If a person is a collector of old games and
antiques, you do not OPEN them! Condition is everything. If you
open an old, first edition Rubik's Cube package, (or an old Barbie
doll, etc.) it just lost 75% of its value!

Now, the Buvos Kocka I spoke of that is worth between $500-$1000 is
NOT the $7.99 Buvos Kocka Studio that they are pumping out of
Hungary. I have two of those that I paid $9.99 for that I use for
speeding--and they are good for that. (Incidently, the ink isn't
even dry on the Studio package! Take that for what it's worth, but
I won't go there.) Anyway, the 7.99 ones you speak of are the
Rubik's Studio Buvos Kocka. The older PRE-IDEAL, pre-1980, Buvos
Kocka are way different; you probably won't see these on Ebay, and I
doubt you have 90 of them either. But, you can see two different
styles of these expensive and rare cubes at:

http://home.houston.rr.com/texasgrape/ There are five pictures
there and they are titled:

Buvos Kocka and Buvos Kocka 2 are the rare ones, and yes, expensive
ones. Hungary Tub, and USA Tub are not as rare, but are very hard
to find UNOPENED, UNTOUCHED, and in MINT condition. Check eBAY if
you don't believe me. Maybe one in a thousand Rubik posts are these
types. And yes, to a collector they are worth from $75-$300
depending on their condition and WHERE they are made. Not going to
argue the point with anyone whether they are worth it or not. I
personally wouldn't pay $2,000 for a Barbie Doll, or $10,000 for a
baseball card, but some do.

Okay, the last picture titled Buvos Kocka Studio is the $7.99 one.
However, I usually have to pay the guy in Hungary $9.99 plus $6.00
shipping. :-( But, for 16 bucks I have a decent speedcube.

Okay GosD, in the past you have given me lessons on speedcubing, now
this is your lesson in collecting vintage games. I'm not going to
post anymore on this subject because this is a speedcubing club, but
I felt I needed to inform some who were not informed on this
subject. It should also help those to know what is authentic and
what is not. GosD: If you have 90 MINT, Unopened, Pre-Ideal, Buvos
Kockas stashed away in your closet (the ones in the light blue
package as in the picture) you can retire on their worth, amigo!
However, if you have opened them all, played with them, and made
them worthless . . . oh well, that's life. Perhaps they will make
good speedcubes.

Lastly . . . GosD, you shouldn't quit this club. You should be
helping the apeedcubing rookies like me. You have given good advice
in the past to help us, and you should continue.

Texasgrape

Maybe one in a thousand Rubik posts are these types. And yes, to a collector they are worth from $75-$300 depending on their condition and WHERE they are made. Not going to argue the point with anyone whether they are worth it or not. I personally wouldn't pay $2,000 for a Barbie Doll, or $10,000 for a baseball card, but some do. GosD: If you have 90 MINT, Unopened, Pre-Ideal, Buvos Kockas stashed away in your closet (the ones in the light blue package as in the picture) you can retire on their worth, amigo! However, if you have opened them all, played with them, and made them worthless . . . oh well, that's life. Perhaps they will make good speedcubes. Lastly . . . GosD, you shouldn't quit this club. You should be helping the apeedcubing rookies like me. You have given good advice in the past to help us, and you should continue. Texasgrape Yahoo! never seen one on eBAY, and I try to always look.

neither were in very good condition. I'm kicking myself now because
I should have got them because gosd said they are well made and make
good speeders!

Date: Mon, 15 Apr 2002 03:09:38 -0000

I've been trying to get my hands on a Rubik's Revenge. I rang the
Australian distributor of Rubik's puzzles (as I live in Australia)
who seemed to think the 4x4x4 had only just been released! I told
them that it's been around for ages, but I've just never actually
*seen* one in Australia. They said they'd be getting some in, but not
till later this year. :/

Can anyone tell me:
(i) When the 4x4x4 was released?
(ii) Whether they've ever seen it in Australia?

Thanks........

must have put a lot of effort into it. I think that we should
appreciate what YOU, Ron, Chris and anyone else has done for the
organization of this event(as I stated earlier I don't know the
specifics). I don't think we(as a club) really appreciate what this
club and the people it consists of have really done. I would like to
thank everyone who has help me progress in my cubing abilities, after
all you didn't have to help. This consists from the founder of the
dominate method that I use, Fridrich, to ALL the top cubers who have
supported or motivated me to advance either directly or indirectly.
All the people who ask and answer the questions, everyone who has
made web pages or videos and anything else that I may have missed. I
think that we shouldn't judge you(DanG) so harshly after all even my
best friend has pissed me off(In reality I have had no conflicts with
you, just confusion). Maybe some people just feel threatened by you,
your ability and your advice. Don't leave the club, I am sure that
everyone can work this out.
Just my perspective,
Collin




92. New sub20er
From: makimoto2000us <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 15 Apr 2002 06:29:55 -0000

Hi Everybody,

I am very happy. I became an another sub20 cubist.
{17.64 19.08 17.95 21.11 (16.81) 21.52 19.75 (22.91) 18.35 20.19
19.40 21.36}= 19.63

I would like to share some tips.

#CUBE
I use hybrid cube. Center piece is from '80s cube, The other pieces
are from new cube. I reuse center piece several times. A first few
days, it tends to pop. But in several days, it will be a very nice
speed cube. If you have extra '80s cube, your new hybride cube will
be in best condition within one day. I never use sandpapers. I have
another 80's cube but I don't want to use it until wc2003.

#PLACE
It was previously discussed. My time is always better at outdoor than
indoor. My eyes works fine under the sunshine. Don't sit in front of
your computer. Let's get out with your cube!

#METHOD
I use Guus' method. F2L+Corners+ Edges. We,Japanese people, call CLL
and ELL (like OLL and PLL). 13 of 42 CLL algs, do not move edges. 7
of 43 do not flip edges. So I can predict which ELL alg should be
used during CLL. Sometimes I can find ELL alg before CLL has been
done.

I still start making cross at top, but finish at bottom. Recently, I
became to memorize or imagine how F2L corners are at B face. So I can
make good pair of corner and edge, without flipping and seeing when
they are not on U. I still often re-grip cube for permution during
F2L but rarely flip just to see behind.



93. Congrats
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 16 Apr 2002 01:25:48 -0000

Congratulations on breaking thirty Heath!!! I'm not getting advances
on my cube. I had a pb of 39 sec. I started learning the F2L from
the speedsolving site. Sure i dropped my total moves from 110 to 80
but my time went from an av of 52 to a min. and a half! It's like
starting the whole year over again. I'm sure all i need is lots of
practise and repitition, but do you got any tips for me? Thanks and
congrats again!
Jake

95. f2l page
From: krrash <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 17 Apr 2002 01:06:39 -0000

I'm working on a page that shows F2L algorithms for both simple cases
and cases that utilize an additional unsolved edge/corner slot. Many
of the algorithms have been generated with Ron's cube solver, and all
of the algorithms can be viewed with Lars' animated java cube
applet. The url for my page is http://oinkleburger.com/cube/f2l/.




96. Re: Congrats
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 17 Apr 2002 03:13:48 -0000

keep workin at it Jake...

What method were you using when you averaged 52? I guess you changed
to doing the cross?....your right, the best thing you can do is
practice and repitition. You really need to force yourself to look
ahead in the f2l, get to where you don't have to think about the
moves and look for the next pieces. Leaning the LL in 2 looks helps
alot too. There's one other possible variable that could of helped
me get those couple seconds faster.....in that last average I
listened to two songs over and over....Machinehead by Bush, and The
Way You Like It by Adema...lol....when ever I cube I listen to up
beat songs, it kinda allows you to get a rhythm with turning the cube
and the music.

thanks for the congrats...

-Heath

My method was a layer by layer, starting with the cross, fl corners, 2l edges, fl cross, fl corners. I'm trying to shorten up and do my f2l all at once and than do the ll. Thanks for your help!! 105. RE: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Favored Color scheme, revised
From: Tyler Robbins <sum1else@...>

For White opposite Blue, The color scheme is as follows: White Opposite Blue Yellow Opposite Green Red opposite Orange With 1 corner having White, Red, Green in clockwise order. 106. Quick question?
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Apr 2002 00:13:54 -0000

Hi I have only been cubing for 6 months and I just broke the 40s
barrier using the corners first method. My best average is 36.5s,
and my pb is 23s. My question is my cube stickers are horrible, and
I am trying to replace them but the old stickers are really hard to
get off. So I was just wondering what people did when restickering
an old cube. How do you get the old stickers off?

Thanks,
Ken B.




107. Re: Quick question?
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Apr 2002 00:51:32 -0000

I know! I went through the same problem. I picked me up a bottle of
goo gone and a hobby knife at the hardware store. It works really
nice. For me at least
Jake



108. Re: Quick question?
From: texasgrape <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Apr 2002 01:53:08 -0000

So I was just wondering what people did when restickering
> an old cube. How do you get the old stickers off?

I take them off with my fingernail; not as tedious as it sounds, but
doesn't damage the cube as a knife may. I use alcohol on a soft rag
to get the old glue off. There still may be a film of glue left
over, but to me, it helps bond the new stickers. I have had
excellent results doing it this way and the stickers last longer
than the originals! I use the stickers from Rubiks.com. Downside:
They are expensive, and they charge 6 bucks for shipping to boot--
but they are indeed good! Someone posted and said they'd send you
one set of stickers for free if you include an SASE. I haven't
tried doing that yet; I didn't find that out until after I bought
mine. Give them a call and see and let us know: Toll free: 866-
437-7767. Doesn't hurt to ask.

:-)

111. Re: Why has Australia missed out on 4x4x4? :(
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Fri, 19 Apr 2002 03:35:08 -0000

I hadn't realised it was so early. I guess I must have missed the first wave of 4x4x4. Or maybe Australia missed out that time as well! I didn't seriously get into cubing till 1987 (I think I was in pre school when the 3x3x3 cube was first released). The person to whom I spoke at the Australian distributor of Rubik's puzzles seemed to almost not believe me when I said the 4x4x4 had been out for *years*! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., bobbit_at_mac_dot_com <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > (i) When the 4x4x4 was released? > > Not quite sure but I know it was around the time the 3xCube went > crazy. 117. Re: Color Scheme PLEASE VOTE
From: jbutler_490 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 17 Apr 2002 16:01:39 -0000

Please, folks, this is the only thing I feel really strongly about
regarding Rubiks cubes.
We must choose the yellow vs white instead of blue vs white.
Think about the symmetry: yellow vs white, green vs blue, red vs
orange are similar in that they differ by the constant color of
yellow. I do not believe any other such pattern is available with the
six colors that must make up the cube.
Please vote for Yellow vs White at this link that Tyler provided:
http://puzzlestore.hypermart.net/vote.htm
Thank you.
Sincerely,
Joey Butler
(Hi, Jessica!)

131. Odd move
From: smoothcuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 21 Apr 2002 20:55:04 -0000

Just wondering, any of you use a move like this when solving Fridrich
method in F2L? U'R' u' R' u R

Where u and u' are moves of the top 2 layers together (E'U and EU').

Example solves the pair on the FL to the front right corner.

Dave



132. Re: f2l page
From: makimoto2000us <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Apr 2002 02:55:42 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., stiff_hands <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Thanks for creating your resource. People interested in your site may > also be interested in http://users.hoops.ne.jp/rokumentai/F2L.htm as well. > > I have a question - are those the moves you actually use? I found > some of them awkward - I cube with thumbs at front. Do you too cube > with thumbs at the front, and if so did you get used to the moves > with practise? Thanks for your interest and questions. When I made that web site on Dec 2001, I used those moves. Although I changed some, I still use 80% of them. I would like to add another moves which I really use as Katsu's evolution page. http://www5.gateway.ne.jp/~katsu-k/ I used a lot of mirror image moves using either right or left hand. (I am right hander.) Recently, I prefer unsymmetric moves with right hand. Basically, I grip cube with thumb at F, but I often regrip. Here is another tip. Evenif the slot to be solved is FR or FL, I regrip and finish it at B face as possible. So I can see the other unsolved slots. I think effective regrip may be useful.
133. Speedcubists
From: wolfheat16 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

about 0.002% sub 25 (1/50 000)
about 0.0002%sub 20 (1/500 000)
(In average of ten times)

Is this numbers true??
what are youre estamates??
/Mike H

138. for some of the new cubist a few F2L
From: duermomucho <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Apr 2002 19:26:51 -0000


Hey guys,

I have a few situations for the F2L, they are differents cases
than those 41 cases that Jessica and Ron posted.
i hope the help,i am sure you've them before,so i'll post some more
later on.

These cases are for the cross at the botton.


To Unsolve To Solve

R2FR2F'U U'FR2F'R2
R2F2R2F2 F2R2F2R2
R2FR2UF'U' UFU'R2F'R2

F'R'URFU U'F'R'U'RF
BRUB2R'B'U U'BRB2U'R'B'
R'U2RF'U'FU' UF'UFR'U2R


These cases are for the cross on the left hand;that is the way i
hold the cube.


To Unsolve To Solve

F2RF2R'D D'RF2R'F2
F2R2F2R2 R2F2R2F2
F2RF2DR'D' DRD'F2R'F2

R'F'DFRD D'R'F'D'FR
LFDL2F'L'D D'LFL2D'F'L'
F'D2FR'D'RD' DR'DRF'D2F




Thanks a lot Ron, I got those cases with your solver.

And thanks again smoothcuber for teaching me how to use Ron's solver.


I hope they help the new cubist.

HAPPY CUBING........ I loooooooove. PEACE.


MANOLO

Date: Thu, 25 Apr 2002 22:12:06 -0000

142. Re: time to sub
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Apr 2002 03:08:14 -0000

thats cool that u guys only spent a couple months or a year and can
solve the cube so fast. Were you taught by someone? I had to come
up with all my stuff on my own. Than after i was able to solve, i
started using the net to bring down my times, and learn new algs. It
is so painful trying to drop sequences i have used for almost three
years, but its worth it trying to reach sub 20. With all the stuff i
know, i taught several people at school how to solve the cube in
around a week or two, and most of them are under a min. 30.
Jake



143. Re: time to sub
From: "cal_meechum" <iron_goat@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Apr 2002 08:24:52 -0000

yeah I was taught by someone, but they taught me like a 6 step
LL and I learned the 3 look on my own. I like teaching people
that are eager to learn. But there is also those think there is
some simple "secret" to the cube and once you know the
"secret" you can solve it easily. Then they get bummed when
they realize they have to memorize a few simple moves. Sorry
kids it aint that easy~!

its funny sometimes when people are in awe of those who can solve the cube...i can do it in 2.5 mins which is a helluva long time...but whenever someone who's never tried solving it (or even those who have) see me do it, their eyes almost pop out and you're automatically labelled a genius! it's a tremendous ego boost! of course, little do they know the world record is sub 20! cal_meechum <iron_goat@...> wrote: yeah I was taught by someone, but they taught me like a 6 step LL and I learned the 3 look on my own. 145. tips for progressing to speed solving?
From: "buddythegoldfish" <sloopy26@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Apr 2002 03:53:09 -0000

i already know a simple F2L 6-step method, lars petrus method, and a
basic F2L then 4 look for last layer method. i'm rather inexperienced
at lars method, so my fastest method is the 6-step, which i peak at
around 40-45 sec. i'm looking for someone to teach me how to progress
and break the 30 sec barrier. maybe tips on new methods or how to
incorporate faster algorithms into the 6-step? any help is
appreciated. thanks.

PS- i took a quick look at the algorithms on speedcubing.com and i'm
looking for an alternative to blindly memorizing 70 or so algorithms
for the last layer. maybe tips on understanding them or working up to
them. thanks again.



146. Re: tips for progressing to speed solving?
From: "cal_meechum" <iron_goat@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Apr 2002 11:32:10 -0000

For you last layer, you can learn the 3-look instead of the 4. I
dropped around 7-10 seconds off my average by doing this. All
you have to learn is about 9 orientation algs and all the perms
which only adds up to 30 algs. It took me about 2 weeks to learn
them all. I think it was worth it.

For your F2L I dont understand what you do. But with a 45
seconds average you must be doing it pretty good already.



147. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: time to sub
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Apr 2002 13:04:48 -0000

I know what you mean. Even if I stuff up and drop the cube mid-
sequence and then take a minute and a half to solve it, everyone is
still terribly impressed. I feel embarrassed if it takes me 90+ secs
because I know that's slow, even for me, but it's still fun that
other people think it's great!

151. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Interesting cubes
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Apr 2002 13:57:57 -0000

Cool!

I like interesting and different cubes, but they always take me
longer to solve. For me, the solid colours are such a key part of
minimising the number of looks and the time taken for each look.

The position of the colours makes a difference to my times too. My
favourite speedcubing cube that I've been using for years has the
white/yellow configuration. As it was becoming a bit worse for wear I
bought a new one. It's a white/blue. I've sovvled it probably a few
dozen times since I bought it and I'm a bit more used to it now, but
it still feels kinda weird. The white/yellow configuration is just so
thoroughly ingrained in my head after so many years. Using something
different is like writing with my left hand (I'm right handed) -- I
can do it, but takes longer, it isn't as neat and it feels unnatural!



152. Silicon spray
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Apr 2002 14:07:44 -0000

As recommended, I used silicone spray on my new cube. It certainly
did make it smoother and much nicer for cubing. It also appears to
have stained the edges of the stickers (no, I didn't spray the
stickers, the spray got on them when I was working the spray in the
mechanism). At first I thought the spray just needed to dry, but it's
been weeks now and the stickers still look stained. Is this normal?

156. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: tips for progressing to speed solving?
From: sloopy26@...
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Apr 2002 13:11:42 -0400

actually, my F2L is an excellent beginner method. it only involves
memorizing one or two moves and can be learned by anyone in a day or two.
it goes basically like this
step 1 - top edges
step 2 - 3 top corners
step 3 - 3 middle edges
(such that you have one corner/edge pair unsolved)
step 4 - bottom edges (oriented and positioned)
step 5 - position all corners
step 6 - orient all corners
i should probably publish this method, its very good for an introduction
to the cube.

anyway, i found some final layer permutation algorithms, totaling about
16. and i already know algorithms to orient corners and edges. so you
think that if i learn all these permutations i can cut 10 seconds off my
time? is there any way you'd recommend learning them? besides just going
through one by one and memorizing, of course. and you said that you were
able to learn all the permutation algorithms in two weeks? thats not bad
at all. any other advice is welcome, thanks.

160. Re: Time to sub 30
From: smoothcuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 28 Apr 2002 15:53:53 -0000

For all you beginners, and any who quit in frustration, just wanted to
say it took me nearly 2 years to avg under 30 sec. I started cross on
top for 6 months, then it took me 6 more months to learn cross on
bottom. The closer I got to 30 sec, the slower the progress was. And
it would have taken me even longer if it weren't for all the help I
received from faster people, mostly in the chatroom.

Dave



161. Re: Preparation for permutation algorithms
From: smoothcuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 28 Apr 2002 16:25:40 -0000

I also lose time prior to the permutation, sometimes 3 or 4 sec even, carrying out the steps you outline. Since I avg at least 7 sec slower than you, I'm afraid I can't help much. I too would like to be able to instantly recognize each perm without having to turn the U. I wonder what the sub 20 crowd does: cubinforspeed, Jessica, Jess, etc. Sorry I can't help. Dave --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., ilovemycube <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hi friendz, > > Maybe I am old-fashioned, but for the time being I stay with this > forum. > > I made some cubing videos to see where I can still improve. I > sometimes lose valuable time during the preparation for the > permutation algorithm. > > These small steps are done after doing the orientation algorithm: > A) move the upper layer to get to a position in which you are able to > recognize which permutation situation the cube is in > B) recognize which permutation algorithm to use > C) move upper layer to get to starting position of the permutation > algorithm > D) execute the permutation algorithm > E) do a correction move of the upper layer to solve the cube > > You can skip step A, if you are able to recognize each situation from > any angle. > > It should be possible to do steps A and B during the end of the > execution of the orientation algorithm, at least for some cases. > > For step C it would be good if you have alternative algorithms, > depending on the angle of the upper layer. On page > http://www.speedcubing.com/final_layer_permutation.html there is an > overview of the algorithms, and f.i. for cases P6 and P7 I can > execute the algorithms for the situation on the image, and for the > situation where the cube is rotated 180 degrees. > > Step D is all about finding the fastest move sequences and short cuts > for your fingers. Guys like Katsu, Pejave and Kyubeman helped me a > lot to improve this step. > > You need to do step E statistically in 75 percent of the cases. But > there are some ways to improve that percentage. > > Here comes my observation. I noticed that for some cases (P1, P2, P3, > P4, P8, P10 [depending on the algorithm I use], P18 and P21) I first > move the upper layer or bottom two layers, to get to the angle where > I do not need to execute step E anymore after step D. Doing this I > lose a lot of time, maybe 1 to 2 seconds, because I always do > consecutive U' moves. So it sometimes takes 3 U' moves and some > thinking time before I can get started. > For all other cases I do not care about the angle, so I just execute > the algorithm, and then do step E. > > The reason for this is probably that for the above cases, the used > permutation algorithm does not end with a correction move of the > upper layer. In other cases because they end up with an easy to do > step E. For most algorithms step E is just a small move with the left > or right index finger (or even a thumb). But for other algorithms, > especially those where the cube is rotated during the algorithm, I > lose valuable time to do the last step E move. > > My questions to you are: Do you recognize this behavior? How do you > handle these situations? Do you have any hints on how to improve? > > Please join the chatroom during the weekends. > > Thanks, > > Ron > http://www.speedcubing.com
162. Re: Other Cubes
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

163. Re: Preparation for permutation algorithms
From: jessica_fridrich <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Apr 2002 13:57:32 -0000

You can recognize the position from looking at just two sides, but I
cannot do this for all positions. I always try to find such a view of
the cube that exhibits the lowest "entropy", looking for the blocks of
solved cubies (those that are already together). Then I usually have
one clue - I look at a particular edge if it is opposite color or not,
which determines the algorithm and also my first move. This is
especially useful for that complicated permutation with a three-cycle
of edges and a three-cycle of corners, that you need to carry out both
ways and in a mirror version. Recognizing the position can be very
fast, but you _need_to_know_ the colors of the cube by heart. I think
it is just practice.

BTW, to contribute to the discussion about progress, here is my 2c
worth: I got to about 1 minute (average) after 3 months, to 35 seconds
after about 6 months, and to an average of 25 after 10 months. Then I
changed to my current F2L system and instantly improved by about 3-4
seconds to low 20's. To get consistently below 20, it took me probably
1.5 years and I reached my best of 17 on average after 18-20 months.
It was in the Spring of 1983 ... :)

Jessica

> I also lose time prior to the permutation, sometimes 3 or 4 sec even,
> carrying out the steps you outline. Since I avg at least 7 sec slower
> than you, I'm afraid I can't help much. I too would like to be able
> to instantly recognize each perm without having to turn the U. I
> wonder what the sub 20 crowd does: cubinforspeed, Jessica, Jess, etc.




164. Re: Preparation for permutation algorithms
From: "cubist3x3only" <cubist3x3only@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Apr 2002 06:42:22 -0000

jessica , or chris hardwick... i have been trying to learn your
method but i can't seem to understand... chris hardwick use's your
method in his video and is he using the R U mostly , i think alot of
people use 1 or 2 algorithims for the f2L can you let me know what
way ..example" put conner and edge together then place ,or set conner
then edge..please let me know thanks....




165. Question about F2L algs
From: jessica_fridrich <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Apr 2002 13:26:38 -0000

I am not sure if I understand your question, but I will try to answer.

Most F2L algorithms can, indeed, be carried out using just two sides.
In some cases, they may not be the shortest ones but still can be
faster because of the fact that only two sides are involved and
because they are "obvious". The algorithms for the F2L are on my page
and on several more pages, such as Chris'. But you do not realy need
to mechanically memorize all of them. Actually, I discourage you from
doing this because I noticed that once there is a set of well-defined
moves, people tend to stop thinking about what they are doing and
instead try to mechanically apply what they learned.

A more valuable approach is to learn a few trivial moves how to
separate the corner and the edge in the LL and how to flip them. Just
play with the cube slowly, observe what is going on and remember that,
especially in the beginning, most corner-edge pairs are not in yet, so
you can use even simpler moves for insertion than when you are
inserting the last pair. There are two basic simple ways how to insert
a corner-edge pair. If you combine some auxiliary short moves with
those two insertion mechanisms, you will discover the moves for most
F2L algorithms. And they will seem natural to you because you came up
with them. If some of them are too long, you can learn a few
not-so-obvious tricks from my F2L algorithms.

When I switched to this system from my old F2L system (first the first
layer including the corners, then inserting two edges into the middle
at the same time), I improved virtually instantly (a week or two) from
an average of 25 to about 21. Most of the moves that I started using
seemed obvious and "natural". But then, by the time I switched to this
F2L system, I was already an "experienced" cuber. I do realize that
for those of you who learn this system as your first one, may have
troubles with it at first. All you need is practice - Gosh, I hate
this answer. Good luck!

Jessica

> jessica , or chris hardwick... i have been trying to learn your
> method but i can't seem to understand... chris hardwick use's your
> method in his video and is he using the R U mostly , i think alot of
> people use 1 or 2 algorithims for the f2L can you let me know what
> way ..example" put conner and edge together then place ,or set conner
> then edge..please let me know thanks....



166. Two-generator group
From: ilovemycube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Apr 2002 16:55:24 -0000

Hi friendz,

I posted a solution to the two-generator group at
http://www.speedcubing.com/two-generator.html

The two-generator group means scrambling and solving the cube only
using moves of two connecting sides, f.i. R and U.
Just try it, it is not as easy as you may think.

The cross/F2L/OLL/PLL system is actually a very good system to solve
two-generator. But since you are only allowed to use R and U moves
you may need to find some other algorithms than you are used to.
After some practice it should be possible to solve the two-generator
group in 10 seconds on average.

For those who have problems solving F2L in general, solving F2L
without rotating, or solving other corner/edge pairs than FR, the two-
generator group will be a very good practice.
You can also solve the two-generator L and U group to practice left
handed shortcuts and finger tricks.

Soon I will post a three-generator solution for the F,U and R group.

Have fun!

Ron
http://www.speedcubing.com

169. Re: F2L pages suggestion
From: "cal_meechum" <iron_goat@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 03 May 2002 06:08:19 -0000

there is a way where all you have to learn is 20 F2L algs

what I do is put the corner piece in the U layer, with the D layer
color in either the F or R faces. This is with the cross on the
bottom. When you have that D color in either the F or R faces
there is only 20 algs to remember.
This is similar to doing the LL in 3 looks by first making a cross
on the top then only memorizing 9 orientation algs.
So yeah you only have to know 20 algs but it takes about 3-6
more moves per pair to get them into position.
I think this is what they mean when they say you can use only
part of this system.
But so far its so hard to practice the F2L algs because its hard to
put the pairs into position to practice the move. You just have to
keep solving the cube over and over and use the F2L algs.

171. Re: whats the best way to look at the cube
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 04 May 2002 01:50:35 -0000

switching from a layer by layer method to the f2l and ll methods. I

sequences fast enough. Althoug i have been improving.. from a min
and a half down to a min, still it is nothing like the 40s i was

172. Re: whats the best way to look at the cube
From: smoothcuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 04 May 2002 16:00:19 -0000

A few tips on this: First, it may help you to use moves that involve just two faces, like R and U, avoiding moves that use more than 3 faces. This may make it easier to spot the pieces. Second, have the moves down cold, so you don't have to think about them. That way, while you're doing a move, you can actively look for the next pair, rather than watching the pair you are inserting. Third, don't do a move so fast that the other pieces are flying around and you can't at least have a general idea of where they are ending up. Fourth, I think knowing how to insert pairs from various angles may help (rather than rotating the cube all the time), but I'm still experimenting with that. The ugly truth is whatever you do, it takes time. In my case years and counting. But stick with it, and good luck. Dave --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "cubist3x3only" <cubist3x3only@y...> wrote: > whats the best way to locate the pieces???? rotate? look at an angle?

178. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] what grade sandpaper should I use?
From: "angela.hayden" <angela.hayden@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 5 May 2002 01:05:42 +0100

Nathan,

I use low grade sandpaper for the big nodules sticking out, then go over the pieces with the finest grade I can find and that seems to work fine. Alternatively I finish it with emery cloth which is very good.
Using an old piece of sandpaper seems to help, as once it is worn it is a little less abrasive.

- stiff_hands

180. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Tactic on the F2L???
From: wolfheat16 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 05 May 2002 01:03:27 -0000

Ok sorry!!! Its the edge corner pairs I mean! When you have done the cross and starts with the pairs, what are the first kind of structure (relation between egde-corner) you looking for? I seem to want to begin finding one "free" corner in the bottom layer (cross on top) and then find the related edge. Hope you´ll understand what I,m trying to explain! /Mike H --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "angela.hayden" <angela.hayden@n...> wrote: > Mike, > not quite sure what you are on about here. Please elaborate. Are you on about doing the cross, or are you on about choosing which edge- corner pairs to solve. Or both? 181. Re: Tactics on the F2L???
From: "angela.hayden" <angela.hayden@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 5 May 2002 03:37:02 +0100

Mike,

I guess people will tackle this problem in many different ways, and many of the ways would be equally valid. What I do is exactly what you describe (except that I have cross on bottom); I find a corner in the U layer and then search for the corresponding edge. Sometimes whilst searching for the corresponging edge I spot a corner-edge pair and do that first instead, but more often the first pair I know the location of will be the one with the corner in the U layer that I originally spotted. Or if I did spot another pair first and didn't like it I would keep searching for that edge.
If I can't spot a corner that is in the U layer (D layer for you) I simply bang the first corner that I find into the U layer whilst looking for the edge. If I know where the edge is already then I might use a more elegant solution, but if I don't then I just bang the corner into that layer as that means I am doing moves and thus am solving the cube. Sometimes I know where the edge is and instead of wasting time deciding what the elegant move is I just bang the corner up anyway as it works out well most of the time and thus on average is quicker for me.
For the subsequent pairs I hope that I have worked out the algs for the next pair before I start on it - generally I try to find a corner that will be in the U layer when I have finished the current corner-edge pair I am placing. If I can't find one, I just bang any old corner that needs solving up into the U layer whilst hunting for its corresponding edge. There may be more elegant and shorter moves that don't involve this, but I am familiar with the situations that occur when the corner is in the U layer, and thus am able to devote my attentions to finding the next pair better.
Most of the time I have the next pair spotted before I finish the current pair. On occassions I don't. You have a choice of various strategies in that situation: you could keep looking until you spot a pair, you could place a single edge, you could place a single corner, you could put a corner into the U layer. If you just keep looking until you spot a pair you may just remain blind to where the cube you are looking for is for ages - normally you spot almost instantly or it takes forever. The other options have the benefit of moving you nearer to completing the cube, and also have the benefit of moving pieces around so that the piece you couldn't find springs into view.

In summary, I think I am saying get the corner into the U layer first, and if you can't spot the associated edge then simply place the corner in its correct slot. (You can always use a working edge later on to place the edge when you finally spot it). Other people will have other ideas, so try this out and make your own mind up.

Somebody else I was in email correspondence with thought that your question meant:
"after the cross has been done, do you go for F2L positions that have both
pieces in the layer opposite the cross first or for one that have at least
one piece in the correct place (but perhaps not correctly oriented) (if the
choice of the two options is open)?"
This is another good question. I should think there is a lot of variation here between the faster cubers.

As stated above, I am looking for corners first, and I look in the U layer. If I don't find one there then I look in the D layer. So I (almost) always go for the situation where one corner is in the U layer and the the edge is anywhere (but preferably in the U layer too). If pieces are in the correct slot but orientated incorrectly it means nothing to me except that I will know where to find the piece later - which is very pleasing. If an edge or corner is in the correct slot and orientated correctly then that is where the "almost" earlier applies. Depending on my mood (very scientific!), and also upon cube specifics (like where the other piece is) I will do one of the following: I will find the other piece and place it using a working corner or edge, I will look to see if there if an edge from one slot solved and a corner from another slot solved and solve the corresponding 2 slots in one go using "non-matching pairs" (see my site if you don't know what I mean), I will place an easy pair that I have spotted, I will find another pair and try to organise it so that I disturb another slot whilst doing that pair in the hope that I will solve a corner or edge in that slot leaving me able to solve 2 slots in one go yet again using "non-matching pairs". Often this means I leave the slot to the end and thus haven't taken advantage of one of the pieces being accidently solved. Something for me to wok on I guess.

Somebody else who I was in chat with thought your question was something about how to you form the cross.
Since it wasn't I won't mention any specifics on doing the cross except to say that you should be able to spot at least a corner before the cross is completed. Also, it is possible to work out where a pair of pieces will be when the cross is completed by tracking their movement before you start doing the cube. I have tried this but cannot do anywhere near the 15 seconds preinspection I give myself except in really easy cases.

I hope this post has given you something to think about and that you find some of this suits you. .

- stiff_hands


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

183. RE: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] cube lube

They give you wax, not silicone -Tyler Robbins <http://www.thepuzzlestore.com/> www.thepuzzlestore.com Specializing in Custom Sequential movement puzzles Ebay UserID: Sum1else -----Original Message----- From: uvwarning [mailto:uvwarning@...] Sent: Sunday, May 05, 2002 11:30 AM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] cube lube Does anyone know what kind of silicone based lube they sell at rubiks.com? I bought a cube kit from them and the lube was really nice. It's this oderless white substance that you inject with a syringe. The problem is that they don't give you very much. I tried getting some silicone spray from the hardware store to replace it and I don't like it. My hands and cube now smell like WD-40. -Nathan Yahoo! Groups Sponsor ADVERTISEMENT <http://rd.yahoo.com/M=194081.2021092.3499911.1829184/D=egroupweb/S=1705 297356:HM/A=1036972/R=0/*http:/www.ediets.com/start.cfm?code=3466> Click Here! <http://us.adserver.yahoo.com/l?M=194081.2021092.3499911.1829184/D=egrou pmail/S=1705297356:HM/A=1036972/rand=520360413> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! 185. 5x5x5 speed cubing
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 05 May 2002 21:55:40 -0000

Since my 4x4x4 is currently busted (weak center pieces consperacy) I
thought i would try jumpin up and speed solve the 5x5x5. I don't have
a good speedy solution and was wonderin if anyone could help or share
there solutions. My times are in the 15 min range but its a start at
least, right!?! I use the centers first method and than i complete

186. Re: Tactics on the F2L???
From: wolfheat16 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 05 May 2002 22:03:27 -0000

Hi!! Thanks for youre descriptions on the F2L! I didn´t mean the cross ok, you described the right stuff, Ok! I start by finding eather an edge or a corner in the U-layer(youre way) then I try to find the corresponding edge or corner by searching the cube counterclockwise until I find it, while doing this I find the next cubies to connect. And so it goes until F2L is solved, perhaps a bit timeconsuming? what do you think? What should I work on to improve my F2L times? I avg tot. about 28´, but my weakness are the F2L it takes about 18- 20sec, and the last layer takes about 9-10sec. I think it depends on the fact that I recently begun learning the F2L system, but that seems to improving to. Before using it I had times at 37´and to start with it became 48´ now I,ve worked myselfe down to 28´(tot). I think practise is the thing I have to do, but it is interesting knowing how faster people are doing. /Mike H ------------------------------------------------------------------ Orginal message... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "angela.hayden" <angela.hayden@n...> wrote: > Mike, > > I guess people will tackle this problem in many different ways, and many of the ways would be equally valid. What I do is exactly what you describe (except that I have cross on bottom); I find a corner in the U layer and then search for the corresponding edge. Sometimes whilst searching for the corresponging edge I spot a corner-edge pair and do that first instead, but more often the first pair I know the location of will be the one with the corner in the U layer that I originally spotted. Or if I did spot another pair first and didn't like it I would keep searching for that edge. > If I can't spot a corner that is in the U layer (D layer for you) I simply bang the first corner that I find into the U layer whilst looking for the edge. If I know where the edge is already then I might use a more elegant solution, but if I don't then I just bang the corner into that layer as that means I am doing moves and thus am solving the cube. Sometimes I know where the edge is and instead of wasting time deciding what the elegant move is I just bang the corner up anyway as it works out well most of the time and thus on average is quicker for me. > For the subsequent pairs I hope that I have worked out the algs for the next pair before I start on it - generally I try to find a corner that will be in the U layer when I have finished the current corner- edge pair I am placing. If I can't find one, I just bang any old corner that needs solving up into the U layer whilst hunting for its corresponding edge. There may be more elegant and shorter moves that don't involve this, but I am familiar with the situations that occur when the corner is in the U layer, and thus am able to devote my attentions to finding the next pair better. > Most of the time I have the next pair spotted before I finish the current pair. On occassions I don't. You have a choice of various strategies in that situation: you could keep looking until you spot a pair, you could place a single edge, you could place a single corner, you could put a corner into the U layer. If you just keep looking until you spot a pair you may just remain blind to where the cube you are looking for is for ages - normally you spot almost instantly or it takes forever. The other options have the benefit of moving you nearer to completing the cube, and also have the benefit of moving pieces around so that the piece you couldn't find springs into view. > > In summary, I think I am saying get the corner into the U layer first, and if you can't spot the associated edge then simply place the corner in its correct slot. (You can always use a working edge later on to place the edge when you finally spot it). Other people will have other ideas, so try this out and make your own mind up. > > Somebody else I was in email correspondence with thought that your question meant: > "after the cross has been done, do you go for F2L positions that have both > pieces in the layer opposite the cross first or for one that have at least > one piece in the correct place (but perhaps not correctly oriented) (if the > choice of the two options is open)?" > This is another good question. I should think there is a lot of variation here between the faster cubers. > > As stated above, I am looking for corners first, and I look in the U layer. If I don't find one there then I look in the D layer. So I (almost) always go for the situation where one corner is in the U layer and the the edge is anywhere (but preferably in the U layer too). If pieces are in the correct slot but orientated incorrectly it means nothing to me except that I will know where to find the piece later - which is very pleasing. If an edge or corner is in the correct slot and orientated correctly then that is where the "almost" earlier applies. Depending on my mood (very scientific!), and also upon cube specifics (like where the other piece is) I will do one of the following: I will find the other piece and place it using a working corner or edge, I will look to see if there if an edge from one slot solved and a corner from another slot solved and solve the corresponding 2 slots in one go using "non-matching pairs" (see my site if you don't know what I mean), I will place an easy pair that I have spotted, I will find another pair and try to organise it so that I disturb another slot whilst doing that pair in the hope that I will solve a corner or edge in that slot leaving me able to solve 2 slots in one go yet again using "non-matching pairs". Often this means I leave the slot to the end and thus haven't taken advantage of one of the pieces being accidently solved. Something for me to wok on I guess. > > Somebody else who I was in chat with thought your question was something about how to you form the cross. > Since it wasn't I won't mention any specifics on doing the cross except to say that you should be able to spot at least a corner before the cross is completed. Also, it is possible to work out where a pair of pieces will be when the cross is completed by tracking their movement before you start doing the cube. I have tried this but cannot do anywhere near the 15 seconds preinspection I give myself except in really easy cases. > > I hope this post has given you something to think about and that you find some of this suits you. . > > - stiff_hands > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

196. Re: cube lube
From: krrash <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 08 May 2002 17:58:52 -0000

Well, it could break your cube. I think that it could erode the plastic. Vaseline does the same thing. This could actually improve how your cube works. You'll have to try for yourself to find out. Just don't be surprised if you lube up your cube with baby oil, put it in a box for a few years, take it out and it is mush. Silicone spray lubricant won't damage your cube, and most people seem to like how it works pretty well. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., cheukyor <no_reply@y...> wrote: > As everything else, don't overuse it. Just try it, it won't break > your cube! > > C > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "k4sauer" <ksauer@h...> wrote: > > Can anyone confirm that Baby Oil is a good lube??? That sounds... > > well, slippery! ;)
197. Re: cube lube

Date: Wed, 08 May 2002 18:27:10 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., krrash <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Well, it could break your cube. I think that it could erode the > plastic. Vaseline does the same thing. This could actually improve > how your cube works. You'll have to try for yourself to find out. > Just don't be surprised if you lube up your cube with baby oil, put > it in a box for a few years, take it out and it is mush. > > Silicone spray lubricant won't damage your cube, and most people seem > to like how it works pretty well. Will it damage your cube for sure? I know vaseline is not good, because it is a petroleum based lubricant which attacks plastic. Is baby oil petroleum based? Click here http://www.johnsonsbaby.com/pro_products/baby_oil.asp It says mineral oil, but it also says fragranced, is that the bad part?
