202. Lube Experiment
From: texasgrape <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 09 May 2002 13:00:55 -0000

I've read all the posts in the past six months on lubes, and I've
tried them all but the wax. I found something different that I like
the best: Armor All! And is safe for all plastics: stickers and
cubes.

The first lube I used was 3 in 1 oil (a light sewing machine oil) I
used it for 2 weeks and then took my cube apart, cleaned it with a
toothbrush and mild soapy water. (The 3 in 1 did make the stickers
peel eventually, but no biggie, cuz I wanted to put new ones on
anyway.) Then I reassembled it completely dry. I turned the layers
45 degrees and with a small paintbrush, dobbed ARMOR ALL on the flat
surfaces showing. Then I turned the other layers 45 and did the
same. Armor All works best for me . . . and I've tried most all of
them. To me, it works better than silicone.

I have found that you need to break the cube in somewhat before
applying anything. When the squares are new and completely smooth
and flat, the lubricant seems to create a suction making it hard to
turn. The 'wear' grooves (from dry break in) keeps this from
happening.

I got another cube and recreated the same effect. (The above cube
is the best I've ever had.) Yep, worked again. Now, a word on
cubes: I've found that ALL cubes do not respond the same no matter
what you use for lubricant just because of the way they are made and
the spring tension. If you have a cube that turns pretty good dry,
then it would be a candidate for a lube. Some cubes are just
hopeless. Also, one of my favorite cubes I use dry! I put Armor
All on it just to help . . .and it does.

In my opinion, a bad cube ain't gonna get good by using a lube, but
a good cube can be enhanced with a lube if it is a good one to begin
with. For what it's worth. :-)

Texasgrape

PS According to the posts, baby oil seems to work well too. Gonna
try it out. I'm not afraid to use a light oil--it's the harsh ones
that will hurt a cube, not the light ones. If baby oil is good for
a new born baby's skin, it ain't gonna hurt plastic!



203. Re: 5x5x5 speedcubing
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 09 May 2002 20:44:51 -0000

ha ha... very funny



204. Sunday Contest for May 12 and announce

http://ulysse.iie.cnam.fr/formet/contest
for the scrambling algs.

site, since Jess Bonde told me he'd like me to handle all of them,
and there is no problem for that. (there is no monthly contest at
www.rubiks.dk anymore)




205. Re: 5x5x5 speedcubing
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 05:28:45 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > ha ha... very funny If you're at all considering speed cubing the 5x5x5 then I would suggest lubing your cube. I like to think I'm a 5x5x5 speedcubist (I don't practice it as much as the 3x3x3 but I still like trying to solve it quickly). Since I've lubed my 5x5x5 though it is so much easier to speed solve. It takes a much greater measure of dexterity because the thing is so loose that it breaks very easily and putting it back together is so hard it's painful. As far as solutions go it's my experience that a centers first solution goes quicker than an edges first solution but that's just me. Richard Carr is much better at big cubes than I, but I would suggest solving the centers, then the edges, then the cube like a 3x3x3. Chris
206. Re: 5x5x5 speedcubing
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 11:03:16 -0000

I'm going to combat the advertizing and rejoin to give some tips
on this.

(Post 1 of ? - Centres)

The first tip is to use a virtual cube. : )
I find that even with the Revenge, if I try to speed cube it is liable
to break into pieces very quickly (when I say break I mean with
some actual pieces physically breaking rather than coming
apart) although maybe a lubed cube would be better. There's no
way I'm going to try to get top speed on my real 5x5x5 (as I might
never get another one). That's now reserved for project blindfold,
if I can achieve some consistency on the Revenge first.
Thus, try a virtual cube like the one at oinkleburger (if you want to
go higher than 5 you have to anyway). Oinkleburger is hard to get
used to but it gets easier when you have to build the centres as
then you don't have to set off at crazy speeds and the geometric
confusion that plays a part in the smaller cubes is less of an
issue.

The second thing is to build the centres first. I used to build them
last and I got awful times that way. Building them first is the way
to go as Chris Hardwick points out. I build my centres differently
from Chris though (and it is probably here I make up time
because he can blitz me on the 3x3x3 - also the centres are the
time-determining factors on big cubes (they take O(n^2) moves
to solve but the edges only take O(n) and the 3x3x3 solution O(1)
moves - i.e. the centres take quadratic time, the edges linear
time and the rest constant time).

Choose any centre to start off with (build it on the F face) and
build the centre horizontal stripe of 3 - push it to the L face) and
build the other horizontal layers of 3 (one at a time) on the F face,
pushing each to the L face as you complete them. Then move
the L face up to the U face so the U centre is completed.

Now do the D centre - recently I have thought of a better way to
start this. Again build in strips of 3 starting at the centre one. It
may be possible to build the 2 outer parts of the centre strip on
one of the F,B,R or L faces. Then you can slice up the centre of
the D face, rotate and slice back down to complete the centre
strip. In other situations you might want to do something else.
(e.g. slice a non-centre slice from the D face rotate the D face
and slice back).

Try, where possible to leave a clean strip of three in the D face
after getting the centre strip. You can then push a complete strip
in there rotate and take out any other mess from the other side.
For the last part, push out the 2nd complete strip, rotate and pull
back in to complete the second centre.

The third and 4th centres should be built adjacently (this part
definitely differs from Chris's - I can't see how to generalize his
method for bigger cubes than 5x5x5). Build the 3rd one before
the 4th (i.e. completely before), centre strip first. Then do the 4th
one. You have to complete the last 2 together. For the 5x5x5 it is
still small enough that there are tricks to enable you to do this
quite fast. For larger cubes you may need to spend a little time
with fidgety conjugation moves near the end but it is still quite
fast.



207. Re: 5x5x5 speedcubing
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 11:16:24 -0000


(Part 2- Edges)

Build the edges one at a time (for the Revenge you can build
them 2 at a time, but it's more complicated to try that here, if at all
possible).
Build the first 8 in the middle layers and store them in the U and
D faces.
The basic plan is to slice layers parallel to the U and D faces.
Fast location of pieces is also vitally important here for really
good times.
For instance, suppose the FR edge has a Red-Green piece in
the centre. Try to locate a Red-Green piece in the U or D layer
and place it in the FL edge (with a LD'L' type of move) in such a
way that then you can slice it into the correct place. Sometimes,
you'll have the pieces all in the middle layer anyway and you may
be able to just slice. If the central edge doesn't match the other
edges, you'll need to flip it. This can be done quite effectively:

match the other two edge pieces, say in the FR edge and put the
centre edge in the FL edge. Then L^2(slice the middle layer
twice)L^2 will complete that edge without messing things up.

If the two non-centre edges are in the same layer, get one of
them correctly aligned with the centre edge and then rotate the
non-middle slice (not containing either non-centre edge) so that
the U and D strips (of the middle layers) look the same. You can
then freely do a half rotation of any of the F, B, R or L sides
without messing up the centres. Use this to get one of the centre
edges in a different layer but not the other. Then slice to
complete the edge.
When you have 8 edges done and stored, reslice the middle
layers to complete the centres.
Chris Hardwick's page describes the technique you'll want to
use for the last 4 edges.
The very last edge may not look right (the centre edge may look
flipped compared to the others). You may as well fix it now
(similarly for any cube of odd side-length) as recognizing it
doesn't take anything special. Again, Chris Hardwick has a move
on the Revenge for flipping an edge which can be adapted for
this. You can try to build more than one of the last 4 edges at the
same time.





208. Re: 5x5x5 speedcubing
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 11:23:12 -0000


(Part 3 - Finishing off)

Treat the thing as a 3x3x3 and go as fast as you can. If you know
all the algorithms (unlike me) and can trigger (again unlike me,
in most cases) it should help your time.
When my mouse isn't playing up (which it often does - Apple
don't seem to be capable of making decent mice, although I
haven't got an optical or cordless one which would probably
help) I find that it is possible to sometimes execute some moves
pretty fast - though not as fast as for a real cube.

(For big even cubes, if you have an edge that needs (parts of it)
flipping, ensure that it is a LL edge. Then after completing the
rest of the edges do the F2L. From the orientation of the 3 other
LL edges you will see which way to flip (parts of) the last edge, if
it needs to be done at all.
Then do the orientation step (or steps if like me you often need
2).
In the PLL stage identify if you will need to switch 2 edges first
and if so do that before permuting. If you don't you may have to
switch them afterwards and then you either need to have a lot of
algorithms at hand or you may need to permute again wasting
time.)

From: Tyler Robbins <sum1else@...>

Easy to reassemble. Don't kid yourselves saying its hard Turn the top 2 layers 45 degrees. Its about 3 inches high, very luminous, textured stickers on it same colours on opposites. It cost me £8 ($12 perhaps?) at a local shop. I've never had one, not scrambled it yet, not sure what others feel like, but, it turns nice and smooth, quite a dry action, easy, I don't understand how anyone could speed solve on it though. Is mine smaller than normal? Do people trigger and stuff on these?

217. Re: Wich pices should I sand?
From: bobbit_at_mac_dot_com <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 20:46:16 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "odabrun" <odabrun@y...> wrote: > Hi everyone- > > I don't know how to sand it, so I'ld know which pieces should I sand > in my cube? Just the edges ones? > > Thanks > > Odair I've never sanded a cube before. BUT, if I was to try, I would only take off any edges that can catch, like the mould marks. I wouldn't attempt to make any inside faces completly flat. I say this because I have heard stories of corners being too loose, like a loose tooth. And of course, it's so annoying for a cube to pop apart, which is far more likely on a cube which is sanded down. I have a really nice cube here, formerly Dan Knight's, and I can still see where the mouldings are, so clearly it's not been sanded very heavily. Also, Ron, a well respected sub 20 second player, would never sand his cubes at all!
218. RE: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Wich pices should I sand?
From: Tyler Robbins <sum1else@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 16:58:33 -0400

Ron's cubes are prepped specially by Ton D. He works them for about 6 hours with no lube. Then he adjusts the tension, and lubes. He then works them for a while more. About sanding. I used to sand, but I found that "chemically sanding" is better. Use Vaseline to eat away the plastic on the edges, it works wonders. Lubricate with Vaseline and use it for about 2 weeks constantly.. Then clean it out and lube with silicone spray (Sythetic with Teflon or Pure silicone) -Tyler Robbins <http://www.thepuzzlestore.com/> www.thepuzzlestore.com Specializing in Custom Sequential movement puzzles Ebay UserID: Sum1else -----Original Message----- From: bobbit_at_mac_dot_com [mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com] Sent: Monday, May 13, 2002 4:46 PM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Wich pices should I sand? --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "odabrun" <odabrun@y...> wrote: > Hi everyone- > > I don't know how to sand it, so I'ld know which pieces should I sand > in my cube? Just the edges ones? > > Thanks > > Odair I've never sanded a cube before. BUT, if I was to try, I would only take off any edges that can catch, like the mould marks. I wouldn't attempt to make any inside faces completly flat. I say this because I have heard stories of corners being too loose, like a loose tooth. And of course, it's so annoying for a cube to pop apart, which is far more likely on a cube which is sanded down. I have a really nice cube here, formerly Dan Knight's, and I can still see where the mouldings are, so clearly it's not been sanded very heavily. Also, Ron, a well respected sub 20 second player, would never sand his cubes at all! Yahoo! 219. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: 5x5x5 speedcubing
From: "Brad Huff" <bhuff70@...>

Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 21:28:19 +0000

I am curious, but how much time did it take you to do your "awful" time with the edge-first solution on your 5X5X5? I currently can do less than 7 minutes with an edge-first solution. Eventually I may have to go to a center-first solution to get faster. I would have to figure out my center-first solution first! 220. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: 5x5x5 speedcubing
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 23:11:52 -0000


It took a long time but then I was using my real cube which is
very stiff - sometimes I have to turn three times in the wrong
direction instead of once in the right direction because it jams so
much. Actually all my cubes are like that to some extent. : )
Basically, if I solve centres last (i.e. join edges, solve like a 3x3x3
and then do centres) it takes a long time because there is very
little freedom of movement. I have to use moves which I
generally use to finish centres on big cubes but all the time. It's
not so efficient.
In order to break 3 minutes I think you really have to go centres
first. With my current technique, I'd find 3 minutes 30 seconds
devastatingly bad, to give an idea of the sort of speed involved.
Indeed, 3 minutes 15 is rather disappointing.
Anything under 2 minutes 50 seconds is very good. Anything
under 2 minutes 45 seconds is extremely good.



221. RE: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: 5x5x5 speedcubing
From: Tyler Robbins <sum1else@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 19:21:33 -0400

My technique is the worst :-) Takes me something like 15 minutes at a normal hand speed (on my Mini 5x5) I do: Top Centers Top Edges Top corners Side edges Bottom edges Centers for the other 5 sides Its very repetitive, and easy to learn. Ill post the link if someone wants it, I got it off of the rubiks website. I don't use a Meffert 5x5, I don't have one at the moment. I sold it because I didn't like the tile pattern. I will buy a new one. My mini 5x5 broke (some idiot in school broke it and wont pay for a new one) Meffert will have new stock of 5x5's for $28 in White-Blue and White-Yellow Ideal style colors. Each type IS limited, so order what you need at first. www.mefferts.com <http://www.mefferts.com/> I would like to thank all those that took my little poll on behalf of Uwe Meffert and myself. -Tyler Robbins <http://www.thepuzzlestore.com/> www.thepuzzlestore.com Specializing in Custom Sequential movement puzzles Ebay UserID: Sum1else -----Original Message----- From: GameOfDeath2 [mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com] Sent: Monday, May 13, 2002 7:12 PM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: 5x5x5 speedcubing It took a long time but then I was using my real cube which is very stiff - sometimes I have to turn three times in the wrong direction instead of once in the right direction because it jams so much. I have to use moves which I generally use to finish centres on big cubes but all the time. It's not so efficient. In order to break 3 minutes I think you really have to go centres first. With my current technique, I'd find 3 minutes 30 seconds devastatingly bad, to give an idea of the sort of speed involved. Indeed, 3 minutes 15 is rather disappointing. Anything under 2 minutes 50 seconds is very good. Anything under 2 minutes 45 seconds is extremely good. Yahoo! 224. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: 5x5x5 speedcubing
From: makimoto2000us <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 14 May 2002 00:04:41 -0000

Hello, everybody interested in big cubes.

I use different method.
http://www.geocities.com/makimoto2000us/cindex-e.htm

I didn't put my 5x5x5 method yet.
It's basically as same as my 4x4x4 method.

Briefly,
#1 Top corners
#2 middle edges
#3 top inners
#4 3 top edges
#5 middle inners
#6 final top edge
#7 bottom edges

#2 and #5 are the most important parts of my solution.
Don't solve inners one by one.
Avoid isolated unsolved inner spot.
When I have time, I would like to update this tip on my web.

I am not good at virtual cubes, but I can solve real 5x5x5 within 5
min. in average.
You can see my solving video.
Thanks.




225. Which cubes are good? / How do you adjust spring tension?
From: "uvwarning" <uvwarning@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 14 May 2002 01:57:07 -0000

I originally bought a cube from rubiks.com and then later bought one
from amazon because I heard that the Oddzon cubes are pretty good for
speed cubing. When I got the one from amazon, it turned out to be the
same as the one from rubiks.com. Then I found out that the one I got
from rubiks.com actually *is* an oddzon cube (it says in little print
on the bottom side of the package). Are these the cubes that are
supposed to be good for speed cubing? The spring tension seems to be
way too tight and I have been unsucessful at prying the middle face
pieces open to adjust them. They seem to be glued on pretty good.

How do I pry these face pieces open?
Is Oddzon the only current manufacture of the cube now?
If I buy an Ideal brand Rubik's cube from ebay, would that be any
better?

-Nathan

I have a Oddzon cube. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Tyler Robbins <sum1else@o...> wrote: > Ron's cubes are prepped specially by Ton D. > He works them for about 6 hours with no lube. > Then he adjusts the tension, and lubes. He then works them for a while > more. > > About sanding. > > I used to sand, but I found that "chemically sanding" is better. > Use Vaseline to eat away the plastic on the edges, it works wonders. > Lubricate with Vaseline and use it for about 2 weeks constantly.. > Then clean it out and lube with silicone spray (Sythetic with Teflon or > Pure silicone) > > > -Tyler Robbins > <http://www.thepuzzlestore.com/> www.thepuzzlestore.com > Specializing in Custom Sequential movement puzzles > Ebay UserID: Sum1else > -----Original Message----- > From: bobbit_at_mac_dot_com [mailto:no_reply@y...] > Sent: Monday, May 13, 2002 4:46 PM > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@y... > Subject: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Wich pices should I sand? > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "odabrun" <odabrun@y...> > wrote: > > Hi everyone- > > > > I don't know how to sand it, so I'ld know which pieces should I > sand > > in my cube? Just the edges ones? > > > > Thanks > > > > Odair > > I've never sanded a cube before. BUT, if I was to try, I would only > take off any edges that can catch, like the mould marks. I > wouldn't attempt to make any inside faces completly flat. I say > this because I have heard stories of corners being too loose, like > a loose tooth. And of course, it's so annoying for a cube to pop > apart, which is far more likely on a cube which is sanded down. I > have a really nice cube here, formerly Dan Knight's, and I can still > see where the mouldings are, so clearly it's not been sanded > very heavily. 229. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: 5x5x5 speedcubing
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 17 May 2002 11:15:01 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Brad Huff" <bhuff70@h...> wrote: > I am curious, but how much time did it take you to do your "awful" time > with the edge-first solution on your 5X5X5? I currently can do less than 7 > minutes with an edge-first solution. Eventually I may have to go to a > center-first solution to get faster. I would have to figure out my > center-first solution first! > > Brad > > Edge first took a really long time (well over 10 minutes, but then again my cube is very hard to turn - as I probably mentioned already all of my current cubes have occasions where they refuse to budge and in order to do a move I have to resort to turning 3 times in the other direction). It probably took 15 minutes or something similar. On a real cube my current method takes, probably 8 minutes but I haven't timed it for ages because I am sick of how long it takes to twist. Given that I can solve the thing in 235-265 moves (quarter turns) it follows that if I could move even at 1 move per second on a real cube I should easily be able to break that time. On the java applet my only problem is if my mouse sticks. On the subject of speed-cubing the 5x5x5, I set a time of 2 minutes 37.509 seconds today. I took quite a lot of moves (255) but was moving relatively fast. Strangely I am in the rather bizarre position of having my 5x5x5 personal best closer to my 4x4x4 PB than my 4x4x4 PB is to my 3x3x3 PB. That's counter-intuitive so it suggest that either my 4x4x4 PB can be improved or that my 5x5x5 PB is better than it should be (or possibly that even cubes are slightly more complicated for their size than odd cubes). > > > >From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> > >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@y... > >To: speedsolvingrubikscube@y... > >Subject: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: 5x5x5 speedcubing > >Date: Mon, 13 May 2002 11:03:16 -0000 > > > >I'm going to combat the advertizing and rejoin to give some tips > >on this. > > > >(Post 1 of ? - Centres) > > > >The first tip is to use a virtual cube. : ) > >I find that even with the Revenge, if I try to speed cube it is liable > >to break into pieces very quickly (when I say break I mean with > >some actual pieces physically breaking rather than coming > >apart) although maybe a lubed cube would be better. There's no > >way I'm going to try to get top speed on my real 5x5x5 (as I might > >never get another one). That's now reserved for project blindfold, > >if I can achieve some consistency on the Revenge first. > >Thus, try a virtual cube like the one at oinkleburger (if you want to > >go higher than 5 you have to anyway). Oinkleburger is hard to get > >used to but it gets easier when you have to build the centres as > >then you don't have to set off at crazy speeds and the geometric > >confusion that plays a part in the smaller cubes is less of an > >issue. > > > >The second thing is to build the centres first. I used to build them > >last and I got awful times that way. Building them first is the way > >to go as Chris Hardwick points out. I build my centres differently > >from Chris though (and it is probably here I make up time > >because he can blitz me on the 3x3x3 - also the centres are the > >time-determining factors on big cubes (they take O(n^2) moves > >to solve but the edges only take O(n) and the 3x3x3 solution O(1) > >moves - i.e. the centres take quadratic time, the edges linear > >time and the rest constant time). > > > >Choose any centre to start off with (build it on the F face) and > >build the centre horizontal stripe of 3 - push it to the L face) and > >build the other horizontal layers of 3 (one at a time) on the F face, > >pushing each to the L face as you complete them. Then move > >the L face up to the U face so the U centre is completed. > > > >Now do the D centre - recently I have thought of a better way to > >start this. Again build in strips of 3 starting at the centre one. It > >may be possible to build the 2 outer parts of the centre strip on > >one of the F,B,R or L faces. Then you can slice up the centre of > >the D face, rotate and slice back down to complete the centre > >strip. In other situations you might want to do something else. > >(e.g. slice a non-centre slice from the D face rotate the D face > >and slice back). > > > >Try, where possible to leave a clean strip of three in the D face > >after getting the centre strip. You can then push a complete strip > >in there rotate and take out any other mess from the other side. > >For the last part, push out the 2nd complete strip, rotate and pull > >back in to complete the second centre. > > > >The third and 4th centres should be built adjacently (this part > >definitely differs from Chris's - I can't see how to generalize his > >method for bigger cubes than 5x5x5). Build the 3rd one before > >the 4th (i.e. completely before), centre strip first. Then do the 4th > >one. You have to complete the last 2 together. For the 5x5x5 it is > >still small enough that there are tricks to enable you to do this > >quite fast. For larger cubes you may need to spend a little time > >with fidgety conjugation moves near the end but it is still quite > >fast. > > > > > __________________________________________________ _______________ > Join the world's largest e-mail service with MSN Hotmail. > http://www.hotmail.com
230. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: 5x5x5 speedcubing
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 17 May 2002 15:24:57 -0000


I've just now obliterated the UWR for the 5x5x5 with a time of 2
minutes 29.317 seconds. That's over 11 seconds off the time
that stood before today (and over 8 seconds off the time that was
set earlier today). No stages were skipped but I knew the
orientation algorithm in the LL which helps (i.e. to orient in one
step instead of two).

233. Edge Building Strategy 5x5x5 (First 8 edges)
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 18 May 2002 23:28:53 -0000


Here's a few short notes on building edges in the 5x5x5.
Each edge consists of a central edge piece and two non-central
edge pieces.
Let's assume that all three pieces are in the middle layers.
Slicing may help you to build the edge straight away. If not, there
are 2 basic scenarios: the non-central edge pieces are in the
same layer (there are 2 similar cases - corresponding to which
layer they are in) or the non-central edges are in different layers
but when slice together with the central edge the central edge is
the opposite way round. Denoting the non-central edges by X
and the central edge by Y these two cases can be made to look
like:

X X (the X's may be in different faces)
Y

and

X
Y
X.

The centres should be correct at least to the point of horizontal
stripes. So they will look a bit like

TTT
UUU
VVV

(not necessarily distinct).

In the first case, use the lower slice to match the two strips
labelled T and V above so the centres look like

TTT
UUU
TTT

Then you can freely rotate the single X through a half turn without
affecting the X adjacent the Y and without messing up the
centres or the edges in the up face and down face (although they
will change position). To be effective, you should have lined up
the correct X and Y at the start (so that they match).

In the second case, slice the Y out (away from the Xs) rotate the
face that contains it (but not the Xs) through a half turn, slice the
Y back to the Xs and then rotate the face you just rotated back
through a half turn (the last rotation is unnecessary if the centres
look like

TTT
UUU
TTT

already.

This strategy is good for the first 8 edges (which are stoed in U
and D faces). After that, you'll want to slice the centres back
together before working on the last 4 edges.




234. newbie question F2L vs Layer by Layer
From: "nureddin1" <tommy.jyrkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 19 May 2002 13:03:55 -0000

Hi everyone.
I started cubing about 1 week ago after having a break for about 18
years or so (!). Anyway, Im now solving it consistanly around 2 min
using Trajbers layermethod, when i try using the F2L method it takes
about 4-5 min.
My questions: Should i get better i layer method first before
switching to F2L? How long did it take for you experienced guys
before you made serious progress?
Should I wait before learning F2L-algs and just try to solve it
myself even if it takes alot of time?
Thanks




235. Re: newbie question F2L vs Layer by Layer
From: smoothcuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 19 May 2002 15:01:58 -0000

If you enjoy tinkering and want to try solving on your own, go for it.
If you are looking to get faster right away, I'd say pick one of the
fast systems (be that F2l, corners-first, etc) and stick with it. It
will take time (maybe a long long time) to get the hang of whatever
system you choose, but even longer if you choose a slow one, and then
switch later to a fast one. I used to use a corner system, and found
it tough to learn the F2l system, as I was used to looking for
different pieces and had to "unlearn" moves. So, if I were in your
spot, I would start right off with a fast system. You will find
others disagree, so of course it's up to you!

Dave



236. LL algs and chat
From: pejave <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 20 May 2002 18:16:46 -0000

I have spent a lot of time adjusting algs to my hands and would
really like to hear if anyone has found solutions better the ones I
found.

You can find my algs at:

http://home01.wxs.nl/~janse625/PetersCubePage.html

I use cuberotations in my algs. I think it's easier that way.
Everything in parentheses is one fluent move. Try some and see if
you like it.


Another thing:
There used to be some people in the chatroom. Now it's getting a bit
slow. I have seen messages from people asking when there is a chat.
Someone replied to that telling that every weekend (from 11.00 EST
untill the last person leaves) there is one, but still they never
showed up. Just try it. I did and it is nice to talk other
cubefreaks. If you have a question just ask it. Some very fast people
may be able to help you. Even if you don't speedcube, just join us
and say what you want to say. (You probably don't get a chance to
talk about the cube at home. At least I don't....)

I hope to talk to you soon.

pejave@...
Peter



237. Dan Knights
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 22 May 2002 01:22:25 -0000

I just shut off the TV after watching Dan Knights solve the cube
on "Thats Incredible." I won't say much in case some of you are
still waiting to see it. I also have been making a slight come back
in my cubing. I have the F2L down at a decent speed and have been
getting times between 50 to 65 sec. I still have a 4 step fl method
but once i get the hang of the F2l at a nice speed then I will work
on a 2 step fl method. I also went to a flea market in Elkhorn WI,
and got some cubes to add to my collection. Nothing to exciting but
enough to keep me excited. I also got an impossiball i recently bid
on ebay. These toys are keeping me busy! Did anyone else see Dan on
TV?
Jake

I have the F2L down at a decent speed and have been getting times between 50 to 65 sec. I still have a 4 step fl method but once i get the hang of the F2l at a nice speed then I will work on a 2 step fl method. I also went to a flea market in Elkhorn WI, and got some cubes to add to my collection. Nothing to exciting but enough to keep me excited. I also got an impossiball i recently bid on ebay. These toys are keeping me busy! Did anyone else see Dan on TV? Jake Yahoo! I ran two 12 long av this morning and while i was working on the 2nd
set, i solved a cube in 13.67!!! It was a very lucky time. The f2l
went so fast and i only did one alg for the ll. I also broke my pb
of 39 to 31.25. My av are around 52 53 cause i cube many 56s for
some odd reason. I'm in the 40s more often now. I am totally
thriled at my new improvements. Just wanted to share. Anyone out
there making improvements?
Jake



247. freak times
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 27 May 2002 23:14:52 -0000

I was wondering what some other cubers do about freak times. Do you
just forget them, or do you keep them on a pb file. In my case a
13.67 time is incredibly fast and i dont want to go around saying
that i solved the cube in 13 sec because i probably wont ever solve
it that fast ever again. I use my fastest unlucky pb whenever people
ask me "what is my fastest time". What do you guys do with lucky
times?
Jake



248. Re: freak times
From: jessica_fridrich <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 28 May 2002 02:42:36 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I was wondering what some other cubers do about freak times. Do you > just forget them, or do you keep them on a pb file. In my case a > 13.67 time is incredibly fast and i dont want to go around saying > that i solved the cube in 13 sec because i probably wont ever solve > it that fast ever again. I use my fastest unlucky pb whenever people > ask me "what is my fastest time". What do you guys do with lucky > times? > Jake Jake, even if you had to use both the orientation and permutation algorithms, you would still be well below 20, right? I personnaly disregard times when I get "too" lucky. This means either that the LL assembled by itself or I got too lucky (this is kind of loose) in the F2L. If I simply skip one stage, such as permutation, it is OK and can be counted towards PB. Otherwise, I would discard it as "cube insufficiently scrambled". Skipping the LL permutation happens once in 72 attempts (skipping the orientation happens once in 216 but this can be increased while finishing the LL) and is not that lucky, in my opinion. It is not that unusual to scramble the cube poorly when one uses some periodic moves or finger shortcuts for scrambling, especially after a long run of solving when one can get careless in scrambling. Your 13 sec. time reminded me what happened to me on the plane last week. I was solving the cube in a moderate pace paying attention to the number of moves and my ability to "see" the cubies in the F2L rather than the speed. This is a very good warming up exercise, btw. An Air Force lieutanant was sitting behind me and asked a few cube- related questions. Then he wanted to time me. I got "moderately lucky" (the permutation algorithm was just U^2) and solved the cube in 13 seconds ... I explained to him that I just got lucky a bit and had a few more attempts (18, 17, 22, 18, and 17). This was not bad considering that the cube was still rather stiff. I have to admit that I do not remember when was the last time I solved the cube in 13 seconds in front of somebody. Those really short times usually do not have witnesses ... :) Jessica

252. Re: freak times
From: "jazzthief81" <lars.vandenbergh@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 28 May 2002 16:12:42 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., jessica_fridrich <no_reply@y...> wrote: > It is not that unusual to scramble the cube poorly when one uses > some periodic moves or finger shortcuts for scrambling, especially > after a long run of solving when one can get careless in scrambling. Good point that. Scrambling in between can get a bit tedious and that's why I use the scrambler from Benoit Formet's page: http://www-eleves.iie.cnam.fr/formet/cube/scramble.htm?nb=25 That way I force myself to scramble the cube sufficiently (and of course, it's random).

Date: Tue, 28 May 2002 19:40:31 -0000

Hi everybody,
I want improve my time. I'm using a layer system and I average 33
seconds. At this time, I think I'm fast enough doing the last layer
(approx. 10 sec.) so my problem surely is the first two ones! So, to
cut down my time, I'm trying to learn the algorithms from Fridrich's
page (make a cross and then move corners and edges two by two). My
main problem is to see a corner-edge pair quickly. How can someone
locate them almost instantaneously? I'm sure there's a simple (maybe
not too simple!) way to do this but I can't figure out.
I'm also interested by the Petrus method but I can't find a detailed
one on the net. Is there a web page where I can found it?
Thanx a lot,
PL

255. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Thinking time
From: sloopy26@...
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 28 May 2002 19:17:37 -0400

http://ng.netgate.net/~mette/lars/cubedude/index.html

thats the link for lars petrus' site, which includes detailed
instructions on his method. i'm personally working on his method right
now, and it has a lot of speed potential. if you combine his method for
the F2L and then incorporate some permutation algorithms from fridrich
method, you'll be unstoppable. you can solve it almost as fast as you
could with fridrich method but you don't need to learn any orientation
algorithms (well, actually you need to learn about 4, but still). if you
want speed without a whole lot of memorization, thats the way to go.

259. 3 look permutation.
From: "nureddin1" <tommy.jyrkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 30 May 2002 14:31:46 -0000

Im moving from the intermideate 4 look LL to Dan Knight´s suggested
advanced 3 look LL ( orient edges, orient corners and permute all).
My questions and observations; In Jessicas page the notation
sometimes starts with (U1), (U2)or (U3).What does this mean?
Some permutations seem to make some logic sense to me and are very
easy to memorise, fo example; R²U Fs R²Bs U R² while others dont make
sense at all like R B U'B'U B U B²R'B U B U'B'. Does anyone have any
suggestions of how to approach these "illogic" algorithms?



260. Re: 3 look permutation.
From: jessica_fridrich <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 30 May 2002 17:11:56 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "nureddin1" <tommy.jyrkas@t...> wrote: > Im moving from the intermideate 4 look LL to Dan Knight´s suggested > advanced 3 look LL ( orient edges, orient corners and permute all). > My questions and observations; In Jessicas page the notation > sometimes starts with (U1), (U2)or (U3).What does this mean? > Some permutations seem to make some logic sense to me and are very > easy to memorise, fo example; R²U Fs R²Bs U R² while others dont make > sense at all like R B U'B'U B U B²R'B U B U'B'. Does anyone have any > suggestions of how to approach these "illogic" algorithms? I think a good way of memorizing is divide the algorithm into "macros" or finger shortcuts. It also helps to follow what happens to the first layer as you perform the algorithm. To adjust the algorithm for your hands, do not be afraid to do some "bold" things, such as performing the whole algorithm with a cube turned by 180 degrees or even upside down. Sometimes you can twist the cube by twisting TWO layers with your right hand rather than just one - this basically twists the cube by 180 degress (a neat trick) without having the regrip the cube. I am sure you find your own tricks that will lead to a unique style of yours. Overall advice, try to "dissect" each algorithm and look at the moves from different angles to figure out the best way to perform them. I am not a big protagonist of the idea that there is just one correct (or best) way to do the algorithms because we are all different and we develop different twisting styles. Besides, it is soooo nice to watch other speed cubists how they handle the cube and perform the algorithms with ease and speed. It never ceases to amaze me to watch others do their magic with the cube. Pleasant memorizing wishes Jessica
261. Re: 3 look permutation.
From: "larrpas" <larrpas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 30 May 2002 17:15:17 -0000

I won't say those algorithms are "illogic". In fact, I think that the permutation algorithms are very simple to learn and as there's only 13 of them (up to isomorphism or 21 if you prefer) you just have to sit and learn them one by one. Then, you'll see some logic. You should also read the hints in Jessica's page (a really good page by the way, thanx a lot) about customizing the algorithms. I learned all the orientation and permutation algoritms about three years ago. It took me less then a week to learn the 21 cases for permutation. Then, I broke my cube and don't touch another one in more then two years! You know what? Even after two years, I still remember all the permutation alg. (but I can't say the same thing about the orientation alg.!). That's what I mean by "you'll see some logic". When an alg. starts with U, U2 or U', it refers to the picture. It just means that you don't have to move the U slice to fit the pictures and then move it again. You were talking about logic, that is pure logic! I hope this will help you, PL --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "nureddin1" <tommy.jyrkas@t...> wrote: > Im moving from the intermideate 4 look LL to Dan Knight´s suggested > advanced 3 look LL ( orient edges, orient corners and permute all). > My questions and observations; In Jessicas page the notation > sometimes starts with (U1), (U2)or (U3).What does this mean? > Some permutations seem to make some logic sense to me and are very > easy to memorise, fo example; R²U Fs R²Bs U R² while others dont make > sense at all like R B U'B'U B U B²R'B U B U'B'. Does anyone have any > suggestions of how to approach these "illogic" algorithms?
262. Re: 3 look permutation.

Then, you'll see some logic. You > should also read the hints in Jessica's page (a really good page by > the way, thanx a lot) about customizing the algorithms. I learned all > the orientation and permutation algoritms about three years ago. It > took me less then a week to learn the 21 cases for permutation. Then, > I broke my cube and don't touch another one in more then two years! > You know what? Even after two years, I still remember all the > permutation alg. 263. oinkleburger.com and other stuff
From: ilovemycube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 02 Jun 2002 06:53:18 -0000

Hi friendz,

Good to see the rising number of members of the club. Welcome!
Again I invite members to join the chatroom during weekends. Prepare
your questions, there is always someone to answer them.
Of course you can also ask them by posting a message.

I would like to recommend the cube applet at
http://www.oinkleburger.com/Cube/Net
It has a decent interface (>2 moves per sec possible) and there is a
high score list. Krrash did a great job, and added some nifty
features lately.

F.i. you can now replay HOW other cubists solved the cubes. Check it
out at http://www.oinkleburger.com/Cube/Net/turnlists/index.cgi
Thanks Krrash!

We were talking about lucky cases, so here is a lucky case I had
yesterday. You can replay it at:
http://www.oinkleburger.com/Cube/Net/turnlists/show.cgi?
file=69ea8ba3e4a70e9b2a31c97858087a47
After F2L the upper layer was solved! Just try it.

You can also replay Dr. C's solves of the big cubes. He is the master
of big cubes and blindfold solving.

For those cubists desperately looking for suitable algorithms, please
check out Pejave's site at
http://home01.wxs.nl/~janse625/PetersCubePage.html
Pejave spent hours and hours looking for the fastest triggers. Thanks
Pejave!

Last but not least: check out the official site of the World Rubik's
Games championship at http://www.rubikswc2003.com
Our friend Gosd123 deserves appreciation for all the things he was
already able to arrange. The next few weeks will be important,
because some sponsors are going to decide whether they will help us.
Thanks Gosd123!

OK, enough talking. Hope to meet you soon in the chatroom or in real
life. I will be staying in Barcelona starting June 29. So if any of
you is there too, please send me a note, so that we can meet.

Happy cubing!

Ron
http://www.speedcubing.com




264. Holy CRAP!! I JUST BEAT THE WORLD RECORD....
From: rquethe <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 02 Jun 2002 23:39:51 -0000

I was just sitting here next to my computer timing myself and as I
was using my 15 second pre-inspection time, the bottom edges were all
in place that I could quickly get them to their right spot. So that
worked out and I got them there in about 2 seconds. Then the F2L just
went by in a flash. I know at least one Corner/edge pair was already
together, but that was it. I don't remember if the LL was in two or
three looks, but it was an easy Permutation alg, just a three edges
one. BUT GOD I FEEL Good... My PB just went from 26 seconds to
20.69.... And only 7 freakin' months of cubing too. You guys better
watch your backs...


I feel so good... I'm king of the WORLD, ha ha

here.

267. Re: Spring tension
From: "cubist3x3only" <cubist3x3only@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 04 Jun 2002 04:52:03 -0000

you have a oddzons rubiks cube .. that kind of cube has rivets.. you
can't adjust the tension in those cubes .you will need a hungarion
rubiks cube or a 1980's rubiks cube they have screws in them you can
adjust..get one on ebay. best place for cubes

270. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Tips for beginner
From: Kanika Ghai <cubaholicus@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 5 Jun 2002 01:28:52 -0700 (PDT)

just out of curiosity... how many people on this egroup actually solved the cube by themselves...i mean, without referring to online solutions? it's perfectly understandable that some might not like to admit to this...! any answers? Jason Boltz <layaway@...> wrote: The way I learned to solve it first was by this web site someone posted in the message board before. http://www.cubeland.fr.st/ That is one basic method for layer-by-layer solving. Once you get that you can go learn more and more algorithms, etc. Good luck. Jason ----- Original Message ----- From: Santhosh To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Wednesday, June 05, 2002 2:16 AM Subject: Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Tips for beginner Dave, Thanx a lot. i will join u guys on this weekend. but before that tell me how can i start with this cube. step by step procedure will be helpful. thanx in advance. santa __________________________________________________ Do You Yahoo!? 273. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Tips for beginner
From: "Brad Huff" <bhuff70@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 05 Jun 2002 22:25:49 +0000




I came up with my own solutions for the Rubik's Cube, Rubik's Revenge and
the Professor. Admitting my own solutions were not the fastest. I borrow
hints from other people when coming up with a faster solution. Almost all
of the algorithms I use, I have discovered for myself. As to how many
other people came up with their own solution...I have no idea!

Brad

>From an earlier email, I mentioned that I solved the Rubik's Cube with my
own solution. To add on to this, that was back in 1981. I was 15 at the
time. When I was 16 I solved the Rubik's Revenge. At 35 I recently solved
the Professor Cube when I first got it in the mail. Seven hours later I
solved it for the first time. Just think, some of you probably weren't
even born yet when I first tackled the cube.

Brad

282. Cycle free paths
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 06 Jun 2002 22:59:43 -0000

I was thinking last night about the following problem (not that I
had any thoughts as to the solving of the problem).
Starting with a position P_0 of the cube (say the solved position)
suppose you make successive (quarter-turn) moves M_1, M_2,
..., M_n resulting in positions P_1, P_2, ..., P_n such that the
positions P_0, P_1, ..., P_n are pairwise distinct (that is no two
are the same). What is the maximum value of such an n?



283. Re: Cycle free paths
From: larrpas <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jun 2002 03:34:17 -0000

Let turn your question into a postulate : there is a sequence of moves M_1, M_2,..., M_n such that the corresponding positions P_1, P_2,..., P_n are pairwise distinct and where n = 43252003274489856000, the order of the permutation group of the Rubik's Cube. I'll think more about your problem, maybe the solution is not so simple but I think I can come up with a proof. PL --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I was thinking last night about the following problem (not that I > had any thoughts as to the solving of the problem). > Starting with a position P_0 of the cube (say the solved position) > suppose you make successive (quarter-turn) moves M_1, M_2, > ..., M_n resulting in positions P_1, P_2, ..., P_n such that the > positions P_0, P_1, ..., P_n are pairwise distinct (that is no two > are the same). What is the maximum value of such an n?
284. Re: Cycle free paths
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jun 2002 18:02:46 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., larrpas <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Let turn your question into a postulate : there is a sequence of > moves M_1, M_2,..., M_n such that the corresponding positions P_1, > P_2,..., P_n are pairwise distinct and where n = > 43252003274489856000, the order of the permutation group of the > Rubik's Cube. I'll think more about your problem, maybe the solution > is not so simple but I think I can come up with a proof. > > PL That would be more of a conjecture than a postulate. I'd be very surprised if it were true. It's certainly true that n is bounded above by the number of total positions and therefore the problem is decideable (hence you wouldn't need a postulate) but I would imagine that n is less than this. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > I was thinking last night about the following problem (not that I > > had any thoughts as to the solving of the problem). > > Starting with a position P_0 of the cube (say the solved position) > > suppose you make successive (quarter-turn) moves M_1, M_2, > > ..., M_n resulting in positions P_1, P_2, ..., P_n such that the > > positions P_0, P_1, ..., P_n are pairwise distinct (that is no two > > are the same). What is the maximum value of such an n?
285. Re: Cycle free paths
From: larrpas <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jun 2002 19:27:51 -0000

Oups, you're right, I was meaning conjecture instead of postulate... With all the researches done about the Rubik Cube, Im pretty sure an answer to your question as already been given. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., larrpas <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > Let turn your question into a postulate : there is a sequence of > > moves M_1, M_2,..., M_n such that the corresponding positions > P_1, > > P_2,..., P_n are pairwise distinct and where n = > > 43252003274489856000, the order of the permutation group > of the > > Rubik's Cube. I'll think more about your problem, maybe the > solution > > is not so simple but I think I can come up with a proof. > > > > PL > > That would be more of a conjecture than a postulate. I'd be very > surprised if it were true. It's certainly true that n is bounded above > by the number of total positions and therefore the problem is > decideable (hence you wouldn't need a postulate) but I would > imagine that n is less than this. > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., GameOfDeath2 > <no_reply@y...> > > wrote: > > > I was thinking last night about the following problem (not that > I > > > had any thoughts as to the solving of the problem). > > > Starting with a position P_0 of the cube (say the solved > position) > > > suppose you make successive (quarter-turn) moves M_1, > M_2, > > > ..., M_n resulting in positions P_1, P_2, ..., P_n such that the > > > positions P_0, P_1, ..., P_n are pairwise distinct (that is no > two > > > are the same). What is the maximum value of such an n?
286. Re: Cycle free paths
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jun 2002 21:46:57 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., larrpas <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Oups, you're right, I was meaning conjecture instead of postulate... > With all the researches done about the Rubik Cube, Im pretty sure an > answer to your question as already been given. Perhaps, but not even the diameter of the group is known and that is an easier problem or at least as easy, I would have thought (if d is the diameter of the group then it is easy to see that d<=n at any rate).
287. Re: Cycle free paths
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 07 Jun 2002 21:49:46 -0000

Perhaps, but not even the diameter of the group is known and that is an easier problem or at least as easy, I would have thought (if d is the diameter of the group then it is easy to see that d<=n at any rate).

289. ACube program...
From: nviennefr <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Hi everyone !

everything !!. However I have read the file "readme.txt"

If some people use it, can you give me a concrete exemple of using?

For exemple to find algorithms to orientation and permutation N°1
according to fridrich' web site?

This program is (normally) enable to ignore some part of the cube. My
goal is to find algos to "solve" from a state1 to another state2
(state2 isn't a solved cube) How can I do???

290. Woa! A new move!
From: eligeon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 08 Jun 2002 14:00:28 -0000

I dunno if anyone has noticed this trick before,so I am going to
post it. When solving the cube on the last layer, you sometimes end
up with the edges opposite there correct color. For instance, all
the corners are set and the whole bottome of the cube is a solid
color, but the red edge is located on the orange side, the orange
edge is located on the red side, the white edge is located on the
yellow side, and the yellow edge is located on the white side. This
series of moves I just discovered allows you to complete the cube in
just 12 moves! Here it is, from any side when the last layer is on
the top. Left Clockwise Right Clockwise Top Twice Left Counter
Clockwise Twice Right Counter Clockwise Twice Top Twice Right
Clockwise and Left Clockwise! If you want more help on this email me
at bgordon@... I will be gone for one week but then I am free!



291. Also, a new pattern!
From: eligeon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 08 Jun 2002 14:06:00 -0000

I apologize for my last post, here is the correct way to switch four
edges in 12 moves. Left clockwise Right clockwise Top Top Left
Counter clockwise Right counter clockwise Front counter clockwise
back counter clockwise Top Top front clockwise and back clockwise. I
will show pics on a page explaining this when I return from
vacation. Also here is a neat pattern with the move I just posted.
Left clockwise Right Clockwise Top Top Left Counter clockwise twice
Right Counter clockwise twice Top Top Left clockwise Right clockwise!



292. Re: Also, a new pattern!
From: krrash <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 08 Jun 2002 18:20:01 -0000

The algorithm you have given can be found here: http://www.ssie.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/permute.html It is the fourth one down. Congratulations on your rediscovery. :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., eligeon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I apologize for my last post, here is the correct way to switch four > edges in 12 moves. Left clockwise Right clockwise Top Top Left > Counter clockwise Right counter clockwise Front counter clockwise > back counter clockwise Top Top front clockwise and back clockwise.
293. Re: Also, a new pattern!
From: larrpas <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 08 Jun 2002 18:40:48 -0000

Anyway, the goal is to solve de cube as fast as possible! So here's to the fastest move for speed cubist : R2 U2 R U2 R2 U2 R2 U2 R U2 R2 I mean for right handed speed cubist! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., krrash <no_reply@y...> wrote: > The algorithm you have given can be found here: > > http://www.ssie.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/permute.html > > It is the fourth one down. > > Congratulations on your rediscovery. :) > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., eligeon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I apologize for my last post, here is the correct way to switch > four > > edges in 12 moves. Left clockwise Right clockwise Top Top Left > > Counter clockwise Right counter clockwise Front counter clockwise > > back counter clockwise Top Top front clockwise and back clockwise.

299. wrist troubles
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 12 Jun 2002 02:55:13 -0000

Hey I have a question, does anyone else out there have wrist troubles
sometimes? I'm getting to the point now where if I cube for an
extended period of time (now about two hours or so) my right wrist
will start to hurt me. My cube is definitely uber-loose and I keep
it cleaned up and mega-greased all the time. However my wrist will
still bug me. I've noticed that when I do an average of ten, if I
rest for about a minute or two between times then my wrist won't bug
me but I definitely can't cube straight through a trial of ten
anymore. My wrist won't hurt, as in a painful hurt, it just gets
sore and uncomfortable to move quickly. Was just wondering if anyone
else has the same problem. I'm a little worried that it bugs me like
this, seeing as I don't want early arthritis or anything but I also
don't want to stop cubing seeing as I'm still pretty addicted. I
have noticed that I cube mostly right handed a lot and have always
done that, so I assume that is definitely, if not the cause, most of
my problem. I'm trying to coordinate my left hand even more than I
usually use it but I haven't really had time to practice a lot
recently because of school. Now that summer has started I'm going to
try to work on more left handed cubing than I usually do and see if
that helps. Anyway if anyone has any ideas then let me know.

Thanks,
Chris

301. Re: wrist troubles
From: "hatadey" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 14 Jun 2002 11:25:43 -0000

I sometimes get troule with my right thumb, if a cubie rubs on the joint I get a very bad twinge, sometimes so nasty i drop the cube. I found that using my wrist more to cube seemed to stop my thumbs from getting hurt too much, maybe if you cubed more by using your fingers it might stop your wrist from hurting so much? Good Luck, Dan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey I have a question, does anyone else out there have wrist troubles > sometimes? I'm getting to the point now where if I cube for an > extended period of time (now about two hours or so) my right wrist > will start to hurt me. My cube is definitely uber-loose and I keep > it cleaned up and mega-greased all the time. However my wrist will > still bug me. I've noticed that when I do an average of ten, if I > rest for about a minute or two between times then my wrist won't bug > me but I definitely can't cube straight through a trial of ten > anymore. My wrist won't hurt, as in a painful hurt, it just gets > sore and uncomfortable to move quickly. Was just wondering if anyone > else has the same problem. I'm a little worried that it bugs me like > this, seeing as I don't want early arthritis or anything but I also > don't want to stop cubing seeing as I'm still pretty addicted. I > have noticed that I cube mostly right handed a lot and have always > done that, so I assume that is definitely, if not the cause, most of > my problem. I'm trying to coordinate my left hand even more than I > usually use it but I haven't really had time to practice a lot > recently because of school. Now that summer has started I'm going to > try to work on more left handed cubing than I usually do and see if > that helps. Anyway if anyone has any ideas then let me know. > > Thanks, > Chris
302. Inconsistencies....
From: rquethe <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 07:16:54 -0000

Ahh! I'm getting so angry at how inconsistent my cubing is. I don't
know what it is I'm doing wrong. I'll be timing myself and have a
great run and get say 26 seconds. The very next timing, everything
will feel exactly the same as the first, but I get a 40 second time,
YUCK!!! I didn't do anything differently that I was consciously aware
of. Yet, I will do over 15 seconds worse. Right now, I have the
ability to always get low thirty second times, possibly high 20
seconds times. But because of the inconsistencies, I always have a 40
second time or two that hurt my average. I need to eliminate them,
but I don't know how. Anyone have any ideas and how I can fix this?


On a different note, I recently made a new video of me solving the
cube in 26 seconds. You can download it at
http://homepages.spider.lu/liquid/26sec.wmv
Everyone tell me what you think about any mistakes I make in the
video. Near the end, I accidentally miss one of my triggers...

my right index finger, the UR edge piece pops out. Is there a better
way of performing this move that I don't know about, to avoid piece
poppage? Or is it my cube that is the problem?

looked at the site http://www.speedcubing.com/ and noticed that there
was 21 final layer algorithms (you know, when the last layer has the
correct bottom color but the pieces need to swap). Could someone
tell me any hints on how to remember them? Or do you just practice
them over and over and over and over?

though, but that does not mean it should go slow.

308. Re: memorizing your turns HELP!
From: smoothcuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 19:15:09 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., eligeon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I have a question, (which means someone probably has an answer) which > is how in god's name do you learn the last layers move. If you are > wondering what the heck I am talking about, then let me clarify. I > looked at the site http://www.speedcubing.com/ and noticed that there > was 21 final layer algorithms (you know, when the last layer has the > correct bottom color but the pieces need to swap). Could someone > tell me any hints on how to remember them? Or do you just practice > them over and over and over and over? Memorizing algs isn't as hard as it seems. Some things that may help: Choose an alg that is comfortable for your hands, rather than just picking the first one you see (try them from different sites). That is very important. Also, at first, just try to recognize the patterns. Solve the cube, and see how quickly you can recognize the permutation when you get to it. When you're trying to memorize the moves, write them down on a sheet of paper. Try to memorize just the first 2 or 3 turns of a move (like R'UR). Do that for all the moves. Then solve the cube, and see if you can remember those first several moves when you reach the perm stage. Soon you'll find you know the first few turns. Then go for the next 2 or 3 turns. Often these will be in the form of finger tricks (short moves you can do quickly, like R'UR). Keep your cheat sheet handy. When you feel like it, you can work on one move over and over for 5 min or so. Before long, you'll think it's all pretty easy. Good luck. Dave
309. Re: memorizing your turns HELP!
From: eligeon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 20:24:55 -0000

Okay. Thx. I will work on it right away! But before I start, is
it really worth the effort? I mean the way I do it takes about 15
seconds, but that is pretty fast for the last layer to me. My
average right now is 1:02. I have yet to cross the minute! Argh!



310. Re: memorizing your turns HELP!
From: smoothcuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 20:40:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., eligeon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Okay. Thx. I will work on it right away! But before I start, is > it really worth the effort? I mean the way I do it takes about 15 > seconds, but that is pretty fast for the last layer to me. My > average right now is 1:02. I have yet to cross the minute! Argh! It depends how fast you want to become. 15 sec for the LL is good. If you learn the LL in two (orientation move, then permutation move), you can eventually get under 10 sec for LL, even down to 6 sometimes. It's your call. Dave
311. Re: memorizing your turns HELP!
From: eligeon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

312. Re: Inconsistencies....
From: bobbit_at_mac_dot_com <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 21:00:08 -0000

> > I dunno about going slower on the first two...., but I would
say
> > that the last layer should have no reason not to be sold fast!
The
> > first and second layer should have some sort of rythem or
> consistency
> > though, but that does not mean it should go slow.
> Sorry, by F2L you meant first 2 layers...right?

Yes, F2L is first two layers and LL is last layer. I say go slower
on the F2L because it allows you to see what's happening as
you do an alg, it helps you to foresee what you need to do next. If
I blaze through the algs on f2l, I finish with a slower time
because there are so many gaps after algs. The LL can be done
as quick as you like I think.



313. Re: Inconsistencies....
From: bobbit_at_mac_dot_com <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 15 Jun 2002 21:07:32 -0000

rquethe, I see you are a fan of Quake. Do you ever play a mod
called True Combat? It rulez, that's official. I play that most days
but I'm not very good to be honest. It's not so manic as arena, it's
more to do with tactics and so on...

If > I blaze through the algs on f2l, I finish with a slower time > because there are so many gaps after algs. The LL can be done > as quick as you like I think. I don't really think you should slow down in the f2l, but make sure you force yourself to look ahead and if the pieces are going too fast for you to keep track of then you might want to slow down just a little bit......and i think what some one else said about keeping a rhythm is important too, so pretty much whenever i cube i listen to music so theres a beat to follow, and you can kind of relax a little bit when cubing that way, its better if the music has a faster tempo... -Heath

want to improve your cubing. I listen to music a lot and the same
goes with cubing. Put those together and since it is summer, I cube
with music at least three to four hours straight. I think it
probably is because you think of the music so the cubing is
subconscence.




316. Corner Method
From: eligeon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jun 2002 17:01:21 -0000

of 30 or less? Thanks!



317. Re: Corner Method
From: rquethe <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jun 2002 20:53:24 -0000

Dan Gosbee uses a corner system and has and average of 16-17 seconds.
So yes, you can go under 30 seconds with a corner system.



318. Re: Corner Method
From: johnlach70 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 18 Jun 2002 22:54:46 -0000

I don't believe that someone can average 16 seconds, corner system, layer system or whatever system. There's a lot of people saying that they can solve a rubik's cube in 12 seconds! The problem is that they're using their own timing method... First of all, the timer should start as soon as we look at the cube because thinking of the moves is part of the solution. I also think that a good cubist almost never have "unlucky" times, so we should never remove the highest times (and a good cubist is suppose to make precise moves and don't break is cube). Finally, because it's hard to tell what is a lucky time, we should remove "enought" good times. So, here's my timing method : - I solve 20 cube scrambled by computer(at least 25 moves)without inspecting them - I remove the highest time (possibly a pop) - I remove the 10 lowest time - I average the other 9 times I know some of you won't agree with this method but I think that it is a fair one. I think that a really good cubist can go near 20 seconds but not below. Tell me what you think. J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., rquethe <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Dan Gosbee uses a corner system and has and average of 16-17 seconds. > So yes, you can go under 30 seconds with a corner system.

From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Tue, 18 Jun 2002 22:58:51 -0000

There's a lot of people saying that > they can solve a rubik's cube in 12 seconds! The problem is that > they're using their own timing method... First of all, the timer > should start as soon as we look at the cube because thinking of the > moves is part of the solution. I also think that a good cubist almost > never have "unlucky" times, so we should never remove the highest > times (and a good cubist is suppose to make precise moves and don't > break is cube). So, here's my timing > method : > - I solve 20 cube scrambled by computer(at least 25 moves)without > inspecting them > - I remove the highest time (possibly a pop) > - I remove the 10 lowest time > - I average the other 9 times > > I know some of you won't agree with this method but I think that it > is a fair one. 326. Re: ANOTHER SPEEDCUBIST?
From: jessica_fridrich <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 19 Jun 2002 15:43:37 -0000

There seems to be way too much emphasis being put on the method or individual algorithms, whether they can be performed in 1.5 sec. or 1.9 sec., and other not really essential details. Here is my personal observation - pick the 10 fastest people, who will all be sub-20 consistently BTW, and I am quite sure you would find out a surprising variety in their systems, algorithms, finger shortcuts, cubing styles, cross on a side or bottom, corners first, by layers, God knows what else. You can study all chess books, replay all games, memorize a huge amount of information, but still you may not play great chess. Because after all, it is the person, his ingenuity, talent, and physical and mental abilities, who plays the chess, not the system. Furthermore, I do not mean this to be directed to any particular person, but in all sports there is certain distribution of performance among contestants no matter how hard we practice. We all have our limits in everything, different gifts, degree of determination and motivation. There will be those who can achieve with ease and those who have to work hard for their success. That's life. Good luck with the cube to everybody and turn more to yourself for answers because this is where the real answers are ... Sorry for sounding like a mentor, but I just could not stand back anymore. Finally, Eligeon, I encourage you to try the corners-first system. It is possible that the by-layer system "does not fit" your mind. Josef Jelinek's (Gloom) site has quite a collection of useful moves for this system. Keep us posted on your progress. Jessica --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., eligeon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hello. For those of you who have not met me in the chat rooms, I > am currently working on speedcubing. In the past weeks I have grown > old of the layer by layer method, and am trying to switch to the > corner first method. I was wondering if anyone knew of a site that > explains indepth the waterman solution? I would be forever grateful. > Thank you, > Eligeon
327. Thanks Jessica
From: eligeon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 19 Jun 2002 16:32:30 -0000

Thank you Jessica. I have already memorized the solution and am
working like mad to find little shortcuts. I want to thank you for
the information, and am glad to say that I have already achieved the
2 minute mark with the solution!
Thank you Jessica
Eligeon

330. A Tip About Solutions
From: eligeon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 19 Jun 2002 23:55:44 -0000

I have noticed that different people become incredibly fast when
they learn to do a certain solution. I think that it depends on how
you visualize it. Anyways, wouldn't it be politically correct to say
that it really is the solution that chooses the person? Not the
other way around? Just a question to ponder about!



331. corner method
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 02:40:16 -0000

Heyo, I was playing around with methods a while ago. I have always
stuck with a layer by layer concept. Just have been making tweeks
along the way. One day i was inspired by the corners first method to
try and create a wacky solution. So far i havent heard of this on
yet. You start by doing the midle layer, then place all the corners,
and then finish with the top and bottom edges. Its kinda weird but
it aint to bad. I don't think that i will ever convert to a corner
method layer though. I just see the layer method a lot better.
Just tossing some cells
Jake



332. Importance of centre strategy for big cubes
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 20 Jun 2002 11:37:20 -0000


Here's some data for the 18x18x18 that I did last night:
(of course some stages had mistakes that will adversely affect
the totals but the main point is not altered)

first centre 707 turns
second centre 858 turns (less freedom so it should take a bit
longer)
third centre 844 turns (less freedom but less places to look - no
need to keep opposite centre fixed also)
fourth centre 840 turns
fifth and sixth centres 1081 turns
first 8 edges 399 turns
next 3 edges 274 turns
cross 9 turns
F2L 31 turns
fixing last edge 43 turns
OLL 12 turns
PLL 18 turns

Net turns for each stage: centres 4330 turns
Edges: 716 turns
3x3x3 part: 70 turns

I got a little lucky in that it was an OLL that I know so that I didn't
need two steps. Also I didn't have to switch 2 edges but that's a
50-50 thing anyway so that's not so lucky.
Anyway, the main thing is that centres massively outweigh edges
with the regular solution being least of all so my slowness at
3x3x3 is really not so big an issue on big cubes.
This is why I maintain that centres are the key for large cubes.

From: eligeon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 02:18:30 -0000

Jessica. And yes Lars and Jessica, you can vote. :)



334. drunk, cross, F2L, and bla bla bla
From: rknapton <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 03:08:59 -0000

E hg800 40 oz.)planned on a 9 ball pool tourney, but was stuck workin
too late again.
2. Cross! switched to the bottom. I'm horrible at it, plus I was
never good when it was at the top... I want it on the bottom b'cuz I
can C where it might come in handy for starting the F2L (according to
cross on bottom). I'd like to eventually B in the low 20's. using
the F2L from speedcubing.com which I'm just learning (I used to
average 35 seconds w/ puting 1 piece in at a time) I'm getting some
times in the 30's. However, now I take up to 10 seconds ALONE to do
the cross on the bottom. of course this will improve... but I'd love
to do it as fast as U sub-20 second cubers. so I'm wondering what is
an average time for U guys on it.. and if you memorize all the moves
4 it B4 you start.?

3. F2L. Delayed learning matching parirs up 4-ever.(4 months)..
however recently I started learning 1 alg a day during my 15 min.
breaks. It's been easy (and I don't consider myself lucky according
to quickness of learning). started w/ the matching pairs connected,
then pairs in the U layer, next pairs wherever. Soon E'nouf I'll use
em' all. So I would suggest learning it if you have any such
desire. Both Ron and Jessica's sites are a wonderful help.
here's the question... what piece... edge or middle. do you spot
first and decide the next alg you'll use. or is it either way or just
different.?

336. Another cube presentation
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 20:01:06 -0000

I was lucky enough to be able to give another cube presentation
today. One of the guys I knew from school, who knew I cubed, his
mother teaches a fifth grade class and he is doing community service
for her school and helping her teach the class. They asked me to
come in today (I just got back) and present the cube and some other
puzzles. Well I brought in a small assortment of puzzles and of
course the cube. The first presentation was kind of cool, Ben's mom
asked the class to each give an estimate of how long it would take me
to do the cube and the closet one would get a prize. Well everyone
guessed in the 2-4 minute range, one person guessed one minute even
and one person guessed 59 seconds. Well I did it in about 25 which
blew them all away. They asked me to do it about 5 or 6 more times.
One of the times I got 20 seconds even and another I got low 22.xx
seconds so they were also amazed at seeing someone break
an "official" world record. Anyway it's not on the scale that some
of you guys have presented but I figured I'd share a cube experience
in case anyone was interested.

Chris

P.S. I'm sloooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooowly getting to the lower
twenties and more times in the sub-twenties. My wrist still bugs me
if I cube for a long time but I'm finding ways to get around that.
Later all.
