(This bugs > > because it means one of two things: He's either lying to impress > me, > > or he actually solved it on his own at 15). > > I think you'll find that there are many people (including many people > on this site) who first solved the cube before the age of 15. I was > 10 years old when I first did the cube. 702. Calling all Fridrich'ers
From: "buddyleeboy" <buddyleeboy@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Aug 2002 16:51:17 -0000


I have to be the most impatient being on this planet. As some of
you know I've been switching to Fridrich's method from Lars's in the
hopes that it will cut down my times. I've been at it for about 5
days and I still haven't hit 20s! (Just kidding... not that
impatient.) I just timed myself and I seem to average about 1:10s on
the F2L using about 2/3 of the "all possible F2L" algs I've memorized
so far. I'm noticing a few problems that I hoped some of you could
help with:

_The Cross:_

Getting the cross is easy, but I can't seem to be able to examine the
cube and memorize all 7-10 moves needed to get to the cross. This
means I'm constantly looking for the cubies I need, and turning the
cube around in my hands which takes tons of time.

_F2L:_

Here's how I do it: I pick a "corner area" (the space where a corner
piece should end up (ie Red-White-Green with white as the color of
the cross)) and go hunt for the corner that fits it. I swing it into
its appropriate "column" on the cube (between the red and green
faces.) Then I hunt for its corresponding edge-piece. If it's already
on the top layer, I do a "mental search query" for the correct
algorithm and do it. If it's a position I don't know yet, I'll morph
the position to fit an alg I do know.
However, if the edge-piece is in an incorrect "column" (ie between
blue and orange) I make exactly 3 moves to get it to the top layer.
1st move breaks the cross and gets the edge-piece up on the top
layer. 2nd move moves the edge-piece out of the way. 3rd move
restores the cross (The same goes if the corner piece is on the
bottom layer between incorrect faces). Then I search for an
algorithm, etc.

_LL:_

Haven't even gotten started. I just practice F2L right now.

I figure that the cross portion is just practice, with very few
hints associated with it. If you have any, please let me know. But
what really concerns me is F2L. Am I doing it the right way? Should I
JUST move the edge-piece to the top layer and then find an alg,
restoring the cross at a later time? If someone could tell me what is
going on in their brain RIGHT after the cross is completed in the
beginning and about to start F2L, it would help me a lot. Especially
from the master herself. Thanks!

-Donnie



703. Re: Calling all Fridrich'ers
From: krrash <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Aug 2002 17:26:33 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "buddyleeboy" <buddyleeboy@y...> wrote: > _F2L:_ > > Here's how I do it: I pick a "corner area" (the space where a corner > piece should end up (ie Red-White-Green with white as the color of > the cross)) and go hunt for the corner that fits it. Not very efficient. Look for first layer corners that are already on the third layer, then go hunting for the corresponding edge. Most of the time you can find one. If not, look for a f2l edge piece on the third layer, and look for the corner. Very rarely, all of the unsolved f2l pieces are misplaced on the first two layers. In which case, bring a corner to the third layer and continue. Sounds like you could use some practice solving for number of turns instead of speed. Try solving the f2l in about 35 turns.
704. Re: Calling all Fridrich'ers
From: "jessica_fridrich" <jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Aug 2002 17:31:06 -0000

Donnie, do not sweat the cross. If you can do 3, do just three and then, as you are inserting them, look for the fourth one. It is OK to use, say 10 moves to do the cross instead of the optimal 7 or so. Do not try to memorize the cross at all price. I sometimes do it exactly this way if the cubies are scattered in unfavorable positions. F2L requires a lot of experience but is lighting fast once mastered. Instead of memorizing the algs from my page, try to develop your own algs and then learn only those that you are having problems with. Do not just apply the algs blindly. Here is my advice. 1) There are two basic ways to bring a corner from the LL into the 1st layer (OK, with the exception when the white is on the bottom): the one that picks up a distant edge along the way and the one that inserts the corner and the edge that is right behind it. Both moves are 3 (or 4) moves long. Now, 90% of the situations can be composed of combinations of those two basic moves. The remaining 10% are less obvious but only a move or two shorter than those "obvious" composed of those two basic moves. The secret is that you do not really need any special algs for the F2L. The savings you gain from using the shortest ones instead of the obvious ones make a small difference that becomes important only when you try to get below 20. 2) In the beginning right after the cross, you can use even simpler and shorter moves to insert the edges because you can use the fact that no corner-edge pair is in place. Again, those simple 3-move basic "algorithms" can do the job. 3) Finally, when I finish the cross, I look at the last layer searching for pairs of cubies. In most cases, there is at least one pair already. Do that one and then repeat again. If you at some point do not see any pairs in the LL, you can do the following. Say, you have a corner in the LL and the edge is somewhere in the middle in some incorrect place. Then use the bottom layer to move the corner to the edge (or down-left or down-right - I hope you know what I mean) and do that 3-move to "pick up" that edge. You can always pick it up into one of the two positions that will only need one of those basic moves to insert the pair into the correct place. You rarely, very rarely, need to remove a corner (or edge) in order to proceed. That will hold you back. Usually, you can do something like I described, which is fast, filled with two-side moves, finger shortcuts, and it is easy to see. 4) Go slowly. The system works best when you do not apply the algs blindly but rather you try to minimize the number of moves, ignoring the time for a while. This is why I also always advice to forget about the time and, instead, start paying attention to the number of moves in the F2L. Then, _very_gradually_ increase the speed. This is the best warm up as well, by the way. Much better than twisting like crazy right from the moment you pick up the cube. I hope this helps. If you have any more questions, let me know. Jessica --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "buddyleeboy" <buddyleeboy@y...> wrote: > > I have to be the most impatient being on this planet. As some of > you know I've been switching to Fridrich's method from Lars's in the > hopes that it will cut down my times. I've been at it for about 5 > days and I still haven't hit 20s! (Just kidding... not that > impatient.) I just timed myself and I seem to average about 1:10s on > the F2L using about 2/3 of the "all possible F2L" algs I've memorized > so far. I'm noticing a few problems that I hoped some of you could > help with: > > _The Cross:_ > > Getting the cross is easy, but I can't seem to be able to examine the > cube and memorize all 7-10 moves needed to get to the cross. This > means I'm constantly looking for the cubies I need, and turning the > cube around in my hands which takes tons of time. > > _F2L:_ > > Here's how I do it: I pick a "corner area" (the space where a corner > piece should end up (ie Red-White-Green with white as the color of > the cross)) and go hunt for the corner that fits it. I swing it into > its appropriate "column" on the cube (between the red and green > faces.) Then I hunt for its corresponding edge-piece. If it's already > on the top layer, I do a "mental search query" for the correct > algorithm and do it. If it's a position I don't know yet, I'll morph > the position to fit an alg I do know. > However, if the edge-piece is in an incorrect "column" (ie between > blue and orange) I make exactly 3 moves to get it to the top layer. > 1st move breaks the cross and gets the edge-piece up on the top > layer. 2nd move moves the edge-piece out of the way. 3rd move > restores the cross (The same goes if the corner piece is on the > bottom layer between incorrect faces). Then I search for an > algorithm, etc. > > _LL:_ > > Haven't even gotten started. I just practice F2L right now. > > I figure that the cross portion is just practice, with very few > hints associated with it. If you have any, please let me know. But > what really concerns me is F2L. Am I doing it the right way? Should I > JUST move the edge-piece to the top layer and then find an alg, > restoring the cross at a later time? If someone could tell me what is > going on in their brain RIGHT after the cross is completed in the > beginning and about to start F2L, it would help me a lot. Especially > from the master herself. Thanks! > > -Donnie

712. Re: The Reunion
From: smoothcuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Aug 2002 17:08:31 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., jason.feng@s... wrote:
> I was just wondering if anyone knows what's happened to some of the
> top cubists from the last world championships? Obviously we've heard
> from Lars Petrus and Jiri Fridrich, but where's Minh Thai? Is he
> retired? Is he on this board under an assumed name?

Then there are the thousands who participated in the US championships
who aren't on these boards. Discounting those, of the 57 on the
unofficial list of best of 10, I count three(!) who participate in
chats, or who even post. One wonders if they are still cubing. Most
weekends you can hear the crickets in the chatroom. I hope this
contest hasn't created a cube isolation, cuz I was liking the advice I
was getting. Now I'm just stagnating again, and losing interest.
Maybe that's what happens.



713. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: The Reunion
From: jason.feng@...

Doesn't sound weird at all. I just can't believe it's been 20 years since the last championships. It's totally understandable that a lot of the participants would lose interest and retire. I guess as a "50- second" cubist at the time, I retired for a while, but I guess the fever is back now. 716. Lowly cuber seeks recognition...
From: "buddyleeboy" <buddyleeboy@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Aug 2002 22:14:19 -0000


Hello everyone. I just found out a few minutes ago that this
competition is the first in 21 years! I sure hope that it can be a
bit more frequent in the years to come. I'm certain a little ESPN
coverage in USA would spark some interest again (I'm one of those who
was not yet born when Minh set the record by the way). Anyway, I
noticed on the list of top 20 at the last championship, that if you
could beat about 50 seconds, you could make the top 20. I average
about 42 seconds and would just be honored to make it on that board.
My question to you guys is, do you think the cubists nowadays have
evolved their times enough to make any hopes of my making the top 20
obliterated? I'm tempted to compete just to say I did it, but if
cubing has grown such that only sub 30'ers need apply, I'm not sure
it would be worth it for me. I don't even know if I am able to
compete. What is the procedure to be a competitor? Thanks all!

-Donnie

P.S. Maybe by then I'll have figured out that Fridrich and have
gotten down to competitive times. (I'm still reading your response to
me Jessica, I really appreciate that! Some of it confuses me so far,
but I'm going to make sense of it, and if I don't I'll ask ya.)

723. Re: orientation #11
From: "gtregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Aug 2002 06:18:17 -0000

I'm not completely sure I know which orientation you're referring to, but if I'm right, try this: R U R' U R U' B U' B' R' Not quite the R U R' F start you though, but it's close... Just to make sure I'm talking about the right orientation, is this right?: - Two edges are correct F and B - Two edges are incorrect (duh) R and L - The two front corners (UFR and UFL) need to turn counter clockwise - and the other two corners (UBR and UBL) need to turn clockwise I just painted the result of this starting position and your first four steps into Ron's cube solver applet (http://www.speedcubing.com/CubeSolver/CubeSolver.html), and that was the first thing it found... Seems like a good sequence to me :-) It has the same effect on the cube (orientation and positioning) as the first algo on Fridrich's page... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@y...> wrote: > ahhh....its drivng me insane, I used to know it...and it was > fast!.......but somehow I lost if from memory. I cant figure out how > i did it before...im pretty sure its not either of them on fridrich's > site...... > > I think this is how I used to do it....I held it with the row of > edges pointing like this " | " and the row of corners and edge were > on the right side.......and I think it started with these moves....R > U R' F....im not 100% sure about those being the moves > though.....those are just the ones my hands are coming up with for > it :S...lol.... > > how do you guys do that move?....does anybody know how to do that > orientation with those first few moves? > > thanks.... > > -Heath

727. Re: orientation #11
From: pejave <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Aug 2002 16:26:49 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@y...> wrote: > ahhh....its drivng me insane, I used to know it...and it was > fast!.......but somehow I lost if from memory. I cant figure out how > i did it before...im pretty sure its not either of them on fridrich's > site...... > > I think this is how I used to do it....I held it with the row of > edges pointing like this " | " and the row of corners and edge were > on the right side.......and I think it started with these moves....R > U R' F....im not 100% sure about those being the moves > though.....those are just the ones my hands are coming up with for > it :S...lol.... > > how do you guys do that move?....does anybody know how to do that > orientation with those first few moves? > > thanks.... > > -Heath It is not the way you used to do it but try it this way: (R'U'RU'R'(DE))(R'URB) (DE) = the 2 bottom layers clockwise Peter

I cant figure out > how > > i did it before...im pretty sure its not either of them on > fridrich's > > site...... > > > > I think this is how I used to do it....I held it with the row of > > edges pointing like this " | " and the row of corners and edge > were > > on the right side.......and I think it started with these > moves....R > > U R' F....im not 100% sure about those being the moves > > though.....those are just the ones my hands are coming up with for > > it :S...lol.... > > > > how do you guys do that move?....does anybody know how to do that > > orientation with those first few moves? > > > > thanks.... > > > > -Heath > > > It is not the way you used to do it but try it this way: > > (R'U'RU'R'(DE))(R'URB) > > (DE) = the 2 bottom layers clockwise > > > Peter wow....thats pretty much the same thing as i was doing except holding on to the top layer and moving the 2 bottom layers, insted of changing my grip on the cube.......this one has promise also....thanks Peter... -Heath
729. Re: Unimpressed with Meffert's Puzzles...
From: "gtregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Aug 2002 16:46:19 -0000

I've had a couple problems with them myself... Bought an assembly cube that was broken when it came (and the piece wasn't in the box, so it must have been broken when they sent it)... So I asked for a replacement piece (it was the center part that holds all the face centers on)... Guess what - when they sent it, the replacement was also broken... Oh, well... Aside from the assembly cube, I've had good luck with their puzzles... My megaminx moves wonderfully, and if I hadn't pushed so hard on my master cube, I wouldn't have broken it :-P It _was_ a pretty solid puzzle, but I was trying too hard without properly lubing it... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., rquethe <no_reply@y...> wrote: > So I buy a Professor's cube and then find out it is defective when I > get it. No problem, they say they'll replace it for free. So I get > my new professor's cube back and guess what? They sent me ANOTHER > defective cube. How incompetent is that. I'm extremely frustrated at > them.... > > > On another note, I have not even looked at a cube in over three > weeks. I'm pathetic... I'm not sure I remember how to solve the durn > things :)
730. Re: Calling all Fridrich'ers
From: "buddyleeboy" <buddyleeboy@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Aug 2002 18:37:53 -0000

Thank you for the help Jessica! Here are a few Q's: > do not sweat the cross. If you can do 3, do just three and then, as > you are inserting them, look for the fourth one. Thank you, this helps. Did it take you a lot of practice to be able to memorize your moves or was this natural for you? > Instead of memorizing the algs from my page, try to develop your own > algs and then learn only those that you are having problems with. I actually use algs from speedcubing.com. I'd use yours, but I'm not certain where, in the cube graphic, the cross is. And at first I was trying to memorize them outright, but there came a day when I was just unable to remember all the "memorization" and suddenly just started to turn sides. 8 out of 10 times I was correct... it was weird. Anyway, through memorization I realized a lot of key "reasons" for moves and just started doing them myself. > 1) There are two basic ways to bring a corner from the LL into the > 1st layer (OK, with the exception when the white is on the bottom): > the one that picks up a distant edge along the way and the one that > inserts the corner and the edge that is right behind it. When you say picking up a distant edge along the way, is this regardless of its orientation? Are you simply getting the two together so you can perform an algorithm? If so, does this mean the majority of the F2L algorithms on your page take place with the corner in the LL and the edge directly connected? > 2) In the beginning right after the cross, you can use even simpler > and shorter moves to insert the edges because you can use the fact > that no corner-edge pair is in place. Again, those simple 3-move > basic "algorithms" can do the job. Can do. > 3) Finally, when I finish the cross, I look at the last layer > searching for pairs of cubies. In most cases, there is at least one > pair already. Do that one and then repeat again. By "pair" do you mean that the corner-piece and the edge-piece are right next to each other? If so, are they correctly oriented? Or do you mean that the corner and its matching edge piece are simply somewhere, in some orientation, on the LL? >If you at some point do not see any pairs in the LL, you can do the following. Say, you > have a corner in the LL and the edge is somewhere in the middle in > some incorrect place. Then use the bottom layer to move the corner to > the edge (or down-left or down-right - I hope you know what I mean) I'm not sure I know what you mean. OK... you're holding a cube with the corner you want in upper-right. The edge piece is middle left. Are you saying I should move, say, R'D'F or something similar? Also, when you're "escaping" the corner and its edge from the bottom and/or middle layer into the LL, do you immediately restore the cross you broke to get it up there? Or do you wait until the pieces are together, for example? > You rarely, very rarely, need to remove a corner (or edge) in order > to proceed. I'm not sure what you mean by remove a corner. > 4) Go slowly. The system works best when you do not apply the algs > blindly but rather you try to minimize the number of moves, ignoring > the time for a while. Will this actually help me significantly? The way I imagine it would go, would be that I sit down for weeks and go slowly, trying to do few moves. Then when I actually tried to speed cube, my mind would just be racing and I wouldn't have the ability to think about those things. After doing few moves for a long time, does your brain recognize enough patterns from previous few-move-solves to cut your time down significantly in practice? Or is it like a guitar teacher telling you to sit "just so" in order to enhance your playing, when its effects are really negligible? Not that I doubt your advice, I just have always wondered what of the tips I've heard are just "good habits." > > I hope this helps. If you have any more questions, let me know. > I shall, and thank you. -Donnie P.S. How is your last name pronounced? Is it Fr-ih-drich, as in Rub-i-k or Fr-ee-drich as in Rubik's R-ee-venge? And same to you Lars!! Is it P-eh-trus as in pock-eh-t cube (ahh forget it) or P-ee-trus. Petr-oo-s or Petr-uh-s? > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "buddyleeboy" <buddyleeboy@y...> > wrote: > > > > I have to be the most impatient being on this planet. As some of > > you know I've been switching to Fridrich's method from Lars's in > the > > hopes that it will cut down my times. I've been at it for about 5 > > days and I still haven't hit 20s! (Just kidding... not that > > impatient.) I just timed myself and I seem to average about 1:10s > on > > the F2L using about 2/3 of the "all possible F2L" algs I've > memorized > > so far. I'm noticing a few problems that I hoped some of you could > > help with: > > > > _The Cross:_ > > > > Getting the cross is easy, but I can't seem to be able to examine > the > > cube and memorize all 7-10 moves needed to get to the cross. This > > means I'm constantly looking for the cubies I need, and turning the > > cube around in my hands which takes tons of time. > > > > _F2L:_ > > > > Here's how I do it: I pick a "corner area" (the space where a > corner > > piece should end up (ie Red-White-Green with white as the color of > > the cross)) and go hunt for the corner that fits it. I swing it > into > > its appropriate "column" on the cube (between the red and green > > faces.) Then I hunt for its corresponding edge-piece. If it's > already > > on the top layer, I do a "mental search query" for the correct > > algorithm and do it. If it's a position I don't know yet, I'll > morph > > the position to fit an alg I do know. > > However, if the edge-piece is in an incorrect "column" (ie > between > > blue and orange) I make exactly 3 moves to get it to the top layer. > > 1st move breaks the cross and gets the edge-piece up on the top > > layer. 2nd move moves the edge-piece out of the way. 3rd move > > restores the cross (The same goes if the corner piece is on the > > bottom layer between incorrect faces). Then I search for an > > algorithm, etc. > > > > _LL:_ > > > > Haven't even gotten started. I just practice F2L right now. > > > > I figure that the cross portion is just practice, with very few > > hints associated with it. If you have any, please let me know. But > > what really concerns me is F2L. Am I doing it the right way? Should > I > > JUST move the edge-piece to the top layer and then find an alg, > > restoring the cross at a later time? If someone could tell me what > is > > going on in their brain RIGHT after the cross is completed in the > > beginning and about to start F2L, it would help me a lot. > Especially > > from the master herself. Thanks! > > > > -Donnie
731. Cube stickers
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Aug 2002 18:58:31 -0000

Something I've noticed recently with my new cube is that the stickers
are already beginning to wear (getting white frayed bits around the
edge of the stickers where the colour has been worn). Is this because
of the particular brand of cube I bought? (it's got "Rubik's Cube" on
the centre white sticker) Or is it because of the silicon spray
(which may have seeped out)?

This is quite different to what I've seen with my old, but favourite,
cube which has been in use for so many years that I can't even
remember when I got it or where it came from. My old cube has never
been lubed and when the stickers wear, the corners of the stickers
just kinda snap off - it doesn't get the white frayed edges like my
new cube. What's going on? (BTW, these old stickers are thicker and
feel more plastic than the stickers on my new cube.)

I remember a while ago someone talking about different types of
stickers that can be found on cubes? Is this what they were talking
about?



732. Re: Cube stickers
From: "buddyleeboy" <buddyleeboy@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Aug 2002 21:01:34 -0000

Yah, the stickers seem to be the biggest problem with cubes today. When I get a brand new cube I wait maybe a week before replacing the stickers. You can replace the stickers either by ordering replacements off of Rubiks.com, which I don't recommend, or do what most do and get 6 different colors of vinyl electrical tape. I found all colors except orange from my local hardware store. However, I couldn't find Orange ANYWHERE!! I went to all the big name stores hardware stores and could only find half-an-inch wide orange tape. Well, let's just say my dad got lucky while on a short vacation in New Mexico, 3 states away. I hope you have better luck. Anyway, I just peel off an original sticker, and cut out a template out of cardboard or something slightly stiff. Then I start cuttin' out the stickers! It's lasted me about 6 months now and I've only replaced 3 since then. Great stuff... -Donnie --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Something I've noticed recently with my new cube is that the stickers > are already beginning to wear (getting white frayed bits around the > edge of the stickers where the colour has been worn). Is this because > of the particular brand of cube I bought? (it's got "Rubik's Cube" on > the centre white sticker) Or is it because of the silicon spray > (which may have seeped out)? > > This is quite different to what I've seen with my old, but favourite, > cube which has been in use for so many years that I can't even > remember when I got it or where it came from. My old cube has never > been lubed and when the stickers wear, the corners of the stickers > just kinda snap off - it doesn't get the white frayed edges like my > new cube. What's going on? (BTW, these old stickers are thicker and > feel more plastic than the stickers on my new cube.) > > I remember a while ago someone talking about different types of > stickers that can be found on cubes? Is this what they were talking > about?

735. Re: Calling all Fridrich'ers
From: "jessica_fridrich" <jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Aug 2002 02:34:23 -0000

> Thank you, this helps. Did it take you a lot of practice to be
able to
> memorize your moves or was this natural for you?

I never learned them all at once but I was memorizing them as I was
developing the system.

> When you say picking up a distant edge along the way, is this
> regardless of its orientation? Are you simply getting the two
together
> so you can perform an algorithm? If so, does this mean the
majority of
> the F2L algorithms on your page take place with the corner in the
LL
> and the edge directly connected?

I meant the algorithms No. 11 and 18 from my web page on the F2L.
The cross is opposite the yellow.

> By "pair" do you mean that the corner-piece and the edge-piece are
> right next to each other? If so, are they correctly oriented? Or
do
> you mean that the corner and its matching edge piece are simply
> somewhere, in some orientation, on the LL?

Anywhere in the LL.

> I'm not sure I know what you mean. OK... you're holding a cube
with
> the corner you want in upper-right. The edge piece is middle left.
Are
> you saying I should move, say, R'D'F or something similar?

F' D' F

> Also, when you're "escaping" the corner and its edge from the
bottom
> and/or middle layer into the LL, do you immediately restore the
cross
> you broke to get it up there? Or do you wait until the pieces are
> together, for example?

LL is up? Yes, I always put it back.

> > You rarely, very rarely, need to remove a corner (or edge) in
order
> > to proceed.
>
> I'm not sure what you mean by remove a corner.

Nothing is in the LL, all cubies are somewhere in the F2L but
incorrectly placed or positioned.

> > 4) Go slowly. The system works best when you do not apply the
> Will this actually help me significantly? The way I imagine it
would
> go, would be that I sit down for weeks and go slowly, trying to do
few
> moves. Then when I actually tried to speed cube, my mind would
just be
> racing and I wouldn't have the ability to think about those
things.
> After doing few moves for a long time, does your brain recognize
> enough patterns from previous few-move-solves to cut your time
down
> significantly in practice? Or is it like a guitar teacher telling
you
> to sit "just so" in order to enhance your playing, when its
effects
> are really negligible? Not that I doubt your advice, I just have
> always wondered what of the tips I've heard are just "good habits."

By going slowly, you will develop "economical" twisting rather than
speedy twisting that is inefficient. You will learn how to "see" the
cubies, how to register several of them at a brief glance, how to
predict where they will end up after you do certain short moves,
etc.

If you try to go too fast, you will be doing many more moves than
you really need. Trust me, the twisting speed is one of the less
important factors, actually. Ron, Dan, help me with this. Am I
telling a lie? :)

Good luck!

Jessica

P.S.: I responded to your Yahoo e-mail as well.

was just too afraid that he'd ask me questions about it.

746. I made a video
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Aug 2002 00:05:50 -0700

A weird thing happened today. I decided to finally set up the
camcorder and shoot a video of my solving, as I have been
procrastinating about for a year or so.

Long story short: To my amazement, I produced my personal best time
ever today, on camera! My previous 20+ year old record was 15.92 sec.
Today I did 14.87.

As any record, it's a lucky time, of course. Both Step 5 (1 chance in
6) and Step 6 (1 chance in 27) were solved when I came to the final
layer. It's not quite only luck, since I can choose from 1 of 2-4
final layer situations when I get to the end of step 4, but something
that only happens once in 50 solutions or so.

But it wasn't really an isolated random thing either. I have footage
of a 16.16 and a few 18-somethings, all done within 30 minutes or so.
Probably my best session ever. And with a cube that's decidedly less
that super smooth.

I made a Quicktime movie of the 14.87. It's 4.3MB, so I decided to
try to distribute it with Gnutella. The file name is "Lars Petrus
solves the cube in 14,87 sec.mov". Try to search for it on LimeWire
or some other Gnutella client, and see if you can grab it.

This is so weird. I *really* thought I was far too old and out of
practice for things like this...


--
"Nearly all men can stand adversity, but if you want to test a man's
character, give him power."
--- Abraham Lincoln

Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@... http://lar5.com

I found an old cube and found Lars's method first and that is what I
have learned. So over the past few days I've been wondering a
couple things...when you say it takes months to get low times, how
much practice is there each day? I just want to get to about a
minute or so...how much practice would be needed? Not in terms of

756. Crap!
From: rquethe <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 12:23:48 -0000

About a month ago I was working diligently on memorizing the
orientation cases. I addition to the 7 or so I had learned from
mastering the 3-look, I had probably memorized close to 15-20 more.
But then I went on vacation to my father's house and didn't bring a
cube or my notes. I did this mostly because I knew I'd be playing
computer games the whole time. This was a horrible mistake though as
I have forgotten all the orientation cases I had so previously worked
hard to remember. There is hope though. I think that even though I
forgot them, it should be easier to remember them the second time
through.

Since people are talking about videos, I may as well plug mine. It's
a 26 second video and you can download it at
http://homepages.spider.lu/liquid/26sec.wmv and be sure to tell me
what you think. At the very end I miss a trigger on the permutation
and waste about half a second. I also seem to take about 2 seconds
looking for my first corner/edge pair after completing the cross. I
find it difficult to look for it while I'm completely the cross. I
imagine this can be solved with some more practice though and slowing
myself down more. Anyway, ta ta for now...



757. Re: I made a video
From: rquethe <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 12:29:03 -0000

playing it with Windows Media Player and Quicktime but neither were
able to run it. The quicktime error that I received was that it
couldn't be opened because a software component needed by the movie
could not be found.



758. Re: Interesting problem
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 12:35:46 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "jessica_fridrich" <jess340@h...> wrote: > While solving the LL, I noticed one interesting position in the LL. > After a simple 4-move commutator B'U'BU, you get the same position > except on a different face - on B instead on U. I wonder what other > solutions there might be for this problem and how this problem could > be generalized. Ideas? > > Jessica I'm not sure I follow the question but there are some moves which will yield the same result if the cube is differently oriented, if that's what you mean (obviously the superflip is one and then the orientation doesn't matter). One such move is R'U'RL2U'R2B2R'L2U'R'UD2R'U2F2U'D2 which is a move I recently found on Cube Explorer 2.21 (looks like Windows has some advantages after all). This move can be done with the cube in 3 different orientations and has the same effect (basically, fix the position of DFL corner but then there are 3 ways to orient the cube). Lots of other such moves exist.

761. Re: Interesting problem
From: "jessica_fridrich" <jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 13:48:36 -0000

No, Richard, I meant something different. Say you have a three-cycle
of corners in the LL (say, it is the U side), and nothing else. You
do the commutator F U' F' U and the three-cycle of corners is now on
the F side rather than the U side (and nothing else has moved
otherwise). In other words, the commutator "transfers" the same
problem (corner three-cycle) to a different side.

Of course, three-cycle of corners is not the position that can have
this property.

Jessica

> I'm not sure I follow the question but there are some moves which
> will yield the same result if the cube is differently oriented, if
> that's what you mean (obviously the superflip is one and then the
> orientation doesn't matter).
> One such move is R'U'RL2U'R2B2R'L2U'R'UD2R'U2F2U'D2 which is a
move
> I recently found on Cube Explorer 2.21 (looks like Windows has
some
> advantages after all).
> This move can be done with the cube in 3 different orientations
and
> has the same effect (basically, fix the position of DFL corner but
> then there are 3 ways to orient the cube).
> Lots of other such moves exist.



762. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] I'm new here...
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 15:36:20 +0100

Hi: welcome to the group!

How often / long you would need to practise in order to improve will be
different from person to person, and will also depend on how you practise.
If all your "practise" is, is solving the cube again and again, you will not
improve as quickly as if you practise in a more strategic, intelligent
manner. Also, a key component to speedcubing is physical, so practising
every day is a big help for developing your muscular "memory".

Using finger-tricks on a well-lubricated cube makes a huge difference; if
you are not sure what I'm talking about check out Dan Kight's videos on his
web-page. If you're keen to get your speed down, I strongly recommend using
finger tricks from the start.

That said, I reckon if someone practises well for about 1.5 to 2 hrs a day,
five days a week, they could reach the 1 minute mark within ten weeks, and
maybe quite a bit sooner.

Good luck!

S.
PS get your friend to work on it too, nothing like some competition to give
you some incentive ...

>So, hi. I just started cubing a couple days ago when I read about a
>friend doing it in 4 minutes...I thought that was impossibly fast so
>I found an old cube and found Lars's method first and that is what I
>have learned. So over the past few days I've been wondering a
>couple things...when you say it takes months to get low times, how
>much practice is there each day? I just want to get to about a
>minute or so...how much practice would be needed? Not in terms of
>just days, but hours/day please :)
>
>Thanks,
>
>-Kighr
>

763. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Interesting problem
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 15:49:10 +0100

Jessica: can you give an algorithm that generates a cube-state such that
when you do F U' F' U the cube state is only different in that the patterns
have all shifted around the cube as a whole? (which is, I think, the start
of the question? Or am I off beam?). Presumably this is a ll
orientation/permutation alg. I suppose it is natural that someone would
only notice this doing the ll; if it happened on a less-solved cube you
probably wouldn't notice that the pattern had moved around the cube in such
a specific way.
S.


>
>No, Richard, I meant something different. Say you have a three-cycle
>of corners in the LL (say, it is the U side), and nothing else. You
>do the commutator F U' F' U and the three-cycle of corners is now on
>the F side rather than the U side (and nothing else has moved
>otherwise). In other words, the commutator "transfers" the same
>problem (corner three-cycle) to a different side.
>
>Of course, three-cycle of corners is not the position that can have
>this property.
>
>Jessica
>
> > I'm not sure I follow the question but there are some moves which
> > will yield the same result if the cube is differently oriented, if
> > that's what you mean (obviously the superflip is one and then the
> > orientation doesn't matter).
> > One such move is R'U'RL2U'R2B2R'L2U'R'UD2R'U2F2U'D2 which is a
>move
> > I recently found on Cube Explorer 2.21 (looks like Windows has
>some
> > advantages after all).
> > This move can be done with the cube in 3 different orientations
>and
> > has the same effect (basically, fix the position of DFL corner but
> > then there are 3 ways to orient the cube).
> > Lots of other such moves exist.

768. How Do You Get Vid's On the Computer?
From: eligeon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 17:07:10 -0000

I was wondering if anyone could tell me how they get their videos
on their pc?



769. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] How Do You Get Vid's On the Computer?
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 18:17:36 +0100

> I was wondering if anyone could tell me how they get their videos
> on their pc?


I'll tell you how I do it on my Mac at home...

I have a firewire camcorder. My Mac runs OSX and it has firewire ports.
iMovie is available for free. Simply plug the camera in, no drivers
necessary, let iMovie do the rest! You can edit and export to your hearts
content. Hell, I can even write DVD disks on my baby and they will play on
most domestic DVD players and nearly all computers with DVD ROM's and the
picture quality is like the original recording!

Can you describe the initial position (as in the sequence you'd need to do on a solved cube to get the position you intend). 771. Re: I made a video
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 18:35:41 +0100

Lars, I don't mean to split hairs here but, I make your solution to be 13.9
seconds! This is like how I time myself, I lose about a second just by
operating a wrist watch. So rather than find an easier way to time myself I
just deduct a second from what I see on my watch.

And although you say that you had some lucky stages on that attempt, I'll
bet you could have knocked a quarter of a second off at the pause near the
end. So, I'm really impressed with that little show off video :]

Also, I can't help thinking that your fingers seem quite long and slender.
Is this a favourable trait in the world of speed cubing? Do others that
average such low times consider themselves to have slender fingers? I have
long but chunky fingers so I sometimes get jammed against my own thumb when
trying slice moves :[



772. Re: How Do You Get Vid's On the Computer?
From: krrash <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 17:55:49 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., eligeon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I was wondering if anyone could tell me how they get their videos > on their pc? If you have a digital camcorder (one that has Firewire, a.k.a. IEEE 1394 plugs on it), you get a Fireware card for your PC to transfer the video to your PC. Such cards usually come with video editing software that you can use to trim the video down to the apppropriate length and convert to popular formats (like MPEG). If you have a non-digital camcorder, you need a video card with TV or NTSC (if you are in the US) input. Some video cards, like the ATI All In Wonder cards, come with TV input. I have an ASUS V7100 Deluxe Combo card that works ok for this. If you want to spend less, you can buy a cheaper card that works with your existing video card to add video input capabilities. One such card is the ATI TV Wonder. This type of card can probably be found for less than $50. Some of these cards come with personal video recorder (PVR) software so that you can use your PC sort of like a Tivo and record TV shows. Lastly, if you don't have a video camera at all, you can use a webcam. The quality won't be nearly as good.
773. God Gave The Speedcuber Two Hands......For a Reason!?
From: eligeon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 18:32:31 -0000

Recently, I was watching one of my speedcubing videos to see if I
could fix mistakes, learn algorithms, you know the works. Well as I
watched the video, I was amazed at the fact that I used both hands to
perform algorithms at blinding speeds. I could'nt even keep up with
the cubes changing directions. Does any expert or someone who has
fast times use two hands to twist the cube instead of finger tricks?
Just a question...



774. Re: God Gave The Speedcuber Two Hands......For a Reason!?
From: "gtregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 22:12:48 -0000

Let me preface what I say with this - I by no means would consider myself an expert (I'm still averaging over 30 seconds), but here's several thoughts: - I think some algorithms lend themselves more easily to be remembered and/or performed with two hands... - Use of two hands doesn't have to be a replacement for finger tricks... Use them together, see if that helps... - Be careful that you don't use two hands more than necessary... At least for me, when I shift the cube between hands, I know this slows the flow considerably... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., eligeon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Recently, I was watching one of my speedcubing videos to see if I > could fix mistakes, learn algorithms, you know the works. Well as I > watched the video, I was amazed at the fact that I used both hands to > perform algorithms at blinding speeds. I could'nt even keep up with > the cubes changing directions. Does any expert or someone who has > fast times use two hands to twist the cube instead of finger tricks? > Just a question...

780. tip for the CROSS
From: rknapton <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Aug 2002 23:17:17 -0000

ok. as a near sub-30 second cuber (never thought I'd make it this
far) here's a tip I've recently realize on forming the cross. (I
recently changed from the top to the bottom) If you think its going
to take a lot of moves... then completly change how you're going to
do it. start w/ what u were going to do last. even if you're 15
seconds of pre-inspect is up.. just change it and it seems to work
out much easier. this quote came to mind while writing this...
(have been drinkin again. uhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh)
"There is nothing like losing all you have in the world for teaching
you what not to do. And when you know what not to do in order not to
lose money, you begin to learn what to do in order to win. Did you
get that? You begin to learn!" ~ Reminiscences of a Stock Operator
by Edwin Lefevre

784. Re: we are back!!!
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Aug 2002 02:01:08 -0000

In little old Wisconsin I've been cubing for around 5 years, 3 of
them actually being able to solve. I was born in 83 so i missed it
all! I got into cubing because it was something that everyone just
kinda forgot about, and no one was able to solve one. The past two
years i spent showing off hoping to gain some competition but last
year was when things really took off. I started a club and taught
people to solve many puzzles. Now the cubing fad is back at high
school and even a neighboring high school i convinced a club to
start. Hopefully dueling between the two schools should create enough
of an uproar to bring in other schools. Well at least i can dream.
Since i graduated last year i am coming back to high school to start
up the group again and do some coaching before college starts. I
guess thats my bit of history and how i got wisconsin back into the
game. I bet we all have somewhat similar stories to tell but the
feeling to be in something before the fad hits certainly feels good,
if i am making sense anymore.
Sorry about the longness of my sobby story
Jake

787. Re: we are back!!!
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Aug 2002 02:35:44 -0000

I love stories like this. I'm always interested to hear how people got into speedcubing. Here's my story... I think I was about 4-5 yrs old when the cube craze first hit the world. The cube interested me at that pointed and I asked my parents if they would buy one for me. Although I was a reasonably bright 5 yr old, I found that the cube was really too hard for me at that age. The cube then spent the next 5 yrs at the back of the cupboard. I dug it out and got back into it when I was about 10 yrs old. At that age I was able to start to get an understanding of how it worked. Also, my hands were no longer too small to manipulate the cube properly!! I worked out F2L by myself, but LL was beyond me at that point so I studied other people's LL algorithms and within a few months I was regularing able to do it in 1.5 mins, with a PB of just under a minute. :) I'd be interested to hear what age's other people were when they started cubing? I've tried to encourage my friends to learn so we can race, but I think they (i) aren't sufficiently interested to put in the time and effort required, and (ii) are a bit daunted by seeing me do it in 1 min (slow by the standards of this group, but quite impressive to someone who can't even to 1 face). Re the WC bringing a cube revival down here... From my observations, Australians do tend to absorb a lot of American culture (I know Toronto is Canada but I talking generally in terms of the Nth American continent), but only through movies and TV shows. If everyone on Friends and Buffy started cubing then I'm sure it would make a comeback here!! Jasmine. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > In little old Wisconsin I've been cubing for around 5 years, 3 of > them actually being able to solve. I was born in 83 so i missed it > all! I got into cubing because it was something that everyone just > kinda forgot about, and no one was able to solve one. The past two > years i spent showing off hoping to gain some competition but last > year was when things really took off. I started a club and taught > people to solve many puzzles. Now the cubing fad is back at high > school and even a neighboring high school i convinced a club to > start. Hopefully dueling between the two schools should create enough > of an uproar to bring in other schools. Well at least i can dream. > Since i graduated last year i am coming back to high school to start > up the group again and do some coaching before college starts. I > guess thats my bit of history and how i got wisconsin back into the > game. I bet we all have somewhat similar stories to tell but the > feeling to be in something before the fad hits certainly feels good, > if i am making sense anymore. > Sorry about the longness of my sobby story > Jake
788. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Interesting problem
From: "jessica_fridrich" <jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Aug 2002 02:41:18 -0000

OK, the easiest thing will be to show the answer to the puzzle. Here is the position. Do U2F2U'R2U'R2UF2U'RUR'U'R' (thank you Herbert for this :)), look at the R face, and then notice that after you do the commutator BRB'R', you get the same position on the B face. Now, what other positions in the LL are so easily "transferable" to a different face using a short sequence of moves as that commutator? Jessica --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "simonl cube" <simonlcube@h...> wrote: > Jessica: can you give an algorithm that generates a cube-state such that > when you do F U' F' U the cube state is only different in that the patterns > have all shifted around the cube as a whole? (which is, I think, the start > of the question? Or am I off beam?). Presumably this is a ll > orientation/permutation alg. I suppose it is natural that someone would > only notice this doing the ll; if it happened on a less-solved cube you > probably wouldn't notice that the pattern had moved around the cube in such > a specific way. > S. > > > > > >No, Richard, I meant something different. Say you have a three- cycle > >of corners in the LL (say, it is the U side), and nothing else. You > >do the commutator F U' F' U and the three-cycle of corners is now on > >the F side rather than the U side (and nothing else has moved > >otherwise). In other words, the commutator "transfers" the same > >problem (corner three-cycle) to a different side. > > > >Of course, three-cycle of corners is not the position that can have > >this property. > > > >Jessica > > > > > I'm not sure I follow the question but there are some moves which > > > will yield the same result if the cube is differently oriented, if > > > that's what you mean (obviously the superflip is one and then the > > > orientation doesn't matter). > > > One such move is R'U'RL2U'R2B2R'L2U'R'UD2R'U2F2U'D2 which is a > >move > > > I recently found on Cube Explorer 2.21 (looks like Windows has > >some > > > advantages after all). > > > This move can be done with the cube in 3 different orientations > >and > > > has the same effect (basically, fix the position of DFL corner but > > > then there are 3 ways to orient the cube). > > > Lots of other such moves exist. > > > > > > > _________________________________________________________________ > MSN Photos is the easiest way to share and print your photos: > http://photos.msn.com/support/worldwide.aspx
789. corners first method......
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Aug 2002 02:46:57 -0000

this is for those of you who are a little experienced with corners
frist methods. Which of these would be better (faster)...

#1). To orient all corners first, then permute them all in one
alg.

#2). To orient and permute 4 corners (lets say white), then
orient the yellow corners then permute them?



i've been playing around with corners first for a couple days, I
don't have any plans to really speed cube with it though. It would
just be nice to get it under a minute once or twice......(using the
first situation, using notes 62 seconds is my fastest :D )

-Heath

792. Jiminy Cricket...
From: "buddyleeboy" <buddyleeboy@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Aug 2002 05:28:10 -0000


So, I've been using this same cube for nearly a year now and it
has treated me a well. But I've noticed that it starts "chirping"
much like the chirps one hears late at night trying to memorize the
orientation cases. Has anyone else noticed this? It's definitely
something to do with the spring mechanism. Sometimes when I do
my "ultra-lube" sessions where I take it all apart, wash it, dry the
pieces, lube each piece, dry it, put it together and play with it for
a few days acheiving ultimate lub-ed-ness, the chirping stops. Then
after about a month when the lube starts to fade, the chirping comes
back. If any of you have noticed this, let me know. Is there any way
to fix it? Am I using a weird cube? (I use one I bought from Toys R'
Us in USA. I don't know if it's the same as the Oddzon. The Rubik's
Cube logo on the white face has color, and the picture I've seen of
Oddzon's cube logo is just black and white.) Any thoughts?

-Donnie

798. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] corners first method......
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Aug 2002 22:04:14 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "DanG" <dgosbee@s...> wrote: > it all depends on what works best for a persons hands.... > > > while each of your corners forst methods involves a certain number of moves, it all depends on how FAST you can execute those moves which determine which is a faster way of acheiving the corners.. > > danG > ----- Original Message ----- > From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@y... > Sent: Tuesday, August 06, 2002 10:46 PM > Subject: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] corners first method...... > > > this is for those of you who are a little experienced with corners > frist methods. Which of these would be better (faster)... > > #1). To orient all corners first, then permute them all in one > alg. > > #2). To orient and permute 4 corners (lets say white), then > orient the yellow corners then permute them? > > > > i've been playing around with corners first for a couple days, I > don't have any plans to really speed cube with it though. It would > just be nice to get it under a minute once or twice......(using the > first situation, using notes 62 seconds is my fastest :D ) > > -Heath > > I figured so. I think that I like the first way better. I didnt like it at first because it uses new algs for me, but after working on them a little bit I found they were pretty simple to learn (as are pretty much all of the algs for the whole corners first method im trying out). I don't think im really cut out for a corners first method though, because of all the slice moves you use. Im not all that great with slice moves :( ........ I did manage to break a minute with the corners first method...without notes even!...54 seconds....i think im going to learn the rest of my algs for the 2 look LL for my speedcuing, then go into a little more detail with the corners first :) -Heath
799. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] corners first method......

Totally different. Hey, I did an average w/ the corners first method and it turned out to be 61.4 seconds..with a pb of 51. I still dont know a few of the algs that go along with it, so sometimes i have to do a step or two twice :)...i'd say thats not too awful bad for seeing the method for the first time 2 days ago! -Heath

803. Finally got it downloaded!!
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Aug 2002 11:09:19 -0000

I've been trying to download Lars' video for the last few days using
different URLs, different browsers, different computers and different
applications but without much luck... until now! Now I can finally
see it for myself!

Lars, while watching the clip I noticed that you just use the ends of
your fingers when speedcubing. I realised that I hold and twist the
cube differently. Much more of my palm comes into contact with the
cube when I'm solving, especially the part of my palm near my thumb.
For example, when turning the right hand slice with my right hand my
my thumb and the bit of palm it's connected to is kinda sitting along
the edge of the right column of the front face. Basically, my
hands 'hug' (can't think of a better word at the moment) the cube
more closely.

I'm thinking that this is slowing down my times because it means I
have to change hand positions quite frequently, and it's also making
it hard for me to learn finger tricks 'cos my hands aren't used to
just using the ends of my fingers.

I shall have to experiment with this. My hands are much smaller which
might make it difficult but I'm curious to see if changing techniques
will (by itself) have a noticeable difference on my times.



804. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Finally got it downloaded!!
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Aug 2002 12:51:53 +0100


>My hands are much smaller which
>might make it difficult but I'm curious to see if changing techniques
>will (by itself) have a noticeable difference on my times.


I wonder ... would we get faster times, and better records, with a cube that
was slightly smaller? My cube is 55x55x55mm: is that standard? Has anyone
made a cube that is 50x50x50, or even 45x45x45? Would they be better for
finger tricks?
S.

805. Quotes
From: ilovemycube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Aug 2002 14:21:03 -0000

Hi friendz,

I am back from a great vacation, and all new records have been
updated.
Welcome to all new members. This forum has been very busy lately, so
I had to read a lot of new messages. Great!

Here are some holiday quotes:
I was solving different puzzles at the pool side to get used to
people watching me while solving. And indeed many people are
interested and watch you. The younger kids are amazed about the
cube: "Wow, it moves!", "What a nice colorful toy!", "What can you do
with that block?". The grown-ups: "Does that stupid thing still
exist?", "Man, you are old-fashioned", "Are you some kind of
exhibitionist?", "Doesn't that thing make you nervous? You should
relax here!", "Can you solve it?" (this one was after I had solved
cubes for 30 minutes).
I was solving the 5x5x5, and did a reasonable 4 minutes or so, then
this wise guy came and said: "Pfff, you are slow! I could do that one
in 1 minute each time". I took my 3x3x3 and said: "I think you meant
this one. But since you are that fast, I will scramble it, and see
how fast you really are.". He walked away saying that he forgot all
his tricks. Later he came back to try the 5x5x5, but he came nowhere
close to solving one side.

Btw. they had the tiled Chinese 3x3x3 cubes in some kind of surprise
gumball machine. Price was $1.

Have fun! See you all in the chatroom during the weekends.

Ron
http://www.speedcubing.com

them, and how much practice they put into it? Thanks guys, you have
helped me get my times from 2 minutes to 45 seconds. Thanks for all
the help!

-Luke

811. magic numbers
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Aug 2002 03:55:31 -0000

I've read that the magic number for the 3x3 is 22 least possible
turns to solve the cube. I was wondering if you guys new the numbers
for a 2x2 4x4 and 5x5?

Jake



812. Re: magic numbers
From: "buddyleeboy" <buddyleeboy@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Aug 2002 05:16:38 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I've read that the magic number for the 3x3 is 22 least possible > turns to solve the cube. I was wondering if you guys new the numbers > for a 2x2 4x4 and 5x5? > > Jake All I know is that the 2x2x2's "God's solution" is 11 moves long in its worst mixed-ness. Don't know about the others. -Donnie
813. Re: magic numbers
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Aug 2002 07:08:36 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I've read that the magic number for the 3x3 is 22 least possible > turns to solve the cube. I was wondering if you guys new the numbers > for a 2x2 4x4 and 5x5? > > Jake Well, it all depends on the metric you use. For the 2x2x2 with quarter turn metric it is 14. With half turn metric it is 11. It isn't actually known for the 3x3x3 - there are just suspicions and known bounds but the exact figure isn't known. Upper bounds should be easy enough to calculate for any cube and some lower bounds too but the intervals may be large. The fact that the cubes of size >3 don't form a group (at least in terms of identifying positions that look the same - you'd have to mark the centres in some way to rectify this) probably makes the analysis harder.

I decided to finally set up the > camcorder and shoot a video of my solving, as I have been > procrastinating about for a year or so. > > Long story short: To my amazement, I produced my personal best time > ever today, on camera! My previous 20+ year old record was 15.92 sec. > Today I did 14.87. > > As any record, it's a lucky time, of course. Both Step 5 (1 chance in > 6) and Step 6 (1 chance in 27) were solved when I came to the final > layer. It's not quite only luck, since I can choose from 1 of 2-4 > final layer situations when I get to the end of step 4, but something > that only happens once in 50 solutions or so. > > But it wasn't really an isolated random thing either. I have footage > of a 16.16 and a few 18-somethings, all done within 30 minutes or so. > Probably my best session ever. 823. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Interesting problem
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 10 Aug 2002 18:11:51 +0100


>OK, the easiest thing will be to show the answer to the puzzle. Here
>is the position. Do
>
>U2F2U'R2U'R2UF2U'RUR'U'R' (thank you Herbert for this :)),
>
>look at the R face, and then notice that after you do the commutator
>BRB'R', you get the same position on the B face.
>
>Now, what other positions in the LL are so easily "transferable" to
>a different face using a short sequence of moves as that commutator?
>

OK I have had a look, it seems that there is just one other (L'U'LU), but
this is only the trivial reflection of the position you have already given.

There are only 4 2-move commutators (any other can be expressed as one of
these plus an initial cube rotation):
1) + 2): LUL'U' and L'U'LU
3) + 4): LU'L'U and L'ULU'

Commutators 1) and, effectively, 2) are solved. (In fact I have presumed 2)
works without testing it, but surely yes.)

You can prove that the LU'L'U/L'ULU' pair is not possible, because:
(a) the commutator only affects three edges (a corner, and the three
corner/edge pairs that radiate from it), and
(b) by restricting the pattern to the ll you need to have one of the three
affected corner/edge pairs solved before performing the commutator, and a
different corner/edge pair (target corner/edge pair) solved after running
the commutator, and
(c) you have no choice over which of the three available corner/edge pairs
the target corner/edge pair needs to be: the corner of this corner/edge pair
has to be the one from the very centre of the 3 affected faces, because with
any of the others three corners it, together with its matching edge, are not
touching each other and so split between two faces: this results in three
unsolved edge/pairs, thus breaking out of the ll, BUT:
if you do use this central corner and its edge, the two remaining edges get
flipped by the commutator, resulting in a different cube pattern.

So it seems to me that it cannot be done. Now I just *know* someone is
going to prove me wrong!
S.

_________________________________________________________________
MSN Photos is the easiest way to share and print your photos:
http://photos.msn.com/support/worldwide.aspx

for a great site!! Not only does he have a great collection of

you use, and if that has made a difference for you!

repeatedly, when I look down at my last mix-up ready to go and there
it is: a perfectly formed cross after about.. oh, 20 moves of mixing!
It got me wondering what kind of lucky instances some of you out
there have had. Especially from the elites. Anything memorable?

834. Re: Unimpressed with Meffert's Puzzles...
From: "cubesforfun" <tallgemini@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 10 Aug 2002 22:19:01 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "gtregay" <Grant@T...> wrote: > I've had a couple problems with them myself... Bought an assembly > cube that was broken when it came (and the piece wasn't in the box, > so it must have been broken when they sent it)... So I asked for a > replacement piece (it was the center part that holds all the face > centers on)... Guess what - when they sent it, the replacement was > also broken... > > Oh, well... Aside from the assembly cube, I've had good luck with > their puzzles... My megaminx moves wonderfully, and if I hadn't > pushed so hard on my master cube, I wouldn't have broken it :-P It > _was_ a pretty solid puzzle, but I was trying too hard without > properly lubing it... > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., rquethe <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > So I buy a Professor's cube and then find out it is defective when > I > > get it. No problem, they say they'll replace it for free. So I get > > my new professor's cube back and guess what? They sent me ANOTHER > > defective cube. How incompetent is that. I'm extremely frustrated > at > > them.... > > > > > > On another note, I have not even looked at a cube in over three > > weeks. I'm pathetic... I'm not sure I remember how to solve the > durn > > things :) I recently bought a meffert cube because I wanted a cube with tiles instead of stickers that was reasonably smooth turning. The cube was very easy to turn out of the box, but after about 30 solutions, became much too loose (without lubing). The cube now overturns, which is impossible to compensate for since there is no spring action. See David Knight's page for more info in this regard: http://benjerry.middlebury.edu/~knights/Cube/CubeInfo1.html#whereget My best time on that cube was about 3min30sec; when I realized that it would be very difficult to progress on that cube, I started buying rubiks.com cubes, which were easy to break in and have very nice spring action. Of course, there are the stickers, but I may follow Knight's advise and just transfer the tiles from the meffert cube to the rubik.com cube. I've yet to lube the cubes but have seen my average 10 rep time go down to 2min06sec, with a non-cheat personal best of 1min44sec using the rubiks.com "new solution". After i reach 1:30, I will start learning faster algorithms like the ll and/or f2l. Wish me luck and happy cubing!
835. Re: Unimpressed with Meffert's Puzzles...
From: "gtregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Aug 2002 02:08:05 -0000

Yeah - the assembly cubes do move very nicely from the start, but they tend to be too unforgiving, making any real speed difficult (especially finger tricks)... I've also experienced the overturning you mentioned; very difficult to work with... Regarding tiles vs. stickers, you can actually buy a set of tiles from Mefferts for $2 or $3 (I don't remember how much, off hand)... They don't have an actual item in their store (at least didn't before), but if you contact them, they can give you instructions on purchasing a set of tiles (if they get back to you - I'm currently waiting for an e-mail response from them on another issue)... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "cubesforfun" <tallgemini@y...> wrote: > I recently bought a meffert cube because I wanted a cube with > tiles instead of stickers that was reasonably smooth turning. > ... > ... > My best time on that cube was about 3min30sec; when I realized that > it > would be very difficult to progress on that cube, I started buying > rubiks.com cubes, which were easy to break in and have very nice > spring action. > Of course, there are the stickers, but I may follow Knight's advise > and just > transfer the tiles from the meffert cube to the rubik.com cube.
836. Re: ...be a lady tonight..
From: "gtregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Aug 2002 02:10:20 -0000

There was a time when I must have been using mostly half turns to mix my cube, because I would frequently mix for several minutes, and then end up with a cube that had no more than 5 steps required to be solved... I've started being much more deliberate in my mixing to assure that it is well mixed... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "buddyleeboy" <buddyleeboy@y...> wrote: > > Weird... here I am at work doing who knows what for whatever > reason for a small amount of money, mixing my cube and solving it > repeatedly, when I look down at my last mix-up ready to go and there > it is: a perfectly formed cross after about.. oh, 20 moves of mixing! > It got me wondering what kind of lucky instances some of you out > there have had. Especially from the elites. Anything memorable? > > -Donnie
837. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Unimpressed with Meffert's Puzzles...
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 11 Aug 2002 03:12:29 +0100

>
> See David Knight's page for
> more info in this regard:
> http://benjerry.middlebury.edu/~knights/Cube/CubeInfo1.html#whereget
>

You mean Dan!

839. I need help with corner orientation
From: "theboywholived81" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Aug 2002 15:59:48 -0000

I'm trying to learn more algorithms for the bottom layer, because I
only know three for the bottom corner orientation. I can solve it
with only these two, but it's harder. I'm doing it Lars Petrus' way,
so the edges are already correctly oriented.
I especially need help with the position where there are two correct
corners, and they are diagonally across from each other, so it forms
a diagonal line. The other's I need help with are the one with two
correct corners that are adjacent to each other.



840. Re: I need help with corner orientation
From: eligeon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Aug 2002 16:41:34 -0000

Hey! I used to have the same problem you did, trust me. Now, you
can fix this two ways. One, learn the algorithms so that you can put
the corners in correct place first. But, trust me it isn't worth
it. Now I expect you are into speedcubing ¿correct? Well, learn to
get the whole bottom one color (skipping the fixing of the corners
part) and memorize the 21 possible algorithms. 21 may seem like a
lot but its not that hard believe it or not. If you do lars method
you already know three of them. Plus, if you want visuals of how to
do all of them go here:
http://www.geocities.com/eligeon/permutations.html
It is worth it! Since doing this, my times have gone from
1:20 to 40!!!

From: "theboywholived81" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Aug 2002 16:50:07 -0000

I am into speedcubing, yes. My best time is already at forty three seconds, so with these, I might be able to get into the thirties! Thanks. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., eligeon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey! I used to have the same problem you did, trust me. Now, you > can fix this two ways. One, learn the algorithms so that you can put > the corners in correct place first. But, trust me it isn't worth > it. Now I expect you are into speedcubing ¿correct? Well, learn to > get the whole bottom one color (skipping the fixing of the corners > part) and memorize the 21 possible algorithms. 21 may seem like a > lot but its not that hard believe it or not. If you do lars method > you already know three of them. Plus, if you want visuals of how to > do all of them go here: > http://www.geocities.com/eligeon/permutations.html > It is worth it! Since doing this, my times have gone from > 1:20 to 40!!!
842. Re: I need help with corner orientation
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Aug 2002 16:52:39 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "theboywholived81" <theboywholived81@y...> wrote: > I'm trying to learn more algorithms for the bottom layer, because I > only know three for the bottom corner orientation. I can solve it > with only these two, but it's harder. I'm doing it Lars Petrus' way, > so the edges are already correctly oriented. > I especially need help with the position where there are two correct > corners, and they are diagonally across from each other, so it forms > a diagonal line. The other's I need help with are the one with two > correct corners that are adjacent to each other. I actually know some of these for once! R'F'L'FRF'LF can be used for 2 diagonally opposite (with the common colour on the B face (for the UBR corner) and the L face (for the UFL corner). R'F'LFRF'L'F can be used for 2 adjacent (with the common colour on opposite faces) (the B and F faces) R2D'RU2R'DRU2R can be used for 2 adjacent (with the common colour on the same face) (the B face) Alternatively you can use the move that you use to twist 3 corners more than once: I make it that you'd need to use it 3 times. The first time you need to twist two of the correct corners and one of the others (*) (a bit of experimentation will let you see which; basically you need to finish up needing to twist 4 corners). Then there'll be 4 corners needing twisting 2 of each type. Twist both of the type that was twisted (*) and one of the others. That should leave you with 3 corners left to twist, if my calculations are correct. Here's a summary: Number of twists needed: 2 1 0 0 (the 2 and 1 need not be adjacent in the real cube) Twist the corners indicated: 1 0 1 1 To leave: 1 1 2 2 Twist the corners indicated: 1 0 1 1 To leave: 0 1 1 1 Twist the corners indicated: 0 1 1 1 To leave: 0 0 0 0 Now you should be done.
843. Re: I need help with corner orientation
From: "theboywholived81" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Aug 2002 17:10:45 -0000

But when I do those, it switches two corners positions, but I position the corners first and then orient them, so those ones won't work for me. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "theboywholived81" > <theboywholived81@y...> wrote: > > I'm trying to learn more algorithms for the bottom layer, because > I > > only know three for the bottom corner orientation. I can solve it > > with only these two, but it's harder. I'm doing it Lars Petrus' > way, > > so the edges are already correctly oriented. > > I especially need help with the position where there are two > correct > > corners, and they are diagonally across from each other, so it > forms > > a diagonal line. The other's I need help with are the one with two > > correct corners that are adjacent to each other. > > I actually know some of these for once! > > R'F'L'FRF'LF can be used for 2 diagonally opposite (with the common > colour on the B face (for the UBR corner) and the L face (for the > UFL corner). > > R'F'LFRF'L'F can be used for 2 adjacent (with the common colour on > opposite faces) (the B and F faces) > > R2D'RU2R'DRU2R can be used for 2 adjacent (with the common colour on > the same face) (the B face) > > Alternatively you can use the move that you use to twist 3 corners > more than once: > > I make it that you'd need to use it 3 times. > > The first time you need to twist two of the correct corners and one > of the others (*) (a bit of experimentation will let you see which; > basically you need to finish up needing to twist 4 corners). > Then there'll be 4 corners needing twisting 2 of each type. Twist > both of the type that was twisted (*) and one of the others. > That should leave you with 3 corners left to twist, if my > calculations are correct. > > Here's a summary: > > Number of twists needed: > 2 1 0 0 (the 2 and 1 need not be adjacent in the real cube) > Twist the corners indicated: > 1 0 1 1 > To leave: > 1 1 2 2 > Twist the corners indicated: > 1 0 1 1 > To leave: > 0 1 1 1 > Twist the corners indicated: > 0 1 1 1 > To leave: > 0 0 0 0 > Now you should be done.
844. Hey everyone
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Aug 2002 17:26:45 -0000

Hey everyone, I haven't posted in a while, or updated my pages in
forever :), so I figured I'd let everyone know what was going on.
For the past six months my right wrist has been hurting during and
after I do the cube. It usually starts to get pretty uncomfortable
after the first solve or two and the discomfort usually starts to
turn into twinges of pain after twenty minutes or more. So obviously
I don't really have the capabilities to practice like I used to. I
practice enough to make sure I don't forget the algorithms and to
prevent me slowing down too much, but I've had to almost completely
give it up. I solve it for maybe 10 or 20 minutes a week. So anyway
I've picked up a new obsession since I can't pursue the cube as
much. I'm as addicted to chess now as I was when I first started the
cube, so I'm not lacking in the whole mental masochism area :) But I
just wanted to let everyone know that because I'm starting college
soon and am going to pursue that with all my energy, and because I
can't hardly cube anymore, realisicly I'm probably not going to
update my pages for a while. Ron has control of the records page to
do with as he wants now so if anyone has any questions or concerns
he's the one to talk to. If the world championships happen I would
love to go and compete, pain or not I want to be there. So hopefully
I'll see some of you guys in the next year. I made Ron a moderator
of the group so if there are any problems or concerns about the group
(moving it, changing it) talk to Ron. So anyway I hope everyone is
doing all right. I'll check out the club every now and then and post
from time to time but I'm probably not going to be around much.

Later,
Chris
