849. Re: Blindfold Cubing: Help me!
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Aug 2002 12:58:06 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., eligeon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I was wondering if someone could help me make sense of this > certain part of blindfold cubing. What do they mean when they say > finding the priority of the edges? I mean, how do you tell the > difference between 0 (good) and 1 (not good)? Not sure which technique you are using. If you are reading it from my page it works like this: the U & D faces have highest priority and the R & L faces have least priority (so the F & B faces have middle priority). Now every edge has colours from two faces and the colours are from different faces which are not opposite (so one colour of the edge will have higher priority than the other). For instance, the UF edge has a high priority colour (corresponding to the colour of the U face) and a middle priority colour corresponding to the colour of the F face. Each edge lies in 2 faces. These faces also have different priorities, one higher than the other. If the higher priority colour lies in the higher priority face then the edge has good orientation (0). Otherwise it has bad orientation (1). So if the UF edge is in the BR position it has orientation 0 if the U colour is on the B face (because U is the higher priority of U and F and B is the higher priority of B and R) and has orientation 1 if the U colour is on the R face. Similarly if the BL edge is in the DR position it will have orientation 0 if the B colour is on the D face and orientation 1 if the B colour is on the R face. Whenever the the U or D colour of an edge is in the R or L face that edge has orientation 1. Whenever the R or L colour of an edge is in the U or D face that edge has orientation 1. Whenever the the U or D colour of an edge is in the U or D face that edge has orientation 0. Whenever the R or L colour of an edge is in the R or L face that edge has orientation 0. This is a good reason to always choose the same colours as the U face and the F face which is something I virtually always do) - I use white and green respectively - as it saves a lot of thought in figuring out the orientation of each piece. The total number of edges of orientation 0 (or equivalently of orientation 1) should be even. If it's not you have to dismantle the cube to solve it. If someone has tampered with the cube it is possible to detect this and go ahead and solve it anyway and at the last moment take out an edge and flip it (or twist an edge or whatever needs to be done) before putting the cube down and removing the blindfold. This should amaze the tamperer yet further. Hope this helps. If not I can try to make the post less confusing.

857. Re: Another luck happenstance..

858. a little advice...
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 00:40:54 -0000

Lars Petrus would probably be one of the best helps here...

Im putting together all the cases/algs for my F2l...as most of you
know I use a modified Petrus method...(Petrus/Fridrich hybrid)...

when expanding to the 2x2x3, what I do is do that first corner/edge
pair, then do the first layer edge. Well, I got all the possible
cases for corner edge pairs figured out with algs..(this doesnt
include when pieces are in either the wrong slot on the middle layer,
or wrong slot on the first layer)...I came up with 37 cases. The
reason there are more cases for mine VS the Fridrich f2l (22) is
because the reflections can't always be performed as reflected
algs.

and well my quetion is, it worth it to learn the alg. to put my
corner edge pair in, AND then learn another alg for the same corner
edge pair that would preserve next first layer edge if it happened to
be in place....the algs that preserve the edge are 1 or 2 moves
longer than the one that wouldnt preserve the edge. So what should i
do...

1. learn 2 algs for the same case, 1 to preserve the edge, and
another thats a couple moves shorter that doesnt preserve the edge...
(on some of the cases the shorter alg, does preserve the edge, so i
wouldn't have to learn 2 algs for ALL the cases)...

2. just learn the shorter alg. and dont worry about preserving the
edge...then use another 3 or 4 moves for the edge...

3. Learn just the algs that preserve the edge for each case...these
will be a couple moves longer...


then im going to be in the same deal for my next corner edge
pair...which on most im going to have to use different algs than the
37 that i already went through (this one having about 37 algs
too) ...THEN theres going to be the 22 algs for the final corner edge
pari...phew..

that is alot of algs for just the f2l, but they are more like
intuition ya know...and i think quite a bit of them are going to be
the same alg. the different corner/edge pairs...


well, what do you guys think??

thanks

-Heath



859. Permutations
From: "moditha" <moditha@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 01:10:32 -0000

Hi

I can complete the cube trying about 1.30 mins. Now I am learning to
speed things up. So I found some resources on the net.

This is the site I am currently refering to.

http://www.ssie.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/permute.html

This page has permutations for the last layer.

Now the problem is, when I match the pattern and try to apply the
algorithm the whole cube gets screwed up. ( for example If I want to
move the last layer 3 middle cubes clock wise I use the algorithm
R²U Fs R²Bs U R² = R²U FB' R²BF' U R² )

now once I moved that I can nicely jumbled my cube :(

What am I doing wrong here ?

When I do the move I turn the cube so the last layer is the top layer.

please help!!!

Also some notations like

R' F R Ba' R Fs R F'R'B2 (U3) <-- U3 isn't it the same as
turning upper layer 3 times clockwise ?

Rgds
moditha




860. Re: Permutations
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 01:40:56 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "moditha" <moditha@y...> wrote: > Hi > > I can complete the cube trying about 1.30 mins. Now I am learning to > speed things up. So I found some resources on the net. > > This is the site I am currently refering to. > > http://www.ssie.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/permute.html > > This page has permutations for the last layer. > > Now the problem is, when I match the pattern and try to apply the > algorithm the whole cube gets screwed up. ( for example If I want to > move the last layer 3 middle cubes clock wise I use the algorithm > R²U Fs R²Bs U R² = R²U FB' R²BF' U R² ) > > now once I moved that I can nicely jumbled my cube :( > > What am I doing wrong here ? > > When I do the move I turn the cube so the last layer is the top layer. > > please help!!! > > Also some notations like > > R' F R Ba' R Fs R F'R'B2 (U3) <-- U3 isn't it the same as > turning upper layer 3 times clockwise ? > > Rgds > moditha well if only that one layer was messed up, then its because your not holding it right, but since the whole cube is messed up then your turning something wrong....tripple check that your turning stuff the right direction, and just to make sure, F= front, B= back, R=right, L= left , D= down (bottom layer) and U= up (top layer)..... hope that helps... ps....man it seems like every messes up the algs when they start out...I know I did at first, and its the same with some people i've helped figure it out....so your NOT alone..haha -Heath
861. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] a little advice...
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Aug 2002 19:32:29 -0700

I don't get the scenario. Does "expanding to the 2x2x3" mean "expanding FROM the 2x2x3"? What is "that" pair? As for what algs to learn, my philosophy is to start with the most common ones. Or more precisely the ones that will earn you the most number of moves on average. One that would save you 10 moves 1% of the time is less important than one that saves you 3 moves10% of the time. Then move down into more and more obscure ones as time permits. It will be a case of more and more diminishing returns. Which of 1, 2 or 3 to pick depends entirely on the frequence of each case, and how much you gain by learning each one. /Lars At 12:40 AM +0000 8/13/02, addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube wrote: >Lars Petrus would probably be one of the best helps here... > >Im putting together all the cases/algs for my F2l...as most of you >know I use a modified Petrus method...(Petrus/Fridrich hybrid)... > >when expanding to the 2x2x3, what I do is do that first corner/edge >pair, then do the first layer edge. Well, I got all the possible >cases for corner edge pairs figured out with algs..(this doesnt >include when pieces are in either the wrong slot on the middle layer, >or wrong slot on the first layer)...I came up with 37 cases. The >reason there are more cases for mine VS the Fridrich f2l (22) is >because the reflections can't always be performed as reflected >algs. > >and well my quetion is, it worth it to learn the alg. to put my >corner edge pair in, AND then learn another alg for the same corner >edge pair that would preserve next first layer edge if it happened to >be in place....the algs that preserve the edge are 1 or 2 moves >longer than the one that wouldnt preserve the edge. So what should i >do... > >1. learn 2 algs for the same case, 1 to preserve the edge, and >another thats a couple moves shorter that doesnt preserve the edge... >(on some of the cases the shorter alg, does preserve the edge, so i >wouldn't have to learn 2 algs for ALL the cases)... > >2. just learn the shorter alg. and dont worry about preserving the >edge...then use another 3 or 4 moves for the edge... > >3. Learn just the algs that preserve the edge for each case...these >will be a couple moves longer... > > >then im going to be in the same deal for my next corner edge >pair...which on most im going to have to use different algs than the >37 that i already went through (this one having about 37 algs >too) ...THEN theres going to be the 22 algs for the final corner edge >pari...phew.. > >that is alot of algs for just the f2l, but they are more like >intuition ya know...and i think quite a bit of them are going to be >the same alg. the different corner/edge pairs... > > >well, what do you guys think?? > >thanks > >-Heath > >To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: >speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > > >Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the ><http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/>Yahoo! Terms of Service. -- "They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever flipped it over?" Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@... http://lar5.com [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

863. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] a little advice...
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 02:49:37 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Lars Petrus <lars@l...> wrote: > I don't get the scenario. Does "expanding to the 2x2x3" mean > "expanding FROM the 2x2x3"? What is "that" pair? > > As for what algs to learn, my philosophy is to start with the most > common ones. Or more precisely the ones that will earn you the most > number of moves on average. One that would save you 10 moves 1% of > the time is less important than one that saves you 3 moves10% of the > time. Then move down into more and more obscure ones as time permits. > It will be a case of more and more diminishing returns. > > Which of 1, 2 or 3 to pick depends entirely on the frequence of each > case, and how much you gain by learning each one. > > /Lars > I dont mean expanding from the 2x2x3, im talking about that first corner edge pair right after the 2x2x2 corner is made.....its like on your site, you say it took you months to figure out the little simple moves, acutally someone you taught showed them to you....i think we're talkin about the same moves for that first pair. for me expanding to the 2x2x3 block is adding a corner edge pair + a top layer edge....(i do the f2l on the top two layers, and i always go around the cube to the right...by going around the cube, i mean that first corner/edge pair is to the right of my 2x2x2 corner, and then my next thing to place is to the right of that..... i go like this.. 2x2x2 corner, corner/edge pair, top edge, corner/edge pair, last top edge, last corner/edge pair... so you suggest not doing either 1, 2 or 3 but to do each case differently by how much it will gain me? thanks -Heath
864. Re: Permutations
From: "theboywholived81" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 04:08:02 -0000

Well, I don't know what you're doing wrong, but what you can do instead to turn the pieces clockwise is this algorithm: R2 T L' R F2 R' L B2 T R2 That turns the bottom layer. Hope that will help for you, if the other one doesn't.. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "moditha" <moditha@y...> wrote: > Hi > > I can complete the cube trying about 1.30 mins. Now I am learning to > speed things up. So I found some resources on the net. > > This is the site I am currently refering to. > > http://www.ssie.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/permute.html > > This page has permutations for the last layer. > > Now the problem is, when I match the pattern and try to apply the > algorithm the whole cube gets screwed up. ( for example If I want to > move the last layer 3 middle cubes clock wise I use the algorithm > R²U Fs R²Bs U R² = R²U FB' R²BF' U R² ) > > now once I moved that I can nicely jumbled my cube :( > > What am I doing wrong here ? > > When I do the move I turn the cube so the last layer is the top layer. > > please help!!! > > Also some notations like > > R' F R Ba' R Fs R F'R'B2 (U3) <-- U3 isn't it the same as > turning upper layer 3 times clockwise ? > > Rgds > moditha

866. 30-Second Barrier
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 05:20:30 -0000

Tonight I just did what I thought was the impossible. I broke the 30-
second barrier. The entire summer I have not done any averages,
because they would always discourage me. I felt like I was not
improving at all. I even stopped timing myself all together. I kept
practicing though. Then tonight I made the decision to do an
average. This is what I got. I was so happy I improved from my last
average by a little over two seconds. So keep on practicing
everyone.

29 30 24 27 (23) 27 29 (32) 26 24 31 26
27.3 + .5 = 27.8

Kenneth

P.S. I was wondering how many people solve corner's first. That
is the way I do it and I wonder how many other people do it that way.




867. Re: 30-Second Barrier
From: "theboywholived81" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 05:26:56 -0000

Congratulations! I just recently broke my forty second barrier, but it was with a small short cut. I use Lars Petrus' method, but I hear the corners first is a really good way to do it. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., redkbrandon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Tonight I just did what I thought was the impossible. I broke the 30- > second barrier. The entire summer I have not done any averages, > because they would always discourage me. I felt like I was not > improving at all. I even stopped timing myself all together. I kept > practicing though. Then tonight I made the decision to do an > average. This is what I got. I was so happy I improved from my last > average by a little over two seconds. So keep on practicing > everyone. > > 29 30 24 27 (23) 27 29 (32) 26 24 31 26 > 27.3 + .5 = 27.8 > > Kenneth > > P.S. I was wondering how many people solve corner's first. That > is the way I do it and I wonder how many other people do it that way.
868. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] a little advice...
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Aug 2002 23:53:53 -0700

Oh, OK, I get it now. And I get why you thought I could answer :) I also do thing in that order. Unless I see some better option. That happens perhaps 1/3 of the time. I'm surprised to hear there are only 37 positions. I don't consciously know any of them, though I'm sure I recognize a lot of them instantly. I just look at it and "understand". I'm not that much into learning a lot of algorithms. That's just a personal preference, and I'm sure you can get better than me at my method if you memorize a ton of algs. The thing with this step is that you have three corners to choose to expand to. That means that being able to see which of the three options is the best (fast!) is just as important as knowing how to solve them. It also means that you don't need to learn any unfortunate cases. All you need to learn is to recognize them and pick an other corner for the expansion!(*) If you once in a 100 solutions happen to get three lousy options, just take that extra second or three to sort it out some how. That's not worth spending valuable brain power on. It sounds like you always pick one of the three corners, regardless of how easy the others are. I realize it may be a really difficult habit to break, but it helps a *lot*. So I think I'm closest to option 2. Hope that helps! /Lars (*) Come to think of it, that's *not* what I do. I look until I find a *good* option, and then I do it immediately. If nothing real good pops out at first, I lower my demands until I settle for one option. At 2:49 AM +0000 8/13/02, addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube wrote: >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Lars Petrus <lars@l...> wrote: >> I don't get the scenario. Does "expanding to the 2x2x3" mean >> "expanding FROM the 2x2x3"? What is "that" pair? >> >> As for what algs to learn, my philosophy is to start with the most >> common ones. Or more precisely the ones that will earn you the most >> number of moves on average. One that would save you 10 moves 1% of >> the time is less important than one that saves you 3 moves10% of >the >> time. Then move down into more and more obscure ones as time >permits. >> It will be a case of more and more diminishing returns. >> >> Which of 1, 2 or 3 to pick depends entirely on the frequence of >each >> case, and how much you gain by learning each one. >> >> /Lars >> > >I dont mean expanding from the 2x2x3, im talking about that first >corner edge pair right after the 2x2x2 corner is made.....its like on >your site, you say it took you months to figure out the little simple >moves, acutally someone you taught showed them to you....i think >we're talkin about the same moves for that first pair. > >for me expanding to the 2x2x3 block is adding a corner edge pair + a >top layer edge....(i do the f2l on the top two layers, and i always >go around the cube to the right...by going around the cube, i mean >that first corner/edge pair is to the right of my 2x2x2 corner, and >then my next thing to place is to the right of that..... > >i go like this.. 2x2x2 corner, corner/edge pair, top edge, >corner/edge pair, last top edge, last corner/edge pair... > >so you suggest not doing either 1, 2 or 3 but to do each case >differently by how much it will gain me? > >thanks >-Heath -- "They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever flipped it over?" Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@... http://lar5.com

From: "papegoja99" <dani@...>

Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 06:55:44 -0000

Hi!
I´m intrested in trying the L Petrus method. But can only find guides
that use a Java-applet for the algs.
Does anyone know of a good site that doesn´t use applets so I can
print it on paper. Find it much easier to follow the guides when they
are on paper than on screen.
Thanks in advance
/Parrot



870. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] The Lars Petrus Method - Print friendly version
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 00:09:10 -0700

I get that question now and then. My stock answer is that if you do "View Source" (or whatever your browser calls it) and look at the html, you'll find the code for applets look like this: <applet code=lrubik.class width=125 height=145> <param name=pos value="ebfeacdcbcafebefcdadcfcbdceaacddfbfebdfaeedacebaffdabb"> <param name=move value="B2L1D3L3U3F3D1R2U1R3L3B1L2U1L3U1B1U1B1U1B2U3B2U1B1R1D1L3D3R3D1L1D1L2R2U2F1D2L2R2U2"> </applet> The "move value" line should be easy for you to decipher if you really find the written notation so useful :-) /Lars At 6:55 AM +0000 8/13/02, papegoja99 wrote: >Hi! >I´m intrested in trying the L Petrus method. But can only find guides >that use a Java-applet for the algs. >Does anyone know of a good site that doesn´t use applets so I can >print it on paper. Find it much easier to follow the guides when they >are on paper than on screen. >Thanks in advance >/Parrot -- "They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever flipped it over?" Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@... http://lar5.com [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

873. Re: Permutations
From: "hatadey" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 09:43:56 -0000

I find, and think you will find too, if you are right handed, the easiest algorithm to execute is R2 D' U2 R' L F2 R L' D R2 These are the basic moves and as you practice them more and more you will see shortcuts like moving the two layers at the end rather than just the one, so you can do it all more or less with your right hand. To move them anti-clockwise, you can use a similar alg, R2 D' R' L F2 R L' D U2 R2 (same, but different positioning of the U2 move) Hope it helps - Dan H :) > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "moditha" <moditha@y...> wrote: > > Hi > > > > I can complete the cube trying about 1.30 mins. Now I am learning > to > > speed things up. So I found some resources on the net. > > > > This is the site I am currently refering to. > > > > http://www.ssie.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/permute.html > > > > This page has permutations for the last layer. > > > > Now the problem is, when I match the pattern and try to apply the > > algorithm the whole cube gets screwed up. ( for example If I want > to > > move the last layer 3 middle cubes clock wise I use the algorithm > > R²U Fs R²Bs U R² = R²U FB' R²BF' U R² ) > > > > now once I moved that I can nicely jumbled my cube :( > > > > What am I doing wrong here ? > > > > When I do the move I turn the cube so the last layer is the top > layer. > > > > please help!!! > > > > Also some notations like > > > > R' F R Ba' R Fs R F'R'B2 (U3) <-- U3 isn't it the same as > > turning upper layer 3 times clockwise ? > > > > Rgds > > moditha
874. Re: Help with finger shortcuts
From: "hatadey" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 09:50:48 -0000

I have been speedsolving for about 4 months now, and for 3 of those, i have been learning and practising the finger tricks and triggers. I am still improving my performance with them, it seems to take a lot of time to get them moving quickly, for instance, you have to take into account the accuracy with which you turn each face, so the cube doesnt get stuck, and the grip you have to use. With practice, you will see how best to hold the cube, the grip and the angle at which you look at it all affect the speed of the trick. I have more or less mastered the right hand (it has taken three months :)) and now, I am working on my left-hand, which is much more difficult for me, but necessary to go faster. I practice maybe a couple of hours each day, often more, hopefully having mastered the right-hand it shoudnt take as long to work out the left hand ones :D - Dan H --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "theboywholived81" <theboywholived81@y...> wrote: > Sorry, I'm still trying to learn those myself! I can do the cube an > about fifty seconds now, but I'm getting better all the time.. > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., eligeon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey, I have been recently learning how to perform finger tricks > or > > triggers. I was wondering if anyone could tell me how long it > took > > them, and how much practice they put into it? Thanks guys, you > have > > helped me get my times from 2 minutes to 45 seconds. Thanks for > all > > the help! > > > > -Luke > > P.S. Please email me at bluebmw_05@e...

877. This is cube related, honest!...
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 13:28:54 +0100

My cubing performance seems to move in cycles, I'm currently about 5 seconds
below my overall average. I expect in a week or so to be having trouble
again, like 5 seconds above my usual average. I decided to go against my
better judgement and have a look at my biorhythms.

We clearly have a mixed bag of beliefs in this group. I wonder how many
believe in biorhythms? Take a look at this site...

http://www.bio-chart.com/

I personally don't think it makes any sense but maybe some of you believe
that your cubing can be affected by your biorhythms? I've never believed in
it, so I was pleased to find that it really doesn't correlate to my cubing
performance at all. My birthday is 17th August 1977 by the way. From my
chart, you'd expect me to be having a bad time right now with my cubing, but
I'm doing really well.

I wonder what our biorhythms will be like at the championships?

879. Re: secret cubers
From: smoothcuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

880. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: secret cubers
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 09:40:16 -0700

Dan and Tony are the first two.

The third guy I thought of is Gaetan Guimond
(http://rubikscuberecord.com/), he with the frightening behind the
back skills.

He does have an explanation on his site, but I can not even begin to
follow it, and he also says "I have yet to see in a book or on the
Net a method that is better than mine up to now. That's why I have
not published mine so far. ", which sounds like he's keeping it
secret. But I guess it's probably just a case of poor English skills.
His french site is probably very clear and coherent.

/Lars

881. Re: The Lars Petrus Method - Print friendly version
From: "theboywholived81" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 16:56:14 -0000

On my website, I wrote out how to do the Lars Petrus method without applets. Go to http://www.geocities.com/rubiks81 to see it. Hope it helps. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "papegoja99" <dani@p...> wrote: > Hi! > I´m intrested in trying the L Petrus method. But can only find guides > that use a Java-applet for the algs. > Does anyone know of a good site that doesn´t use applets so I can > print it on paper. Find it much easier to follow the guides when they > are on paper than on screen. > Thanks in advance > /Parrot
882. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Two Q's
From: "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 21:09:00 +0200

I still have problems figuring out wether my cube is a good speed cube or
not. So I figure this is a good way of telling:

If I place my right index finger (I'm right handed) on the back sticker of
the BRU corner and pull as hard as I can with the most momentum etc. using
my right thumb, placed on the F sticker of the FR edge piece to help. How
far should the U layer turn? I can make it turn slightly more than a quarter
turn, i.e. 100 degrees or so. Is this sufficient?

Secondly, does anyone have a site that explains finger tricks for the F2L
algorithms with the F2L on bottom? While Jess Bondes site is good for anyone
learning LL and F2L on left (I think) it doesn't help me doing it on the
bottom.

Thanks

_________________________________________________________________
MSN Photos is the easiest way to share and print your photos:
http://photos.msn.com/support/worldwide.aspx



883. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Two Q's
From: "theboywholived81" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 19:16:19 -0000

My cube is a fairly good one, and that's about how far mine turns. I can almost get it 180 degrees. If yours is too stiff, then I would advise taking it apart, then spraying it with silicone spray. They sell pretty good silicone-based lubricant at Rubiks.com. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Eivind Fonn" <htkra1d@h...> wrote: > I still have problems figuring out wether my cube is a good speed cube or > not. So I figure this is a good way of telling: > > If I place my right index finger (I'm right handed) on the back sticker of > the BRU corner and pull as hard as I can with the most momentum etc. using > my right thumb, placed on the F sticker of the FR edge piece to help. How > far should the U layer turn? I can make it turn slightly more than a quarter > turn, i.e. 100 degrees or so. Is this sufficient? > > Secondly, does anyone have a site that explains finger tricks for the F2L > algorithms with the F2L on bottom? While Jess Bondes site is good for anyone > learning LL and F2L on left (I think) it doesn't help me doing it on the > bottom. > > Thanks > > _________________________________________________________________ > MSN Photos is the easiest way to share and print your photos: > http://photos.msn.com/support/worldwide.aspx
884. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: secret cubers
From: "gtregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 20:10:46 -0000

I just took a look at Gaetan's site... It is a little hard to follow, and the English version is incomplete... It is a corners first method, but the English version stops there (doesn't show how he does the edges)... I don't know French, but I looked at the French version, and there were images that I could infer were related to solving the edges... As I understand his method, it is a fairly standard corners first method that works something like this: 1) Orient 3 corners by inspection (he seems to require for orienting the rest that there be a face with exactly three properly oriented) 2) Orient the other 5 corners (he has sequences for all possibilities) 3) Put the corners on their respective faces (U corners on U face, D corners on D face) 4) Position all corners together 5) Place 3 U edges 6) Place all D edges 7) Orient other edges 8) Place the other edges >From his page, I understand how to do the corners efficiently, but (lacking the French knowledge), I still don't understand how the corners first method works well... It always takes me a long time (number of steps) to solve all the edges after the corners... Where can I find a thorough description of this method (the whole process) with algs? --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Lars Petrus <lars@l...> wrote: > Dan and Tony are the first two. > > The third guy I thought of is Gaetan Guimond > (http://rubikscuberecord.com/), he with the frightening behind the > back skills. > > He does have an explanation on his site, but I can not even begin to > follow it, and he also says "I have yet to see in a book or on the > Net a method that is better than mine up to now. That's why I have > not published mine so far. ", which sounds like he's keeping it > secret. But I guess it's probably just a case of poor English skills. > His french site is probably very clear and coherent. > > /Lars
885. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: secret cubers
From: "jazzthief81" <lars.vandenbergh@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 21:02:34 -0000

You can find a good explantion for placing the edges on this page: http://cube.misto.cz/corners.html At the bottom you can find algorithms for placing the top and bottom edges and for orienting and permuting the middle layer edges. On the same site you can find 8 algorithms for placing the final U- or D-layer edge and orienting the middle-layer edges simultaneously: http://cube.misto.cz/_MAIL_/cfsm.html This only leaves the middle layer to be permuted (which only takes 4 to 6 moves). This is great for saving moves. If you're also interested in an alternative way of placing the corners in as few moves as possible, I can recommend you Ron's algorithms for placing and orienting the final layer corners in one look. http://www.speedcubing.com/corners_first_corners.html This averages 8,5 moves and with a bit af practise you can solve the corners in about 17-18 moves (Ron needs 15 moves). Using this method I can solve the cube corners-first in about 60-65 moves, which is OK considering I only learnt it two weeks ago. Lars --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "gtregay" <Grant@T...> wrote: > I just took a look at Gaetan's site... It is a little hard to > follow, and the English version is incomplete... It is a corners > first method, but the English version stops there (doesn't show how > he does the edges)... I don't know French, but I looked at the > French version, and there were images that I could infer were related > to solving the edges... As I understand his method, it is a fairly > standard corners first method that works something like this: > 1) Orient 3 corners by inspection (he seems to require for orienting > the rest that there be a face with exactly three properly oriented) > 2) Orient the other 5 corners (he has sequences for all possibilities) > 3) Put the corners on their respective faces (U corners on U face, D > corners on D face) > 4) Position all corners together > 5) Place 3 U edges > 6) Place all D edges > 7) Orient other edges > 8) Place the other edges > From his page, I understand how to do the corners efficiently, but > (lacking the French knowledge), I still don't understand how the > corners first method works well... It always takes me a long time > (number of steps) to solve all the edges after the corners... Where > can I find a thorough description of this method (the whole process) > with algs? > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Lars Petrus <lars@l...> wrote: > > Dan and Tony are the first two. > > > > The third guy I thought of is Gaetan Guimond > > (http://rubikscuberecord.com/), he with the frightening behind the > > back skills. > > > > He does have an explanation on his site, but I can not even begin to > > follow it, and he also says "I have yet to see in a book or on the > > Net a method that is better than mine up to now. That's why I have > > not published mine so far. ", which sounds like he's keeping it > > secret. But I guess it's probably just a case of poor English > skills. > > His french site is probably very clear and coherent. > > > > /Lars
886. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Two Q's
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 2002 22:51:36 +0100

> I still have problems figuring out wether my cube is a good speed cube or
> not. So I figure this is a good way of telling:
>
> If I place my right index finger (I'm right handed) on the back sticker of
> the BRU corner and pull as hard as I can with the most momentum etc. using
> my right thumb, placed on the F sticker of the FR edge piece to help. How
> far should the U layer turn? I can make it turn slightly more than a quarter
> turn, i.e. 100 degrees or so. Is this sufficient?


Sounds like mine is way looser. If I tightly hold two layers steady in my
left hand, like holding the L face and middle slice, I can easily spin the R
layer with a finger just pressing against the R face. I don't even have to
press against the U, B, D or F face, I just use friction grip alone to spin
the R face and I can do it quickly too. Mine isn't as loose as some people
like it, but it's all a matter of opinion.

888. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Two Q's
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 01:31:00 +0100

> This makes me realise that my new cube is still way too stiff!!
> Perhaps I shall get out the silicon spray again this weekend...
>
> Jasmine.


Well, the great thing about lube is that it can be washed out if you think
it's become too loose. There's no worries about irreversible damage if you
use silicone.



889. Re: 30-Second Barrier

of times ...ill pull 28's or 30.. even 25 sometimes.. most important
thing is you think your not improving , but you are... every time.
I've been cubing for 7 1/2 months im at that time. Its all about
practicing.

HI every one just posting to say hey, i'am not new here, i used to be
duermomucho, and carlitin8plus but know i am yoamomicubo; which
means, in english, ilovemycube.

HEY RON i hope you do not mind that; i guess i should have asked you,
but anyway u can always tell me about it.

I also had a PB, personal best of 21.42 secs.

hey guys F2L that is all it is to me the rest orienting and LL piece
of cake, as i wrote that is to me.

i hope averybody is doing well and ur times are slowly going down.

i will soon gonna have my PB as my average.

P.S Hey Jessica i'am stiil bangging my head that you were here in NYC
and i could not see you, i was away for a long weekend and miss your
posting, i hope that when you come next time i could see you. i can
not wait to that happening soon, I hope you are doing great to
Jessica,and the advice you gave me for the F2l is working just i you
told me, i made copy of that posting and i still read it, thanks
again for that, and i hope you comeback to the city soon.

892. progress
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 03:43:06 -0000

today I made a new best average....I only beat my previous one by .2
seconds but hey, its goin down :D...new avg is 28.6

its almost crazy how many times i've hit 22 the past couple days....I
cant remember the last time I got that low except for the last 3 or 4
days

I guess the reason I was gettin my low times (22 and such) was
because I was just movin right along through both the f2l and the
LL...but last night and the first average I did today it seemed like
my f2l was taking forever...somethin like around 20 seconds or a
little more....and with a good LL I would still get under 30, but
with a "not so good" (and a really bad f2l) my times would be
anywhere from low to high 30s.

I finally got all the 2 look algs learned Friday or so, and so now im
using a straight 2 look for the LL.....but a few of them still take
too long to recognize and the moves aren't quite fast enough yet...I
just need to practice them a lil more I guess...(that would usually
be where the "not so good" LL comes in...haha

Im still tryin to figure out just how im gonna start improving my
F2L, so I havn't really started improving it yet..(any tips would be
greatly appreciated...please refer to my "a little advice" post) haha

alot of the reason for this post was that I couldn't think of
anything better to do...and I thought I could let you peoples know
how I was goin...

and thats all I have to say about that
-Heath

895. Re: secret cubers
From: "simonlcube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 09:10:58 -0000

In the chat room on the weekend someone mentioned a Polish girl who is
working through all 1211 last layer algs. Maybe not a secret method,
but if someone got on stage with a one-look last layer I reckon there
would be some pretty surprised people!

Can anyone substantiate this, or is this a cube-myth?

S.



896. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: secret cubers
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 10:20:26 +0100

> In the chat room on the weekend someone mentioned a Polish girl who is
> working through all 1211 last layer algs. Maybe not a secret method,
> but if someone got on stage with a one-look last layer I reckon there
> would be some pretty surprised people!
>
> Can anyone substantiate this, or is this a cube-myth?
>
> S.


I heard of one guy that was learning the 1211 algs too. But he quickly
found that the thinking time to select the correct alg was very high. So,
it's not just the effort involved in learning them all, it's practicing
executing them with the minimal delay. There's no point in condensing to
stages into one if you have to think for too long.



897. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: secret cubers
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 03:04:18 -0700

I'm also working through the 1211 LL algs. I'm at about 50, 1160 to go...

Or in other (less obnoxious) words, I'd be much more impressed if
somebody had *completed* learning all the 1211, not just were hoping
to learn them.

It doesn't seem like it should take much time to recognize a position, though.

/Lars

like the cubing version of swiss cheese! Still, an average of 35 these days
is good going for such a basic system.

Go to http://www.geocities.com/rubiks81 to see it. Hope it > > helps. > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "papegoja99" <dani@p...> wrote: > > > Hi! > > > I´m intrested in trying the L Petrus method. But can only find > > guides > > > that use a Java-applet for the algs. > > > Does anyone know of a good site that doesn´t use applets so I can > > > print it on paper. Find it much easier to follow the guides when > > they > > > are on paper than on screen. > > > Thanks in advance > > > /Parrot
903. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: secret cubers
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 16:08:46 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "simonl cube" <simonlcube@h...> wrote: > The suggestion was that she was more than half-way through. > So is this true? Who out there has actually got the highest persentage of > the 1211 learnt and at their finger tips? I know about 35; Lars knows about > 50 ... > S. anybody who has the LL down to 2 looks would know 53 alg for the LL...unless of course you use a different 2 look method than orient all, permute all.
904. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: secret cubers
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 17:32:42 +0100

> anybody who has the LL down to 2 looks would know 53 alg for the
> LL...unless of course you use a different 2 look method than orient
> all, permute all.


I'm not sure I'm qualified to comment on this but; Just because you know OLL
algs, surely that doesn't mean that you'd know when to use them in a one
look LL system. You'd have to look at all your OLL algs and learn what PLL
function it happens to perform at the same time. Right? Maybe :-/ I
don't use OLL algs but I just presumed that they don't normally preserve any
permutations already established (?)



905. Re: secret cubers
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 16:55:33 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "simonl cube" <simonlcube@h...> > wrote: > > The suggestion was that she was more than half-way through. > > So is this true? Who out there has actually got the highest > persentage of > > the 1211 learnt and at their finger tips? I know about 35; Lars > knows about > > 50 ... > > S. > > anybody who has the LL down to 2 looks would know 53 alg for the > LL...unless of course you use a different 2 look method than orient > all, permute all. I don't know anything like 53 algorithms for the LL (and probably not for the entire cube) for the LL but I can do the entire cube in 1 look and the method I use in that case is orient all, permute all.
906. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: secret cubers
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 17:04:28 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > > anybody who has the LL down to 2 looks would know 53 alg for the > > LL...unless of course you use a different 2 look method than orient > > all, permute all. > > > I'm not sure I'm qualified to comment on this but; Just because you know OLL > algs, surely that doesn't mean that you'd know when to use them in a one > look LL system. You'd have to look at all your OLL algs and learn what PLL > function it happens to perform at the same time. Right? Maybe :- / I > don't use OLL algs but I just presumed that they don't normally preserve any > permutations already established (?) correct....but what im saying is that those 53 algs are going to be included in the 1211.....i think it would be kinda pointless to be able to recognize which OLL positions would be lucky enough to permute also...
907. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: secret cubers
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 18:56:38 +0100


>
>Uh oh. Simon, that was a joke :). Sorry...
>
>Dave
>

That's OK! The funny thing is, I can just imagine someone sitting somewhere
in a basement (yes, definitely a basesment) with a printout of all 1211
algs. Quitely, stealthily, this faceless person, perhaps with some grudge
against the world in general, grimly works through the list, ticking them
off as they are recorded in a cold, mechanical mind. Each day the person
awakes and reaches for the cube, driven by one goal: "The WORLD
CHAMPIONSHIPS will be mine! Haaahaaa ...."

Ahem, excuse all, just letting my imagination get the better of me. Back to
those OLL algorithms. 53 out of 1211 will do for me.
S.
BUT ... is there anyone out there with more than 53?

908. Re: secret cubers
From: krrash <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 18:13:55 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "simonl cube" <simonlcube@h...> wrote: > Ahem, excuse all, just letting my imagination get the better of me. Back to > those OLL algorithms. 53 out of 1211 will do for me. > S. > BUT ... is there anyone out there with more than 53? When you say 53, are you referring to the 57 cases on this page? http://home01.wxs.nl/~janse625/AllesFastOrient.html Sometimes when I am solving orientation cases where the corners are correctly oriented and positioned, but two edges are flipped, I can figure out a move that will solve the last layer in one step, but this situation doesn't come up very often.
909. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: secret cubers

>http://home01.wxs.nl/~janse625/AllesFastOrient.html

Sorry, 57. And yes those ones. As it happens, I have a printout of that
page, which I use to help me find my own finger tricks!

So ... thank you for putting that page up!
Simon

915. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: secret cubers
From: larrpas <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 2002 20:48:16 -0000

53 is the total number of algorithms modulo symmetry needed to complete the last layer in two algorithms using the Fridrich method (40 for the orientation and 13 for the permutation). The number 57 you guys are talking about is the number of possible orientation cases (without the solved one) including symmetric positions. Counting it this way, there's 78 algorithms needed to completely solve the last layer. But then, the 1211 cases go up to ???. LP --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "simonl cube" <simonlcube@h...> wrote: > > > > BUT ... is there anyone out there with more than 53? > > > >When you say 53, are you referring to the 57 cases on this page? > > > >http://home01.wxs.nl/~janse625/AllesFastOrient.html > > > > Sorry, 57. And yes those ones. As it happens, I have a printout of that > page, which I use to help me find my own finger tricks! > > So ... thank you for putting that page up! > Simon > > > > _________________________________________________________________ > Send and receive Hotmail on your mobile device: http://mobile.msn.com

And the cubes last time were brand new and un-lubed, and you didn't get to choose the color orientation(red across from orange, blue across from green, etc.). Which must have made a large difference on the time. But this time, people get to use their own cubes. If I do go, I'll probably win the Youngest Person to Solve the Cube award, if there is one. signing up doesnt close...the way I understand it is you can just
walk into the contest and have a go at it....

that is a pretty good idea to raise money to get to the
contest...lol...

maybe just stand on the street corner with a sign saying..."send me
to Toronto to the Rubiks Cube World Championships"..and have a
suitcase under the sign where people can toss money in...and all you
have to do is solve the cube :)....OR...bet people 50 bucks that you
can solve it...and if people bet ya, then you'll have enough money to
go in no time....

LOL > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > signing up doesnt close...the way I understand it is you can > just > > > walk into the contest and have a go at it.... > > > > > > that is a pretty good idea to raise money to get to the > > > contest...lol... > > > > > > maybe just stand on the street corner with a sign > saying..."send me > > > to Toronto to the Rubiks Cube World Championships"..and have a > > > suitcase under the sign where people can toss money in...and > all > > you > > > have to do is solve the cube :)....OR...bet people 50 bucks > that > > you > > > can solve it...and if people bet ya, then you'll have enough > money > > to > > > go in no time.... > > > > > > Yahoo! 933. Keep a cube handy
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 14:54:55 -0000

I often keep a cube with me in my bag in case I'm stuck waiting for
someone or waiting for a bus, in the way that some people keep a book
with them to keep them occupied when waiting for something. I also
sometimes keep a spare cube in a drawer at work in case Rubik's cubes
just happened to come up in conversation -- so I can just grab it and
demonstrate on the spot.

This all seemed quite normal to me but one of my friends commented
with surprise when he realised that I kept one in my bag.

Does everyone else do stuff like this?



934. Blindfold
From: smoothcuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 15:38:09 -0000


I give all credit for the method to GameofDeath; it's his that I use.
I would not have figured it out on my own. Thanks for your help!
Stiffhands also has a site which I'm sure is good, I just tried GoD's
first.

So, I am a student of Richard's; he is the master :)! Richard, I may
have blown the blindfold mystique, now that guys see that I can do it,
haha.

Anyway, it's a fun diversion, and I encourage all to try.

Richard, I look forward to hearing any changes/improvements you may
make with your method. If I were to get faster, I'd need to work on
the perming stages. As for 4 cubes, maybe in awhile I'll try it, but
for now it's back to one!

Dave

939. 5 x 5 cube help
From: cubed68 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 16:02:02 -0000

guys i need help with my professors cube.i`ve solved all cubies bar
the edge cubies on the bottom face.they need to either flipped or
swapped to another spot.i`ll be taking some pics of the cube later to
show anyone if they think they can help me.

cheers guys

Peter



940. Re: 5 x 5 cube help
From: krrash <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 16:43:02 -0000

I think you are looking for this move: r2 B2 U2 l U2 r ' U2 r U2 F2 r F2 l ' B2 r2 (lower case r and l refer to the inner slices next to R and L.) This will swap two edge cubies on the UF edge. I found that move here: http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/4-step3.html This is a parity problem that arises because you can cycle 3 pieces, but you can't truly swap two pieces. My guess is that the above sequence disturbs some identically colored face pieces, but I haven't checked for sure. Before I figured out that move, I used to solve it by doing a quarter turn of an inner slice (like r) which would move 4 edge pieces in a way that you can't move them with 3-cycles. Then, I would move the pieces back with 3-cycles, which would be possible because of the two extra pieces that needed swapping. The disadvantage of this method is that it messed up a lot of center pieces. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., cubed68 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > guys i need help with my professors cube.i`ve solved all cubies bar > the edge cubies on the bottom face.they need to either flipped or > swapped to another spot.i`ll be taking some pics of the cube later to > show anyone if they think they can help me. > > cheers guys > > Peter

Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 17:21:36 -0000

Also, in social situations (family get-togethers, etc.) I find that I'm not really all that much of a talker, but I'll take out my cube, and then people will start talking with me about that... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I often keep a cube with me in my bag in case I'm stuck waiting for > someone or waiting for a bus, in the way that some people keep a book > with them to keep them occupied when waiting for something. 945. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Keep a cube handy
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 20:07:02 +0100

> I often take a cube to school with me, so I can do it at lunch. Two
> of my friends can do it too, and they bring one with them too. People
> are amazed at us. :)
> I wish I had a MegaMinx. It sounds hard.. I can't even figure out a
> 4x4x4 cube.
> By the way, is it just me, or do people in this group use periods
> alot.......?


Hey, I only decided to learn the 4x4x4 a couple of weeks ago. It only took
one sitting with Chris Hardwicks page. I had it down in an evening! If you
know how to do a 3x3x3 then there are hardly any new algs to learn. You can
do all the centres by intuition alone and you can do the edges with only one
alg to learn. Hopefully from there you solve it just as the 3x3x3 but
usually you have to apply one or two parity fixing algs.

I have a mega minx but I'm scared to scramble it. I keep studying it,
trying to figure out if I can apply what I already know to it. One thing
scares me is that there are two of every edge colour combination.



946. Brand Spankin' New Member!
From: "cuber3x3" <jumboflea@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 19:16:37 -0000

Hey all you cubers! Im a new member to this group (or any Yahoo group for that matter). I'm 14 years old and have been cubing for... um... 3 months. I'm obsessed with cubing as Im sure most of you are. My PB is 46 secs, but Ive done better without timing it (figures). My average is rather slower then those who are faster (I think Im about 56 secs). I use a layer by layer f2l (Wich I really dont like) and a 3 look LL (except for a few situations where I use a 4 look because I dont know the 3 look). I plan on learning the rest of the 3 looks and then learning a totally new f2l method. I already failed at the Petrus method. I dont think my brain works that way. Im strongly considering Jessica's method. Atleast now I can get some help from people who already use the method. Im happy to be apart of this group. Lookin foward to seeing you all at the worlds if I bring my time down and my parents decide to love me:)
-cuber3x3

949. check this out...
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 16 Aug 2002 22:42:27 -0000

haha...I was just looking for a blindfolded cubing page when i came
across this ......

http://home.planet.nl/~gkorthof/kortho47.htm

here the quote that cought my interest...

"The chance that even one protein appeared spontaneously is equal to
the chance that a blindfolded person could solve the Rubik cube:
using 1 move per second. It takes 300 times the age of the Earth."

im not trying to support evolution here....just thought it was funny
that the author thought it so impossible for someone to solve the
cube blindfolded...hehe

announcements: Anyone interested in learning the Rubik's Club? Meet
in the EH room after school for more info.....

around... Oh boy!! I had 11 people sign this year, not counting the
5 or 6 i got last year.
Give it a try!

954. I'm using a new method
From: "theboywholived81" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 17 Aug 2002 04:48:45 -0000

I've decided to use the corners first method, because it seems like
it would be faster. Does anyone out there have any tips or helpful
algorithms for corners first?



955. Re: I'm using a new method
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 17 Aug 2002 08:42:16 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "theboywholived81" <theboywholived81@y...> wrote: > I've decided to use the corners first method, because it seems like > it would be faster. Does anyone out there have any tips or helpful > algorithms for corners first? I use corners first. Right now I have a personal best average of 27.8 and I can tell that my average can still go down much further. I used the algorithms from the wonderful site www.speedcubing.com check it out. ken

I've liked since 7th grade that I said something stupid to to make
her think I didn't like her so she went and got an idiot boyfriend
instead and has been dating losers in the years since but recently
broke up with a guy and has been seeing a lot of me lately under the
apparent guise of friendly support, is now single. BUT I CUBE!!! Is
there any hope for me anymore?? Must I make a choice?

Sincerely,
Distraught Smitten Cubist

961. Understanding the cube
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 17 Aug 2002 14:38:34 -0000

I've started using a Lars/Jessica/other method. I had a go at Lars'
F2L method, and although I could do it, for some reason it wasn't
really connecting well with the cube part of my brain. So, I had a
look at Jessica's F2L method, not so much for specific algorithms,
more just for the concept, ie. do the cross, the insert top
corner/middle edges. I found that seemed to fit more naturally with
the way I think about the cube. As for the LL, I'm using several
Lars' algorithms which I learnt a while ago and a couple of others
that I learnt years ago.

Anyway, my point is that I was looking for a way to improve my
understanding of the cube - not really focusing on speed at the
moment but on understanding what each twist does to the cube rather
than just blinding applying algorithms. I'm hoping that a better
understanding of how the cube works will mean that I can be more
intuitive and efficient in solving and faster at identifying the best
options.

Does this make sense?

Jasmine.

978. "CUBIST "lession 101
From: "cubist3x3only" <cubist3x3only@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Aug 2002 06:56:44 -0000

Not once i got called a geek or a fag for speed cubing in public.
people sometimes even go crazy when i speed cube. We speed Cubist can
do something that other people can't do. And when people see us do
this soo fast, they go out of there minds. I think its far
from "dorky" or "Queer" but art and talent.

980. Re: 5 x 5 cube help
From: cubed68 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Aug 2002 13:16:34 -0000

r u sure bout this krrash,this looks like a move for a 4 x 4 cube Peter --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., krrash <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I think you are looking for this move: > > r2 B2 U2 l U2 r ' U2 r U2 F2 r F2 l ' B2 r2 > > (lower case r and l refer to the inner slices next to R and L.) This > will swap two edge cubies on the UF edge. > > I found that move here: http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/4- step3.html > > This is a parity problem that arises because you can cycle 3 pieces, > but you can't truly swap two pieces. My guess is that the above > sequence disturbs some identically colored face pieces, but I haven't > checked for sure. Before I figured out that move, I used to solve it > by doing a quarter turn of an inner slice (like r) which would move 4 > edge pieces in a way that you can't move them with 3-cycles. Then, I > would move the pieces back with 3-cycles, which would be possible > because of the two extra pieces that needed swapping. The > disadvantage of this method is that it messed up a lot of center > pieces. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., cubed68 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > guys i need help with my professors cube.i`ve solved all cubies bar > > the edge cubies on the bottom face.they need to either flipped or > > swapped to another spot.i`ll be taking some pics of the cube later > to > > show anyone if they think they can help me. > > > > cheers guys > > > > Peter

r u sure bout this krrash,this looks like a move for a 4 x 4 cube Peter --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., krrash <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I think you are looking for this move: > > r2 B2 U2 l U2 r ' U2 r U2 F2 r F2 l ' B2 r2 > > (lower case r and l refer to the inner slices next to R and L.) This > will swap two edge cubies on the UF edge. > > I found that move here: http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/4- step3.html > > This is a parity problem that arises because you can cycle 3 pieces, > but you can't truly swap two pieces. My guess is that the above > sequence disturbs some identically colored face pieces, but I haven't > checked for sure. Before I figured out that move, I used to solve it > by doing a quarter turn of an inner slice (like r) which would move 4 > edge pieces in a way that you can't move them with 3-cycles. Then, I > would move the pieces back with 3-cycles, which would be possible > because of the two extra pieces that needed swapping. 983. Re: 5 x 5 cube help
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Aug 2002 15:15:11 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., cubed68 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > r u sure bout this krrash,this looks like a move for a 4 x 4 cube > > Peter > You don't have any moves for the 3x3x3 that also work for the 4x4x4? > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., krrash <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I think you are looking for this move: > > > > r2 B2 U2 l U2 r ' U2 r U2 F2 r F2 l ' B2 r2 > > > > (lower case r and l refer to the inner slices next to R and L.) > This > > will swap two edge cubies on the UF edge. > > > > I found that move here: http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/4- > step3.html > > > > This is a parity problem that arises because you can cycle 3 > pieces, > > but you can't truly swap two pieces. My guess is that the above > > sequence disturbs some identically colored face pieces, but I > haven't > > checked for sure. Before I figured out that move, I used to solve > it > > by doing a quarter turn of an inner slice (like r) which would move > 4 > > edge pieces in a way that you can't move them with 3-cycles. Then, > I > > would move the pieces back with 3-cycles, which would be possible > > because of the two extra pieces that needed swapping. The > > disadvantage of this method is that it messed up a lot of center > > pieces. > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., cubed68 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > guys i need help with my professors cube.i`ve solved all cubies > bar > > > the edge cubies on the bottom face.they need to either flipped or > > > swapped to another spot.i`ll be taking some pics of the cube > later > > to > > > show anyone if they think they can help me. > > > > > > cheers guys > > > > > > Peter
984. Re: Blindfold Cubing: Help!
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Aug 2002 15:42:19 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., eligeon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I have gotten very close to figuring out how to solve a rubiks cube > with a blindfold on, but I cannot figure out how to memorize numbers > as they are oriented and permutated. Anyone have any suggestions? It very much depends on your system of memorization. With the system I use you have to memorize about 35 numbers although in practice you remember about 40 numbers (it's possible to save 5 numbers if you really want because you don't have to remember any of the details for the last edge or corner, saving 4 numbers, and you can also remember just the orientation of either the penultimate edge or the penultimate corner (but not both). For a Revenge you need to remember about 40 numbers and 24 letters but it's actually harder than learning 2 cubes because everything is intertwined whereas with 2 cubes you have disjoint puzzles to work on. The main thing is to know or be able to work out exactly the position and orienation of every piece before you start or else it's very unlikely to end up a successful endeavour. In practice you should try and figure out pairs of edges that you might flip together (instead of remembering a sequence of 12 0's and 1's) and similarly for corners. Make very sure that you know the permutations particularly well because you should orient the pieces first. (If not, you need to carry extra information around with you, or at least memorize it in a different order, which is more difficult to work out from just looking at the cube.) As for memorizing sequences of numbers, I often just try to remember the numbers as numbers but there are things you might do instead: for instance you could associate events to pairs of numbers like Tokyo to 68 (since the Tokyo Olympics were in 1968) or New York to 2 12 since the area code for Manhattan is 212 etc. Once you find something that seems to work it's just a question of having a good memory and also being able to switch stuff in your mind quickly. Last night for instance (at about 3am of all crazy times) I had a first attempt at doing 4 cubes blindfolded simultaneously - 3am was the start time for solving the cubes, memorization had taken place earlier - then I'd had a bit of a break and watched a couple of films, then I completed memorizing the cubes - having not memorized teh edge permutation of the 4th cube - and then I spent a fair bit of time checking everything was in place in my mind. On each cube I oriented every piece correctly and permuted the edges correctly and on the first, third and fourth cubes I permuted the corners correctly too, but on the second cube I only permuted the bottom corners correctly and was left with a corner permutation starting 3 4 1 2 instead of 1 2 3 4. This was actually due to a lapse of concentration and I was able to figure out exactly where I had gone wrong, namely after getting the D face corners into position I just completely forgot to permute the corners in the U face. Had the corner permutation been odd instead of even I would no doubt have realized this when it came to finishing up the edges but unluckily that was not the case and when I removed the blindfold (about 4.05am) and realized what had happened I was left to rue my costly error. I was still able to recall the initial positions of each of the 4 cubes so I figure I'm probably in good shape to have another crack at it soon. It is at least something that gives hope for a future crack at the 5x5x5. Anyway the best advice is to spend as much time as you need to take in the information and not to rush things. It's only 40 numbers to remember so it's not any more difficult than remembering 6 telephone numbers (except that usually you wouldn't have to start messing around with them in your head). Another tip (as I mentioned above) is to orient the pieces first. Unless, like me, you try to remember the initial positions for afterwards so that you can make a record of the cubes you have solved blindfolded, this will allow you to completely forget the orientation information relatively early on in the solution. Also, if you place the last 4 edges first (in the permutation stage) it may help you in terms of not having to memorize as much for as long (although in practice it may be better to place edges as the situation dictates). Finally remember that it is a lot easier than it sounds. After you've solved the cube blindfolded a few times you'll wonder why you ever thought it might be difficult.

From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Aug 2002 15:53:07 -0000

When I ever try to go in, I get this > message: Your browser is unable to support Java. Please enable Java > and reload or try our HTML Client. Does anyone know of a solution > to this problem? 988. Re: Understanding the cube
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Aug 2002 16:48:04 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I've started using a Lars/Jessica/other method. I had a go at Lars' > F2L method, and although I could do it, for some reason it wasn't > really connecting well with the cube part of my brain. So, I had a > look at Jessica's F2L method, not so much for specific algorithms, > more just for the concept, ie. do the cross, the insert top > corner/middle edges. I found that seemed to fit more naturally with > the way I think about the cube. As for the LL, I'm using several > Lars' algorithms which I learnt a while ago and a couple of others > that I learnt years ago. > > Anyway, my point is that I was looking for a way to improve my > understanding of the cube - not really focusing on speed at the > moment but on understanding what each twist does to the cube rather > than just blinding applying algorithms. I'm hoping that a better > understanding of how the cube works will mean that I can be more > intuitive and efficient in solving and faster at identifying the best > options. > > Does this make sense? > > Jasmine. Try to get a book on group theory and look at permutation groups. A lot of useful stuff can be obtained from that. In particular, you may find out why so many moves involve conjugation or commutators. Also some of the best known solutions (in terms of number of moves) are based on group theory, using the Jordan-Holder theorem to descend through a sequence of normal subgroups to solve the cube.

996. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Keep a cube handy
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Aug 2002 22:33:04 -0000

Yes, I'm also all for correct spelling and grammar online, but exaggerated punctuation and correct punctuation are not necessarily mutually exclusive. For example: "Rubik's cubes are fun to solve!" "Rubik's cubes are fun to solve!!" Both sentences express excitement about cube solving, the second one is just more animated (--> body language analogy). :) As for more picky things, in the context of casual online conversations I'm not so concerned about stuff like hanging prepositions, split infinitives and parallel construction. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > > I'm all for exaggerated and excessive punctuation in online > > conversation. Facial expressions and body language contribute as much > > in face-to-face communication as the actual words spoken. 1006. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Blindfold
From: "stiff_hands" <angela.hayden@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 2002 07:58:59 -0000

I found the following comments quite interesting.

GameOfDeath2 wrote in reply to Eivind Fonn talking about stiff_hands
method:
> I originally had thought about a similar technique as it seemed to
> make more sense mathematically but I rejected it as being too hard
> compared to the method I currently use.
> Afterwards I saw stiff_hands' page and I still think that it is
> probably too hard. : )

My method evolved (from comments made by krrash before the old
messages were purged) on the basis of making sense mathematically.
The intention wasn't to make an easy method but one that I could
understand worked; that took a long time to achieve because I didn't
understand much about the cube before I started as I was into
the 'black box' approach ie doing moves that achieved an effect
without knowing why. Doing so has increased my understanding of the
cube (Jasmine - maybe working through the concepts on my site will
help you).
The plus side of going through this is I now see how incredibly easy
the 3x3 is to solve and am flabbergasted that I ever found it
difficult.
I often have to apologise to people who email me finding my site
hard. All I can say (since I am unable to update it currently) is
that the method does work and that you can use whichever ideas of
moves that you find helpful. If you understand everything then you
can always improvise.

- stiff_hands



1007. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Blindfold
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 2002 11:49:31 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "stiff_hands" <angela.hayden@n...> wrote: > I found the following comments quite interesting. > The main difficulty I had was this: if you decompose the permutations into their cycle structure you either have to figure out how to invert each possible cycle (either by a series of algorithms - at least one for each cycle and then only if you have the mental agility to figure out complicated conjugations - or else by a method of reducing the cycle length, which would also need some computation, probably by 2, in which case you might end up with a load of transpositions to take care of which would probably involve turning double transpositions into 3 cycles and then removing them or using a move to do a transposition of corners and a transposition of edges). That seems like an awful lot of work. Two other options would be: a) figure out the entire solution in advance - this would be done mentally, but it seems a bit of a fudge, since you still have sight of the cube whilst you work out the solution - but that could be quite difficult too. b) Use a group theoretic description of the cube to condense the information into a few short sequences and then fix the sequences one by one (without altering the others) - which is basically what my method is. It's also got some mathematics behind it but you don't really need to know as much mathematics as in the cycle solution. All the algorithms I use at the moment are either Jessica Fridrich algorithms or concatenations of those algorithms, but I use only a very limited number of them. Maybe soon I will add to these algorithms so I can work towards improving speed and efficiency for the World Championships. > GameOfDeath2 wrote in reply to Eivind Fonn talking about stiff_hands > method: > > I originally had thought about a similar technique as it seemed to > > make more sense mathematically but I rejected it as being too hard > > compared to the method I currently use. > > Afterwards I saw stiff_hands' page and I still think that it is > > probably too hard. : ) > > My method evolved (from comments made by krrash before the old > messages were purged) on the basis of making sense mathematically. > The intention wasn't to make an easy method but one that I could > understand worked; that took a long time to achieve because I didn't > understand much about the cube before I started as I was into > the 'black box' approach ie doing moves that achieved an effect > without knowing why. Doing so has increased my understanding of the > cube (Jasmine - maybe working through the concepts on my site will > help you). > The plus side of going through this is I now see how incredibly easy > the 3x3 is to solve and am flabbergasted that I ever found it > difficult. > I often have to apologise to people who email me finding my site > hard. All I can say (since I am unable to update it currently) is > that the method does work and that you can use whichever ideas of > moves that you find helpful. If you understand everything then you > can always improvise. > > - stiff_hands

1014. Overall cubing skills
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 2002 18:28:32 -0000

Today I tried something new. I wanted to test my overall cubing
ability. So I messed up my 5x5x5 4x4x4 and 3x3x3. Then I started
the timer and did all of them in a row like a relay. My time was
11min 39sec. Approximately 7min for the 5x5, 4 min for the 4x4, and
under 30s for the 3x3. How may other people have tried this? It
could be considered for competition at the world championship?

-Kenneth




1015. Re: Overall cubing skills
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 2002 18:35:34 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., redkbrandon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Today I tried something new. I wanted to test my overall cubing > ability. So I messed up my 5x5x5 4x4x4 and 3x3x3. Then I started > the timer and did all of them in a row like a relay. My time was > 11min 39sec. Approximately 7min for the 5x5, 4 min for the 4x4, and > under 30s for the 3x3. How may other people have tried this? It > could be considered for competition at the world championship? > > -Kenneth Yes, I've thought about this - although a relay should have 4 legs so you should include the 2x2x2. I was thinking about it from the blindfold point of view starting with the 2x2x2 (and therefore keeping the hardest one requiring most memory to last, to make the challenge more difficult).
1016. Re: Overall cubing skills
From: ilovemycube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 2002 18:58:01 -0000

Hi Kenneth,

Yes, I think timing 3x3x3, 4x4x4 and then 5x5x5 is a good idea.
In fact I already have one record post for it, but I wait until
someone else also posts a record for it to have some kind of
comparison. I propose that the order of solving is free. (I prefer to
start with the 5x5x5.)

Of course the biggest difference will be made by the 5x5x5. So if you
are good at that one, then you can set a really good time.

Hi Heath,

Nice video! Not the perfect circumstances to speed solve, so also a
very good time. If you make a new video, then please also make sure
the cube is a bit bigger on the screen.
In Windows Media Player you can adjust the brightness of the video
when playing it.

Have fun,

Ron
http://www.speedcubing.com




1017. Re: Overall cubing skills
