1028. Question on Corners First
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 00:08:17 -0000

Hi, while I was practicing today I counted the number of moves to
complete the corners. I found on average I would solve the corners
around 18 to 19 moves. I am using the algorithms from
speedcubing.com for the bottom corners. There it says I should be
able to do it on average in 15 moves, using only 8.5 for the bottom
corners. So I was wondering how to get the first layer corners done
in on average 6.5 moves. Is there any method besides finding one
corner putting it in, finding another putting it in, and so on.
Thanks

-Kenneth




1029. Re: Question on Corners First
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 00:35:35 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., redkbrandon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hi, while I was practicing today I counted the number of moves to > complete the corners. I found on average I would solve the corners > around 18 to 19 moves. I am using the algorithms from > speedcubing.com for the bottom corners. There it says I should be > able to do it on average in 15 moves, using only 8.5 for the bottom > corners. So I was wondering how to get the first layer corners done > in on average 6.5 moves. Is there any method besides finding one > corner putting it in, finding another putting it in, and so on. > Thanks > > -Kenneth Well, I've only used the corners first method a little bit, and im sure your wayyyyyy faster than me using corners first, but what I try to do is see if there is a way to match up 2 corners before i put them in position. And I try to keep other corner matched if they already are....i just did an average for first layer corners, and I came up with 6.1 moves....(I either did corners on white or yellow) well *$%! now that I think of it we probably dont do the top corners the same. I just orient the 4 corners, and you probably want them permuted too....o well...just tryin to help. -Heath
1030. a different corners first question.
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 02:06:50 -0000

Okay, heres the deal. I was just looking at Rons corners first algs.
to "orient and position last edge of top layer, and to orient the
middle layer edges." I understand it all (finally). BUT, what if
the top layer edge is in its spot just flipped (the "B" cubie), and
your trying to orient it and the middle layer edges. There are no
shown algs for that. So what would you do?

thanks in advance for any help!

-Heath



1031. Re: a different corners first question.
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 06:38:38 -0000

There are two algs for that and they are on Ron's page. It is on the "orient and position last edge of top layer, and to orient the middle layer edges," page. It is under "All top and bottom layer edges are already in place" and then under "Last top layer edge is twisted." Hope this helps -Kenneth --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Okay, heres the deal. I was just looking at Rons corners first algs. > to "orient and position last edge of top layer, and to orient the > middle layer edges." I understand it all (finally). BUT, what if > the top layer edge is in its spot just flipped (the "B" cubie), and > your trying to orient it and the middle layer edges. There are no > shown algs for that. So what would you do? > > thanks in advance for any help! > > -Heath
1032. Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: "promethee2003" <promethee2003@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 07:47:47 -0000

I'm looking for a simple method to do the cube, to teach children.
So , we need a minimum of algorithms !
Do you have any suggestion ?

Promethee




1033. Re: Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 07:59:07 -0000

I'd recommend Lars Petrus' method: http://lar5.com/cube/ I wasn't actually aware of Lars' method at the time, but in terms of the number of algorithms and the complexity of algorithms, Lars' is similiar to the method I learnt when I was 10 years old. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "promethee2003" <promethee2003@y...> wrote: > I'm looking for a simple method to do the cube, to teach children. > So , we need a minimum of algorithms ! > Do you have any suggestion ? > > Promethee

1035. Re: Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: rquethe <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 09:23:55 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I'd recommend Lars Petrus' method: http://lar5.com/cube/ > > I wasn't actually aware of Lars' method at the time, but in terms of > the number of algorithms and the complexity of algorithms, Lars' is > similiar to the method I learnt when I was 10 years old. > While I'll agree that Lars' system uses relativily few algorithms, my personal opinion is that a simplisitic corners first system would be very effective at teaching little kids. There are few algorithms and the ones that are there are relatively easy to learn IMO. For example, I have a copy of Verasano's book which teaches a very easy to learn method. You may be able to find something similar on the internet.

1038. Re: Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Here is the page I first learned from. I really don't remember how easy it was to learn from. I think I solved my first cube in about thirty min while reading that page. It is corners first. 1039. Re: Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 15:25:00 -0000

In my club at school, I teach a simple layers method with only 4 algs
to memorize in the ll. It gives them a conselpt of the workings of
the cube and it is a simple and logical solution. I think beginers
would have a problem with a corners first method mainly because its
illogical and won't make a whole lot of sense for an inexperienced
cuber. So far i havent seen any problems with my solution. I
managed to teach my 12 yearold cousin in one day. The highschool
members had little trouble with it, and if you get really good at the
solution you can achieve times in the 50 - 60sec range. It is also a
good solution to add algs and the f2l method in the future.



1040. Re: CUBE MOVIE
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 15:31:42 -0000

I thought the math was pretty cool. I have no understanding of what
they were doing to get the answers but in the comentary the directors
actually had a college professor work out the mathmatics to generat
1. if the next room has a trap
2. a coordinate system
3. permutations
all in 9 digits.
For it being a low budget film, i thought they did incredibly well
for using one cubical chamber to film the whole movie. The
characters were somewhat annoying. The cop especially. But without
props, without multiple scenes, they certainly made a good film.
Jake



1041. Re: Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: "gtregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 16:39:39 -0000

I'm also working on a solution for beginners. However, I haven't even started putting it into writing. I came across a "simple solution" by Mark Jeay's on www.rubiks.dk a while ago, but it's not there anymore. There is a link to his site (http://jeays.net/rubiks.htm), but the solution I attribute to him isn't on his site. He currently has two different solutions listed, neither of which is the one I found previously. The solution I came up with is very much the same as what I had read initially, but I found his descriptions difficult to understand (the wording was a bit confusing), and it used more algorithms than necessary. My solution, which I will eventually put on my web page, will have less algorithms and more concepts that can be applied; really having only two "algorithms" to learn, both of which are fairly short. I'll have to work on that page sometime soon, but don't wait on me; I do work full time, so this may be further in the future than I mean it to be. I used this solution to teach a co-worker in about a week, using only about 10-15 minutes per day. As far as speed, I timed myself twice, and it took just over a minute for me. If this were my usual method, I could probably do it in under a minute, but not by much. The solution isn't really aimed at speed. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "papegoja99" <webmaster@p...> wrote: > I´m trying to put together a page for beginners. > It´s not done yet. Only has the first 2 layers. > But I think I´ll have it finished pretty soon. > When it´s done I´ll also add some PDF-files so you can print it > without any disturbing pagebreaks. > The site is in swedish, but the cube pages are in english (hope my > spelling is good enough). > http://www.papegoja.net > > /Papegoja > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "promethee2003" > <promethee2003@y...> wrote: > > I'm looking for a simple method to do the cube, to teach children. > > So , we need a minimum of algorithms ! > > Do you have any suggestion ? > > > > Promethee
1042. Re: CUBE MOVIE
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 16:42:04 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I thought the math was pretty cool. I have no understanding of what > they were doing to get the answers but in the comentary the directors > actually had a college professor work out the mathmatics to generat > 1. if the next room has a trap > 2. a coordinate system > 3. permutations > all in 9 digits. > For it being a low budget film, i thought they did incredibly well > for using one cubical chamber to film the whole movie. The > characters were somewhat annoying. The cop especially. But without > props, without multiple scenes, they certainly made a good film. > Jake Spoiler (the level of mathematics used) This movie puts forth ideas like it takes a genius to figure out if 3 digit numbers like 315, 218 or 732 are prime in less than an hour. These numbers were generally (when not prime) divisible by 2, 3 or 5 so it's a bit of an insult in that regard. Even when it got to something very slightly more complicated - whether a number was a prime power or not - it's still hardly complicated stuff. Movies involving mathematics (e.g. Cube, Pi, The Mirror Has Two Faces) are generally quite annoying in their treatment of the mathematics. Good Will Hunting is another case in point. The Harvard professor gives them a full term to do something which can be easily solved by a pre-university student (transition matrices and cubing of matrices etc. - it certainly isn't beyond A-level and some of it is more basic yet) in a few minutes and then they reckon the guy is a genius because he can do just that. If the problem had been more challenging it wouldn't have been such an insult.
1043. Re: Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: "theboywholived81" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 18:22:15 -0000

I think that the easiest way to solve it, that can also be done considerably fast is the corners first. You don't need to memorize very many algorithms, and to do the layer-by-layer method or the Lars Petrus method fast, you would need to memorize several algorithms. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "gtregay" <Grant@T...> wrote: > I'm also working on a solution for beginners. I agree with Dan. Corners first made total sense to me. I spent a couple days looking for the easiest solution. The one I found was this. It is corners first, and there is nothing illogical about it! I have even taught my 10-year-old cousin how to do it. I think it really maters on how well it is explained and on personal preference. -Kenneth http://jjorg.chem.unc.edu/personal/monroe/cube/rubik.html --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "gosd123" <dgosbee@s...> wrote: > > > > I totally disagree with the following comment! > > "I think beginers > would have a problem with a corners first method mainly because its > illogical and won't make a whole lot of sense for an inexperienced > cuber. 1046. Re: Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 2002 23:09:06 -0000

I see that the consensus seems to be a corners first method. I don't
really know much about this method so could neither recommend it nor
reject it. One thing I would say is that it would be worth
considering is whether the method is adaptable further down the
track. Having a method that is easy to learn and can get you down to
1-2 mins without too much effort is good, but if it won't ever get
you down to 30s then consider whether it's worth putting in more
effort now to learn a method that's adaptable later on if you get
really keen.

Like I said, I don't know the corners first method so I don't know
how adaptable it is or what sort of times it can get you, I just know
that I've found it difficult to switch methods now that I know one
quite thoroughly!!

Having said all this, if the aim is just to be able to *do* the cube
(even if it takes several minutes) then it probably doesn't matter
too much which method you use. I've never seen a method that wouldn't
get you down to under 2 mins.



1047. Re: Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 01:18:51 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "promethee2003" <promethee2003@y...> wrote: > I'm looking for a simple method to do the cube, to teach children. > So , we need a minimum of algorithms ! > Do you have any suggestion ? > > Promethee Something I think works well for pretty much anybody (including little kids) is teach them a simple way to do the F2L, could be: like jessicas, lars, a hybrid of the 2, first layer then middle layer edges, or however they understand the F2L best. Then for the LL if you take a look @ Dan knights 4 look for LL, and take just the first alg for each look you could solve the cube. You would have to do each Step more than once to get it into position, but you only have to learn 4 algs! 7 if you count reflections... Im teaching one of my brothers friends like that. He is doing the F2L mostly like I do. I just showed him the algs for the LL the day before yesterday. I dont know how dedicate he is to learning the algs right away, but he is working on them. I gave him the algs over MSN messenger. So I bet there would be better (quicker) results if I show him in person how to do each step and how to hold the cube and all. ................. I think a simple corners first method would be good for kids too. There would be more algs to learn though. But not TOO many. -Heath
1048. Re: a different corners first question.
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 02:28:28 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., redkbrandon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > There are two algs for that and they are on Ron's page. It is on > the "orient and position last edge of top layer, and to orient the > middle layer edges," page. It is under "All top and bottom layer > edges are already in place" and then under "Last top layer edge is > twisted." > Hope this helps > > -Kenneth > Since I cant get that to work. Lets make sure im on the same 'page' as you. What im wanting to do is, when the last top layer edge is twisted; I want to orient the middle layer edges and flip the top layer edge at the same time. >From what I have found with those algs. The ones you said to use, the middle layer has to be oriented first, then you flip the last top edge, and flip the middle layer edges. I may be wrong, but the only way I can get those two algs to work is if I have the middle layer oriented first. If they're not oriented all that happens really is the top edge gets flipped. Am I totally losing my mind, by not being able to find the right way to understand this. Or am I right that the edges have to be oriented first.. just to make 100% sure, these are the algs that I was trying... RU2R'E2R2E'R'U2R'...and... LELELEL thanks again. -Heath
1049. Re: Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: rquethe <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 02:32:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I see that the consensus seems to be a corners first method. I don't > really know much about this method so could neither recommend it nor > reject it. One thing I would say is that it would be worth > considering is whether the method is adaptable further down the > track. Having a method that is easy to learn and can get you down to > 1-2 mins without too much effort is good, but if it won't ever get > you down to 30s then consider whether it's worth putting in more > effort now to learn a method that's adaptable later on if you get > really keen. > > Like I said, I don't know the corners first method so I don't know > how adaptable it is or what sort of times it can get you, I just know > that I've found it difficult to switch methods now that I know one > quite thoroughly!! > > Having said all this, if the aim is just to be able to *do* the cube > (even if it takes several minutes) then it probably doesn't matter > too much which method you use. I've never seen a method that wouldn't > get you down to under 2 mins. Of course it is adaptable. Like everyone's said, it's all personal preference. A proper corner's first system can get you into sub- twenty seconds with proper practice. Minh Thai used a corners first system and won the last championship. One thing I'd like to say. Although a corner's first system is certainly not illogical, one could make a case that a layer's system makes more sense( though not necessarily). All the cube newbies I've encountered have always tried to fix the cube layer by layer as opposed to some different approach to it. With the exception of a very smart friend of mine who learned the cube by himself and uses a corners system. Most people tend to think very linearally. When breaking apart problems, they do it in a fashion that is the simplest to visualize for them. It could be asserted that a layer or slice is easier for a newbie to understand than perhaps the corners of the cube. Of course, this really is dependant on the person and how they think. So it may be the best idea to introduce simplified versions of both systems and see what the general preference is.
1050. Re: Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 02:47:25 -0000

Your comments definitely make sense to me. When I first started cubing (no other cubers to talk to -- just me and my cube), I also attempted doing it layer-by-layer-by-layer. It never actually occurred to me to try anything else. It wasn't until my cubing skills got more advanced and I was able to talk to other cubers that I discovered there were quite a few other strategies, most of which were more efficient that the way I'd been doing it!! I also completely agree with the comments people have been making about personal preference being a factor. There is no answer to the question "which is THE best method?" (now I'm feeling post modern...). Some methods are okay for young beginners (eg. Lars', corners first), some would be very difficult for young beginners (eg. Jessica's). Of the methods that are okay for young beginners, it depends on how your brain works as to which one will be easier to pick understand and learn. I guess what I really meant when I first suggested Lars method is not that it is the best method for beginners, just that it is a suitable method for beginners. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., rquethe <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Of course it is adaptable. Like everyone's said, it's all personal > preference. A proper corner's first system can get you into sub- > twenty seconds with proper practice. Minh Thai used a corners first > system and won the last championship. > > One thing I'd like to say. Although a corner's first system is > certainly not illogical, one could make a case that a layer's system > makes more sense( though not necessarily). All the cube newbies I've > encountered have always tried to fix the cube layer by layer as > opposed to some different approach to it. With the exception of a > very smart friend of mine who learned the cube by himself and uses a > corners system. Most people tend to think very linearally. When > breaking apart problems, they do it in a fashion that is the simplest > to visualize for them. It could be asserted that a layer or slice is > easier for a newbie to understand than perhaps the corners of the > cube. > > Of course, this really is dependant on the person and how they think. > So it may be the best idea to introduce simplified versions of both > systems and see what the general preference is.
1051. Re: a different corners first question.
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 05:15:56 -0000

Lets see if I can help.
let me go through what you wrote..

> Since I cant get that to work. Lets make sure im on the
same 'page'
> as you. What im wanting to do is, when the last top layer edge is
> twisted; I want to orient the middle layer edges and flip the top
> layer edge at the same time.

So what you want to do is to orient all the edges. That is what
those algs do. Once you use the alg then you must position the
middle layer edges.

> From what I have found with those algs. The ones you said to use,
> the middle layer has to be oriented first, then you flip the last
top
> edge, and flip the middle layer edges.

I don't really know what you are meaning by saying flip and orient.
But from what I am guessing, you think that all the middle layer
edges must be oriented first then the alg orients the top edge, and
then after the doing the alg you must again orient the middle layer
edges?

>I may be wrong, but the only
> way I can get those two algs to work is if I have the middle layer
> oriented first. If they're not oriented all that happens really is
> the top edge gets flipped.

It is impossible to just flip only one edge.

>
> Am I totally losing my mind, by not being able to find the right
way
> to understand this. Or am I right that the edges have to be
oriented
> first..
>
> just to make 100% sure, these are the algs that I was trying...

My guess is that you are holding the cube wrong, or you might not be
sure of the reason for these algs.

Here is how you hold the cube for each alg:

This alg is for when there is the flipped edge in the top layer, and
one flipped one in the middle layer. Make sure that the edge in the
top layer is on the left side, and the one that needs flipping in the
middle layer is on the front right. Then do
> RU2R'E2R2E'R'U2R'...and...

This is for when there is the flipped edge in the top layer, and
three flipped in the middle layer. Again make sure that the edge in
the top layer is on the left side, and that the one that does not
need flipping in the middle layer is on the front left. Then do

>LELELEL

One last thing. You might want to try to do the algs on a finished
cube to get a better idea of what it is doing.

Good luck and I hope I haven't confused you more.

-Kenneth




1052. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 09:50:23 +0100

Here's my 2 cents ... When I first picked up the cube, it never occurred to me to do either corners-first or layer-by-layer. It seemed obvious to me to do one face, then a second face, then a third, etc. I worked out a method that did just that, doing opposite sides as a time. It took me about 10-20 minutes, nearly all that time spent getting the first two faces (after that its easy). The reason it took so long was because the algs. I had worked out did not cover all possible outcomes (so the solution was incomplete). But if I kept at it the cube eventually purmuted to a pattern that I could solve. Anyway, that was my intuition! S. >From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >Subject: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Rubik's for children (little bit >off topic) >Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 02:47:25 -0000 > >Your comments definitely make sense to me. 1054. Re: CUBE MOVIE
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 12:20:32 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > > Well, it's more like a kick in the head. I preferred Plan 9 From > > Outer Space. > > > Have you ever seen a Bruce Lee film called Game Of Death 2 ??? I have a film called Game Of Death 2 but I wouldn't really call it a Bruce Lee film. Sure he's in it but it was made long after he died using old footage. Also, his character dies in it pretty early on as he does something rather crazy involving a coffin and a helicopter. It's sort of an inverse to the (planned) Game Of Death, where the main guy has to go down an underground tower instead of up through floors of a building (as in Game Of Death), a building which would have been taller had Bruce Lee lived long enough to complete the film. It's a little while since I've watched Game Of Death 2, but I don't think it had bad mathematics in it.
1055. Re: Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 14:07:04 -0000

DanG ! Take it easy!! I'm not ripping on the corners first method.
For a BEGINNER cuber, with little or no understanding of the cube,
will have problems understanding it. What do most non cubers try to
do with the cube? Solve A FACE! Using a Layers method, I Feel,
works the best for non cubers because not only are you solving a FACE
but you teach to sovle the layer coresponding with the face. Think
back before you could solve the cube. you didn't automaticaly
think... Hey I'm going to solve all the corners first!... I have a
hard time believing that. With no help fro anybody or from the
internet, a layers method would be the easiest most logical way of
solving the cube.
If you would like to continue this argument just e-mail me
j_rueth@...



1056. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: "stiff_hands" <angela.hayden@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 15:03:02 -0000

This brought back memories...

"simonl cube" wrote:
> When I first picked up the cube, it never occurred to me to do
either corners-first or layer-by-layer. It seemed obvious to me to
do one face, then a second face, then a third, etc.

...when I first picked up a cube I wasn't sure what to do and tried
various things. Not being a rigorous mathematician at that age I
couldn't work out complex algs. Having got nowhere with corners first
and got stuck at two layers with layers first I came up with the
method you describe. I got nowhere with that either. Oh well.

I think layer first is easier for a beginner playing with a cube
without help (in person or internet) to make progress with, but I
think corner first is just as easy if it is being taught.

stiff_hands



1057. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 08:47:17 -0700

Probably true, but the problem is that layer-ny-layer is such a bad
method. It hurts to think that people are taught it. Once you've
learned a method, it's very hard to unlearn it, so you're condemning
those people to a life time of inferior cubing.

/Lars

At 2:07 PM +0000 8/23/02, j_rueth wrote:
>DanG ! Take it easy!! I'm not ripping on the corners first method.
>For a BEGINNER cuber, with little or no understanding of the cube,
>will have problems understanding it. What do most non cubers try to
>do with the cube? Solve A FACE! Using a Layers method, I Feel,
>works the best for non cubers because not only are you solving a FACE
>but you teach to sovle the layer coresponding with the face. Think
>back before you could solve the cube. you didn't automaticaly
>think... Hey I'm going to solve all the corners first!... I have a
>hard time believing that. With no help fro anybody or from the
>internet, a layers method would be the easiest most logical way of
>solving the cube.
>If you would like to continue this argument just e-mail me
>j_rueth@...

--
"They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever
flipped it over?"

Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@... http://lar5.com


1058. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: "theboywholived81" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 17:57:25 -0000

I totally agree with you. In order to make the layer-by-layter method fast, you need to memorize about 100 algorithms. Layer by layer is the first one I learned, and I learned about twenty algorithms and I could do it in an average of 2 minutes 15 seconds. Corners is definitely the best way that is also easy. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Lars Petrus <lars@l...> wrote: > Probably true, but the problem is that layer-ny-layer is such a bad > method. It hurts to think that people are taught it. Once you've > learned a method, it's very hard to unlearn it, so you're condemning > those people to a life time of inferior cubing. > > /Lars > > At 2:07 PM +0000 8/23/02, j_rueth wrote: > >DanG ! Take it easy!! I'm not ripping on the corners first method. > >For a BEGINNER cuber, with little or no understanding of the cube, > >will have problems understanding it. What do most non cubers try to > >do with the cube? Solve A FACE! Using a Layers method, I Feel, > >works the best for non cubers because not only are you solving a FACE > >but you teach to sovle the layer coresponding with the face. Think > >back before you could solve the cube. you didn't automaticaly > >think... Hey I'm going to solve all the corners first!... I have a > >hard time believing that. With no help fro anybody or from the > >internet, a layers method would be the easiest most logical way of > >solving the cube. > >If you would like to continue this argument just e-mail me > >j_rueth@y... > > -- > "They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever > flipped it over?" > > Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@l... http://lar5.com
1059. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: "gtregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 18:12:08 -0000

Okay, I'd avoided the argumentative portion of this discussion so far, but I had to respond to this one! Lars - I realize your method isn't a "typical" layer by layer method (cross, F2L, LL), but it is still essentially layer by layer (unless you've converted to a corners first method). There are just two relatively minor differences: 1) you don't wait for U edges to be complete before starting work on the rest of the F2L 2) you orient D edges before completing the F2L So, are you also complaining about having learned the method that you use? Secondly, are you saying that layer by layer is bad in general ("you're condemning those people to a life time of inferior cubing")? I was under the impression that several sub 20 speed cubists used a layer by layer method, making it arguable which is "better". Using the layer by layer method, I personally average under 35 seconds. I realize this is by no means spectacular, but I'm still using a 3 look LL, and my F2L leaves quite a bit to be desired (I'm very poor at looking ahead, but I'm working on it). When I was first trying to speed things up, I tried learning a standard layer by layer method and your method. I found your method for the F2L to be difficult, but maybe I just didn't spend enough time working through it. Just recently I've looked into using the corners first method. I don't have any algs memorized yet, but using algs found on speedcubing.com and elsewhere, I've found that it takes me at least 60-70 steps, while using my regular method, I can routinely solve in 50-60 steps. Again, I may just have a poor grasp of how to do it, but I can't make the corners first method very efficient. That said, I don't see why a layer by layer method should be labeled as "such a bad method" since the other options don't seem reasonable for any sort of speed for me (obviously not in general though, because there are those who can use the other methods and solve in sub 20 times). --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Lars Petrus <lars@l...> wrote: > Probably true, but the problem is that layer-ny-layer is such a bad > method. It hurts to think that people are taught it. Once you've > learned a method, it's very hard to unlearn it, so you're condemning > those people to a life time of inferior cubing. > > /Lars > > -- > "They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever > flipped it over?" > > Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@l... http://lar5.com

1061. Re: Rubik's for children (little bit off topic)
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 2002 19:45:50 -0000

A corners first method is not as hard to comprehend as you think. The way I learned was to solve a face, then solve the bottom corners, then the bottom edges. As a beginner I didn't think of it as a corners first, but as solving a face then the opposite face and then the middle. I ended up having to learn only three algs to do the cube. Using this method as a beginner really appealed to me, and everyone I teach. To say corners-first is harder to comprehend as a beginner, is ridiculous. My 2 cents. -Kenneth --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "gosd123" <dgosbee@s...> wrote: > > its not an arguement nor am i argueing!!! > > > > your totally wrong with your comments.......period!! and you cannot > > provide me with any explaination other than personal preference... > > > > thats all for me on this subject.... > > > > > > if you want to continue you email me...!! > > > > haha > > > > > > Don't be such a baby! We are simply stating opinions and not > trying to knock everyone down. Using a simple layers method is > easily adaptible to the f2l and a 2 look final layer. > > I just gave you several of reasons in my previous post. So far no > one has been convincing me with any reasons for the corners method. > I take back saying that the corners method is illogical, but it is > impractical for beginers to comprehend!!! This is fun, keep at it!!! > Jake > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > DanG ! Take it easy!! 1064. Re: a different corners first question.
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 00:50:26 -0000

lets try this a different way.

heres my situation; the last top layer edge is in place, but
twisted. And the middle layer edges are totally scrambled. What i
want to do is flip that top layer edge so it is correct (which those
algs do), and i want to orient the middle layer edges all in one alg.

the move LELELEL solves the cube when you need one top layer edge
flipped, and 3 middle layer edges flipped. as i said earlier my
middle layer edges aren't oriented yet. but that move does work
great when all the middle layer edges are in place but 3 need flipped.

if you still dont understand, then i guess im doing something wrong.
I have no idea what though, because I would bet my best speed cube
that I am right. And if i am doing somethin wrong i guess im a lost
cause. so i'll just have to figure out the algs im lookin for
another way....(maybe usin Rons cube solver)....

till next time.
-Heath

1070. What does "layer by layer" mean?
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 11:05:20 -0700

We're using different terms here. When I say "layer by layer" [LBL] I mean a method where you first build the first layer, then the second, and finally the third. This is painfully inefficient, since with one solved layer, there is absolutely nothing meaningful you can do with out breaking up that layer. So all the algorithms go 1. Break up the first layer 2. Do something useful 3. Restore the first layer Obviously, that first layer is really just a decoration, not a true step on the way to the solution. Good solutions only have algs of type 2 in them. It seems you think of any method that ends up with solving a final layer as a LBL method. I'm not saying that is right or wrong, only that that is not what I meant. The LBL methods ugly cousin is the face by face method, which is probably *really* the first method most people try. It is in disrepute due to be almost impossible to solve by though. To be clear: The Jessica method is not at all a LBL method with my definition. I like to think of it as the LBL method, with the steps 3 and 1 taken out of it. Which of course makes it a non LBL method... But it makes sense to me... /Lars At 6:12 PM +0000 8/23/02, gtregay wrote: >Okay, I'd avoided the argumentative portion of this discussion so >far, but I had to respond to this one! > >Lars - I realize your method isn't a "typical" layer by layer method >(cross, F2L, LL), but it is still essentially layer by layer (unless >you've converted to a corners first method). There are just two >relatively minor differences: >1) you don't wait for U edges to be complete before starting work on >the rest of the F2L >2) you orient D edges before completing the F2L >So, are you also complaining about having learned the method that you >use? Secondly, are you saying that layer by layer is bad in general >("you're condemning those people to a life time of inferior >cubing")? I was under the impression that several sub 20 speed >cubists used a layer by layer method, making it arguable which >is "better". > >Using the layer by layer method, I personally average under 35 >seconds. I realize this is by no means spectacular, but I'm still >using a 3 look LL, and my F2L leaves quite a bit to be desired (I'm >very poor at looking ahead, but I'm working on it). When I was first >trying to speed things up, I tried learning a standard layer by layer >method and your method. I found your method for the F2L to be >difficult, but maybe I just didn't spend enough time working through >it. > >Just recently I've looked into using the corners first method. I >don't have any algs memorized yet, but using algs found on >speedcubing.com and elsewhere, I've found that it takes me at least >60-70 steps, while using my regular method, I can routinely solve in >50-60 steps. Again, I may just have a poor grasp of how to do it, >but I can't make the corners first method very efficient. > >That said, I don't see why a layer by layer method should be labeled >as "such a bad method" since the other options don't seem reasonable >for any sort of speed for me (obviously not in general though, >because there are those who can use the other methods and solve in >sub 20 times). > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Lars Petrus <lars@l...> wrote: >> Probably true, but the problem is that layer-ny-layer is such a bad >> method. It hurts to think that people are taught it. Once you've >> learned a method, it's very hard to unlearn it, so you're >condemning >> those people to a life time of inferior cubing. >> >> /Lars >> >> -- >> "They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever >> flipped it over?" >> >> Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@l... <http://lar5.com>http://lar5.com > >Yahoo! Groups Sponsor > >To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: >speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > > >Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the ><http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/>Yahoo! Terms of Service. -- "They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever flipped it over?" Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@... http://lar5.com [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1071. Re: CUBE MOVIE

1072. Re: What does "layer by layer" mean?
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 18:33:32 -0000

The layer by layer method is indeed inefficient for speed. Well, I
guess it isn't too bad, my friend is doing a LBL with a 4 or 5 look
last layer in under a minute. He has a personal best in the 40's.
The thing about a LBL is that it is easily adabptable to an F2l and a
2 look LL.
Lars method isn't exactly a LBL method. But it has its similarites.
Its more of a "cube constructing" or an "expanding" plan. When i
first started cubing, i thought the most logical way of solving was
creating a 2x2 then a 2x2x3 then a 2x3x3. It worked but I wasn't
good at it. I don't think i got under 2 min using it. But then
again I was a beginer with no understanding.

Also the corners first method is also similar to a LBL method. Once
you complete the corners, some do top layer, middle layer, and final
the bottom layer. Some do top and bottom with middle last. But All
solutions has their ties with a LBL method. They just have their own
unique twist to them



1073. Re: What does "layer by layer" mean?
From: "gtregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 2002 19:00:22 -0000

Okay, I get what you're saying now - yes layer by layer is bad, but as j_rueth points out in another message, layer by layer does adapt well to a F2L and 2 look LL method, which can end up very fast. I think, then, that we agree. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Lars Petrus <lars@l...> wrote: > We're using different terms here. When I say "layer by layer" [LBL] I > mean a method where you first build the first layer, then the second, > and finally the third. > > This is painfully inefficient, since with one solved layer, there is > absolutely nothing meaningful you can do with out breaking up that > layer. So all the algorithms go > > 1. Break up the first layer > 2. Do something useful > 3. Restore the first layer > > Obviously, that first layer is really just a decoration, not a true > step on the way to the solution. Good solutions only have algs of > type 2 in them. > > It seems you think of any method that ends up with solving a final > layer as a LBL method. I'm not saying that is right or wrong, only > that that is not what I meant. > > The LBL methods ugly cousin is the face by face method, which is > probably *really* the first method most people try. It is in > disrepute due to be almost impossible to solve by though. > > To be clear: The Jessica method is not at all a LBL method with my > definition. I like to think of it as the LBL method, with the steps 3 > and 1 taken out of it. Which of course makes it a non LBL method... > But it makes sense to me... > > /Lars >

1077. Re: Cuber's Curse
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

1079. Re: What does "layer by layer" mean?
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 25 Aug 2002 03:15:06 -0000

This is exactly what I meant when I said 'layer-by-layer-by-layer' method. I used this phrase to distinguish it from the more sophistocated and more efficient F2L/LL layer methods. Jasmine. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Lars Petrus <lars@l...> wrote: > We're using different terms here. When I say "layer by layer" [LBL] I > mean a method where you first build the first layer, then the second, > and finally the third. > > This is painfully inefficient, since with one solved layer, there is > absolutely nothing meaningful you can do with out breaking up that > layer. So all the algorithms go > > 1. Break up the first layer > 2. Do something useful > 3. Restore the first layer > > Obviously, that first layer is really just a decoration, not a true > step on the way to the solution. Good solutions only have algs of > type 2 in them. > > It seems you think of any method that ends up with solving a final > layer as a LBL method. I'm not saying that is right or wrong, only > that that is not what I meant. > > The LBL methods ugly cousin is the face by face method, which is > probably *really* the first method most people try. It is in > disrepute due to be almost impossible to solve by though. > > To be clear: The Jessica method is not at all a LBL method with my > definition. I like to think of it as the LBL method, with the steps 3 > and 1 taken out of it. Which of course makes it a non LBL method... > But it makes sense to me... > > /Lars > > At 6:12 PM +0000 8/23/02, gtregay wrote: > >Okay, I'd avoided the argumentative portion of this discussion so > >far, but I had to respond to this one! > > > >Lars - I realize your method isn't a "typical" layer by layer method > >(cross, F2L, LL), but it is still essentially layer by layer (unless > >you've converted to a corners first method). There are just two > >relatively minor differences: > >1) you don't wait for U edges to be complete before starting work on > >the rest of the F2L > >2) you orient D edges before completing the F2L > >So, are you also complaining about having learned the method that you > >use? Secondly, are you saying that layer by layer is bad in general > >("you're condemning those people to a life time of inferior > >cubing")? I was under the impression that several sub 20 speed > >cubists used a layer by layer method, making it arguable which > >is "better". > > > >Using the layer by layer method, I personally average under 35 > >seconds. I realize this is by no means spectacular, but I'm still > >using a 3 look LL, and my F2L leaves quite a bit to be desired (I'm > >very poor at looking ahead, but I'm working on it). When I was first > >trying to speed things up, I tried learning a standard layer by layer > >method and your method. I found your method for the F2L to be > >difficult, but maybe I just didn't spend enough time working through > >it. > > > >Just recently I've looked into using the corners first method. I > >don't have any algs memorized yet, but using algs found on > >speedcubing.com and elsewhere, I've found that it takes me at least > >60-70 steps, while using my regular method, I can routinely solve in > >50-60 steps. Again, I may just have a poor grasp of how to do it, > >but I can't make the corners first method very efficient. > > > >That said, I don't see why a layer by layer method should be labeled > >as "such a bad method" since the other options don't seem reasonable > >for any sort of speed for me (obviously not in general though, > >because there are those who can use the other methods and solve in > >sub 20 times). > > > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Lars Petrus <lars@l...> wrote: > >> Probably true, but the problem is that layer-ny-layer is such a bad > >> method. It hurts to think that people are taught it. Once you've > >> learned a method, it's very hard to unlearn it, so you're > >condemning > >> those people to a life time of inferior cubing. > >> > >> /Lars > >> > >> -- > >> "They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever > >> flipped it over?" > >> > >> Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@l... <http://lar5.com>http://lar5.com > > > >Yahoo! Groups Sponsor > > > >To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > >speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@y... > > > > > > > >Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the > ><http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/>Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > -- > "They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever > flipped it over?" > > Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@l... http://lar5.com > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1080. Best place to buy Rubik's stuff online?
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 25 Aug 2002 03:23:05 -0000

I've finally accepted that the 4x4x4 and the 5x5x5 cubes are NEVER
going to be available in Australia and my only option is to get them
online. As I've mentioned before, I'm skeptical about buying a cube
without being able to see it first, so I'm relying on you guys to
tell me where is a good place to get the Revenge and the Professor
online? With the exchange rate what it is, and with international
post from the other side of the world this isn't going to be cheap so
I want the cube to be a good cube!

Thanks in advance,

Jasmine.



1081. Re: Best place to buy Rubik's stuff online?
From: rquethe <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 25 Aug 2002 05:00:13 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I've finally accepted that the 4x4x4 and the 5x5x5 cubes are NEVER > going to be available in Australia and my only option is to get them > online. As I've mentioned before, I'm skeptical about buying a cube > without being able to see it first, so I'm relying on you guys to > tell me where is a good place to get the Revenge and the Professor > online? With the exchange rate what it is, and with international > post from the other side of the world this isn't going to be cheap so > I want the cube to be a good cube! > > Thanks in advance, > > Jasmine. Rubiks.com and Mefferts are both good for the 4x4x4... As far as the 5x5x5 goes, I believe Meffert's is the only makers of it unless you can find an old one on E-bay or something. I had bad luck TWICE with buying the Professor's cube at Meffert's, so I'm a bit sore about that. You still may get a functional cube from them though. And shipping is free! If the cube doesn't work you can send it back for full refund.

at the edges already.

J,

I would have to recommend one of these babies, especially the Rubenking.

http://cubeman.vg-network.com/cubesell.html

Forget about speed cubing, or at least mine are not good for speed cubing.
But they are fantastically fiendishly difficult!

Oh, and as for rubiks.com not doing the 5x5x5... perhaps they will soon.
Nudge nudge wink wink.

I bought a Rubik's brand cube > from a department store earlier in the year and it was kinda stiff > (even after lubing) and the stickers are pretty crap and are wearing > at the edges already. > > In addition to the 4x4x4, the 5x5x5 and the Megaminx I'm thinking > about buying, I already have many varieties of the 3x3x3, the 2x2x2, > Square-1, Pyraminx, Impossiball and a Skewb. The only potential problems with it are the stickers and the fact that it is kind of stiff to move. Don't buy meffert's 3x3x3, the assembly cube is horrible for cubing fast. Meffert's has good Square-1, pyraminx and skewb.

extent, but it is still not very effective. I've tried rubbing,
scratching etc and have had little success. Anyone have any remedies?

1088. Re: Sticky stuff under the stickers?

Did Rubik's change their stickers? Me and some friends bought some
cubes at Wal-mart. Before the stickers started peeling right away.
But the cubes we recently bought, the stickers are quite nice and
aren't peeling. We've had them for quite some time! Still no
peeling!!! Does anyone know?
Jake



1089. Re: Best place to buy Rubik's stuff online?
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 25 Aug 2002 14:48:26 -0000

I am enjoying my 4x4 from rubiks. The stickers are pretty bad. My
friend has had one for some time as well. I think the big problem
with the 4x4 is that the centers like to break.
5x5s on the other hand... Mefferts are ok. They turn nice, but for
speeding they like to grab and rotate the center corner cubies.
Often when I'm using it, a 2x2x5 group tends to pop out. So i try not
to use it to often. Instead i have a 5x5 that i bought almost a year
ago off of ebay. No troubles with this one. Don't know who makes it
or who sells em. But that 5x5 worked best for me!
For other puzzles the skewb is tons of fun and easy to solve. It is
a fast puzzle

Speaking of skewbs, is anyone skewbing at the RWC?

Jake



1090. Re: Sticky stuff under the stickers?
From: "theboywholived81" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 25 Aug 2002 15:02:42 -0000

Something that I like to do with the cube, is wait a week or two for the plasticky film to start coming off, then take off just the plastic. Then I wash it because there's some stickyness on it, then I paint it. It works really well. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > GOO GONE WORKED FOR ME!!! > > Did Rubik's change their stickers? We've had them for quite some time! Still no > peeling!!! Does anyone know? > Jake

1092. Re: Sticky stuff under the stickers?
From: "simonlcube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 25 Aug 2002 17:40:04 -0000

> How do you remove that? <snip> Anyone have any remedies? Dip a cotton bud into white spirit and gently clean the cube face with that. It will take a few seconds to completely clean. Dry with a paper towel. S.
1093. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Sticky stuff under the stickers?
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 25 Aug 2002 18:48:45 +0100

> How do you remove that? <snip> Anyone have any remedies? Maybe I'll get flamed for this; I like to strip my cube down and place all the corners and edges in a bowl of water from a just boiled kettle. Leave them there for about 10 minutes and then take them out one by one while towelling the goo off. You can also give the fixings a wipe too, ready for lubing as well as fresh stickers. Am I being a plank? I must warn that the corners can end up with water in them, but it will drain out eventually.
1094. Re: What does "layer by layer" mean?
From: kappa962 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 25 Aug 2002 18:37:23 -0000

I don't understand how Jessica's method doesn't qualify as a LBL
method under this description. Every F2l alg breaks up what is
solved on the first layer, and subsequently restores it.
Furthermore, if you slightly reword the three steps, the LL algs
also fit into this catagory.

1. Take apart what you have already solved
2. Do something useful
3. Put it back together

With a few algorithms omitting step 2 to become

1. Take apart what you have already solved
3. Put it back together in a different way than you took it apart

- Mark

> layer. So all the algorithms go
>
> 1. Break up the first layer
> 2. Do something useful
> 3. Restore the first layer
>
> Obviously, that first layer is really just a
> decoration, not a true step on the way to the
> solution. Good solutions only have algs of
> type 2 in them.
>
> To be clear: The Jessica method is not at all
> a LBL method with my definition. I like to
> think of it as the LBL method, with the steps
> 3 and 1 taken out of it. Which of course makes
> it a non LBL method...
> /Lars




1095. [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Sticky stuff under the stickers?
From: "jazzthief81" <lars.vandenbergh@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 25 Aug 2002 20:28:38 -0000

That's also how I clean my cubes, Robert. It works very well. If I only need to replace a few stickers, I just remove the glue with a damp towel. But I never use strong glue to put the stickers on so I can clean it more easily afterwards. I used to use Super Glue but it ruins your cube. The stickers still hold very well with the one I use now. Lars --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > > How do you remove that? <snip> Anyone have any remedies? > > Maybe I'll get flamed for this; I like to strip my cube down and place all > the corners and edges in a bowl of water from a just boiled kettle. Leave > them there for about 10 minutes and then take them out one by one while > towelling the goo off. You can also give the fixings a wipe too, ready for > lubing as well as fresh stickers. > > Am I being a plank? I must warn that the corners can end up with water in > them, but it will drain out eventually.

1098. Re: What does "layer by layer" mean?
From: rquethe <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 02:01:23 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., kappa962 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I don't understand how Jessica's method doesn't qualify as a LBL > method under this description. Every F2l alg breaks up what is > solved on the first layer, and subsequently restores it. > Furthermore, if you slightly reword the three steps, the LL algs > also fit into this catagory. > > 1. Take apart what you have already solved > 2. Do something useful > 3. Put it back together > > With a few algorithms omitting step 2 to become > > 1. Take apart what you have already solved > 3. Put it back together in a different way than you took it apart > > - Mark > I disagree. Once you have the cross formed, each F2L algorithm places corner/edge pairs into "slots." And you've broken nothing. If you wasted time putting a corners and edges in seperately, then you would be breaking the first layer. This is not the case though. You're sort of right about the last layer, but by the time any method gets down to its last steps, you have to temporarily break parts that you've already done.

Hi! I placed an order from Rubiksshop.com I bought 3x3x3 and 4x4x4. Also bought extra stickers for both, and there cube-lub. The lub isn´t that good, so I wouldn´t recomend you to buy it. I also didn´t like the 3x3x3 cube. The center pieces are a little larger than the rest which makes it turn poorly. I think I was unlucky getting one that´s sort of defect. The 4x4x4 is great. Turns smoothly and feels great! At first I thought the freight cost was way to high. $15 USD. But when I got a knock on my door from Schenker (freight company like UPS) with my cubes I was impressed. Even a taxi costs more than $15 to my home. So with this in mind it wasn´t so expensive. But I do think they should have a cheaper alternativ where I go to the post office and sign for it instead. /Parrot --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I've finally accepted that the 4x4x4 and the 5x5x5 cubes are NEVER > going to be available in Australia and my only option is to get them > online. With the exchange rate what it is, and with international > post from the other side of the world this isn't going to be cheap so > I want the cube to be a good cube! > > Thanks in advance, > > Jasmine.
1101. Looking ahead: a practice routine?
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 11:28:43 +0100

Hi everyone. I have been working on getting my F2L times down, and on the
bus one night last week I suddenly had the following idea for a practice
routine that might be helpful ...

The F2L requires moving four corner/edge pairs (CEPs) into four "slots". So
four sequences are required to complete F2L. There are sets of algorithyms
that do not disturb the other three slots, and usually people learn these
first. Sometimes it is possible to slot a CEP using a shorter algorithm
that displaces one or more slots: these shortcuts can be used when you know
that the slots being displaced have not yet been solved.

So, you end up becoming familiar with a whole bunch of algorithms for
solving F2L.

OK; for the rest of this email I am ignoring inflections and inversions.

The shortest algorithm for slotting a CEP is either:
R U R' OR R U'R'
If I am able to slot a CEP with one of these and nothing else I feel pretty
lucky! Most of the time I need a longer algorithm, BUT: nearly all of the
algorithms I use end with R U R'/R U'R' (there are a few exceptions). In
other words, I do a 3-move sequence that sets the CEP up so that R U R'/R
U'R' does the trick.

So, when I do the F2L (cross on bottom) the solving process divides into two
parts:
1) LOOK:
1a) find a CEP that needs solving
1b) note where the corresponding slot is
1c) identify the best (i.e. quickest) algorithm to use (so really plan all
of step 2), that follows
2) EXECUTE, without a pause, the following:
2a) U/U'/U2 - 1 in 4 chance that this is needed, but using alternative
sequences reduces this
2b) some 3-move sequence
2c) R U R'/R U'R'
1) look: identify another CEP etc.
2) execute
1) ... etc., four times

This ends up as follows (everything in brackets is done without pause):
look - (some 3/4-move sequence + R U R'/R U'R') - look - (some 3/4-move
sequence + R U R'/R U'R') - look - (some 3/4-move sequence + R U R'/R U'R')
- look - (some 3/4-move sequence + R U R'/R U'R')

To speed this up, the general advice is "look ahead": that is, combine the
looking with the executing. Another usual tip here is to slow down, which
funnily enough makes sense: slowing down makes it easier to do that looking
ahead stuff.

OK, here's my idea. As a practice routine, try this instead:
look - (some 3/4 move sequence) - look - (R U R'/R U'R' + some 3/4 move
sequence) - look - (R U R'/R U'R' + some 3/4 move sequence) - look - (R U
R'/R U'R' + some 3/4 move sequence + R U R'/R U'R')

In other words, split the slotting process so that you force yourself to
work out the BEST move sequence for the next CEP before completing the
sequence at hand.

If you find this too hard to start with, then you could do this instead:
look - (some 3/4 move sequence + R U/R U') - look - (R' + some 3/4 move
sequence + R U/R U') - look - (R' + some 3/4 move sequence + R U/R U') -
look - (R' + some 3/4 move sequence + R U R'/R U'R')
and then graduate up to looking two moves ahead, and then three moves ahead.

I think that by practising in this way, it might be possible to get a handle
on this "looking ahead" business. At the very least, it starts getting your
brain into a looking ahead frame of mind

What do you all think?
S.



_________________________________________________________________
Join the world�s largest e-mail service with MSN Hotmail.
http://www.hotmail.com



1102. Re: Looking ahead: a practice routine?
From: "jessica_fridrich" <jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 12:42:10 -0000

Simon, you are right! This is what I meant in my posting No. 801 in hint No. 2. Today, I am planning to post on my page examples of how I solve and how I think during the F2L so that you can see those little tricks I use in F2L (and some of them are of the type you mentioned in your e-mail). Jessica --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "simonl cube" <simonlcube@h...> wrote: > Hi everyone. I have been working on getting my F2L times down, and on the > bus one night last week I suddenly had the following idea for a practice > routine that might be helpful ... > > The F2L requires moving four corner/edge pairs (CEPs) into four "slots". So > four sequences are required to complete F2L. There are sets of algorithyms > that do not disturb the other three slots, and usually people learn these > first. Sometimes it is possible to slot a CEP using a shorter algorithm > that displaces one or more slots: these shortcuts can be used when you know > that the slots being displaced have not yet been solved. > > So, you end up becoming familiar with a whole bunch of algorithms for > solving F2L. > > OK; for the rest of this email I am ignoring inflections and inversions. > > The shortest algorithm for slotting a CEP is either: > R U R' OR R U'R' > If I am able to slot a CEP with one of these and nothing else I feel pretty > lucky! Most of the time I need a longer algorithm, BUT: nearly all of the > algorithms I use end with R U R'/R U'R' (there are a few exceptions). In > other words, I do a 3-move sequence that sets the CEP up so that R U R'/R > U'R' does the trick. > > So, when I do the F2L (cross on bottom) the solving process divides into two > parts: > 1) LOOK: > 1a) find a CEP that needs solving > 1b) note where the corresponding slot is > 1c) identify the best (i.e. quickest) algorithm to use (so really plan all > of step 2), that follows > 2) EXECUTE, without a pause, the following: > 2a) U/U'/U2 - 1 in 4 chance that this is needed, but using alternative > sequences reduces this > 2b) some 3-move sequence > 2c) R U R'/R U'R' > 1) look: identify another CEP etc. > 2) execute > 1) ... etc., four times > > This ends up as follows (everything in brackets is done without pause): > look - (some 3/4-move sequence + R U R'/R U'R') - look - (some 3/4- move > sequence + R U R'/R U'R') - look - (some 3/4-move sequence + R U R'/R U'R') > - look - (some 3/4-move sequence + R U R'/R U'R') > > To speed this up, the general advice is "look ahead": that is, combine the > looking with the executing. Another usual tip here is to slow down, which > funnily enough makes sense: slowing down makes it easier to do that looking > ahead stuff. > > OK, here's my idea. As a practice routine, try this instead: > look - (some 3/4 move sequence) - look - (R U R'/R U'R' + some 3/4 move > sequence) - look - (R U R'/R U'R' + some 3/4 move sequence) - look - (R U > R'/R U'R' + some 3/4 move sequence + R U R'/R U'R') > > In other words, split the slotting process so that you force yourself to > work out the BEST move sequence for the next CEP before completing the > sequence at hand. > > If you find this too hard to start with, then you could do this instead: > look - (some 3/4 move sequence + R U/R U') - look - (R' + some 3/4 move > sequence + R U/R U') - look - (R' + some 3/4 move sequence + R U/R U') - > look - (R' + some 3/4 move sequence + R U R'/R U'R') > and then graduate up to looking two moves ahead, and then three moves ahead. > > I think that by practising in this way, it might be possible to get a handle > on this "looking ahead" business. At the very least, it starts getting your > brain into a looking ahead frame of mind > > What do you all think? > S.
1103. See how I solve the F2L
From: "jessica_fridrich" <jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 14:02:50 -0000

As I promised, here are a few examples of how I solve (and think)
during the F2L:

http://www.ssie.binghamton.edu/fridrich/examples.html

On this page, I ask you to scramble the cube using a scrambling
algorithm that I provide and then I walk you step-by-step through
different possibilities for the cross and corner-edge pairs showing
little tricks along the way.

I also added to my page the hints I posted in message No. 801:

http://www.ssie.binghamton.edu/fridrich/f2l.html

Both pages are linked through my main cube and system pages.

Let me know if this is useful.

Jessica



1104. Re: Best place to buy Rubik's stuff online?
From: "gtregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 21:46:53 -0000

I bought a megaminx from Mefferts a couple years ago, when they came with tiles. If you don't like the stickers, you can always buy a set of tiles for $12 (but keep in mind you'll have to glue on all 132 of them!). Mine didn't move very well at first (my first time-trials were more than 8 minutes after breaking it in quite a bit), but with some silicone lube, and a lot of playing with it, it's become farily smooth (my average solve now is around 3 minutes even). As far as the assembly cube, I would have to agree - they aren't good for speed. You will find that overturning becomes a real problem - it almost moves too easily. Also, they don't have the give required for finger tricks. > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > And what about Meffert's Megaminx? I was thinking about getting one > of > > those too. And what about their 3x3x3? --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., rquethe <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I have a friend who bought Meffert's Megaminx and he liked it. The > only potential problems with it are the stickers and the fact that it > is kind of stiff to move. Don't buy meffert's 3x3x3, the assembly > cube is horrible for cubing fast. Meffert's has good Square-1, > pyraminx and skewb.
1105. Re: 4x4 Help!!
From: "gtregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 2002 22:50:48 -0000

Let me preface what I say with this; I've found that at least for working with the oinkleburger.com applet, centers last ends up having many more moves than centers first. Therefore, you may want to consider trying centers first. However, as my master cube is currently broken, I can't really test the alternatives on a physical 4x4x4 cube, so feel free to disregard this advice! Also, fixing the parity problems encountered with a centers first method can require some fairly lengthly algs to be memorized. Anyways, these may not be the most efficient algs to use, but try this. I'm not sure what semantics you're used to, but here's what I'll use: 1) r, u, and d are the slices next to R, U, and D respectively 2) E' is equivelant to ud' 3) Centers will be described by their face and position on the face (e.g. Fdr is the center on F in the d and r slices) For each sequence I'll indicate either which pieces move from F and D or which stay in their respecive faces. 2 pair swap - moves Fdr, Fdl, Dbr, and Dbl (rd'r'd)F'(rd'r'd)D'(rd'r'd)DF 2 treo swap - leaves Ful and Dbl (rE'r'E)F'(rE'r'E)D2(rE'r'E)D2F Face swap - moves all 4 centers from D to F and vice versa (rE'r'E)F2(rE'r'E)D2(rE'r'E)D2F2 Try it out. Let me know if I made a mistake. Good luck! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > My 4x4 this past year has definately improved much this year. I do a > centers last method and was wondering if anyone has any algs to move > two or more centers from the D face to the F face. Any info will be > appreciated > Jake
1106. Megaminx
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 2002 12:12:59 -0000


Is the 6 colour megaminx or the 12 colour megaminx more difficult?
I got a megaminx a while back but some of the stickers started to
fall off almost immediately, so I have decided to paint it (plus
some of my cubes) and I want to know which is harder.

Certainly the corner pieces have positions uniquely determined in
either puzzle and in that respect the 6 colour one is arguably
harder as it requires more time to determine where a corner belongs,
but possibly the similar edge pieces in a 6 colour puzzle can be
permuted in different ways (using double transpositions) that can't
arise in a 12 colour one - yielding more solutions. I imagine that
latter possibility can arise.

So, should I paint it with 12 colours or with 6?

At the moment I only have 1 colour, : ), which is blue, which I
picked up today. One of the blue stickers from my 5x5x5 is missing
so I hope to start doing the blue face of that and then go on to the
others if it seems to work (and if I can get the colours).



1107. Re: Megaminx
From: krrash <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 2002 17:43:35 -0000

With a 6 color megaminx, you might be able to locate your edge pieces more quickly in the beginning because there are two of each piece and you only need to find one of them, but on the other hand the 12 color megaminx has fewer pieces with each color, so if you are looking for a piece with a specific color, it should stand out more. At the end you can have a parity problem which requires swapping two opposite edge pieces. The 12 color megaminx shouldn't have parity problems. It might also be interesting to look for a different color arrangement of the 6 color megaminx that doesn't have identical colors opposite each other but retains some sort of symmetry. The parity problem might be easier because you could have identical pieces that are closer together. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Is the 6 colour megaminx or the 12 colour megaminx more difficult? > I got a megaminx a while back but some of the stickers started to > fall off almost immediately, so I have decided to paint it (plus > some of my cubes) and I want to know which is harder. > > Certainly the corner pieces have positions uniquely determined in > either puzzle and in that respect the 6 colour one is arguably > harder as it requires more time to determine where a corner belongs, > but possibly the similar edge pieces in a 6 colour puzzle can be > permuted in different ways (using double transpositions) that can't > arise in a 12 colour one - yielding more solutions. I imagine that > latter possibility can arise.

Date: Tue, 27 Aug 2002 20:13:29 +0200

method do you use? Is your cube lubed enough? Are your finger tricks
efficient? Do you look ahead?

Another thing people tend to notice is that you may get stuck in a specific
timeframe for a long time and then suddenly, one day, you will drop a few
seconds without any seemingly good reason.

>I'm trying to get my times lower, as my current average is about
