I was takin a look at the Unofficial World Records page just now and
noticed he had some pretty impressive records in the Unique records
category...(and for speedcubing a 3x3x3 too)...

1263. your first cube...
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 2002 02:39:30 -0000

ok this serves no real value, I just want to hear the stories on how
everyone got their first cube. Or the first time they ever played
with a Rubiks Cube...



I think when I bought my first cube it was on the way home from a Ski
trip. This was more than a year before i got into cubing i think. I
had about a 5 hour ride home, and we were at a mall in Pueblo
Colorado. I found a cube in one of the stores and thought it would
give me something to do on the way home. So I got it, and messed
with it most the way home, in about a week or 2 I think I was able to
solve the f2l a couple times using some layer by layer method(i
didn't look at the hint book)...but I had no idea on the LL so i
pretty much gave it up......

The next year I went on the same ski trip and again, I got a cube at
the mall, this time i figured out how to decode the hint book. I
would solve the first layer on my own, then use the book for the
middle layer edges, and i couldnt understand the LL very good, so i
kept working at it, and the next day i finally did the right
combination and solved the cube.......the rest is history.

-Heath



1264. Re: your first cube...
From: "James Potter" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 2002 03:03:23 -0000

There's been a Rubiks Cube in my house pretty much since I was born. I got sort of interested in them when I was about eight, and I solved it when I was ten( I think it was a lucky case though. ;). It wasn't until a year later when I found my dad's Rubiks Cube booklet (The Simple Solution to the Rubiks Cube), and I memorized that solution. I thought I was pretty good then, but my average was about 2.5 minutes. The solution in that book is really bad, and almost useless for serious speed cubers. I found all the websites on the internet about the Cube later that year, and then I learned Lars Petrus' way. Now my average is something like 45 seconds. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@y...> wrote: > ok this serves no real value, I just want to hear the stories on how > everyone got their first cube. Or the first time they ever played > with a Rubiks Cube... > > > > I think when I bought my first cube it was on the way home from a Ski > trip. This was more than a year before i got into cubing i think. I > had about a 5 hour ride home, and we were at a mall in Pueblo > Colorado. I found a cube in one of the stores and thought it would > give me something to do on the way home. So I got it, and messed > with it most the way home, in about a week or 2 I think I was able to > solve the f2l a couple times using some layer by layer method(i > didn't look at the hint book)...but I had no idea on the LL so i > pretty much gave it up...... > > The next year I went on the same ski trip and again, I got a cube at > the mall, this time i figured out how to decode the hint book. I > would solve the first layer on my own, then use the book for the > middle layer edges, and i couldnt understand the LL very good, so i > kept working at it, and the next day i finally did the right > combination and solved the cube.......the rest is history. > > -Heath
1265. Re: your first cube...
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 2002 08:32:26 -0000

> ok this serves no real value, I just want to hear the stories on
how
> everyone got their first cube. Or the first time they ever played
> with a Rubiks Cube...

For me I remember the cube when I was very young. I still remember
the day when my mom was mad with me when I too (like everyone else)
took the stickers off to fix the cube. The cube to me was an
impossible puzzle from when I was young to about a year ago. But
recently it all started when I got a new cube for Christmas in 2000.
It was my freshman year in college, and because of my studies I threw
it aside. Then a year ago this month I picked it up after a soccer
game (that I won) and thought to myself, I can do this. So after
about an hour of playing with it, and only able to get one layer
done, I looked for help on the Internet. After much search for a
solution that seemed easy, I found one, and started following the
steps. Not much later I had a finished cube. When I was done, I
thought to myself, "There is no way I can memorize this."
But after
having my brother mess it up, and me trying to fix it again, and
again. I soon memorized it. It wasn't until last Christmas that
I
actually started trying to speed-cube. From that day on I have been
totally addicted. Anyway that's my story.

-Kenneth





1266. Alternative solving...
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 2002 15:59:59 +0100

Anybody any good at solving in a single, or other odd amount, of flat
mirrors? I just did it and it took a long while!

Also, curved mirrors which cause strange effects? I have Apple Pro speakers
and there is a concave mirror in the middle of them. I could not solve in
that mirror at all! See, you get this perfect reflection of a cube but it
almost seems that you are solving on a TV cos the reflection is flipped
BUT!... When you come to turn a face, completely the wrong thing happens!



1267. Re: your first cube...
From: "betrayedfiber" <htkra1d@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 2002 15:12:54 -0000

Well there was a market downtown, I guess I was about 12 then. Me and my sister went there and I "won" a cube at this game. Basically what I did was to fish after stuff. A man in front of the fishgame thing would ask me which of the prizes I wanted the most, and I said a cube and a man behind it put a cube on the hook and I fished it out. Veeerry exciting. Anyway I was too scared of messing it up so much I couldn't solve it in the beginning, but eventually of course it got scrambled, and I couldn't solve it. It didn't come with a solution booklet and I didn't know what to do. So it just stayed in the shelves, collecting dust for years with a few occasional attempts to "finally solve it", which were unsuccessful of course, I started looking on the internet. I stumbled upon Lars' site, and frankly I didn't understand anything. Next I found another one with a very simple layer by layer method, which I learned. And I got interested in speed cubing and managed to average 1 min 30 with this method and this crappy cube. Now, 3 months later I have a new cube of course. But I still got the old one. It's so loose every single corner piece can be moved in its place. When I get a lockup and keep turning the pieces can go so far apart it looks like I can fit a second edge piece in there. It's probably gonna fall apart soon :) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@y...> wrote: > ok this serves no real value, I just want to hear the stories on how > everyone got their first cube. Or the first time they ever played > with a Rubiks Cube... > > > > I think when I bought my first cube it was on the way home from a Ski > trip. This was more than a year before i got into cubing i think. I > had about a 5 hour ride home, and we were at a mall in Pueblo > Colorado. I found a cube in one of the stores and thought it would > give me something to do on the way home. So I got it, and messed > with it most the way home, in about a week or 2 I think I was able to > solve the f2l a couple times using some layer by layer method(i > didn't look at the hint book)...but I had no idea on the LL so i > pretty much gave it up...... > > The next year I went on the same ski trip and again, I got a cube at > the mall, this time i figured out how to decode the hint book. I > would solve the first layer on my own, then use the book for the > middle layer edges, and i couldnt understand the LL very good, so i > kept working at it, and the next day i finally did the right > combination and solved the cube.......the rest is history. > > -Heath
1268. Re: your first cube...
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 2002 15:38:43 -0000

I was in sixth grade or back in 1995-6. My great aunt brought over a
box of my Dad's cousin's stuff. In it was... suprise suprise... a
cube. My uncles got into the craze in the 80's. Know none of them
can solve the cube or even owns one. So that left me without any
referances.
In about eight grade I figured the cube is probably easier than it
appears if i just applied some simple logic. I developed a system,
almost like lars' method. But still I couldn't complete the final
layer. My Freshman year 1998-99 I decided to chech the net for help
with the final layer. I found four algs, and adapted them to
complete the final layer.

R2 D' U2 SR U2 SR' D R2

(SR U)4 (SR U')4

R' U L U' R U L' U'

R' D R F D F' U' F D' F' R' D' R U

I don't remember where I found the above.
After apllying these four moves with a somewhat Lars begining, I
could solve the cube in 3 - 5 min. This was too slow so I changed to
a layers method. This got my times down to 1 min.

Now I do the F2l and a 3 look LL.

I think i did pretty good coming up with my own solution. It is much
harder to do when you don't use the net or any sources but i got
pretty far using an inefecient method for my first years in cubing.

Jake



1269. Re: your first cube...
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 2002 17:02:09 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@y...> wrote: > ok this serves no real value, I just want to hear the stories on how > everyone got their first cube. Or the first time they ever played > with a Rubiks Cube... > On a ferry either to or from Denmark - early 80's (probably 83 or 84). Solved it 6 times on the ferry (average solving time was pretty slow then - solving times were probably up to half an hour) but not for quite a while afterwards. It was much easier on the first day than later on - perhaps naivety, youthful abandon and beginner's luck played their part. I still have that cube.

1273. Student teachers :-)
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Sep 2002 16:25:52 -0000

About four weeks ago, I taught a coworker how to solve the cube.
With less than a week of practice, the student became the teacher, as
she started to teach another of our coworkers (I helped in the
teaching process a little bit). Now, he's taken the knowledge home
(along with a new cube from the store), and taught his 11 year old
son. Within a couple days of learning, he is now solving the cube in
about 3 - 3 1/2 minutes.

1278. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] ..........silence..........
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2002 09:51:53 +0100

> are due this month (60+ million words). I am about as busy as cn possibly
> be! ... but I still cube about an hour a day: on the bus back home, and
> before I go to sleep. At the moment I am working on shortcuts in the F2L.

>
> S.

Can I ask... It seems a lot of you have cubed on busses, trains, planes and
other public areas. I feel too self conscious where people don't expect to
see me cube. I'd feel more confident at a competition. How do you guys
just sit there in public and cube? Are you forever having people stare at
you? That's the part that puts me off.

1280. Re: ..........silence..........
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2002 15:21:46 -0000

I love speeding in public. It helps promote cubing (especially in
stores that sell cubes). It is fun to see reactions of people, the
same "stupid" comments. I also like making it look like anyone can
solve a cube. Most people think they aren't smart enough to solve
one. But out in public being my stupid self really encourages others.
Jake



1281. Re: Student teachers :-)
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2002 15:27:51 -0000

I probably taught or helped a good dozen people. Out of that 12 or
so 2 are die hards and we get together and cube often. They probably
taught several people as well. One person I helped make in school,
made copies of the notes i wrote out and was handing them out to
people. So just from me it probably spread down to 20 - 30 people!!!
It's great!!! At this rate everyone will be solving in time for the
competition hehehehe!!!!
It's good to find someone to share info with, instead of keeping it
all to yourself and trying to keep it some secret. Sharing with
others open up new options and solutions as well as competion and
drive to improve.
Keep on teaching!
Jake



1282. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] ..........silence..........
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2002 17:35:56 +0100


>Can I ask... It seems a lot of you have cubed on busses, trains, planes and
>other public areas. I feel too self conscious where people don't expect to
>see me cube. I'd feel more confident at a competition. How do you guys
>just sit there in public and cube? Are you forever having people stare at
>you? That's the part that puts me off.

It does not really bother me at all to cube on the bus. Anyway, people in
Oxford just seem too polite / reserved to make any comment at all. The only
remark I have ever (over)heard was from a four-year-old, who asked his
mother "What is that man doing?" I would have given him a cube to play
with, but the mother seemed so embarrassed by the whole thing that it seemed
more prudent to not say anything at all. Strange, eh?

If someone on the bus is watching me solve it it feels no different. It is
not until I have a friend looking on with stopwatch in hand that I start to
get the shakes, etc. etc.
S.
>
>

There's a shop here in England called Globe, The Discovery Store. They
always have them things and there is always a broken spike. I normally
manage to get the ball out by spiraling the ball out. I've always
wondered if that's not possible when there is not a missing spike!

While we are a bit off topic:

There are two doors guarded by two people. One person always lies and
the other always tells the truth. One door will bring you certain
death and the other door will bring you good fortune. You can only ask
one question to get you through the correct door.

What do you ask?



1289. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Impossible puzzle
From: "Lars Vandenbergh" <lars.vandenbergh@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2002 22:35:25 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > > This is off topic, but I am curious if anybody knows how to remove > > that spiky ball from the cage. I am beginning to suspect that there > > must be some sort of "dirty tricks" involved ... If anyone has any > > idea how to solve this, please, let me know. Thanks! > > > > Go to > > > > http://putziespuzzles.com/3d3.html > > > > and scroll down. > > > > Jessica > > There's a shop here in England called Globe, The Discovery Store. They > always have them things and there is always a broken spike. I normally > manage to get the ball out by spiraling the ball out. I've always > wondered if that's not possible when there is not a missing spike! > > While we are a bit off topic: > > There are two doors guarded by two people. The guard will always point you to the door which brings you good fortune. Just think about it and you'll understand :) Lars

> While we are a bit off topic:
>
> There are two doors guarded by two people. One person always lies
and
> the other always tells the truth. One door will bring you certain
> death and the other door will bring you good fortune. You can
only ask
> one question to get you through the correct doors
> What do you ask?

Well, while we are off topic, here is another one I really like:

Two friends meet after many years. They talk and then ask about
their children. One guy says: "I have three children." The other
asks: "How old are they?" The first one says: "If you multiply their
ages, you get 36". The other guy thinks for a while and says: "Well,
I do not know how old they are. Can you tell me more?" The first guy
points to a building nearby and says: "If you add their ages, you
will get exactly the number of windows on that building." The other
guy thinks for a while and then says: "Well, I still do not know
their ages." The first guy adds more information: "The oldest one
wears glasses." The first guy smiles and says: "OK, now I know how
old your children are." Do you know their ages, too?

If you happen to know this one, please, do not spoil the fun by
posting the solution. It is a cute problem.

Jessica

P.S.: BTW, the cage or the spiky ball do not look like there is
something hidden in them. I still am not convinced that one cannot
remove the spiky ball just by twisting and turning. BTW, this type
of puzzle is very famous in Czech Republic. We call it "Hedgehog in
a cage".



1292. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Impossible puzzle

Since we're all asking logic puzzles and stuff that's off topic, try this one: A man without eyes saw plums on a tree. He did not take plums, and he did not leave plums. How can this be?

hints. If anybody gives up, e-mail me and I will answer by e-mail

grade math.

Jessica

The oldest one wears glasses

late sons

1302. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Impossible puzzle
From: kyubeman <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 01:59:38 -0000

Good answer to that very simple logic question lars. I would have
responded sooner with this, but I just now saw it. There is ANOTHER
answer to that one, in case you cared. You could ask: "Which way
would you tell me to go if I asked you which way was fortune?" This
too will tell you the correct path. Obviously, this leads to an
endless loop of answers, IE which way would you tell me if i asked
you which way would you tell me if i asked you which way would you
tell me... etc ad infinitum. Here's a slight modification to that
logic puzzle:

There are 2 paths, guarded by THREE people. One leads to fortune, the
other horrendous doom, etc. ONE person can only tell lies. Another
can only tell the truth. The last person, will sometimes tell the
truth, and will sometimes tell lies. You have only THREE questions,
and you have absolutely no idea which person you are talking to. How
can you find the correct path?

-Ross



1303. Weird dreams
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 02:24:01 -0000

While were moving in tangents....

Well, I have seasonal allergies, some of you might be plagued as
well, and August and early Sept are the primal worst days of it all.
Instead of going with perscription medication, but being a big tough
guy I thought i would tough it out this year. Of course i proved
myself wrong. Any way I'm taking Benydryl just normal over the
counter stuff, and that stuff totally wipes me out.
To get to the point, I have been sleeping very well. And during this
period of sleep I have again been dreaming crazy dreams. I have had
some weird cubing dreams in the past (virtual cube popping out of
disc thingy, and the infamous pop while on a roller coaster).
Anyway I have been having weird dreams again but none of them are
about the cube or anything. I don't know why I'm typing this stuff
but I'll keep you all updated on any weird cube dreams.

How have your dreams been lately?
Jake

1305. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Impossible puzzle
From: Jason Feng <jason.feng@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 2002 20:25:22 -0700

I used to love all these little tricky questions, unfortunately I know
the answers to almost all of them, so I won't add to the discussions
here, but I would like to pose two of my favorite questions in the past
36 years (I don't remember much when I was inside my Mom's womb). One is
simple yet tricky, the other is downright agonizing but can be figured
out.

1) Three men walk into a motel and ask for a room. The desk clerk says a
room is $30 so each man pays $10 towards the cost. Later, the clerk
realizes he made a mistake, that the room should have been $25. He calls
the bell boy over and asks him to refund the other $5 to the three men.
The bellboy, not wanting to mess with a lot of change dividing the $5
three ways, decides to lie about the price, refunding each man $1 and
keeping the other $2 for himself. Ultimately each man paid $9 towards
the room and the bellboy got $2, totaling $29. But the original charge
was $30, where did the extra $1 go?

2) In front of you are 12 pearls, 11 being real and one fake. The real
ones all weigh the same and the fake one differs in weight from the real
ones (may weigh more or less). With a balance scale and three weighings
how can you weed out the fake one and determine whether it is too heavy
or too light?

Enjoy, and no blurting out answers until some discussion...

1307. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Impossible puzzle

Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 09:53:39 +0100

I have that puzzle. One of the spikes is shorter than the other, once that
is identified the rest is pretty easy. There is a bit of a cheat involved
because at one stage you need to apply a little bit of force: not a lot, but
there is a bit of a squeeze.
S.

1308. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Impossible puzzle
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 10:34:40 +0100


>Well, while we are off topic, here is another one I really like:
>
>Two friends meet after many years. They talk and then ask about
>their children. One guy says: "I have three children." The other
>asks: "How old are they?" The first one says: "If you multiply their
>ages, you get 36". The other guy thinks for a while and says: "Well,
>I do not know how old they are. Can you tell me more?" The first guy
>points to a building nearby and says: "If you add their ages, you
>will get exactly the number of windows on that building." The other
>guy thinks for a while and then says: "Well, I still do not know
>their ages." The first guy adds more information: "The oldest one
>wears glasses." The first guy smiles and says: "OK, now I know how
>old your children are." Do you know their ages, too?
>
>If you happen to know this one, please, do not spoil the fun by
>posting the solution. It is a cute problem.
>


Jessica: I had not seen that one before, but I really enjoyed it! ... my
thoughts below (possible spoiler, so don't look if you don't want to! I
have posted what I think is the answer, I hope that's ok...
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.



Eight possible answers:


age multiply add
1,1,36 = 36 = 38
1,2,18 = 36 = 21
1,3,12 = 36 = 16
1,4,9 = 36 = 14
1,6,6 = 36 = 13
2,2,9 = 36 = 13
2,3,6 = 36 = 11
3,3,4 = 36 = 10

The point of the windows questions is that after being told that he *didn't*
know the answer. For this to be so, it must have been one of the sums that
gives you more than one possible answer. There is only one sum with that
quality: 13.

So the ages are either 1,6,6 OR 2,2,9.

But we know that there is an eldest one, so that means that 1,6,6 is not
possible, because there are two who are 6 yrs old.

So the answer must be 2,2,9

S.


_________________________________________________________________
MSN Photos is the easiest way to share and print your photos:
http://photos.msn.com/support/worldwide.aspx



1309. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Toy strore in London,
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 10:39:30 +0100

> Where can I get the good rubik cube in London ?
> please let me know the complete address, because on 20 Sep, I'm going to
> there.
>
> thanks,
> -eh-
>
Well, Hamley's in Regents Street.
http://www.hamleys.co.uk/
That's possibly the best toy shop you'll ever visit! However I don't know
that they definitely do have cubes. Hamley's is very famous, you should
have no trouble getting directions. It's in the middle of the curve between
Oxford Street Tube station and Piccadilly Circus. Look for the flags!

Not far from there is a gadget shop called 'The Gadget Shop'. Got that?
http://www.gadgetshop.com/
That's in Oxford Street and it's the big one from their popular chain. I've
seen Oddzon cubes in some of The Gadget Shops, but again I don't know if
that one will sell them. The shop is located between Oxford Street tube
station and Tottenham Court Road, it's on the north side of the road on a
junction and once you roughly in the vicinity, someone should be able to
tell you where it is. Look for the pinky purlply neon sign!

I can't think of any shops that definitely-definitely sell them I'm afraid
but I'm sure you'll have fun in those shops anyway!

1311. Re: Impossible puzzle
From: _jaap <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 10:51:33 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "simonl cube" <simonlcube@h...> wrote: > I have that puzzle. One of the spikes is shorter than the other, once that > is identified the rest is pretty easy. > > >This is off topic, but I am curious if anybody knows how to remove > >that spiky ball from the cage. I am beginning to suspect that there > >must be some sort of "dirty tricks" involved ... If anyone has any > >idea how to solve this, please, let me know. Thanks! The four bars of the cage are not arranged in a square. Two of the bars are slightly further apart. Once you have found which ones, the rest is just fiddling about till it works. Jaap
1312. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Weird dreams
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 11:53:33 +0100

> How have your dreams been lately?
> Jake
>

I was saying last night about waking up from a dream and having the solution
to a problem. These dreams are called 'lucid dreams' and you have them
whilst in REM.

The British magazine, New Scientist, published an experiment written by an
American doctor. Readers had to come up with the solution to a problem and
send them in with a description of how they came up with the solution.
Eleven readers had odd dreams that gave clues as to the answer.

Let's see how you guys do, and again please don't ruin it by posting the
answer straight away. (unless you put a warning and a big gap like some of
you have)

Here's the problem:
Construct an object comprising of four triangles using only six lines of
equal length.

1314. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Weird dreams
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>

> My thoughts on the triangle thing are way way down below, so avoid if you
> want to solve it yourself ...

Perfect Simon

It is really easy but some people get a mental block (pardon the pun) and
they only come up with the answer in their dreams. They dream of things
quite like what you have mentioned and at the time it doesn't seem to mean
anything. Then they wake up and everything becomes clear!

So, if you can't come up with that answer, perhaps you should sleep on it ;)

>
> age multiply add
> 1,1,36 = 36 = 38
> 1,2,18 = 36 = 21
> 1,3,12 = 36 = 16
> 1,4,9 = 36 = 14
> 1,6,6 = 36 = 13
> 2,2,9 = 36 = 13
> 2,3,6 = 36 = 11
> 3,3,4 = 36 = 10
>
> The point of the windows questions is that after being told that
he *didn't*
> know the answer. For this to be so, it must have been one of the
sums that
> gives you more than one possible answer. There is only one sum
with that
> quality: 13.
>
> So the ages are either 1,6,6 OR 2,2,9.
>
> But we know that there is an eldest one, so that means that 1,6,6
is not
> possible, because there are two who are 6 yrs old.
>
> So the answer must be 2,2,9
>
> S.
>
>
> _________________________________________________________________
> MSN Photos is the easiest way to share and print your photos:
> http://photos.msn.com/support/worldwide.aspx



1316. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Impossible puzzle
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 14:19:01 +0100

>Bravo, Simon, that's the correct answer!
>
>Jessica

Here's one for you, Jessica, and anyone else. I know we are *completely*
off the topic, but this is one of my own favourite puzzles. Maybe we can
swap more at Toronto. :-)

You are in a ten-story house, and are on the bottom floor. On the top floor
is a room with three electric lights (your normal light bulbs).

Now each light has a switch that turns it on/off, but these switches are on
the ground floor. You know that the switches are all off, but you do not
know which switch is connected to which light.

Now becuase you have been speedcubing for 16 hrs straight, you are feeling
very tired: so how do you establish which switch is connected to which light
using the switches down stairs and only ONE walk up all those stairs? (the
lift is out of order) You cannot see the lights from downstairs, its too
cold to go outside, and the top floors have no windows anyway.

Post answers a few screens down, so that people can have the satisfaction of
solving it themselves if they want to!
S.

_________________________________________________________________
Join the world�s largest e-mail service with MSN Hotmail.
http://www.hotmail.com



1317. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Impossible puzzle

My problem is that I know so many logical puzzles that I rarely
encounter one that I do not know. I know this one, Simon :) I like
it, too!

BTW, I have one very beautiful puzzle that is not so well known but I
cannot post it here because I might offend somebody ... I tried to
reformulate it to some other human activity so that it is publishable
but I was not able to do it. I am very interested not whether or not
you solve it (I know you will), but how to reformulate it to make it
less objectionable. Everybody, e-mail me if you are interested :) It
could be something quite practical for you, guys, btw ... ;)

Jessica

1319. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Impossible puzzle
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 13:57:44 -0000

Some of the others gave me problems as I thought them through, but here's what comes to me for this one... (Only scroll down if you want to see my answer) . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . Because you can only go up the stairs once, you can only be sure of one light/switch connection based on sight - use the sense of touch for a second one. Before I walk upstairs, I would turn on two lights, leave them on long enough to heat up, turn one of them off and go upstairs. The one that is still on matches up with the switch that is still on. The one that is not on, but is warm (or hot) matches up with the switch that was turned on and then off. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "simonl cube" <simonlcube@h...> wrote: > >Bravo, Simon, that's the correct answer! > > > >Jessica > > Here's one for you, Jessica, and anyone else. I know we are *completely* > off the topic, but this is one of my own favourite puzzles. Maybe we can > swap more at Toronto. :-) > > You are in a ten-story house, and are on the bottom floor. On the top floor > is a room with three electric lights (your normal light bulbs). > > Now each light has a switch that turns it on/off, but these switches are on > the ground floor. You know that the switches are all off, but you do not > know which switch is connected to which light. > > Now becuase you have been speedcubing for 16 hrs straight, you are feeling > very tired: so how do you establish which switch is connected to which light > using the switches down stairs and only ONE walk up all those stairs? (the > lift is out of order) You cannot see the lights from downstairs, its too > cold to go outside, and the top floors have no windows anyway. > > Post answers a few screens down, so that people can have the satisfaction of > solving it themselves if they want to! > S. > > _________________________________________________________________ > Join the world's largest e-mail service with MSN Hotmail. > http://www.hotmail.com
1320. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Impossible puzzle
From: "Jessica Fridrich" <jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 13:58:11 -0000

> 1) Three men walk into a motel and ask for a room. The desk clerk
says a
> room is $30 so each man pays $10 towards the cost. Later, the clerk
> realizes he made a mistake, that the room should have been $25. He
calls
> the bell boy over and asks him to refund the other $5 to the three
men.
> The bellboy, not wanting to mess with a lot of change dividing the
$5
> three ways, decides to lie about the price, refunding each man $1
and
> keeping the other $2 for himself. Ultimately each man paid $9
towards
> the room and the bellboy got $2, totaling $29. But the original
charge
> was $30, where did the extra $1 go?
>
> 2) In front of you are 12 pearls, 11 being real and one fake. The
real
> ones all weigh the same and the fake one differs in weight from the
real
> ones (may weigh more or less). With a balance scale and three
weighings
> how can you weed out the fake one and determine whether it is too
heavy
> or too light?

Jason, those are cute little problems. Unfortunately, I know them
both ;) I know one more about scales and boxes that is much less well
known with very difficult non-unique solution. I will post it later.

Jessica

1322. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Impossible puzzle
From: "papegoja99" <webmaster@...>

On the lawn (grass) there is: a couple of stones, a scarf and a
carrot.

to how they got there.
How did they get there?



1323. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Impossible puzzle
From: "James Potter" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 14:50:15 -0000

I think I know!! . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . You flip the first switch, then wait a while. Then you flip another switch, and walk up the stairs. Whichever lightbulb that's on and is the hottest is the first one, whichever one that's on but isn't as hot is the second one, and whichever one is off is the last one. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "simonl cube" <simonlcube@h...> wrote: > >Bravo, Simon, that's the correct answer! > > > >Jessica > > Here's one for you, Jessica, and anyone else. 1326. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Impossible puzzle
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 14:58:41 -0000

Since noone else has answered this one yet. (scroll for my answer) . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . Ask each person the same question you proposed for the other puzzle: "Which way would you tell me to go if I asked you which way was fortune?" Two of the people will point to the correct door. The liar will lie about his lie, pointing to the correct door. The truthful person will tell the truth about his truthful answer, pointing to the correct door. The third person will potentially point to either door, but at this point, it doesn't matter. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., kyubeman <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Good answer to that very simple logic question lars. I would have > responded sooner with this, but I just now saw it. There is ANOTHER > answer to that one, in case you cared. You could ask: "Which way > would you tell me to go if I asked you which way was fortune?" This > too will tell you the correct path. Obviously, this leads to an > endless loop of answers, IE which way would you tell me if i asked > you which way would you tell me if i asked you which way would you > tell me... etc ad infinitum. Here's a slight modification to that > logic puzzle: > > There are 2 paths, guarded by THREE people. One leads to fortune, the > other horrendous doom, etc. ONE person can only tell lies. Another > can only tell the truth. The last person, will sometimes tell the > truth, and will sometimes tell lies. You have only THREE questions, > and you have absolutely no idea which person you are talking to. How > can you find the correct path? > > -Ross

1328. Thank you Lars, here it goes
From: "Jessica Fridrich" <jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 17:31:34 -0000

> >BTW, I have one very beautiful puzzle that is not so well known
but I
> >cannot post it here because I might offend somebody ... I tried to
> >reformulate it to some other human activity so that it is
publishable
> >but I was not able to do it. I am very interested not whether or
not
> >you solve it (I know you will), but how to reformulate it to make
it
> >less objectionable. Everybody, e-mail me if you are interested :)
It
> >could be something quite practical for you, guys, btw ... ;)
> >
>
> Doctors and rubber gloves.

Thank you, Lars ;)

Three doctors are about to inspect a patient who has a dangerous skin
disease. The doctors also have a skin disease, each one has a
different one and all three are different from the patient's disease.
The doctors need to inspect the patient but they only have two gloves
(not pairs, just a sigle glove twice). All four diseases are not
fatal if you only have one, but if you happen to have any two of
them, you die immediately. The disease spreads by physical contact.
How will all three doctors inspect the patient so that they do not
infect each other and all four stay alive?

Jessica (not responsible for your associations)

BTW, I give on the plum problem. What is solution?

Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 17:33:04 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > > How have your dreams been lately? > > Jake > > > > I was saying last night about waking up from a dream and having the solution > to a problem. These dreams are called 'lucid dreams' and you have them > whilst in REM. > > The British magazine, New Scientist, published an experiment written by an > American doctor. Readers had to come up with the solution to a problem and > send them in with a description of how they came up with the solution. > Eleven readers had odd dreams that gave clues as to the answer. > > Let's see how you guys do, and again please don't ruin it by posting the > answer straight away. (unless you put a warning and a big gap like some of > you have) > > Here's the problem: > Construct an object comprising of four triangles using only six lines of > equal length. I can get 8 triangles with 6 lines of equal length (all equilateral, 2 sets of congruent triangles, one having 2 triangles and the other 6 a quarter of the size of the larger triangles, plus you get a regular hexagon as a bonus).

1331. Re: Thank you Lars, here it goes

To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 17:43:43 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Jessica Fridrich" <jess340@h...> wrote: > > >BTW, I have one very beautiful puzzle that is not so well known > but I > > >cannot post it here because I might offend somebody ... Everybody, e-mail me if you are interested :) > It > > >could be something quite practical for you, guys, btw ... ;) > > > > > > > Doctors and rubber gloves. > > Thank you, Lars ;) > > Three doctors are about to inspect a patient who has a dangerous skin > disease. The doctors also have a skin disease, each one has a > different one and all three are different from the patient's disease. > The doctors need to inspect the patient but they only have two gloves > (not pairs, just a sigle glove twice). All four diseases are not > fatal if you only have one, but if you happen to have any two of > them, you die immediately. Why does the patient need a third opinion, especially in this life- endangering situation? I can only imagine they aren't in the UK - in the winter we sometimes run out of (or at least very short of) emergency beds throughout the entire country so we probably don't even have 2 gloves to spare. If the gloves are shaped like Klein bottles, I guess there is no solution. On a similar topic, if you make double sided sticky tape into a mobius strip what is it then? Other possibilities, do the inspections require physical contact. Why can't they use something other than gloves and is it important that they are rubber? > Jessica (not responsible for your associations) > > BTW, I give on the plum problem. What is solution?

1333. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Weird dreams
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 19:31:13 +0100

> Sure, I can think on a platonic level but I can get 8 triangles
> instead of only 4 - surely that's twice as good?

tut tut Dr.C you're just being plain greedy with your eight triangles.

Here's a good one:

1. There is a 5 house terrace and each house is a different colour. In
each
house lives one person, each from a different country.
2. The 5 owners each like a certain drink, smoke a
certain brand of cigar, and keep a certain pet.
3. No owners have the same pet, smoke the same brand of cigar or
drink the same beverage.

The Brit lives in the red house.
the Swede keeps dogs as pets.
The Dane drinks tea.
The green house is on the left of the white house.
The green house's owner drinks coffee.
The person who smokes Pall Mall rears birds.
The owner of the yellow house smokes Dunhill.
The man living in the centre house drinks milk.
The Norwegian lives in the first house.
The man who smokes Blends lives next to the one who keeps cats.
The man who keeps the horse lives next to the man who smokes Dunhill.
The owner who smokes Bluemasters drinks beer.
The German smokes Prince.
The Norwegian lives next to the blue house.
The man who smokes blends has a neighbour who drinks water.

The question is, who owns the fish?


You won't need to add up or read between the lines or think outside of
the cube for this one. All the evidence is there, so just use plain
logic! This took me about 15 mins and I found a spreadsheet quite
handy. Have fun!



1334. Gemuetlichkiet Weekend
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 2002 19:46:33 -0000

This weekend, in our little wisconsin town, we have a german
celebration every year at the fair grounds. Its lots of fun and I'm
going to be there all weekend showing off my cubing. I'm thinking
about just bringing a 3x3, mainly because i need to practise plus it
is the most recognizable. If you could bring one other puzzle for
public show off other than another 3x3 what would it be?
Mine would probably be a skweb.

Whats yours?
Jake



1335. Re: Thank you Lars, here it goes
From: "James Potter" <theboywholived81@...>

I think you're talking about my plum riddle: A man without eyes saw plums on a tree. He did not take plums and he did not leave plums. How can this be? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . The man didn't have EYES, he had one eye. He saw two plums, he took one, meaning he didn't take PLUMS, he took one. He didn't leave PLUMS, he just left one. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Jessica Fridrich" <jess340@h...> wrote: > > >BTW, I have one very beautiful puzzle that is not so well known > but I > > >cannot post it here because I might offend somebody ... 1337. Re: Thank you Lars, here it goes

> Only one inspects him, or two with one hand each? I don't know. > BTW, did anyone get the one about the guys and the kids and the ages? Yes, I think a number of people got that one right. Each doctor uses one hand to inspect the patient. Jessica > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Jessica Fridrich" > <jess340@h...> wrote: > > > >BTW, I have one very beautiful puzzle that is not so well known > > but I > > > >cannot post it here because I might offend somebody ... I tried > to > > > >reformulate it to some other human activity so that it is > > publishable > > > >but I was not able to do it. I am very interested not whether > or > > not > > > >you solve it (I know you will), but how to reformulate it to > make > > it > > > >less objectionable. Everybody, e-mail me if you are > interested :) > > It > > > >could be something quite practical for you, guys, btw ... ;) > > > > > > > > > > Doctors and rubber gloves. > > > > Thank you, Lars ;) > > > > Three doctors are about to inspect a patient who has a dangerous > skin > > disease. The doctors also have a skin disease, each one has a > > different one and all three are different from the patient's > disease. > > The doctors need to inspect the patient but they only have two > gloves > > (not pairs, just a sigle glove twice). All four diseases are not > > fatal if you only have one, but if you happen to have any two of > > them, you die immediately. The disease spreads by physical > contact. > > How will all three doctors inspect the patient so that they do not > > infect each other and all four stay alive? > > > > Jessica (not responsible for your associations) > > > > BTW, I give on the plum problem. What is solution?
1338. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Re: Thank you Lars, here it goes
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 14 Sep 2002 00:56:52 +0100

> Each doctor uses one hand to inspect the patient.
>
> Jessica


Whoo hoo!...
.
.
.











































One doctor wears both gloves on one hand and examines. This
contaminates the outside of one glove and the inside of another. The
next doctor uses the outer glove which has a clean inside and has
already touched the patient once it may as well again. The last doctor
takes the inner glove from the first doctor but wears it inside out and
puts the outer glove on it again!

I'm not normally any good at these, so I'm now feeling pretty good :]

I too gave up in the plums riddle but I'm still working on the 12
pearls problem.

1343. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] 5 x 5 cube
From: makimoto2000us <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 14 Sep 2002 01:30:35 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., cubed68 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > cheers bloke,i can do the 4 x 4 cube okay.i`ve managed to solve most > of the 5 x 5 on my own,it just the last layer bottom edge cubies i > cant figure out what to with.will moves from the 4 x 4 solutions work > with the 5 x 5 Hi Peter, I solve the last layer bottom edges in the last step. If you can solve 4x4x4 layer by later, you can figure out how to solve 5x5x5. My solution for 4x4x4 can be applied for 5x5x5. Try Step 7. Masayuki http://users.hoops.ne.jp/rokumentai/cindex-e.htm

Date: Sat, 14 Sep 2002 02:41:45 -0000

greatest one at the rubik's cube on the stage.

scene with this great one trick. The cube is too large and yet he is
the king. My god who is it? Camera or public no problem.

I am a magician and he did'nt right back to me about his trick...
Do you have and ideal how he does it????????

Robert

1357. Fridirich - Go Slow
From: "mylib_2000" <mylib_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 16 Sep 2002 02:13:05 -0000

Hello, I am here to attest that Jessica's advice about slowing down
on the F2L does work ! I forced myself to slow down and I solved in
three conscutive times in 25,27&27 which is fast for me. Also, I am
still using 3 looks for the LL. I haven't learned all of the
oreintations yet to do it in 2.



1358. i need help
From: "skaterguy2182" <skaterguy2182@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 Sep 2002 02:33:59 -0000

tell me what to do!!!!!!!



1359. Re: i need help
From: "James Potter" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 Sep 2002 14:57:05 -0000

Most people can solve two layers without help. If you can do that, then you just need to memorize about five or six sequences of moves. You can find complete solutions to the cube all over the internet. Try the links at http://www.speedcubing.com and you might want to look at my site: http://www.geocities.com/rubiks81 It's not very good, but it's okay. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "skaterguy2182" <skaterguy2182@y...> wrote: > I am a beginer and i need help on how to solve the cube someone just > tell me what to do!!!!!!!
1360. Pocket (2x2x2) cube.
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 Sep 2002 16:51:56 -0000

A coworker of mine just recently bought a pocket cube - it's
impossible to move! Is this common, or did she just get a really bad
one? I don't have one yet myself, so I don't know.



1361. Re: [Speed cubing group] Pocket (2x2x2) cube.
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 Sep 2002 19:09:31 +0100

> A coworker of mine just recently bought a pocket cube - it's
> impossible to move! Is this common, or did she just get a really bad
> one? I don't have one yet myself, so I don't know.

A Pocket Cube as in a 2x2x2? They're often hard to turn by nature of
the mechanism which will keep jamming. You should lube it but there's
not much more you can do. I would advise never to force it though! It
might fall apart and they are a bugger to put back together. Imho,
it's best to use minimal force and sometimes jiggle to complete turns.
I have a giant 2x2x2 which is not a Rubik brand, it's stiff but it
doesn't jam. I can tell that a lube would make it excellent. So it
just goes to show how different cubes can be.

If you are talking about a mini 3x3x3, they are not as easy to
manipulate because they don't have springs on the centres.



1362. Re: Pocket (2x2x2) cube.
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 Sep 2002 20:08:36 -0000

Again I don't know why Rubiks changed from their old 2x2 mechanics to
this piece of junk. They are certainly a pain without getting
lubed. I recently picked up a new 2x2 and sprayed it with silicon
right away. NOw it works pretty good, be careful with the lube
though, these stickers don't like it much.
jake



1363. Re: i need help
From: "betrayedfiber" <htkra1d@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 18 Sep 2002 11:56:46 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "skaterguy2182" <skaterguy2182@y...> wrote: > I am a beginer and i need help on how to solve the cube someone just > tell me what to do!!!!!!! I suggest this page. No previous knowledge required. Just imagine how the cube is divided into pieces and how the center pieces are stationary and follow the instructions *CAREFULLY* you should do fine. These two methods are no good for speeding though so if you want to learn a speedmethod, you need something like Lars or Jessicas or a corners first method. Mark Jeays page: http://jeays.net/rubiks.htm

is made from, but it has less give.

clean their cubes? Also I was wondering how often do people go
through cubes? I have been cubing for about 5 or 6 months on my
cube, and it is already a little bit too loose for me.

Just wondering

1368. Coincidence?
From: "papegoja99" <webmaster@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 19 Sep 2002 11:19:06 -0000

LINCOLN vs KENNEDY

Abraham Lincoln got chosen for congress 1846.
John F Kennedy got chosen for congress 1946.

Abraham Lincoln was elected president 1860.
JFK was elected president 1960.

Both the names Lincoln and Kennedy contain 7 letters.
Both were very interested in human rights.

Both there wifes lost there children while living in the White house.

Both presidents got shot on a friday.
Both presidents got shot in the head.

Lincoln´s secretery was named Kennedy.
Kennedy´s secretery was named Lincoln.

Both got shot by a southerner.
Both successors were southerners.

Both successors were named Johnson.
Andrew Johnson, who succeded Lincoln, was born 1808.
Lyndon Johnson, who succeded Kennedy, was born 1908.
Both successors names contain 13 letters.

John Wilkes Booth, who shot Lincoln, was born 1839.
Lee Harvey Oswald, who shot Kennedy, was born 1939.

Booth ran from a theatre, and was arrested in a warehouse.
Oswald ran from a warehouse, and was arrested in a theatre.

Both Booth and Oswald was killed before there trial.

And finaly....
One week before Lincoln got shot he was in Monroe, Maryland.
One week before Kennedy got shot he was in Marylin Monroe.

Coincidence?



1369. Re: Coincidence?
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 19 Sep 2002 12:26:15 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "papegoja99" <webmaster@p...> wrote: > LINCOLN vs KENNEDY > > Abraham Lincoln got chosen for congress 1846. > John F Kennedy got chosen for congress 1946. > > Abraham Lincoln was elected president 1860. > JFK was elected president 1960. > > Both the names Lincoln and Kennedy contain 7 letters. Each has 2 "n"s too. One has 2 "l"s and the other 2 "k"s. "l" and "k" are next to each other in the alphabet. Of course John and Abraham are of rather different lengths. Doesn't the disparity count against your theory or do you just ignore those results. > Both were very interested in human rights. You would hope so. > > Both there wifes lost there children while living in the White house. > > Both presidents got shot on a friday. > Both presidents got shot in the head. > > Lincoln´s secretery was named Kennedy. > Kennedy´s secretery was named Lincoln. > > Both got shot by a southerner. > Both successors were southerners. > > Both successors were named Johnson. > Andrew Johnson, who succeded Lincoln, was born 1808. > Lyndon Johnson, who succeded Kennedy, was born 1908. > Both successors names contain 13 letters. 13 is the smallest size of subgroup not in the cube group. Neither Lincoln nor Kennedy solved the cube. > > John Wilkes Booth, who shot Lincoln, was born 1839. > Lee Harvey Oswald, who shot Kennedy, was born 1939. > You didn't mention that both their names contain 15 letters. > Booth ran from a theatre, and was arrested in a warehouse. > Oswald ran from a warehouse, and was arrested in a theatre. > > Both Booth and Oswald was killed before there trial. > > And finaly.... > One week before Lincoln got shot he was in Monroe, Maryland. > One week before Kennedy got shot he was in Marylin Monroe. I don't think you can back up that last claim. > > Coincidence? Yes. Neither of them kept Swedish parrots either.
1370. Re: Coincidence?
From: "James Potter" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 19 Sep 2002 14:26:12 -0000

Nope. Not coincidence. Fate. One time on a TV show, they were talking about that, and they said that you can find creepy things about anything, and they chose two random people, Martin Luther King, adn someone else. They found about ten creepy coincidences. Another cool weird creepy amazing thing is this: Take a twenty dollar bill, and fold it in half longways, so it's still the original length. then fold it in half the other way, then unfold it. Fold itdiagonally, so the edge of the dollar bill sets in the other fold. Then fold the other side diagonally again. It should look something like this: |....| |....| |....| .\../ ..\/ But without the dots. Now look at it. On side one, is the twin towers burning down. On side two is the Pentagon burning down. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "papegoja99" <webmaster@p...> > wrote: > > LINCOLN vs KENNEDY > > > > Abraham Lincoln got chosen for congress 1846. > > John F Kennedy got chosen for congress 1946. > > > > Abraham Lincoln was elected president 1860. > > JFK was elected president 1960. > > > > Both the names Lincoln and Kennedy contain 7 letters. > > Each has 2 "n"s too. One has 2 "l"s and the other 2 "k"s. "l" and "k" > are next to each other in the alphabet. > > Of course John and Abraham are of rather different lengths. Doesn't > the disparity count against your theory or do you just ignore those > results. > > > Both were very interested in human rights. > > You would hope so. > > > > > Both there wifes lost there children while living in the White > house. > > > > Both presidents got shot on a friday. > > Both presidents got shot in the head. > > > > Lincoln´s secretery was named Kennedy. > > Kennedy´s secretery was named Lincoln. > > > > Both got shot by a southerner. > > Both successors were southerners. > > > > Both successors were named Johnson. > > Andrew Johnson, who succeded Lincoln, was born 1808. > > Lyndon Johnson, who succeded Kennedy, was born 1908. > > Both successors names contain 13 letters. > > 13 is the smallest size of subgroup not in the cube group. Neither > Lincoln nor Kennedy solved the cube. > > > > > John Wilkes Booth, who shot Lincoln, was born 1839. > > Lee Harvey Oswald, who shot Kennedy, was born 1939. > > > > You didn't mention that both their names contain 15 letters. > > > Booth ran from a theatre, and was arrested in a warehouse. > > Oswald ran from a warehouse, and was arrested in a theatre. > > > > Both Booth and Oswald was killed before there trial. > > > > And finaly.... > > One week before Lincoln got shot he was in Monroe, Maryland. > > One week before Kennedy got shot he was in Marylin Monroe. > > I don't think you can back up that last claim. > > > > > Coincidence? > > Yes. Neither of them kept Swedish parrots either.
1371. Re: i need help
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 19 Sep 2002 17:04:49 -0000

A while ago we were talking about what methods are good for teaching beginners. In message 1185, I had said the following: >I came across a "simple solution" by Mark Jeays on www.rubiks.dk >a while ago, but it's not there anymore. There is a link to his >site (http://jeays.net/rubiks.htm), but the solution I attribute to >him isn't on his site. He currently has two different solutions >listed, neither of which is the one I found previously. I was wrong! I looked over his site too quickly before. His "Easier to Memorize Solution" is actually what I use, except that I had reversed steps 2 and 3 (second layer edges before first layer corners). In my opinion, it's a little hard to follow on his site without illustrations, but it is a very easy approach to learn. Also, though it may not be all that great for speed, it lends well into learning Jessica's approach. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "betrayedfiber" <htkra1d@h...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "skaterguy2182" <skaterguy2182@y...> wrote: > > I am a beginer and i need help on how to solve the cube someone just > > tell me what to do!!!!!!! > > I suggest this page. No previous knowledge required. Just imagine how the cube is divided into pieces and how the center pieces are stationary and follow the instructions *CAREFULLY* you should do fine. These two methods are no good for speeding though so if you want to learn a speedmethod, you need something like Lars or Jessicas or a corners first method. > > Mark Jeays page: http://jeays.net/rubiks.htm

1374. New Cube
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 20 Sep 2002 08:52:05 -0000

Today I went out and bought a new cube to eventually replace the one
I currently use. I buy my cubes from a small store in the mall called
Learning Express. They have a good selection. They have the Rubik's
cube ($9), a no name cube(only $5), a pocket cube 2x2x2, a UFO, a
Rubik's snake, a Simpson's magic, a Homer 2x2, and a no name
3x3x3
key chain. Anyway when I went to buy it I asked how often they sold
the cube. I was surprised to hear that she sold at least one a day!
She said that she thought the craze was coming back, parents coming
in to buy their kids the cube. Anyway just thought I would share...

-Kenneth

1377. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New Cube
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 20 Sep 2002 20:26:19 +0100

> I love them puzzly stores. When I move to Illinois I'm gonna hunt
> one down and see if i can work there... or at least advertise hehehe
> jake

If the guy that went to London and wanted to find a cube shop is
reading this. Have you been yet?

It's hard to find a cool shop that sells cubes here in England. At the
local major mall, there is a shop called "The Puzzle Store" At first,
they only sold jigsaws, hundreds of them! Then they started stocking a
few little Mefferts puzzles but I can only take it that they didn't
sell enough cos they don't even do them anymore, back to boring jigsaws.

People often mention Toys R Us on here but it's probably a different
franchise to the Toys R Us here in England, cos I've never found decent
cubes there either.

1379. Thought processes in blindfold cubing
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 21 Sep 2002 11:25:43 -0000


Today, I did the cube blindfolded whilst getting my hair cut -
technically, I wasn't blindfolded, but the cube was under the black
sheet they put over so it was effectively the same. There was a bit
of time pressure as I had to finish before the cut.

Anyway, I have a particularly clear recall of my thought processes
on this cube, so I thought I'd go through it for those who are
trying to solve the cube blindfolded.

Initial position:

Corners: 4 3 7 1 2 6 8 5, 2 0 0 1 0 0 0 0
Edges: 1 5 11 4 10 12 9 8 3 6 7 2, 1 1 0 1 1 1 0 1 1 0 1 0

(for notation see my blindfold page).

First of all I fixed the orientation of the 2 corners that needed
orienting - they were in positions 1 and 4 (the UFR and UBL
positions).

(F'U2)(R'F'LFRF'L'FBL'BR2B'LBR2B2)(U2F)

Then I oriented the edges: first the ones in positions 9 and 11 (FR
and BR). I rotated the whole cube so that the (true) R side was on
top and the (true) U side was behind (i.e. in the usual places of
the U and B faces respectively). Then I did

FsUF'U'BsLFL'F2URsF2LsUF2 (these are not the true Fs etc., but Fs
etc. with respect to the current orientation of the cube - similarly
throughout).

I returned the cube to its original orientation then rotated so that
the U face was behind and the B face on top before doing

(U')(FsUF'U'BsLFL'F2URsF2LsUF2)(U) to correct the orientation of the
edges in positions 2, 6 (UB, DB).

I did the same thing with the U face behind and the L face on top,
i.e.
(U')(FsUF'U'BsLFL'F2URsF2LsUF2)(U) to correct the orientation of the
edges in positions 4, 8 (UL, DL).

To finish off the orientation I did the same thing with
the U face behind and the F face on top, i.e.
(U')(FsUF'U'BsLFL'F2URsF2LsUF2)(U) to correct the orientation of the
edges in positions 1, 5 (UF, DF).

Then I rotated so that the U face was on top and the B face behind
again (i.e. usual position).

(U2)(RaU2Ra'Fa'U2Fa) placed corners 1, 3 and 4 and put corner 7
(DBR) into position 2 (UFL).

With the B face on top and F face behind,

F'LF'R2FL'F'R2F2 placed corners 5 and 8 (DFR and DBL).

Still corners 7 and 2 (DBR, UFL) needed to be swapped.

With the cube in its proper orientation,

(B2)(L'BL'F2LB'L'F2L2)(B2) placed corner 7 at the expense of corners
1 and 2 needing to be switched.

To switch those corners, I rotated the cube so that the U face was
still on top but the F face was behind and used

U'L2DF2D'L2B2D'R2DB2

before restoring the cube to its proper orientation. This had the
effect of also switching the edges in positions 1 and 2 (i.e. edges
5 and 1).

Next, I cycled the edges 11, 3 and 7 (in positions 3, 9 and 11) with
R face on top and B face behind using L2U'BsL2FsU'L2 (this was a
little inefficient, I should have used U instead of U'). The
intention was to cycle 9 into place and simulatneously place edge
11, but then I would still need to place several other edges which
would have been easier the other way.

This was followed by (in proper orientation) U2R2U2R2U2R2, placing
edge 1.

Again with R face on top and B face behind
L2U'BsL2FsU'L2 placed edge 3. This got edge 11 back into position 9
for the 3 cycle I alluded to earlier but now edges 1 and 3 were
placed and 7 would be placed as a bonus.

Then, still with R face on top and B face behind
R2UFsR2BsUR2 placed edges 9, 11 and 7.

With L face on top and B face behind,

(R')(R2UFsR2BsUR2)(R) placed edge 2, completing the first layer.
Of course, some Rs could be cancelled here, saving time, but its
easier not too, in terms of keeping focused.

Still with L face on top and B face behind,

(L')(L2UBsL2FsUL2)(L) placed edge 5.

Still with L face on top and B face behind,

(L))(L2UBsL2FsUL2)(L') placed edges 6, 12 and 10, completing the
cube.

Finally, I restored the cube to its proper orientation (i.e. with my
chosen U face on top and F face in front) and waited for the haircut
to finish, which was probably no more than 2 or 3 minutes.



1380. Re: [Speed cubing group] Thought processes in blindfold cubing
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 21 Sep 2002 13:53:52 +0100


>Today, I did the cube blindfolded whilst getting my hair cut -
>technically, I wasn't blindfolded, but the cube was under the black
>sheet they put over so it was effectively the same. There was a bit
>of time pressure as I had to finish before the cut.

Thanks for posting this Dr C. I found it really useful.
S.

PS I shudder to think what the hairdresser / other customers thought was
going on under the black cover.

1381. Re: [Speed cubing group] Thought processes in blindfold cubing

1382. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New Cube
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 21 Sep 2002 15:07:56 +0100

Wal Mart are very well known here as an American thing. We don't (as
yet) have a Wal Mart here, but they own one of our major super market
chains. I've heard something about re-branding the chain. The
supermarket is currently called ASDA (pronounced azda and it's short
for associated dairies). ASDA do not currently sell cubes I'm afraid.
The thing is, most of our supermarkets are not as big as yours. I know
that they will start building some super mega ultra double sized
supermarkets soon, it's the American influence. Hopefully, more cubes
on the way!

Date: Sat, 21 Sep 2002 15:28:54 -0000

We don't (as > yet) have a Wal Mart here, but they own one of our major super market > chains. I've heard something about re-branding the chain. The > supermarket is currently called ASDA (pronounced azda and it's short > for associated dairies). ASDA do not currently sell cubes I'm afraid. > The thing is, most of our supermarkets are not as big as yours. I know > that they will start building some super mega ultra double sized > supermarkets soon, it's the American influence. Hopefully, more cubes > on the way! Whenever I get a new cube, the little plasticy film things start to peel immediately. I either paint it, or I put vinyl film stickers on, but the worst part is that I can't turn the cube fast because it's soo loose! I got this one off the net, where can I find a good one?
1384. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New Cube
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 21 Sep 2002 17:10:40 +0100

> Whenever I get a new cube, the little plasticy film things start to
> peel immediately. I either paint it, or I put vinyl film stickers
> on, but the worst part is that I can't turn the cube fast because
> it's soo loose!
> I got this one off the net, where can I find a good one?
>
IMHO, I believe that Oddzon make the best NEW cubes. You can get far
better ones if you buy an old one though. I bought a cube off Ebay,
from the esteemed cuber, Dan Knights. I'd also recommend speaking to
Dan Gosbee (DanG), I'm sure he can supply you with the goods, or at
least point you in the right direction.

1391. Cube with a picture in each face
From: "Daniel Gondran" <lorusbr@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 21 Sep 2002 21:25:48 -0300

Hello All,

First of all, sorry my bad english.

I have a rubik´s cube with a picture stamped in each face.

When the cube is resolved, the central piece of two opposites faces stay
upside-down!

All the other faces are ok.

My question: Is there a sequence of moviments to fix it???

Thanks in advance.

Daniel

1392. Re: [Speed cubing group] Youngest person to solve the cube
From: "Robert Roue" <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 22 Sep 2002 13:12:33 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > > Now I need someone to translate her Polish quote ;-) > > > I have a bona fide Polish Friend. I'll get her to translate it. > > This is what I learnt from her so far. Co tam u ciebie? That means, > How are you? OK, this is what my friend, Sophie came up with. What she said has got nothing to do with Rubik's Cube!! she says 'greetings for all the young polish people living in POland and in the world. Vikki' (wikusia is an abreviation of Victoria). where did u get it from??? Sophie I hope that is of some use to you all!
1393. Re: Cube with a picture in each face
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 22 Sep 2002 13:21:33 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Daniel Gondran" <lorusbr@y...> wrote: > Hello All, > > First of all, sorry my bad english. > It is better than that of many native speakers. > I have a rubik´s cube with a picture stamped in each face. > > When the cube is resolved, the central piece of two opposites faces stay > upside-down! > > All the other faces are ok. > > My question: Is there a sequence of moviments to fix it??? (R2UFsR2BsUR2)^3 (Fs=FB', Bs=BF') will turn the centres on the U and R faces a half turn. Do this again but with the L face on top and the U face on the R and the net effect will be to turn the centres on the opposite R and L faces by a half turn. I'm sure there are quicker ways to do this, though. It's possible to do them individually too. Also, sometimes you might get them turned only by a quarter (there has to be an even number of those). > > Thanks in advance. > > Daniel > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

1395. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cube with a picture in each face
From: "Daniel Gondran" <lorusbr@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 22 Sep 2002 21:44:15 -0300

Yes! It Worked!! Many many many many thanx!!! Daniel ----- Original Message ----- From: GameOfDeath2 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Sunday, September 22, 2002 10:21 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cube with a picture in each face --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Daniel Gondran" <lorusbr@y...> wrote: > Hello All, > > First of all, sorry my bad english. > It is better than that of many native speakers. > I have a rubik´s cube with a picture stamped in each face. > > When the cube is resolved, the central piece of two opposites faces stay > upside-down! > > All the other faces are ok. > > My question: Is there a sequence of moviments to fix it??? (R2UFsR2BsUR2)^3 (Fs=FB', Bs=BF') will turn the centres on the U and R faces a half turn. Do this again but with the L face on top and the U face on the R and the net effect will be to turn the centres on the opposite R and L faces by a half turn. I'm sure there are quicker ways to do this, though. It's possible to do them individually too. Also, sometimes you might get them turned only by a quarter (there has to be an even number of those). [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1396. Re: Cube with a picture in each face
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 23 Sep 2002 01:46:48 -0000

If top and bottom need to turn in half use: R2F2B2L2D2R2F2B2L2U2

If top needs to be turned twice: (URLU2L'R')2

If top quarter clockwise and RIGHT quarter: R'UD'FBRL'UR'LFB'U'D

TOP AND BOTTOM QUARTER: RL'F2B2RL'URL'F2B2RL'D'

I think these all work

Jake

1403. my new puzzles!!
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 04:33:34 -0000

I just got a square-1, a megaminx, and a 5x5x5 cube. The megaminx
looks like the most interesting of the 3 puzzles, i cant wait till i
mix it up :)...im only going to work on them one at a time, and i
started with the square-1. So im not going to mix up the megaminx
until i solve the square-1...and the 5x5x5 will be last. Im NOT
going to cheat, by looking on the internet for solutions. So far I
can solve the f2l of the square-1. Im not sure if thats the best way
to go about solving it though...im thinkin it might be better to make
it a square first then find ways of moving things with out getting it
out from the square shape...(i havn't found the moves for that yet
though)...:|... oh well...
wish me luck.

ps....i was bored, and wanted to post something so this was it lol

-Heath
