1409. You little minx
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 14:58:58 +0100

How do people rate Megaminx for difficulty?

On Mefferts, they have the 5x5x5 and Megaminx as the joint hardest I think?
I've still not scrambled my Megaminx, but I can't imagine it's anywhere near
as hard as the 5x5x5. For a start, the are no slice turns, it's all caps.
Surely it's easy enough to get to the last cap at least? Then you just need
to perhaps adapt some 3x3x3 algs and maybe fix some parity issues?



1410. Re: You little minx
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 14:44:11 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > How do people rate Megaminx for difficulty? > I solved it the first time I tried. > On Mefferts, they have the 5x5x5 and Megaminx as the joint hardest I think? > I've still not scrambled my Megaminx, but I can't imagine it's anywhere near > as hard as the 5x5x5. A 5x5x5 isn't really that much more difficult than a 4x4x4. >For a start, the are no slice turns, it's all caps. > Surely it's easy enough to get to the last cap at least? Then you just need > to perhaps adapt some 3x3x3 algs and maybe fix some parity issues? No problems there; the corners and edges of the megaminx can be done independently. i.e. it is possible to solve one without (ultimately) changing the other (although obviously at intermediate stages it is likely to be changed).
1411. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: You little minx
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 15:59:03 +0100

> No problems there; the corners and edges of the megaminx can be done
> independently. i.e. it is possible to solve one without (ultimately)
> changing the other (although obviously at intermediate stages it is
> likely to be changed).
>

What are you saying here? You can change one edge without affecting any
other edge and you can change one corner without affecting another corner?
Or are you saying that you can change any edge without affecting any other
corner and visa versa?

Also, there are pairs of edges that are the same on the 6 colour minx. Does
this pose a problem?



1412. Re: You little minx
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 16:51:11 -0000

Provided you don't solve the 3x3x3 cube using a corners first method, the megaminx will not be much different until you get to the last face. Even then, it's just a matter of knowing (or figuring out) how to approach it - I do it in four steps: 1) orient edges 2) position edges 3) orient corners 4) position corners Also, some of the algs are going to be a bit different. As far as difficulty, I can solve my megaminx faster, on average, than my master cube, much less a 5x5x5 (which I've never actually been able to try, aside from computer versions). However, I have to admit that while my my minx moves very well, my master cube isn't very well broken in. I've lubed my 4x4x4, but it still doesn't move very well. Anyways, I think what makes the megaminx difficult (or at least time consuming)is the challenge in looking for pieces. I've never tried a 5x5x5, but with my 4x4x4, I know the main reason I can't go faster isn't because of time wasted looking for pieces - it's mainly the difficulty of moving the puzzle. Consider this: - On a 5x5x5 cube, the center pieces are on one of only 6 faces. The edge pieces are on one of only 12 edges, and the corners are in only one of 8 corner positions. - On a megaminx, the edges are on one of 30 edges (or 2, if you have a 6 color minx) and the corners are in one of 20 corner positions. Additionally, if you have a 6 color minx, every corner has a semi- twin; they share colors, but not in the same orientation. Also, there is a potential parity problem - you'll have to swap two identical edges to fix it. Depending on how far along you get in your solution (and how your solution goes), you may have to redo a considerable amount of the puzzle (I don't personally know of any algs for a minx that affect only the edge pieces). --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > How do people rate Megaminx for difficulty? > > On Mefferts, they have the 5x5x5 and Megaminx as the joint hardest I think? > I've still not scrambled my Megaminx, but I can't imagine it's anywhere near > as hard as the 5x5x5. For a start, the are no slice turns, it's all caps. > Surely it's easy enough to get to the last cap at least? Then you just need > to perhaps adapt some 3x3x3 algs and maybe fix some parity issues?
1413. [Speed cubing group] Re: You little minx
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 17:16:53 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > > No problems there; the corners and edges of the megaminx can be done > > independently. i.e. it is possible to solve one without (ultimately) > > changing the other (although obviously at intermediate stages it is > > likely to be changed). > > > > What are you saying here? You can change one edge without affecting any > other edge and you can change one corner without affecting another corner? > Or are you saying that you can change any edge without affecting any other > corner and visa versa? I'm saying that the edges can be solved without affecting the corners and vice versa. The permutations are all even (because face turns are 5 cycles of corners and 5 cycles of vertices - in the cube they are 4 cycles of corners and of vertices so the permutations can be odd). It follows, since the alternating group is generated by 3- cycles, that if you can do a move which just 3-cycles corners then you can permute the corners without affecting the edges. Similarly if you can do a move which just 3-cycles edges then you can permute the edges without affecting the corners. Both types of move exist. Furthermore you can flip 2 edges without doing anything else and you can twist 3 corners without doing anything else. Using conjugation, it is straightforward to see that you only need to have one 3-cycle algorithm for corners, one 3-cycle algorithm for edges, one algorithm to flip 2 edges and one algorithm to twist 3 corners. (You need that the group is 2-transitive on the corners and 2-transitive on the edges, but that's not so hard.) It follows that the corners and edges can be solved independently - this isn't always the case in the cube. The centres can be twisted independently too. > > Also, there are pairs of edges that are the same on the 6 colour minx. Does > this pose a problem?
1414. Re: You little minx
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 17:41:24 -0000

Pretty much the minx is a combination of the alexanders star and the impossiball or thomas ball. Both alone are easy to solve so I'm guessing that when there together there not all that bad either. My friend had a minx and i could get it down to the last pentagon, he tried showing me moves but they didn't stick, anyway these moves reminded me of a skewbical sequence. So you can pretty much solve the minx as a whole and apply skewb like sequences to the last pentagon. I don't know if this makes any sense, or if i am horribly off but thats the way i look at it. Jake (I wrote my dissapointed letter today) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > > > No problems there; the corners and edges of the megaminx can be > done > > > independently. i.e. it is possible to solve one without > (ultimately) > > > changing the other (although obviously at intermediate stages it > is > > > likely to be changed). > > > > > > > What are you saying here? You can change one edge without > affecting any > > other edge and you can change one corner without affecting another > corner? > > Or are you saying that you can change any edge without affecting > any other > > corner and visa versa? > > I'm saying that the edges can be solved without affecting the > corners and vice versa. The permutations are all even (because face > turns are 5 cycles of corners and 5 cycles of vertices - in the cube > they are 4 cycles of corners and of vertices so the permutations can > be odd). It follows, since the alternating group is generated by 3- > cycles, that if you can do a move which just 3-cycles corners then > you can permute the corners without affecting the edges. Similarly > if you can do a move which just 3-cycles edges then you can permute > the edges without affecting the corners. Both types of move exist. > > Furthermore you can flip 2 edges without doing anything else and you > can twist 3 corners without doing anything else. > > Using conjugation, it is straightforward to see that you only need > to have one 3-cycle algorithm for corners, one 3-cycle algorithm for > edges, one algorithm to flip 2 edges and one algorithm to twist 3 > corners. (You need that the group is 2-transitive on the corners and > 2-transitive on the edges, but that's not so hard.) > > It follows that the corners and edges can be solved independently - > this isn't always the case in the cube. > > The centres can be twisted independently too. > > > > > Also, there are pairs of edges that are the same on the 6 colour > minx. Does > > this pose a problem?

1416. Orientation for F2L
From: "Adam Slate" <adam@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 17:20:01 -0400

I've always solved using the corners-first method and I'm toying with the idea of learning the Fridrich method. Just curious... do most people solve the first two layers pointing down (i.e., the bottom two layers) or pointing up (the top two layers). Is there any significant consensus on this?

Thanks,
Adam


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1417. Re: Orientation for F2L
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 22:29:52 -0000

When I first learned a layer-by-layer method, I had my cross on the top. Doing it like that made it hard to look ahead, though, as most of the unsolved pieces were not directly visible. When I started improving my F2L, I moved my cross to the left, because I found some algs for the F2L that worked with the cross on the left. I've found lately, though, that I have an easier time looking ahead if my LL is up, so that the face I can see completely is also completely unsolved, and more likely to have the pieces I'm looking for. I would say my recommendation is to have the cross down, unless you can look ahead well with it at the left, and find those algs easier to perform. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Adam Slate" <adam@s...> wrote: > I've always solved using the corners-first method and I'm toying with the idea of learning the Fridrich method. Just curious... do most people solve the first two layers pointing down (i.e., the bottom two layers) or pointing up (the top two layers). Is there any significant consensus on this? > > Thanks, > Adam

Did you see the marble > thing he's selling? What I like about rubik puzzles is the mechanical > genius behind them. That marble thing was pretty cool, but he shouldn't advertise it or try to sell it. If he said something like: I found a new puzzle! Click here to see it! Then it would be better.
1419. Re: Orientation for F2L
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 23:27:53 -0000

I go top down. When I first got into cubing, this seemed the natural way to do it and so I got used to it. As you point out, there are logical reasons why not to do it this way. Having said this, years ago a friend who does LL on top taught me a new LL algorithm. Because he had LL on top, that was how I learnt it. So now when I'm doing the LL, I have the original cross face on the top or the bottom depending on the particular LL sequence. Hmmm... this is rather inefficient isn't it. :/ Jasmine. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Grant Tregay" <Grant@T...> wrote: > When I first learned a layer-by-layer method, I had my cross on the > top. Doing it like that made it hard to look ahead, though, as most > of the unsolved pieces were not directly visible. When I started > improving my F2L, I moved my cross to the left, because I found some > algs for the F2L that worked with the cross on the left. I've found > lately, though, that I have an easier time looking ahead if my LL is > up, so that the face I can see completely is also completely > unsolved, and more likely to have the pieces I'm looking for. I > would say my recommendation is to have the cross down, unless you can > look ahead well with it at the left, and find those algs easier to > perform. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Adam Slate" <adam@s...> wrote: > > I've always solved using the corners-first method and I'm toying > with the idea of learning the Fridrich method. 1421. Re: [Speed cubing group] Orientation for F2L
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 25 Sep 2002 09:00:28 +0100

It is going to boil down to personal taste I suppose, but it is not entirely subjective. Judging from the sites on the Fridrich method it seems that more people do F2L with the cross underneath than on the top or on the side. When I began learning F2L I started with the cross on the bottom. After learning the main algs I suddenly realized that working with the cross on the side would be equally fast, and maybe, for me, faster. (Especially for algs where the corner / edge pair are not touching, and the corner cube has the cross colour facing up.) But at that stage I was not thinking about the looking ahead part, and I reckon that cutting down on the looking/thinking part is more important for getting F2L times down than executing algs 5% faster. And for me looking ahead feels more natural with the cross on the bottom than on the side. Good luck Adam! I would be interested to know what you decide to do, and how you find F2l comparing with corners first. I have been learning F2L for a while, and have only recently started to get a glimpse of its true speed potential. It seems to me that to get F2L times down you need to be able to look ahead pretty much for the whole thing, plus have a large repertoire of short cuts that take advantage of the spare corners that are available at the start of the F2L, but not at the end. S. >From: "Adam Slate" <adam@...> >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> >Subject: [Speed cubing group] Orientation for F2L >Date: Tue, 24 Sep 2002 17:20:01 -0400 > >I've always solved using the corners-first method and I'm toying with the >idea of learning the Fridrich method. Just curious... do most people solve >the first two layers pointing down (i.e., the bottom two layers) or >pointing up (the top two layers). Is there any significant consensus on >this? > >Thanks, >Adam > > >[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > _________________________________________________________________ Send and receive Hotmail on your mobile device: http://mobile.msn.com

1429. First post
From: "dsletten" <dsletten@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 01:11:43 -0000

Hi all. I wanted to post to this group to thank the speed cubing
community for having such a great net presence! I thought it might
be fun to share how I recently got interested / obsessed with
learning to speed solve, so...

I was in elementary school when the cube came out, and learned
the "Simple Solution" from the book, a basic layer by layer approach,
as I'm sure you know. So I somehow kept that knowledge alive and
well for the intervening 15 years or so (!) and then I went to a
great baseball game a while ago... It was the Giants game when Barry
hit number 600, and it was 80s night, so they gave away Gaints-themed
Rubiks cubes to the fans! This was a picture cube with pics of 4 of
the players! So I showed off to my friends that I could all-but-
solve it (the only problem being the final orientation of the
centers).

So the next day I hit the web, found a site that had the moves to
rotate centers on a picture cube, and in the process found all the
speed solving sites. That sounded pretty darn cool to me, so I tried
learning Lars' method first, but found it too different from the way
I was used to. So then I found Jessica's site, and ever since I've
been memorizing alogrithms!

So much thanks to everyone who has a solver site out there,
particularly Lars, Jessica, and Dan Knights, and whoever that was
with the picture solver site!

(I'm about halfway throught the LL algos, and have improved from 90
sec to around 50 sec. cool!)

-Dan

Welcome to the club!....

yeah, hang in there on those algs and make sure you learn them so
they fit your hands, and you can do them with finger tricks...(in
other words, learn them so you can do them FAST)....

if you ever have any questions about moves or any aspect of the cube
(or any other related puzzles) feel free to ask away!......oh and on
the weekends a few or more of us members can be found in the chat
room (there is a link on the left side of the screen)....the chat
room is really good for getting/giving help.

lol, its kewl that your name is Dan, lol....Dan knights averages 17.3
seconds, and Dan goosbe averages 16.89 seconds.. :D so i guess that
means your destin for greatness.....but ya know maybe you just need a
three letter name, because Ron is right in there too! haha

-Heath

1434. Megaminx & 5x5x5

coloured. I tried asking but got no response. Also, does anybody
know the exact colour scheme for their 5x5x5 (i.e. not just white-
opposite-blue, but the rest of it too). Finally, do their tiles
stick or not. I once got a tiled cube and one tile came off almost
immediately, but my Megaminx stickers also came off really fast - in
fact one came off before I ever used it.



1435. Re: Megaminx & 5x5x5
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 16:48:26 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > It's unclear whether the Megaminx at Meffert's is 12-coloured or 6- > coloured. I tried asking but got no response. Also, does anybody > know the exact colour scheme for their 5x5x5 (i.e. not just white- > opposite-blue, but the rest of it too). Finally, do their tiles > stick or not. I once got a tiled cube and one tile came off almost > immediately, but my Megaminx stickers also came off really fast - in > fact one came off before I ever used it. the megaminx I just got from mefferts has 6 colors. On mefferts.com you can get the 5x5x5 in either white opp yellow, red/orange, green/blue....OR, white opp. blue, yellow/green, red/orange. the tiles stick out....the tiles look like they would stay on fairly well, if not then a little super glue would hold them on :D......on my minx, some of the stickers were already coming off in the package...im going to have to use some super glue or something to get them to stick. -Heath
1436. Re: Megaminx & 5x5x5
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 16:55:22 -0000

I'm glad to hear I'm not the only person that has trouble gettings answers from the Mefferts. I once got an e-mail from them saying they thought they had responded, but since "we get over 100 e-mails per day, ..." I guess they skipped mine. So, your e-mail may have gotten lost in the mix. Anyways, I got a megaminx from Meffert's store, back when it came with tiles. Mine is (was) 12 colors. I would assume they still are. >From the picture though (https://www.megasecurestores.com/mefferts.com/images/puzzles/new/mega minx-l-stickers.jpg), it looks like there are two yellow faces that aren't event directly opposite. I suppose that one may have been made special for the picture, though (don't know why they would, but ...). For the 5x5x5, they have two color schemes these are the pairs of opposite sides: 1) White-Yellow, Green-Blue, Red-Orange 2) White-Blue, Green-Yellow, Red-Orange (Taken from http://www.mefferts.com/index_noflash.html) Again, from the pictures (https://www.megasecurestores.com/mefferts.com/images/puzzles/new/prof cube-blue-l.jpg and https://www.megasecurestores.com/mefferts.com/images/puzzles/new/profc ube-yellow-l.jpg), it looks like these are your two color scheme options (Putting Blue on the U face): Option1 - D=Green, F=Red, B=Orange, L=White, R=Yellow Option2 - D=White, F=Red, B=Orange, L=Yellow, R=Green As far as whether or not the tiles stick, not really. So far I've gotten 2 tiled puzzles from them - a 3 color assembly cube (haven't used it much, so the tiles haven't come off) and a 12 color megaminx. At first, quite a few of the megaminx's tiles had come off, so I decided I would take them all off and reglue them with super glue, but after doing one face (11 tiles), I realized how long it was going to take (121 tiles to go), and now I just reglue as necessary. I would guess I've probably had my megaminx for 1 1/2 years, and have reglued at least half of the tiles (but I do put a it through a lot of use). I asked them about this, and they claimed that they recently (probably 1/2 - 1 year ago now) had to make their glue weaker to abide by new toy safety laws. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > It's unclear whether the Megaminx at Meffert's is 12-coloured or 6- > coloured. I tried asking but got no response. Also, does anybody > know the exact colour scheme for their 5x5x5 (i.e. not just white- > opposite-blue, but the rest of it too). Finally, do their tiles > stick or not. I once got a tiled cube and one tile came off almost > immediately, but my Megaminx stickers also came off really fast - in > fact one came off before I ever used it.

that they had received my order, it was a personal email from Hong Kong (I

order page).

1439. Triggers for Petrus Method
From: Ranovek <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 22:46:10 -0000

Hi, this is my first time posting here. I have just bought the cube
a month ago, but since then I have been completely enamored
with it. I currently am solving it using the Petrus Method with a
best time of 1:05, still trying to break the one minute mark.
Anyways, I found on the website that all the listed trigger are
made for the left hand since that is apparently what Lars uses to
solve it. I was wondering if there's an easy conversion to right
hand (since that's what I use) or whether I basically have to find
my own triggers. Any help would be appreciated.

~Matthias



1440. Re: [Speed cubing group] Triggers for Petrus Method
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 2002 23:20:54 -0000

...you could do the reflection of what Lars does. you would change
how you hold the cube to..F side becomes L, R side becomes F, U
staies U...

for a reflection like that the moves would change like this
R=L'
R'=L
L=R'
L'=R
R2=L2
L2=R2
U=U'
U'=U
D=D'
D'=D
D2=D2
F=F'
F'=F
F2=F2
B'=B
B=B'
B2=B2
....there that should cover everything, i hope
lol

-Heath



1441. Re: Orientation for F2L
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 27 Sep 2002 07:18:49 -0000

If I've had a bit of a practice then about a minute, otherwise more like 70-75 seconds. I should explain a few things at this point. These times are using an old inefficient layer-by-layer-by-layer method that I learned many years ago. I know this method is crap, so I've been working on learning the Fridrich method for the F2L. I've pretty much learnt the moves, but they are not yet in my subconscious (ie. I have to think about what I'm doing) so I don't actually use them when demonstrating speedcubing for people. I'm sure my times will improve when I've got the Fridrich F2L stuff in my subconscious. As the for LL, I'm currently using a combination of some algorithms I learnt many years ago plus a few Petrus LL algs. Using the stuff I've been learning recently it still takes me a few minutes because I have to think about the steps. While I'll always think that the cube is probably the best puzzle ever invented, I'm not a must-cube-for-hours-a-day person. There are times when I cube a bit everyday, and there are periods when I don't cube for weeks or months at a time. Jasmine. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > What times are you getting? > Jake > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > I go top down. When I first got into cubing, this seemed the > natural > > way to do it and so I got used to it. As you point out, there are > > logical reasons why not to do it this way. > > > > Having said this, years ago a friend who does LL on top taught me a > > new LL algorithm. Because he had LL on top, that was how I learnt > it. > > So now when I'm doing the LL, I have the original cross face on the > > top or the bottom depending on the particular LL sequence. > > > > Hmmm... this is rather inefficient isn't it. :/ > > > > Jasmine. > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Grant Tregay" <Grant@T...> > wrote: > > > When I first learned a layer-by-layer method, I had my cross on > the > > > top. Doing it like that made it hard to look ahead, though, as > most > > > of the unsolved pieces were not directly visible. When I started > > > improving my F2L, I moved my cross to the left, because I found > > some > > > algs for the F2L that worked with the cross on the left. I've > > found > > > lately, though, that I have an easier time looking ahead if my LL > > is > > > up, so that the face I can see completely is also completely > > > unsolved, and more likely to have the pieces I'm looking for. I > > > would say my recommendation is to have the cross down, unless you > > can > > > look ahead well with it at the left, and find those algs easier > to > > > perform. > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Adam Slate" <adam@s...> > wrote: > > > > I've always solved using the corners-first method and I'm > toying > > > with the idea of learning the Fridrich method. Just curious... > do > > > most people solve the first two layers pointing down (i.e., the > > > bottom two layers) or pointing up (the top two layers). Is there > > any > > > significant consensus on this? > > > > > > > > Thanks, > > > > Adam

1455. Re: Studio Cubes
From: turnthatcube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 28 Sep 2002 07:06:28 -0000

A studio cube is a real Rubiks Cube with the old 1980 logo from Hungary, suitable to make it a speed cube. It has vinyl stickers and screws under the center cap. The rubiks.com cubes have poor sticker quality, but I believe the are or will be replaced. And the new Rubik.com (Oddzon) cubes do not have any screws under the center, so you can not fine tune the tension. So in short the Oddzon cube is fine, but a Studio Rubiks Cube from Hungary is better. You would only need a speedcube is your average is near 30 Seconds. Else you can only gain little time because of the best material. I prepare the cubes for Ron van Bruchem, he as an avergae of 17 Seconds. I gues even with a bas cube he will be fast e.g. 17.5 seconds. But if you want the best you must make your own speedcube. The best cube however are the 1980 Arxon Rubik's cube, but you would need a new unused one to make it a speedcube. But this is a collectable. Thats all Ton --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., cubacca1972 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I am not sure I understand what a studio cube is. Is it the same as > the ones sold at rubiks.com? Are there multiple companies which > manufacture official rubik's cubes? > > If they are different, what qualities make them so good for speed > cubing? > > Do they have vinyl or paper stickers? > > Where can I get one? > > Lucas

This cube will make a > great speedcube. 1459. oddzon cubes
From: "betrayedfiber" <htkra1d@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 28 Sep 2002 15:47:10 -0000

Inspired by the recent speedcube talk explosion here, I tried to follow Dennenbroeks step by step instruction on one of MY cubes, which is NOT a studio cube and it turned out bad. Anyway, I believe this is an Oddzon cube, maybe an "old" oddzon cube seeing as how someone just explained that "new" oddzon cubes don't have screws under the center caps. I'll describe it. I can remove the center caps with a knife, and there are screws under them but it's basically impossible for me to turn them, as I can't hold back the metal ring around them (i.e. the metal ring turns with the screw). It does have those stickers with a film on them that wear out in days. I was just wondering if anyone had any step by step instructions ala Dennenbroeks that apply to these cubes, as these are basically the only ones I can get hold of. I have a "decent" one but it's singing on it's last verse I suppose.

All I know to do is to work it intensively for two weeks and then lube it with silicon spray (which I got). So there aren't any cheap shortcuts like with the studio cubes (which I can't get hold of by the way). I just tried lubing one that I didn't work as intensively on beforehand (a new one). It worked out all right apart from one thing, I have to use a lot of force to *begin* turning a side, but when it has started moving it moves all right.

Also about that crispy sound. On the Jon Morris' video - is THAT crispy? Will it remain crispy after being used a while and lubed etc.?

Whey, that's a lot of questions. Hope someone got the answers



1460. RE: [Speed cubing group] oddzon cubes
From: Tyler Robbins <sum1else@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 28 Sep 2002 12:00:25 -0400

Go into the "Files" section of the site Get MVC-001v.mpg That's what "Crisp" cubes sound like. Remember though, it isnt as loud as it is on the vid. In this vid the cube is 1" away from the camera's mic. That's my favorite cube. its better than any rubik studio cube. I think its English. Wokinham Berks I think. (Thanks dan, for recommending this kind of cube) The cubies are hollow yet it turns better than any studio I've ever had. -Tyler Robbins <http://www.thepuzzlestore.com/> www.thepuzzlestore.com Specializing in Custom Sequential movement puzzles Ebay UserID: Sum1else -----Original Message----- From: betrayedfiber [mailto:htkra1d@...] Sent: Saturday, September 28, 2002 11:47 AM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] oddzon cubes Inspired by the recent speedcube talk explosion here, I tried to follow Dennenbroeks step by step instruction on one of MY cubes, which is NOT a studio cube and it turned out bad. 1461. Re: [Speed cubing group] oddzon cubes
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 28 Sep 2002 21:03:21 -0000

So far the oddzon cubes are the only cubes in my area. This is how i
break mine in for a somewhat speedcube.
1. first do several solves
2. next stretch the cube
I like to use plastic gift cards, old drivers liscense, phone
cards, etc...

I stick the cards in between the pieces
Put cards in vertically on F and B
Horizontally on R and L
and = on U and D
THis usually works well if you let the cube sit for awhile or cycle
the cards around from = to ||
WARNING: some oddzon cubes begin to pop after too much stretching!!!

3. Remove every piece from the cube and lube each piece and skeleton
with silicon.
Wait untill silicone is dry before reassembling cube.

4. Next i like to spin each side independantly and then do all slices
for awhile.

This works pretty good for me. Don't try stretching mefferts cubes
or cubes without any springs, they like to snap the centers off.

Again this is how i do my cubes, I think its the best way to break in
an oddzon cube, but thats just me
Jake



1462. Skewbing
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 29 Sep 2002 20:02:32 +0100

I've had a Skewb for about a year and it has been sadly neglected. I
can solve it using my own algs, but my technique stinks. Has anyone
got a video I can watch? Can someone make a video? I'd like to see
how people manipulate the Skewb, because I find it quite hard.

Mine is a mini one by the way. I have a proper one in the pipeline.

one gives me RSI, I only figured out two algs to solve it and it could
take me anywhere from 5 mins upwards to solve. It's so funny how it
moves though. That's why I've splashed out on the full size one.
Hopefully I can improve my fingering that way.

1466. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Skewbing
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 30 Sep 2002 18:46:52 +0100

> Yeah! turning is so weird but I find it the easiest palming the
> puzzle with one hand and turning with the other if that helps,
> otherwise it likes to "jump" out of my grasp. I'm ranked second on
> the unofficial records page the last time i checked.
>
Using my two home grown algs, I got 1:40 this afternoon. I hope I can
get faster when the full size one turns up! My method goes like this:
Fix four corners on bottom. Use 4 move alg to fix last four corners
(may need to be used a few times!). Use 12 move alg to fix centres
(again, may be needed a few times!).

Funny thing is, I can't get my head around the Skewb Diamond at all! I
know it's the same as the Skewb (corners are equivalent of faces of
Skewb, etc). Just need to work on it some more I suppose.

1484. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Skewbing
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 2 Oct 2002 19:15:26 +0100

> Using my two home grown algs, I got 1:40 this afternoon. I hope I can
> get faster when the full size one turns up! My method goes like this:
> Fix four corners on bottom. Use 4 move alg to fix last four corners
> (may need to be used a few times!). Use 12 move alg to fix centres
> (again, may be needed a few times!).
>
> Funny thing is, I can't get my head around the Skewb Diamond at all! I
> know it's the same as the Skewb (corners are equivalent of faces of
> Skewb, etc). Just need to work on it some more I suppose.

Yesterday, I took delivery of my first full size Skewb and instantly my
times plummeted! I can get down to about 40 seconds and I know that
this time tomorrow I'll have got it down some more :]

I also got a Skewb Ultimate, but there is a loose piece of plastic
inside. It still works but I'm not happy about the rattle, anyone else
get a rattle?

AND! I got a Pyraminx with loose tiles in the packing :[ Worst of
all, there is a tile that has been glued on so wonky that it overlaps
another tile and stops it from turning. I emailed Mefferts yesterday
about it and they didn't reply. I'm not happy with them, because I've
seen postings on here about the loose tiles.

1487. Re: First post
From: "dsletten" <dsletten@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 02 Oct 2002 19:31:14 -0000

I'm intentionally not timing myself too much right now, until I learn more of the algs. BUT, I'm usually solving the F2L in 35 secs, and the LL in 15 when I know the orient and permute. I'll bet my fastest is low 40s. I think the hardest part is quickly finding corner-edge pairs in the F2L, but I guess that just comes with practice, right? I find that I can start looking for the next pair with 2 or 3 moves left to place the one I'm working one. I suppose when you're really good, you pretty much start looking for the next pair as soon as you start the move sequence to place the current one? -Dan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "James Potter" <theboywholived81@y...> wrote: > Cool, that's the book I learned the cube first in too. > What's your Personal Best time?
1488. My first winnings!
From: rquethe <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 04 Oct 2002 00:37:28 -0000

I won $150 in a local high school talent show contest. My talent:
solving Rubik's cubes of course. Specifically, I solved four cubes in
under such-and-such amount of time. They had me do an encore
performance on an outside stage for a festival here in town. Hundreds
of people watched as I solved four cubes in two minutes seven
seconds. BOY did that feel great! Averaged 31.75 seconds per cube and
that's without any preinspection time of any sort. In short, this was
a great experience for getting better at cubing in front of people.
I've found that when my thoughts are going as fast as I can, I do
poorly, but when I think about looking ahead, I do great. You just
have to actively solve the cube. In this way, everything transitions
smoothly and you don't slow down.

I'm going to use this money for A - Going to Toronto, or B - buying
more puzzles... Haven't made up my mind yet.



1489. [Speed cubing group] Re: Make your own speedcube!
From: "dsletten" <dsletten@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 04 Oct 2002 00:38:59 -0000

I'm wondering where y'all get replacement stickers too... guess I'll email this guy myself. I personally found some colored tape that I've used to make stickers on 2 of my cubes. They both had the extremely crappy stickers with the plastic coating on top. For those who care, I found Scotch brand colored plastic tape at an Orchard Hardware store, which gave me white, yellow (a little pale though), red, blue, and green. I then found orange electrical tape (and a better yellow and green) at Fry's Electronics, a massive electronics store / chain around here. So it's possible to find some decent tape to use, it's just a pain to cut it up into lots of little squares! Oh well, at least I don't have to feel all those nasty curling plastic coating things any more. -Dan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "DanG" <dgosbee@s...> wrote: > email wc2003@r... > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: cheukyor > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@y... > Sent: Friday, September 27, 2002 3:58 PM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Make your own speedcube! > > > Where can I get that same cube for $6.98, Dan? > > Also... ANYBODY know where can I get PVC stickers???? I bought some > from Rubiks.com and they turned out to be cheap paper stickers and > not PVC as they had advertised... SUX, actually, really SUX > > Please, anybody know? or are anyone of you selling them?

1491. Mefferts
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 04 Oct 2002 09:54:00 +0100

I recently got some puzzles from Mefferts and two of them have problems. The
Ultimate has a rattle and the Pyraminx has tiles that fall off. I emailed
Uwe and he advised that I simply take apart the Ultimate and get the loose
ball bearing out. I hate taking apart those Skewb things, they are so hard
to get back together :[ Anyway, I did it, but it still rattles. There is
something in one of the sealed 'fixed' corners. Can anyone advise what I
should do about it?

I have offered an opinion to Uwe about the tiles falling off. Apparently,
they cannot use superglue in the factory anymore. That means for the
foreseeable future, all tiled puzzles from Meffets are liable to loose their
tiles. I suggested that he should change the design so that the tiles clip
in, in a secure manner. That way, no glue is needed and also, you can
change the colour layout if you prefer it your own way. There would be no
more surveys and arguments then ;)

Do you think that's a good idea? Can anyone suggest to Mefferts a way of
making tiles that clip in securely? It would have to be designed so that
the tiles sit flat with no visible clips, the tiles don't 'shift' around and
they can easily be taken off with a small screw driver, say.




1492. Re: Mefferts
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 04 Oct 2002 23:29:27 -0000

Sounds good in theory but if it involves major changes as far as the equipment goes then I'd be surprised if they did it. For the tiles to clip in then I'd imagine that this would mean the moulded plastic would have to be indented instead of flat (which is what I imagine they are for the stickers?). I'd be interested to hear if there are any improvements! Jasmine. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > I recently got some puzzles from Mefferts and two of them have problems. The > Ultimate has a rattle and the Pyraminx has tiles that fall off. I emailed > Uwe and he advised that I simply take apart the Ultimate and get the loose > ball bearing out. I hate taking apart those Skewb things, they are so hard > to get back together :[ Anyway, I did it, but it still rattles. There is > something in one of the sealed 'fixed' corners. Can anyone advise what I > should do about it? > > I have offered an opinion to Uwe about the tiles falling off. Apparently, > they cannot use superglue in the factory anymore. That means for the > foreseeable future, all tiled puzzles from Meffets are liable to loose their > tiles. I suggested that he should change the design so that the tiles clip > in, in a secure manner. That way, no glue is needed and also, you can > change the colour layout if you prefer it your own way. There would be no > more surveys and arguments then ;) > > Do you think that's a good idea? Can anyone suggest to Mefferts a way of > making tiles that clip in securely? It would have to be designed so that > the tiles sit flat with no visible clips, the tiles don't 'shift' around and > they can easily be taken off with a small screw driver, say.

available in Australia). She's working in Washington. I think in
Arlington. Is there anywhere nearby that sells good 4x4x4's and

Jasmine.



1494. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Mefferts
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 5 Oct 2002 00:58:36 +0100

> Sounds good in theory but if it involves major changes as far as the
> equipment goes then I'd be surprised if they did it. For the tiles to
> clip in then I'd imagine that this would mean the moulded plastic
> would have to be indented instead of flat (which is what I imagine
> they are for the stickers?). I'd be interested to hear if there are
> any improvements!
>
> Jasmine.

The Mefferts puzzles are indeed flat sided for both the stickered and
the tiled versions. If they changed to clip ons, then there would be
lots of mould changes, like you say. It would be for both the puzzle
pieces and for the tiles themselves. Don't forget though, that they
currently sell two versions of the Professor, because people like two
different colour schemes. If they made clip ons, they could ship them
without them even attached! They would save money on the production
line in that respect.



1495. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Mefferts
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 5 Oct 2002 12:55:08 +0100

Mefferts are sending me a replacement Ultimate with no need to return
the one with loose ball bearings. Very kind of them I think.

1500. Variation on a Permutation.
From: rquethe <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 06 Oct 2002 04:45:49 -0000

Many of you are probably aware of the move (R'UR'U')x²y'(R'UR'U')
(x'(R²U'))(R'URU).

I have a (very) slight variation on it.

y2(L'UL'U')yx²(R'UR'U')(x'(R²U'))(R'URU)

As you can see, the first part is slightly altered but everything
else is the same. I was wondering if anyone thinks this is any easier
to do or not.



1501. Re: 20 sec cubers?
From: nviennefr <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 06 Oct 2002 17:19:26 -0000

Hi,

I average 25' and I use Fridrich system I think it's difficult to
break 23-24' barrier. And it requires a very hard work to improve.

I've got another question to speedcubist:
I am interrested on how many time speedcubist who have sub-20 record
( like Dan(s) , Ron, Jess etc...) usually do the cube ? 19-20?????

With my experience, I have calculated that you just add 2 second to
your personnal record to obtain your usually average . For exemple,
for me who have a record at 25' I usually average at 27' What do you
think guy about this ???


Nicolas.

1504. Dutch Cube Day 2002
From: "Ron" <ron@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 07 Oct 2002 12:57:53 -0000

Hi friendz,

Yesterday was the 22nd Dutch Cube Day. It was a big success.

We finally had the chance to meet with a.o. Dan Gosbee (gosd123),
Jessica Fridrich, Mirek Goljan, Oliver Hayden (stiff_hands), Ton
Dennenbroek (turnthatcube), Jaap Scherphuis (_jaap), Peter Jansen
(pejave) and Lars Vandenbergh (jazzthief81).

Check out the short report on my site and a big pile of pictures on
Ton Dennenbroek's site. http://members.lycos.nl/tdennenbroek/
Hope to post more pictures soon.

Thanks to Dan for coming over to Holland and for the presents!
Also thanks to Jessica and Mirek for being so nice and for joining us
for dinner.

It was an inspiring day. Hope to meet all the other speedcubists one
day. You are not alone!
You should have seen us in the restaurant. 6 cubes on the table and
the waiters were wondering which planet we came from.

Have fun,

Ron
http://www.speedcubing.com

1507. Amazing new record for me!
From: "david_cubemaster" <davidwesley@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 08 Oct 2002 21:02:01 -0000

Hi all cubers out there!
Today I made a great new record, avg 23,1! And I also solved the
cube on 13,5 sec! I could hardly beleive it, when I watched the
time. I was a bit lucky in the F2L, but not very much, and I had to
do both LL algs.

The past month I have thought myself to become faster and faster...
but nothing happened to my times (usually around 25,the fastest was
24.8). I was just waiting for an avg of maybe 24-24.5 any time soon,
but today I was in a really good shape. I always thought that I was
better than my times showed, and now I have got evidence of that.

With one year to go, I am starting to think about a way to get to
the WC. Hopefully, I will then have a sub-20 avg at least.
Keep practising!
/David (david_cubemaster)

1510. First attempt at Minxing
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 9 Oct 2002 01:06:16 +0100

I've been collecting puzzles for about 18 months but none of them ever
get played with... Until recently that is! They don't know what's hit
them! I have self taught myself (?!) the Skewbs, the quickest being
the Cube at 20 seconds (average 35 I guess), but the Diamond and
Ultimate take me a few minutes at the moment.

Tonight I tackled the MegaMinx. DAMN! It took well over an hour to
get as far as an oriented last cap! But even this I'm very proud of!
I found most simple cube moves worked until the last cap and now I'm
just fiddling :/ I found that a Sune can be adapted, for example
R'U2RU2R'UR or R'U2'RUR'UR but I don't yet know what can be done with
them, hehe, I think more observations are in order!. I don't expect
I'll be able to solve the last cap, at least not on my first attempt, I
don't even know how to spot a parity problem (six colour). I'll keep
trying but I think I'll have to resort to surfing for permutation algs!



1511. Re: First attempt at Minxing
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Oct 2002 02:44:23 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > I've been collecting puzzles for about 18 months but none of them ever > get played with... Until recently that is! They don't know what's hit > them! I have self taught myself (?!) the Skewbs, the quickest being > the Cube at 20 seconds (average 35 I guess), but the Diamond and > Ultimate take me a few minutes at the moment. > > Tonight I tackled the MegaMinx. DAMN! It took well over an hour to > get as far as an oriented last cap! But even this I'm very proud of! > I found most simple cube moves worked until the last cap and now I'm > just fiddling :/ I found that a Sune can be adapted, for example > R'U2RU2R'UR or R'U2'RUR'UR but I don't yet know what can be done with > them, hehe, I think more observations are in order!. I don't expect > I'll be able to solve the last cap, at least not on my first attempt, I > don't even know how to spot a parity problem (six colour). I'll keep > trying but I think I'll have to resort to surfing for permutation algs! its cool that you just started working on the megaminx. Yesterday was the first time i got the nerve to mix up my megaminx. I solved all but the last cap in about 25-30 mins..i've mixed it up and re-did all that i can do and solved all but the last cap 3 or 4 times now. I timed the last time and it wa about 7 and a half mins. I too need to figure out something for the LL on it....one time i oriented the LL, but had no clue how to permute it. good luck to you. -Heath
1512. Re: First attempt at Minxing
From: kappa962 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Oct 2002 03:22:17 -0000

> Tonight I tackled the MegaMinx. DAMN! It took well over an
> hour to get as far as an oriented last cap! But even this
> I'm very proud of! I found most simple cube moves worked until
> the last cap and now I'm just fiddling :/ I found that a Sune
> can be adapted, for example R'U2RU2R'UR or R'U2'RUR'UR but I
> don't yet know what can be done with them, hehe, I think more
> observations are in order!. I don't expect I'll be able to
> solve the last cap, at least not on my first attempt, I don't
> even know how to spot a parity problem (six colour). I'll
> keep trying but I think I'll have to resort to surfing for
> permutation algs!

No need to surf, just keep careful notes of what each algorithm you
find does to the pieces. If you spend an hour or two with a piece of
paper, a pencil, and a magaminx, you should be able to find enough
algs to solve it. Just think of as many ways as you can of taking
apart what has already been solved, and then putting it back in a
different way or order, then document what effect your new-found
algorithms have on the pieces in the last cap.
Oh, yeah, if you can orient all but one of the edges, you have a
parity problem.
-Mark

1514. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: First attempt at Minxing
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 09 Oct 2002 10:13:10 +0100

> No need to surf, just keep careful notes of what each algorithm you
> find does to the pieces. If you spend an hour or two with a piece of
> paper, a pencil, and a magaminx, you should be able to find enough
> algs to solve it. Just think of as many ways as you can of taking
> apart what has already been solved, and then putting it back in a
> different way or order, then document what effect your new-found
> algorithms have on the pieces in the last cap.
> Oh, yeah, if you can orient all but one of the edges, you have a
> parity problem.
> -Mark
>
Ahh, thanks for the parity tip, I thought it would be something like that.
It's lucky that my first go doesn't have a parity problem then :] If I do
get a parity problem, I imagine it must be bitchin'! So much to change! As
for trying different algs and noting the differences, I have 8 Sune
variations to check out and I have some ideas for a few other algs too.

Heath, how are you getting on with hunting all the pieces and fixing parity?
Or do you have the 12 colour?

Cheers guys



1515. The 2x2x2 Cube
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Oct 2002 14:22:28 -0000

Have you guys found that non-cubers tend to assume that the 2x2x2 is
easier than it looks?

The other day a friend commented that he thought the 2x2x2 would not
be too difficult. (I'm sure that any regular 3x3x3 cuber would find
the 2x2x2 fairly easy to solve, but not so for non-cubers.) So of
course I challenged him on that point! I showed him my solved 2x2x2,
messed it up in front of him and then left it with him and told him
to let me know when he'd solved it. That was 2 days ago.

It was quite fun to watch his initial expressions as he realised
that, even for the 2x2x2, you have to have some idea what you're
doing in order to solve it...

Jasmine.



1516. Re: [Speed cubing group] The 2x2x2 Cube
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 09 Oct 2002 17:31:03 +0100

> Have you guys found that non-cubers tend to assume that the 2x2x2 is
> easier than it looks?
>
> The other day a friend commented that he thought the 2x2x2 would not
> be too difficult. (I'm sure that any regular 3x3x3 cuber would find
> the 2x2x2 fairly easy to solve, but not so for non-cubers.) So of
> course I challenged him on that point! I showed him my solved 2x2x2,

> to let me know when he'd solved it. That was 2 days ago.

> that, even for the 2x2x2, you have to have some idea what you're
> doing in order to solve it...
>
> Jasmine.
>

YES!

I've had people look in awe at my growing puzzle collection. They always
recognise the 3x3x3 and say, "I remember them" (and the usual crap comments
follow). Of course, I'll show them how I can do it and they say "WOW, I
could never do that". Then... "ooh! I can do that easy one though!, haha"
as they have a look at a 2x2x2 for the first time in their lives. I just
grin and let them believe what they like :]

there would be too many pieces you would have to change for a parity
problem. just switch too of the same edge pieces :)...

1518. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: First attempt at Minxing

> first time I got to it, and i got it oriented. And I dont think

> problem. just switch too of the same edge pieces :)...

Yeah, but the two same pieces are on opposite sides of the puzzle. Can
someone tell me the average amount of moves and time required to fix a
parity on the Megaminx?



1519. Re: First attempt at Minxing
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Oct 2002 23:03:45 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., kappa962 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I don't even know how to spot a parity problem (six > > colour). > Oh, yeah, if you can orient all but one of the edges, you have a > parity problem. Unless I'm mistaken, the parity problem affects LL edge permutation, not orientation. To spot this, you should find that you can properly position 3 edges, leaving 2 that need to be swapped.
1520. [Speed cubing group] Re: First attempt at Minxing
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Oct 2002 23:10:42 -0000

> > when i have time i'll try to figure out some algs for that LL.
I would make one suggestion here; Don't try to orient all then
permute all. Moving edges without messing with the corner
orientations takes longer sequences than it's worth, from what I've
seen. I would recommend this: Orient edges, permute edges, fix
parity if necessary, orient corners, permute corners.



1521. [Speed cubing group] Re: First attempt at Minxing
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Oct 2002 23:15:48 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > > I dont think there would be too many pieces you would > > have to change for a parity problem. just switch > > too of the same edge pieces :)... > Yeah, but the two same pieces are on opposite sides of > the puzzle. Can someone tell me the average amount of > moves and time required to fix a parity on the Megaminx? I don't actually have a 6 color minx, but I confirmed this alg with kkrash (who does have a 6 color) when I came up with it. It's a little difficult to explain the effect, so it's probably easier to just do it, and see what it does. Make sure that U, F, L, and R are completely solved, and apply the sequence. I'll use the following notation: + = 1 click clockwise ++ = 2 clicks clockwise - = 1 click counterclockwise -- = 2 clicks counterclockwise U, F, L, and R are as expected (holding a face at U, and another at F, L and R are on opposition sides of F, both being adjacent to both F and U): L++ U- R+ F- R- F- R- F- R- F- R+ F+ R+ F+ R+ F+ U+ L-- You should see that only one edge on L, and two edges and two corners on R are affected. To fix the parity problem with this, place your LL on R with the two edges that need to swap in the two positions affected (not adjacent to U). So, to answer your original question, it takes 18 faces turns (20 clicks) to fix the parity problem with this method.
1522. [Speed cubing group] Re: First attempt at Minxing
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 09 Oct 2002 23:21:58 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Grant Tregay" <Grant@T...> wrote: > > > when i have time i'll try to figure out some algs for that LL. > I would make one suggestion here; Don't try to orient all then > permute all. Moving edges without messing with the corner > orientations takes longer sequences than it's worth, from what I've > seen. I would recommend this: Orient edges, permute edges, fix > parity if necessary, orient corners, permute corners. Thats what i was thinkin about doin :) I took my minx to school today and mixed it up this morning. Most the people thought i was crazy to have something that looked that complex. haha. One of my friends who thinks he knows everything told me the easiest way to solve the minx would be to solve the F2L, then solve the last 2 layers....leaving an unsolved zig zag in the middle layer. He thought that once you solved the f2l and L2L that you could easily do the middle layer :| ....HA. oh well, after messing with his idea for awhile I abandoned it....anybody else know people like that? lol :D -Heath

accord, but I see you've posted an alg so I'll just go straight for
that.

1524. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: First attempt at Minxing
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 01:22:56 +0100

> I don't actually have a 6 color minx, but I confirmed this alg with
> kkrash (who does have a 6 color) when I came up with it. It's a
> little difficult to explain the effect, so it's probably easier to
> just do it, and see what it does. Make sure that U, F, L, and R are
> completely solved, and apply the sequence. I'll use the following
> notation:
> + = 1 click clockwise
> ++ = 2 clicks clockwise
> - = 1 click counterclockwise
> -- = 2 clicks counterclockwise
> U, F, L, and R are as expected (holding a face at U, and another at
> F, L and R are on opposition sides of F, both being adjacent to both
> F and U):
> L++ U- R+ F- R- F- R- F- R- F- R+ F+ R+ F+ R+ F+ U+ L--
>
> You should see that only one edge on L, and two edges and two corners
> on R are affected. To fix the parity problem with this, place your
> LL on R with the two edges that need to swap in the two positions
> affected (not adjacent to U).
> So, to answer your original question, it takes 18 faces turns (20
> clicks) to fix the parity problem with this method.
>

Man did I mess this up or what! I think I did your alg OK but whatever
I did afterwards was irreversibly stupid! Back to the start again,
oops!

Hey, I just want to share this, it made me giggle anyway.

Take the PLL alg RB'R F2 R'BR F2 R2

Try to apply that to the Minx, I tried two ways (not sure about the
notation, B might be wrong):

R+B-R+ F++ R-B+R+ F-- R-- and R+B-R+ F-- R-B+R+ F++ R--

At first I thought I'd found two PLL algs, since the orientation seemed
to be preserved. Well, I wasn't wrong about the orientation, but it
took me way too long to notice the permuting properties of these algs!



1525. [Speed cubing group] Re: First attempt at Minxing
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 14:04:25 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@y...> wrote: > One of my friends who thinks he knows everything told me > the easiest way to solve the minx would be to solve the > F2L, then solve the last 2 layers....leaving an unsolved > zig zag in the middle layer. He thought that once you > solved the f2l and L2L that you could easily do the middle > layer :| ....HA. oh well, after messing with his idea for > awhile I abandoned it.... I've messed with several different ways of solving the megaminx, in an effort to find the easiest and quickest method. I've done it that way, but once you have the F2L done, the L2L becomes a little more complicated. Also, the zig-zag is possible, not even necessarily all that difficult (just do edges first, then corners), but it takes a lot of moves and just doesn't seem worth it to me. Another method I played with is doing all edges first (all 30 of them) before placing a single corner. This would make fixing parity much simpler on a six color minx, because you could swap two opposite edges in 7 moves (9 clicks), without worrying about messing up the corners. However, this has the same down side as zig zag last; each corner placement takes many more moves than necessary. I've found that the best approach (for me anyways) is a modified F2L and four look LL approach.
1526. [Speed cubing group] Re: First attempt at Minxing
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 15:06:41 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > Hey, I just want to share this, it made me giggle anyway. > > Take the PLL alg RB'R F2 R'BR F2 R2 > > Try to apply that to the Minx, I tried two ways (not sure > about the notation, B might be wrong): Notation always gets a little confusing, but you could easily rotate this to use L F and R for clarity. > R+B-R+ F++ R-B+R+ F-- R-- and R+B-R+ F-- R-B+R+ F++ R-- > > At first I thought I'd found two PLL algs, since the > orientation seemed to be preserved. Well, I wasn't wrong > about the orientation, but it took me way too long to > notice the permuting properties of these algs! At first I thought I must have done this wrong - I did it on my solved megaminx, and after I was done, it was stilled solved. Then I realized what you meant; These algs don't do a thing! I used to do corner permutations differently, but yesterday I came up with the alg that I think you were looking for. Try this instead (do it on a solved U face to see it's effect): L+ U+ L- F+ R+ F- L+ F+ R- F- U- L- Also, you can replace the U+ and U- with U++ and U--, respectively, to rotate 3 non-adjacent corners. The inverses or reflections of these can be used to rotate in the opposition direction, for example: R- U- R+ F- L- F+ R- F- L+ F+ U+ R+ With these 4 algs (the two stated, and the ones with U+ and U- replaced with U++ and U--), I'm pretty sure you can always permute the corners in two steps.
1527. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: First attempt at Minxing
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 16:48:05 +0100

>> At first I thought I'd found two PLL algs, since the
>> orientation seemed to be preserved. Well, I wasn't wrong
>> about the orientation, but it took me way too long to
>> notice the permuting properties of these algs!
> At first I thought I must have done this wrong - I did it on my
> solved megaminx, and after I was done, it was stilled solved. Then I
> realized what you meant; These algs don't do a thing!
On reflection, it's easy to see why it doesn't do anything! You can remove
the F moves, since they play no part in the alg anyway. Then the rest of
the moves can be contracted to R+B-R+ R-B+R- Which of course can be
contracted to no moves at all!

1529. [Speed cubing group] Re: First attempt at Minxing
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Oct 2002 23:02:21 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > Hey, I just want to share this, it made me giggle anyway. > > Take the PLL alg RB'R F2 R'BR F2 R2 > > Try to apply that to the Minx, I tried two ways (not sure about the > notation, B might be wrong): > > R+B-R+ F++ R-B+R+ F-- R-- and R+B-R+ F-- R-B+R+ F++ R-- I didn't realize it at first, but you can use the first alg you mentioned with a small change.. I tried to line these up so you could easily see the differences. Change it from this -> R+ B- R+ F++ R- B+ R+ F-- R-- to this -> R+ B- R++ F++ R-- B+ R++ F-- R++ Basically add an R+ before each F movement and an R- after each F movement.
1530. [Speed cubing group] Re: First attempt at Minxing

1531. [Speed cubing group] Re: First attempt at Minxing
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Oct 2002 14:43:49 -0000

Sorry, I had explained most of it back in post 1707, and didn't bother with re-explaining... > I'll use the following notation: > + = 1 click clockwise > ++ = 2 clicks clockwise > - = 1 click counterclockwise > -- = 2 clicks counterclockwise > U, F, L, and R are as expected The sequence I adapted from Robert, however, used B and not U. With U, F, L, and R in the positions you would expect, the 'B' referred to is the one behind R. From typical notation, R becomes R+ and R' becomes R-. Does that make this clearer? R+ B- R++ F++ R-- B+ R++ F-- R++ --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I dont understand that notation what so ever. Anybody think they can > explain it to me? > > > -Heath

1533. Anyone here go to UCI?

1534. Fast Times For Crowds.
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Oct 2002 18:53:11 -0000

About two weeks ago, I was asked by a friend of mine to be a street
performer at a fancy dinner for a church. He said I could have free
food, so I said sure. My gig was to go up to a table of 10 people
say "how is your dinner," and then say "could some one
scramble this
for me." Then I would fix it. It was a lot of fun. At first my
times were bad for me, around 30-35s with one horrible 50s time.
Then at that table I had the horrible time I had them mix it again,
and that time I solved it in 20s. From then on I was on fire, and
was averaging from 24-29s. I even had a couple more low times around
the 21, and 22s. Any way it was a lot of fun, and good crowd
experience. Another thing happened yesterday, at work. We were in a
meeting, and at the beginning another friend told my boss that I
could solve the cube in fewer than 30s. He then had me take it out
and solve it for everyone there. I thought that I was going to have
a bad time because I was nervous, but I calmed myself down and did it
in 21s. I was really happy with that and it impressed my boss.
Anyway just thought I would share.

-Kenneth




1535. [Speed cubing group] Re: First attempt at Minxing
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Oct 2002 19:12:41 -0000

I just looked through several solutions (the first few items returned from a search for a "Megaminx Solution" on google), and as far as I can tell from that, and what I've seen in the past, there is no standard. There are various notations used (See Jaap's megaminx page at http://www.org2.com/jaap/puzzles/megaminx.htm or Meffert's solution page at http://www.mefferts.com/puzzles/megasol1.html for a couple examples), but no standard. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > >> I'll use the following notation: > >> + = 1 click clockwise > >> ++ = 2 clicks clockwise > >> - = 1 click counterclockwise > >> -- = 2 clicks counterclockwise > >> U, F, L, and R are as expected > > The sequence I adapted from Robert, however, used B and not U. With > > U, F, L, and R in the positions you would expect, the 'B' referred to > > is the one behind R. From typical notation, R becomes R+ and R' > > becomes R-. Does that make this clearer? > > > > R+ B- R++ F++ R-- B+ R++ F-- R++ > > Is there a typical notation used for algs that use the U > face and all 5 adjacent faces? Or even including the > other half?

1538. Megaminx
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Oct 2002 02:29:19 -0000

Wow! Thanks to Tyler I finally have my own minx. I solved three
times after i got all of the tiles glued on. Mine is a 12 color...
very pretty. I couldn't believe how easy it is to solve. All you
really need to know is how to solve a 3x3 cube! With a little
adaptations its basically the same. You corner first methoders
though would have some problems applying it to a megaminx.
Jake



1539. Re: Megaminx
From: "moocowbob2000" <sum1else@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Oct 2002 03:17:42 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Wow! Thanks to Tyler I finally have my own minx. I solved three > times after i got all of the tiles glued on. Mine is a 12 color... > very pretty. I couldn't believe how easy it is to solve. All you > really need to know is how to solve a 3x3 cube! With a little > adaptations its basically the same. 1540. Re: Megaminx
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Oct 2002 15:44:39 -0000



Yes! I had no trouble at all!!
It is a very nice puzzle, I'm glad to have it in my collection.
Heres what I do.

One star
F2L
lower middle corners and adjacent edges
M2L
(Last layer)
Flip up edges (normal 3x3 algs)
move edges(adapted easily from a 3x3 alg)
flip up corners
move corners

The last layer corners gave me the most problems because i
experimented with 3x3 moves and the of course switched edges around.
So I use one 3x3 alg to orientate 2 corners at a time. Once all are
up I just use a simple corner move that moves three corners.
It's not bad at all.
I may play a little more trying to shorten things up, or i may search
the net and see what solutions are out there.
Jake



1541. Un-smooth cube
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 13 Oct 2002 23:03:41 -0000

I was in a puzzle shop yesterday and saw a cube whose packaging
claimed "smoothest cube ever!" Needless to say, I didn't believe
this. I asked the shop assistant if there was an opened one so I
could have a go and see if indeed it was smooth. They opened one for
me. I told them I was happy to buy it, but only if it was smooth. It
wasn't. The shop assistant said that maybe it would be smooth after
playing with it for a while. This made me think of DanG's rule of not
using cubes that aren't smooth straight out of the box. Hmmm. I have
plenty of cubes that aren't too smooth so I wasn't going to buy
another potentially crap cube. Anyway, I put the cube back to it's
original state (ie. solved) and told them that it wasn't a smooth
cube, yet alone "the smoothest cube ever!"

Jasmine.



1542. Re: [Speed cubing group] Un-smooth cube
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 01:02:35 +0100

> I was in a puzzle shop yesterday and saw a cube whose packaging
> claimed "smoothest cube ever!" Needless to say, I didn't believe
> this. I asked the shop assistant if there was an opened one so I
> could have a go and see if indeed it was smooth. They opened one for
> me. I told them I was happy to buy it, but only if it was smooth. It
> wasn't. The shop assistant said that maybe it would be smooth after
> playing with it for a while. This made me think of DanG's rule of not
> using cubes that aren't smooth straight out of the box. Hmmm. I have
> plenty of cubes that aren't too smooth so I wasn't going to buy
> another potentially crap cube. Anyway, I put the cube back to it's
> original state (ie. solved) and told them that it wasn't a smooth
> cube, yet alone "the smoothest cube ever!"
>
> Jasmine.
>

They sell cubes that make that claim in a shop here in England called
Globe, The Discovery Store. I bought one. I have a sneaky suspicion
they are made by Mefferts. They are smooth in a way, but useless for
speed cubing because they don't have springs. They become amazingly
slippy after a dose of silicone, far too slippy if you ask me! But
then, it's all a matter of taste :]

By the way, Mefferts make that very claim themselves.

1544. No Subject
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Oct 2002 22:59:32 -0000

I've been trying to get some people at work into cubing. As I
mentioned in an earlier post, I lent my 2x2x2 to someone. He's now
pretty confidently doing half the cube (ie. one layer). I know this
is pretty basic to us, but it's exciting to someone who's never
played with cubes before. Also, he's doing it without any algorithms
from me or the net. I think he wants to work it out himself.
Hopefully he'll have 2x2x2 solved soon and will be keen to start the
3x3x3! :)

On the topic of the 3x3x3, there's someone at work who said he 'used
to be able to do it'. I'm usually skeptical when anyone says this. I
mentioned 'layer methods' and 'corners first methods' and he said he
used a corners first method and then proceeded to describe how he
used to go about it (although he couldn't remember any specific
algorithms). I'm not really familiar with any corners first methods,
but the way he described it sounded like either (i) he did actually
used to know it; or (ii) he'd read a website about it. I reckon (i)
is true. So anyway, I lent him one of my 3x3x3s yesterday. I'm keen
to see how he's going with it today!

Jasmine.



1545. Cubing buddies
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Oct 2002 00:49:11 +0100

Jasmine, sounds like you work in a cool place! You know, here in
England I'm finding it hard to get people interested in cubing. My
boss and I both learnt at the same time, the difference being that he
was pleased enough to achieve less than five minutes. I wasn't.

I show my friends and some are impressed, others think I'm an anorak
(know what I mean?). Well, I am an anorak I suppose ;] Anyway, in my
duties to spread the interest, all I meet are people that assume they
can never do it but never try. Ironically, the only person who has
asked me to teach her is actually struggling. I'm game though :] I
bought her a hello kitty 3xcube, so I'll have to teach centre algs too
:\

I met a couple who were visiting from America last week. They said
they both used to cube when they were dating 20 years ago but they
don't remember how, so I gave them one of my cubes. I'll email them
soon to see if they've got anywhere! Never know, the cube might
rekindle some dating memories ;-)



1546. Re: Cubing buddies
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

he
> was pleased enough to achieve less than five minutes. I wasn't.

I lent my 2x2x2 (and my Rubik's clock) to a software engineer and the
3x3x3 to a technical tester. I guess it's not unlikely that people in
this field of work would be interested in puzzles. :)

> I show my friends and some are impressed, others think I'm an
anorak
> (know what I mean?). Well, I am an anorak I suppose ;] Anyway, in
my
> duties to spread the interest, all I meet are people that assume
they
> can never do it but never try. Ironically, the only person who has
> asked me to teach her is actually struggling. I'm game though :]
I
> bought her a hello kitty 3xcube, so I'll have to teach centre algs

an anorak was a jacket with a hood?

Jasmine.



1547. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubing buddies
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 15 Oct 2002 10:07:54 +0100

> Anorak? I don't think I know what it means in this context. I thought
> an anorak was a jacket with a hood?
>
> Jasmine.
>

An anorak is someone with an obsessive hobby for something that most people
really wouldn't be interested in. It comes from the people who sit in deck
chairs next to rail tracks in their anoraks, rain or shine, train spotting.

I'm a cube anorak :]

Other forms of anorak are: html anorak, stamp anorak and twitchers (extreme
bird watching). I think everyone has an anorak hobby or two ;]

1551. Rubik's Cube Club
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 16 Oct 2002 07:40:47 -0000

About two weeks ago I was thinking how cool it would be if I started
a Rubik's cube club at my school University of California, Irvine. I
even got the info on how to start it. Then last week my brother and
I were walking on campus, And I was talking about the cube and how
cool it would be to have a Rubik's club, and how we would put up
posters, and right then my brother said "like that one" Anyway
someone had beat me to it. So today was the Third meeting, and my
first. So right now we are teaching about 6 people how to do the
cube. It's pretty cool. Also the weekend we are having a "Lube your
Cube day." Anyone else have a Rubik's club at there college, or high
school?

-Kenneth
