1558. Happy new 4x4x4 cuber
From: gogozergus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 10:22:13 -0000

I bought a 4x4x4 at Meffert's yesterday, found a solution by myself
(corners first), and today I can do it in 3min23 :-))

It often takes me more than 200 moves (slice turn==2 moves, half
turn==1 move). Could you tell me if this is good or bad?

The cube quality seems ok, much stronger than the 5x5x5 I received and
destroyed in 2 hours last week.

The problem comes from the stickers. Orange and brown look almost
identical.



1559. Re: [Speed cubing group] Happy new 4x4x4 cuber
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 11:30:36 +0100

> I bought a 4x4x4 at Meffert's yesterday, found a solution by myself
> (corners first), and today I can do it in 3min23 :-))
>
> It often takes me more than 200 moves (slice turn==2 moves, half
> turn==1 move). Could you tell me if this is good or bad?
>
> The cube quality seems ok, much stronger than the 5x5x5 I received and
> destroyed in 2 hours last week.
>
> The problem comes from the stickers. Orange and brown look almost
> identical.
>

I'd say if you've not been doing it long and you found the solution yourself
then that's outstanding!

It takes me a little longer than the time you mention. I use the solution
from Chris Hardwick. I can go faster but I don't practice enough.

What make is your destroyed 5xCube? Can anyone tell me if the new
rubiks.com 5xCube is up to much? Better than Mefferts? I don't like my
Mefferts one, it's too catchy and flimsy.

I think these guys that are in charge of stickers all need a good slap. Can
it be that hard to make all the stickers easily distinguishable?




1560. RE: [Speed cubing group] Happy new 4x4x4 cuber
From: Tyler Robbins <sum1else@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 06:38:20 -0400

I agree, meffert's 4x4 stickers really suck.. Get a set of stickers from Rubiks.com, those are pretty nice Meffert's 4x4 is better though mechanically.. So you decide what's more important to you, mechanics or stickers. As far as 5x5 goes. The last production of Meffert 5x5's weren't that great, they caught a lot. The production from before that was good, and I bought a 1995 one and it was amazing (new in package) Rubik's 5x5 isn't for sale yet, they bumped it back a month. As soon as that thing is sold ill have a review for you guys. I prefer the mini 5x5 for playing, but its no good for speeding. For speeding, a 1995 5x5 is the best. -Tyler Robbins <http://www.thepuzzlestore.com/> www.thepuzzlestore.com Specializing in Custom Sequential movement puzzles Ebay UserID: Sum1else -----Original Message----- From: Robert Roue [mailto:r.roue@...] Sent: Thursday, October 17, 2002 6:31 AM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Happy new 4x4x4 cuber > I bought a 4x4x4 at Meffert's yesterday, found a solution by myself > (corners first), and today I can do it in 3min23 :-)) > > It often takes me more than 200 moves (slice turn==2 moves, half > turn==1 move). 1561. Re: Rubik's Cube Club
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 16:51:30 -0000

I started one in High School and it is still going now that I'm in college. It feals good that something you started is still sticking. I have yet to start one in college. The interest for most college students is beer and sex, so it would be very hard to convince people to cube. I'll still work on it though. What really helps to make a club is first teach one or two people in the school to show that it is actually learnable. Find some apprentaces before diving right into a club, it will be easier to manage with a sidekick instead of being a loner. Jake -- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "James Potter" <theboywholived81@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., redkbrandon <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > About two weeks ago I was thinking how cool it would be if I > started > > a Rubik's cube club at my school University of California, > Irvine. 1562. Re: Rubik's Cube Club
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 17:35:23 -0000

I know what you mean. I didn't start the club, but the person who did had already taught one person, and then only 6 people came, 3 of which could already solve the cube (Including me). So in total we had 8 people there and 5 could solve it and 3 could not. It is going to be fun. A good thing is that this club is really motivating me to practice more and more. And as everyone here knows more practice means faster times. -Kenneth --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I started one in High School and it is still going now that I'm in > college. 1563. Re: Happy new 4x4x4 cuber
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 17:41:52 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., gogozergus <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I bought a 4x4x4 at Meffert's yesterday, found a solution by myself > (corners first), and today I can do it in 3min23 :-)) > > It often takes me more than 200 moves (slice turn==2 moves, half > turn==1 move). Could you tell me if this is good or bad? > Well, oinkleburger counts slice (quarter) moves as 1 move and half turns as two moves, so I'm on a slightly different count from you but I have no other verifiable data of my own to go on. (I guess the recent ones I could step through but I'm not doing that!) Anyway, of 486 attempts at the 4x4x4 this year (on oinkleburger, real cube attempts aside as I've never counted my moves there - and also the blindfold solutions would up the number a lot) I have had 13 that took me 200 moves or more. The minimum number of moves was 120. The average was 164.1605 moves and this was also the median and the mode (21 of the cubes). There was only one mode. The (sample) standard deviation was around 16.63 so that 200 moves plus is over 2.15 standard deviations away from the mean (which may not mean much depending on the distribution). Of course, I don't bother to finish every cube I start on oinkleburger so that could account for some distortion. So I'm over 200 (this year) in about 2.67% of cases. A similar exercise on the solutions of other cubers on oinkleburger (only using the oinkleburger data) shows that Ron is over 200 on about 29.47% of 285 cases and Grant Tregay is above 200 moves on about 41.01% of 317 cases. Of course, these are generally attempts for speed. I imagine that if one were to go slower the number of moves would fall a little. In particular, I know that sometimes my number of moves is going to be high because I can't orient the LL in one step all the time (in fact probably quite a lot of the time) and also I'm not at all efficient in doing the cross and one of the F2L algorithms I never figured out on oinkleburger as the geometry was too scary so I use another one which is less efficient. So I would say that you can definitely go sub 200 moves and on a regular basis. Even though I probably lose on average a lot of moves on the 3x3x3 to a lot of people (I'd say that I probably average a lot closer to 70 as opposed to low 50s or better) I make up a bit on other areas. I think that if you can solve the centres and edges efficiently you will regularly dip the 200 move barrier. > The cube quality seems ok, much stronger than the 5x5x5 I received and > destroyed in 2 hours last week. > > The problem comes from the stickers. Orange and brown look almost > identical.
1564. Re: Rubik's Cube Club
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 17:47:24 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., redkbrandon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I know what you mean. I didn't start the club, but the person who > did had already taught one person, and then only 6 people came, 3 of > which could already solve the cube (Including me). So in total we had > 8 people there and 5 could solve it and 3 could not. It is going to > be fun. A good thing is that this club is really motivating me to > practice more and more. And as everyone here knows more practice > means faster times. > Not sure about that! My times (on real cubes at least) don't seem to get any better. It would help if I could take on board all the algorithms and had a cube which (by "the Ton criterion") was classified as good for speed-cubing, but I don't think I can move my hands or my mind much faster and so my best average of 10 is likely ever to lie in the high 30s and not improve even if I do practice a lot. Maybe,as a result, someday I can get my average blindfold time (solving part only of course, in the context I am about to state) down to the same as my average sight time. : ) > -Kenneth > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I started one in High School and it is still going now that I'm in > > college. It feals good that something you started is still > > sticking. I have yet to start one in college. The interest for > most > > college students is beer and sex, so it would be very hard to > > convince people to cube. I'll still work on it though. > > What really helps to make a club is first teach one or two people > in > > the school to show that it is actually learnable. Find some > > apprentaces before diving right into a club, it will be easier to > > manage with a sidekick instead of being a loner. > > Jake > >

Orange and brown look almost > > identical. It seems like my 4x4x4 is impossible to solve, although I'm almost positive it's not. What I do is I get all the centers together, then all the edges together, then solve it like a big 3x3x3, but then at the end, one edge is always incorrectly oriented. Can anyone help me?

Could you tell me if this is good or bad? > > > > > > > Well, oinkleburger counts slice (quarter) moves as 1 move and half > > turns as two moves, so I'm on a slightly different count from you > > but I have no other verifiable data of my own to go on. (I guess > the > > recent ones I could step through but I'm not doing that!) > > > > Anyway, of 486 attempts at the 4x4x4 this year (on oinkleburger, > > real cube attempts aside as I've never counted my moves there - > and > > also the blindfold solutions would up the number a lot) I have had > > 13 that took me 200 moves or more. > > > > The minimum number of moves was 120. The average was 164.1605 > moves > > and this was also the median and the mode (21 of the cubes). There > > was only one mode. The (sample) standard deviation was around > 16.63 > > so that 200 moves plus is over 2.15 standard deviations away from > > the mean (which may not mean much depending on the distribution). > > Of course, I don't bother to finish every cube I start on > > oinkleburger so that could account for some distortion. > > > > So I'm over 200 (this year) in about 2.67% of cases. A similar > > exercise on the solutions of other cubers on oinkleburger (only > > using the oinkleburger data) shows that Ron is over 200 on about > > 29.47% of 285 cases and Grant Tregay is above 200 moves on about > > 41.01% of 317 cases. > > > > Of course, these are generally attempts for speed. I imagine that > if > > one were to go slower the number of moves would fall a little. > > In particular, I know that sometimes my number of moves is going > to > > be high because I can't orient the LL in one step all the time (in > > fact probably quite a lot of the time) and also I'm not at all > > efficient in doing the cross and one of the F2L algorithms I never > > figured out on oinkleburger as the geometry was too scary so I use > > another one which is less efficient. > > > > So I would say that you can definitely go sub 200 moves and on a > > regular basis. Even though I probably lose on average a lot of > moves > > on the 3x3x3 to a lot of people (I'd say that I probably average a > > lot closer to 70 as opposed to low 50s or better) I make up a bit > on > > other areas. I think that if you can solve the centres and edges > > efficiently you will regularly dip the 200 move barrier. > > > > > The cube quality seems ok, much stronger than the 5x5x5 I > received > > and > > > destroyed in 2 hours last week. > > > > > > The problem comes from the stickers. Orange and brown look almost > > > identical. > > It seems like my 4x4x4 is impossible to solve, although I'm almost > positive it's not. What I do is I get all the centers together, then > all the edges together, then solve it like a big 3x3x3, but then at > the end, one edge is always incorrectly oriented. Can anyone help me? I could be wrong but I guess most people here use Chris Hardwick's moves for correcting this and for the switching of two edges (another possible thing that can happen). They are particularly useful moves as they don't affect anything else (assuming the centres are solved). In regular solving you should do it at the start of the LL. In blindfold solving you should do it at the end. Chris's other move (switching 2 edges) should be used liberally in blindfold cubing. For instance, if the corner permutation is odd (so that you are left with two corners to switch) you can switch the corners in a regular 3x3x3 way (switching two edges as well) and then switch the edges back by themselves) so that the edges remain unchanged from their initial state.
1567. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Happy new 4x4x4 cuber
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 21:13:38 +0100

> It seems like my 4x4x4 is impossible to solve, although I'm almost
> positive it's not. What I do is I get all the centers together, then
> all the edges together, then solve it like a big 3x3x3, but then at
> the end, one edge is always incorrectly oriented. Can anyone help me?

I hope you mean edge pair. If it's only one edge, I'd panic if I were
you :P

r2 B2 U2 l U2 r' U2 r U2 F2 r F2 l' B2 r2



1568. Re: Happy new 4x4x4 cuber
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2002 20:14:30 -0000

Just so you don't have to go find them, the sequences to which he
referred are these (Uppercase letters are face moves, lowercase are
slice moves):
To flip (reorient) the edge pair at UF, use one of the following:
r2 B2 U2 l U2 r' U2 r U2 F2 r F2 l' B2 r2
(R2r2) B2 U2 (Ll) U2 (R'r') U2 (Rr) U2 F2 (Rr) F2 (L'l') B2 (R2r2)

The second is easier to do (with a physical cube, but not for applet
cubes), but it will also swap UFL <-> UFR and UL <-> UR and reorient
UFL and UFR, so it is definately best to do it at the beginning of
the LL. The other sequence he referred to swaps UF and UB:
r2 U2 r2 U2 u2 r2 u2

> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., James Potter wrote:
> > It seems like my 4x4x4 is impossible to solve, although
> > I'm almost positive it's not. What I do is I get all the
> > centers together, then all the edges together, then
> > solve it like a big 3x3x3, but then at the end, one edge
> > is always incorrectly oriented. Can anyone help me?

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., GameOfDeath2 wrote:
> I could be wrong but I guess most people here use Chris
> Hardwick's moves for correcting this and for the switching
> of two edges (another possible thing that can happen). They
> are particularly useful moves as they don't affect anything
> else (assuming the centres are solved).
>
> In regular solving you should do it at the start of the LL. In
> blindfold solving you should do it at the end.

Yeah - if you have only one edge piece flipped, then someone peeled
off your stickers and switched them; you can't even put only one edge
piece in flipped if you take the puzzle apart.

1572. [Speed cubing group] Re: Happy new 4x4x4 cuber

1573. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Happy new 4x4x4 cuber
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 09:50:43 +0100

> Where you say r, do you mean the single right slice or both right
> slices?
>

Only single.

If both were intended to turn, the notation would say:

Rr

Or:

(Rr)

Or:

rR


You probably get the gist by now :]



1574. Re: Happy new 4x4x4 cuber
From: gogozergus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Thanks for your answer GameOfDeath.

I guess I'm spending too much time on the middle layers. Solutions
like the one on Hardwick's site seem shorter, but the problem is I
don't *understand* the final algorithms fixing edges or corners, and I
don't like it ;-) I can find algorithms with similar results, but I
need 50 moves.

But, parity could be *very easily* fixed before the end. That's why
I'm looking for a method following the steps:
- Do centers
- Fix corners parity
- Fix edges parity (***)
- Do Edges
- Do 3x3x3

An idea for step (***) ?



1575. Re: Happy new 4x4x4 cuber
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 12:54:24 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., gogozergus <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Thanks for your answer GameOfDeath. > > I guess I'm spending too much time on the middle layers. Solutions > like the one on Hardwick's site seem shorter, but the problem is I > don't *understand* the final algorithms fixing edges or corners, and I > don't like it ;-) I can find algorithms with similar results, but I > need 50 moves. > > But, parity could be *very easily* fixed before the end. That's why > I'm looking for a method following the steps: > - Do centers This is probably the most important step. Do one centre, then the opposite centre. Make the 4th centre adjacent the 3rd one (Chris' method is opposite but I think it is not as fast). Best to join the edges next. Then solve as a 3x3x3. Flip the edge (if needed) just before OLL, switch 2 edges (if needed) just before PLL. > - Fix corners parity Not sure what you mean here. If it's what I think it is, then you can just go U (or nothing at all). > - Fix edges parity (***) Very uncertain here. I don't see where you've joined the edges yet (unless it is in "Do edges"), but then the amount of work needed to see if you need to swap 2 edges must be huge. > - Do Edges > - Do 3x3x3 > > An idea for step (***) ?
1576. Re: Happy new 4x4x4 cuber
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 13:03:24 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., gogozergus <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Thanks for your answer GameOfDeath. > > I guess I'm spending too much time on the middle layers. Solutions > like the one on Hardwick's site seem shorter, but the problem is I > don't *understand* the final algorithms fixing edges or corners, and I > don't like it ;-) I can find algorithms with similar results, but I > need 50 moves. > > But, parity could be *very easily* fixed before the end. That's why > I'm looking for a method following the steps: > - Do centers > - Fix corners parity > - Fix edges parity (***) > - Do Edges > - Do 3x3x3 > > An idea for step (***) ? Another approach you could try which can guarantee your edges is centres last, but it takes a lot longer to do it this way (I used to do it like that myself). On another note, it occurred to me yesterday that if one could get an edge 4 cycle algorithm then one could ensure that in the final stages one had at most one corrective algorithm to do, rather than perhaps two. Such an algorithm would do something like this: the edge pair B A C D would become D C B A (of course, some centres would be altered, but with solved centres the effect would be unnoticeable). Thus the algorithm would do something like: |< > | \/| | /\| v v (can't quite get the arrows right at the top), which in effect would flip the edge and switch 2 joined edges in one step. This seems to be the best compromise in a centres first technique (with unmarked centres) because without extensive planning getting the centres in the right place to avoid problems seems impossible to guarantee.
1577. Re: Happy new 4x4x4 cuber

the other method down. I'm hoping to drop.
Jake



1578. Re: Happy new 4x4x4 cuber
From: gogozergus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 13:19:22 -0000

> > - Fix corners parity
>
> Not sure what you mean here. If it's what I think it is, then you
> can just go U (or nothing at all).
>

It's just a first step to solve the parity problem. Solve the corners,
then you are sure they won't disturb you in the next step. The only
wrong parity will be found in edges.

> > - Fix edges parity (***)
>
> Very uncertain here. I don't see where you've joined the edges yet
> (unless it is in "Do edges"), but then the amount of work needed to
> see if you need to swap 2 edges must be huge.
>

Yes, maybe huge, I don't know if there is an easy solution to this
step (Note: edges are not joined yet!). I was looking for some
mathematical equation telling me if the cube is solvable without
moving a single inner layer. Just like in blindfolded 3x3x3 cubing,
when you know corners won't be solvable if you don't permute 2 edges
first.


Gilles.

1584. Re: Stupid barriers
From: gogozergus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 14:50:46 -0000

(Although some of the algs are still a little shaky) You don't need algorithms for the first 2 layers and the cross (standard method or Petrus'). Just use the force, Luke. Then, 2 algorithms for corners permutation, 3 for corners orientation (1+optimizations), and 3 for egdes permutation. Averages 63 moves, <30 seconds.
1585. New file uploaded to speedsolvingrubikscube
From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

Date: 18 Oct 2002 15:43:37 -0000


Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the speedsolvingrubikscube
group.

File : /Rubik cube solving blindfolded.doc
Uploaded by : ralf_laue
Description : The Guinness Book rules for solving a cube blindfolded. (Record breakers should also follow the general rules, see www.guinnessworldrecords.com)

You can access this file at the URL

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/files/Rubik%20cube%20solving%20blindfolded.doc

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit

http://help.yahoo.com/help/us/groups/files

Regards,

ralf_laue







1586. [Speed cubing group] Re: Stupid barriers
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 15:45:20 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue wrote:
> How good are you at stringing the algs together with
> minimal pause?
Okay, I have to admit that this is one of my big downfalls. But I
can't really figure out how to look ahead when I'm busy working
through the current step - that's why I have to memorize algs. Once
the alg is memorized, and I don't have to think about it, then I'm
more likely to be able to look ahead. I only know 7 F2L algs
(leaving me to think through the other 34). I can think through the
others pretty quickly, but that doesn't let me look ahead. I've
tried to follow the advice given for practicing looking ahead, but I
still can't seem to improve it.



1587. Re: Stupid barriers
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 16:08:17 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., gogozergus wrote: > You don't need algorithms for the first 2 layers and the > cross (standard method or Petrus'). Just use the force, > Luke. Then, 2 algorithms for corners permutation, 3 for > corners orientation (1+optimizations), and 3 for egdes > permutation. Averages 63 moves, <30 seconds. For the cross, there aren't really any algs you could use - there are way too many possibilities. I can think pretty well through most of the 41 F2L situations, but for 7 of them, I really needed algorithms. For the LL, it looks like you skipped edge orientation (I'm guessing you use Lars' approach), so I orient in 2 "looks" (3 algs for edges, 7 for corners), and permute in 1 look (21 algs). Unfortunately, the time I spent working on LL algs so far hasn't really seemed to improve my time much - most of my time is lost on the F2L.
1588. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Stupid barriers
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 17:15:16 +0100

> Okay, I have to admit that this is one of my big downfalls. But I
> can't really figure out how to look ahead when I'm busy working
> through the current step - that's why I have to memorize algs. Once
> the alg is memorized, and I don't have to think about it, then I'm
> more likely to be able to look ahead. I only know 7 F2L algs
> (leaving me to think through the other 34). I can think through the
> others pretty quickly, but that doesn't let me look ahead. I've
> tried to follow the advice given for practicing looking ahead, but I
> still can't seem to improve it.
>

I think you're actually on a winner here. If you have to think your way
through the F2L algs but you can do them pretty quick, then in the long run
it'll be better for you. Once you get that time down by practicing, you'll
be in a better position to look ahead. If you get a chance to glance at the
pieces before you commence an alg, then you might also get the chance to
know where they'll end up (or one piece maybe?). Then you've got a head
start on the next alg.

Remember though, going really fast in the F2L can work against you! Take it
easy, watch the pieces move, predict, plan ahead. It'll work better that
way. Then, for the LL, go for it as quick as you can!

I know my times are nothing amazing, but the going slow on F2L still makes a
difference to me.



1589. Re: Happy new 4x4x4 cuber

If it's what I think it is, then you > > can just go U (or nothing at all). > > > > It's just a first step to solve the parity problem. Solve the corners, > then you are sure they won't disturb you in the next step. The only > wrong parity will be found in edges. > > > > - Fix edges parity (***) > > > > Very uncertain here. I don't see where you've joined the edges yet > > (unless it is in "Do edges"), but then the amount of work needed to > > see if you need to swap 2 edges must be huge. > > > > Yes, maybe huge, I don't know if there is an easy solution to this > step (Note: edges are not joined yet!). I was looking for some > mathematical equation telling me if the cube is solvable without > moving a single inner layer. Just like in blindfolded 3x3x3 cubing, > when you know corners won't be solvable if you don't permute 2 edges > first. Well, you can permute them afterwards at the end of doing the corner permutations (in the last step) if necessary, which is what my old system did but the new system is going to be much better. In 4x4x4 blindfolding there really isn't an issue here. > > > Gilles.
1590. Re: Happy new 4x4x4 cuber
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 18 Oct 2002 17:00:19 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Does anyone know any shortcuts of Chris's 4x4 solution. If you are > willing to share It would be grately appreciated. > I am still solving faster using a centers last method but once i get > the other method down. I'm hoping to drop. > Jake Centres last is not the way to go, if you want speed, mainly because it is difficult to switch many centres in one go without messing stuff up. Chris' solution is not bad for the most part. We differ a little on getting the centres - I think I save some moves here - and probably on the edge building. I do think it would be good to have a 3rd algorithm for the end that combines the effect of the other 2 (a 4 cycle of edges as I noted in an earlier post). In any event, for bigger cubes, the centres are the thing that eats up the time as the number of centres is quadratic in the cube size and the number of edges is only linear in the cube size. Corrections are also linear in the cube size and then the ordinary solution is of constant order. It follows that doing the centres efficiently must be the most important thing for large cubes. I imagine thre is some effect even on rather small cubes. Already on the 4x4x4 the number of centre pieces is equal to the number of edge pieces.

1593. Re: Happy new 4x4x4 cuber
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Oct 2002 01:08:42 -0000

Yes, I know that a centers last is going to doom me, but I just can't get good times with any centers first solutions. I'll keep playing though. The biggest cubes I've done is just a 5x5x5. I do agree that a centers last will ruin any hopes of getting good times with a 5x5, but then again, same as a 4x4. At least in a 5x5 you can place a corner and edge center in at the same time. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Does anyone know any shortcuts of Chris's 4x4 solution. If you > are > > willing to share It would be grately appreciated. > > I am still solving faster using a centers last method but once i > get > > the other method down. I'm hoping to drop. > > Jake > > Centres last is not the way to go, if you want speed, mainly because > it is difficult to switch many centres in one go without messing > stuff up. > > Chris' solution is not bad for the most part. We differ a little on > getting the centres - I think I save some moves here - and probably > on the edge building. I do think it would be good to have a 3rd > algorithm for the end that combines the effect of the other 2 (a 4 > cycle of edges as I noted in an earlier post). > > In any event, for bigger cubes, the centres are the thing that eats > up the time as the number of centres is quadratic in the cube size > and the number of edges is only linear in the cube size. Corrections > are also linear in the cube size and then the ordinary solution is > of constant order. It follows that doing the centres efficiently > must be the most important thing for large cubes. I imagine thre is > some effect even on rather small cubes. Already on the 4x4x4 the > number of centre pieces is equal to the number of edge pieces.
1594. God's Algorithm
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Oct 2002 03:30:35 -0000

on the mathmatics behind it all. How can you come up with an
estimated number of restoring the cube from any position? I asked my
math proffessor, but I think I royaly confused her when I was
explaing the difference between permutations and orientations. Is
there some sort of formula? Also how does one find the calculation
of how many positions the cube can be in? I would like to know more
about the mathmatics of the cube to.. well... I don't know why. Its
scary what an obsession can do to you.

Sorry about the ramble
Jake

1596. Calculation of the number of positions of the cube
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 19 Oct 2002 18:07:02 -0000


It's pretty straightforward. First of all you need to figure out
some invariants - things that don't change if you twist the cube.

The easiest invariant to find is that the corner and edge
permutations will always have the same signature as permutations.
That's because a quarter twist of a face gives rise to a 4-cycle of
edges and a 4-cycle of corners (both odd permutations).

Another couple of less obvious invariants are the total edge
orientation (modulo 2) and the total corner orientation (modulo 3).

These are in fact the only invariants (and you can see this
explicitly by showing that any cube satisfying these 3 conditions
can be solved).

It follows that the number of possible positions of the cube is
equal to

1/2*(12!*8!)*2^11*3^7=12!*8!*2^10*3^7.

If we allow for twisting of centres as well then it is easy to see
that for any position the total number of quarter turns the centres
are twisted (modulo 2) is equal to 0 if the edge and corner
permutations are even and 1 otherwise. Since in the solved cube
(without regard to centres) the corner and edge orientations are
even it follows that for a solved cube the total number of quarter
turns the centres are twisted are even. In particular, an even
number of them are twisted an odd number of quarter turns and the
rest an even number of quarter turns. It remains to see that a
centre can be twisted a half turn without affecting anything else
and that 2 non-opposite centres can be twisted a quarter turn
(direction unimportant due to previous part) without affecting
anythin else to get the total number of positions. These moves are
both possible.
It follows that the first 5 centres can be in any of 4 possible
twists and then the last one is confined to 2 possibilities. Thus in
the larger sense the total number of positions is equal to

12!*8!*2^10*3^7*4^5*2=12!*8!*2^21*3^7.

In terms of finding short solutions to the cube this is an unsolved
problem. There are lower bounds and upper bounds but the exact
answer is not known. Even if one was to know the maximum number of
moves needed to solve the cube that still wouldn't tell us for a
given position the best solution - it would only say that one needs
only to search up to this maximum depth.

The best solutions at the moment (as far as I know) are to use a
chain of normal subgroups.
As far as I'm aware the current best upper bound is around 42
quarter turns (maybe 29 half turns) but I haven't really read any
literature on it, in terms of anything outside of the results.

The 3x3x3 cube has a group structure. Higher order cubes do not if
we identify two positions if they look the same (in other words
treat all the red centre pieces as the same etc.). In such a case
they'd have more than one solved state which messes things up. With
marked centres they would form a group. So the problem should be
harder for larger cubes.

http://bfladder.redcloak.org/div/bbcube.zip

1598. Amazing, I did it. I broke a 30 second average!
From: rquethe <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 20 Oct 2002 23:44:56 -0000

I haven't done an average for a couple of weeks thinking, "Why
bother? I haven't improved any." During the chat this weekend, I was
mentioning how I've been stuck in the low thirty seconds for months
now. Then this afternoon I just practiced a lot in my room and then
came to my computer to do an average. The first average tried sucked
horribly. The reason being that the cube I was using was worn down
and the stickers contrasted poorly. So pieces were popping out and I
was stuck figuring out if it was blue or green I was looking at. I
said, "Screw this!" and I got a better cube and brought out a lamp so
I could see better. I then proceeded to do wonderfully. See for
yourself.

31.06, 27.13, 26.35, 28.38, 27.26, 25.51, 27.91, 32.82(Pop), (32.14),
27.91, 31.71, (24.69), 32.02
= 28.524!

Beat my previous average by 2.5 seconds or so. It felt real good. Now
to bring that down about 6 more seconds and I will be complacent.

1607. Re: Stupid barriers
From: gogozergus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 2002 12:26:20 -0000

> Which algs would you say are the essential to learn?

It's a matter of preference. The most important thing is to understand
what they do, don't learn by heart.

I like the two-generator solution.

Firstly, 2 layers + the cross (bottom edges orientation) (using
standard or Petrus method) + corners position (LU'R'UL'U'R or
RB²L'DL'D'L²B²R').

And finally, one or two of the following algorithms that can be done
very fast with one hand, even if they are not the shortest ones:
- corners orientation: ( RUR'URU2R' | inverse | symetrical ) |
combinations.
- edges permutation: ( R2U'R'U'R2URURU2R | symetrical |
R2U2R2U2R2UR2U2R2U2R2U' (6 right hand moves if done right) |
R2UR2UR'U2R2U2R2U2R'U'R2U'R2 ).



1608. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Stupid barriers
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 2002 13:42:39 +0100

> - corners orientation: ( RUR'URU2R' | inverse | symetrical ) |
> combinations.
>

Ahh yes, a Sune.

> - edges permutation: ( R2U'R'U'R2URURU2R | symetrical |
> R2U2R2U2R2UR2U2R2U2R2U' (6 right hand moves if done right) |
> R2UR2UR'U2R2U2R2U2R'U'R2U'R2 ).
>

Any chance you could encapsulate the tricks in brackets? I'd find this
useful for finding the 6 right hand moves.

Cheers



1609. [Speed cubing group] Re: Stupid barriers
From: gogozergus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Oct 2002 13:11:13 -0000


> > R2U2R2U2R2UR2U2R2U2R2U' (6 right hand moves if done right)
>
> Any chance you could encapsulate the tricks in brackets? I'd find
this useful for finding the 6 right hand moves.

(R2U2)(R2U2)(R2U)(R2U2)(R2U2)(R2U')

You can change rotation every move. I mean: (R'R'UU)* (RRU'U')$
(R'R'U)* (RRU'U')$ (R'R'UU)* (RRU')$
()* moves start with a finger pushing FDR cube.
()$ moves start with a finger pushing BDR cube.

If your right wrist hurts, use (L'R')U2(LR)(FB)U2(F'B') :-)

1613. RE: [Speed cubing group] Question on Square 1

Yea, See the section with the square-1 Label? Pry it off, theres a screw inside. Chances are you will need to crack the piece off, it doesn't easily pry, you might ruin The external of the puzzle. Any other construction questions, ask me or visit Twisty Megasite: http://www.network54.com/Hide/Forum/43402 in case some of you don't know, twisty megasite is a forum to trade, sell, or learn about construction, or anything really. Basically, its everything except Speedcubing (which is covered here..) 1615. Cube Injuries!
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Fri, 25 Oct 2002 07:50:08 -0000

Oww, my wrist hurts. Today I was cubing like usual, but instead of
cubing for cubing sake I did it to relax and think about my day.
After a while all of a sudden my wrist had a shot of pain to it.
Then I realized that I probably had been cubing for like 30 min of
non-stop cubing, probably like 40 solves and scrambles. Anyway that
made me think, props to you, Dan on your marathon, I'm 20 and my
wrists hurt only after 40 solves, I don't think I could even come
close to what you did. Dan how did you do on your attempt, I know
you did your 1500 cubes, but was it hard for you, how long did it
take, did your wrists hurt after, and do you think you can do even
more say 2000?

-Kenneth

1619. How lucky is too lucky?
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Oct 2002 01:59:14 -0000

I was wondering to what degree of luck are we considering lucky. For
example when I am doing corners first, and if after I solve the first
four corners, and the other four are already solved it is like a 1 in
43 chance, I think. Is that too lucky? In like four averages of 12,
I will most likely get that case. My next question is what about
when after I simultaneously put the last two edges in, and the middle
layer is solved, that is like a 1 in 18 chance. And I will most
likely get that case in only two averages of 12. Or would it be too
lucky if I got both of those at the same time, making it like a 1 in
43x18 chance, which is 1 in 774 chance of getting that case, which is
obviously lucky. So what makes a time lucky?

Thanks,

-Kenneth




1620. Re: How lucky is too lucky?
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Oct 2002 03:23:22 -0000

to quote speedcubing.com, "we will summarize a lucky case as follows:
Any step in your solution that is over 5 moves long that is skipped
due to the pieces already being correctly laid on the cube so as to
render the step unnecessary is too lucky. (Except if you worked for
it, f.i. by anticipating the next step.)" I think this is a fairly
common way of determining a solve to be lucky. So, in your example,
if solving the last four corners takes 5 moves (on average), then
skipping it would be considered lucky (same with the middle layer).

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., redkbrandon wrote:
> I was wondering to what degree of luck are we considering
> lucky. For example when I am doing corners first, and if
> after I solve the first four corners, and the other four are
> already solved it is like a 1 in 43 chance, I think. Is
> that too lucky? In like four averages of 12, I will most
> likely get that case. My next question is what about when
> after I simultaneously put the last two edges in, and the
> middle layer is solved, that is like a 1 in 18 chance. And
> I will most likely get that case in only two averages of 12.
> Or would it be too lucky if I got both of those at the same
> time, making it like a 1 in 43x18 chance, which is 1 in 774
> chance of getting that case, which is obviously lucky. So
> what makes a time lucky?
>
> Thanks,
>
> -Kenneth



1621. Re: How lucky is too lucky?
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Oct 2002 08:37:32 -0000

I understand that but here is where I will disagree with this
definition of luck. For example when I solve the 4x4x4, my method
runs in to a parity error half the time. So I have a 1 out of 2
chance of skipping that stage. The move to fix the parity error is
very long. So according to your definition I can only count the
times when I ran in to the parity error, because the others are
considered lucky. Why is luck bad in this case? I don't
consider a
50-50-chance luck. Because if one did consider that luck, then they
must throw out half of their times. Another question, how often does
one have a lucky run? Is there a probability associated with it? And
if there is a probability, what is it and is it the same for
everyone? How often do people think they get a lucky run? Is it one
out of 12 solves? (This would account to why we throw out one time in
an average of 12) I think that to know this probability it would be
much easier for me and maybe others, to decide what is an okay amount
of luck, and what is not an okay amount of luck.

I also think that we should add to your definition of luck to include
the chance of skipping a stage. For example allow for lucky cases if
they come up say 1 out of five times, or more, or something like
that. I would use one out of five, because then on average it would
comes up twice in an average run. So I would add to the definition
you wrote below:

>"we will summarize a lucky case as follows:
> Any step in your solution that is over 5 moves long that is skipped
> due to the pieces already being correctly laid on the cube so as to
> render the step unnecessary is too lucky. (Except if you worked for
it, f.i. by anticipating the next step, or if on average the case
comes up one time for every five solves.)"

Am I making any sense? Or do people think that luck in the case I
described above with the 4x4x4 should still be considered lucky.

What does everyone think?

The guy who asks too many questions,
-Kenneth

1623. Re: [Speed cubing group] Lubed cube today.
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 26 Oct 2002 15:54:32 +0100

> I ordered a 4x from rubiks.com and added a cube lube set (tube and a
> couple sets of stickers) for 4 bucks. It came in today.
>
> I just put a drop in and that's all it took. Still have the whole
> tube left. I haven't opened the 4x yet because I haven't been able to
> put my 3x down.

Yeah, the new rubiks lube is better than it used to be. It used to be
wax, which worked great while it was wet. It was rubbish the next time
you pick it up though, infact it was worse that how it started! Very
stiff, easily give you RSI.

The new stuff is silicone based. I think it's too watery for me, but I
know people on here like the spray lube which is probably much the same
texture. The stuff I use does not run, it's a very stiff lube that was
to be worked in to the cube. Once worked in, it's a lovely smooth
action.



1624. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: How lucky is too lucky?

Have fun,

Ron

1625. Graphite Lube?
From: Ranovek <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Oct 2002 02:52:59 -0000


I have found that the actual silicon lube doesn't seem to help all
that much. I am wondering if anyone has tried using graphite as
a lubricant since it generally works very well on plastics. I am a
little worried that it might make the cube a little too loose.
Anyone tried it?

~Matthias

1627. Re: Variation on a Permutation.
From: "hatadey" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 27 Oct 2002 11:14:44 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., rquethe <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Many of you are probably aware of the move (R'UR'U')x²y'(R'UR'U') > (x'(R²U'))(R'URU). > > I have a (very) slight variation on it. > > y2(L'UL'U')yx²(R'UR'U')(x'(R²U'))(R'URU) > > As you can see, the first part is slightly altered but everything > else is the same. I was wondering if anyone thinks this is any easier > to do or not. Doesn't seem any easier for me, if anything I find it makes slightly more difficult, because you have to break L'UL'U' into two parts L'U and L'U' to execute it smoothly. But, it might be easier for some of you lefties out there ;) Dan
1628. Cubie Tightening

necessary. But can anybody suggest how I might make the
individual "cubies" tight? So that they are bound to each other?
Any suggestions as how to transform a regular cube into
a "speedcube" would be extremely helpful.

1633. [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubie Tightening
From: turnthatcube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 2002 21:32:38 -0000

According to my information: All cube's with the new Rubik's logo are manufactured in Hong Kong under controle of Seven Towns and are the same -that is internal-. Except for the Rubik's Studio cube's with the old 1980 logo, they are produced under controle of the Hungary firm Rubik's Studio run by Erno Rubik. So the Odzonn cube is the same as the Rubiks.com cube, they new ones are good but not the best for speedcubing. You can order a Rubik's Studio cube's for $16 including shipment online on my home page, they will be shiped directly from Hungary. See http://www.speedcubing.com/ton/ Ton --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Seth Hartley-Werner <hartlesx@j...> wrote: > I ordered my cube from Rubiks.com. Where can I order an Oddzon cube? > > Seth > > --On Monday, October 28, 2002 1:46 AM +0000 j_rueth > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > It depends on the cube. Oddzon cubes aren't the greatest for > > speedcubing, but they're still doable. What kind of cube do you have? > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "pycnonotux" <hartlesx@j...> > > wrote: > >> I know that in order to make the axles tight, a lubrication is > >> necessary. But can anybody suggest how I might make the > >> individual "cubies" tight? So that they are bound to each other? > >> Any suggestions as how to transform a regular cube into > >> a "speedcube" would be extremely helpful.
1634. Holy Pyramorhix!
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 2002 22:53:54 +0000

I just had a major 'holy cow' moment! An almighty penny just dropped
in my echo chamber of a head. I've never been able to solve the
Pyramorphix at will, only by half chance, it seems the most illogical
and weird thing ever! I always try to solve my puzzles without
instructions if I can, and I've never read a solution to this. I was
just staring at it dreamily and I realised it's just a 2x2x2 cube!
This may seem obvious to many of you, but it's not everyday that
someone like me has an insight like this! It was like a lucent
daydream!

So, I decided to see if I could rotate two corners of my choosing in a
desired direction. I held it so I could see the cross sections like on
a 2x2x2 cube, a clear horizontal and vertical line and a back line too.
I turned the F face clockwise, performed a Sune on the R face, then
again on the L face, and finally turned the F face anti-clockwise. HEY
PRESTO! I turned two corners!

I've not done a complete scramble and controlled solving yet, I'm gonna
do some more testing first. I always understood that you aim for a
pyramid shape first and then move the pieces around (a beginners
method?). From what I can see right now, it will be quicker and
relatively easy to start moving pieces to the right place straight
away, a pyramid will prevail by natural causes :]

Does it use a regular 2x2x2 Rubik's style mechanism? Is my solution
vision pretty much how others do it quickly? I can see that some
orientation is unnecessary, as there are four featureless faces anyway.



1635. Re: Holy Pyramorhix!
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 2002 23:25:11 -0000

Yes the mechanism is the same. I've messed around with a
pyramorphinx a couple times. YOu can just apply 2x2 moves to get the
puzzle solved. It is also fairly easy to make the pyrimid shape, get
the 4 caps in correct orrientation than do the centers last. Both
are easy. As far as speeding, i don't think too many people compete
for this one. I could be wrong though!!!
Jake



1636. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Holy Pyramorhix!
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 28 Oct 2002 23:47:46 +0000

> Yes the mechanism is the same. I've messed around with a
> pyramorphinx a couple times. YOu can just apply 2x2 moves to get the
> puzzle solved. It is also fairly easy to make the pyrimid shape, get
> the 4 caps in correct orrientation than do the centers last. Both
> are easy. As far as speeding, i don't think too many people compete
> for this one. I could be wrong though!!!
> Jake

I have solved this puzzle several times now :] I'm so happy that I
have solved many of my puzzles now without using instructions.
Although... I feel I cheated a little on this one because I simply
applied algs I already know for the 2x2x2, which I never figured out
anyway, they are my 3x3x3 algs that I read online.



1637. Rubik's Cube/Erno Rubik
From: "Andy Rothman" <jonez_soda@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 2002 00:44:03 -0000

Hey everyone,

I've been searching the internet for quite some time looking for some
way that I would be able to come in contact with Erno Rubik with no
success. Why am I doing this you ask? Well, for college I'm
conducting a semester long research project on the Rubik's
cube...specifically it's history and how to solve it. Finding
information on the history of the cube and how to solve it is easy
enough...there is info all over the internet as well as in text books
that I have found. What I think would be a real kicker to my
project, though, would be if I were able to get in contact with Erno
himself and ask him how he first came up with the idea...well just
conduct an informal or formal interview with him...I'm sure it would
greatly increase my chance of getting a good project grade as well as
impress my instructor. So if anyone has any information/knows how I
can get in contact with Mr. Rubik, it would be very much appreciated.

Andy



1638. i'm still overwhelmed and excited at the same time WOW, Jessica
From: "manolo" <yoamomicubo@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 2002 02:06:36 -0000

Hey Hi Everyone,

I just came back home from meeting Jessica and now i know for sure
she is for real,This girl is amazing, as a person and with a rubik's
cube in her hand, forget it about it that is (insane).

I spent 5 hours with Jessica and now i'am trying to digest in my
system, how good she really is; i know there is a bunch of great
cubist out there which i respect, but this girl is good boys.

Anyway we had some food and talk, and i did some magic tricks for
her,and then i ask her to solve the cube fast for me.. I brought a
timer with me and she said ok time me.. the restaurant was very dark
and you could easily confuse yellow for white, green for blue, and so
forth, well you gyus know that.. well she did it in (16:87 secs),not
bad for such a dark place..

I did some more magic tricks for her, and we talk some more,she put
her cube away and show me a wonderful colletion of puzzles she
have,and one of the toys she has it is a top that float in the air
spining for about 5 mints, It was really great wow..

2 hours later the owner of the restaurant decided that we should
leave the place bcuz we were there for a long long time that is what
he said, so 10 later we left and when to my gym and place where i
work, i introduced Jessica to my coworker and told them about
Jessica; right away they wanted to see Jessica solving the cube again,
she was cold, bcuz she had put the cube away for 2 hours but she ok
time me again, this time there were more light in the pool office
where i work, and i time Jessica again and she did it in
(14.93secs),not that bad after you have not grab the cube for over
tow hours..

I should add that those time were not lucky cases she went to the
whole f2l,orienting,and LL, in both of then, i was very impressed,
and i still am, i have never seen in person and on top of that
Jessica solving the cube that fast WOW..

Jessica thank you for everything and you know what Jessica you forgot
all the cubes with your name and last name, maybe i will mail them to
you..

OK guys this is my story for the day, right Jessica is driving back
to binghamton, she should getting there by 11:30, I wish she have a
nice and safe drive.

Jessica thanks again and you have open my head about speed cubing..

Have a good evening everyone..
Yoamomicubo
Manolo



1639. Re: i'm still overwhelmed and excited at the same time WOW, Jessica
From: "Jessica Fridrich" <jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 2002 04:56:45 -0000

Manolo, I am really glad we finally met. And thank you for today's wonderful and magical afternoon. Manolo is a great close-up magician, guys, and girls, in addition to a pretty fast cuber! I spent most of those 5 hours with my mouth open in disbelief. It seems like magic and cube go well together. Thank you for those tricks!! I promise I will practice. I remembered the cubes when I was crossing the George Washington bridge ... Looks like we will have to meet again in January :) Yeah, that 16.87 in a near complete darkness was a surprise even for me :) Ron, Ton, I greased one of my older cubes and it now twists incredibly. I instantly improved with this cube. It is somewhat stiffer than yours but this stiffness is optimal for my twisting style. Any looser and I would get stuck too often or risk a "pop". Thanks once more, Manolo, for everything. I hope our meeting will help you to squeeze your times! Good luck! 1641. Re: How lucky is too lucky?
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 2002 14:03:20 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > Hi friendz, > > I agree with Kenneth, so I changed the rules a little. > See http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/records-rules.html > I hope you agree, but if not, then please send me some text suggestions. > > Have fun, > > Ron > http://www.speedcubing.com > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] I think there should also be a sense of proportion. For instance, at the moment there is only one time on the board for 17x17x17 and clearly it is bad (not as good as the 19x19x19 time for instance) so when it is broken the time will likely come down by a lot (at least 15 minutes, say). If this time just happens to come from a solve where, for instance, the LL is already oriented (saving a matter of seconds) should it be discounted given that it would clearly have been well under the old time even if the LL had had to be oriented.
1642. Re: How lucky is too lucky?
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 2002 19:46:19 -0000

> --- "Ron van Bruchem" wrote:
> > ... I changed the rules a little.
> > See http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/records-rules.html
--- GameOfDeath2 wrote:
> I think there should also be a sense of proportion. For
> instance, at the moment there is only one time on the
> board for 17x17x17 and clearly it is bad ... If this time
> just happens to come from a solve where, for instance,
> the LL is already oriented (saving a matter of seconds)
> should it be discounted given that it would clearly have
> been well under the old time even if the LL had had to be
> oriented.

I'd never really thought about it this way, but you've got
a really good point. When you do very large cubes with a
"centers first" method, the last several steps (solving it
like a large 3x3x3 cube) take only a small percentage of
the total time (and likewise of the total number of steps).
Maybe the wording should include not only the likelihood
that a given step is skipped, but the percentage of a
solution that is skipped. To make sure that skipping any
step on a 3x3x3 would be considered lucky, the "skipped
portion" allowance would have to be very small, maybe one
or two percent.

So maybe the text could change from:
"A lucky time is any time you solve the puzzle and a step
(3 or more moves) of your normal solution is skipped. There
are two exceptions:
1) You worked for it, f.i. by anticipating the next step.
2) The chance to skip the step is 20 percent or more."

to something like this:
"A lucky time is any time you solve the puzzle and a step
of your normal solution is skipped. There are three
exceptions:
1) You worked for it, f.i. by anticipating the next step.
2) The chance to skip the step is 20 percent or more.
3) The skipped step represents less than 1 percent of
the total time and/or moves for your complete
solution."

With this definition, I couldn't skip any of my standard
3x3x3 steps until I'm working on a 6x6x6 cube or bigger
without considering it to be lucky (my good solves on the
5x5x5 take less than 300 moves). Of course this definition
also has its limitations, because there should be some
cumulative effect here; What if you skip multiple steps
that fit the constraints? How many skipped steps are
acceptable? etc.

What think ye?




1643. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: i'm still overwhelmed and excited at the same time WOW, Jessica
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>

Date: Tue, 29 Oct 2002 22:15:30 +0100

Hi Jessica and Manolo,

It would be nice to see you on top of the average list. Probably at #1!!

Have fun and keep on cubing,

Ron
http://www.speedcubing.com

1644. new timer version...again again
From: jess_bonde <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 29 Oct 2002 22:30:59 -0000

Timer 2.1 is available at:
http://www.rubiks.dk
in the downloads section

new features:

-saves personal records in cookie (I haven't had success with
this feature on the Mac)
-new improved countdown and timer style, also new countdown
sounds
-progress from previous time and average
-number of cubes solved
-average of entire session (incl. fastest and slowest)
-general safety features
-version for 1024x768 and 800x600

I have tested the timer and I hope I have found all the bugs, but if
you should find any, I would be very happy if you would let me know.

I also have a new chat on my page, I will try be on occasionally in
the weekends. I hope to see some of you there

Enjoy,
Jess.

1646. Re: [Speed cubing group] new timer version...again again
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 00:32:40 +0000

> Timer 2.1 is available at:
> http://www.rubiks.dk
> in the downloads section
>
> new features:
>
> -saves personal records in cookie (I haven't had success with
> this feature on the Mac)
> -new improved countdown and timer style, also new countdown
> sounds
> -progress from previous time and average
> -number of cubes solved
> -average of entire session (incl. fastest and slowest)
> -general safety features
> -version for 1024x768 and 800x600
>
> I have tested the timer and I hope I have found all the bugs, but if
> you should find any, I would be very happy if you would let me know.
>
> I also have a new chat on my page, I will try be on occasionally in
> the weekends. I hope to see some of you there
>
> Enjoy,
> Jess.


Hi Jess,

I'm glad to report that this is an excellent update. Even the part
where you say that you can't get the cookies to work on the Mac... My
Mac is working fine with them. I've set my Mac to alert for all
cookies and I have done many tests. Every time a cookie needs
updating, it's working perfectly. I've closed the timer and reopened
and it still holds the times. And also, the stopwatch is not clipping
like it used to. As we say in England, Job's a good'un!

For your reference, I'm running Mac OSX 10.2.1 with Internet Explorer.

THANKS FOR A GREAT PIECE OF WORK JESS!

1650. Re: How lucky is too lucky?
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 13:49:06 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Grant Tregay" <Grant@T...> wrote: > > --- "Ron van Bruchem" wrote: > > > ... I changed the rules a little. > > > See http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/records-rules.html > --- GameOfDeath2 wrote: > > I think there should also be a sense of proportion. For > > instance, at the moment there is only one time on the > > board for 17x17x17 and clearly it is bad ... If this time > > just happens to come from a solve where, for instance, > > the LL is already oriented (saving a matter of seconds) > > should it be discounted given that it would clearly have > > been well under the old time even if the LL had had to be > > oriented. > > I'd never really thought about it this way, but you've got > a really good point. When you do very large cubes with a > "centers first" method, the last several steps (solving it > like a large 3x3x3 cube) take only a small percentage of > the total time (and likewise of the total number of steps). Exactly. Also on the huge cubes, you're very likely to get some good luck and some bad luck at some point in the centres and/or edges, even if it isn't apparent. e.g. in the 20x20x20 cube there are 1944 centre pieces. They can't all be bad. > Maybe the wording should include not only the likelihood > that a given step is skipped, but the percentage of a > solution that is skipped. To make sure that skipping any > step on a 3x3x3 would be considered lucky, the "skipped > portion" allowance would have to be very small, maybe one > or two percent. > > So maybe the text could change from: > "A lucky time is any time you solve the puzzle and a step > (3 or more moves) of your normal solution is skipped. There > are two exceptions: > 1) You worked for it, f.i. by anticipating the next step. > 2) The chance to skip the step is 20 percent or more." > > to something like this: > "A lucky time is any time you solve the puzzle and a step > of your normal solution is skipped. There are three > exceptions: > 1) You worked for it, f.i. by anticipating the next step. > 2) The chance to skip the step is 20 percent or more. > 3) The skipped step represents less than 1 percent of > the total time and/or moves for your complete > solution." > > With this definition, I couldn't skip any of my standard > 3x3x3 steps until I'm working on a 6x6x6 cube or bigger > without considering it to be lucky (my good solves on the > 5x5x5 take less than 300 moves). Of course this definition > also has its limitations, because there should be some > cumulative effect here; What if you skip multiple steps > that fit the constraints? How many skipped steps are > acceptable? etc. > > What think ye? Difficult to say really. I think if you get a little lucky but knock a disproportionate amount off your time it's a bit harsh to discount it completely. e.g. suppose someone does something crazy like solves the 20x20x20 in 2 hour but as soon as (s)he's done with the centres and edges the cube is solved. They've save less than a minute on the last part but destroyed the old time. Should that last piece of luck really count against? One reason I ask is that on my 6x6x6 time I came across every stage (including flipping part of one edge and switching 2 edges) and was just shy of the 4 minute barrier which is currently my focus on the big cubes. Clearly the sub 4 minute 6x6x6 is achievable but, despite my expectations that I would get there, it hasn't yet come. If I do achieve it but don't have to say put one of the edge-corner pairs in (yet still have to switch 2 edges and flip parts of an edge which would compensate more than the amount saved by the one corner-edge pair) what is my situation in terms of the UWR? In fact, skipping a 3x3x3 stage will really not save much time at all in the framework of the big cubes. Flipping an edge (or part of one) or switching 2 edges take much longer.
1651. Re: How lucky is too lucky?
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Oct 2002 18:22:27 -0000

>Clearly the sub 4 minute 6x6x6 is achievable but, despite
> my expectations that I would get there, it hasn't yet come.

It has now (and with no skipped stages (in the 3x3x3 sense) plus a
single edge flip (though not switching 2 edges).

3" 52.645'

1658. downloadable simulations
From: madscan_99 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 01 Nov 2002 13:49:19 -0000



http://www.tux.org/~bagleyd/puzzles.html

I want to suggest a link for you to post.
http://www.tux.org/~bagleyd/puzzles.html DAVID BAGLEY has put
together a package of his FREE windows-based programs including a
cube simulator that allows at least as high as 10x10x10 to run
flawlessly on my old 486 -66mhz-24 mbRAM machine as well as pyramids,
octahedra,dino, skewb,etc. all with the ability to
increase/decrease "layers" and change from face turning to corner
turning modes where applicable. These program allows you to save the
current state of your cube (including all the moves done to get to
that state) to a file called xxxxx.dat(can be renamed to allow for
multiple save states) and reload it later to continue where you left
off. worked great for my first-ever effort to solve 9x9x9,which took
several half-hour sessions to finally complete(which I then saved to
the ".dat" file,and which ,when reloaded, plays an impressive
little "movie" as the simulator displays every single state the cube
was in from start to finish in rapid-fire succession) The download is
small and the functionality is UNSURPASSED !!!! BY FAR THE BEST
SOFTWARE SIMULATION I'VE YET TO USE AND I BELIEVE BY FAR THE BEST
SOFTWARE SIMULATION OUT THERE!!!! (DEBATABLE, I'M SURE) DID I MENTION
IT'S FREE??? Try it, you'll love it. thanks

1660. speed 4x4, 5x5
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 01 Nov 2002 20:02:02 -0000

I was just wondering what people thought about speedsolving the 4x4x4
and 5x5x5. I know for the 3x3x3 there is really no better solution,
whether it be corners first or Jessica's method. But I was
wondering
if that also goes for the 4x4x4 and 5x5x5. I currently use my own
system, based on how I solve the 3x3x3. I solve the top center,
followed by the bottom center. Then I finish the top layer, followed
by the bottom corners and edges. Next I solve the middle edges, fix
parity error, and then finish with the middle centers. Now I don't
think I can go much further with this method, and was wondering if I
should just abandon it and learn a centers first method, or if I
could tweak my system and make it better.

Any suggestions?

Thanks,

-Kenneth Brandon





1661. Re: speed 4x4, 5x5
From: "James Potter" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 01 Nov 2002 21:03:48 -0000

I only just figured out how to solve a 4x4x4, using my own solution and my own algorithms. I solve the centers, then I get the edge pairs together, then I just use it like a big 3x3x3. But I need a few algorithms for the bottom layer. I need to know how to orient one edge, how to switch two edges across, and two edges diagonally. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., redkbrandon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I was just wondering what people thought about speedsolving the 4x4x4 > and 5x5x5. I know for the 3x3x3 there is really no better solution, > whether it be corners first or Jessica's method. But I was > wondering > if that also goes for the 4x4x4 and 5x5x5. I currently use my own > system, based on how I solve the 3x3x3. I solve the top center, > followed by the bottom center. Then I finish the top layer, followed > by the bottom corners and edges. Next I solve the middle edges, fix > parity error, and then finish with the middle centers. Now I don't > think I can go much further with this method, and was wondering if I > should just abandon it and learn a centers first method, or if I > could tweak my system and make it better. > > Any suggestions? > > Thanks, > > -Kenneth Brandon
1662. Re: speed 4x4, 5x5
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 02 Nov 2002 21:11:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., redkbrandon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I was just wondering what people thought about speedsolving the 4x4x4 > and 5x5x5. I know for the 3x3x3 there is really no better solution, > whether it be corners first or Jessica's method. But I was > wondering > if that also goes for the 4x4x4 and 5x5x5. I currently use my own > system, based on how I solve the 3x3x3. I solve the top center, > followed by the bottom center. Then I finish the top layer, followed > by the bottom corners and edges. Next I solve the middle edges, fix > parity error, and then finish with the middle centers. Now I don't > think I can go much further with this method, and was wondering if I > should just abandon it and learn a centers first method, or if I > could tweak my system and make it better. > > Any suggestions? > Go centres first. Do one centre, then do the opposite one. Make the 4th centre adjacent the 3rd. Put the edges together. Correct last edge if necessary (5x5x5). Solve pretty much as you'd do a 3x3x3. At the start of the last layer you may have to flip the edge (4x4x4). At the permutation stage you may first have to swap 2 edges (4x4x4). I'm pretty sure you can get a good time like this. > Thanks, > > -Kenneth Brandon

1664. Just bought my Rubik's Cube....solved ONE side.
From: "BJ Fuller" <vaafanculo@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 04 Nov 2002 06:55:20 -0000

I'm a Rookie,

I just bought my Rubik's Cube 3 days ago. I solved one side on the
first day. I was pretty psyched. Solving one side is pretty easy
now.

I thought it would be pretty cool if I could solve the whole thing.
I looked at a bunch of web pages regarding solving the cube. They're
all extremely confusing.

Are there any web pages or instructional material that is easy to
follow?

A lot of these steps, diagrams, pictures, show what moves to do when
the cube is already solved. My cube is all mixed up. So it doesn't
help out very much.

Are there any sites or books or documents which show the steps in a
slow, easy-to-follow format?

This cube is depressing me already.

Help

BJF



1665. Re: Just bought my Rubik's Cube....solved ONE side.
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 04 Nov 2002 08:07:17 -0000

Hi there, I am glad that you are interested in the cube! Here is the site that I learned from. I too was in your shoes about a year and two months ago. I liked this site because there was no notation to learn (even though now that I know it, it seams very easy,) and it was easy to follow. I think that with my cube in hand and reading this page it took me around 45 min to solve the cube for the first time. Good luck, and let us know if you get it solved, and then if you memorize the solution. http://jjorg.chem.unc.edu/personal/monroe/cube/rubik.html -Kenneth P.S. Time yourself for fun, and then if you want you can post your time at www.speedcubing.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "BJ Fuller" <vaafanculo@h...> wrote: > I'm a Rookie, > > I just bought my Rubik's Cube 3 days ago. 1666. Re: [Speed cubing group] Just bought my Rubik's Cube....solved ONE side.
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 04 Nov 2002 10:00:23 +0000

> Are there any web pages or instructional material that is easy to
> follow?
>
> A lot of these steps, diagrams, pictures, show what moves to do when
> the cube is already solved. My cube is all mixed up. So it doesn't
> help out very much.
>
> Are there any sites or books or documents which show the steps in a
> slow, easy-to-follow format?
>
> This cube is depressing me already.
>
> Help
>
> BJF
>

I know what you mean, but it all depends on which method you want to learn.
This is the site that I learnt from, which of course means I found (and
still do find) the easiest to follow. I suppose I've become biased, but I
think you should look:

http://www.cubeland.fr.st/

Using only the moves on that site, you can average under a minute easily.
It will also be a good way to start learning a complete Jessica method and
get under 20 seconds. If you want to learn some other system, hopefully
someone else will have a beginners link?

The moves I learnt from that site have led to me learning to do the 2x2x2,
3x3x3, 4x4x4, 5x5x5, pyramorphix and megaminx. The extra moves needed for
the big cubes I got from Chris Hardwick's corner on:

http://www.speedcubing.com/

Best leave that for later though, eh?



1667. Re: speed 4x4, 5x5
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 04 Nov 2002 15:30:29 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., redkbrandon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I was just wondering what people thought about speedsolving the 4x4x4 > and 5x5x5. I know for the 3x3x3 there is really no better solution, > whether it be corners first or Jessica's method. But I was > wondering > if that also goes for the 4x4x4 and 5x5x5. I currently use my own > system, based on how I solve the 3x3x3. I solve the top center, > followed by the bottom center. Then I finish the top layer, followed > by the bottom corners and edges. Next I solve the middle edges, fix > parity error, and then finish with the middle centers. Now I don't > think I can go much further with this method, and was wondering if I > should just abandon it and learn a centers first method, or if I > could tweak my system and make it better. > > Any suggestions? > > Thanks, > > -Kenneth Brandon Actually, I'll go a bit further. I don't think you can really be competitive at the highest level if you don't do centres first. Centres last is a lot slower (although it makes putting the edges together quicker) and I don't think it will produce stunning times. Your method is sort of half way between these extremes but it seems that you are leaving 4 centres to the end. I don't think that can be efficient. You can probably get away with leaving 2 (adjacent) centres to the end but you'll still lose a bit of time.
1668. Re: [Speed cubing group] Just bought my Rubik's Cube....solved ONE side.
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Tue, 05 Nov 2002 00:13:05 -0000

My cube is all mixed up. So it doesn't > > help out very much. > > > > Are there any sites or books or documents which show the steps in a > > slow, easy-to-follow format? > > > > This cube is depressing me already. > > > > Help > > > > BJF > > heres one of the sites I found the most useful when I started out. http://lar5.com/cube/ ....its easier to follow than most pages because it doesn't have any confusing notation. I dont use the whole method on that page. but I use the first couple steps then go on my own after that. Because I thought it was easier to leave a step out.... maybe you could give it a try.... oh, welcome to the club and i hope ya figure out how to solve the cube!... -Heath

heres one of the sites I found the most useful when I started out.
http://lar5.com/cube/ ....its easier to follow than most pages
because it doesn't have any confusing notation. I dont use the whole
method on that page. but I use the first couple steps then go on my
own after that. Because I thought it was easier to leave a step
out....

maybe you could give it a try....

oh, welcome to the club and i hope ya figure out how to solve the
cube!...

-Heath
