--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "BJ Fuller" <vaafanculo@h...> wrote: > I'm a Rookie, > > I just bought my Rubik's Cube 3 days ago. I solved one side on the > first day. I was pretty psyched. Solving one side is pretty easy > now. > > I thought it would be pretty cool if I could solve the whole thing. > I looked at a bunch of web pages regarding solving the cube. They're > all extremely confusing. > > Are there any web pages or instructional material that is easy to > follow? > > A lot of these steps, diagrams, pictures, show what moves to do when > the cube is already solved. My cube is all mixed up. So it doesn't > help out very much. > > Are there any sites or books or documents which show the steps in a > slow, easy-to-follow format? > > This cube is depressing me already. > > Help > > BJF If youre a beginner, then I wouldn't recommend Lars Petrus' site or Jessica Fridrich's. Thgey're mainly for semi-experienced cubists. I have a site about the cube with some solutions, so you might want to check it out. URL: http://www.geocities.com/rubiks81
1673. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Just bought my Rubik's Cube....solved ONE side.
From: Kåre Krig <karkr936@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Nov 2002 18:06:54 +0100


> If youre a beginner, then I wouldn't recommend Lars Petrus' site or
> Jessica Fridrich's. Thgey're mainly for semi-experienced cubists. I
> have a site about the cube with some solutions, so you might want to
> check it out. URL: http://www.geocities.com/rubiks81
>

Actually for me the Petrus method have shown to be quite easy to learn and teach. I solved my first cube using the Petrus method. The first day I couldent solve it without cheating and looking at the page at least once every cube, but from the second day I had no problems at all. The problem with the Petrus method is that it require that the cubist do lots of thinking during solving instead of having a lot of memorized algs to solve everything.

I have found it to be quite easy to teach in person too. Its not that hard to build a 2*2*1, and then I show how to make a 2*2*2 from it. Then getting to 2*2*3 is also no problem. Flipping edges is the part that seems to be the hardest part to grasp. Also geting in the last pices in the f2l could be a problem. Last layer is just 3 algs to memorize.

It might be a bit harder than some methods but the approch made sence to me when I learned it and the good thing is that you get a top class method.

/Kï¿½re



1674. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Just bought my Rubik's Cube....solved ONE side.
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 05 Nov 2002 19:46:18 -0800

At 18:06 +0100 11/5/02, Kåre Krig wrote:
> Flipping edges is the part that seems to be the hardest part to grasp.

That's a frustrating one, because when I teach people in person, that
is the easiest step. But when explaining it in text it becomes the
hardest. I did a full rewrite a few months back. I think that helped,
but it still seems much harder than it really is.

>Also geting in the last pices in the f2l could be a problem.

Yeah, that is clearly the hardest part of it. Once you learn a few
common positions and a trick or two, it's not hard, but it's tough to
get there.

>Last layer is just 3 algs to memorize.

I recently taught a friend, and she had some problems with the
"thinking" parts (Steps 1, 2 & 4), but she got the final 3 algs in
about 5 minutes each!

--
"They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever
flipped it over?"

Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@... http://lar5.com


1675. Rubik's Cube and Revenge
From: "cubeman35" <speedcubist@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Nov 2002 04:08:00 -0000

I noticed something weird about first using the Rubik's Revenge and
then switching over to the Rubik's Cube. At first using the Rubik's
Revenge felt big and akward. Then as I went back to using my Rubik's
Cube, it felt small and akward. After a while, though, I got used to
switching back and forth between the two different sized cubes and
they just felt normal again. Also, going from solving the Rubik's
Revenge to solving the Rubik's Cube made the Rubik's Cube seem real
simple and quick to solve. I take usually around 34 seconds to solve
it, and once in a while under 30.

-Travis Waddell

popping. Is there a way to fix it or keep it from popping? What
about lubing it? Would silicon make a difference to it?
Just wondering what some of you do.
Jake



1678. Re: megaminx pops
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Nov 2002 23:39:40 -0000

I have problems with pieces popping from my megaminx all the time. Part of avoiding this is just making sure you have the pieces lined up right before going on to the next move (losing a couple seconds every solve is better than popping a piece every solve!). However, I don't remember what it was like prior to a good silicon lubing. In the process of lubing it the first time, one of the screws came loose, and I had to retighten it (and glue it in place). I have found, though, that as the lube wears thin (and my megaminx gets a bit harder to move again), I'm more likely to pop pieces. Right after relubing, it always seems to be a fair amount better. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Just wondering if anyone else is having problems with their minxs > popping. Is there a way to fix it or keep it from popping? What > about lubing it? Would silicon make a difference to it? > Just wondering what some of you do. > Jake

1682. lubing minx and barrier update
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Nov 2002 15:48:08 -0000

My Megaminx is moving incredibly!!!! Just a little squirt of
silicone helped me considerably. With the puzzle turning stiffly i
couldn't break 9 min. Now I'm getting 6-7 min times!!! I'd like to
get this down below five min. At the rate of my improvements it
shouldn't take real long.

I finally got an average below 40. 39.39 so just barely below forty.
Like one person said its much nicer having a 2 instead of a 3 in
front of there times, the same appies here as well, hehehehe.
Anyway, I think music has a gigantic role in cubing. I know we had a
serious discusion earlier about music while cubing. It certainly
makes a different. Maybe some of you newer cubers that recently
joined showed try playing some tunes while you cube. It will help
you stay in a consistent pace and I think that is what helped me get
fairly consistent times.
Jake



1683. So you thought speedcubing is useless
From: "Ron" <ron@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Nov 2002 16:44:10 -0000

Hi friendz,

Many people ask me why I am involved in something so useless.
Well to prove that more people are spending hours and hours doing
something useless other than speedcubing, check this out:
http://www.speedstacks.com/qt_lg.html

Speedstacking (http://www.speedstacks.com) is maybe even more popular
than speedcubing. They organized the Rocky Mountain Cup Stacking
Championships on April 6th, 2002 with over 950 participants!!!!

So what do you think: should we try to create the WSCF (the World
Speed Cubing Federation)?

Have fun,

Ron
http://www.speedcubing.com

> something useless other than speedcubing, check this out:
> http://www.speedstacks.com/qt_lg.html

Haahaha, that's the funniest thing I've seen in a long time! Another funny
thing I've seen on the internet is grocery bag packing! (in America of
course). These guys can completely fill out grocery bags in a blur, and to
prove it's been done properly, a judge cuts the bag down the side leaving
the groceries free standing. If the bag is cut and the groceries collapse,
it is deemed to be packed badly and is disqualified!

Sorry to be a little off topic, but...

I've been thinking it would be fun to learn a few magic tricks, just
for fun. my question to Manolo is where to start and how to go about
it? Do you buy a book, buy tricks from magic stores, take a class,
find a teacher, or...?

In other news I'm having SO much fun with Jess's timer! I get
distracted by timing myself, writing down times, doing the Math etc.
Now I just cube and press the space bar! My record so far is 21.88,
which is my best average ever, and I think I can trim 1-2 seconds off
that if I get my head in gear and stop being so wildly uneven.

1686. newbie
From: "Sam Fontana" <robot8387@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Nov 2002 02:49:53 -0000

Hi this is my first time posting but ive been reading it for a while.
Ive been cubing for about 3 monthes only using the edge first layer
method. I barly avg 1 45 but would like to learn the lars or jessicas
method. i dont have a computer at home so the only time i get to a
comupter is at the library and i cant watch videos here so i have to
go to a internet cafe to watch it but have to pay. im a manual
learner so i dont really understand the text on these pages. so i was
wandering if anyone has any tips to help me learn these. oh i allmost
forgot i have an older cube with screws under the caps and was
wondering how to loosen the springs and it has a lot of cube dust it
it and i as wondering if i should lube it with silicon or if graphite
is a possability want to know can you make a cube so lose that it
will pop a lot? and what do i use to resticker my cube. thanks for
the help.



1687. Re: [Speed cubing group] newbie
From: "Justin Vining" <viningjc@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 7 Nov 2002 22:29:24 -0500

Hey Sam, if you need a sort of hands on learning try Jon Morris' site, http://nascarjon.curvedspaces.com/cube.htm He uses Jessica's method and has great cube applets to show you exactly how to turn the cube for every algorithm you would need to know to use Jessica's method.

Also if you got some free time to kill you can check out my cube site. I have recently been creating it and everyday I'm adding more to it. http://icdweb.cc.purdue.edu/~viningjc/cube.html

Happy Cubing, Justin Vining

1689. Re: [Speed cubing group] newbie
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 08 Nov 2002 10:19:01 +0000

> Hi this is my first time posting but ive been reading it for a while.
> Ive been cubing for about 3 monthes only using the edge first layer
> method. I barly avg 1 45 but would like to learn the lars or jessicas
> method. i dont have a computer at home so the only time i get to a
> comupter is at the library and i cant watch videos here so i have to
> go to a internet cafe to watch it but have to pay. im a manual
> learner so i dont really understand the text on these pages. so i was
> wandering if anyone has any tips to help me learn these. oh i allmost
> forgot i have an older cube with screws under the caps and was
> wondering how to loosen the springs and it has a lot of cube dust it
> it and i as wondering if i should lube it with silicon or if graphite
> is a possability want to know can you make a cube so lose that it
> will pop a lot? and what do i use to resticker my cube. thanks for
> the help.
>

http://www.cubeland.fr.st/ uses the little applets to show the moves. It's
very simple to get started with and has the potential to be expanded to a
full blown Jessica method.

As for lubing and whether a cube can become too loose, well yes that can
happen for sure. The best way to minimise poppage but have a super smooth
turning cube is don't bother sanding down the internals. I know some people
sand pieces to make them pass by each other with no catching. It's probably
better to be patient and wear the cube in with normal use.

You say you have a lot of cube dust inside your cube. Some people will tell
you that the dust alone is a very effective way to make your cube turn
nicely. It all depends on how you want it to feel. Dan Gosbee in Canada
doesn't sand or lube or anything, he just buys in bulk and only the ones
that feel good right from the box are used. The rest are deemed as spares I
guess?

It sounds like your cube has been worn in quite nicely though. So
personally, I would strip it down and wash all the corners and edges in very
hot water. I just drop them in freshly boiled water and wait for the water
to cool enough to pick them out. Just use a toothbrush or something to
clean the centres. Then dry off, reassemble and use a stiff silicone lube.
If the water ruins the stickers, just put new decent ones back on. I can
send you a set of stickers if need be.

Other people might prefer a spray lube, but I don't like how it runs and
drips.



1690. Blindfold cubing - another type of relay (team event).
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Nov 2002 13:14:48 -0000


Scramble 4 cubes A, B, C, D - you'll need to duplicate the
scrambling on another 4 cubes.

Person 1 gets to see cubes A, B.
Person 2 gets to see cubes B, C.
Person 3 gets to see cubes C, D.
Person 4 gets to see cubes D, A.

Whilst blindfolded, person 1 solves cube A into the position of cube
B which (s)he then puts down (being careful in terms of the
orientation of the cube as a whole). This cube is then given
(unseen) to person 2, with that exact orientation - so in advance
there should be some agreement in the team that it will be passed
with a certain configuration of centres - not necessarily the same
at each link).
Person 2 solves the cube to position C. Then person 3 gets it,
whilst blindfolded, and solves it position D.
Finally person 4 gets it, whilst blindfolded, and solves it back to
position A.




1691. Re: So you thought speedcubing is useless
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Nov 2002 13:31:57 -0000

Another example of extreme speed - search the web for "Stade Olympique de l'Emyrne" 149 Here's one such link: http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/funny_old_game/2406113.stm (Bear in mind that there probably wasn't much, if any, added time, and unlike American football, for example, the clock doesn't stop when the ball goes out of play so you have to figure getting the ball back to the centre each time in the 90 minutes.) PS I'd have to say that the stacking of cups at that speed was fairly impressive. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Ron" <ron@s...> wrote: > Hi friendz, > > Many people ask me why I am involved in something so useless. > Well to prove that more people are spending hours and hours doing > something useless other than speedcubing, check this out: > http://www.speedstacks.com/qt_lg.html > > Speedstacking (http://www.speedstacks.com) is maybe even more popular > than speedcubing. 1694. Re: Magic and magic
From: "manolo" <yoamomicubo@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Nov 2002 16:12:22 -0000

--- Hi Lars, Yeah, I really think that magic and speedcubing are very similar. when i started doing magic, i went to the magic store in my area and bought two books one for card tricks and one for coin tricks. Lars it depends what kind of tricks you prefer, I like cards and coin tricks the most, but i also do other tricks with dollar bills and cigarette and more. so i would suggest that you get a book with over all magic and then see in which one you want to get better,then you can get a book that mainly specialize in either cards or coin or cigarette or else.. I have a few books for cards, for coins, for cigarette and for overall magic, close up magic i mean. I do not remember the name of the book i have for overall magic, I lent it to a friend and he has not return it to me, but tomorrow i'm going to the magic store and i'll get it for you.. I personaly think that books are better then tapes because you can get better technique by reading and reading, but it is not a bad idea to watch some tapes, you learn something from it too. I will get you the name of the book, and we all going to be practicing magic in Toronto. Hi every one I wish everybody is feeling well and getting ready for Toronto one way or another...By for now and have a good weekend everyone. Manolo T In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Lars Petrus <lars@l...> wrote: > >At 4:56 +0000 10/29/02, Jessica Fridrich wrote: > > > >It seems like magic and cube go well together. Looks like we will > >have to meet again in January :) > > Sorry to be a little off topic, but... > > I've been thinking it would be fun to learn a few magic tricks, just > for fun. my question to Manolo is where to start and how to go about > it? Do you buy a book, buy tricks from magic stores, take a class, > find a teacher, or...? > > In other news I'm having SO much fun with Jess's timer! I get > distracted by timing myself, writing down times, doing the Math etc. > Now I just cube and press the space bar! My record so far is 21.88, > which is my best average ever, and I think I can trim 1-2 seconds off > that if I get my head in gear and stop being so wildly uneven. > > At 15:41 +0000 11/7/02, j_rueth wrote: > >Heyoh. I was just wondering if there is anyone that uses the petrus > >method and is reaching times below 20, preferably and av under 20. > >Thanks Much!!! > >Jake > > I've heard from several under 30 ones, but I don't know of anyone > below 20. Not that I keep any track of them at all. > > In my 21.88 run, I was under 20 5 times out of 12. > > -- > "They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever > flipped it over?" > > Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@l... http://lar5.com
1695. Re: Blindfold cubing - another type of relay (team event).
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Nov 2002 17:31:23 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > That sounds neat and all but are there enough blindfold cubists out > there to have this relay. Just an idea - not necessarily meant as a race. Just to see if it could be done. You only need 4 people and there are certainly enough for that. Alternatively, you could have 1 person do it but with checkpoints, so to speak - like they have to stop at each designated position (and possibly end up solving it too). >I can understand the whole race against > each other, and a cooperative race is very clever, my thoughts is > that there won't be too much competiton, or is it meant that way? As I said, I wasn't really meaning a race - just curious if it could be done. My friend had suggested to me getting from one scrambled state to another and this was possible so I figured it was a way to generalize it. It's not as scary as the other idea I had involving scrambling 6 5x5x5s! > > What if they had a layers battle,(no blindfold sorry) > each team is made up of three people, first does FL, second does ML > and last does LL. > You could even do one for the Corners first method. > Just divy out the chores. I think that would be wild!!! > > jake > True, but not many speed people do the cube layer by layer either. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > > > Scramble 4 cubes A, B, C, D - you'll need to duplicate the > > scrambling on another 4 cubes. > > > > Person 1 gets to see cubes A, B. > > Person 2 gets to see cubes B, C. > > Person 3 gets to see cubes C, D. > > Person 4 gets to see cubes D, A. > > > > Whilst blindfolded, person 1 solves cube A into the position of > cube > > B which (s)he then puts down (being careful in terms of the > > orientation of the cube as a whole). This cube is then given > > (unseen) to person 2, with that exact orientation - so in advance > > there should be some agreement in the team that it will be passed > > with a certain configuration of centres - not necessarily the same > > at each link). > > Person 2 solves the cube to position C. Then person 3 gets it, > > whilst blindfolded, and solves it position D. > > Finally person 4 gets it, whilst blindfolded, and solves it back to > > position A.

Have you tried the book Conquer the Cube? It's a bit confusing, but you can solve it really fast that way. If you want an easy way to do it, then try the book called the Simple Solution to the Rubiks Cube. It's extremely easy, but it takes you about two minutes or so to solve it. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "BJ" <vaafanculo@h...> wrote: > thanks bud > > hopefully I'll find someone. > > later > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@y... > Sent: Sunday, November 10, 2002 12:08 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Denver, Colorado > > > > Denver...kewl Im about a 5 or 6 hours drive from there. 1709. Need Help for Rubik's Revenge
From: Erwin Hidayat <erwinh@...>
To: Speedcubing <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 11 Nov 2002 13:14:13 +0700

Hi All,

I've tried to solve Rubik's Revenge using 3x3x3 method,
I've solved for the center, edge, and put the corner in the right place.

BUT, the corner doesn't flip right,
I meant one of three side from the corner already match with the side,
but the others (two sides) of the corner are switched.

Does any one can help me ?

sorry if my question have been asked.

thanks,
-eh-



1710. Re: [Speed cubing group] Need Help for Rubik's Revenge
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 11 Nov 2002 10:04:48 +0000

> Hi All,
>
> I've tried to solve Rubik's Revenge using 3x3x3 method,
> I've solved for the center, edge, and put the corner in the right place.
>
> BUT, the corner doesn't flip right,
> I meant one of three side from the corner already match with the side,
> but the others (two sides) of the corner are switched.
>
> Does any one can help me ?
>
> sorry if my question have been asked.
>
> thanks,
> -eh-


There are two algs you will need to know to correct parity problems.

(R2r2)B2U2(Ll)U2(R'r')U2(Rr)U2F2(Rr)F2(L'l')B2(R2r2)

Will flip one edge, this can be done anytime after the F2L.

r2U2r2(u2U2)r2(u2U2)

Will swap two edge pieces (or two corner pieces). This can be done as soon
as you notice it needs doing, but it messes up whatever else you have done
on the LL.

I hope I got this info right! By the way, these algs are really easy.
Notice that the brackets hold the same sides, so you just turn both parts
the same, rather than slices.

1713. Cube Debut
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Nov 2002 03:44:13 -0000

Hey all! How's everyone doing? Been a while since I posted, but
here goes. I wanted to hold out on this until I knew it might happen
but it looks like I might be on MTV for a very short time to do the
cube. They want me to fill part of a 15 second channel break, from
what I understand, doing finger tricks and showing off speed cubing
techniques. I told the guy that I can't solve the cube in less the
15 seconds reliably at all, having only done it once EVER. He said
the time wasn't so important, just showing the method of doing it
really fast. Well anyway they're mailing me the tickets tomorrow so
it seems like it might happen. No guarantees that they'll air it or
anything, I just know they're going to fly me to New York this coming
Monday for the film shoot. So anyway I'm really excited, I hope they
end up airing it, even if it is only less than 15 seconds :) So
anyway I'm still in the cube scene, sort of part time I guess heh
heh. Still averaging around 22-24 seconds though :( I lubed my cube
and got some frequent 18's and 19's but still averaging 22-24. I'm
trying some tips I got off Jessica's site and they help me sometimes
but other times I mess it up or the cube is just like "Eh... I think
I'll hide all the pieces he's looking for" so those times are a
little slower than usual :) Anyway just letting you guys know I
might be spreading the word of the cube some (hopefully more people
will convert to speed cubing or just cubing in general).

Chris

P.S. The people at my college don't seem as interested in the cube
as at my old high school but I have met one person who's trying to
learn to do it, and I taught one of my suitemates how to solve it.
So I'm slowly spreading out here too a little.

Later all

1717. Re: [Speed Solving Rubik's Cube] Where to buy a cube in London?
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 13 Nov 2002 10:46:42 +0000

Below is a re-post, something I wrote a few weeks ago. You probably don't
need the amount of detail that I've written, but I've also added some more.


Hamley's in Regents Street.
http://www.hamleys.co.uk/
That's possibly the best toy shop you'll ever visit! However I don't know
that they definitely do have cubes. Hamley's is very famous, you should
have no trouble getting directions. It's in the middle of the curve between
Oxford Street Tube station and Piccadilly Circus. Look for the flags!

Not far from there is a gadget shop called 'The Gadget Shop'. Got that?
http://www.gadgetshop.com/
That's in Oxford Street and it's the big one from their popular chain. I've
seen Oddzon cubes in some of The Gadget Shops, but again I don't know if
that one will sell them. The shop is located between Oxford Street tube
station and Tottenham Court Road, it's on the north side of the road on a
junction and once you roughly in the vicinity, someone should be able to
tell you where it is. Look for the pinky purlply neon sign!

There's Beatties too, a fairly big one can be found on the right of the road
that goes from Centre Point towards Holborn station. Again, I don't know if
they sell cubes for sure.

I get mine from The Entertainer, outside Debenhams ground floor in Lakeside
Shopping Centre. They don't stock many at a time and run out pretty quickly
from what I can tell, but they always have a few different Rubiks Puzzles.
The Cubes are Oddzon branded, which are just... OK. Also in Lakeside, visit
Globe, The Discovery Store, ground floor near centre. They sell some very
cheap cubes but they are no good for speed cubing (I really mean that!).

If you want my opinion though, visit Ebay. You can find a real cube from
Hungary! You won't pay much for them and they have much more potential.
Look for Ideal brand or Studio Cube or Büvös Kocka (?) One such seller who
I can vouch for is Andreas http://go.to/rubiks4sale

I live in Essex by the way. Nice to meet you :] The best cube I ever
bought was from Ebay, it's a second hand Studio cube, previously used by
esteemed cubist Dan Knights who averaged 18 seconds on it. I average about
double that though!



1718. Re: Cube Debut
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Nov 2002 14:25:41 -0000

Thats Awesome!!! Knock em dead!

I'm also having trouble converting people at my college as well. The
interest was so big in High school but now people are more like, "Get
a real life, or a job at least" I do have some people interested in
cubing but they are more awstruck that they could never solve one.
Oh well, it looks like we got some work to do!!!
Jake




1719. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cube Debut
From: "Justin Vining" <viningjc@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 13 Nov 2002 10:33:15 -0500

Congrats on landing the job with MTV. That is pretty sweet!

About trying to convert people to cubing, I am having a totally opposite experience here at Purdue. EVERYONE wants to learn! I've tought over 20 people in the last month or two and many many more are learning. You can check out our progress at http://icdweb.cc.purdue.edu/~viningjc/cube

Everyone have a great day and happy cubing!
-justin vining

1720. [Speed cubing group] Re: Cube Debut
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 13 Nov 2002 23:57:43 -0000

Wow very cool, MTV is cool. And good job Justin 20 people is very
impressive.
Our club at the University of California, Irvine (UCI), is called
RubiXtremE. So far we have taught 10 or so people. Doing pretty
well. I have encouraged them to post their times, so hopefully we
will be seeing some of their times soon. Now that they all know the
cube, some are moving to the 4x4 and 5x5 while some want to go
faster. We already have some fast people, two people are around a
min average I am at 25s and a couple other under 2 min. It is
getting to be fun. We are soon going to have a competition, or a
booth, on campus, so some of us can show off our skills, and also to
get some publicity. Then hopefully we will interest more people in
the cube, and catch up to Purdue's 20 people. Good luck to other
people trying to teach the cube at their campuses.

-Kenneth

I'm taking a short holiday in England (London and Oxford) between 21
Nov and 1 Dec. If anyone is in that area and wants to meet up for a
chat, do let me know. I'm not really a speedcuber (70 secs), more of
a general puzzle collector/solver and magician. And if you want me to
take anything from my collection along, take a look at my site and
let me know.

book. Some of the greatest tricks of all time have been card tricks
and there are a million book sout there with hundreds and hundreds of
card tricks in them. Thats how I got my start doing magic. It's even
better becasuse every house has a deck or towo for you to use
whenever you want to amaze some people. Well hope that helps

Mike

1726. Speedcubing video
From: "Lars Vandenbergh" <lars.vandenbergh@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 15 Nov 2002 15:01:46 -0000

Hi,

today at school we were working on our multimedia project so I asked if I could use the camera to make a video of me while speedcubing. I only got 1 attempt because the batteries of the DV-camera were running low. Anyway, you can watch the result at:

http://lars.studentenweb.org/cube/lars.mpg

I did a decent 22.30 seconds. F2L was quite clumsy, my hands stopped a couple of times, but OLL and PLL were both easy cases. I can definately do better and hope to do some more videos.

Have fun,

Lars

1730. Bought a new puzzle today
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 17 Nov 2002 12:03:53 -0000

While on an expedition to buy a birthday present for someone (a
Rubik's cube, of course) I found a puzzle I had never seen before.
Obviously, I had to buy it immediately. At first I thought it was
just a variation of the Rubik's Sphere (ie. spherical version of the
Rubik's cube), but upon opening the box I discovered that the
mechanics, and therefore necessary algorithms, were different.

I checked the Twisty Puzzles site so I could tell you what it
actually was. Mechanically, it's like the Chromesix Colour Ball (aka:
Cromoball, Chromosix): http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/fs.cgi?
str=puzzle.cgi?pid=561. The only difference with mine is visual - it
has numbers on each circular 'face'. So, as well as matching the
colours, the numbers need to be in the right order and the right way
up.

When I started solving it I was aiming to do the colours, the
position of the numbers and the orientation of the numbers, all at
the same time. I was making reasonable progress but then I decided to
ignore the numbers and just fix the colours. Once I stopped worrying
about the numbers I fixed all the colours pretty quickly. I was quite
proud of myself because it's been a long time since I've figured out
a new puzzle by myself. :) After accomplishing the colours I started
positioning and orienting the numbers on the colours. I've done 5 of
the 6 faces. I'm almost there! I was so excited to get this far so
quickly that I had to write a post. :)

Does anyone else have this puzzle?

Jasmine.

1732. Progress
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2002 14:21:13 -0000

I've made some progress this past month. I've improved my average
now from a 40 or 44 down to 37. It does feal good reducing that
number. Now I'll have to try and go for under 35 :)

Anyone else making any progress?
Jake



1733. Re: Progress
From: gogozergus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2002 15:12:45 -0000

1737. Cube Debut again
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 04:09:52 -0000

Just got back from my trip to New York, filming for MTV. It was
great! Everyone loved it, it was definitely a hit. Just before I
was to go on they had me sit kinda behind the camera and warm up
some, and I started drawing a huge crowd of all the backstage
people. It was crazy! They must have filmed me for like 1 1/2 or 2
hours straight just trying to get cool shots and interesting angles.
Unfortunately I couldn't use my cube because it was too beat up
looking from being worn down, but they let me grease up the cube they
had gotten for me so it worked out. Overall it was cool, they never
really timed me so I don't know how I was doing on time but I had a
few spots that were really well executed for being on a brand new
cube. They said that they'd send me the tape of it in about a month,
so I guess that means that sometime in about a month or so from now
they'll start airing it (they sounded like they were pretty sure they
were going to air it). So anyway I can't talk long, I have a paper
due tomorrow at 9:00am (the joys of college heh heh). But anyway it
was awesome and I think they really liked it a lot.

Chris



1738. Plastics
From: cubacca1972 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 04:48:20 -0000

Hi All

I recently picked up some Studio cubes, and have been working on
making them into speed cubes.

I tried using silicone spray as a lubricant, and found that it causes
the plastic in the cube to erode (I can gouge it with a fingernail).

So the studio cubes seem to be made out of a different type of
plastic than used in my oddzon cubes, which tolerate the same spray
very well.

Has this happened to anyone else who uses studio cubes?

Lucas

1740. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cube Debut again
From: "Justin Vining" <viningjc@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 11:24:33 -0500

Hey Odair, I'm not Chris, but I only use new cubes not lubed right out of the box. It only takes about 10 minutes for me to prepare them and after that they are ready to go. All i do is use silicone spray, work it into the cube until it feels good. I've found I like the feel of a new cube and I have very few cube pops. I hate that! Also by using new cubes, I've found a tremendous difference just between new oddzon cubes. Sometimes it doesn't matter what you do to a new cube it's not going to be a speed cube. I usually just teach someone how to solve the cube and sell the "bad" cubes to them and keep the best for myself.
Anyways I hope this helps,

Happy Cubing,
justin vining
http://icdweb.cc.purdue.edu/~viningjc/cube

1743. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cube Debut again
From: "Jessica Fridrich" <jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 18:30:57 -0000

Just my 2c: I always used to lube the cube by removing an edge and two corners and spraying a silicon oil in, putting the edge and the corner back and then twisting to spread the oil evenly between the cubies. However, in doing so, the cube became VERY _sticky_ and was worse than before lubing. To avoid this, in my experience, it is very important when you lube your cube to take it completely apart, spread the cubies on a flat surface and then spray the cubies with the spray. Now, this is very important: Do not assemble the pieces immediately but wait a while. The volatile ingredient of the oil will evaporate and then the surfaces will become almost dry, but greasy - this is what you want. (It is probably this volatile ingredient that causes the stickiness and it stays inside the cube for quite a long time before it also evaporates) When you assemble the cube, it will twist PERFECT even though it was stiff before. If you do not loosen the screws, the cube may in one day or so become to hard to twist again, so you will need to lube again and/or loosen the screws. Happy cubing! Jessica > What "magic silicone spray" is this one you are using that takes you just 10 minutes to prepare your cube? > Odair > > Justin Vining <viningjc@p...> wrote: > Hey Odair, I'm not Chris, but I only use new cubes not lubed right out of the box. It only takes about 10 minutes for me to prepare them and after that they are ready to go. All i do is use silicone spray, work it into the cube until it feels good. I've found I like the feel of a new cube and I have very few cube pops. I hate that! Also by using new cubes, I've found a tremendous difference just between new oddzon cubes. Sometimes it doesn't matter what you do to a new cube it's not going to be a speed cube. I usually just teach someone how to solve the cube and sell the "bad" cubes to them and keep the best for myself. > Anyways I hope this helps, > > Happy Cubing
1744. Re: [Speed cubing group] Plastics
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 19:49:34 +0000

> Just my 2c: I always used to lube the cube by removing an edge and
> two corners and spraying a silicon oil in, putting the edge and the
> corner back and then twisting to spread the oil evenly between the
> cubies. However, in doing so, the cube became VERY _sticky_ and was
> worse than before lubing. To avoid this, in my experience, it is very
> important when you lube your cube to take it completely apart, spread
> the cubies on a flat surface and then spray the cubies with the
> spray. Now, this is very important: Do not assemble the pieces
> immediately but wait a while. The volatile ingredient of the oil will
> evaporate and then the surfaces will become almost dry, but greasy -
> this is what you want. (It is probably this volatile ingredient that
> causes the stickiness and it stays inside the cube for quite a long
> time before it also evaporates) When you assemble the cube, it will
> twist PERFECT even though it was stiff before. If you do not loosen
> the screws, the cube may in one day or so become to hard to twist
> again, so you will need to lube again and/or loosen the screws.
>
> Happy cubing!
>
> Jessica

I want to put my two pence in too :]

I wonder if it's the volatile ingredient that makes the silicone
'sprayable' (not a real word apparently!). I have also used the lube
from rubiks.com which is silicone these days (used to be wax). The new
formula also makes for a sticky cube! It's runny and comes in an easy
to apply syringe. I think this might also have a volatile ingredient
to make it runny.

IMHO, the silicone I use is way better. It's not runny and not
sprayable, but it is easy to put in a syringe for clean application. I
bought this pot of silicone from a plumbing shop. It's VERY thick
indeed! Turn the pot upside-down for a day and it will not shift! I'm
guessing this stuff has no volatile ingredients.

"For lubricating pipe and fittings, spigots and ring seals on plastic
push-fit waste, soil and underground drainage systems"

If you use a syringe the cube can be used straight away with no mess!
If you use a little too much, it doesn't matter, it just collects in
any cavity inside the cube. If you use WAY too much, it will ooze out
for a while :]

Even though it's very thick, it is super slippery and will make for a
very fast cube.

I hope I helped!



1745. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cube Debut again
From: "mylib_2000" <mylib_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 02:31:28 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Jessica Fridrich" <jess340@h...> wrote: I have had only mediocre results with the silicone spray. I use Vaseline and it works great at lasts a long time ! Just my 2c: I always used to lube the cube by removing an edge and > two corners and spraying a silicon oil in, putting the edge and the > corner back and then twisting to spread the oil evenly between the > cubies. However, in doing so, the cube became VERY _sticky_ and was > worse than before lubing. To avoid this, in my experience, it is very > important when you lube your cube to take it completely apart, spread > the cubies on a flat surface and then spray the cubies with the > spray. Now, this is very important: Do not assemble the pieces > immediately but wait a while. The volatile ingredient of the oil will > evaporate and then the surfaces will become almost dry, but greasy - > this is what you want. (It is probably this volatile ingredient that > causes the stickiness and it stays inside the cube for quite a long > time before it also evaporates) When you assemble the cube, it will > twist PERFECT even though it was stiff before. If you do not loosen > the screws, the cube may in one day or so become to hard to twist > again, so you will need to lube again and/or loosen the screws. > > Happy cubing! > > Jessica > > > What "magic silicone spray" is this one you are using that takes > you just 10 minutes to prepare your cube? > > Odair > > > > Justin Vining <viningjc@p...> wrote: > > Hey Odair, I'm not Chris, but I only use new cubes not lubed right > out of the box. It only takes about 10 minutes for me to prepare them > and after that they are ready to go. All i do is use silicone spray, > work it into the cube until it feels good. I've found I like the feel > of a new cube and I have very few cube pops. I hate that! Also by > using new cubes, I've found a tremendous difference just between new > oddzon cubes. Sometimes it doesn't matter what you do to a new cube > it's not going to be a speed cube. I usually just teach someone how > to solve the cube and sell the "bad" cubes to them and keep the best > for myself. > > Anyways I hope this helps, > > > > Happy Cubing

eventually get under a minute.... i was also wondering where the hell

1749. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cube Debut again
From: gogozergus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 09:31:52 -0000

It works!!!!!!! I did one of my best times yesterday (21 secs) and I have it on video (DivX5 codec). http://grrroux.free.fr It doesn't have sound. Anyway, my cube's almost silent and I like it this way (smooth edges and good lube). --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Jessica Fridrich" <jess340@h...> wrote: > Just my 2c: I always used to lube the cube by removing an edge and > two corners and spraying a silicon oil in, putting the edge and the > corner back and then twisting to spread the oil evenly between the > cubies. However, in doing so, the cube became VERY _sticky_ and was > worse than before lubing. To avoid this, in my experience, it is very > important when you lube your cube to take it completely apart, spread > the cubies on a flat surface and then spray the cubies with the > spray. Now, this is very important: Do not assemble the pieces > immediately but wait a while. The volatile ingredient of the oil will > evaporate and then the surfaces will become almost dry, but greasy - > this is what you want. (It is probably this volatile ingredient that > causes the stickiness and it stays inside the cube for quite a long > time before it also evaporates) When you assemble the cube, it will > twist PERFECT even though it was stiff before. If you do not loosen > the screws, the cube may in one day or so become to hard to twist > again, so you will need to lube again and/or loosen the screws. > > Happy cubing! > > Jessica >
1750. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cube Debut again

erode plastics, right?




1751. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cube Debut again
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 15:29:48 -0000

Okay, my two cents...

I used to use vaseline. I thought then that it was wonderful.
There are two main problems I had with it, though (which I don't
have with a silicon spray):
1) It didn't last. It was only good for a week or two. After
that, it really sludged up, and it was worse than unlubed until
I completely cleaned it out and relubed. A good silicon lube
can last me a couple months (I don't cube as much as others, I'm
sure).
2) It was a mess! Whenever I popped a piece (and this happened
frequently, with my very loose cube), I had a plastic/vaseline
mixture mess to clean up. I had to wipe down the cube and wash
my hands before I could get back to cubing. With the silicon, I
just pop the piece back in and get back to cubing.

If you still want to try the vaseline ('cuz you can't find any
silicon), just put some vaseline on the end of a Q-Tip and apply
it to each screw (where the center pieces connect to the middle
of the puzzle). Then also apply some to the back of one or more
of the center pieces (enough to spread around inside the cube),
reassemble the cube, and use it for a while to spread the
vaseline around.

Good luck!

> > > I have had only mediocre results with the silicone spray.
> > > I use Vaseline and it works great at lasts a long time !
> > vaseline works? how to you apply it.. do tell! cause i have
> > some of that junk... just cant find the silicon...
> You gotta be concerned about the petroleum in Vaseline. It's
> supposed to erode plastics, right?



1752. Re: Cube Debut again
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 17:33:58 -0000

Beware of vaseline!!! It'll turn the inside to mush!!!

I picked up a cube at an antique store. I'm guessing the thing was
sitting there at least 5 to 10 years. It turns very nice, but the
inside was filled with vaseline. I advise that you use vaseline for
awhile, clean it out, and use silicone. The vaseline will erode
making a smoother surface, then when you apply the silicone, it gets
better. But don't mix the silicon and vaseline together, thats bad!!!

1755. Re: [Speed cubing group] its me again

I have never been to a Walmart that doesn't have silicone and if your Walmart doesn't have it try K-mart or Target. All of these stores will have it. Also your cube from toys r' us should be ok to speed cube with as long as its Rubik's brand, just lube it up and it should be good. Also you don't need finger shortcuts to break a minute with the layer method.

1758. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cube Debut again
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 00:11:30 -0000

I use Black Magic Professional Protectant. It's a car dashboard polish/cleaner. It has a picture of a car dashboard on the bottom of the bottle. Anyway this stuff is amazing. I take a new cube, take it completely apart and lube each piece. Then I let the pieces sit for 10 minutes or so and then I put the cube back together. Afterward the cube turns very well, except that a new cube still won't cut corners. I had the problem of getting stuck every now and then on Monday because I was triggering this new cube like a cube that cuts corners (which fails miserably by the way heh heh). Anyway the Black Magic stuff is great, it's the only stuff I use (it's a silicone base). The only way I know how to wear a cube down to where it cuts corners is to use it for a long time, never tried sanding but I hear it works if you do it right. My strategy is just to never throw your cube away. I have the same cube from 4 years ago when I first started. When it starts to pop pieces a LOT, around 2 years old or so, just stick with it and your hands will adjust to the looser cube and you won't pop pieces anymore. I have to go through adjustment periods every now and then, like if I use someone else's cube for a while, to get readjusted to my superloose cube or else I pop pieces pretty much every trial. It also works the other way, if I start using other people's cubes I try to cut corners too much and end up locking up the cube a lot. The only problem is you ONLY cube your best on YOUR cube. I don't know if it works better but I say don't throw the cube away until it's absolutely 100% dead and it will be a great speed cube. Then again I'm still not to sub-20 so maybe this plays a role? Just my two cents, Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Odair Brun <odabrun@y...> wrote: > > Congratulations Chris! > I just would know how do you grease your cube so nice in a short time to get a good time? > Thanks > Odair > cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote:Just got back from my trip to New York, filming for MTV. It was > great! Everyone loved it, it was definitely a hit. Just before I > was to go on they had me sit kinda behind the camera and warm up > some, and I started drawing a huge crowd of all the backstage > people. It was crazy! They must have filmed me for like 1 1/2 or 2 > hours straight just trying to get cool shots and interesting angles. > Unfortunately I couldn't use my cube because it was too beat up > looking from being worn down, but they let me grease up the cube they > had gotten for me so it worked out. Overall it was cool, they never > really timed me so I don't know how I was doing on time but I had a > few spots that were really well executed for being on a brand new > cube. They said that they'd send me the tape of it in about a month, > so I guess that means that sometime in about a month or so from now > they'll start airing it (they sounded like they were pretty sure they > were going to air it). So anyway I can't talk long, I have a paper > due tomorrow at 9:00am (the joys of college heh heh). But anyway it > was awesome and I think they really liked it a lot. > > Chris > > > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@y... > > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/ > > > > > --------------------------------- > Do you Yahoo!? > Yahoo! Web Hosting - Let the expert host your site > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

1766. taking the cube apart???
From: misleadyouth86 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 23:36:24 -0000

how do you do it without breaking it???




1767. Re: taking the cube apart???
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 23:43:53 -0000

First, let me say that if you have a cube without springs (e.g.
Meffert's assembly cube), this isn't the way to do it! Here's what I
wrote back in August (Post #1289):

Here's how I normally do it (no tools necessary, provided your
hands are strong enough/cube is loose enough):
1) rotate R so FR is directly next to UF
2) Put your right thumb on the F side of FR, pointing toward UF
(with the tip of your nail touching UF)
3) Put your left index finger on UFR and left thumb on DFR
4) Push your hands together (UF to the left with your right hand,
UFR and DFR right with your left hand), wedge your thumb in
between the two edges (UF and FR), and then use the leverage
to pull FR out.
5) After the one piece is out, the rest should come with no trouble.

I avoid using a screw driver or anything else hard, because I feel
like I'm scratching up the inside of my cube.


--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., misleadyouth86 wrote:
> how do you do it without breaking it???

1771. Re: im gonna go craZY!!
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 03:15:14 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., misleadyouth86 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > nothin i do makes the cube spin easily like i see on all the speed > cubing videos... nothing works! nothing! is it just my cube? do i > need to loosen it or something? ugh... im slowly going insane... It usually takes some time to break a cube in. Usually I get a new cube when i can tell that my current speed cube is going to need replacing soon (like a week or 2 in advance)....and I just let one of my friends mess with it for a few days, then I lube it with "prestone silicone lubricant".....and it will still need more breaking in, so i either let the friend have it for a little longer or i use it to cube sometimes. I have sanded the insides of a cube before, it worked ok. I didnt think it was any better than just breaking it in. I sanded the flat inside areas of the edge and corner pieces. Not on the mechanism that holds it all together. I just got a rubiks studio cube a couple weeks ago. It was REALLY stiff at first, even after i sprayed it with silicone. It just needed breaking in. Now it might just be the best cube i have ever had. ..........hope this helps... -Heath

cubing videos... nothing works! nothing! is it just my cube? do i
need to loosen it or something? ugh... im slowly going insane...

1774. Stretching your cube
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 13:44:26 -0000

Have you tried stretching your cube. This works only if your cube has springs in the skeleton, if it doesn't, it will snap the center s off. THis what you do, take plastic gift cards, credit cards, phone cards, etc. and wedge them inbetween the peices, This stretches the center upward and after a couple minutes it reduces the tension in the springs. Be careful though, this can make your cube pop if you do it too much!!! Also your corner problem, your gonna have to take your cube apart to fix it. Hope this helps jake --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Chad Smith" <chazzzle1@i...> wrote: > Snap Silicon Spray. Mostly white can with a blue cap on it. I got mine at Menards. > ----- Original Message ----- > From: misleadyouth86 > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@y... > Sent: Thursday, November 21, 2002 8:28 PM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] im gonna go craZY!! > > > nothin i do makes the cube spin easily like i see on all the speed > cubing videos... nothing works! nothing! is it just my cube? do i > need to loosen it or something? ugh... im slowly going insane... > > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@y... > > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1775. Lube idea + intro
From: "james.dale2" <james.dale2@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 14:30:06 -0000

Hello speed cubers.
I am not really a speed cuber yet, unless you call 3.30 fast :)
Anyway I have a real old cube that I thought was pretty useless,
but I lubed it up with baby oil, and it turns very nice now. Has
anybody else tried this?

JD

ingredients mostly.

Did anyone try graphites yet?

lucky cube.

original ones are too weak now. I can't find 2.5mm springs in stores.


Gilles.



1778. Making an F2L practice quiz...
From: kyubeman <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 22:21:31 -0000

I'm currently in the process of making an *advanced* f2l quiz for
practice. The idea, will be several hundred advanced cases of f2l,
all listed without pictures. It will be listed in the following
format:

1: F' U2 L' U' L2 F L' (8, FR)

Where, the first sequence of turns will set up the pattern to be
solved, and in parenthesis is the number of moves it should be able
to be solved in (as a guideline only, less or more doesn't really
matter, but the goal is efficiency), and after that is which corner
is to be solved. (in this case, the front right)

You COULD reverse the set up sequence to solve, but I would advise
that you don't look at it, and try to figure out alternatives. For
example, I would solve the above situation with a different alg:

(U)R U2 R2 D' F' D R

Hopefully this quiz will help me and others out with tricky
situations and seeing better on the f2l. I'm currently doing shows
of the play Cyrano de Bergerac, in which I am a lead for perfomance
this weekend. After the show nights are over, I will begin creating
it. I mention to everyone, because I want to ultimately have as many
cases as possible. The goal will be to get all the way through
without missing one! If anyone would like to discuss, email at
cybeross@..., or come to chat this weekend in the mornings! Let
me know what you think, especially those cubers nearing/under sub 20!

-Ross

lubricant called "#747 silicon lubricant" but its not in stores...
its by bulk for a large company... so i was wondering if california
just doesnt have god damn silicon... ... im going to check target
tonight just incase... but im sure they wont have it either.... if
you have any ideas hook me up

Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 01:43:21 -0800

I'm in San Francisco, and you can find this stuff in any Kragens or Pep Boys. I've found it in every automotive store I've looked for it in. OK, that's just 5 or so stores over the years, but the stuff is not hard to find if you know where to find it. Usually on or near the shelf with the wax and various shinyfiers. 1785. 62.50 moves per second
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 13:35:39 -0000


Just posted a time on oinkleburger for the 1x1x1 cube (which they
now have!) of 0.016 seconds at a turn rate of 62.50 moves per
second. It's possible to solve it in 0 turns sometimes and 1 turn
other times. I don't know what the decision process is.

1794. Mefferts "Xmas Special"...
From: "papegoja99" <webmaster@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 07:17:13 -0000

Hi everyone!
I guess some of you guys and gals also got the mefferts Xmas special.
Has I´ve been planing on ordering a 5x5x5 cube this seems like a good
deal.
But they seem small.... (it says "6cm x 6cm x 6cm" or 2,36 inch for
you yanks)
My Rubik´s 4x4x4 is 6,5cm (2,55 inch).
Has anyone used a Mefferts 5x5x5 cube that is only 6cm? The cubies
must be realy small. Won´t they break?
Is it worth it?
/Papegoja




1795. Re: Mefferts "Xmas Special"...
From: gogozergus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 07:36:05 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "papegoja99" <webmaster@p...> wrote: > Hi everyone! > I guess some of you guys and gals also got the mefferts Xmas special. > Has I´ve been planing on ordering a 5x5x5 cube this seems like a good > deal. > But they seem small.... (it says "6cm x 6cm x 6cm" or 2,36 inch for > you yanks) > My Rubik´s 4x4x4 is 6,5cm (2,55 inch). > Has anyone used a Mefferts 5x5x5 cube that is only 6cm? The cubies > must be realy small. Won´t they break? > Is it worth it? > /Papegoja Mine is (was) 7cm. It died after 3 hours. The plastic stickers were too thick.
1796. Re: [Speed cubing group] Mefferts "Xmas Special"...
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 10:09:04 +0000

> Hi everyone!
> I guess some of you guys and gals also got the mefferts Xmas special.
> Has I´ve been planing on ordering a 5x5x5 cube this seems like a good
> deal.
> But they seem small.... (it says "6cm x 6cm x 6cm" or 2,36 inch for
> you yanks)
> My Rubik´s 4x4x4 is 6,5cm (2,55 inch).
> Has anyone used a Mefferts 5x5x5 cube that is only 6cm? The cubies
> must be realy small. Won´t they break?
> Is it worth it?
> /Papegoja
>

I have all three of the cubes in that special, I can tell you everything I
know about them. They turn very smoothly and easily, but there is not much
give. This means that you have to meticulously make sure everything is
straight before turning another side. If all is not straight, then it
totally locks up. I'm not much of a speed cuber on the big cubes, but they
still add maybe 15% to my times because they are not forgiving enough.

They are built from hollow parts, if you know what I mean. When you turn
some sides 45 degrees, you can see into some of the cubies. They are white
opposite yellow and there is a purple instead of orange.

I have not tried to lube them, so perhaps I would get more luck from them
that way. I think they are very well built, and I've never worried that
I'll break them. I think that some of you guys demand more from your cubes
though! I've never broken the centres of a normal 4x4x4 yet!

It's interesting that mefferts say they can be disassembled, I've never
tried this!

My advice is, if you want a neat looking cube for your collection, this is
very neat! But if you want to speed cube, it's probably not the one. If
you get it and lube it, then post your results so I know whether to bother.



1797. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Mefferts "Xmas Special"...
From: Tyler Robbins <sum1else@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 06:35:19 -0500

This mini cube has been selling on ebay, it is not made by Meffert. It will NOT fall apart like mefferts does, but, it is very small, and not for speedcubing. If you want a cube to play with it, get it. Same for the 4x4. The 2x2 is actually Bigger than a normal 2x2x2, it is nice. The stickers arent that great on these, But the puzzle is better, and it is worth it. Tyler Robbins <http://www.thepuzzlestore.com/> http://www.thepuzzlestore.com Specializing in Custom Sequential Movement Puzzles Ebay ID: Sum1ese -----Original Message----- From: gogozergus [mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com] Sent: Monday, November 25, 2002 2:36 AM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Mefferts "Xmas Special"... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "papegoja99" <webmaster@p...> wrote: > Hi everyone! > I guess some of you guys and gals also got the mefferts Xmas special. > Has I´ve been planing on ordering a 5x5x5 cube this seems like a good > deal. > But they seem small.... (it says "6cm x 6cm x 6cm" or 2,36 inch for > you yanks) > My Rubik´s 4x4x4 is 6,5cm (2,55 inch). > Has anyone used a Mefferts 5x5x5 cube that is only 6cm? The cubies > must be realy small. Won´t they break? > Is it worth it? > /Papegoja Mine is (was) 7cm. It died after 3 hours. The plastic stickers were too thick. I'm not much of a speed cuber on the big cubes, but > they > still add maybe 15% to my times because they are not forgiving enough. > > They are built from hollow parts, if you know what I mean. When you > turn > some sides 45 degrees, you can see into some of the cubies. They are > white > opposite yellow and there is a purple instead of orange. > > I have not tried to lube them, so perhaps I would get more luck from > them > that way. I think they are very well built, and I've never worried that > I'll break them. I think that some of you guys demand more from your > cubes > though! I've never broken the centres of a normal 4x4x4 yet! > > It's interesting that mefferts say they can be disassembled, I've never > tried this! > > My advice is, if you want a neat looking cube for your collection, this > is > very neat! But if you want to speed cube, it's probably not the one. > If > you get it and lube it, then post your results so I know whether to > bother. > > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@y... > > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! > <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/> Terms of Service. > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Tyler Robbins <http://www.thepuzzlestore.com/> http://www.thepuzzlestore.com Specializing in Custom Sequential Movement Puzzles Ebay ID: Sum1ese -----Original Message----- From: jasmine_ellen [mailto:no_reply@yahoogroups.com] Sent: Monday, November 25, 2002 6:50 AM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Mefferts "Xmas Special"... I gather a lot of people here have bought online from Mefferts so I assume they are pretty reputable, but I was wondering how long it takes. They say free airmail postage which is pretty good, but I'm in Australia. I didn't see anything on their site about how long it will take. Anyone else buying online from overseas? Jasmine. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Tyler Robbins <sum1else@o...> wrote: > Oh yes, > Don't disassemble the 4x4x4 it's a completely different mechanism and > you need 3 hands to put it back together. > Have fun with the 5x5 :-) > > I don't know why he says they can be disassembled. > His can be too > > > Tyler Robbins > <http://www.thepuzzlestore.com/> http://www.thepuzzlestore.com > Specializing in Custom Sequential Movement Puzzles > Ebay ID: Sum1ese > > -----Original Message----- > From: Robert Roue [mailto:r.roue@b...] > Sent: Monday, November 25, 2002 5:09 AM > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@y... > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Mefferts "Xmas Special"... > > > Hi everyone! > > I guess some of you guys and gals also got the mefferts Xmas special. > > Has I´ve been planing on ordering a 5x5x5 cube this seems like a good > > deal. > > But they seem small.... (it says "6cm x 6cm x 6cm" or 2,36 inch for > > you yanks) > > My Rubik´s 4x4x4 is 6,5cm (2,55 inch). > > Has anyone used a Mefferts 5x5x5 cube that is only 6cm? The cubies > > must be realy small. Won´t they break? > > Is it worth it? > > /Papegoja > > > > I have all three of the cubes in that special, I can tell you everything > I > know about them. They turn very smoothly and easily, but there is not > much > give. This means that you have to meticulously make sure everything is > straight before turning another side. If all is not straight, then it > totally locks up. I'm not much of a speed cuber on the big cubes, but > they > still add maybe 15% to my times because they are not forgiving enough. > > They are built from hollow parts, if you know what I mean. When you > turn > some sides 45 degrees, you can see into some of the cubies. They are > white > opposite yellow and there is a purple instead of orange. > > I have not tried to lube them, so perhaps I would get more luck from > them > that way. I think they are very well built, and I've never worried that > I'll break them. I think that some of you guys demand more from your > cubes > though! I've never broken the centres of a normal 4x4x4 yet! > > It's interesting that mefferts say they can be disassembled, I've never > tried this! > > My advice is, if you want a neat looking cube for your collection, this > is > very neat! 1802. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Mefferts "Xmas Special"...
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 12:39:12 +0000

> The Xmas Special looks good, especially since I don't yet have a
> 4x4x4 or a 5x5x5. I might get a pyraminx while I'm at it. I gather a
> lot of people here have bought online from Mefferts so I assume they
> are pretty reputable, but I was wondering how long it takes. They say
> free airmail postage which is pretty good, but I'm in Australia. I
> didn't see anything on their site about how long it will take. Anyone
> else buying online from overseas?
>
> Jasmine.
>

Well, yes they are reputable, but I don't think they are renowned for their
'quality'. The thing is, these Christmas special cubes are not actually
Mefferts. They are far better than any Mefferts cube I've tried, even if
they are no good for speed cubing.

Speaking of my experience with Mefferts brand cubes. My professor cube kept
pinging a centre cap off, which I had to file so it didn't catch anymore.
My puzzle ball keyring un-screwed itself 5 minutes after I got it, and I had
trouble getting it back together. My Skewb keyring started to do the same
thing, but I rescued it before it came apart. My Pyraminx lost 10 tiles
immediately. My Skewb Ultimate had springs and ball bearings loose inside
it. Oh, and the stickers kept sliding off my megaminx.

Having said that, my full size Skewb is excellent, as is my Skewb Diamond.
And as I say, the Christmas special isn't actually Mefferts made anyway.

Everything from Mefferts is actually sent from Hong Kong. If you have a
problem with anything that they send you, just pester them by email. They
sent me a Skewb Ultimate replacement and didn't ask for the broken one back.



1803. [Speed cubing group] Re: Mefferts "Xmas Special"...

1804. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Mefferts "Xmas Special"...
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 13:29:21 +0000

> Sounds like you don't have a vary high opinion of Mefferts brand
> products!
>
> I wasn't after these puzzles for speedcubing (gotta work out how to
> solve them first!!), I was just hoping that they'd be decent quality
> for regular use.
>
> Jasmine.
>

Well, I don't have a high or a low opinion of them. I think they should get
their act together with their quality control.

As for the Christmas Special, I think you should go for it, it's a lovely
collection. They're quite odd to look at because the stickers are so...
perfect! I think they're made really well and Mefferts have a lot to learn
from the guys who make these.

1807. Return of defect cubes...
From: "papegoja99" <webmaster@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 14:29:01 -0000

Any one ever tried to return a defect/broken cube to Rubik´s?
I bought a Rubik´s Revenge online from Hessport. It broke yesterday!
Only used it for about 2 hours total. And it was realy smooth, so I
never applied any extra force.
One of the middle/face cubies broke. So wonder if you take a look at
how little plastic is keeping it in place!
Any how... has anyone ever tried to get a cube replaced by
Rubik´s/Hessport?

/Papegoja

1809. Re: [Speed cubing group] (unknown)
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 16:24:02 +0000

I think it is a fantastic record, Richard. Congratulations! It seems you can now complete your cubing marathon by starting with 5x5x5, moving to the 4x4x4, 3x3x3, 2x2x2 *and then* finish with the much more pleasing, logically satisfying finale of a 1x1x1. But why stop there? Continuing to a 0x0x0 should not be discounted, and in the same spirit we are then propelled into the intriguing world of "negative cubing": cubes such as -1x-1x-1, -2x-2x-2 ... But back to the 1x1x1: the record seems to be 0.032 seconds, but this is using a computer interface. I wonder if I could do better with the real thing, a timer, and some really good lube. Does anyone know where you can buy a 1x1x1?? Any suggestions appreciated. I am thinking of using a "corner-first" method. :-) S. >From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >Subject: [Speed cubing group] (unknown) >Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 19:03:35 -0000 > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., misleadyouth86 <no_reply@y...> >wrote: > > how dumb... the 1x1x1? thats like solving a puzzle with only one > > piece left to put in... haha... how pointless > >Not so pointless. It's still possible to compete on it. My time has >been beaten now so there is competition. > >Besides, it's a good contrast to doing a 20x20x20. : ) > _________________________________________________________________ STOP MORE SPAM with the new MSN 8 and get 2 months FREE* http://join.msn.com/?page=features/junkmail
1810. Re: [Speed cubing group] (unknown)
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 16:45:33 +0000

> But back to the 1x1x1: the record seems to be 0.032 seconds, but this is
> using a computer interface. I wonder if I could do better with the real
> thing, a timer, and some really good lube. Does anyone know where you can
> buy a 1x1x1?? Any suggestions appreciated.
>

I made my own 1x1x1 using only the parts from a standard 3x3x3. Trust me,
it can be done with only one donor cube! I'll sell you mine if the price is
right. Or if you want me to do a construction instruction sheet, then give
me a while to make one and get it proof read.

According to my calculations, a 0x0x0 or lower is not possible because the
corners intrude on the territory of the centres. If someone has any ideas
on a different shape or something, then that would be helpful.

1812. Re: [Speed cubing group] Return of defect cubes...
From: "aWAKEn" <a_wake_n@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 12:15:22 -0500

I had the same problem with a 4X4 from Hessport last month, although in my case, the white logo center piece was broken before I even opened the package. I think that they may be getting broken or cracked during assembly. At any rate, I spoke with Patrick Hess and had a new one in the mail the day after my package arrived. (they would not cover my shippnig however.) Also, if you guys look around on Rubiks.com, there is a note on one of the pages stating that the 4x4 is "not for speedcubing" and that it will break easy, almost sounds like a disclaimer.

1813. Re: 62.50 moves per second
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 17:47:22 -0000

At first, I thought this looked kinda pointless, but I thought
I'd give the 1x1x1 a go. I succeeded in solving it in .010
seconds at 100 turns per second (check out
http://www.oinkleburger.com/Cube/Net/turnlists/index.cgi and
look for me at Tue Nov 26 9:37:29 2002). I tried a few more
times to get that again but couldn't. I think with that, I'm
done trying! I don't think I'll be able to improve on that!

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., GameOfDeath2 wrote:
>
> Just posted a time on oinkleburger for the 1x1x1 cube (which they
> now have!) of 0.016 seconds at a turn rate of 62.50 moves per
> second. It's possible to solve it in 0 turns sometimes and 1 turn
> other times. I don't know what the decision process is.




1814. Dropped a sec with new cube
From: "david_cubemaster" <davidwesley@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 18:08:28 -0000

My new Rubik's studio cube works great! Now I really understand why
all the cubes on those videos sound so smooth. After lubricating it,
I made a new record almost a whole second lower than my earlier. My
avg is now at 22.33(before 23.1), and I think I might be able to
improve even more because of the uneven times. Keep practising,
it'll give result! David Wesley

1816. Re: [Speed cubing group] (unknown)
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 18:16:32 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "simonl cube" <simonlcube@h...> wrote: > I think it is a fantastic record, Richard. Congratulations! It seems you > can now complete your cubing marathon by starting with 5x5x5, moving to the > 4x4x4, 3x3x3, 2x2x2 *and then* finish with the much more pleasing, > logically satisfying finale of a 1x1x1. But why stop there? Continuing to a > 0x0x0 should not be discounted, and in the same spirit we are then propelled > into the intriguing world of "negative cubing": cubes such as -1x- 1x-1, > -2x-2x-2 ... > > But back to the 1x1x1: the record seems to be 0.032 seconds, but this is > using a computer interface. I wonder if I could do better with the real > thing, a timer, and some really good lube. Does anyone know where you can > buy a 1x1x1?? Any suggestions appreciated. > > I am thinking of using a "corner-first" method. > > :-) > I use corners last myself. > S. > > >From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> > >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@y... > >To: speedsolvingrubikscube@y... > >Subject: [Speed cubing group] (unknown) > >Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 19:03:35 -0000 > > > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., misleadyouth86 <no_reply@y...> > >wrote: > > > how dumb... the 1x1x1? thats like solving a puzzle with only one > > > piece left to put in... haha... how pointless > > > >Not so pointless. It's still possible to compete on it. My time has > >been beaten now so there is competition. > > > >Besides, it's a good contrast to doing a 20x20x20. : ) > > > > > _________________________________________________________________ > STOP MORE SPAM with the new MSN 8 and get 2 months FREE* > http://join.msn.com/?page=features/junkmail
1817. Re: (unknown)
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 18:20:30 -0000


> No, I've had 0.015 recorded and Ron has had 0.010 seconds. I've
also
> had 0 seconds on 1 turn but it doesn't record the time. : (
>

http://www.oinkleburger.com/Cube/Net/index.cgi?
order=1&time=0&turns=1&starttime=1038334722881&name=Dr.+C&hash=c4bb4f
58daf65ed6f5428cdb4bf56468

You get stuff like this coming up after you solve it in 0, but they
don't get recorded. I've had it several times but haven't had a
positive time under 0.015 seconds yet.

I was never very quick on the smaller cubes though.

1820. Studio Cube worth it?

Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 16:33:07 -0500

I have a lubed .com cube, which works great, except it could stand to be a little looser.

1821. Re: Studio Cube worth it?
From: cubacca1972 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 2002 00:25:21 -0000

I Recently picked up some studio cubes, and have had problems with lubing them. I use Wynn's Slick'nShine multi use silicone lubricant on my oddzon cubes with excellent results. When I use the same product on my studio cubes, the plastic errodes to the point where the cube sheds a black, powdery residue. The plastic gets soft, so that I can scratch it with my fingernail. Do you find that the plastic quality is OK with your cube? Lucas --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "aWAKEn" <a_wake_n@h...> wrote: > Anyone out there using a studio cube? What do you think of them in comparison to the new cubes? > I have a lubed .com cube, which works great, except it could stand to be a little looser. > > aWAKEn > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1822. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Studio Cube worth it?
From: "aWAKEn" <a_wake_n@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 19:37:21 -0500

My cube hasn't had any problems yet. I am using Prestone silicone lubricant spray. Maybe the slick n' shine stuff contains some kind of petroleum or other ingredient that is eating away at the inside of the older plastic parts. I have not used a studio cube yet, so I don't know if your situation is normal. aWAKEn ----- Original Message ----- From: cubacca1972 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Tuesday, November 26, 2002 7:25 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Studio Cube worth it? Do you find that the plastic quality is OK with your cube? Lucas --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "aWAKEn" <a_wake_n@h...> wrote: > Anyone out there using a studio cube?
