1826. i have been having problem with the red and orange color, they look soooo simila
From: "manolo" <yoamomicubo@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 2002 14:14:15 -0000

Hi everyone, have not been posted these days, busy life i guess...
anyway, i just got 3 studios cube and i think they are very good,
execpt for some of the colors,, yes i have been having problem with
the (red) and (orange) colors they just seem so alike, i hope that i
guess used to them soon because i just got them as i said...
this very morning i was cubing a bit and i happen a lot that i
placed the orange color instead of the red color, because of the
similarities..
But other then that, it is very smooth and with the silicon base it
is even smoother of course.
I apply the silicon, the way jessica told me, you have to remove all
the cubies and spray them, and very important, you have to let them
Dry totally before you asamble them back, if you do not do it that
way it will get stffer..

happy cubing everyone and have a happy thanksgiving everyone living
in usa, and for the rest of the guys out there have a great day..--

Manolo T.





1827. Re: i have been having problem with the red and orange color, they look soooo simila
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 2002 18:52:12 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "manolo" <yoamomicubo@y...> wrote: > Hi everyone, have not been posted these days, busy life i guess... > anyway, i just got 3 studios cube and i think they are very good, > execpt for some of the colors,, yes i have been having problem with > the (red) and (orange) colors they just seem so alike, i hope that i > guess used to them soon because i just got them as i said... > this very morning i was cubing a bit and i happen a lot that i > placed the orange color instead of the red color, because of the > similarities.. > But other then that, it is very smooth and with the silicon base it > is even smoother of course. > I apply the silicon, the way jessica told me, you have to remove all > the cubies and spray them, and very important, you have to let them > Dry totally before you asamble them back, if you do not do it that > way it will get stffer.. > > happy cubing everyone and have a happy thanksgiving everyone living > in usa, and for the rest of the guys out there have a great day..-- > > Manolo T. I had the very same problem with my studio cube. The red and orange are almost the same color. Heres what I did.... I had an old 80's cube (ideal toys brand) laying around that i had used for speedcubing awhile back but it got REALLY loose and no good for cubing anymore :(....the stickers are still in great shape on it, so I stole the stickers off of the 80s cube and put them on the Studio cube. I really like the orange color of the 80s cube because it is really bright. So i dont have a problem with getting confused between red and orange :) hope this helps

1833. Re: [Speed cubing group] What's all this cube brand talk?

1834. Re: what is good for replacing stickers?
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 05:09:16 -0000

Some people here have had good luck with nail polish. Good luck
finding good colors, though.

My wife and I went to the store, and Wet 'n' Wild makes a good
red, green, white, and yellow (color numbers 414, 416A, 449B and
423B respectively), although I haven't actually painted my cube
yet - they look good in the bottles, though. The green is
actually a metallic green. For the blue, I turned to L'oreal
Paris, Jet-set quick dry nail enamel, color #235 (orbit). My
orange is "Super Top Speed" Revlon, color #260 (Swoop). Just
make sure you do a few coats, let it dry completely (can take
quite a while), and put on a top coat or two with "hard as
nails" to reduce denting.

In my opinion, it looks a lot better than stickers (I did paint
some on an old cube) and seems much more durable, but it takes
a lot of time to do.

Hope this helps.

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., misleadyouth86 wrote:
> i heard about electric tape... but any other ideas?
> regards,
> casen

1836. Re: [Speed cubing group] what is good for replacing stickers?
From: Kåre Krig <karkr936@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 07:01:41 +0100

----- Original Message ----- From: misleadyouth86 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> Date: Thursday, November 28, 2002 0:31 am Subject: [Speed cubing group] what is good for replacing stickers? > i heard about electric tape... but any other ideas? just wondering > > > regards, > > casen > I have used electric tape when I rebuilt a ordinary cube to a bandaged cube. If I dident I would not be able to tell what subcubes are glued together. It works ok but the corners of the tape dont stick onto the cube that good when I'm using it. Mabye this would work better if I had rounded the corners when I was cutting the tape. Also, it was impossible to find orange tape so I had to use black. Black tape is a bad idea because usually each sticker is a color surrounded by black. Takes some time to get used to. So if you can get all six colors in nail polish I would suggest you use that. Unless nail polish is far more expencive, I have no idea about prices for it. /Kï¿½re ps. Still havent solved that bandaged cube.
1837. Re: what is good for replacing stickers?
From: gogozergus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 09:10:23 -0000

The best solution I've found and the less expensive too: Plastic separators (I don't know if it's the right word - "intercalaire" in french). $1 for 6 sheets of different colors, enough for many many cubes. Use Neoprene glue. It lasts for years, never gets damaged, you can wash it (or cube under water), etc. Take a look at the cube in my hands on the video: http://grrroux.free.fr (too dark, sorry) Hope this helps, Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., misleadyouth86 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > i heard about electric tape... but any other ideas? just wondering > > > regards, > > casen
1838. Re: [Speed cubing group] what is good for replacing stickers?
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 09:15:05 +0000

Hi Casen: welcome to the group, BTW.

Yes. You can get replacement stickers from rubiks.com. Strangely, the
replacement stickers are much much better than the stickers they use on
their cubes! (Bizarre or what?) I have not actually ordered stickers
myself because someone from this group was kind enough to send me a set,
gratis (Thanks Robert!). The result is *excellent*: each colour comes in a
set of nine that you can put onto a face in one go. The original stickers
lasted about 6 weeks, but I put a replacement set on about 5 months ago and
they are pretty much the same now as they were when I first applied them.
The colours are really good, in my opinion.

So, try the stickers from rubiks.com. For $4.99 you get three sets, which
should last for years.

http://www.rubikshop.com/cgi-bin/shop.cgi/SID=1038474108.9550.r/num=stkcls

Good luck with your cubing: keep us posted on your progress!

S.

>
>i heard about electric tape... but any other ideas? just wondering

http://join.msn.com/?page=features/virus

> should last for years.
>
> http://www.rubikshop.com/cgi-bin/shop.cgi/SID=1038474108.9550.r/num=stkcls
>
> Good luck with your cubing: keep us posted on your progress!
>
> S.
>

I've not been following this thread, I'm afraid. If someone is stuck for
replacement stickers, I still have a set that I can send. If you want them,
send me your address and I'll post them. I don't mind posting these
anywhere in the world for free if someone will use them.

Just to let you know though, the only ones I have left are holographic!
They are all the correct colours, except where white will be silvery. There
are six sheets, one for each face. They are pre arranged with the correct
spacing so you literally just slap them on all in one go! I'm not sure how
good holographic is for speed cubing, especially if the light is not right.

I think I also have a set for the Revenge. I'm not at home to check, but if
I do have a set then they are plain (not holographic) and if someone wants
them, let me know. I used a set of these on my own Revenge and they do fray
a little but so far they have stayed put and not lost any laminate. The red
is a bit similar to the orange too.



1840. Re: [Speed cubing group] what is good for replacing stickers?
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 12:28:45 -0000

> Just to let you know though, the only ones I have left are
holographic!
> They are all the correct colours, except where white will be
silvery. There
> are six sheets, one for each face. They are pre arranged with the
correct
> spacing so you literally just slap them on all in one go! I'm not
sure how
> good holographic is for speed cubing, especially if the light is
not right.

I have a cube with holographic stickers. It looked so cool that I had
to buy it, more just as a collectible rather than a speed cube
though. I found that the pale colours (eg. yellow and silver) were
different to distinguish quickly so I never used it as a speed cube.
Other reason was that the particular was way too loose.

My holographic cube has pink instead of orange. I'm curious, what
colours are your holographic stickers?

Jasmine.

1847. Re: [Speed cubing group] what is good for replacing stickers?
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 17:17:04 -0000

The Wet 'n' Wild nail polish is cheapest - under $1 per bottle
for a .5 oz (14 mL) bottle. I haven't actually gone through much
yet since I haven't worn my stickers down yet), but I would guess
that each bottle is good for at least 3-4 cubes, if not more. The
other two that I got (for green and orange) were as much as $2 - $3
per bottle.

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Kåre Krig wrote:
> So if you can get all six colors in nail polish I would suggest
> you use that. Unless nail polish is far more expencive, I have
> no idea about prices for it.

aWAKEn
----- Original Message -----
From: simonl cube
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, November 28, 2002 4:15 AM
Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] what is good for replacing stickers?


Hi Casen: welcome to the group, BTW.

Yes. You can get replacement stickers from rubiks.com. Strangely, the
replacement stickers are much much better than the stickers they use on
their cubes! (Bizarre or what?) I have not actually ordered stickers
myself because someone from this group was kind enough to send me a set,
gratis (Thanks Robert!). The result is *excellent*: each colour comes in a
set of nine that you can put onto a face in one go. The original stickers
lasted about 6 weeks, but I put a replacement set on about 5 months ago and
they are pretty much the same now as they were when I first applied them.
The colours are really good, in my opinion.

So, try the stickers from rubiks.com. For $4.99 you get three sets, which
should last for years.

http://www.rubikshop.com/cgi-bin/shop.cgi/SID=1038474108.9550.r/num=stkcls

Good luck with your cubing: keep us posted on your progress!

S.

>
>i heard about electric tape... but any other ideas? just wondering

1851. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: my new cube

1852. Re: [Speed cubing group] what is good for replacing stickers?
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 17:45:13 +0000

> I ordered a few sets of replacement stickers from Rubiks.com two months ago,
> and didn't find the quality to be very impressive. Maybe I am just harder on
> my stickers, but I think the replacement stickers are just as bad as the
> original .com stickers.
>
> aWAKEn

Tricky one this. Did you get the plastic ones or the laminate ones?

My first cube was an oddzon fitted with paper laminate and they looked crap
after one week. I put rubiks.com stickers on and they've been on for 18
months. I recently bought a new oddzon cube, which still come with paper
laminate but they're better than the old paper laminate.

Perhaps the sticker kit you got from rubiks.com is simply their latest paper
laminate version rather than the decent plastic ones? In a way, I can see
why they would prefer to supply replacements that also wear out, so they can
make repeat sales... Well wouldn't you?

I think my spangly holo-stickers are not paper laminate though, as they are
also spangly on the reverse. Still no takers?

> I think my spangly holo-stickers are not paper laminate though, as they are
> also spangly on the reverse. Still no takers?
>

Offer is now closed, I have a taker :]

Mine are plastic, I believe, but they do have a laminate over the top to keep the color from wearing away. This peels and rolls towards the center, making for an unsightly cube after only two-three weeks.

1855. Anyone tried a photo cube?
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 12:19:45 -0800

I stumbled on a place that will make custom cubes with your photos
(See below). I'm certainly making one for a friend. Has anyone tried
this? Are they good? Are the pictures well done or are they that
stupid laminate format? Should they be protected in some way if you
expect heavy use?

http://www.memorylanegifts.com/product.asp?action=view&cat=17&navid=142&prodID=183

--
"They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever
flipped it over?"

Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@... http://lar5.com


1856. Re: [Speed cubing group] Anyone tried a photo cube?
From: "aWAKEn" <a_wake_n@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 15:31:23 -0500

I would assume that the photo cube is similar to using Rubiks.com DIY kit stickers. You can print whatever you want on them at your desktop, and then you apply the laminate on top of the ink to protect it from wear. My guess is that they would be similar to the Rubiks replacement stickers with the laminate.

sixpoint

1857. Re: [Speed cubing group] Anyone tried a photo cube?
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 20:53:08 +0000

> I would assume that the photo cube is similar to using Rubiks.com DIY
> kit stickers. You can print whatever you want on them at your
> desktop, and then you apply the laminate on top of the ink to protect
> it from wear. My guess is that they would be similar to the Rubiks
> replacement stickers with the laminate.

Sounds like some great potential here. Print onto any suitable paper,
and then run the paper through a proper laminating machine. Most print
shops have them, as do repro departments at schools etc... If the
plastic is heavy, you could end up with some very heavy duty tiles to
glue onto your cube!



1858. Re: [Speed cubing group] Anyone tried a photo cube?
From: "aWAKEn" <a_wake_n@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 15:56:25 -0500

Not a bad idea! However, I don't know how you would round the edges, so that the tiles don't get caught on your fingers, or worse under your nails("Ouch!").

sixpoint
----- Original Message -----
From: Robert Roue
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, November 28, 2002 3:53 PM
Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Anyone tried a photo cube?


> I would assume that the photo cube is similar to using Rubiks.com DIY
> kit stickers. You can print whatever you want on them at your
> desktop, and then you apply the laminate on top of the ink to protect
> it from wear. My guess is that they would be similar to the Rubiks
> replacement stickers with the laminate.

Sounds like some great potential here. Print onto any suitable paper,
and then run the paper through a proper laminating machine. Most print
shops have them, as do repro departments at schools etc... If the
plastic is heavy, you could end up with some very heavy duty tiles to
glue onto your cube!

1859. Re: [Speed cubing group] Anyone tried a photo cube?
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 21:26:52 +0000

> Not a bad idea! However, I don't know how you would round the edges,
> so that the tiles don't get caught on your fingers, or worse under
> your nails("Ouch!").
>
> sixpoint

A wise consideration. Perhaps they would not only need to be rounded,
but also beveled? So the profile becomes lower towards the edges. It
would probably also be necessary to do a neat gluing job, right up to
the edges. I'm no good at this malarkey though. I should be banned
from touching super glue, that stuff is evil!

I've always thought it would be a good idea if the labels were counter
sunk, so the label edges are protected. I suppose this can only be
done on a cube that was molded with sticker-pits (do you know a better
word!??).



1860. Re: [Speed cubing group] Anyone tried a photo cube?
From: "aWAKEn" <a_wake_n@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 16:31:12 -0500

You could always use a Dremel rotary tool, with a router attachment, to cut a recess that the label would fit into. However, I am not sure how much the integrity of the cube would be jeopardized by thinning the plastic sides. Also, It would take a lot or precision. I'll give it a try this week, with a cheap cube that I broke last week. Maybe you could set the stickers in the slots, then put a nice clear top-coat on them to keep them nice forever.

sixpointcube
----- Original Message -----
From: Robert Roue
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, November 28, 2002 4:26 PM

> so that the tiles don't get caught on your fingers, or worse under
> your nails("Ouch!").
>
> sixpoint

but also beveled? So the profile becomes lower towards the edges. It
would probably also be necessary to do a neat gluing job, right up to
the edges. I'm no good at this malarkey though. I should be banned
from touching super glue, that stuff is evil!

I've always thought it would be a good idea if the labels were counter
sunk, so the label edges are protected. I suppose this can only be
done on a cube that was molded with sticker-pits (do you know a better
word!??).

1862. Practice Routines
From: "hatadey" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Nov 2002 19:37:12 -0000

Hello,

I was wondering, do any of you 'cube professionals' have practice
routines which you go through to help you remember/understand solving
certain stages of the cube better? I am looking for other practices
rather tham simply just endless solving of the cube.

Also while I'm here, i need some expert advice on recognising the
permutations, is there a simple surefire way of recognising each
perm, without having to ask yourself several questions in your mind,
to determine which permutation you have?

Your advice will be greatly appreciated

Dan H :)



1863. Re: Practice Routines
From: kyubeman <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Nov 2002 20:20:46 -0000

Hey there! I believe that Katsu's page has some great practice for
OLL, he has a little part of his site that will flash certain
algorithms for a limited time, and you have to perform them. This is
very useful for learning those cases quickly. As for the
permutations, my advice would be to print out pictures of all the LL
permutation cases, and get a stop watch. Without looking at the cube
(this is unnecessary) go through EACH permutation in a row, going
down the sheet with no pauses between each permutation. This is
known as a Time Attack. (So you know, the elite are a little over a
minute, so shoot for that). If you are interested in F2L practice, I
will soon have a practice quiz that will help with many *advanced*
situations. If you aren't at that level yet, then just go over the
F2L cases you do know, and consider trying them from all angles as a
warm up.

Hope this helps.

-Ross



1864. Re: Practice Routines
From: "mylib_2000" <mylib_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Nov 2002 21:10:20 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., kyubeman <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey there! I believe that Katsu's page has some great practice for > OLL, he has a little part of his site that will flash certain > algorithms for a limited time, and you have to perform them. This is > very useful for learning those cases quickly. As for the > permutations, my advice would be to print out pictures of all the LL > permutation cases, and get a stop watch. Without looking at the cube > (this is unnecessary) go through EACH permutation in a row, going > down the sheet with no pauses between each permutation. This is > known as a Time Attack. (So you know, the elite are a little over a > minute, so shoot for that). If you are interested in F2L practice, I > will soon have a practice quiz that will help with many *advanced* > situations. If you aren't at that level yet, then just go over the > F2L cases you do know, and consider trying them from all angles as a > warm up. > > Hope this helps. > > -Ross For the LL I orient/permute corners in one alogorithm and then orient/permute edges in one algorithm. The system for recognizing the corners is explained on Ron's site and also Akimoto has it on his. For me this works faster because you will only have to look at edges for the last step. Also this method requires I think 6 less algorithms than the standard LL way.
1865. Re: my new cube
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Nov 2002 01:29:43 -0000

The Rubik's brand one I bought earlier in the year I got from Toys 'r' Us. The smooth one that I just bought was from a new puzzle shop in Canberra called Socrates. I'll try and remember to check the packaging so I can let you know more detail. It's soooo smooth compared to all my other cubes. It's so EXCITING! :) It's the first cube I've ever had that would be suitable for finger tricks (now I have no excuse not to learn them). I've been cubing much more in the last week since getting the new cube. It's so exciting to have a smooth cube that I just can't put it down!! :) Jasmine. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., cubed68 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > I also just bought a new cube. The box claimed "smoothest cube > ever". > > It was okay when opened it, but after a quick spray of silicon it > was > > certainly very smooth. Much smoother than the Rubik's brand cube I > > bought earlier this year!! > > > > Jasmine , what sort of Rubiks cube was that ? one from the rubiks > web page or a original cube from the 80`s. > > > Peter > > > www.speedcubing.com/ton/ for Rubiks Studio cubes.7 - 10 days > delivery , $16.00 US .way cheaper than bidding for a cube on e bay
1866. Re: What's all this cube brand talk?
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Nov 2002 01:38:18 -0000

Based on this group, I'd say that far more serious cubers are male. I just love puzzles. Any type where there are lots of little pieces have have to fit together in a complicated way, eg. Rubik's puzzles, scrabble, crosswords, jigsaw puzzles. Fun! I've even found a job where I get to use (vaguely related) logic problem solving (I work on expert systems). :) Jasmine. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > From all the stories i've heard guys enjoy the cube much more than > the ladies. I don't know why that is. I also found that most guys > are willing to learn, where the ladies think that they can't or just > don't care. I don't know... Jasmine enlighten us! > Jake > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > Hmmm... is it only guys what have these problems?? My boyfriend > > thinks it's cute and quirky that I'm into speedcubing. Sometimes > when > > we are with people he'll grab my cube (I usually keep one in my > bag) > > and mess it up, knowing I won't be able to resist solving it, and > > make me demonstrate speedcubing to our friends. > > > > Jasmine. > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > > > > Oddzon cubes are the answer to all of life's problems. > > > > > > > > > > Questionable, when your girlfriend leaves you because you don't > put > > the > > > damn cube down!
1867. Re: [Speed cubing group] what is good for replacing stickers?
From: rquethe <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Nov 2002 05:07:53 -0000


> So, try the stickers from rubiks.com. For $4.99 you get three
sets, which
> should last for years.
>

Uh, did you get different stickers than me? I ordered 2 sets of three
from Rubiks.com and the only reason they've lasted as long as they
have is because I don't cube all that much anymore. Given being in a
normal cubing mood, I'd give those stickers about two weeks tops for
lasting. They were exactly the same as the ones that came on the cube
for me.

although i find the action pretty smooth myself,anyone here got one??

1869. Long time no see!
From: cubin4speed <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Nov 2002 07:56:47 -0000

Hi All,

Dan Knights here. I kind of ducked out of the online speed cubing
world for the last year or so - I've been doing a lot of travelling,
climbing, and working. But I'm glad to see that this club is so
active!

For some time I've been working on incorporating my left hand into my
solution. My goal is to significantly reduce the amount that I have
to turn the whole cube in my hands while solving, by performing
mirror-images of moves "Lefty". And I know my left hand is capable
because I play guitar and my left hand does things that my right hand
can only balk at.

But this has proven to take a lot longer than I thought! It's been
hard to focus when my times went from 17's to 27's. It's only
recently that I've been able to average under 20 again. (WITH the
use of my left hand.) Anyway, I expect this to effect an overall
reduction in time after further practice.

So I wish you all peace and good cubing, and congrats to all the
newbie cubists who are hacking their times down toward the teens!

Dan



1870. Re: [Speed cubing group] Long time no see!
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Nov 2002 14:10:28 +0000

> Hi All,
>
> Dan Knights here. I kind of ducked out of the online speed cubing
> world for the last year or so - I've been doing a lot of travelling,
> climbing, and working. But I'm glad to see that this club is so
> active!
>

Hi Dan! Welcome back to the fold!

I bought a cube from your Ebay auction in January or so. Back then I
averaged something like 90 seconds. I still use your cube and I
average 35 when I'm in the right frame of mind :]

Do you think you will be attending the Championships in Canada?



1871. Re: [Speed cubing group] what is good for replacing stickers?
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Nov 2002 14:17:03 +0000

> Uh, did you get different stickers than me? I ordered 2 sets of three
> from Rubiks.com and the only reason they've lasted as long as they
> have is because I don't cube all that much anymore. Given being in a
> normal cubing mood, I'd give those stickers about two weeks tops for
> lasting. They were exactly the same as the ones that came on the cube
> for me.

If your replacement stickers were white on their adhesive side, then
you got the crappy paper laminates. If they were the same colour both
sides, then you have plastic ones.

My ones are plastic right through and I expect them to last for years.
They can even be submerged in water and it's no problem at all. If I
get messy with my lube and the stickers get gooed up, then a quick wipe
and they are as good as new again. The only thing that has gone wrong
so far is a lifted corner that would not stick down again. I just cut
it off and it hardly shows.

If you got the paper laminates, then that's just rotten luck. I wonder
if you explicitly requested plastic ones, would they supply them to
you? It's no good them supplying paper laminates that are as bad as
the original stickers.



1872. Re: Long time no see!
From: smoothcuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Nov 2002 16:25:08 -0000

Hi Dan, Thanks for helping me out about 3 yrs ago-- I've got my times down to around 23 sec, where I've been stuck for some time. Nice to see you're still cubing. I hope you find the time to post every now and then; many of us can use advice from one of the top cubists! Just to let you know, a bunch of us are usually in the chat room on Sat and Sun, pretty much any time of day; so if you have time and feel like it, drop by. 1877. Blindfold Cube.
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 01 Dec 2002 07:28:56 -0000

About a month ago, I did my first blindfold cube. Right after I
finished it, I wrote down the starting position and all the steps I
took to solve it. I just finally put it up on my website. Check it
out!

http://www.Tregay.net/Grant/Cube/blindfold.html

The cube section of my site is growing - slowly, but surely! I've
also added some of the more common cube related links.



1878. Re: Practice Routines
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 01 Dec 2002 07:46:13 -0000

I wouldn't really consider myself a pro, but... The only practice
routine I have at this point is the PLL algs. I have a sequence
that runs me through all 21 algs from a solved cube, back to a
solved cube with several checkpoints along the way (where the
cube should be solved). I timed myself once at about 1:38 for the
whole sequence - obviously room for improvement. Some day, I'll
have to put the practice routine up on my website.

I intend to come up with a similar sequence for practicing all of
the OLL algs, once I have all of them learned. I've still got
quite a ways to go on that, though. I haven't even thought about
one for the F2L, but that would be great to have.

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "hatadey" wrote:
> I was wondering, do any of you 'cube professionals' have
> practice routines which you go through to help you
> remember/understand solving certain stages of the cube better?
> I am looking for other practices rather tham simply just
> endless solving of the cube.




1879. Re: my new cube
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 01 Dec 2002 21:38:30 -0000

The label said Maestro Magic Cube. It was very smooth once I'd lubed it. Not perfectly and evenly smooth all around, but mostly pretty smooth. Also, it was only AUS$11.95 which is cheaper than the Rubik's brand cubes I've seen in Toys 'r' Us and Kmart. I've taken this cube apart yet, but I did remove the centre white cap. Had this weird plasticy thing unlike other cubes I've seen. Apparently a local puzzle store is about to get in some Revenge cubes (finally!), but now that I've ordered the Mefferts Xmas pack of cubes (which includes a 4x4x4) I will probably just wait for Mefferts. Good to hear that the Revenges are making their way to your side of the country too! :) Jasmine. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., cubed68 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > cool stuff indeed,if a good cube can be found in Australia than that > sounds real good to me.most of mine come from the USA via ebay and i > hate dealing that way,total pain some times. > > my new cube is still a bit stiff but i think it will be good,except > when i have to adjust the spring inside,getting te centre caps off > look to be a task in itself.trying to get them out without damaging > the caps etc may be tricky...plus glueing the stickers back on > with "WHAT" kind glue is another problem. > > i stumbled across the Rubiks Revenge in my local puzzle shop today,i > bought it for the heck off it.i`ve heard they are`nt that great > although i find the action pretty smooth myself,anyone here got one?? > > that all for now > > Peter

1881. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: my new cube
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 1 Dec 2002 23:20:47 +0000

> The label said Maestro Magic Cube. It was very smooth once I'd lubed
> it. Not perfectly and evenly smooth all around, but mostly pretty
> smooth. Also, it was only AUS$11.95 which is cheaper than the Rubik's
> brand cubes I've seen in Toys 'r' Us and Kmart.
>
> I've taken this cube apart yet, but I did remove the centre white
> cap. Had this weird plasticy thing unlike other cubes I've seen.
>

I had one of them cubes! On the packaging it claimed that it's the
smoothest turning cube ever. It sure was smooth but I found that it
would lock up sometimes. I used it for a long time without any lube
and I didn't think much of it. Then I put a little drop of silicone in
it and WOW! It stopped locking up and it just flew along! The only
trouble is, I found it too loose. That could be because I'd worn it in
a bit too much before the lube.

If you rub the centre stickers, you should find that there is a hole.
The plasticy thing is like a rivet. I wonder if these are actually
made my Mefferts.

1883. [Speed cubing group] Re: my new cube
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 02 Dec 2002 11:41:36 -0000

Yep. I had totally the same experience with the silicon. I've found that silicon always improves a cube, but the difference it made with the Maestro cube was AMAZING!! The cube is great at the moment but I'd been concerned that it would become too loose. I was hoping to find screws when I took off the centre white cap, but alas, no. I'm going to go back to the same puzzle store on the weekend and get a spare or two if they still have any. It's so difficult to find a good cube in Canberra! 1884. Re: my new cube..part 10
From: cubed68 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 02 Dec 2002 11:50:42 -0000

you`ll love the mefferts 4x4 ,i picked one up last xmas and it is a
real gem.the turning action is primo......LOL.

this is the first time i`ve seen the rubiks 4x4 cubes here,i`m hoping
the stickers will hold out because i`ve heard they are the shitty
paper/laminate kind...mmmmm.

worst comes to worst i`ll use a glue called Loctite 401 to put a
clear hard layer over the stickers,don`t wont too though...all those
stickers would need 3/4 coats.

happy cubing Jasmine

Peter



1885. Does this happen to anyone else??
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 02 Dec 2002 12:08:37 -0000

I was interstate visiting friends this weekend and, of course, took
my cube along. As you can guess from my last few posts, I'm pretty
excited about my new cube. I couldn't stop playing with the cube all
weekend. I wasn't off in a corner cubing by myself or anything silly
like that. I just played with my cube while chatting with my friends.
They all know I'm into cubing so they didn't pay much attention which
was good because I wasn't in the mood for speed demonstrations, I
just wanted to enjoy the spin of my new cube.

I had brought along a 2nd cube in case any of them wanted to have a
play too. I ended up showing the basics to one of my friends. I
started with the cross, then the rest of the F2L, then on to the LL.
Then a crazy thing happened. We were almost done, only 3 LL edges to
fix. I was about to show her Lars P's 'Allen' algorithm when I
suddenly had a blank. I use this algorithm almost every solution,
without thinking or even looking at the cube. But when I had to do it
slowly and step-by-step, I couldn't! I just sat there staring at the
cube not being able to remember past the first two turns.

During the same afternoon I happened to be learning two new algs and
had I been asked to teach those algs it would have been fine -- I
could remember those step-by-step, but not the alg that I'd been
using for years.

I guess the part of the brain that stores the information when we
first learn an alg is quite different to the part that stores it when
it moves into our subconscious. It's like I initially know an alg as
a series of individual steps, but after a while I know it as a block
movement.

Bizarre...

Jasmine.



1886. Re: my new cube..part 10
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 02 Dec 2002 12:17:06 -0000

I've never heard of Loctite 401 -- I assume it is available from hardware stores? What about clear nail polish, would that work too? I remember some discussion recently about using coloured nail polish in replace of colour stickers. I guess this means that nail polish doesn't damage cubes? I can't wait to get my new cubes. I know they've got a long way to travel so I'm just going to have to wait. :( How long did it take to get your cubes from Mefferts to WA? Jasmine. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., cubed68 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > you`ll love the mefferts 4x4 ,i picked one up last xmas and it is a > real gem.the turning action is primo......LOL. > > this is the first time i`ve seen the rubiks 4x4 cubes here,i`m hoping > the stickers will hold out because i`ve heard they are the shitty > paper/laminate kind...mmmmm. > > worst comes to worst i`ll use a glue called Loctite 401 to put a > clear hard layer over the stickers,don`t wont too though...all those > stickers would need 3/4 coats. > > happy cubing Jasmine > > Peter
1887. Re: [Speed cubing group] Does this happen to anyone else??
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 02 Dec 2002 12:19:55 +0000

YEP! I get that too. There is an alg I use most solutions. Sometimes when
I'm going slow, I can't get it! The harder I try to think about it, the
worse it gets! The only way I can get going again is to scramble the cube
and do it fast, and I can do it without even thinking about it. Or, when I
get jammed, I do a different alg instead, even if it's the wrong one, then I
see what needs doing from there :]



1888. Re: [Speed cubing group] Does this happen to anyone else??
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 02 Dec 2002 12:31:14 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > worse it gets! The only way I can get going again is to scramble the cube > and do it fast, and I can do it without even thinking about it. This is normally what I do in these situations and it's normally fine after that. But even this didn't work. I had to put the cube away and then come back to it half an hour later!! Jasmine.
1889. Re: my new cube..part 10
From: cubed68 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 02 Dec 2002 13:45:04 -0000

yeppers your local hardware should have it.it dries very quick so you
have to be very carefull not to touch it or your finger or whatever
will be stuck there...LOL.

i`m not sure about clear nail polish,worth looking into though.the
glue pretty much well stays on and will not flake off like i would
imagine polish would.

my cubes from Mefferts took about 10 days,pretty quick i thought.when
did you order yours ?

Peter

1891. New Personal Best!
From: nascarjon2001 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 02 Dec 2002 14:06:02 -0000

Yesterday I sat down to make a new video of my cubing. I was
determined to catch a fast one on video. After around 30 solves with
a few 17's and 18's I solved the cube in 14.2 seconds, shattering my
old record of 16 seconds. And catching it on video to boot! I
posted the video on my site.
Now all I need to do is get an average below twenty.

Happy Cubing.


Jon
http://nascarjon.curvedspaces.com/cube.htm





1892. Re: Does this happen to anyone else??
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 02 Dec 2002 14:27:36 -0000

My guess is that the moves are more intuitive or subconscious or whatever they call it. The thing is you first had it recorded by memorizing the alg, but eventually as you get faster and faster, you drop the algorithm because you don't need to remember the notation to execute the move at your current speed. This makes it difficult to recall algs. I think thats how it works(?) Your 'smoothest cube ever' cube are definately smooth. I had one as well. The problem I had with it is that you can't 'cut the corners' or allwoing you to perform certain finger tricks. Also the center kernal in mine was fragile and the center of one side broke off. I don't know if it was cheapy plastic or just a fragile cube. Becareful! Jake --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > > worse it gets! The only way I can get going again is to scramble > the cube > > and do it fast, and I can do it without even thinking about it. > > This is normally what I do in these situations and it's normally fine > after that. But even this didn't work. I had to put the cube away and > then come back to it half an hour later!! > > Jasmine.

Hi Ton, GameOfDeath2, I'm new here. PMFJI. Twenty years ago I got my average time down to about 27 seconds. I am just getting back into it, at the moment I'm down to about a minute to a minute and a half. Among the "not recommended" cubes on Ton's site (nice site by the way) is the Rubik's Deluxe which came out about 20 years ago. I must disagree with this. This cube was fast enough for the 27 second average, and what's more it's very durable as I still use it. I recently lubed it for the first time with graphite and it is faster, though I'm not back up to speed yet. I sent off for a Hessport cube with their silicone-based lube and it's pretty nice. If you can't buy these in England maybe you can do it through the internet. Does anyone have information about the new "Deluxe Edition" put out by Winning Moves company? Is this cube better than their regular cube? Is their regular cube good? 1900. OH MY GOD!!! BWAHHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAH!!!!!!!!!!!!!
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 03 Dec 2002 05:23:49 -0000

I've been stuck at the same crappy average of 22.0 for 2 1/2
years.... and I FINALLY BEAT IT!!!!
BWAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAH!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I was
starting to get sick of 22.0 seconds heh heh but I finally got a
better one, and under the weirdest circumstances too!

here were the times,

21.79 20.76 (26.24) 20.65 (18.39) 22.89 22.02 22.28 (pop) 19.09 24.40
20.93 19.74 = 21.455 = 21.46

Wow, I forgot what this high feels like!!!! Bwahahah!!! ok
sorry. :) :) :) :) :) :)

So anyway I broke it under some strange circumstances. When I was up
in New York they had to change the stickers on my cube because it was
so beat up looking. They had me filming with a brand new cube that
I'd lubed up while they changed the stickers. Anyway, when I got
back home and was messing with my cube it was turning really weird.
It kept sticking a LOT, so I figured "wow ok time for a lube" and I
took it apart, cleaned the inside, then lubed it and was ready for it
to be working like new. Well it still stuck on me like CRAZY. So I
took the cube apart again and was looking at some of the pieces and
whereas all my pieces should be worn down like crazy from being 4 1/2
years old some were CLEARLY brand new. So anyway I think they
switched some pieces with the new cube to save time from having to
switch all the clean stickers over. Well I was doing an average
tonight, after realizing I don't have all of my orginal cube, and
just decided to cube harder (turn the faces hard enough to just get
through the sticks). Well this average was the result of that! I'm
sooo happy!!! Yet so confused... Ok I have a question. All you sub
20'ers and other very fast people, how often do you change cubes, how
loose is your cube, and all that? I figured if I can't break my
average on my cube, but I can break my average using some of my cube
and some pieces from a new cube, then maybe it is better to not have
a super loose cube but one that puts up some resistance? Anyway this
really gives me some motivation to start practicing again. I'm
trying to take it really light so as not to screw my wrist over for
another six months but I can't wait to take another average!!!

So anyway I think I'm THE slowest person, or definitely one of the
slowest, to speed cube and try to make it to sub-twenty but I'm one
stepping stone closer. I'm going to start practicing again, but I
would appreciate some feedback on people's cubes. I'm starting to
think that maybe the super-loose never throw your cube away strategy
is a bad idea.

Later,
Chris

P.S. BWAHAHAHAHHAHAHA!!!!!!!!!!! and it only took 2 1/2 years to
get past 22.0 seconds!!!!

1905. Progress report and cube thorts
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 03 Dec 2002 13:21:32 +0000

Thanks for your encouragement, Nicolas.

Just to let you all know ...

I had been working on the F2L up until two weeks ago, and now have a large
number of shortcuts under my fingers. As is to be expected I suppose, since
learning these my F2L time have got a bit slower, because the recognition
part of the process is different and more complex. Also, I find that these
new shortcuts make looking ahead more difficult, because they move the
cubies around in slightly different ways. But with a bit more practise
learning these shortcuts should pay off.

But since two weeks ago I have finally taken the plunge and set to learning
all the llo algs. I know some of you out there seem to learn these in a
matter of days, but it takes me about 3 days just to learn one! I think
maybe some people are "naturals" and others are not; if so it seems I am in
the "not" camp! But I also know that practise can make up for that, and
anyway any such differences iron out over time - as long as you are willing
to put that time in, of course.

Since I started speedcubing about half a year ago I have never fussed *too*
much over my times, instead trying to concentrate on cutting down the number
of moves it takes to solve the thing, and ensuring that my technique is
relaxed and smooth with the algs that I execute. Hopefully if I keep my
focus on these two aspects of speedcubing faster times will eventually
follow. For me, if I start concentrating purely on speed I start to
seriously tense up: the muscles in my hands start to lock up, and this gets
transmitted down into the cube itself. I wonder, does anyone else find that?

Anyway, for me one of the attractions to solving the cube very quickly is
that when it works it is in some way a creative act, a sort of dance or
something (particularly the cross and F2L). Solving it really fast (which
for me is under 30 seconds, only done this a few times!) is just
exhilarating: when everything flows together it just feels fantastic.
Somehow, a number of various things, some abstract and some not, all blend
together into this single burst and BANG! ... chaos is replaced by beautiful
order. Hmmm ... or am I just full of pompous, pseudo-intellectual pap?

Whatever: happy cubing everyone!

S.

PS If I can reliably make sub-30 averages I am hoping my reward will be a
return ticket to Toronto in guess-when 2003!
PPS I can't make the chat room for the next few weeks: I have moved house
and at the moment do not have access on weekends :-( but will be get back
there soon!



_________________________________________________________________
Tired of spam? Get advanced junk mail protection with MSN 8.
http://join.msn.com/?page=features/junkmail



1906. Are you a Rubik's Master???
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 03 Dec 2002 18:06:42 -0000

What qualifies as a Rubik's Master? I remember one person stating
that a Rubik's master is someone who not only can solve the 3x3 but
the 5x5 and square 1 as well.
Would a rubiks master be ranked by time, varity of puzzles they can
solve, years of experience, etc???
What do you think?
Jake



1907. Re: Are you a Rubik's Master???
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 03 Dec 2002 18:39:30 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > What qualifies as a Rubik's Master? I remember one person stating > that a Rubik's master is someone who not only can solve the 3x3 but > the 5x5 and square 1 as well. > Would a rubiks master be ranked by time, varity of puzzles they can > solve, years of experience, etc??? > What do you think? > Jake Somebody who can solve the Rubik's Magic Master Edition, I presume - I think that's the only (Rubik) puzzle with Master in the title. I've never even seen a square 1 (outside of pictures on the web), so I fail on variety and I can't say I'd qualify as a cube master by any sensible criterion because I am far too slow on the main event (3x3x3) (time), I don't know anywhere near enough algorithms (time too and just general sophistication/knowledge of puzzle). As for years of experience, I started early but there was a period of probably 12-14 years where I didn't do the cube (or very, very rarely) so I don't really pass there either. People who are really good at puzzles probably know some group theory - at least as far as conjugations and commutators and their effects in regard to permutations. Also many of the best known algorithms, from what I understand (although I haven't actually seen the details), use Jordan-Holder decompositions of groups to solve puzzles.

1909. Re: OH MY GOD!!! BWAHHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAH!!!!!!!!!!!!!
From: kyubeman <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 04 Dec 2002 01:35:31 -0000

That sounds great! You will come back and beat me no doubt now! I
have a few questions however. I recall that you stopped rotating
during f2l for a while, and your times suffered horridly. Surely you
resumed rotating again to get this average? Or did you actually
figure it out. If you HAVE indeed stopped rotating together as I
have, I have some ideas as to why you didn't get faster perhaps.
Since I stopped rotating altogether for the f2l, I have devoted EVERY
SINGLE cubing moment to the search for optimized cases and advanced
tricks for the f2l. I have learned at least 100 since only a month
ago. Did you likewise devote your time? It seems to me that if you
didn't actively search to better your cases, there would be no way to
improve. Which reminds me. A few of us in the cube chat, are
creating an f2l cases file. We are coming up with solutions for each
of the 41 "standard" f2l cases from every angle without rotations.
We have turned up a great deal so far, and we'd love to have you drop
in, it may very well be worth your time! I'd really like to discuss
how you went about your improvement after so long, as I feel that I
myself am very nearing a jump.

Yesterday, I took with me my big analog clock and practiced for hours
on end. This was all not rotating of course. All my times were
comfortably in the low 20's. A few 17 and 18's, but mostly 21-23. I
was listening to music as well, and studying cases. It was then,
that I decided to try going full speed, rotating as free as I
pleased. To my surprise, I had 5 times: 17, 18, 17, 19, 18. I
couldn't believe it. I stopped right there. I promised myself to
learn all the cases that I'm working on, and get down to these times
without rotating before I get back into my old habit. (BTW, it was
with cube rotations that I achieved my average of 20.17 seconds). I
know that as soon as I complete (this may never happen! :) ) my quest
for f2l knowledge, I will drop below 20. It's a good feeling, but I
still have a long way to go. Well, enough of this rant, just curious
to see how you're doing.

Congratulations! Good to see you cubing again! Please come to
weekend chat!

-Ross

many hours of searching for a driver on the Internet, I finally found
one. And I then got my first ever video of me doing the cube. I
wanted to post it but then realized that it is like 19MB. So I was
wondering if there is an easy way to compress it. The video is an
avi file. Does anyone know how?

-Kenneth




1911. *sigh* oh well...
From: kyubeman <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 04 Dec 2002 05:13:03 -0000

I was just reading about Jess Bonde and his Guinness attempt at 2,000
cubes. I was extremely disappointed to find out that if he broke the
record during just *one* of those times, he would set the new
official world record. What is the fun of that?!?!?! He has a HUGE
advantage over EVERYONE else... No pressure... Virtually unlimited
tries. Given 2,000 attempts, it is almost certainty that he will
have at least *one* lucky cube state. If this happens, it will
surely be a new record of 15 seconds or even less. He has virtually
unlimited attempts to do it, I guess that is my major complaint. I'm
all for him solving 2,000 in 24 hours, I think that's great... It's
just... I really wanted to go to the competition and have everyone
there to beat the world record of 22.95 in official competition.
Anything less than that would seem to discredit the record and it's
following. Perhaps I am wrong to feel bad about this, it just seems
like a lot of effort, to be perhaps tossed away by one lucky cube
state out of 2,000. If you disagree, don't mind me, just being
stupid I suppose. *sigh*

-Ross

1914. Re: Progress report and cube thorts
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 04 Dec 2002 11:53:46 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "simonl cube" <simonlcube@h...> wrote: > > Anyway, for me one of the attractions to solving the cube very quickly is > that when it works it is in some way a creative act, a sort of dance or > something (particularly the cross and F2L). Solving it really fast (which > for me is under 30 seconds, only done this a few times!) is just > exhilarating: when everything flows together it just feels fantastic. > Somehow, a number of various things, some abstract and some not, all blend > together into this single burst and BANG! ... chaos is replaced by beautiful > order. Hmmm ... or am I just full of pompous, pseudo-intellectual pap? I find that some algs just flow through the fingers more smoothly than others, and so there are some algs I really enjoy and other algs that I only do because I have to. Also, sometimes I have a smooth run where the whole solution flows together well (very satisfying) and other times it gets broken up (poppage, dropping the cube, or simply taking a second or two to find the right cubie). Jasmine.

1916. Understanding algorithms
From: gogozergus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 04 Dec 2002 13:17:05 -0000


I recently designed from scratch all the algorithms needed for the LL
permutation step. I don't want to reinvent the wheel. I'm an engineer
and I just need to understand what I'm doing and be able to remember
these algorithms after a 10 year pause.

Of course, I'm far from optimal sequences, some of them can take 17
moves (R2==1 move, M==2 moves).

I'd like to know if you, speedcubers, understand every move of every
algorithm, what it does and how it works, or if you just read it and
practice until you know it by heart?

In http://www.speedcubing.com/algorithms.html, code P21:
L'U'LF2R'DRUR2D'R2U'F2, can you explain how this sequence was
conceived ? (ok ok, Cube Explorer ;-)

Gilles.



Yesterday, I broke my best average time with 25.23 (using only 6 algs)
:-)))

I was extremely disappointed to find out that if he broke the > record during just *one* of those times, he would set the new > official world record. What is the fun of that?!?!?! 1921. Doing one whole side as first step
From: "stiff_hands" <angela.hayden@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 04 Dec 2002 14:27:43 -0000

I am currently swapping from the normal jiri method to corners first and wish to hear the experiences of other people on a particular facet of the solution method I am learning, so please reply! What I am interested in is the first stage of my solution: I fully complete one face. From years of jiri practise I can do four edges fast and then do the four corners fairly quickly (just like a normal f2l except not bothered which pieces appear in the middle layer) so doing this way is <15 quite easily. What I am attempting though is to do the four corners first, and then insert the centre and four edges. Despite Marc Waterman suggesting this can be done in 6-7 secs on average I am normally doing low to mid teens for this stage (and when it goes a little badly can be a lot longer). Has anybody else tried this both ways? Does corners then edges give faster times for the layer than the other way round? How fast can you lot out there do the single face on a normal go and at best? Any tips that might help? I seem to remember Jessica used to do one face first (is that right?) so it would be interesting to know how she did it as she was a fast cuber at thtat stage. thanks, stiff_hands
1922. Re: OH MY GOD!!! BWAHHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAH!!!!!!!!!!!!!
From: "stiff_hands" <angela.hayden@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 04 Dec 2002 14:38:33 -0000

My cubes were a little loose so I discarded the corners and put in
fresh corners that I mixed and matched from a few spares (something
katsu recommended once) and I found that the cube felt well worn in
(due to using a well worked spider) and was a couple of seconds
quicker on average. I think that the gain is mainly that the little
pauses that appear when you concentrate upon keeping the faces
aligned with a loose cube start to disappear when there isn't so much
risk of cube lockup.
I now have a cube from Ton and it is really nice - it has screws
which means that it can be adjusted until the faces turn properly,
and then lubed. This means the cube can be broken in very quickly.
Just one tip for everybody out there: don't use a serrated knife to
get the caps off or you will make a complete mess - I am so glad I
bought two ;) This cube is definitely the best I have ever used so I
am hoping to go sub20 within the next 6 months.
In short; loose cubes are limiting (or maybe not since really it is
all personal preference) and the cubes that Ton (and others) supply
are the bees knees. Get one now!
- stiff_hands



1923. Re: [Speed cubing group] Understanding algorithms
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 04 Dec 2002 15:13:58 +0000

Hi Gilles: congratulations on your great new average, BTW, I am looking
foward to one day (soon??) posting something similar...


You say how for each algorithm you want / need to understand what each
algorithm does, down (I think) to every move. I find this interesting
because it is the complete opposite of how I cube, and the antithesis of my
final goal. For me the execution of the orientation and permutation
algorithms are almost completely a tactile action during which the
algorithms are experienced as single events. If I try to split an algorithm
down to separete moves my mind does not really come up with the goods (try
saying the alphabet backwards: the knowledge is there, but not easily
retrieved).

It is bit like reading: when you start learning to read you might need to
divide words into their syllables, or even the letter-components, but over
time you read words as single entities (except very long words, perhaps, if
they are new to you). The same goes for the cube: the algorithms that you
learn becomes your "cube-language", comprised of single moves (letters) that
may or may not sit together as triggers (syllables); these make algorithms
(words) which work together to form complete solutions (sentences /
narratives).

As I become more fluent in this language, combining words into meaningful
sentences (i.e. flowing algorithms together to solve the cube), so solving
the cube becomes more natural, and takes less time.

So for me, the whole goal is to move away from a deconstructed knowledge of
any algorithm, and instead aim for the opposite: to "flatten out" my
awareness until solving the cube is experienced as a single action (and
hopefully, one day, one that takes less than 20 seconds to complete!).


>
>I recently designed from scratch all the algorithms needed for the LL
>permutation step. I don't want to reinvent the wheel. I'm an engineer
>and I just need to understand what I'm doing and be able to remember
>these algorithms after a 10 year pause.
>
>Of course, I'm far from optimal sequences, some of them can take 17
>moves (R2==1 move, M==2 moves).
>
>I'd like to know if you, speedcubers, understand every move of every
>algorithm, what it does and how it works, or if you just read it and
>practice until you know it by heart?
>
>In http://www.speedcubing.com/algorithms.html, code P21:
>L'U'LF2R'DRUR2D'R2U'F2, can you explain how this sequence was
>conceived ? (ok ok, Cube Explorer ;-)
>
>Gilles.
>
>
>
>Yesterday, I broke my best average time with 25.23 (using only 6 algs)
>:-)))
>
>

1927. Something I've noticed
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 04 Dec 2002 19:28:05 -0000

I've noticed something about the way I've been cubing recently (after
my cube got its pieces mixed up with a new cube). I just took
another average and got 22.50 which is something I would have
considered a really good average on my looser cube. I noticed
something though, I get a lot more sub twenty times per average, and
my sub twenty times are faster. With my loose cube I'd get the
occasional 19 but now I'm getting 18's regularly and the occasional
17. Anyway I also think I've noticed a change in the way I do the
F2L. All my really fast times (17 and 18 for me) are done when I do
something a little different during the F2L. Normally while I'm
putting in a corner edge pair I'm either paying attention to that
corner edge pair and I pause afterward looking for the next pair, or
I'm looking for another PAIR while putting in the current one which,
if I locate a pair, saves time. On my recent really fast times I've
noticed that I just sort of take a mental note of the other first
layer corners and middle edges that I see as I'm putting in a corner
edge pair. For a period of 2 or 3 moves I may be tracking 2 or 3
pieces on the edge of my concentration but as soon as I locate the
pair to one of those pieces my mind tracks that pair and I take off
with it after I finish the pair I'm on. These times have all
resulted in 17's or 18's which is really really good for me. Anyway
I don't know if this helps anyone who's working on F2L, but I'm
trying to do this more consistently.

Also Ross, yeah I was paying attention to whether or not I twisted
the cube while I was taking that average. I don't twist it very
much, not like I used to. I noticed that I put pieces into the back
pairs a lot so I guess I got used to doing most of the
moves "backwards". I do twist sometimes but it's usually if the move
is just at a really awkward angle or if I'm turing a face and
twisting the cube at the same time.

Anyway just my two cents on a possible improvement to doing the F2L.

Later,
Chris



1928. Re: Something I've noticed
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 04 Dec 2002 19:48:02 -0000

I need to improve both my f2l and ll skills but i find my LL skills
to be worse, I usually have the F2L completed in 18 to 26 sec, but my
Last layer takes about 10 to 15 sec. If i can reduce both of these
areas i can achieve better times. My question is what can I do to
reduce these, My LL is obvious but the F2L, I'm not sure how to make
it better. Maybe I need one of those *clicks* again
jake



1929. Re: Doing one whole side as first step
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 04 Dec 2002 20:01:14 -0000

I (although very biased) think that doing corners then edges is much faster that edges then corners. For my entire cubeing history, I have done corners first. When I started doing the cube, I would solve one layer. I did a corner, then an edge, then corner, or whatever felt good. Then on my own choosing I stopped doing it like that and started doing the corners, and then edges. I did that because I knew I needed to do one first and another second so that I could speed up my recognition. And it was hard for me to visualize four edges without corners, because I would not know where to put them (because I did not know my color configuration.) So with much practice I have done one layer first in that way corners, then edges. Then after much practice I learned of Marc Waterman, and his method, which was very similar to mine. The major difference was that he did the corners without the center. That was a hard step for me. I still do not do it that way when I am solving for speed. Now I haven't read his method in a long time. But I believe he does not do the entire layer first, but he does corners, then edge, then edge with center, then one last edge. My method is very similar to that, in which I do corners around the center, then three edges. The missing edge is used as a Keyhole when doing the bottom layer edges. So anyway after reading your message I went to time myself on how fast I did one layer. I solved the layer how I normally do, then looked at the timer, and then finished the layer and looked again at the timer. Here is what I got: 1. 7 8 2. 9 10 3. (13) (15) 4. 6 9 5. 8 10 6. (6) (7) 7. 9 10 8. 8 9 9. 8 8 10. 6 8 11. 7 8 12. 7 11 7.5+.5=8 9.1+.5=9.6 So on average it takes me 8 seconds to get a layer done minus one edge, and 9.6 seconds to complete a layer. While I was timing myself I realized that the time really depended on how fast I could get the corners done. And sometimes the corners would really depend on how the state of the cube was when it was scrambled. So I think that the best way to improve first layer times is to practice getting the corners done quickly. I remember that Marc Waterman would solve two adjacent corners, and then the other two simultaneously. And that I think is the best way to do it. If my memory is good I remember that he would do all four corners on average in 6.5 moves. I think that for me, my next step on improving this part of my solution would be to learn all possibilities of solving the second two corners. I hope that through all of my babbling I might have helped you a little. Good luck, -Kenneth --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "stiff_hands" <angela.hayden@n...> wrote: > I am currently swapping from the normal jiri method to corners first > and wish to hear the experiences of other people on a particular > facet of the solution method I am learning, so please reply! > What I am interested in is the first stage of my solution: I fully > complete one face. From years of jiri practise I can do four edges > fast and then do the four corners fairly quickly (just like a normal > f2l except not bothered which pieces appear in the middle layer) so > doing this way is <15 quite easily. What I am attempting though is to > do the four corners first, and then insert the centre and four edges. > Despite Marc Waterman suggesting this can be done in 6-7 secs on > average I am normally doing low to mid teens for this stage (and when > it goes a little badly can be a lot longer). > Has anybody else tried this both ways? Does corners then edges give > faster times for the layer than the other way round? How fast can you > lot out there do the single face on a normal go and at best? Any tips > that might help? I seem to remember Jessica used to do one face first > (is that right?) so it would be interesting to know how she did it as > she was a fast cuber at thtat stage. > thanks, > stiff_hands

If this happens, it will > surely be a new record of 15 seconds or even less. He has virtually > unlimited attempts to do it, I guess that is my major complaint. I'm > all for him solving 2,000 in 24 hours, I think that's great... It's > just... I really wanted to go to the competition and have everyone > there to beat the world record of 22.95 in official competition. > Anything less than that would seem to discredit the record and it's > following. 1935. Re: Doing one whole side as first step
From: "mylib_2000" <mylib_2000@...>

(13) (15) > 4. 6 9 > 5. 8 10 > 6. So I think that the > best way to improve first layer times is to practice getting the > corners done quickly. > > I remember that Marc Waterman would solve two adjacent corners, and > then the other two simultaneously. And that I think is the best way > to do it. If my memory is good I remember that he would do all four > corners on average in 6.5 moves. I think that for me, my next step > on improving this part of my solution would be to learn all > possibilities of solving the second two corners. > > I hope that through all of my babbling I might have helped you a > little. > > Good luck, > > -Kenneth So Kenneth, when you do the second face corners do you permute and oreint in one algorithm ? I participate in the Sunday contest often and you usually beat me by a few seconds. I'm trying to use the Waterman method but haven't learned the sequences for solving edges two at a time yet. How do you finish your last edges ? > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "stiff_hands" > <angela.hayden@n...> wrote: > > I am currently swapping from the normal jiri method to corners > first > > and wish to hear the experiences of other people on a particular > > facet of the solution method I am learning, so please reply! > > What I am interested in is the first stage of my solution: I fully > > complete one face. From years of jiri practise I can do four edges > > fast and then do the four corners fairly quickly (just like a > normal > > f2l except not bothered which pieces appear in the middle layer) so > > doing this way is <15 quite easily. What I am attempting though is > to > > do the four corners first, and then insert the centre and four > edges. > > Despite Marc Waterman suggesting this can be done in 6-7 secs on > > average I am normally doing low to mid teens for this stage (and > when > > it goes a little badly can be a lot longer). > > Has anybody else tried this both ways? Does corners then edges give > > faster times for the layer than the other way round? How fast can > you > > lot out there do the single face on a normal go and at best? Any > tips > > that might help? I seem to remember Jessica used to do one face > first > > (is that right?) so it would be interesting to know how she did it > as > > she was a fast cuber at thtat stage. > > thanks, > > stiff_hands
1936. Re: Doing one whole side as first step
From: cubacca1972 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 05 Dec 2002 01:52:08 -0000

I am currently learning a corners first method and would say that corners, then edges is faster. I worked out all 18 algs where ULB and ULF are solved, and the remaining U corners are in DRB and DRF positions. Placing the last 2 corners takes an average of 4.77 moves, ranging from 4 to 6 moves, plus 1 "alg" 1 move long (R2). I try to solve the edges of the first side as advised by Waterman (1st edge, 2nd edge with center, then last 2), but find that doing the second edge plus center somewhat tricky. I imagine that as I get better at this, I will be able to recognisethose situations where I can save moves while placing the last 2 edges. Anyhow, I Didn't like hunting for the correct corners to start the one side, so I now use Gaetan Guimond's method to get all 8 corners oriented and positioned. I can still solve the edges a la Waterman without disturbing the remaining corners, and they are already done when I finish the first side. This saves me the need to memorize the 18 (17 plus R2) algs, plus the 42 algs necessary to orient and permute the remaining corners. I think this may cost me a few moves, but it saves me a lot of grief. By the way, which slice moves work best for you? I switched from M slice moves to E slice moves, as I was finding it difficult to execute M slice moves very smoothly. Lucas --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "stiff_hands" <angela.hayden@n...> wrote: > I am currently swapping from the normal jiri method to corners first > and wish to hear the experiences of other people on a particular > facet of the solution method I am learning, so please reply! > What I am interested in is the first stage of my solution: I fully > complete one face. From years of jiri practise I can do four edges > fast and then do the four corners fairly quickly (just like a normal > f2l except not bothered which pieces appear in the middle layer) so > doing this way is <15 quite easily. What I am attempting though is to > do the four corners first, and then insert the centre and four edges. > Despite Marc Waterman suggesting this can be done in 6-7 secs on > average I am normally doing low to mid teens for this stage (and when > it goes a little badly can be a lot longer). > Has anybody else tried this both ways? Does corners then edges give > faster times for the layer than the other way round? How fast can you > lot out there do the single face on a normal go and at best? Any tips > that might help? I seem to remember Jessica used to do one face first > (is that right?) so it would be interesting to know how she did it as > she was a fast cuber at thtat stage. > thanks, > stiff_hands

1938. Re: *sigh* oh well...
From: jess_bonde <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 05 Dec 2002 03:28:30 -0000

Hi everybody.

I'm sorry I didn't discover this discussion sooner.
I've been thinking about this issue also.
It would not be fair if I had 2000 tries to break the world record.
But let me tell you that Guinness actually recognized this.
I don't know what their rules are, on one hand: I think the world
record should be the time when someone does this in good conditions
at top speed. On the other hand, the terms should be equal for
everyone, and I think the people at Guinness would get tired of us if
we all applied for a record attempt.

Here is what I plan to do:
I will start my session for 2000+ cubes at 12.00 on Dec. 16th. using
my own javascript timer. Everytime I reach 100 cubes, I will print
the results, keeping track of averages etc.
When I get a pop, I will not stop the timer, but assemble the cube
and solve it, and keep the time.
When I get a lucky time, I will stop the timer as close to my session
average as possible and accept the time, as I believe that this will
also count as a solved cube.

As for best time (I believe this is the main issue)
At 11.30 I will do 12 cubes trying to break the world record of 22.95
sec. These solves will be timed by another person with a stopwatch.
I have not consulted this with Guinness, but I think they will aprove.
This is the way a final has been announced for the WC, so I think
this is fair.
When I have done these 12 cubes, I will announce the times in my cube
log at: http://www.rubiks.dk , you can concider the best of these to
be the new world record if you want to (should it be below 22.95), I
will not assume anything before I get the recognition from Guinness.

I hope people can relate to this, otherwise feel free to speak up.

Jess.
