1945. Re: Doing one whole side as first step
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 05 Dec 2002 07:54:37 -0000


> So Kenneth, when you do the second face corners do you permute and
> oreint in one algorithm ? I participate in the Sunday contest often
> and you usually beat me by a few seconds. I'm trying to use the
> Waterman method but haven't learned the sequences for solving edges
> two at a time yet. How do you finish your last edges ?

Yes I do permute and orient in one algorithm (from
www.speedcubing.com). I too have not learned the sequences for
solving the edges two at a time, mainly because I know as soon as I
do my times will suffer dramatically. For my last edges I am slowly
learning the algs on speedcubing for simultaneously putting in the
last edge, and flipping edges in the middle layer. I found that
compared to the algorithms for the corners, they are easy to learn,
and much easier to mix up and forget.

-Kenneth




1946. Re: Doing one whole side as first step
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 05 Dec 2002 08:30:10 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., cubacca1972 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I am currently learning a corners first method and would say that > corners, then edges is faster. I worked out all 18 algs where ULB > and ULF are solved, and the remaining U corners are in DRB and DRF > positions. Placing the last 2 corners takes an average of 4.77 > moves, ranging from 4 to 6 moves, plus 1 "alg" 1 move long (R2). > > I try to solve the edges of the first side as advised by Waterman > (1st edge, 2nd edge with center, then last 2), but find that doing > the second edge plus center somewhat tricky. I imagine that as I get > better at this, I will be able to recognisethose situations where I > can save moves while placing the last 2 edges. > > Anyhow, I Didn't like hunting for the correct corners to start the > one side, so I now use Gaetan Guimond's method to get all 8 corners > oriented and positioned. I can still solve the edges a la Waterman > without disturbing the remaining corners, and they are already done > when I finish the first side. This saves me the need to memorize the > 18 (17 plus R2) algs, plus the 42 algs necessary to orient and > permute the remaining corners. I think this may cost me a few moves, > but it saves me a lot of grief. > Do you know how many moves on average it takes you to complete the corners, using Gaetan Guimond's method? > By the way, which slice moves work best for you? I switched from M > slice moves to E slice moves, as I was finding it difficult to > execute M slice moves very smoothly. I have found that M slices are great for me. I only have one move that uses E slices. It is E2 M E2 M. It took me forever to get that move down, because E moves were foreign to me. But after much practice, I like just doing that move over and over again for the heck of it. But my favorite move, using finger triggers, is U' M' U. I Do the U' with my left index, at the same time perform a R together with a M'. Then I perform an R' and then a U with my right index. So the move could be [U' (M'R)] (R' U) When done nicely it feels like you are doing two moves, U' U. -Kenneth > Lucas > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "stiff_hands" > <angela.hayden@n...> wrote: > > I am currently swapping from the normal jiri method to corners > first > > and wish to hear the experiences of other people on a particular > > facet of the solution method I am learning, so please reply! > > What I am interested in is the first stage of my solution: I fully > > complete one face. From years of jiri practise I can do four edges > > fast and then do the four corners fairly quickly (just like a > normal > > f2l except not bothered which pieces appear in the middle layer) so > > doing this way is <15 quite easily. What I am attempting though is > to > > do the four corners first, and then insert the centre and four > edges. > > Despite Marc Waterman suggesting this can be done in 6-7 secs on > > average I am normally doing low to mid teens for this stage (and > when > > it goes a little badly can be a lot longer). > > Has anybody else tried this both ways? Does corners then edges give > > faster times for the layer than the other way round? How fast can > you > > lot out there do the single face on a normal go and at best? Any > tips > > that might help? I seem to remember Jessica used to do one face > first > > (is that right?) so it would be interesting to know how she did it > as > > she was a fast cuber at thtat stage. > > thanks, > > stiff_hands
1947. Re: 4x4x4 options
From: "Grant Tregay" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 05 Dec 2002 18:57:50 -0000

Okay, since there's been so much discussion on this lately, I'll say
my bit.

I originally got a 4x4x4 from Mefferts. First thought - if you're
concerned about cost, Mefferts' 4x4x4 wins - only $18 with shipping.
Rubiks.com will charge you at least $26.88 with shipping (if you're
in the US or Canada), or a nice $38.88 with shipping for you
international folks.

However, while I was writing this up, I went to look at Mefferts.com
and they don't seem to have the 4x4x4 in their store anymore. You
can get it as part of the "Xmas special", but that one is smaller
(6cm sides) than the original (6.5cm sides), so it couldn't be used
for replacement pieces. Can anyone who has the "Xmas special" from
mefferts confirm this size difference (Compare it with another 4x4x4
cube)? Anyways, the special is $36, so this also makes Rubiks.com
the cheaper option for anyone in the US or Canada (although you get
a nice 5x5x5 with the Mefferts.com deal).

Second thought - While my original 4x4x4 broke shortly after getting
it from Mefferts, the replacement that they sent me hasn't had any
problems, and I've been using it for several months now. How have
other people had theirs break (aside from Neal, who dropped his)?
Regardless, it's not really surprising that they break so easily.
The center pieces are held on by a very small amount of plastic, and
there aren't any springs in the puzzles (as there typically are in a
3x3x3), so shock (like dropping it) and extra strain will have a
more direct affect on this small connecting section. I've changed
my method, so that slice moves (u, d, l, r, f, and b, not E, S, or
M) are virtually eliminated. If you need those slice moves, you
might want to do things like (Rr) R' instead of r, to avoid the
excess strain that they put on the centers. If you do centers last
(which you probably shouldn't do anyways ;-), this could add
considerably to your times.

Finally, I bought a new puzzle (spent the $18), but I plan to keep
the old one around to use as replacement pieces in case the new one
does break on me. I would love to share, but there are enough
people that have broken their 4x4x4 cubes that I would not have any
replacement pieces left for me (call me stingy, I guess). Someone
could go into the business of selling "replacement pieces" - buy a
4x4x4 cube from rubiks.com for the $27 and sell the 24 center pieces
for $1.25 or so (decide your own profit), plus shipping cost.

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "meat15k" wrote:
> So,
> I got my 4x4x4 a week ago, and enjoyed it for about 4 hours.
> Later that day I dropped it and it broke. I fixed all but one
> piece and managed to reassemble it for the most part. I really
> want a 4x4x4 cube. I was thinking I should either buy another
> one and use pieces from my broken 4x4x4 to fix it if the new
> one ever broke or to find a better quality cube. What's the
> best quality 4x4x4? I want to be able to use it for at least
> a month, it's rediculous how crappily made the Rubik's ones
> are. Is Meffert's a good place to look? Any ideas would be
> appreciated.
>
> Thanks,
> -Neal.

1952. Re: Doing one whole side as first step
From: cubacca1972 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 06 Dec 2002 00:46:30 -0000

>
>
> Do you know how many moves on average it takes you to complete the
> corners, using Gaetan Guimond's method?
>
> I just calculated the average as follows:

1. Get all U and D facelets on the U or D face- 3.94 moves (16 Algs)

2. Move all U facelets to U face and D to D face 3.67 moves (3 Algs)

3. Permute position corners correctly- 7.4 moves (5 Algs)

for an average of 15.01 moves. It may take 0-2 moves to get one of
the 16 initial position, and 0-1 moves to align the U and D face in
step 2.

The Worst case scenario would be 2+6+1+5+11=25 moves. The best case
scenario would be 0+3+0+3+3=9 moves, with all steps performed.

I am not sure about the frequency of each situation, so this is just
a straight average.
>
>
>
> > Lucas

layer method and stuck at 46 seconds... but oh well i wish you luck
and just thought i would give my opinion



1954. A system appropriate for a 10y old?
From: "Jessica Fridrich" <jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 06 Dec 2002 03:00:24 -0000

I received an e-mail from a 10y old Ethan:

"Hi I'm a 10 year old kid. I love the Cube I can solve it in 4
minutes. What I need is a kid friendly message to solve in 45
seconds to 2 minutes. If you could make or find me a method. I would
be very happy. Thanks, Ethan"

Could anybody recommend a suitable system and a web page? I feel
like mine is a sort of an overkill although I do realize that one
could carve out, say 8-10 simple moves for this purpose. Does anyone
have such a "downscaled" version of an advanced system on their
pages?

Thanks for help,

Jessica



1955. Re: A system appropriate for a 10y old?
From: "James Potter" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 06 Dec 2002 03:34:16 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "Jessica Fridrich" <jess340@h...> wrote: > I received an e-mail from a 10y old Ethan: > > "Hi I'm a 10 year old kid. I love the Cube I can solve it in 4 > minutes. What I need is a kid friendly message to solve in 45 > seconds to 2 minutes. If you could make or find me a method. I would > be very happy. Thanks, Ethan" > > Could anybody recommend a suitable system and a web page? I feel > like mine is a sort of an overkill although I do realize that one > could carve out, say 8-10 simple moves for this purpose. Does anyone > have such a "downscaled" version of an advanced system on their > pages? > > Thanks for help, > > Jessica You should look on the Speedcubing.com links page, they have alot of good stuff. Also, the books 'Conquer the Cube' and 'The Simple Solution to the Rubiks Cube' would probably help, but the Simple Solution book is a verry slow solution. My site might help also: http://www.geocities.com/rubiks81 I explain three different ways to solve the cube.

1957. a funny thing happened to me today.
From: "double_nubbins" <ken_murkot@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 06 Dec 2002 09:33:45 -0000

i was sitting in a restaraunt and while i was waiting for the food to
come, i was practicing on the cube. i hurt my hand really bad
earlier this year and i am trying to learn how to turn the cube with
my other hand. i moved R-U'-R with a "trigger" and the noise was
so loud it sounded like a gun being cocked. the guy at the next
table reached in and pulled out HIS gun.
So anyway, be warned....
-ken

1959. Re: *sigh* oh well...
From: yuriprt <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

There were times faster than 22.95s in competitions and they were still not accepted. According to Rubiks.com the fastest time was 16.5s. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "heretocube" <rolerknight1977@c...> wrote: > nothing against you jess or whatever i wish you the world of luck in > solving 2000 cubes in 24 hours which i am sure you will do... but i > still think that the fastest time should only be done in > competition..... there have been many times better than 22.95 but > none of them were accepted cuz they weren't in compitition... it's > not like i could beat it cuz i'm still basically using a layer by > layer method and stuck at 46 seconds... but oh well i wish you luck > and just thought i would give my opinion
1960. Re: *sigh* oh well...
From: "stiff_hands" <angela.hayden@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 06 Dec 2002 13:20:38 -0000

I met with somebody who worked with guiness book of records and
destroyed the world record for him. He was trying to encourage me to
get a couple of independent witnesses, video footage and some photo
stills of my cubing at some point in the future so that I could set
the record officially. And yes, I could have as many attempts as I
wanted.
I thought the reason none of us have done this yet is that 22.95 is a
fairly lame and easy to beat marker, and it would probably upset more
people than it impressed.
I guess it would be more legitimate after a large championship to
attempt to beat the record in that manner, but it would still be like
getting a 147 at snooker in practise (fairly routine) rather than in
competition (which would be almost never).
I have no gripes with anybody who does break the record in this
manner, but at some point the record is going to be about 6 seconds
by somebody who averages middle teens, and then the beating of the
record will only occur on freak cubes.
Since we have moved on from the days of it being an extreme sport
where the best of three attempts counted, perhaps guiness should be
encouraged to only consider averages as records. I would propose that
we do 13 cubes, discard the best time and the worst two times, and if
you pop a cubie you put it back in and continue until solved (which
means likely to be your worst time). This would also stop 'cheating
pops' when you think your average might be compromised.
Anyway, good luck Jess.
ps I am on BBC1 TV 14th Dec 09:00-12:00 on Childrens Tv. I am on a
section called "Strangely Talented" and am probably first on about
10:30.

I have a question mostly to sub 20 cubers. I have always done the
cross on top and then turned the cube 180 degrees before starting
with the F2L. Do you think I should change to doing the cross on
bottom? Would it be worth the effort?

1966. Re: [Speed cubing group] Doing the cross on the bottom or the top??
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 6 Dec 2002 23:51:36 +0100

Hi David and other friendz,

> I have a question mostly to sub 20 cubers. I have always done the
> cross on top and then turned the cube 180 degrees before starting
> with the F2L. Do you think I should change to doing the cross on
> bottom? Would it be worth the effort?
I always solve both cross and F2L on the bottom. I used to solve the cross on
top, but I had problems finding the first corner/edge pair after the cross. That
is when I started solving on the bottom, but it took me a long time to get used
to it!
Now I can solve the cross on the bottom, on the left and on top.

If I were you I would try the left or the bottom for a while.

Have fun,

Ron
http://www.speedcubing.com

1970. Re: Doing the cross on the bottom or the top??
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 07 Dec 2002 00:38:28 -0000

Doing the cross on top is (from what i've experienced) is easy but
not the greatest. I suggest to either put the cross on the bottom or
on the side. Doing the cross on top leaves you searching for the
next step a bit longer.
thats my bit
jake

1973. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Doing the cross on the bottom or the top??
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 7 Dec 2002 00:58:43 +0000

> Doing the cross on top is (from what i've experienced) is easy but
> not the greatest. I suggest to either put the cross on the bottom or
> on the side. Doing the cross on top leaves you searching for the
> next step a bit longer.
> thats my bit
> jake


I always solve white cross. I didn't learn how to do this a particular
way, so natural evolution took place. That's the best way really. My
hands decided that the left palm was better. Finally, the cross is on
the bottom. I don't pretend to do this quickly, average under 5
seconds I suppose. If I time myself I'll get a few 1-2 seconds and
some 8-9 seconds. I feel so dumb when that happens!

1975. Re: 4x4x4 options
From: "c4r7 <c4r7@...>" <c4r7@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 07 Dec 2002 18:24:47 -0000

My rubiks 4x4x4 broke the same way (I'm still waiting for the replacement)I was thinking about maybe if you lubed them it would be less friction on that little piece you were talking about. I've got the 5x5x5 still in the box. I'm afraid to open it don't want it to break getting it out of the box. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Grant Tregay" <Grant@T...> wrote: > Okay, since there's been so much discussion on this lately, I'll say > my bit. > > I originally got a 4x4x4 from Mefferts. First thought - if you're > concerned about cost, Mefferts' 4x4x4 wins - only $18 with shipping. > Rubiks.com will charge you at least $26.88 with shipping (if you're > in the US or Canada), or a nice $38.88 with shipping for you > international folks. > > However, while I was writing this up, I went to look at Mefferts.com > and they don't seem to have the 4x4x4 in their store anymore. You > can get it as part of the "Xmas special", but that one is smaller > (6cm sides) than the original (6.5cm sides), so it couldn't be used > for replacement pieces. Can anyone who has the "Xmas special" from > mefferts confirm this size difference (Compare it with another 4x4x4 > cube)? Anyways, the special is $36, so this also makes Rubiks.com > the cheaper option for anyone in the US or Canada (although you get > a nice 5x5x5 with the Mefferts.com deal). > > Second thought - While my original 4x4x4 broke shortly after getting > it from Mefferts, the replacement that they sent me hasn't had any > problems, and I've been using it for several months now. How have > other people had theirs break (aside from Neal, who dropped his)? > Regardless, it's not really surprising that they break so easily. > The center pieces are held on by a very small amount of plastic, and > there aren't any springs in the puzzles (as there typically are in a > 3x3x3), so shock (like dropping it) and extra strain will have a > more direct affect on this small connecting section. I've changed > my method, so that slice moves (u, d, l, r, f, and b, not E, S, or > M) are virtually eliminated. If you need those slice moves, you > might want to do things like (Rr) R' instead of r, to avoid the > excess strain that they put on the centers. If you do centers last > (which you probably shouldn't do anyways ;-), this could add > considerably to your times. > > Finally, I bought a new puzzle (spent the $18), but I plan to keep > the old one around to use as replacement pieces in case the new one > does break on me. I would love to share, but there are enough > people that have broken their 4x4x4 cubes that I would not have any > replacement pieces left for me (call me stingy, I guess). Someone > could go into the business of selling "replacement pieces" - buy a > 4x4x4 cube from rubiks.com for the $27 and sell the 24 center pieces > for $1.25 or so (decide your own profit), plus shipping cost. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "meat15k" wrote: > > So, > > I got my 4x4x4 a week ago, and enjoyed it for about 4 hours. > > Later that day I dropped it and it broke. I fixed all but one > > piece and managed to reassemble it for the most part. I really > > want a 4x4x4 cube. I was thinking I should either buy another > > one and use pieces from my broken 4x4x4 to fix it if the new > > one ever broke or to find a better quality cube. What's the > > best quality 4x4x4? I want to be able to use it for at least > > a month, it's rediculous how crappily made the Rubik's ones > > are. Is Meffert's a good place to look? Any ideas would be > > appreciated. > > > > Thanks, > > -Neal.

1978. Ambidextrous?
From: kyubeman <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 Dec 2002 08:48:15 -0000

I have a question: How many people in this club use their "opposite"
hand to cube with, or are better with the hand other than they write
with? I am technically "left-handed" as I write and throw with my
left hand. However, I naturally have always favored my Right hand
for solving the cube. Only recently have I started to train my left
hand for triggers, though it is my predominant hand. Am I the only
one who does this? My left hand is actually finally starting to
improve, I can do some permutations in under 3 seconds with it, and
will soon bring it up to speed. How many people here cube equally
well with either hand? Just some weird questions I have. I'm still
not sure why I have always cubed with my left hand. You'd think I'd
naturally try with my left. Then again, I am ambidextrous in many
things. I throw a frisbee with my right hand, I also kick with my
right foot *slightly* more accurately than my left foot, though both
are VERY good and very equal for soccer. Just found it odd, is all.

-Ross

1980. Re: Ambidextrous?
From: "Travis Waddell <speedcubist@...>" <speedcubist@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 Dec 2002 10:03:01 -0000

I am right handed and use my right hand for most twisting and triggers on the cube. I also use my left hand, but I'm not as good with my left hand. So, I'm kind of ambidexterous. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kyubeman <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I have a question: How many people in this club use their "opposite" > hand to cube with, or are better with the hand other than they write > with? Only recently have I started to train my left > hand for triggers, though it is my predominant hand. Am I the only > one who does this? My left hand is actually finally starting to > improve, I can do some permutations in under 3 seconds with it, and > will soon bring it up to speed. How many people here cube equally > well with either hand? Just some weird questions I have. I'm still > not sure why I have always cubed with my left hand. 1981. Re: Ambidextrous?
From: "stiff_hands <angela.hayden@...>" <angela.hayden@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 Dec 2002 11:45:14 -0000

Ross,
I would hesitate to call myself ambidextrous, maybe neither handed
would be more accurate ;) I play racket sports above the shoulder
with my right arm, and below the shoulder with my left, my writing is
unreadable with either hand, my left foot was equal to my right until
I broke my leg whence the left became dominant, I throw with my
right, snooker lefthanded, cricket right handed. When I played the
piano 15 years ago both hands were okay, but trying recently I find
my left hand has no idea. So no real pattern; no rhyme nor reason.
As regards cubing, when I started 3 years back both hands were
equally poor, but with a lot of practise my right hand is now much
better than the left. For some reason my left hand has just not
improved.
- stiff_hands






1982. Re: Ambidextrous?
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 Dec 2002 12:00:42 -0000

When I first read your question I realised that I wasn't quite sure what I did. I knew I used both hands to cube, but wasn't sure whether one was dominant. I had to run through a solution and check. Here's what I found: 1. The cross -- both hands, but right slightly hand dominant 2. Rest of F2L -- both hands, but right hand dominant 3. LL -- both hands, but LEFT hand slightly dominant I was surprised to discover that my left hand did more of the work for the most complicated part of the solution. I write with my right hand, but I can type and use a mouse equally well with both hands. I also play piano and flute, which would have helped develop digital dexterity in both hands. Jasmine. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kyubeman <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I have a question: How many people in this club use their "opposite" > hand to cube with, or are better with the hand other than they write > with? I am technically "left-handed" as I write and throw with my > left hand. However, I naturally have always favored my Right hand > for solving the cube. Only recently have I started to train my left > hand for triggers, though it is my predominant hand. Am I the only > one who does this? My left hand is actually finally starting to > improve, I can do some permutations in under 3 seconds with it, and > will soon bring it up to speed. How many people here cube equally > well with either hand? Just some weird questions I have. I'm still > not sure why I have always cubed with my left hand. You'd think I'd > naturally try with my left. Then again, I am ambidextrous in many > things. I throw a frisbee with my right hand, I also kick with my > right foot *slightly* more accurately than my left foot, though both > are VERY good and very equal for soccer. Just found it odd, is all. > > -Ross
1983. Re: Understanding algorithms
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 Dec 2002 12:27:28 -0000

Here are my thoughts on this subject... When solving, I pretty much understand what happens in F2L. I never memorised F2L algs from a website, I just kept playing with the cube until I understood how to solve F2L. For LL, I've learnt other people's algs but I don't really understand how they work. I find that when I understand how an alg works, I no longer think of it as an alg. If I think about LL, I could identify and count all the discrete algs I use. However, for F2L, I have no idea. I just do what needs to be done. Jasmine. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, gogozergus <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I recently designed from scratch all the algorithms needed for the LL > permutation step. I don't want to reinvent the wheel. I'm an engineer > and I just need to understand what I'm doing and be able to remember > these algorithms after a 10 year pause. > > Of course, I'm far from optimal sequences, some of them can take 17 > moves (R2==1 move, M==2 moves). > > I'd like to know if you, speedcubers, understand every move of every > algorithm, what it does and how it works, or if you just read it and > practice until you know it by heart? > > In http://www.speedcubing.com/algorithms.html, code P21: > L'U'LF2R'DRUR2D'R2U'F2, can you explain how this sequence was > conceived ? (ok ok, Cube Explorer ;-) > > Gilles. > > > > Yesterday, I broke my best average time with 25.23 (using only 6 algs) > :-)))
1984. Re: [Speed cubing group] Ambidextrous?
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 08 Dec 2002 16:03:27 +0000

I am actually left handed, but for some reason do quite a few mundane actions with my right hand (scissors, bottle-opening, ironing, ok not much ironing ... ). When cubing it seems to be: cross, pretty much left hand only f2l: both hands, but anything with my left hand is faster ll: left hand dominates majorly Maybe I need to start getting my right hand more involved? S. >From: kyubeman <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >Subject: [Speed cubing group] Ambidextrous? >Date: Sun, 08 Dec 2002 08:48:15 -0000 > >I have a question: How many people in this club use their "opposite" >hand to cube with, or are better with the hand other than they write >with? I am technically "left-handed" as I write and throw with my >left hand. However, I naturally have always favored my Right hand >for solving the cube. Only recently have I started to train my left >hand for triggers, though it is my predominant hand. Am I the only >one who does this? My left hand is actually finally starting to >improve, I can do some permutations in under 3 seconds with it, and >will soon bring it up to speed. How many people here cube equally >well with either hand? Just some weird questions I have. I'm still >not sure why I have always cubed with my left hand. You'd think I'd >naturally try with my left. Then again, I am ambidextrous in many >things. I throw a frisbee with my right hand, I also kick with my >right foot *slightly* more accurately than my left foot, though both >are VERY good and very equal for soccer. Just found it odd, is all. > >-Ross > _________________________________________________________________ MSN 8 with e-mail virus protection service: 2 months FREE* http://join.msn.com/?page=features/virus

2002. Re: Ambidextrous?
From: "double_nubbins <ken_murkot@...>" <ken_murkot@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 Dec 2002 07:36:32 -0000

i am a true ambidextreous. i can write, shoot, hammer, saw, pick up, put down, and hitchhike equally well. when i cube, i always would use either hand, depending on the situation. now, however, since i hurt my left hand, i have trouble forcing myself to use it. my natural tendency is to try to use my right hand and my ring and pinky fingers on my left, which must look pretty funny. (i lost my first and second fingertips in july and am still trying to learn to use them again) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kyubeman <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I have a question: How many people in this club use their "opposite" > hand to cube with, or are better with the hand other than they write > with? I am technically "left-handed" as I write and throw with my > left hand. However, I naturally have always favored my Right hand > for solving the cube. Only recently have I started to train my left > hand for triggers, though it is my predominant hand. Am I the only > one who does this? My left hand is actually finally starting to > improve, I can do some permutations in under 3 seconds with it, and > will soon bring it up to speed. How many people here cube equally > well with either hand? Just some weird questions I have. I'm still > not sure why I have always cubed with my left hand. You'd think I'd > naturally try with my left. Then again, I am ambidextrous in many > things. I throw a frisbee with my right hand, I also kick with my > right foot *slightly* more accurately than my left foot, though both > are VERY good and very equal for soccer. Just found it odd, is all. > > -Ross

2004. A different theory
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 Dec 2002 14:37:26 -0000

In my math class we are currently doing fractals, golden ratio, and
knot theory. Were supposed to do a project on either of the subject
and I'm thinking that knot theory is pretty close to what we are
doing with the cube. When the cube is scrambled its just like a
giant know or group of knots. We untangle into smaller and smaller
knots until we have a circle (solved state). I'll talk to my teacher
today and play around with the idea some more.
jake



2005. Re: A different theory
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 Dec 2002 18:13:28 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > In my math class we are currently doing fractals, golden ratio, and > knot theory. Were supposed to do a project on either of the subject > and I'm thinking that knot theory is pretty close to what we are > doing with the cube. When the cube is scrambled its just like a > giant know or group of knots. We untangle into smaller and smaller > knots until we have a circle (solved state). I'll talk to my teacher > today and play around with the idea some more. > jake Can't say that it's like a knot. I don't know too much about knots but from what I recall a knot is basically a continuous injection from S^1 into R^3 or, if you prefer a continuous map from [0,1] to R^3, injective on [0,1) and having the same image at 0 and 1. Telling if a knot is the unknot is also a difficult problem in general. Telling if the cube is solved is generally easy. You might try and see if you can find out about groups associated with knots and find a knot associated to the cube group but this is likely to be very hard and, in anyway, isn't a good idea for a project. Try a project unrelated to the cube - otherwise people might think you're obsessed with it! There are quite interesting things concerning the golden ratio that you could look into. It has connections with art and also with nature (through the Fibonacci sequence). If you ever saw "The Human Face" (BBC - John Cleese and Elizabeth Hurley probably been on US TV too, as it is out there on video and/or DVD) then the number John keeps going on about is the golden ratio (of course, after a short time he crudely cuts it off to 3 decimal places or so). If you go with knot theory an interesting idea, but possibly not one your teacher is after so maybe you should check first, is to look at generalizations, mapping S^2 continuously into R^4 for example (or more generally S^n into S^{n+2}). That's quite general and it may be quite difficult to come up with results but you might be able to generalize some of the concepts of knot theory. For instance, in R^4 every knot is equivalent to the unknot (taking a knot to be an embedding of S^1 into R^4 here). Perhaps it is true that every embedding of S^n into R^{n+3} has a similar property? Fractals are pretty cool. The most famous examples are the Mandelbrot set, the snowflake curve and the Julia sets. We had an exercise about the Mandelbrot set in first term undergraduate (or maybe it was second term - whatever, in our first topology class). Probably it was to show that it was compact (seems pretty easy off the top of my head, but maybe I am skipping details, boundedness is obvious and closure seems easy too, but I may be wrong about that) and I think connected, but connected may have been mentioned as a property rather than an exercise. That is less clear to me, so I'm not going to claim that we definitely did that. It may even be path connected, at least locally. I wonder if you might be able to combine the snowflake curve with the Fibonacci sequence in some way (in terms of dividing the sides not into thirds but into 3 pieces connected with this sequence) and hence to the golden ratio. What kind of fractal might you get? Anyway, there are a few ideas. I'm afraid my brain isn't used to much, mathematically speaking (or otherwise!), any more so they may not be good suggestions but I think they could be OK. My tip is to leave the cube out of it and save that for a group theory class. You can do a whole bunch of stuff on it there.
2006. Re: Make your own speedcube!
From: "d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@...>" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 Dec 2002 20:30:05 -0000

Hi All, I mentioned that I used graphite to lubricate the cube, there is however a small problem associated with this. The graphite doesn't stay within the cube, and gets all over my fingertips. This is lessening over time, though. If anyone's interested I'm starting to get below a minute on a regular basis. David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > Hi Ton, GameOfDeath2, > > I'm new here. PMFJI. > > Twenty years ago I got my average time down to about 27 seconds. I > am just getting back into it, at the moment I'm down to about a minute > to a minute and a half. > > Among the "not recommended" cubes on Ton's site (nice site by the > way) is the Rubik's Deluxe which came out about 20 years ago. I must > disagree with this. This cube was fast enough for the 27 second > average, and what's more it's very durable as I still use it. I > recently lubed it for the first time with graphite and it is faster, > though I'm not back up to speed yet. > > I sent off for a Hessport cube with their silicone-based lube and > it's pretty nice. If you can't buy these in England maybe you can do > it through the internet. > > Does anyone have information about the new "Deluxe Edition" put out > by Winning Moves company? Is this cube better than their regular cube? > Is their regular cube good? > > Thanks in advance > > David J > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., turnthatcube <no_reply@y...> > > wrote: > > > Hi, > > > > > > You can buy the Rubik's cube from The Rubik's Studio Hungary > > online > > > using paypal for $17.99 including shipment. This cube will make a > > > great speedcube. Use the instructions on my site how to make a > > > speedcube. > > > > > > http://members.lycos.nl/tdennenbroek/ > > > > > > See bottom on my home page, > > > > > > Kind regards, > > > Ton > > > > The only new cubes I can get in England all fall into your "not > > recommended" category, unfortunately.
2007. Re: Understanding algorithms
From: "d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@...>" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 Dec 2002 20:53:25 -0000

Hi Gilles, You asked, > I'd like to know if you, speedcubers, understand every move of every algorithm, what it does and how it works, or if you just read it and practice until you know it by heart? < I am not familiar with all of the terminology in use. What people here are calling algorithms I call sequences. I use the term algorithm for the overall approach. For example, "corners first, then edges" is an algorithm. All that I do on the cube I have figured out myself, and I understand most of it. I've just picked it up again and I'm not only remembering what I used to do, but so far I'm learning something new every day. I don't have a full set of sequences yet, but I'm working on it. The only book I read on the cube was Minh Thai's. I read it, not to learn what he did, since I saw him in person, but to see how he thought about it. Interesting read. I recommend the game he played with it. I've read a few sequences online, and they are very cool, but I must say that I consider all the levels to be equal, so I count a center slice the same as an outer level (or "side"). I also count any movement of a level as one move, so R, R2, and R' are each one move. I recommend understanding what algorithms (sequences) do, as it will give you more opportunities. David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, gogozergus <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I recently designed from scratch all the algorithms needed for the LL > permutation step. I don't want to reinvent the wheel. I'm an engineer > and I just need to understand what I'm doing and be able to remember > these algorithms after a 10 year pause. > > Of course, I'm far from optimal sequences, some of them can take 17 > moves (R2==1 move, M==2 moves). > > I'd like to know if you, speedcubers, understand every move of every > algorithm, what it does and how it works, or if you just read it and > practice until you know it by heart? > > In http://www.speedcubing.com/algorithms.html, code P21: > L'U'LF2R'DRUR2D'R2U'F2, can you explain how this sequence was > conceived ? (ok ok, Cube Explorer ;-) > > Gilles. > > > > Yesterday, I broke my best average time with 25.23 (using only 6 algs) > :-)))
2008. Re: *sigh* oh well...
From: "d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@...>" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 Dec 2002 21:24:31 -0000

Hi All, About this "World Record" attempt: For those who have been working on getting fast enough to set a new mark at the World Championship, I say ignore this "World Record" "event." A "World" record, for those who are new to language, is where people from all over the *world* compete for it. One person competing against no one else isn't even a competition, never mind a local regional, state, country, continent, or world competition. If there were something like 1000 cube mixes, even 1000 "standard" cube mixes, and people from all over got to try them simultaneously, that would be different. Do it live on TV and the internet, lots of places linked up, with 50 of the same mixes at a time given to a group at each place who actually mixed the cubes up, and have at it. Sorry for the rant, but some things that are ridiculous need to be pointed out. Comments are welcome. Thank you, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, yuriprt <no_reply@y...> wrote: > There were times faster than 22.95s in competitions and they were > still not accepted. According to Rubiks.com the fastest time was > 16.5s. > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., "heretocube" > <rolerknight1977@c...> wrote: > > nothing against you jess or whatever i wish you the world of luck > in > > solving 2000 cubes in 24 hours which i am sure you will do... but > i > > still think that the fastest time should only be done in > > competition..... there have been many times better than 22.95 but > > none of them were accepted cuz they weren't in compitition... it's > > not like i could beat it cuz i'm still basically using a layer by > > layer method and stuck at 46 seconds... but oh well i wish you > luck > > and just thought i would give my opinion
2009. [Speed cubing group] Re: my new cube..part 10
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 Dec 2002 21:30:29 -0000

My new puzzles have arrived!!! So excited!!! :) It was like Xmas -- all these new toys! I got the Mefferts Xmas package (2x2x2, 4x4x4, 5x5x5), a Megaminx and a transparent cube. :) And it did only take 2 weeks! I going to start with the 4x4x4 and leave the others alone until I solve the 4x4x4. I might see how far I can get on my own. If it gets too frustrating then I'll check out solutions online. I played with the 4x4x4 for the first time last night and managed to to all the edges, and the centres on one face. I did this several times but then kept stuffing up the whole cube trying to work out the centres. This morning I'm having trouble getting all the edges again. Maybe I was just lucky last night. I didn't think it was just luck since I was able to do it more than once. Oh well. I shall just keep working at it. The 4x4x4 was quite stiff when I pulled it out of the box, but a bit of silicon spray has fixed it. The stickers appear to be the plastic kind so the silicon spray isn't staining them (yay!) On other cube purchasing news, I bought 2 spare Maestro cubes since my first one was so good, and it's so difficult to find a good cube in Canberra, Australia. Jasmine. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cubed68 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > cool stuff,let me know what you think of your cubes.i love my 4 x 4 > from mefferts.my 5 x 5 is ok ,but i`ve never tried any other 5 x 5 > cubes so i cant compare.i would`nt even bother trying to speed cube > with it....LOL > > Peter > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I just got an email from Mefferts saying that my cubes were sent > from > > Hong Kong on 30 Nov. I might even see them on Monday then! :) > > > > Jasmine. > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@y..., cubed68 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > yeppers 10 working days from memory,so if you ordered your cubes > on > > > the 25 th they should`nt be far away > > > > > > Peter

2011. memorizing algs
From: "Sam Fontana <robot8387@...>" <robot8387@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 Dec 2002 23:43:34 -0000

does anyone have any tips for memorizing algs? when im reading them
off paper i can do them on the cube but then i dont remember or
understand what im doing. and can some one explain how to do the
inverse alg for jessicas method? and why are therea few algs for each
position. thanks for any help



2012. Re: memorizing algs
From: misleadyouth86 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 2002 00:25:18 -0000

hey sam, what i do to memorize the permutation algs is start with a solved cube... then i do one permutation alg and then its opposite to bring it back to a solved state... repeat that until you have memorized both the algs and then learn some more.... take your time though... cramming just makes you forget... as for the permutaion algs... i dont know how to memorize those either... because a new one pops up every time i solve the cube... there is no way to sit there and go through the sequences until you have memorized it... but any way i hope i have helped... =) casen --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Sam Fontana <robot8387@y...>" <robot8387@y...> wrote: > does anyone have any tips for memorizing algs? when im reading them > off paper i can do them on the cube but then i dont remember or > understand what im doing. and can some one explain how to do the > inverse alg for jessicas method? and why are therea few algs for each > position. thanks for any help
2013. Re: memorizing algs
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 2002 00:46:39 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Sam Fontana <robot8387@y...>" <robot8387@y...> wrote: > does anyone have any tips for memorizing algs? when im reading them > off paper i can do them on the cube but then i dont remember or > understand what im doing. and can some one explain how to do the > inverse alg for jessicas method? and why are therea few algs for each > position. thanks for any help When I memorize an alg. I do it one alg. at a time. I go through the different algs for that position (even look on different sights for other algs for that position) and find which ever alg I like the best. Then I do the alg over and over while looking at if from the paper and figure out finger tricks for the alg. Sooner or later I wont need to look at the paper anymore. I keep doing the alg for awhile and try to do it fast. When I can do it at top speed and dont have to think about the moves then the alg is pretty well learned. Then I go to the next alg. Sometimes i'll still have a little trouble with the alg the next day, but the alg is still 90% memorized so its eazy to go back and work the alg. again. Theres a few for each posisition because not everyone will want to learn the same alg, because not all algs fit everyones hands the same...you get that? lol It is better to actually understand the alg, but its not a must. For the F2L I understand everything im doing (mainly because i came u w/ it all myself) but in the LL I dont worry about being able to understand what happening. I just let the LL algs. be 'magic'. haha... inverse algs- ok I dont have a sheet of permutation algs infront of me BUT I do have some Orientation algs, so i'll show you the inverse of an orientation alg. R U2 R2 F R F' U2 R' F R F' for inverse you do the alg backwards and turn the side the opposite way, so that algs invere would be: F R' F' R U2 F R' F' R2 U2 R' :D......hope this helps -Heath
2014. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: *sigh* oh well...
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 2002 01:24:22 +0000

> Hi All,
>
> About this "World Record" attempt:
>
> For those who have been working on getting fast enough to set a new
> mark at the World Championship, I say ignore this "World Record"
> "event."
>
> A "World" record, for those who are new to language, is where
> people from all over the *world* compete for it. One person competing
> against no one else isn't even a competition, never mind a local
> regional, state, country, continent, or world competition.
>
> If there were something like 1000 cube mixes, even 1000 "standard"
> cube mixes, and people from all over got to try them simultaneously,
> that would be different. Do it live on TV and the internet, lots of
> places linked up, with 50 of the same mixes at a time given to a group
> at each place who actually mixed the cubes up, and have at it.
>
> Sorry for the rant, but some things that are ridiculous need to be
> pointed out.
>
> Comments are welcome.

I have a comment, and it is that I disagree. I've watched endless
world record attempts on TV and not all of them involve people from
'all over the world' competing directly. If one person can be
recognised for being the best at something, then the record can and
should stand.

However, I believe that having 2000 attempts at breaking the record is
unfair, but Jess has already put our minds at rest (right?). His
record for endurance is the one which will hopefully be proven, that's
all. If he should beat the world record on any of the 2000+ attempts,
then it can't stand because timing conditions will not have been in
place.

Jess has stated that he hopes to have a stab at the world record in a
special 'twelve' solves session. As far as I'm concerned, this is
plenty fair enough. I don't think it matters that it's not in a
competition scenario. After all, the guys that see how high they can
get by standing on the crates that they are stacking (if you follow?)
don't have a group of challengers watching and waiting to beat them.

If you think you can beat the world record and you are lucky enough to
get Guinness interested in your individual efforts, then I say good
luck to you. I think that Guinness will show more interest during the
cube revival. Good luck to Jess on his 'twelve' solves and good luck
to all the contestants who will be on the spot-light at the world
championships. I'm sure the winner will get their twelve tries too.

The pressure is most definitely; ON!



2015. Re: memorizing algs
From: "Jessica Fridrich <jess340@...>" <jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 2002 01:48:19 -0000

I included a few per position so that you can choose the one that is best for your hands. In some cases, the shortest algorithm may not be the fastest to perform, depending on how well one can handle slice moves, antislice moves, awkward moves that use 4 or 5 sides, etc. Also, the concept of "the shortest" is relative depending on how you count the moves. This is why I included the number of moves in four different countings so that you can see right away how many slices/antislices and double turns there are. I have to admit that most orientation algorithm do not make much sense to me and it is hard to explain "why" they work. I remember them in a few "macros", such as removing a corner or two, doing this and then putting them back. Or, removing a corner, doing a particular finger-shortcut and another one, etc. In my personal experience, some of the shortest algorithms are "inexplicable" and hard to explain why they work. In other words, one can find them by accident using intuition or using a computer but not by a logical thought sequence. As an example, take the shortest move for twisting three corners without moving them: R U2 R' L' B L F' L F' L B' L2 F2 Can anyone explain this one to me? I doubt. But it works, it is beautiful and you can use it in your system. On the other hand, some permutation algorithms are easy to understand because they are commutators (they have the structure ABA'B', where A and B are macros). To answer the question about inverses, they are quite easy. Just write the algorithm backwards and do backwards all the moves, too. This means F' instead of F, B instead B', B2 is, of course, the same. Good luck! Jessica --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Sam Fontana <robot8387@y...>" <robot8387@y...> wrote: > does anyone have any tips for memorizing algs? when im reading them > off paper i can do them on the cube but then i dont remember or > understand what im doing. and can some one explain how to do the > inverse alg for jessicas method? and why are therea few algs for each > position. thanks for any help
2016. Re: A different theory
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 2002 01:51:26 -0000

Wow, thanks for all the cool ideas.
I already spoke with my math teacher today, she was very thrilled
about the knot theory associated with the cube.
Im going to an art school so math isn't a hard core study. Im in the
advanced class and it is all things weve done in high school. So
pretty much if we use one of the themes and present it well, the
teacher is happy. It sucks that it isn't a challenging course but
some people are struggling with it.
ANyway... I taped some string to three edges of the cube and did a
three edge swap and came up with some interesting stuff. After you
do the three edge swap the circle becomes a trefold knot or kinda
looks like a three pointed star. A great example of what we are
looking at in our knot theory unit. Basically we weren't looking at
formulas and stuff in this unit. Our teacher just wanted us to know
of its existance and that it is important today. A virus is a
perfect example of how a knot is applied today. Basically the virus
twists, and cuts and ties our DNA so that it produces a reaction or
disease. What scientists do is come up with something that prevents
the virus to make the knot.
If you think about it the cube is not just one knot but many many
knots. Slowly we unravel each knot loop by loop until we are left
with a giant circle. It may not be applied for any usefulness
towards the cube but the cube is a good tool to demonstrate how a
knot can be twisted or untwisted. Thats all I'm trying to prove.
Jake

2020. Re: [Speed cubing group] Help! 2x2 cube came apart
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 2002 10:28:14 +0000

> I am really hoping that someone could help me. I just bought a
> Rubik's 2x2 mini cube it was sticking very badly. To make a long
> story short it came apart. I am able to assemble the top and bottom
> but I need help joining them back together. Could anyone here help me
> please?
>
> Stall
>

We'll help!!!

If you've got the cube that has eight corner pieces, a skeleton, three
sleeves and 24 slider thingies, then I had the same accident. You'll notice
that two of the 24 sliders are a different shape, these two are to go with
the fixed side of the skeleton (the side without the sleeves). Once you've
got them in place, build your whole cube, leaving one piece until last. The
last piece needs brute force I'm afraid (lots!). Please don't sue me if
something snaps though.

If you need more info, then email me direct.

I understand that there is also a 'ball' type mechanism. I don't know how
these go together. If someone knows where I can get a ball type, then let
me know! I need one for my collection!



2021. Re: [Speed cubing group] Ambidextrous?
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 2002 11:22:47 +0000

>I am completely left handed, (except for using the computer mouse).
>But for some weird reason, I cube with my right hand naturally. I've
>tried to use my left hand, but it's hard, even though I use my left
>hand for EVERYTHING. Weird, huh?
>

It is weird. I guess the left / right hand stuff is not that cut and dry,
at least in terms of cubing.

When I started cubing I wanted to get my RIGHT hand doing more things, so
started forcing myself to do all my scrambling with my right hand (afterall,
30% of cubing is spent scrambling). This helped my right hand learn
triggers quite a lot, and now it does not feel so unnatural to use my right
hand. But I still need to work on it a fair bit.

S.

2022. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Understanding algorithms
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 2002 12:03:04 +0000

> All that I do on the cube I have figured out myself

Hi David.

If I have understood you correctly, you are getting sub-minute times (which
is great: congratulations!) using a method and moves that you have developed
yourself. A few people in this club (myself included) have manged to work
out their own solutions, but I think only a few of those would have been
able to get such fast times with their own method. I am very impressed:
that's amazing! The moves I used are lost in the haze of the far more
effient moves that I found quite soon after, but my own method took four or
five minutes to complete; it was : face+layer, opposite corners, remaining
edges. It is possible to fix all the edges at the end using one algorithm
(or was it two?; sequcences in your terminology, if I understand you
correctly), and the hardest part was getting the corners the right way after
solving one side. It took me ages because I could only solve corners if
they were in one state, so I have to keep going through phases until they
were just so.

So: WOW! What is your general approach to solving the cube? And how do you
find your moves? Is it trial and error? Do you use any programs to help?

S.

PS welcome to the club, by the way! If you do not know, the chat room is
quite active on the weekends, it seems especially Sunday late afternoon /
evenings UK time. I suppose it might get even livlier at evenings US time,
but I would never know!

PPS what is this "game" that you recommend?

Sorry to post so many questions...

2024. Re: [Speed cubing group] Understanding algorithms
From: gogozergus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 2002 14:31:23 -0000

Thanks for your answers. I asked this question because it's *very* difficult for me to remember algorithms (or sequences) I do not understand. Don't know exactly why. Maybe because my mind is just not good for this. Or I'm psychologicaly stuck because I don't like this way of thinking. The image you propose is good. Algorithms are like words, with a meaning of their own. But when I speak, I always think about the words I use too, they never come naturaly. An advantage of understanding what I do on the 3x3x3: Today I received a Megaminx, and had no problem applying similar techniques and solved it quite fast. But don't misunderstand me, I really would like to be able to learn and remember tons of mystic sequences! Gilles. PS: I broke my record yesterday: 15 seconds. Ok, that was a lucky cube ;-) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "simonl cube" <simonlcube@h...> wrote: > > You say how for each algorithm you want / need to understand what each > algorithm does, down (I think) to every move. I find this interesting > because it is the complete opposite of how I cube, and the antithesis of my > final goal. For me the execution of the orientation and permutation > algorithms are almost completely a tactile action during which the > algorithms are experienced as single events. If I try to split an algorithm > down to separete moves my mind does not really come up with the goods (try > saying the alphabet backwards: the knowledge is there, but not easily > retrieved). > > It is bit like reading: when you start learning to read you might need to > divide words into their syllables, or even the letter-components, but over > time you read words as single entities (except very long words, perhaps, if > they are new to you). The same goes for the cube: the algorithms that you > learn becomes your "cube-language", comprised of single moves (letters) that > may or may not sit together as triggers (syllables); these make algorithms > (words) which work together to form complete solutions (sentences / > narratives). > > As I become more fluent in this language, combining words into meaningful > sentences (i.e. flowing algorithms together to solve the cube), so solving > the cube becomes more natural, and takes less time. > > So for me, the whole goal is to move away from a deconstructed knowledge of > any algorithm, and instead aim for the opposite: to "flatten out" my > awareness until solving the cube is experienced as a single action (and > hopefully, one day, one that takes less than 20 seconds to complete!). > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@y...>" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > Hi Gilles, > > You asked, > I'd like to know if you, speedcubers, understand every > move of every algorithm, what it does and how it works, or if you just > read it and practice until you know it by heart? < > > I am not familiar with all of the terminology in use. What people > here are calling algorithms I call sequences. I use the term algorithm > for the overall approach. For example, "corners first, then edges" is > an algorithm. > > All that I do on the cube I have figured out myself, and I > understand most of it. I've just picked it up again and I'm not only > remembering what I used to do, but so far I'm learning something new > every day. I don't have a full set of sequences yet, but I'm working > on it. > > The only book I read on the cube was Minh Thai's. I read it, not to > learn what he did, since I saw him in person, but to see how he > thought about it. Interesting read. I recommend the game he played > with it. > > I've read a few sequences online, and they are very cool, but I > must say that I consider all the levels to be equal, so I count a > center slice the same as an outer level (or "side"). I also count any > movement of a level as one move, so R, R2, and R' are each one move. > > I recommend understanding what algorithms (sequences) do, as it > will give you more opportunities. > > David J > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Here are my thoughts on this subject... > > When solving, I pretty much understand what happens in F2L. I never > memorised F2L algs from a website, I just kept playing with the cube > until I understood how to solve F2L. For LL, I've learnt other > people's algs but I don't really understand how they work. I find > that when I understand how an alg works, I no longer think of it as > an alg. If I think about LL, I could identify and count all the > discrete algs I use. However, for F2L, I have no idea. I just do what > needs to be done. > > Jasmine. >
2025. Re: [Speed cubing group] Ambidextrous?
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 2002 15:06:35 -0000

Just to add my own experience to this. I cube mostly right handed, though I'm trying to teach my left hand to do more. Right now I'm purposely trying to learn certain algorithms strictly left hand to try to balance it out and train my left hand. Anyway so I'm very right hand dominant when I cube, but when I do the cube one handed my left hand is significantly faster than my right almost every time. I can get some good times with my right, but it feels very clunky and I lock up the cube a lot. However I can achieve really smooth turning with my left. So now I always cube with my left hand if I'm doing it one handed. Strange how this handedness isn't very straight forward. It's kinda cool that way though. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > If you are curious about other people's thoughts on this, then look here: > > http://www.aol.drspock.com/discussion/message/0,1812,29610,00.html > > They are non-cubers, so it gives another angle.
2026. Re: [Speed cubing group] Ambidextrous?
From: "Grant Tregay <Grant@...>" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 2002 15:56:49 -0000

Wow, this totally describes me, Chris! I thought I was the only
right-hand dominant cubist who did the one handed cube lefty :P
It's good to hear that I'm not alone! Although I noticed that in
a video of you solving one handed, it was done with your right hand.
Is this something that changed after a while? Anyway, I even have
the same experience that one handed with my right hand is just
"clunky" and locks up. I wonder if it has anything to do with the
fact that as I'm solving normally, the right hand typically does
larger, less precise movements (e.g. triggers), and the left hand
is responsible for alignment of over/under triggers and such.

2029. Re: Help! 2x2 cube came apart
From: "stallback2000 <stallback2000@...>" <stallback2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 2002 18:41:38 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: >> We'll help!!! > > If you've got the cube that has eight corner pieces, a skeleton, three > sleeves and 24 slider thingies, then I had the same accident. You'll notice > that two of the 24 sliders are a different shape, these two are to go with > the fixed side of the skeleton (the side without the sleeves). Once you've > got them in place, build your whole cube, leaving one piece until last. The > last piece needs brute force I'm afraid (lots!). Please don't sue me if > something snaps though. > > If you need more info, then email me direct. > > I understand that there is also a 'ball' type mechanism. I don't know how > these go together. If someone knows where I can get a ball type, then let > me know! I need one for my collection! Thanks so much Robert!!! I got it back together just as you described. One small note though, my cube only has only 12 sliders, 8 corner pieces, a skeleton and 3 sleeves. When I was down to the last piece I simply slipped the corner piece in position and slid the piece over the sliders and onto the corner piece. Worked great. Thanks again!! Stall
2030. Re: A different theory
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 2002 20:41:03 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Wow, thanks for all the cool ideas. > I already spoke with my math teacher today, she was very thrilled > about the knot theory associated with the cube. > Im going to an art school so math isn't a hard core study. Im in the > advanced class and it is all things weve done in high school. So > pretty much if we use one of the themes and present it well, the > teacher is happy. It sucks that it isn't a challenging course but > some people are struggling with it. > ANyway... I taped some string to three edges of the cube and did a > three edge swap and came up with some interesting stuff. After you > do the three edge swap the circle becomes a trefold knot or kinda > looks like a three pointed star. A great example of what we are > looking at in our knot theory unit. Basically we weren't looking at > formulas and stuff in this unit. I guess that's pretty cool. Here are some other ideas: I suppose the question that could be asked then is if you tape string to different parts of the cube what knots and links are possible by mixing the cube up. In particular, you could try messing the cube up and solving it (possibly in a simplistic way such as doing a 3 cycle 3 times. Is the result the unknot or not? I guess that's the sort of direction you might go with this. Does the "unseen" twisting of centres have any effect? You could also look at links. Is it possible to jam the cube in some way (i.e. it can't twist anymore because of the knotting going on around it). Which positions aren't possible? These last two questions may be quite difficult to answer of course. Here's another, probably difficult question: how many isomorphism classes of knots can be so obtained? (Isomorphism in the category of knots, to be more specific.) If you've got a 4x4x4 you could look at doing the same sort of thing there too. Then the really good questions would come from looking at nxnxn cubes and seeing what kind of results are possible. You could also try higher dimensional analogues with tesseracts and so forth. Provided the string is attached to different pieces, does the end result depend on the point of the piece to which you attach the end of the string? Can you find a continuous [0,1]-indexed sequence of homeomorphisms (I can't remember what that's called - perhaps isotopic, I'll check and confirm some other time) that show they are equivalent, if indeed they are? What are the possible linking numbers of the knots? (PS On the Golden ratio I forgot to mention that the ratio does not depend on the starting points of the Fibonacci sequence (if you define it like this), at least provided the product of the two initial values is non-negative (and the sum positive). Other Fibonacci type sequences have similar results with different ratios. Probably, though I haven't looked into it, if you look at linear difference equations with constant coefficients (and zero constant term) such that the characteristic equation doesn't have repeated roots - and actually quite possibly if it does, if my brain is working)) hen you could achieve similar results. I mention this as an aside because I don't think you are going to do the golden ratio.) >Our teacher just wanted us to know > of its existance and that it is important today. A virus is a > perfect example of how a knot is applied today. Basically the virus > twists, and cuts and ties our DNA so that it produces a reaction or > disease. What scientists do is come up with something that prevents > the virus to make the knot. > If you think about it the cube is not just one knot but many many > knots. Slowly we unravel each knot loop by loop until we are left > with a giant circle. It may not be applied for any usefulness > towards the cube but the cube is a good tool to demonstrate how a > knot can be twisted or untwisted. Thats all I'm trying to prove. > Jake
2031. Re: A different theory
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 2002 20:52:38 -0000


Homotopic. I assume an isotopism would be a homotopism with a
continuous inverse but it seems clear that here there would be a
continuous inverse if there was a homotopism so that if they were
homotopic they'd be isotopic too.

One person competing > > against no one else isn't even a competition, never mind a local > > regional, state, country, continent, or world competition. > > > > If there were something like 1000 cube mixes, even 1000 "standard" > > cube mixes, and people from all over got to try them simultaneously, > > that would be different. As far as I'm concerned, this is > plenty fair enough. I don't think it matters that it's not in a > competition scenario. After all, the guys that see how high they can > get by standing on the crates that they are stacking (if you follow?) > don't have a group of challengers watching and waiting to beat them. > > If you think you can beat the world record and you are lucky enough to > get Guinness interested in your individual efforts, then I say good > luck to you. If it's something cube-related, then it's probably something you'd be interested in learning anyway, if it means that you also get an assignment out of the way the BONUS! 2036. the cube improves learning capabilities
From: misleadyouth86 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 00:09:26 -0000

you know... this year i just started to rapidly understand math and
chemistry and all of the equations come so easily now... i dont even
have to try to get an A+.... and coincidentily i just started doing
the cube this year.... and ive noticed the faster i can do the
cube... the faster i understand new math concepts and the faster i
can crank out my homework... so you see the cube is a valuable brain
expanding device ... i can only imagine how fast jessica fridrick and
dan knight are at doin algebra equations.. haha... anyhow... just
though i would say somethin..

casen



2037. Theoretical fastest average
From: cubacca1972 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 00:39:51 -0000

When solving for speed, it seems like there is a zen like state where
you just know what to do, there are no delays between algs, etc.

I am curious to know how fast the cube can be solved if you are
presented with a cube scrambled exactly the same way over and over
again.

How fast could you solve it? What kind of average is possible?

As this is no longer a case of a randomly scrambled cube, it is only
a theoretical average.

I took this mixing alg from Jess Bonde's timer app:

B' L2 U B' D L' B R' F' L' F2 U B2 D' F D' U2 F2
R' D' L R' B U' D2

and will practice solving it over and over.

I would be curious to see what kind of times would be generated, and
also to see if people using the same method (eg, F2L) would end up
with the same LL, end stage or same number of moves.

Lucas



2038. Re: Theoretical fastest average
From: "James Potter <theboywholived81@...>" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 01:04:32 -0000

I know exactly what you mean. I don't even pay attention most of the time when I'm cubing, I just look at the cube, then my hands do the work. It will be interesting to see the results of that experiment you're doing. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cubacca1972 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > When solving for speed, it seems like there is a zen like state where > you just know what to do, there are no delays between algs, etc. > > I am curious to know how fast the cube can be solved if you are > presented with a cube scrambled exactly the same way over and over > again. > > How fast could you solve it? What kind of average is possible? > > As this is no longer a case of a randomly scrambled cube, it is only > a theoretical average. > > I took this mixing alg from Jess Bonde's timer app: > > B' L2 U B' D L' B R' F' L' F2 U B2 D' F D' U2 F2 > R' D' L R' B U' D2 > > and will practice solving it over and over. > > I would be curious to see what kind of times would be generated, and > also to see if people using the same method (eg, F2L) would end up > with the same LL, end stage or same number of moves. > > Lucas
2039. working on something new
From: "heretocube <rolerknight1977@...>" <rolerknight1977@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 02:10:38 -0000

well not many people on here know me yet but if you don't mind i'd
like to give a progress report on my cubing.. current ave for me is
56 seconds and pb of 43 seconds... i use a layer by layer method
basically... i tried learning to solve cross on bottom but ended up
going with cross on left and seems easier than cross on top cuz i can
see what is going on... i'm pretty much used to that now and am
starting to learn some of the corner/edge algs for F2L... well wish
me luck... i have vactation next week and i think i can get a lot in
then... see everyone around...
