2042. Re: [Speed cubing group] Ambidextrous?
From: cubin4speed <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 03:07:00 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Grant Tregay <Grant@T...>" <Grant@T...> wrote: wonder if it has anything to do with the > fact that as I'm solving normally, the right hand typically does > larger, less precise movements (e.g. triggers), and the left hand > is responsible for alignment of over/under triggers and such. I totally agree with your reasoning. I find it very hard to do triggers with my left hand, and I always assumed that my left hand was just not precise enough. However, after further analysis, I realized that when a left-handed trigger move got blocked, it was usually my right hand's fault for not maintaining proper alignment of the cube! For the first 3 years of my speed-cubing interest, my cubing was completely dominated by my right hand. Everything else that I do in life is right handed, including playing the guitar... which actually means that my LEFT hand is the one on the fret board. After playing guitar for nearly 13 years, my left hand is capable of playing really fast and intricate riffs. So for the last 5 or 6 months, I have been training my left hand on the cube. This has been really frustrating, but now I can do pretty much everything "lefty" as well. I think this is definitely the best way to solve, and I am sure that given enough time my left hand will become almost as good as my right... I just hope it doesn't take 13 years!
2043. Re: Theoretical fastest average
From: redkbrandon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 03:53:42 -0000

> B' L2 U B' D L' B R' F' L' F2 U B2 D' F D' U2 F2
> R' D' L R' B U' D2
>
> and will practice solving it over and over.
>
> I would be curious to see what kind of times would be generated,
and
> also to see if people using the same method (eg, F2L) would end up
> with the same LL, end stage or same number of moves.

Well I thought that was pretty interesting so here is what I came up
with. I did an average of that scramble Here is what i got:

1. 30 2. 28 3. 24 4. 22 5. 21 6. 22 7. 23 8. 20 9. 21 10. 19 11. 20
12. 21

I was practically sleeping when I started that is why I got that 30,
but I think if I did another 12 on the same scramble, I would get
20.9 average. I normally average in the high 25s. I thought it
would be cool to see how other people do on this scramble. Here is
how I fixed it:

1. F' U F2 Top Corners 1sec
2. M' E R U' M U R2 (R2M2L) U M U' First Three Edges 4sec
3. [U2 L U' R2 U L' U' R2 U'] Bottom Corners 4sec
4. (L'R') F' M F (M'R') F M' F' R' F' M' F2 M2 F' R'3 Bottom Edges
6sec
5. (M2R2)F M2 F2 M F Simultaneously put last two edges in 3sec
6. (RL) [U' M' U M' U2 M U M U M U2 M' U2] Flip edges in M layer 3sec

(R'3 is = to R' R' R') I did this so I do not have to rotate the cube.

It took me forever to figure the notation out. But here is how I
solve the cube fast. It would be different if I were doing it for
fewer turns.

Step 3 is a memorized move off of speedcubing.com
Step 6 is kind of a self-taught memorized move

I am working on learning algs to get rid of step 6. I think the algs
would drop off about 14 moves on this solve and 3 sec on this
average. Which would mean I would be averaging almost 17s for this
scramble! That is good motivation to keep working on learning algs.

Anyway anyone want to count my moves for this solve?

A nice count would be like 59 if you count things like (L'R') R2 M,
and M2 as one move. A mean count would be like 100, if you count R2
and M as two moves and M2 as four. So how many moves is this?

Well enough putting it off I must study for finals!

-Kenneth



2044. Re: Theoretical fastest average
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 04:10:12 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cubacca1972 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > When solving for speed, it seems like there is a zen like state where > you just know what to do, there are no delays between algs, etc. > > I am curious to know how fast the cube can be solved if you are > presented with a cube scrambled exactly the same way over and over > again. > > How fast could you solve it? What kind of average is possible? > > As this is no longer a case of a randomly scrambled cube, it is only > a theoretical average. > > I took this mixing alg from Jess Bonde's timer app: > > B' L2 U B' D L' B R' F' L' F2 U B2 D' F D' U2 F2 > R' D' L R' B U' D2 > > and will practice solving it over and over. > > I would be curious to see what kind of times would be generated, and > also to see if people using the same method (eg, F2L) would end up > with the same LL, end stage or same number of moves. > > Lucas Well Lucas, looks like my "zen like state" is 19 seconds. I did just what you were saying. I did an average of that scramble you posted (and I almost know it by heart now :S) haha. First I just speed solved the cube, and I got a time of 27.2 seconds. Then I went back through the cube until I figured out exactly how I solved it the first time (one move took FOREVER to figure out how I did it, because there was another way that I thought I had done it when I was going back through it) lol. After knowing exactly what I did the first time I solved it, I speed solved it again a couple times, (21 and 20 seconds)...then I felt I was ready to take an average on it. times were : 18,18,20,19,18,(20),19,(17),19,18,18,18 =18.5+.5 =19 I dont know why I took an average of 12 lol, should of just did 10. oh well. I even wrote down ALL the moves I used to solve. Moves were as follows: 2x2x2: x z' (R' U2 R2 L2 U2) 2X2X3: (D2 R) y (L' F2 L D2 U F U') next corner/edge pair(w/ last top edge):(R D) z2 y' (R U R' U' R U R') last corner/edge pair: z2 (D2 R' D' R D R' D' R D2) y (L D' L') OLL alg: z2 (L F L' R U R' U' L F' L') PLL alg: y' (B2 L U L' B2) x' (R B' R B R2) Just some #'s: total moves = 57 turns per second on very first solve = 2.1 turns per second on average = 3 time wasted looking for pieces in very first solve = 8.2 % of time looking for pieces = 30% I put all the moves so maybe you guys ( if you wanted) could check out exactly what I do if your not for sure. Umm... I dont really know why I put those #'s lol .enjoy!. p.s. I guess what this means is that even if I cut out all my time looking for pieces some of you guys are STILL faster than me. So I will have to cut LOTS of time off from looking for pieces AND improve on my system if I wanna catch up to you guys.

2046. A different approach
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 16:20:10 +1100

Here I describe a new approach to solving the cube.

--
(Hopefully this will display in a fixed-width font)

First, build a 2x2x2 block (as in the petrus method)

- - -
- - -
- - -

- - - - - - - - - - - -
- - - - o o o o - - - -
- - - - o o o o - - - -

- o o
- o o
- - -

Then, attach three 2x2x1 blocks.

one:

- - -
- x x
- x x

- - - - x x x x - - - -
- - - - o o o o - - - -
- - - - o o o o - - - -

- o o
- o o
- - -

two:

- - -
- x x
- x x

- - - - x x x x - - - -
- x x x o o o o - - - -
- x x x o o o o - - - -

x o o
x o o
- - -

three:

- - -
- x x
- x x

- - - - x x x x - - - -
- x x x o o o o x x x -
- x x x o o o o x x x -

x o o
x o o
- x x

This much can be achieved without any memorised move sequences, and leaves 4
corners and 3 edges to solve (forming a tripod shape). There are only two
possibilities for edge orientations. One is when they are already oriented,
and the other is when two need to be flipped - this case can be done in only 4
moves (or sometimes 3 if you join with the previous step).

>From here, it is just a matter of how to stage the final step. How many
different configurations are possible after the edges have been oriented? How
many after the edges have been oriented AND permuted?

The tripod shape seems to have three advantages:

1. It gives you more maneuverability (see for example how easily the edges can
be oriented)
2. There is one less edge to worry about than in the "last layer" approach.
3. The remaining configurations may be more symmetrical, resulting in less
sequences to memorise.

Now, one reason for writing this email is that I would like to write a program
that will calculate the number of possible cube positions given certain
constraints. First, there are the natural constraints of the cube which are
always present. Then, there are user imposed constraints. Finally the program
should filter out any positions that are symmetrical with existing positions.
If anyone would like to help me with this program, (particularly the
mathematical side of it), please send me an email to rheise@...

Ryan


2047. Possible improvement
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 16:33:50 +1100

I have thought of a possible improvement that may apply to more than
just one method.

To demonstrate, consider the petrus method:

1. solve a 2x2x3 block
2. complete the first two layers by adding a 3x2x1 slice
3. complete the last layer

One approach for step 2 is:

a. build a 2x2x1 section
b. add on a 1x2x1 section

For (a), you can choose between 4 starting points and pick the easiest one. If
you find a good one, it can be done in 2, 3 or 4 moves. Otherwise it can take
about 8 moves. Sometimes there are no good options among the 4 starting
points.

But now consider that there are actually 8 different 3x2x1 slices to choose
from in step 2. The slice you choose doesn't have to join with step 1 with
matching colours, it just needs to be the same shape. In the final step, you
can slide this slice back to where it should go in just one move.

This gives you 8 different options for step 2a, greatly increasing your
chances of finding a good option.

Once you get to the final layer, you have to be able to recognise all the
patterns with three of the pieces being a different colour, but it's not as
difficult as you might think - try it. Of course, some systems for the last
layer may be easier to handle than others.

This idea also applies, with more opportunities, in the tripod approach
described in my last email.

Ryan


2048. Re: A different approach
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 17:01:37 +1100

On Wed, Dec 11, 2002 at 04:20:10PM +1100, Ryan Heise wrote:

> (Hopefully this will display in a fixed-width font)

If you viewed this through the Yahoo! Groups web page, it would not have
displayed correctly. The diagrams are of cube configurations. The middle
row of each diagram shows 4 faces (LFRB). The top and bottom rows show
the top and bottom faces (U and D). They should be right-shifted to
align with the F face.

Ryan


2049. Re: [Speed cubing group] Theoretical fastest average
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Dec 2002 23:28:30 -0800

This was a lot of fun! Don't know why I haven't ever thought of doing something like this before. I spent a few minutes trying to find the best possible solution by solving it several times slowly and checking all the alternatives. I've never ever done that either before! I found a really good solution (see below) pretty soon. After ~10 times I was ready to time it. It took ~5 tries to get down to a plateau of 14-15 seconds. But it really didn't feel very zen. It took ~10 more attempts until things suddenly started flowing as they should, and I was doing 12-12.5 seconds. I used the Bonde Timer. I really don't know how you guys handle the notation! It just doesn't mix with my cubing brain. I got the wrong result 1/3 of the time. This is why I did my animation applet... When you do this, you really notice any deficiencies in your cube! My solution: (The steps bleed into each other a bit) 1. 2x2x2 B' L2 F2 2. 2x2x3 U2 L2 3. twist edges U' B F' L' F 4. 2x3x3 U2 L2 U2 L' 5+6. twist & place corners B' U F2 U' B U F2 U2 7. place edges L' D2 L F' B D2 F B' L D2 32 moves in 12.5 sec is 2.6 moves/sec. Someone else can probably do the same solution faster? That would be fun. There are 5(!) 12 turn solutions for the final layer position, instead of the 18 turn one I used, so you can get it down to 26-27 moves that way. See position 40 at http://www.ai.univ-paris8.fr/~bhelmste/cube/solutions_567.html I also made an animation for it, since I had to anyway to figure out the notation. It will be at http://lar5.com/cube/zen.html as soon as my ISPs ftp server is up again. /Lars At 0:39 +0000 12/11/02, cubacca1972 wrote: >When solving for speed, it seems like there is a zen like state where >you just know what to do, there are no delays between algs, etc. > >I am curious to know how fast the cube can be solved if you are >presented with a cube scrambled exactly the same way over and over >again. > >How fast could you solve it? What kind of average is possible? > >As this is no longer a case of a randomly scrambled cube, it is only >a theoretical average. > >I took this mixing alg from Jess Bonde's timer app: > >B' L2 U B' D L' B R' F' L' F2 U B2 D' F D' U2 F2 >R' D' L R' B U' D2 > >and will practice solving it over and over. > >I would be curious to see what kind of times would be generated, and >also to see if people using the same method (eg, F2L) would end up >with the same LL, end stage or same number of moves. > >Lucas > > >To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: >speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > >Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the ><http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/>Yahoo! Terms of Service. -- "They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever flipped it over?" Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@... http://lar5.com [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
2050. Re: [Speed cubing group] Theoretical fastest average
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>

Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 10:25:38 +0000

> My solution:
> (The steps bleed into each other a bit)
>
> 1. 2x2x2 B' L2 F2
> 2. 2x2x3 U2 L2
> 3. twist edges U' B F' L' F
> 4. 2x3x3 U2 L2 U2 L'
> 5+6. twist & place corners B' U F2 U' B U F2 U2
> 7. place edges L' D2 L F' B D2 F B' L D2
>
> 32 moves in 12.5 sec is 2.6 moves/sec. Someone else can probably do
> the same solution faster? That would be fun.
>

WOW! Lars, that really shows the amazing efficiency in your method! It's
not many moves more than the scrambling alg!

2054. Re: [Speed cubing group] Ambidextrous?
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 14:35:04 -0000

As I mentioned in a previous post on this topic, there are many
things I do with both hands. I am, however, right-handed and so my
right hand is always better than, or at least no worse than, my left
hand. Bizarrely though, my left hand is the one I naturally use when
clicking my fingers. My right hand is very bad at clicking fingers,
and it feels quite unnatural, much like holding a pen in my left hand.

Jasmine.



2055. Re: my new cube..part 10
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 15:02:33 -0000

I was able to get all edges + centres on one face + half centres on many other faces, fairly quickly. Over the last 2 days I hadn't really progressed beyond that though. :( I didn't really know what I was doing. I remembered there had been some debate a little while ago about whether it was better to do edges first or centres first, but I couldn't remember what the consensus had been. I hadn't paid too much attention to those posts because I didn't have a 4x4x4 at that point. Anyway, I just started playing and realised that my natural instinct was to start solving edges first. After two days and not much progress, I decided to look around at different approaches to see if a different method would suit me better. I found that with the regular cube doing cross->F2L->LL fits in my brain better than 2x2x2->2x2x3->F2L->LL, so I wondered if a different 4x4x4 approach might help. I read the intro stuff to Chris H's revenge solution and had a go at centres first. I was trying really hard to resist looking up solutions, and just read ideas instead and see what I could do with them. Unfortunately, I have little will power with these things :/ I ended up reading a few of the algs on Chris' page. Not many though, only 4 or 5 to get me started. I'll try and resist looking at it again for a little while and play around with a centres first approach. (I didn't actually memorise any of Chris' algs, I just tried a few of them once.) So yes, my 4x4x4 is now solved, but unfortunately I can't say that it was entirely my own work. :/ I'm going to leave the 5x5x5 until I have the 4x4x4 under control. After the 5x5x5, I'll move on to the megaminx. I've never played with a skewb diamond. I have a regular skewb (somewhere!) and found it to be rather unimpressive. The diamond looks a bit more exciting though. Jasmine. BTW, Chris, I found your revenge solution easy to follow (well, the bits I looked at anyway). --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Have you solved your 4x4 yet? 2061. Re: my new cube..part 10
From: "Grant Tregay <Grant@...>" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 16:44:44 -0000

If you're looking at doing the puzzles in order of difficulty, I'd
skip to the megaminx before going on to the 5x5x5. Well, maybe I'm
thinking about time to solve, and not actual solution difficulty,
but still...

I don't have a 5x5x5, but I've solved one more than enough times on
oinkleburger (along with even larger cubes). My latest average (on
a real cube, not an applet) for the 4x4x4 was about 20 seconds
faster than what my posted megaminx average time is (although I
think my megaminx time is probably 10-15 seconds better now),
while I anticipate the 5x5x5 will take me another 1-2 minutes, at
least (once I get mine for Christmas and get it lubed and broken
in).

The only actual time reference I have is someone else here, who
recently got a 5x5x5 and took over or close to 1/2 hour to solve
it the first few times, even though he could solve the 4x4x4 in
under 3 minutes. I do know, however, that he's gotten that time
down to something under 10 minutes, which is closer to where my
megaminx times started, once I had the solution down.

2063. [Speed cubing group] Re: *sigh* oh well...
From: "d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@...>" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 17:25:36 -0000

Hi Robert, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > > Hi All, > > > > About this "World Record" attempt: > > > > For those who have been working on getting fast enough to set a new > > mark at the World Championship, I say ignore this "World Record" > > "event." > > > > A "World" record, for those who are new to language, is where > > people from all over the *world* compete for it. One person competing > > against no one else isn't even a competition, never mind a local > > regional, state, country, continent, or world competition. > >[snip] > > Comments are welcome. > > I have a comment, and it is that I disagree. I've watched endless > world record attempts on TV and not all of them involve people from > 'all over the world' competing directly. If one person can be > recognised for being the best at something, then the record can and > should stand. Thanks for your response. Please allow me to clarify a point or two. I was addressing the "fastest solve" record not the "average" solve record. I'm sorry I didn't make that clear. I take your point. There is, however, a difference in the kinds of records. If the record you're going after is how long it takes to solve 2000 randomly mixed cubes, then this can be tried by anyone at anytime. This is scattershot and there is a law of large numbers that means that the random mixes in large enough numbers are reasonably similar...probably. > > However, I believe that having 2000 attempts at breaking the record is > unfair, but Jess has already put our minds at rest (right?). We agree on this. > His > record for endurance is the one which will hopefully be proven, that's > all. > If he should beat the world record on any of the 2000+ attempts, > then it can't stand because timing conditions will not have been in > place. > > Jess has stated that he hopes to have a stab at the world record in a > special 'twelve' solves session. As far as I'm concerned, this is > plenty fair enough. This is where we differ. > I don't think it matters that it's not in a > competition scenario. After all, the guys that see how high they can > get by standing on the crates that they are stacking (if you follow?) > don't have a group of challengers watching and waiting to beat them. You are right, they don't, but they have a reliable and enforceable standard of measuring height. In my view the "12 solves" fails this fairness test for at least two reasons. One is because there is no standard of measurment for isolated tries. It can only be fair if anyone who is tested faces the same challenge (not a seemingly similar challenge) and faces *unknown* mixes. This problem is partly because there is no way to agree upon a "blind" set of mixes that anyone can try at another time. There is no way to keep that "blind" set of mixes secret, and if they are not secret they can be analysed and practiced. Another reason is that the "12 solves" do not meet the "same challenge" requirement is because the number is too small. IMO it's simple not a large enough random sample. Someone could meet up with several mixes that happen to fit well with his or her style. Understand that I'm not knocking Jess' efforts or talent. I don't think it's fair for Guinness to wait until the end to time 12 cubes. In sport world records are usually set when the athlete is fresh. This is like telling a runner go run 30 miles then we'll time you in the mile. This is not to say that this Guinness "World Record" event can't be fun, I'm just saying that it need not take the wind out of the sails of those who have been working hard to beat the world record at next year's official competition. Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > > Hi All, > > > > About this "World Record" attempt: > > > > For those who have been working on getting fast enough to set a new > > mark at the World Championship, I say ignore this "World Record" > > "event." > > > > A "World" record, for those who are new to language, is where > > people from all over the *world* compete for it. One person competing > > against no one else isn't even a competition, never mind a local > > regional, state, country, continent, or world competition. > > > > If there were something like 1000 cube mixes, even 1000 "standard" > > cube mixes, and people from all over got to try them simultaneously, > > that would be different. Do it live on TV and the internet, lots of > > places linked up, with 50 of the same mixes at a time given to a group > > at each place who actually mixed the cubes up, and have at it. > > > > Sorry for the rant, but some things that are ridiculous need to be > > pointed out. > > > > Comments are welcome. > > I have a comment, and it is that I disagree. I've watched endless > world record attempts on TV and not all of them involve people from > 'all over the world' competing directly. If one person can be > recognised for being the best at something, then the record can and > should stand. > > However, I believe that having 2000 attempts at breaking the record is > unfair, but Jess has already put our minds at rest (right?). His > record for endurance is the one which will hopefully be proven, that's > all. If he should beat the world record on any of the 2000+ attempts, > then it can't stand because timing conditions will not have been in > place. > > Jess has stated that he hopes to have a stab at the world record in a > special 'twelve' solves session. As far as I'm concerned, this is > plenty fair enough. I don't think it matters that it's not in a > competition scenario. After all, the guys that see how high they can > get by standing on the crates that they are stacking (if you follow?) > don't have a group of challengers watching and waiting to beat them. > > If you think you can beat the world record and you are lucky enough to > get Guinness interested in your individual efforts, then I say good > luck to you. I think that Guinness will show more interest during the > cube revival. Good luck to Jess on his 'twelve' solves and good luck > to all the contestants who will be on the spot-light at the world > championships. I'm sure the winner will get their twelve tries too. > > The pressure is most definitely; ON!
2064. [Speed cubing group] Re: Understanding algorithms
From: "d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@...>" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 17:30:41 -0000

Hi Simon, > > All that I do on the cube I have figured out myself < < > If I have understood you correctly, you are getting sub-minute times (which is great: congratulations!) using a method and moves that you have developed yourself. < That's what I meant. Thanks! > A few people in this club (myself included) have manged to work out their own solutions, [snip] < Very good. I always thought that that was the point of the cube, besides the amazing mechanism, and the incredible leap of intuition that it took for Rubik to design it. For me it's the only way to go. > [unsnip] but I think only a few of those would have been able to get such fast times with their own method. < Really? I'm surprised to hear this. I'd have thought that what I do/did was commonplace. Besides, I could be vastly more efficient overall and in particular. > I am very impressed: that's amazing! The moves I used are lost in the haze of the far more effient moves that I found quite soon after, but my own method took four or five minutes to complete; it was : face+layer, opposite corners, remaining edges. < Perhaps if you had stuck with your own ways, you would have found those better methods, and sequences on your own. > It is possible to fix all the edges at the end using one algorithm (or was it two?; sequcences in your terminology, if I understand you correctly), < If this is a question, you're asking about moving and flipping over the edges of the last level. Good question. In all cases the movement of the edges (without flipping) can be done with one sequence. Also, with one sequence I can flip any two over, or flip all four over (without moving them). So that's half of it. I know several "combo" sequences, which do both - move and flip. But I don't have the complete set, yet. > and the hardest part was getting the corners the right way after solving one side. It took me ages because I could only solve corners if they were in one state, so I have to keep going through phases until they were just so. < Once I developed two sequences, one each for solving, respectively, all the last four corners' orientations, then their positions, the times started coming down drastically. The second time I solved a cube it took me and hour; the third time took 15 minutes. But this is pattern recognition, isn't it? It's all in how you look at it. > So: WOW! What is your general approach to solving the cube? < Comprehension and looking ahead. The more information I have about what the next steps require, the more efficient I can be. If the next thing I do can solve two things at once, that's better than only solving one; solving three's better than solving two. If you look at it one way I use an 8 step algorithm, but I rarely need to take all eight steps. When the sequences are combined there are fewer moves. Generally I can solve the cube in 54 moves, sometimes in as few as 36, not counting "lucky" mixes. > And how do you find your moves? Is it trial and error? < Not really. Sometimes when I look for a solution to a particular problem I won't touch the cube, but try to think it out. [I recently got a 4x4x4 and that's how I approached it. Everything I tried worked, so there wasn't any error, so it really wasn't trial and error.] Sometimes I find new sequences at speed. Sometimes I try things and see what turns up, but again, no error...Exploration means never having to say you are lost. :) > Do you use any programs to help? < No, though it might be fun to lay out a few. S. > PS welcome to the club, by the way! < Thanks! > If you do not know, the chat room is quite active on the weekends, it seems especially Sunday late afternoon / evenings UK time. I suppose it might get even livlier at evenings US time, but I would never know! < I'm rarely on line weekends, but I'll visit if I can. I believe that I'm 8 hours west of London, so 6-8PM there is 10AM-noon here. > PPS what is this "game" that you recommend? < Start with a solved cube and make a hidden move, hand it to a buddy. He/she puts it back. Your buddy makes a move and hands it to you. You put it back. Then two moves...then three moves...etc. A general approach is, for example, to get to where you can solve any four before you work on five. > Sorry to post so many questions... Not a problem. Thanks for the interest. How long have you been speedcubing? What kind of times do you turn in, and how many moves? Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "simonl cube" <simonlcube@h...> wrote: > > All that I do on the cube I have figured out myself > > Hi David. > > If I have understood you correctly, you are getting sub-minute times (which > is great: congratulations!) using a method and moves that you have developed > yourself. A few people in this club (myself included) have manged to work > out their own solutions, but I think only a few of those would have been > able to get such fast times with their own method. I am very impressed: > that's amazing! The moves I used are lost in the haze of the far more > effient moves that I found quite soon after, but my own method took four or > five minutes to complete; it was : face+layer, opposite corners, remaining > edges. It is possible to fix all the edges at the end using one algorithm > (or was it two?; sequcences in your terminology, if I understand you > correctly), and the hardest part was getting the corners the right way after > solving one side. It took me ages because I could only solve corners if > they were in one state, so I have to keep going through phases until they > were just so. > > So: WOW! What is your general approach to solving the cube? And how do you > find your moves? Is it trial and error? Do you use any programs to help? > > S. > > PS welcome to the club, by the way! If you do not know, the chat room is > quite active on the weekends, it seems especially Sunday late afternoon / > evenings UK time. I suppose it might get even livlier at evenings US time, > but I would never know! > > PPS what is this "game" that you recommend? > > Sorry to post so many questions... >
2065. Re: my new cube..part 10
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 18:11:23 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I was able to get all edges + centres on one face + half centres on > many other faces, fairly quickly. Over the last 2 days I hadn't > really progressed beyond that though. :( I didn't really know what I > was doing. I remembered there had been some debate a little while ago > about whether it was better to do edges first or centres first, but I > couldn't remember what the consensus had been. I hadn't paid too much > attention to those posts because I didn't have a 4x4x4 at that point. > Anyway, I just started playing and realised that my natural instinct > was to start solving edges first. > > After two days and not much progress, I decided to look around at > different approaches to see if a different method would suit me > better. I found that with the regular cube doing cross->F2L->LL fits > in my brain better than 2x2x2->2x2x3->F2L->LL, so I wondered if a > different 4x4x4 approach might help. I read the intro stuff to Chris > H's revenge solution and had a go at centres first. Centres first is definitely the way to go, although I'm glad I first did it edges first because I can use the algorithms I figured out there to do the revenge blindfolded. If you get the chance in Scrabble (and it's quite unlikely) play oxyphenbutazone across 3 triple word scores - if these include the first o, the b and the final e you'll get a multiplier of 27 on your word score - if you also play the z you can get a double letter score on it and maybe even play it across another word. You can get 560 just for the z! Like this you can get a score of close to 1700 for the one word which should win you the game. > > I was trying really hard to resist looking up solutions, and just > read ideas instead and see what I could do with them. Unfortunately, > I have little will power with these things :/ I ended up reading a > few of the algs on Chris' page. Not many though, only 4 or 5 to get > me started. > > I'll try and resist looking at it again for a little while and play > around with a centres first approach. (I didn't actually memorise any > of Chris' algs, I just tried a few of them once.) > > So yes, my 4x4x4 is now solved, but unfortunately I can't say that it > was entirely my own work. :/ > > I'm going to leave the 5x5x5 until I have the 4x4x4 under control. > After the 5x5x5, I'll move on to the megaminx. > > I've never played with a skewb diamond. I have a regular skewb > (somewhere!) and found it to be rather unimpressive. The diamond > looks a bit more exciting though. > > Jasmine. > > BTW, Chris, I found your revenge solution easy to follow (well, the > bits I looked at anyway). > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, j_rueth > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Have you solved your 4x4 yet? They are fun puzzles. How about you > > 5x5? The skewb diamond is fairly easy puzzle. I solved it under > 15 > > min. when i first opened it. Good luck with your puzzles! > > Jake > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > I am totally enjoying my new puzzles. My 4x4x4 pretty much hasn't > > > left my sight since I got it. I haven't actually had much time to > > > play with it yet, but I've been taking it with my everywhere I > go. > > > > > > Last night I was meeting friends at a restaurant, I was there a > > > little early and so I played with my cube until my friends > arrived. > > > After dinner, we went back to my friend's apartment to play > > Scrabble > > > (another thing that I sometimes get obsessive about, but not as > > much > > > as cubes). I played with my cube in between turns. I have also > been > > > taking my cube to work and playing with it while walking from the > > > carpark to the office and while waiting for my computer to start > up. > > > > > > Jasmine. > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, j_rueth > > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Yeah! new toys! 2067. Re: my new cube..part 10
From: gogozergus <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 18:38:24 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Grant Tregay <Grant@T...>" <Grant@T...> wrote: > If you're looking at doing the puzzles in order of difficulty, I'd > skip to the megaminx before going on to the 5x5x5. Well, maybe I'm > thinking about time to solve, and not actual solution difficulty, > but still... Megaminx? Piece of cake. I got one yesterday for the first time and solved it in 20 minutes. I was very surprised when I realized how easy it was, if you apply a very simple layer by layer 3x3x3 method. Gilles.
2068. Re: my new cube..part 10
From: "Grant Tregay <Grant@...>" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 21:29:34 -0000

> "Grant Tregay" wrote:
> > If you're looking at doing the puzzles in order of difficulty,
> > I'd skip to the megaminx before going on to the 5x5x5. Well,
> > maybe I'm thinking about time to solve, and not actual solution
> > difficulty, but still...
"GameOfDeath2" wrote:
> Maybe, but I can solve the 5x5x5 quicker than I can do a corner
> 3 cycle on the megaminx (at least half of the time).

Is this really true or is this a great exageration? How long do each
of these puzzles take you?

Regardless, there are likely several different factors here -
practice, method efficiency, and puzzle "movability." I'm guessing
you've spent much more time practicing the 5x5x5 (either in physical
or applet form) than you have on the megaminx. Each of these can
have a great impact on your time:

1) Practice is obvious - the more the practice the faster you'll be
(in theory, anyways). Also, extra practice usually improves both
solution efficiency and puzzle movability.

2) Improved solution efficiency is twofold - move count and "delay"
reduction. I found that most of my time was spent in looking for
pieces. You (in general, not you specifically) may have a method
that uses very few moves, but requires difficult piece location,
making for longer pauses, or you may have a solution that is
virtually pause free, but takes an enormous amount of moves. The
answer (as with all puzzles) is to find the solution in the middle
with a minimum of both pauses and moves producing the best time.

3) Puzzle movability is again obvious. It's just a matter of the
amount of impact that this has. I wouldn't be surprised if a new
megaminx (especially with a different color scheme) gave me a time
twice that of what I currently have. They can get really, really
bad!

Btw, the corner 3 cycle on the megaminx is only 12 moves, if done
right - 8 disregarding orientation, or 15 with a slightly less
efficient algorithm. If those 8-15 moves take longer than the
250 - 300 that it is likely to take to solve the 5x5x5, then I'd
say there's a problem with your megaminx puzzle (at the very least
it's not lubed)!

Good luck!



2069. Re: Theoretical fastest average
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 22:06:44 -0000

I just tried the theoretical fastest average thing, using the same scramble that you guys used. Here was the average (18) (16) 16 18 18 16 17 18 16 16 (pop) 16 16 = 17.2 Here are the moves I used to solve it B L' F2 L2 B: Forms cross and keeps blue/orange pair intact F' U2 F: places orange/blue pair U' B2 R B2 R': places blue/red pair U2 F U' F2 L F L': places orange/green pair B' U2 B U' L U L': places green/red pair R' F' R L' U' L U R' F R: orientation case F2 U' L R' F2 L' R U' F2: permutation case This was 46 moves so at fastest 2.875 moves/sec and at my slowest 2.556 moves/sec What I did was to just do the scramble and try to figure out different ways to do it. I found a two or three ways to do it in 46 moves but this one had orientation and permutations cases that I liked a little bit better. I did notice that after I had the solution memorized I spent about 80% of my concentration on keeping my cube lined up after each turn. I also realized exactly how much time I spend looking for pieces, anywhere from hardly any pauses at all to 10-12 seconds based on these runs. Heh heh guess I know what I need to work on :) This was fun, I'd like to see if I can find a solution better than 46 moves and try this again. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cubacca1972 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > When solving for speed, it seems like there is a zen like state where > you just know what to do, there are no delays between algs, etc. > > I am curious to know how fast the cube can be solved if you are > presented with a cube scrambled exactly the same way over and over > again. > > How fast could you solve it? What kind of average is possible? > > As this is no longer a case of a randomly scrambled cube, it is only > a theoretical average. > > I took this mixing alg from Jess Bonde's timer app: > > B' L2 U B' D L' B R' F' L' F2 U B2 D' F D' U2 F2 > R' D' L R' B U' D2 > > and will practice solving it over and over. > > I would be curious to see what kind of times would be generated, and > also to see if people using the same method (eg, F2L) would end up > with the same LL, end stage or same number of moves. > > Lucas
2070. Re: [Speed cubing group] Theoretical fastest average
From: "Jessica Fridrich <jess340@...>" <jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Dec 2002 23:04:04 -0000

Wow, Lars, this is really phenomenal. 32 (or 26) moves so quickly -
I am amazed. Do you think this was a lucky case for you, or can you
pretty much do around 35 moves if you try slow and multiple cases?

I wonder if we can find a shorter algorithm than the scrambling one
for this position using just our brains and no computers. I have to
admit that I am less interested in how fast one can do a particular
sequence of moves, actually.

I sent the scrambling algorithm to Mirek Goljan and to my surprise,
without knowing your solution, he generated a different solution,
but the first 5 moves are exactly the same as yours! He used a
modified layer-by-layer approach that he uses to solve the cube for
the least number of moves. He thinks that this is not a coincidence
and it reflects the fact that the cube is not randomized well ....
Anyway, here is his solution with 29 moves:

B' L2 F2 U2 L2 F U F' B2 L U' F U F' B L' F' L B2 L B' L2 F L' B U D
L2 D' (29)

Note that after the first 11 moves, you have essentially 2 layers
solved! After those 11 moves, you will have a three-cycle of corners
and a three-cycle of edges (with flips) all constrained to the L
side. I wonder if those 11 moves could be a good starting point to
solve the position in fewer than 25 moves (the length of the
scrambling algorithm).

Jessica

> This was a lot of fun! Don't know why I haven't ever thought of
doing
> something like this before. I spent a few minutes trying to find
the
> best possible solution by solving it several times slowly and
> checking all the alternatives. I've never ever done that either
> before! I found a really good solution (see below) pretty soon.
>
> After ~10 times I was ready to time it. It took ~5 tries to get
down
> to a plateau of 14-15 seconds. But it really didn't feel very zen.
It
> took ~10 more attempts until things suddenly started flowing as
they
> should, and I was doing 12-12.5 seconds. I used the Bonde Timer.
>
> I really don't know how you guys handle the notation! It just
doesn't
> mix with my cubing brain. I got the wrong result 1/3 of the time.
> This is why I did my animation applet...
>
> When you do this, you really notice any deficiencies in your cube!
>
>
> My solution:
> (The steps bleed into each other a bit)
>
> 1. 2x2x2 B' L2 F2
> 2. 2x2x3 U2 L2
> 3. twist edges U' B F' L' F
> 4. 2x3x3 U2 L2 U2 L'
> 5+6. twist & place corners B' U F2 U' B U F2 U2
> 7. place edges L' D2 L F' B D2 F B' L D2
>
> 32 moves in 12.5 sec is 2.6 moves/sec. Someone else can probably
do
> the same solution faster? That would be fun.
>
> There are 5(!) 12 turn solutions for the final layer position,
> instead of the 18 turn one I used, so you can get it down to 26-27
> moves that way. See position 40 at
> http://www.ai.univ-paris8.fr/~bhelmste/cube/solutions_567.html
>
> I also made an animation for it, since I had to anyway to figure
out
> the notation. It will be at http://lar5.com/cube/zen.html as soon
as
> my ISPs ftp server is up again.
>
> /Lars
>
> At 0:39 +0000 12/11/02, cubacca1972 wrote:
> >When solving for speed, it seems like there is a zen like state
where
> >you just know what to do, there are no delays between algs, etc.
> >
> >I am curious to know how fast the cube can be solved if you are
> >presented with a cube scrambled exactly the same way over and over
> >again.
> >
> >How fast could you solve it? What kind of average is possible?
> >
> >As this is no longer a case of a randomly scrambled cube, it is
only
> >a theoretical average.
> >
> >I took this mixing alg from Jess Bonde's timer app:
> >
> >B' L2 U B' D L' B R' F' L' F2 U B2 D' F D' U2 F2
> >R' D' L R' B U' D2
> >
> >and will practice solving it over and over.
> >
> >I would be curious to see what kind of times would be generated,
and
> >also to see if people using the same method (eg, F2L) would end up
> >with the same LL, end stage or same number of moves.



2071. my first blindfolded cube
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Dec 2002 06:35:17 -0000

Hey all, finally solved my first cube while blindfolded! I had tried
a while back and all I could manage was the 2x2x2. Then I looked at
Richard Carr's page for his blindfold method. I never really looked
at it much, I just sort of glanced at the pictures and noticed that
the pieces were numbered, that's all I really got out of it. Well
anyway I was trying to think how to memorize the cube quickly, and I
thought about how Richard numbers the cube. So I sat down with a
sheet of paper, drew out a cube and came up with a number system that
made sense to me. I memorized that system, then I sat down with my
cube and scrambled it. When I took the blindfold off for that solve
I thought I was done but the cube was 5 moves away from solved. Then
I tried it again and my cube was still pretty scrambled when I
thought I was done. Then the third time I actually got it! Took me
about an hour to do it the third time. Anyway I was just REALLY
excited to finally get it. Thanks Richard for the hint, I didn't
actually study your method but it gave me a hint in the right
direction :)

Later all, I hope to get faster with this heh heh it was really fun

Chris



2072. Re: [Speed cubing group] Theoretical fastest average
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Dec 2002 00:51:06 -0800

At 23:04 +0000 12/11/02, Jessica Fridrich <jess340@...> wrote: >Wow, Lars, this is really phenomenal. 32 (or 26) moves so quickly - >I am amazed. Do you think this was a lucky case for you, or can you >pretty much do around 35 moves if you try slow and multiple cases? It's definitely a lucky case. I'm not sure how lucky - I've only ever done this once. Based on getting a 42.5 average when thinking hard on 13 cubes (http://lar5.com/cube/examples.html), I'm pretty sure I could get under 40 if I get to try until I find the best way. And if I get to use the Helmstetter index, that will take 3-5 more moves off. Now, doing those 13 solutions, I did feel unusually lucky, and since they too came from the Bonde mixer (old Sunday competition), my scientific training compels me to mention that they may not be 100% mixed. Maybe 25 moves isn't really enough? How do you find out? Then again, I hadn't really done that Real Hard Thinking stuff in many years, so it's hard to know what "usual" luck would mean nowadays. >I wonder if we can find a shorter algorithm than the scrambling one >for this position using just our brains and no computers. Does the Helmstetter index count as using computers? If so, you may not want to read the end of this message :-) > I have to >admit that I am less interested in how fast one can do a particular >sequence of moves, actually. > >I sent the scrambling algorithm to Mirek Goljan and to my surprise, >without knowing your solution, he generated a different solution, >but the first 5 moves are exactly the same as yours! Not too surprising. Once you see the first one, the next four really stand out. If you're looking for building "blocks". >He used a >modified layer-by-layer approach that he uses to solve the cube for >the least number of moves. He thinks that this is not a coincidence >and it reflects the fact that the cube is not randomized well .... >Anyway, here is his solution with 29 moves: > >B' L2 F2 U2 L2 F U F' B2 L U' F U F' B L' F' L B2 L B' L2 F L' B U D >L2 D' (29) Turn 11 has to be B' B' L2 F2 U2 L2 F U F' B2 L B' >Note that after the first 11 moves, you have essentially 2 layers >solved! After those 11 moves, you will have a three-cycle of corners >and a three-cycle of edges (with flips) all constrained to the L >side. I wonder if those 11 moves could be a good starting point to >solve the position in fewer than 25 moves (the length of the >scrambling algorithm). Using Helmstetters index I get exactly 25. I doubt there is anything better. B' L2 F2 U2 L2 F U F' B2 L B' F2 U2 D2 B' U' B U2 F' U F D2 F2 L2 U That's Goljans 11, 12 from the index, and 2 to clean up. Out of 25 moves 12 are half turns. And of the remaining 13, 9 are in 3 "x U x'" sequences. Whatever that may mean... I put this one one the animation page as well: http://lar5.com/cube/zen.html /Lars -- "They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever flipped it over?" Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@... http://lar5.com
2073. Re: my new cube..part 10
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Dec 2002 09:49:59 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Grant Tregay <Grant@T...>" <Grant@T...> wrote: > > "Grant Tregay" wrote: > > > If you're looking at doing the puzzles in order of difficulty, > > > I'd skip to the megaminx before going on to the 5x5x5. Well, > > > maybe I'm thinking about time to solve, and not actual solution > > > difficulty, but still... > "GameOfDeath2" wrote: > > Maybe, but I can solve the 5x5x5 quicker than I can do a corner > > 3 cycle on the megaminx (at least half of the time). > > Is this really true or is this a great exageration? How long do each > of these puzzles take you? > It's really true. Lately, my 5x5x5 times are getting better and worse than 2'30" is really quite disappointing. (I've only just started on megaminx because before I first ever touched it a sticker fell off - I solved it like that but before I went on it again a lot more fell off. I've recently got around this problem.) Anyway, my 3-cycle move (like a LL permutation so I need to preserve orientation etc.) is 72 moves or if I need to do the other way 144 moves as there's no way I'm going to try to invert a 72 move algorithm so I do it twice. That's if the 3 are all adjacent in one layer. If they aren't it's even longer! To do the algorithm 3 times on my megaminx takes about 5 minutes or 100 seconds a go - so half the time it takes 200 seconds which is a lot longer than it takes to solve the 5x5x5. My puzzle isn't lubricated (I've only ever lubricated a couple of 3x3x3's because the large puzzles seem fragile) and I can get less than a move a second out of my megaminx. Sometimes it jams a lot so I need to go 4 times round the wrong direction instead of once in the right direction. > Regardless, there are likely several different factors here - > practice, method efficiency, and puzzle "movability." All 3 affect me! >I'm guessing > you've spent much more time practicing the 5x5x5 (either in physical > or applet form) than you have on the megaminx. Each of these can > have a great impact on your time: > > 1) Practice is obvious - the more the practice the faster you'll be > (in theory, anyways). Also, extra practice usually improves both > solution efficiency and puzzle movability. > > 2) Improved solution efficiency is twofold - move count and "delay" > reduction. I found that most of my time was spent in looking for > pieces. You (in general, not you specifically) may have a method > that uses very few moves, but requires difficult piece location, > making for longer pauses, or you may have a solution that is > virtually pause free, but takes an enormous amount of moves. The > answer (as with all puzzles) is to find the solution in the middle > with a minimum of both pauses and moves producing the best time. > I'm really looking for a low move count method. Delay is not as big a deal for me at this point. > 3) Puzzle movability is again obvious. It's just a matter of the > amount of impact that this has. I wouldn't be surprised if a new > megaminx (especially with a different color scheme) gave me a time > twice that of what I currently have. They can get really, really > bad! > > Btw, the corner 3 cycle on the megaminx is only 12 moves, if done > right Evidently I'm not doing it right! I can cycle them in 8 moves if I don't care about orientation or what happens to the edges but I'm thinking like LL of the cube so not to disturb other stuff (like if it's the last thing to do). To correct all that other stuff takes me another 64 moves. >- 8 disregarding orientation, or 15 with a slightly less > efficient algorithm. If those 8-15 moves take longer than the > 250 - 300 I can't remember the last time I needed 300 moves to solve the 5x5x5. >that it is likely to take to solve the 5x5x5, then I'd > say there's a problem with your megaminx puzzle (at the very least > it's not lubed)! > > Good luck!
2074. Re: my first blindfolded cube
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Dec 2002 09:52:54 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey all, finally solved my first cube while blindfolded! I had tried > a while back and all I could manage was the 2x2x2. Then I looked at > Richard Carr's page for his blindfold method. I never really looked > at it much, I just sort of glanced at the pictures and noticed that > the pieces were numbered, that's all I really got out of it. Well > anyway I was trying to think how to memorize the cube quickly, and I > thought about how Richard numbers the cube. So I sat down with a > sheet of paper, drew out a cube and came up with a number system that > made sense to me. I memorized that system, then I sat down with my > cube and scrambled it. When I took the blindfold off for that solve > I thought I was done but the cube was 5 moves away from solved. Then > I tried it again and my cube was still pretty scrambled when I > thought I was done. Then the third time I actually got it! Took me > about an hour to do it the third time. Anyway I was just REALLY > excited to finally get it. Thanks Richard for the hint, I didn't > actually study your method but it gave me a hint in the right > direction :) No problem - I've only got the "beginner" method on the web anyway. I'm working on intermediate and advanced levels but I don't think I'll be good enough to master even the intermediate level. The advanced level is cool though. Fast people such as yourself would probably be able to solve the cube in 2 minutes (including memorization) with it. > > Later all, I hope to get faster with this heh heh it was really fun > > Chris
2075. Re: [Speed cubing group] Theoretical fastest average
From: "james.dale2" <james.dale2@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 12 Dec 2002 11:56:29 -0000

> I wonder if we can find a shorter algorithm than the scrambling one
> for this position using just our brains and no computers. I have to
> admit that I am less interested in how fast one can do a particular
> sequence of moves, actually.

D F2 U R B2 D L2 F R2 F' D' R2 D' R' U B R2

Produces the same scramble.
Sorry I did use a computer for that.



2076. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Understanding algorithms
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Dec 2002 13:49:17 +0000

>
> Really? I'm surprised to hear this. I'd have thought that what I
>do/did was commonplace. Besides, I could be vastly more efficient
>overall and in particular.

I think you will find that most people have pooled together ideas and moves
as part of the process of refining their method.

>
> Perhaps if you had stuck with your own ways, you would have found
>those better methods, and sequences on your own.

Maybe, but for me the sharing aspect of cubing - down to the moves
themselves - is part of what it makes it so much fun!

> How long have you been speedcubing? What kind of times do you turn
>in, and how many moves?

For about 6 months, after a 20 year break.
I have not timed myself for a while, and have been concentrating on getting
my number of moves down, but between 30 and 40 seconds.
About 55 moves, going down to 50 moves once I have completed learning my
current set.

Best of luck completing your set of combo moves. It sounds like your
ability to move the cube in your mind is far more developed then my own, and
I suspect you have the potential to be an extremely capable blindfold
cubist.

S.

> It's definitely a lucky case. I'm not sure how lucky - I've only
> ever done this once....
> And if I get to use the Helmstetter index, that will take 3-5 more
> moves off.
> Using Helmstetters index I get exactly 25. I doubt there is
> anything better.

> B' L2 F2 U2 L2 F U F' B2 L B' F2 U2 D2 B' U' B U2 F' U F D2 F2 L2 U

You didn't mean anything at all better, did you? Because I have yet
to put a scrambled cube state into "Cube Explorer" that it couldn't
solve in less than 25 moves. Sure enough, when I gave it this one,
Cube Explorer gave me a 20 move solution almost immediately.




2078. Re: my new cube..part 10
From: "Grant Tregay <Grant@...>" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Dec 2002 16:42:43 -0000

GameOfDeath2 wrote:
> > "GameOfDeath2" wrote:
> > > Maybe, but I can solve the 5x5x5 quicker than I can do a corner
> > > 3 cycle on the megaminx (at least half of the time).
> > Is this really true or is this a great exageration? How long do
> > each of these puzzles take you?
>
> It's really true. Lately, my 5x5x5 times are getting better and
> worse than 2'30" is really quite disappointing.
Wow! Perhaps you should update the unofficial records with this
time! The best one there right now is right at 3 minutes. Now you've
got my interest - do you have the capability of making and uploading
videos? I'd love to see a 5x5x5 being solved, period! But that
fast would be even more amazing. I have yet to touch a 5x5x5, so
it's still a bit surreal to me.

> Anyway, my 3-cycle move (like a LL permutation so I need to
> preserve orientation etc.) is 72 moves or if I need to do the other
> way 144 moves
Again - wow! I can give you some algs that I've come up with, if
you're interested. I don't want to spoil it, though, if you're the
type that likes to be able to come up with the solution on your own.
I personally have never been able to do that. I find other people's
solutions on the internet, and then I try to improve from there. The
12 move sequence that I mentioned (along with its inverse, and a
slight modification) can cycle any 3 corners on one face without
disturbing edges at all and without disturbing corner orientation
(i.e. the only affect it has is to cycle 3 corners). I hadn't
counted my moves on the megaminx in quite a while, but my whole
solution for the megaminx used to be (and probably still is) between
150 and 200 moves on average (I think it was right around 180). I
just counted one, and it took 193 moves for the whole solution.

> To do the algorithm 3 times on my megaminx takes about 5 minutes or
> 100 seconds a go - so half the time it takes 200 seconds which is a
> lot longer than it takes to solve the 5x5x5.
Now I understand! Between long algs and an unlubed minx, I could see
how it takes so much longer than your 5x5x5.

> My puzzle isn't lubricated ... (because the large puzzles seem
> fragile) and I can get less than a move a second out of my
> megaminx. Sometimes it jams a lot so I need to go 4 times round the
> wrong direction instead of once in the right direction.
I don't want for you to ruin your minx, but I can say that mine (a 12
color, tiled version from Mefferts) lubed quite nicely with the same
silicon spray I use for my 3x3x3 cube. After lubrication, based on
the move count I mentioned before and my times (usually in the 2:30 -
2:50 range), I can get a little better than 1 move per second. The
only problem I had is that the lube loosened a screw on one of the
centers, so I had to reglue it, and I made it a little tighter than I
would've liked. But, in general I'd say that my megaminx seems just
as sturdy as my 3x3x3 cube, if not more so, because of its weight.
But, like I said... Don't ruin your minx on my account of saying it
will be fine :-P Oh, and two other side affects - pieces don't catch
as easily, but I also didn't pop pieces at all until I lubed my
megaminx, if memory serves me correctly. That's probably just
because I hadn't used the puzzle enough to loosen it to the point of
popping pieces yet, though.

> > Regardless, there are likely several different factors here -
> > practice, method efficiency, and puzzle "movability."
> All 3 affect me!
As they do us all - it's just a matter of positive or negative
affect :-P

> I'm really looking for a low move count method. Delay is not as
> big a deal for me at this point.
That's usually the best place to start - get a low move count, and
then see where you can cut corners to reduce delays, possibly adding
some moves to the overall solution. What method do you use to solve
the megaminx, if you don't mind my asking? My approach is basically
star (cross) & F2L from the cube, applied to several faces, working
down to a LL, which I do in order of edge orientation, edge
permutation, corner orientation, and finally corner permutation.

> I can't remember the last time I needed 300 moves to solve the
> 5x5x5.
I wasn't completely sure on the move count, here - I just looked at
the oinkleburger applet, saw a few that were around 250-280, and
figured that 250-300 was probably a reasonable range.




2079. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: *sigh* oh well...
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 12 Dec 2002 16:46:22 +0000

> In my view the "12 solves" fails this fairness test for at least
> two reasons. One is because there is no standard of measurment for
> isolated tries. It can only be fair if anyone who is tested faces the
> same challenge (not a seemingly similar challenge) and faces *unknown*
> mixes. This problem is partly because there is no way to agree upon a
> "blind" set of mixes that anyone can try at another time. There is no
> way to keep that "blind" set of mixes secret, and if they are not
> secret they can be analysed and practiced.
>

Much like the thread for the "theoretical fastest average" I suppose :)

> Another reason is that the "12 solves" do not meet the "same
> challenge" requirement is because the number is too small. IMO it's
> simple not a large enough random sample. Someone could meet up with
> several mixes that happen to fit well with his or her style.
>

I understand what you are saying. Don't you think though that even in a
competition scenario, one person might have a time which is considerably
faster than the other contestants, even if he or she is not nearly as good
as the others.

I was reading a thread some weeks ago about Lars Petrus on a bad day getting
high twenties. Boy I wish he and I were in competition together on a day
like that. Head to head, Lars on a bad day, Rob on a good day, Lars gets 28
seconds and Rob gets 27! (one off of course!) hehe! Everyone would be
convinced that I am better. Of course I'd keep it secret that I average
about 35 :)

When Minh Thai claimed the world record, it was popular opinion that he beat
people who were thought to be faster. I guess that on the day, even though
they all solved the same state, his solution worked better for that
particular state. His record might not have stood if the cube looked a
little different! It's just the nature of the cube.

Hey, maybe I could make a huge stack of crates (never done it before!) and
beat the pros if they keep getting a freak gust of wind! (or do they do it
indoors now?)

I think that the only benefit that Jess will get on the day is less pressure
in a more familiar environment perhaps? He still has to beat the record in
just twelve tries, which is no mean feat. And it might only be a short
lived record, there is still a good chance that it will be smashed again at
the championships! Sure, the goal posts will have moved, but it can only
make the competition more exciting!

And confirms that this particular mix is in a favorable mix state. And when I think of it, that is how we can answer if those 25 move mixes are really random enough. Run a bunch of them through Cube Explorer, and see if they produce a lower average than 35 move ones. Heck, if you're at it, test all numbers from 20 upwards, and see where it flattens out. Maybe someone's already done that? -- "They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever flipped it over?" Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@... http://lar5.com
2082. Megaminx vs 5x5x5
From: "Grant Tregay <Grant@...>" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Dec 2002 18:43:27 -0000

I thought it was time for a subject line change :-P

GameOfDeath2 wrote:
>"Grant Tregay " wrote:
>>GameOfDeath2 wrote:
>>> It's really true. Lately, my 5x5x5 times are getting better and
>>> worse than 2'30" is really quite disappointing.
>>Wow! Perhaps you should update the unofficial records with this
>>time! The best one there right now is right at 3 minutes.
>It's there - my real cube is no good for speed cubing on (it jams
>and has similar problems to my megaminx) so I just go on
>oinkleburger.
Ah. I thought you were talking about a real 5x5x5 puzzles. I've
found that I can solve the 4x4x4 significantly faster on the applet
than I can on an actual cube - averaging just under 2:00 this month
on the applet and more like 2:35 on the real thing. I can only guess
how much worse my real 5x5x5 will be.

>Wouldn't mind a 3-cycle move - only 8 months to go to the contest
>and I think I'm going to need 2 or 3 months to get my megaminx to
>the point where I am happy....
Originally, I said the alg and its inverse, however I guess I
actually meant its reflection - I always get those mixed up. For
these sequences, U and F are adjacent, and L and R are on opposite
sides of U and F, as they would be on a cube. Notation can get tricky
if you try to include other faces, or describe the impact this has
(e.g. What face is D? The one below FL or the one below FR?).
Anyways, try these on a solved megaminx to see their affect:
1) (L' F') (L U') (R' U) (L' U') (R U) (F L)
2) (L' F' F') (L U') (R' U) (L' U') (R U) (F F L)
3) (R F) (R' U) (L U') (R U) (L' U') (F' R')
4) (R F F) (R' U) (L U') (R U) (L' U') (F' F' R')
Note that the only difference between 1 and 2 or between 3 and 4 is
how far F is turned at the beginning and end. 1 and 3 cycle 3
corners that are all next to each other, 2 and 4 cycle 3 corners
where 1 is not attached. Seeing as there are 5 corners on the LL,
you also should be able to position all corners with at most 2
repetitions, leaving 2 correct after the first, and placing the last
3 the second time.

>I can't remember the last time I needed 300 moves to solve the
>5x5x5.
Btw, I just checked and it was December 5th on the applet :-P Your
average move counts for the last 4 months have been at or under 267,
though, so I guess 300 is a bit high.




2083. Re: Megaminx vs 5x5x5
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Dec 2002 19:35:17 -0000



> 1) (L' F') (L U') (R' U) (L' U') (R U) (F L)
> 2) (L' F' F') (L U') (R' U) (L' U') (R U) (F F L)
> 3) (R F) (R' U) (L U') (R U) (L' U') (F' R')
> 4) (R F F) (R' U) (L U') (R U) (L' U') (F' F' R')

Thanks, I'll try.

> Note that the only difference between 1 and 2 or between 3 and 4 is
> how far F is turned at the beginning and end. 1 and 3 cycle 3
> corners that are all next to each other, 2 and 4 cycle 3 corners
> where 1 is not attached. Seeing as there are 5 corners on the LL,
> you also should be able to position all corners with at most 2
> repetitions, leaving 2 correct after the first, and placing the
last
> 3 the second time.
>
> >I can't remember the last time I needed 300 moves to solve the
> >5x5x5.
> Btw, I just checked and it was December 5th on the applet :-P Your
> average move counts for the last 4 months have been at or under
267,
> though, so I guess 300 is a bit high.

For the period since oinkleburger started recording moves (about 6
months) it's under 264.
Also in that time I've only gone 300+ 12 times (out of 368) of which
4 were in my marathon attempt for 5x5x5's in one hour (where I
messed up one cube very badly and at least two others in a smaller
way).
I think without time pressure it would be pretty easy to solve it in
under 300 every time and probably under 280 too.
3 times this month is quite bad. I've been feeling a bit slow
recently. I guess it's the Manx weather - it's freezing here.

2085. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: *sigh* oh well...
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Dec 2002 22:00:47 +0000

>
> :)
>
> What overall algorithm do you use?
>

I'm a lazy cuber, very few algs. White cross, F2L which places three
corners, then three edges, then the remaining pair. Then OE, PE, PC,
OC, if you follow? I know more F2L algs than I actually use, I just
don't see the cases quick enough.

> I think that part of what won him the day was his composure. I
> remember that at one point he started to go one way and paused because
> he spotted something better. Then he just sailed through the last
> half. You wouldn't happen to know where footage of that is, would you?
>
>

I think I have it on a rough looking WMV file, but I'd have to track it
down. I'll let you know!



2086. Re: Theoretical fastest average
From: nascarjon2001 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Dec 2002 22:58:25 -0000

I tried this exercize as well. It was very fun. I never realized how fast I turned the cube. The first couple of times that I solved using the same scramble as everyone else I solved it in 20 then after about 5 or 6 times I got down around 14 and decided to do the average this is what I got: 12.94, 12.83, 13.11, (12.15), 12.78, 13.91, 13.37, (13.98), 12.94, 13.18, 12.45 = 13.07 average. This is how I solved the cube: Cross: L F' U2 Y L' R2 1st Corner/Edge: U L' U L 2nd Corner/Edge: U2 R2 F R F' 3rd Corner/Edge: U Y' L' U L U' Y' R U' R' 4th Corner/Edge: U L' U' L U L' U' L U L' U' L Orientation: F' U' F L F' L' U L F L' Permutation: X' L' U L' D2 L U' L' D2 L2 54 moves not counted the cube rotations. Wich means that I was averaging 4.131 turns per second! Jon --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I just tried the theoretical fastest average thing, using the same > scramble that you guys used. Here was the average > > (18) (16) 16 18 18 16 17 18 16 16 (pop) 16 16 = 17.2 > > Here are the moves I used to solve it > > B L' F2 L2 B: Forms cross and keeps blue/orange pair intact > F' U2 F: places orange/blue pair > U' B2 R B2 R': places blue/red pair > U2 F U' F2 L F L': places orange/green pair > B' U2 B U' L U L': places green/red pair > R' F' R L' U' L U R' F R: orientation case > F2 U' L R' F2 L' R U' F2: permutation case > > This was 46 moves so at fastest 2.875 moves/sec and at my slowest > 2.556 moves/sec > > What I did was to just do the scramble and try to figure out > different ways to do it. I found a two or three ways to do it in 46 > moves but this one had orientation and permutations cases that I > liked a little bit better. I did notice that after I had the > solution memorized I spent about 80% of my concentration on keeping > my cube lined up after each turn. I also realized exactly how much > time I spend looking for pieces, anywhere from hardly any pauses at > all to 10-12 seconds based on these runs. Heh heh guess I know what > I need to work on :) This was fun, I'd like to see if I can find a > solution better than 46 moves and try this again. > > Chris > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cubacca1972 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > When solving for speed, it seems like there is a zen like state > where > > you just know what to do, there are no delays between algs, etc. > > > > I am curious to know how fast the cube can be solved if you are > > presented with a cube scrambled exactly the same way over and over > > again. > > > > How fast could you solve it? What kind of average is possible? > > > > As this is no longer a case of a randomly scrambled cube, it is > only > > a theoretical average. > > > > I took this mixing alg from Jess Bonde's timer app: > > > > B' L2 U B' D L' B R' F' L' F2 U B2 D' F D' U2 F2 > > R' D' L R' B U' D2 > > > > and will practice solving it over and over. > > > > I would be curious to see what kind of times would be generated, > and > > also to see if people using the same method (eg, F2L) would end up > > with the same LL, end stage or same number of moves. > > > > Lucas

2094. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: *sigh* oh well...
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Dec 2002 18:19:36 -0800

At 16:46 +0000 12/12/02, Robert Roue wrote:
>
>When Minh Thai claimed the world record, it was popular opinion that he beat
>people who were thought to be faster. I guess that on the day, even though
>they all solved the same state, his solution worked better for that
>particular state. His record might not have stood if the cube looked a
>little different! It's just the nature of the cube.


I remember that the third cube was in a pretty good position for my
method. And as it turned out I was the fastest of all on that one. So
sure, things like that matter.

To me a lot of this discussion is about the wrong thing. Measuring a
single solution is just not a good way to measure records in this
sport. Instead of arguing how you can best arrange doing single
solution records, why don't we scrap the whole concept, and figure
out how to do a proper record, like the average of 10 out of 12 rule
for the world championships.

I also think that 10 is on the low side, but why not have a 10
solution record, and a 25, 100, etc?

That a book publisher that knows nothing about cubing has decided
that this is how to measure the world record does not make it
"official", set in stone, or anything that we have to care at all
about. If we define some rules and standards etc, those *will* be the
official records.


--
Master: You were destined to die! It was written!
Buffy: What can I say? I flunked the written.

Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@... http://lar5.com

2096. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: *sigh* oh well...
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 13 Dec 2002 10:20:28 +0000

> To me a lot of this discussion is about the wrong thing. Measuring a
> single solution is just not a good way to measure records in this
> sport. Instead of arguing how you can best arrange doing single
> solution records, why don't we scrap the whole concept, and figure
> out how to do a proper record, like the average of 10 out of 12 rule
> for the world championships.
>
> I also think that 10 is on the low side, but why not have a 10
> solution record, and a 25, 100, etc?
>

Sure, this sounds like a better idea. How many cubes do you think can be
done before people's times suffer from fatigue? Do you think 100 would be
OK for this?

I realise that if any single time can be taken for the record, then one day
the record will stand at something unreal, maybe sub 10, and it will not
reflect the average of the record holder. Averages are a more reliable
measure of performance, but maybe that just has to be counted as a different
(and better) class of world record.



2097. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Theoretical fastest average
From: "james.dale2" <james.dale2@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 13 Dec 2002 14:14:55 -0000

> >> B' L2 F2 U2 L2 F U F' B2 L B' F2 U2 D2 B' U' B U2 F' U F D2 F2 L2 U
> >
> >You didn't mean anything at all better, did you? Because I have yet
> >to put a scrambled cube state into "Cube Explorer" that it couldn't
> >solve in less than 25 moves. Sure enough, when I gave it this one,
> >Cube Explorer gave me a 20 move solution almost immediately.
>
> In my head I meant from move 11, when it's a two full layer position
> of sorts, but I didn't write it.
>
> James Dale got 17 moves out of his computer, which I think is very
> low? And confirms that this particular mix is in a favorable mix
> state.

I just tried out 5 more of Jess Bondes mixers.
Cube explorer got 18,19,19,19,18 moves.
It might find even lower ones but it starts taking too long to search.
I don't think its that 25 moves doesn't mix the cube enough, I just
think the cube is never more than about 20 moves away from solved.
Try this mixer that I engineered - the cube certainly looks very mixed
ineed, but is only 19 moves from solved :
U' F2 D' R U D2 B' L' U F' R' L' D2 R' L2 U' D' L2 B2 (19f)

I think the problem is that all x-step methods are simplifying the cube so
that your brain can get around a number of discrete phases and when you
are following each step its goal is not a solved cube but a partially solved
cube. Of course you'd have to be some kind of freak to be able to just look
at a cube and solve it in one 20 move step each time.

James
