2100. [Speed cubing group] Re: my new cube..part 10
From: "Grant Tregay <Grant@...>" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Dec 2002 15:25:21 -0000

Yeah - I realized that I shouldn't have posted my reply before
looking through the rest of the messages. I went and took a look at
his site - found his method for the 4x4x4, and I'd assume it's
similar to his 5x5x5 approach. So for him it's corners first, middle
layer edges (FR, FL, BR, & BL), U centers, U edges, middle layers
centers (on F, B, L, and R), and finally the LL.

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Robert Roue wrote:
> Did you see his other videos in that folder? And also have you
> looked at the link he posted earlier?



2101. God's alg. average
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Dec 2002 15:34:48 +0000

Dr C., (or anyone else!),

There are 43illion possible cube states with a 3x3x3 cube.

As I undertand it, it has not been proved that the maximum number of moves
required to solve a cube from one of these states is 25. To date, however,
no cube state has been found that takes more than 25 moves to solve.

OK here's the question: Is there any way of working out the *average* number
of minimum moves required to solve the cube? In other words, if we were to
calculate the minimum number of moves required for each state, what would
the average be?

I am asking becuase if we knew this average (let's say is is _n_) then we
could say that a cube state that can be "unscrambled" in fewer than _n_
moves was not scrambled properly, and conversely, a cube that takes more
than _n_ moves to solve is scrambled.

I guess what would be interesting is a table like this filled in:
% of cube states that can be solved in one move or less: ?
% of cube states that can be solved in two moves or less: ?
% of cube states that can be solved in three moves or less: ?
% of cube states that can be solved in four moves or less: ?
etc.
... the average would be where the 50% line is drawn.

Is that a big ask? Has it been done already? If it cannot be done, can
educated approimations be done instead? Can it be done with a 2x2x2?
S.

_________________________________________________________________
Tired of spam? Get advanced junk mail protection with MSN 8.
http://join.msn.com/?page=features/junkmail



2102. Re: God's alg. average
From: "Grant Tregay <Grant@...>" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Dec 2002 16:34:31 -0000

Well, for the 2x2x2, this has been done. You can see the breakdown
of how many states there are for each # of moves to solve for all
3,674,160 cube states at ->
http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/cube2.htm. The average (if
I did it right) comes out to 8.76 moves, which is 79.60% of the
maximum number of moves (11). If we assume the maximum for the 3x3x3
to be in the range of 20-25 moves, and if we assume the average to
again be about 80% of the maximum (a lot of assumptions, I know),
then the average number of moves required when applying God's
algorithm would be somewhere in the range of 16-20 moves.

As far actually doing the table for a 3x3x3, I think there are too
many states to do this. I suppose I could be wrong, but with over 43
quintillion cube states, that would take much too long of a time (at
least years), even with a fast computer. If the average is actually
only 16 or 17, though, you might be able to get at least to that
point relatively quickly.

Regardless, you would still run into the problem of memory
requirements. Think of it like this: you have to store the cube
state for each of more than half of the cubes. With over 21
quintillion cube states (21,626,001,637,244,928,000 is half of the
total), even if you could store the state in only one byte, you'd
need 21 million terabytes of storage to represent this. I don't know
of any computers with this kind of ability! I suppose you could
apply cube rotations for symetric states, reducing the number by a
multiple of 24, but that's still quite a bit out of reach.

Anybody with ideas of how to approach this using educated guesses,
though? I'd say that's our best bet.

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "simonl cube" wrote:
> I guess what would be interesting is a table like this filled in:
> % of cube states that can be solved in one move or less: ?
> % of cube states that can be solved in two moves or less: ?
> % of cube states that can be solved in three moves or less: ?
> % of cube states that can be solved in four moves or less: ?
> etc.
> ... the average would be where the 50% line is drawn.
>
> Is that a big ask? Has it been done already? If it cannot be done,
> can educated approimations be done instead? Can it be done with a
> 2x2x2?
> S.




2103. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: God's alg. average
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 13 Dec 2002 16:41:38 +0000

> Anybody with ideas of how to approach this using educated guesses,
> though? I'd say that's our best bet.
>

If anyone owns/operates or knows somebody who owns/operates a super computer
like the latest piece of work from Cray? Long shot? Well, if anyone does,
then I'm sure the programmers would love a challenge like this! Bit of a
break from the norm, particle accelerators and all that simple stuff!



2104. Re: God's alg. average
From: "Jessica Fridrich <jess340@...>" <jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Dec 2002 18:27:18 -0000

The answers to the questions you raised also depend on the counting.
It is easier to find some bounds is you count quarter-moves (by 90
degrees) as one move and those by 180 degrees as two. It is known
that some highly symmetrical states require at least 24 moves (if I
remember correctly) and because there is an algorithm that has
exactly 24 moves, we pretty much know that the cube group diameter
for quanter-moves (q-moves) is at least 24. I think those symmetrical
positions include superflip (all edges flipped all else in place) and
supertwists (all corners twisted).

A good place to learn about this is Mike Reid's page
http://www.math.umass.edu/~mreid/Rubik/m_symmetric.html and follow
the links to Cube-Lovers mailing list archives. Maybe there is a web
page that summarizes the knowledge regarding the cube group diameter
and related issues.

I personaly think that for face turns (180 degrees = one move) the
diameter of the cube group is 20. We know (see the page referenced
above) that certain positions require at least 20 moves. If you run
Cube Explorer by generating random positions and then always going
for the optimal solution, you will find out that no position will
require more than 20 face moves. A few years back, when the optimal
solvers appeared, I heard of somebody who just kept his workstation
running continuously trying random positions and finding the optimal
algorithm looking for some answers as to the percentage of positions
with different number of moves. I also remember that he never
encountered a position that required more than 20 face moves.

However, it is still an open question whether the cube group has
a "tail" in the sense of a few positions very far from the solved
state (farther than 20) that you will not likely generate by random
searches. In my opinion, the farthest positions will be those with a
high degree of symmetry, such as superflip. Based on this gut-
feeling, I would consider the cube diameter for face turns to be 20.

When it comes to the average number of moves, again, my guess is that
it would be between 18 and 19, maybe closer to 19. This is based on
an anecdotal evidence of running the Cube Explorer a few times
myself. I think that a position that requires 17 indicates that the
cube is most likely not well mixed. But I am not sure at all how
exceptional this is.

Now, if you make, say 25 random moves from a solved cube, you may not
be mapping the "cube space" densely enough to have a good confidence
that what you obtain is a position that requires on average those 18-
19 moves despite of the fact that the diameter of the cube is 20,
which is less than 25. As you do more and more moves, you will
approach asymptotically the distribution whose average number of
moves would approach those estimated 18-19 moves. It is an important
question to know the number of moves that will produce this, though,
so that we have some idea how many moves are necessary for a fair
mixing.

Jessica

> Dr C., (or anyone else!),
>
> There are 43illion possible cube states with a 3x3x3 cube.
>
> As I undertand it, it has not been proved that the maximum number
of moves
> required to solve a cube from one of these states is 25. To date,
however,
> no cube state has been found that takes more than 25 moves to solve.
>
> OK here's the question: Is there any way of working out the
*average* number
> of minimum moves required to solve the cube? In other words, if we
were to
> calculate the minimum number of moves required for each state, what
would
> the average be?
>
> I am asking becuase if we knew this average (let's say is is _n_)
then we
> could say that a cube state that can be "unscrambled" in fewer than
_n_
> moves was not scrambled properly, and conversely, a cube that takes
more
> than _n_ moves to solve is scrambled.
>
> I guess what would be interesting is a table like this filled in:
> % of cube states that can be solved in one move or less: ?
> % of cube states that can be solved in two moves or less: ?
> % of cube states that can be solved in three moves or less: ?
> % of cube states that can be solved in four moves or less: ?
> etc.
> ... the average would be where the 50% line is drawn.
>
> Is that a big ask? Has it been done already? If it cannot be done,
can
> educated approimations be done instead? Can it be done with a
2x2x2?
> S.

2105. [Speed cubing group] Re: Understanding algorithms

Besides, I could be vastly more efficient overall and in particular. < < > I think you will find that most people have pooled together ideas and moves as part of the process of refining their method. < I see some interesting things...I really like working things out for myself. > Maybe, but for me the sharing aspect of cubing - down to the moves > themselves - is part of what it makes it so much fun! I can see that it can be that way. > > How long have you been speedcubing? What kind of times do you turn in, and how many moves? > For about 6 months, after a 20 year break. > I have not timed myself for a while, and have been concentrating on getting my number of moves down, but between 30 and 40 seconds. > About 55 moves, going down to 50 moves once I have completed learning my current set. < Yeah, sometimes it's better not to try for speed per se, but to slow down when choosing what goes next. > Best of luck completing your set of combo moves. < Thanks, > It sounds like your ability to move the cube in your mind is far more developed then my own, and I suspect you have the potential to be an extremely capable blindfold cubist. < I've never tried it. 2106. New Member
From: "James Trimm <jstrimm@...>" <jstrimm@...>

Hello, My name is James Scott Trimm. I was introduced to the CUBE in while in high school in the 1980's. In a school of about 1,000 students (L.D. Bell High School in Hurst Texas) only four of us could solve the cube (Myself, Tommy Moak, Richad Delinski and Jeremy <something>) We used to cube race during lunch every day (I have not heard from them in nearly 20 years... any of you guys here?) >From the cube I found interest in related spacial puzzles. I am currently wrestling with square 1. I also enjoy three-dimesional chess: http://www.3dchessfederation.com http://groups.yahoo.com/group/3-d-chess/ Which also involves three-dimesnional thinking. James Scott Trimm

2108. Re: Understanding algorithms
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 14 Dec 2002 13:04:53 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@y...>" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > Hi Simon, > > > > Really? I'm surprised to hear this. I'd have thought that what I > do/did was commonplace. Besides, I could be vastly more efficient > overall and in particular. < < > > > I think you will find that most people have pooled together ideas > and moves as part of the process of refining their method. < > > I see some interesting things...I really like working things out > for myself. > > > Maybe, but for me the sharing aspect of cubing - down to the moves > > themselves - is part of what it makes it so much fun! > > I can see that it can be that way. > > > > How long have you been speedcubing? What kind of times do you > turn in, and how many moves? > > For about 6 months, after a 20 year break. > > I have not timed myself for a while, and have been concentrating on > getting my number of moves down, but between 30 and 40 seconds. > > About 55 moves, going down to 50 moves once I have completed > learning my current set. < > > Yeah, sometimes it's better not to try for speed per se, but to > slow down when choosing what goes next. > > > Best of luck completing your set of combo moves. < > > Thanks, > > > It sounds like your ability to move the cube in your mind is far > more developed then my own, and I suspect you have the potential to be > an extremely capable blindfold cubist. < > > I've never tried it. I once solved a friends cube over the phone, > does that count? 2110. Re: my new cube..part 10
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 14 Dec 2002 13:29:17 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > If you get the chance in Scrabble (and it's quite unlikely) play > oxyphenbutazone across 3 triple word scores - if these include the > first o, the b and the final e you'll get a multiplier of 27 on your > word score - if you also play the z you can get a double letter > score on it and maybe even play it across another word. You can get > 560 just for the z! Like this you can get a score of close to 1700 > for the one word which should win you the game. That's amazing! I can't imagine ever being able to play this word though since it's a 15 letter word and each player only ever has 7 letters at a time. It would mean that 8 of the letters would already have to be conveniently placed on the board in exactly the right place! It's still pretty amazing to even conceive of such a high scoring word. I shall email my Scrabble friends about it. They will also be amazed. :) Jasmine.

maybe someone here is in need of a project of this magnitude? Or
perhaps it's impractical? Geniuses, discuss amongst yourselves. But
if someone can do it, I hope they can also make an OSX client for me!

2113. Still having fun with my new 4x4x4
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 14 Dec 2002 16:10:42 -0000

I've been playing with my new Revenge cube since Monday and have sort
of got it under control now. By "sort of" I mean that I can solve
many of the last layer states, but not all (need to learn a few more
algs). I've been pretty slack about it really. I haven't been in the
mood for learning heaps of new algs so I've just been trying to use
intuition and adapt 3x3x3 algs (although I did grab a few Revenge
algs from Chris H's page).

I'm sure I'm not being very efficient, and I'm still spending a lot
of time inspecting the cube during the solution. Also, I'm trying to
be gentle with my 4x4x4 (which slows me down) since I hear that they
are much more fragile than the 3x3x3.

I timed a few solves yesterday and they were all ~9-10 mins. I'm not
too concerned by this since my initial aim was just to be able to
solve a Revenge. I'm sure I'll be able to cut down this time with
practise.

Jasmine.



2114. Re: New Member
From: "James Trimm <jstrimm@...>" <jstrimm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 14 Dec 2002 16:37:56 -0000

Nourse's Simple Solution. My times average around 1 min. 30 sec. I am aware that other solutions are faster. 2117. Re: Understanding algorithms
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 14 Dec 2002 20:44:08 -0000


> If there are any official rules of blindfolded cubing, where
can I
> find them?
>
> David J
>

There are, but since they include using new cubes fresh out of the
box, scrambled by independent witnesses with stopwatches etc. I've
not done it by the official rules. Basically I'd say it counts if
the cube is well scrambled, you examine it (you're not allowed to
make moves on it or written notes in this period) and then without
looking at it again (e.g. blindfold, eyes closed or dictating the
solution to someone else) you solve it. It should be solved
completely when you next look at it - otherwise it doesn't count -
and there shouldn't be people telling you that you're very close or
anything like that which may assist you in your solution.




2118. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: God's alg. average
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 14 Dec 2002 13:05:50 -0800

The math is pretty simple here, and still after 20 years very daunting. I don't remember the exact number of position, but it's around 10 to the 18th power. Which is a billion billons (in US terms). So for each byte you need to to store the data for each position, you end up with a billion gigabytes of disk space. I guess this is possible today, but it would cost about a billion dollars, per byte. How long does performing a billion billion computations take? A good number to remember when thinking about things like these, is that a year is 31.5 million seconds. So if you go through 1000 positions per second, you'll need about 30 years in total. Hm. I started out this wanting to prove how impossible this still is, but I guess it's not that far out of reach these days. It'll still need a few more years of Moores law before it can be done by people like us, but if it was a really important military or scientific project, it would already be underway. /Lars At 14:15 +0000 12/14/02, Robert Roue wrote: >I was wondering about the calculations for this. People say that it >would take sooo long for a computer to figure this out. How about if >we all had our computers calculating a portion of this. Like a >collaborative effort. > >I'm sure most of you have heard of SETI@home ><http://setiathome.ssl.berkeley.edu/>http://setiathome.ssl.berkeley.edu/ > >I don't have the brains to make something similar for the cube, but >maybe someone here is in need of a project of this magnitude? Or >perhaps it's impractical? Geniuses, discuss amongst yourselves. But >if someone can do it, I hope they can also make an OSX client for me! -- "They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever flipped it over?" Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@... http://lar5.com [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
2119. No Subject
From: "Hana M. Bizek <hanabizek@...>" <hanabizek@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 15 Dec 2002 00:19:38 -0000





2120. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: God's alg. average
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 15 Dec 2002 13:16:01 +1100

On Sat, Dec 14, 2002 at 01:05:50PM -0800, Lars Petrus wrote:

> I don't remember the exact number of position, but it's around 10 to
> the 18th power. Which is a billion billons (in US terms). So for each
> byte you need to to store the data for each position, you end up with
> a billion gigabytes of disk space. I guess this is possible today,
> but it would cost about a billion dollars, per byte.

If you're just counting how many positions at each depth, then you only
need storage space for 20 integers (if 20 is the maximum depth) but it
would take much longer - just iterate through each cube position
linearly (eg.
http://home.t-online.de/home/Kociemba/math/coordlevel.htm), solve each
position to find its depth, then increment the count for that depth (not
practical, though)

If you want something more efficient, you would need an array of bits -
one bit for each cube position to indicate whether that cube position
has been counted. Then the procedure is to generate each cube position.
If a cube position just generated has not been counted before, then it
is counted for its depth and flagged, and the procedure continues.

Ryan

2122. Rubik's cube art
From: "Hana M. Bizek <hanabizek@...>" <hanabizek@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 15 Dec 2002 13:29:44 -0000

Hi, group,
Rubik's cube art is a way of using Rubik's cube as an art medium,
either to create pieces from multiple cubes or from a single cube.
I "specialize" in multi-cube art, and my pieces, or "things" are
three dimensional (3D) structures. If you have any questions about
the terminology or judicious twiddling, please raise your questions
in this group and I will try to answer them. One of my things, the 3-
color Vasarely design, may be seen in my profile. This and other
designs may also be seen at http://cube.misto.cz. Please visit and be
welcome. :-)
I have a question of my own: do you know of anyone who creates 3D
designs from Rubik's cubes? I am unable to find anyone who can do it.
I need a little help from you. I know that there are pople on the web
who construct 2D, picture-like designs. I started those too, many
years ago, but gave them up in favor of 3D designs, which I consider
more challenging. However I did not, in my wildest dreams, imagine
that it would be so hard to find 3D designers. The method is not
*thjat* hard! So if you are doing this or know of anybody who does,
please send me email. Thank you.
Finally, let me apologize for the empy message I sent yesterday.
Computers are not my strong suit. Ignore that message, or, if
possible, throw it out. I would do this myself, but I don't know how!
Hana a kostky

2124. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: God's alg. average
From: Kåre Krig <karkr936@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 15 Dec 2002 15:26:59 +0100

----- Original Message ----- From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...> Date: Sunday, December 15, 2002 3:16 am Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: God's alg. average > On Sat, Dec 14, 2002 at 01:05:50PM -0800, Lars Petrus wrote: > > > I don't remember the exact number of position, but it's around > 10 to > > the 18th power. Which is a billion billons (in US terms). So for > each > > byte you need to to store the data for each position, you end up > with > > a billion gigabytes of disk space. I guess this is possible > today, > > but it would cost about a billion dollars, per byte. > > If you're just counting how many positions at each depth, then you > onlyneed storage space for 20 integers (if 20 is the maximum > depth) but it > would take much longer - just iterate through each cube position > linearly (eg. > http://home.t-online.de/home/Kociemba/math/coordlevel.htm), solve each > position to find its depth, then increment the count for that > depth (not > practical, though) > > If you want something more efficient, you would need an array of > bits - > one bit for each cube position to indicate whether that cube position > has been counted. Then the procedure is to generate each cube > position.If a cube position just generated has not been counted > before, then it > is counted for its depth and flagged, and the procedure continues. > > Ryan > Looks like we have the memory/time tradeoff that seems to be present at most cs problems. I personally think the best way to solve this would be to compute all positions of depth less than or equal to n ( n = 10 mabye?) and use that as a lookup table when searching for the shortest solutions for the rest of the positions. /Kï¿½re

2129. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: God's alg. average
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 15 Dec 2002 17:50:05 -0800

At 15:26 +0100 12/15/02, Kåre Krig wrote:
>
>I personally think the best way to solve this would be to compute
>all positions of depth less than or equal to n ( n = 10 mabye?) and
>use that as a lookup table when searching for the shortest solutions
>for the rest of the positions.
>
>/Kåre

How do you mean the lookup table thing would work?

As for data storage, I think all you really need is a reference to
the next position to get to, to get to the solution. When solving you
can compare the two positions, and figure out what move is needed to
get there. That's about 8 bytes per position, I believe.

/Lars

--
"They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever
flipped it over?"

Lars Petrus, San Francisco - lars@... http://lar5.com


2130. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: God's alg. average
From: Kåre Krig <karkr936@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 16 Dec 2002 13:13:10 +0100

----- Original Message ----- From: Lars Petrus <lars@...> Date: Monday, December 16, 2002 2:50 am Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: God's alg. average > At 15:26 +0100 12/15/02, Kï¿½re Krig wrote: > > > >I personally think the best way to solve this would be to compute > >all positions of depth less than or equal to n ( n = 10 mabye?) > and > >use that as a lookup table when searching for the shortest > solutions > >for the rest of the positions. > > > >/Kï¿½re > > How do you mean the lookup table thing would work? > > As for data storage, I think all you really need is a reference to > the next position to get to, to get to the solution. When solving > you > can compare the two positions, and figure out what move is needed > to > get there. That's about 8 bytes per position, I believe. > > /Lars My idea was that when solving a position of higher depth (>n) you have to first get to a position of depth n. So solve all positions with depth less than or equal to n. Then save the positions and depth for all with deepth n. You then know that all other positions will have solutions that pass thru one of the ones you have saved. When you have found the shortest path to one of those allready solved states you just look up the solution from that pototion, or you don care about the solution and just save the depth (n) for that pos. Then ofcourse it is nessesary to sort out what positions are less than or equal to n moves first. Mabye that could be done by applying moves to the solved state. /Kï¿½re
2131. new lube
From: "heretocube <rolerknight1977@...>" <rolerknight1977@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 16 Dec 2002 16:04:40 -0000

i went and got some new lube that kyubeman told me about... ace brand
silicone lubricant spray and a new cube... everyone knows with new
cubes they have to be broken in... well i didn't play with it at all
took it strait apart and lubed it within half an hour of buying it,
it was turning 5 times better than any i've ever owned... my only
prob now is that there is no friction and i'm overturning it... guess
i'll have to get used to it.... thanks ross :)

2135. Re: 2000 cubes...today
From: "heretocube <rolerknight1977@...>" <rolerknight1977@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 16 Dec 2002 17:54:13 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Dont forget that Jess Bonde's 2000 cubes in 24 hrs is today! You > > can watch it on his site. in the webcam section. > > > > I was just checking it out, but the video window is too small and > i > > cant seem much of the video at all :( > > > > -Heath > > ok, if you click to view the webcam link in a new window you can > see it all. type in address... www.rubiks.dk/webcam2 and you can see it
2136. question about 2000 cubes
From: "heretocube <rolerknight1977@...>" <rolerknight1977@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 16 Dec 2002 17:57:18 -0000

does anyone know how you can check his progress throughout the
attempt i have tried all i can think of and can't find it




2137. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: God's alg. average
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 16 Dec 2002 18:12:25 +0000

Thanks for your reply and links, Jessica and others. The crux of my question was can we break down the 43,252,003,274,489,856,000 positions into percentages that require moves (and by a move I mean one quarter turn of one face). Working this out by brute force would indeed take a lot of processing, but is there perhaps a more elegant method? We do not need to know what the positions are, or how to solve them. All we need to know are how many there are. We know that the number of positions that can be solved in 0 moves = 1. But take the first line in my desired table: % of cube states that can be solved in one move or less. Well, there are six faces that can each be moved in two different ways, producing 12 cube positions. Plus the cube could be solved, so 12+1=13 positions, which = 3.01^-17% So that's the first line done. Next: % of cube states that can be solved in two moves or less. Well, we have 12 positions, each of which can be manipulated in 12 different ways. One of each 12 will return it back to a solved state, so that = (12*11)+12+1= 145 = 3.35^-16% % of cube states that can be solved in three moves or less = (132*11)+(12*11)+12+1 = 1597 = 3.69^-15% Now surely there is some pattern to this? For example, I notice that the sequence: 1, 13, 145, 1597 can also be written as: (1), (12+1), (12^2+1), (12^3-12^2+1) Do we really need 256 Crays to this? I appreciate that things are going to get fairly complicated fairly quickly, but perhaps pencil and paper can go places that brute force cannot? S. >From: "Jessica Fridrich <jess340@...>" <jess340@...> >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: God's alg. average >Date: Fri, 13 Dec 2002 18:27:18 -0000 > >The answers to the questions you raised also depend on the counting. >It is easier to find some bounds is you count quarter-moves (by 90 >degrees) as one move and those by 180 degrees as two. It is known >that some highly symmetrical states require at least 24 moves (if I >remember correctly) and because there is an algorithm that has >exactly 24 moves, we pretty much know that the cube group diameter >for quanter-moves (q-moves) is at least 24. I think those symmetrical >positions include superflip (all edges flipped all else in place) and >supertwists (all corners twisted). > >A good place to learn about this is Mike Reid's page >http://www.math.umass.edu/~mreid/Rubik/m_symmetric.html and follow >the links to Cube-Lovers mailing list archives. Maybe there is a web >page that summarizes the knowledge regarding the cube group diameter >and related issues. > >I personaly think that for face turns (180 degrees = one move) the >diameter of the cube group is 20. We know (see the page referenced >above) that certain positions require at least 20 moves. If you run >Cube Explorer by generating random positions and then always going >for the optimal solution, you will find out that no position will >require more than 20 face moves. A few years back, when the optimal >solvers appeared, I heard of somebody who just kept his workstation >running continuously trying random positions and finding the optimal >algorithm looking for some answers as to the percentage of positions >with different number of moves. I also remember that he never >encountered a position that required more than 20 face moves. > >However, it is still an open question whether the cube group has >a "tail" in the sense of a few positions very far from the solved >state (farther than 20) that you will not likely generate by random >searches. In my opinion, the farthest positions will be those with a >high degree of symmetry, such as superflip. Based on this gut- >feeling, I would consider the cube diameter for face turns to be 20. > >When it comes to the average number of moves, again, my guess is that >it would be between 18 and 19, maybe closer to 19. This is based on >an anecdotal evidence of running the Cube Explorer a few times >myself. I think that a position that requires 17 indicates that the >cube is most likely not well mixed. But I am not sure at all how >exceptional this is. > >Now, if you make, say 25 random moves from a solved cube, you may not >be mapping the "cube space" densely enough to have a good confidence >that what you obtain is a position that requires on average those 18- >19 moves despite of the fact that the diameter of the cube is 20, >which is less than 25. As you do more and more moves, you will >approach asymptotically the distribution whose average number of >moves would approach those estimated 18-19 moves. It is an important >question to know the number of moves that will produce this, though, >so that we have some idea how many moves are necessary for a fair >mixing. > >Jessica > > > Dr C., (or anyone else!), > > > > There are 43illion possible cube states with a 3x3x3 cube. > > > > As I undertand it, it has not been proved that the maximum number >of moves > > required to solve a cube from one of these states is 25. To date, >however, > > no cube state has been found that takes more than 25 moves to solve. > > > > OK here's the question: Is there any way of working out the >*average* number > > of minimum moves required to solve the cube? In other words, if we >were to > > calculate the minimum number of moves required for each state, what >would > > the average be? > > > > I am asking becuase if we knew this average (let's say is is _n_) >then we > > could say that a cube state that can be "unscrambled" in fewer than >_n_ > > moves was not scrambled properly, and conversely, a cube that takes >more > > than _n_ moves to solve is scrambled. > > > > I guess what would be interesting is a table like this filled in: > > % of cube states that can be solved in one move or less: ? > > % of cube states that can be solved in two moves or less: ? > > % of cube states that can be solved in three moves or less: ? > > % of cube states that can be solved in four moves or less: ? > > etc. > > ... the average would be where the 50% line is drawn. > > > > Is that a big ask? Has it been done already? If it cannot be done, >can > > educated approimations be done instead? Can it be done with a >2x2x2? > > S. > > > > _________________________________________________________________ > > Tired of spam? Get advanced junk mail protection with MSN 8. > > http://join.msn.com/?page=features/junkmail > _________________________________________________________________ Add photos to your messages with MSN 8. Get 2 months FREE*. http://join.msn.com/?page=features/featuredemail
2138. Median number of moves
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 16 Dec 2002 18:40:04 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "simonl cube" <simonlcube@h...> wrote: > Next: % of cube states that can be solved in two moves or less. > > Well, we have 12 positions, each of which can be manipulated in 12 different > ways. One of each 12 will return it back to a solved state, so that = > (12*11)+12+1= 145 = 3.35^-16% Well 145 doesn't equal 3.35^-16%. Maybe you want 3.35*10^{-16}% of 43252003274489900000. In any event, you are mistaken since some of these positions are the same. e.g. R*R=(R')*(R'). So you'd have to subtract 6 here. It looks like you are trying to compute the number of words of length less than n in a free group on 6 generators. The cube group is not free - it's finite and non-trivial. Certainly one would expect that the median number of moves is far easier to obtain than the mean number of moves. There is a problem in that the concept median doesn't necessarily have an easy interpretation with discontinous data. As Jessica pointed out, the answer will depend on the number of generators you use. In one extreme case the mean number of moves will be just under 1 (there'd be 21626001637244950000 generators and the mean would be 43252003274489899999/43252003274489900000 moves) and the median number of moves would be 1 in a usual sort of interpretation. In the 2 generator case (where you only have 2 basic moves to solve the cube) the number would probably be quite large. One would expect that for the usual 6 generator case the median is within 2 or 3 of the diameter of the group (i.e. the maximum number of moves needed to solve any position).
2139. [Speed cubing group] Re: God's alg. average
From: "d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@...>" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 16 Dec 2002 19:04:41 -0000

Hi Simon, Jessica, and others, I've had the thought that a place to start would be with all of the corner positions, and then at least one shortest-route solution for each. They would essentially be "pointing", linking, to each other... Then define the edge changes that would accompany those solutions. Then define all of the edge changes possible without changing the corner positions. This last seems to be handled better if slices, are defined in the same way as, say, the upper and lower layers. I have a question. How would you count the "every possible exclusion" of the following limitation: a. you can't move only two edges alone, with no other changes; b. you can't move only two corners, with no other changes; c. you can move those two edges and two corners if you move them together? David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "simonl cube" <simonlcube@h...> wrote: > > Thanks for your reply and links, Jessica and others. The crux of my > question was can we break down the 43,252,003,274,489,856,000 positions into > percentages that require moves (and by a move I mean one quarter turn of one > face). > > Working this out by brute force would indeed take a lot of processing, but > is there perhaps a more elegant method? We do not need to know what the > positions are, or how to solve them. All we need to know are how many there > are. > > We know that the number of positions that can be solved in 0 moves = 1. But > take the first line in my desired table: % of cube states that can be > solved in one move or less. Well, there are six faces that can each be > moved in two different ways, producing 12 cube positions. Plus the cube > could be solved, so 12+1=13 positions, which = 3.01^-17% > > So that's the first line done. > > Next: % of cube states that can be solved in two moves or less. > > Well, we have 12 positions, each of which can be manipulated in 12 different > ways. One of each 12 will return it back to a solved state, so that = > (12*11)+12+1= 145 = 3.35^-16% > > % of cube states that can be solved in three moves or less = > (132*11)+(12*11)+12+1 = 1597 = 3.69^-15% > > Now surely there is some pattern to this? For example, I notice that the > sequence: > 1, 13, 145, 1597 can also be written as: > (1), (12+1), (12^2+1), (12^3-12^2+1) > > Do we really need 256 Crays to this? I appreciate that things are going to > get fairly complicated fairly quickly, but perhaps pencil and paper can go > places that brute force cannot? > S. > > > > > > > >From: "Jessica Fridrich <jess340@h...>" <jess340@h...> > >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > >To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > >Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: God's alg. average > >Date: Fri, 13 Dec 2002 18:27:18 -0000 > > > >The answers to the questions you raised also depend on the counting. > >It is easier to find some bounds is you count quarter-moves (by 90 > >degrees) as one move and those by 180 degrees as two. It is known > >that some highly symmetrical states require at least 24 moves (if I > >remember correctly) and because there is an algorithm that has > >exactly 24 moves, we pretty much know that the cube group diameter > >for quanter-moves (q-moves) is at least 24. I think those symmetrical > >positions include superflip (all edges flipped all else in place) and > >supertwists (all corners twisted). > > > >A good place to learn about this is Mike Reid's page > >http://www.math.umass.edu/~mreid/Rubik/m_symmetric.html and follow > >the links to Cube-Lovers mailing list archives. Maybe there is a web > >page that summarizes the knowledge regarding the cube group diameter > >and related issues. > > > >I personaly think that for face turns (180 degrees = one move) the > >diameter of the cube group is 20. We know (see the page referenced > >above) that certain positions require at least 20 moves. If you run > >Cube Explorer by generating random positions and then always going > >for the optimal solution, you will find out that no position will > >require more than 20 face moves. A few years back, when the optimal > >solvers appeared, I heard of somebody who just kept his workstation > >running continuously trying random positions and finding the optimal > >algorithm looking for some answers as to the percentage of positions > >with different number of moves. I also remember that he never > >encountered a position that required more than 20 face moves. > > > >However, it is still an open question whether the cube group has > >a "tail" in the sense of a few positions very far from the solved > >state (farther than 20) that you will not likely generate by random > >searches. In my opinion, the farthest positions will be those with a > >high degree of symmetry, such as superflip. Based on this gut- > >feeling, I would consider the cube diameter for face turns to be 20. > > > >When it comes to the average number of moves, again, my guess is that > >it would be between 18 and 19, maybe closer to 19. This is based on > >an anecdotal evidence of running the Cube Explorer a few times > >myself. I think that a position that requires 17 indicates that the > >cube is most likely not well mixed. But I am not sure at all how > >exceptional this is. > > > >Now, if you make, say 25 random moves from a solved cube, you may not > >be mapping the "cube space" densely enough to have a good confidence > >that what you obtain is a position that requires on average those 18- > >19 moves despite of the fact that the diameter of the cube is 20, > >which is less than 25. As you do more and more moves, you will > >approach asymptotically the distribution whose average number of > >moves would approach those estimated 18-19 moves. It is an important > >question to know the number of moves that will produce this, though, > >so that we have some idea how many moves are necessary for a fair > >mixing. > > > >Jessica > > > > > Dr C., (or anyone else!), > > > > > > There are 43illion possible cube states with a 3x3x3 cube. > > > > > > As I undertand it, it has not been proved that the maximum number > >of moves > > > required to solve a cube from one of these states is 25. To date, > >however, > > > no cube state has been found that takes more than 25 moves to solve. > > > > > > OK here's the question: Is there any way of working out the > >*average* number > > > of minimum moves required to solve the cube? In other words, if we > >were to > > > calculate the minimum number of moves required for each state, what > >would > > > the average be? > > > > > > I am asking becuase if we knew this average (let's say is is _n_) > >then we > > > could say that a cube state that can be "unscrambled" in fewer than > >_n_ > > > moves was not scrambled properly, and conversely, a cube that takes > >more > > > than _n_ moves to solve is scrambled. > > > > > > I guess what would be interesting is a table like this filled in: > > > % of cube states that can be solved in one move or less: ? > > > % of cube states that can be solved in two moves or less: ? > > > % of cube states that can be solved in three moves or less: ? > > > % of cube states that can be solved in four moves or less: ? > > > etc. > > > ... the average would be where the 50% line is drawn. > > > > > > Is that a big ask? 2150. Finaly solved my 4*4*4
From: Kåre Krig <karkr936@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 Dec 2002 12:12:09 +0100


After two weeks I fï¿½naly solved my 4*4*4 cube. As soon as I got it in the mail I solved centers and matched all but two edge pairs. Then I couldent figure out how to swap between that last two pairs and dident do much work on it. Then last night before falling asleap I realized that my move ( R u lï¿½uï¿½ R') actually don just match up the fu pair but swap pices from the three pairs fu, fd, lb. So this morning I figured out how the swaps where made and worked the cube untill I had three unsolved edge pairs. Currently I solve permutation error by scrambling and resolving, not the best way but it worked this time.

Got down to sub-60 average on the 3*3*3 too.

1650 cubes in 18h, Jess Bonde is quite amazing.

/Kï¿½re



2151. DONE!!!!!
From: jess_bonde <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 Dec 2002 15:51:40 -0000

Hi gang.
My attempt to solve 2000 cubes was a succes.
The time was 22 hours and 16 minutes.
I have printed out stats at every 100 cubes, and I'll be posting them
on my website soon. (right now I need to rest)
I send a giant thank you to all the people who were watching and were
on the chat supporting and cheering. I'm sorry for the poor camera
feed at some points, not only were we solving cubes but we also had
to maintain the cameras and they were a b.... at some points.
How about Morten... is he a friend or what? staying up for 24 hours
just scrambling cubes.
Thanks all.

Jess.

2161. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: God's alg. average
From: Ryan Heise <rheise@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 18 Dec 2002 13:54:41 +1100

On Fri, Dec 13, 2002 at 06:27:18PM -0000, Jessica Fridrich <jess340@...> wrote: > However, it is still an open question whether the cube group has > a "tail" in the sense of a few positions very far from the solved > state (farther than 20) that you will not likely generate by random > searches. In my opinion, the farthest positions will be those with a > high degree of symmetry, such as superflip. Based on this gut- > feeling, I would consider the cube diameter for face turns to be 20. Maybe you could test this theory on simpler versions of the cube: - just the corners of the cube (ie. 2x2x2) - just the edges of the cube - a cube where opposite sides are the same colour. - smaller cube groups > I heard of somebody who just kept his workstation > running continuously trying random positions and finding the optimal > algorithm looking for some answers as to the percentage of positions > with different number of moves. I also remember that he never > encountered a position that required more than 20 face moves. He probably didn't encounter a position that required only 8 moves (let alone 0 moves) to solve either, but the symmetry theory does sound plausible. > Now, if you make, say 25 random moves from a solved cube, you may not > be mapping the "cube space" densely enough to have a good confidence > that what you obtain is a position that requires on average those 18- > 19 moves despite of the fact that the diameter of the cube is 20, > which is less than 25. As you do more and more moves, you will > approach asymptotically the distribution whose average number of > moves would approach those estimated 18-19 moves. It is an important > question to know the number of moves that will produce this, though, > so that we have some idea how many moves are necessary for a fair > mixing. Another way is to generate a random arrangement of the pieces, and then use CubeExplorer to find a move sequence to reach that position. Ryan

2172. F2L question
From: "heretocube <rolerknight1977@...>" <rolerknight1977@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 18 Dec 2002 20:54:17 -0000

I have been working on learning the f2l basically 41 algs altogether
i was thinking that if i only learned the 11 algs that has the corner
in the right place and if i come up with the corner on the top just
use RUR' to drop it into place (about a half second finger trick) and
just apply one of the 11 algs to it would that be reasonable...
please if you have any input for me let me know... am i just trying
to learn to fast or is that a good start to learn maybe i'll loss a
second or 2 but my mind wouldn't be jumbled up with algs and that
will get me working on my probs for the last layer... sorry about the
babling i'm just anxious to break 30 seconds now that i got my ave
under 50...



2173. Re: F2L question
From: kyubeman <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 18 Dec 2002 22:39:01 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "heretocube <rolerknight1977@c...>" <rolerknight1977@c...> wrote: > I have been working on learning the f2l basically 41 algs altogether > i was thinking that if i only learned the 11 algs that has the corner > in the right place and if i come up with the corner on the top just > use RUR' to drop it into place (about a half second finger trick) and > just apply one of the 11 algs to it would that be reasonable... > please if you have any input for me let me know... am i just trying > to learn to fast or is that a good start to learn maybe i'll loss a > second or 2 but my mind wouldn't be jumbled up with algs and that > will get me working on my probs for the last layer... sorry about the > babling i'm just anxious to break 30 seconds now that i got my ave > under 50... Hey chris. I think it's always a good idea to experiment with the f2l, as obviously people have many styles. I think the BEST part of your proposal, is that you are going to learn at least 11 of the 41. I say this is the best idea, because I think you should eventually learn them all! As for doing it the way you suggest, it would be very good practice for those 11, but how many moves would it take? Theoretically, to place the last corner edge pair could take 14 turns to place, which is quite a bit high for someone trying to get below 30. So, I think your best bet is to ultimately learn the 41, and if it helps you learn by doing it the way you describe, then by all means go for it! Just make sure you learn from the experience! Another point I would make, is that the cases where the corner is on top, are mostly VERY easy! There are 14 cases that can all be solved by using the same "idea" shall we say. You might just find, that they appear to be a jumble of algs at first, but later, you will soon begin to understand them, and they will no longer be "algs" at all! Try an assortment of things, and assess your weakpoints. If you are losing more time on your F2L than on your LL, maybe consider working out a good f2l system BEFORE heavy LL practice. Good luck, and just keep at it. I'm sure it will soon fall into place. I trust I will see you in the chat this weekend, if you have any other questions! -Ross
2174. answers to questions and pictures available
From: jess_bonde <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 19 Dec 2002 00:43:47 -0000

>Hi Jess,
>Congratulations for solving 2000 cubes in a day!
>How much time was spent putting one cube down and picking up
>another, and did you have to wait sometimes for the next mix?
>Did Morten get anything for mixing that many cubes?
>How are his hands today?
>How would you be better prepared if you were to try again?
>David J

When I had a succesful solve (non-lucky and non-pop), and the next
cube was already scrambled, I pressed spacebar 3 times to stop the
timer, accept the time and start the next all at once. The countdown
time was 7 seconds (modified version not available for download ;o)
as I didn't think 5 seconds would be enough)
I started out with 10 seconds inspection but found myself waiting too
long to get started.
I switched after aprox. 100 cubes.
This turned out to be a wise choice. 2000 x 3 seconds = 1 hour 40
minutes.

Morten didn't get anything for it except food, hurting wrists and
tired eyes. But he knows I would do the same thing for him.

I waited for the next mix sometimes but that didn't matter.

If I ever were to do this again I would:
- have more people to scramble, not just 1
- record it all on VHS

>Jess: I have looked at your stats: what amazing times! Just out of
>interest, when doing your 2000 cubes, do you remember what your
>WORST time
>was?? I mean, did you do one real stinker?
>
>S.

After solving 1600-1700 cubes I started to forget how to twist
corners without flipping the edge in f2l. This resulted in some times
around 40 and 50 because I kept on trying.
I only had 1 time above 1 minute when a cube litteraly exploded in my
ands.

>Jess I'm definitely impressed! Congratulations on the record man! I
>could never do that, literally my wrist would probably explode :) I
>was wondering something about the 2000 cubes. Did you run into any
>lucky cubes? I assume these were counted because that's just a
>property of solving the cube that it might come up lucky once or
>more. It seems like those would be a blessing to run into,
>especially after several hundred full solves. Anyway I was just
>curious and serisouly congrats again!
>
>Chris

I think I had about 20 lucky cases but in the end I couldn't tell if
I was orienting or permuting so I actually didn't think about it. I
counted lucky cases as a solved cube of course but I tried to stop
the timer as close to my session average so it wouldn't affect it.
In the end it didn't matter because my times were pretty bad.

>Apperently, The new official record isn't 22,95 but 16,92 secondes
>for one cube with inspection !!.
>How many try do you execute for obtain this ?
>Do you do this before, during or after your marathon cube ??
>Can anyone do such a record outside cube competition in his own
>country ?? Because I think there is less pressure to beat a record
>at home than in a World competition !!!!!!
>
>PS: Congratulation for your Marathon cube Jess !!!!!
>
>Nicolas.

The record of 16.92 is not including inspection.
I did inspect the cube for 10 seconds
The old record was not including inspection either.
Before I started the marathon I solved 12 cubes and the 4th was 16.92
I guess anyone can do this but I would never call up Guinness just to
set one speed record. I did this in relation to the marathon.
I think the pressure was pretty high after all. The 12 cubes just
flew away and I was very very happy to get a good time so early.

AND NOW FOR THE INFORMATION!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I have uploaded some pictures from the marathon at:
http://www.rubiks.dk

enjoy,
Jess.

2178. Blindfold cubing
From: "James Potter <theboywholived81@...>" <theboywholived81@...>

Date: Thu, 19 Dec 2002 01:55:59 -0000

to solve the corners, but I need to use a pencil & paper for the
permutation numbers(I use Richard Carr's solution for blindfold
cubing). Does anyone have any tips that could help me? And how do
you memorize so many numbers?

2181. F2L algorithms, perhaps LL orientation/permutation videos
From: kyuubree <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 19 Dec 2002 06:42:02 -0000

Is there a site anywhere that possesses videos of algorithms for
these executions, with the cross on the bottom? I tried the ones on
rubiks.dk but alas...

Or, I have a list of my own algorithms with these but I am having
a hard time learning; I learn better by observing videos (I learned
the Z-Permutation from Dan Knights by watching his vid only twice; I
am more of a visual learner, and it's nice to see an experienced
cuber execute these moves). Anyways, if anyone is willing to (I
seriously don't expect anyone to do this, it's a wild request), I
could upload my algorithms and some kind soul could make vids of them
and delete them afterwards or something. Sorry that this post sounds
so selfish and lazy, but I've tried myself multiple times (nearly a
year now, I have no video camera of my own to use).




2182. Re: Blindfold cubing
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 19 Dec 2002 08:37:40 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "James Potter <theboywholived81@y...>" <theboywholived81@y...> wrote: > I'm beginning to learn to do the cube blindfolded. So far I'm able > to solve the corners, but I need to use a pencil & paper for the > permutation numbers(I use Richard Carr's solution for blindfold > cubing). Does anyone have any tips that could help me? And how do > you memorize so many numbers? Most important is to be able to look at a piece and know what number it represents so take some time on a solved cube and think to yourself that this particular colour combination goes with this number. For instance, on my cubes the edge coloured white-green-red is edge 1 and the blue-yellow-red edge is edge 7 etc. Memorizing the corners (position-wise) amounts to memorizing a sequence of 8 numbers (not much longer than a telephone number). For the orientation it's best to just think of pairs or triples of corners that you will orient together. I tend to be good at just memorizing digits - I once memorized pi to 830 decimal places without any real sort of memorization technique (I'd use groups of 3 and 4 and sometimes note things like some group was a prime or a cube etc.) Nonetheless, it is possible to associate pairs of numbers with things to try to make life easier. I'll try and post some suggestions in my lunch break.
2183. Re: [Speed cubing group] F2L question
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 19 Dec 2002 16:48:28 +0000

Hi Chris. Under 50 seonds is great! I'm also keen to average under 30
seconds! Jessica (I think) posted a few months ago that in speedcubing
there's no free lunch ... if you want to get your f2l times down then you
will probably want to get those 41 learnt, plus others! There are lots of
different ways to do the f2l, and what works best for one person might not
be best for someone else, so experiment with different moves and approaches
and try to tailor it to fit your hands and mind.

But however you do it, learning f2l seems to fall into two parts: there is
the learning of the algorithms themselves, and then there is also learning
to *recognize* the patterns as they come up, improving until you start to
"look ahead", seeing what to do next while finishing up something else.
Now, as has been said many times on this forum in many different ways,
learning the actual algorithms (whichever ones you deide to do) for f2l is
not as difficult as the last layer algorithms, becuase (a) a lot of them
fall into one of only a few "groups", and (b) most of them are short enough,
or direct enough, to see how the algorithm "works", making memorization
easier.

For that reason, I think it is the recognition part of the f2l that requires
the most attention. And that is why my tip would be yes, learn those 11
ones first as you suggest. But once learnt try to avoid doing f2l with just
those 11 algorithms and no others for any length of time, because if you do
you may find yourself needing to "re-learn" the recognition part of the f2l,
and the re-learning may take more time then the learning itself. So I would
suggest that once you have those 11 under your fingers start on the others
as soon as you can. I promise you, if you just gird those loins, straighten
that back, bite that bullet and stiffen those lips (I'm getting a slightly
odd picture here ;-)) the 41 algorithms will quickly become about 10
algorithms plus 30 others that all become one of about four different sorts.
Getting all 41 down as a chunk will help with the recognition part of your
f2l, plus lay a good foundation for the looking ahead part (which I am still
working on ... arrgggghh!!).

Pretty soon after getting those 41 done you will want to start thinking
about using empty slots to cut down your number of moves, like the ones at:
http://www.oinkleburger.com/cube/f2l/
My point above holds with the shortcuts as well: if you train your brain for
too long to see f2l with just the 41 set, you may find that under pressure
(e.g. time pressure) your mind will most annoyingly bring up only those 41,
and no others (does anyone else have that?).

Anyway, very best with your f2l. I find practising f2l to be the most fun
part of Jessica's method. It might take a while, but at least I will enjoy
working on it. Now orienting the last layer in one look ... that's pure
slog!
S.

>
>I have been working on learning the f2l basically 41 algs altogether
>i was thinking that if i only learned the 11 algs that has the corner
>in the right place and if i come up with the corner on the top just
>use RUR' to drop it into place (about a half second finger trick) and
>just apply one of the 11 algs to it would that be reasonable...
>please if you have any input for me let me know... am i just trying
>to learn to fast or is that a good start to learn maybe i'll loss a
>second or 2 but my mind wouldn't be jumbled up with algs and that
>will get me working on my probs for the last layer... sorry about the
>babling i'm just anxious to break 30 seconds now that i got my ave
>under 50...
>

2185. update on my f2l
From: "heretocube <rolerknight1977@...>" <rolerknight1977@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 20 Dec 2002 01:10:08 -0000

well i was asking about opinions of learning only 11 of the 41 algs
and i appreciate the feedback that i got but now that i am farther
into it i see that if i only use 11 algs then i am no farther than i
was before cuz i am still taking the extra time to drop the corner
needed into the bottom layer so i am basically still doing a layer by
layer... and with further inspection of the f2l algs they are all
easy to learn cuz there is an alg for each situation that uses my 3
fav faces F, U, R... which all fit my hands good i am only through
abuot 10 of the 41 but have also found different algs that aren't
listed and work better for some situations than the algs that are
listed.... i guess that is the good thing about learning new
stuff....



2186. Re: Blindfold cubing
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 20 Dec 2002 14:05:36 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Sorry, didn't get much time at lunch today. I will try tomorrow. You can try to associate pairs of numbers with stuff like the Olympics: e.g. 1 2 Stockholm 2 4 Paris 2 8 Amsterdam 3 2 Lake Placid (Winter - summer location conflicts with 84) 3 6 Berlin 4 8 London 5 2 Helsinki 5 6 Melbourne 6 4 Tokyo 6 8 Mexico (City) 7 2 Munich 7 6 Montreal 8 4 Los Angeles 9 2 Barcelona 9 4 Lillehammer 9 6 Atlanta 9 8 Nagano (You can't get the pair 8 8 so no Seoul, unfortunately.) I only actually knew some of these (looked up the rest). I'd probably think more of 36 as being a square. Dialing codes: e.g. 2 12 (Manhattan) 4 11 (directory enquiries - US) 6 11 (report phone needing fixing - US) 9 11 (emergency - US) Health forms 1 11 (E1 11 is the form you get to be covered in Europe on holiday from the UK) Primes 1 3, 1 7, 1 9, 2 3, 2 9, 2 11, 3 1, 3 7, 3 11, 4 1, 4 3, 4 7, 5 3, 5 9, 6 1, 6 7, 7 1, 7 3, 7 9, 8 3, 8 9, 8 11, 9 7, 9 11, 10 1, 10 3, 10 7, 10 9, 11 3, 12 7 Squares 1 6, 2 5, 3 6, 4 9, 6 4, 8 1, 12 1 Cubes 2 7, 6 4, 12 5 Alphabet 2 6 Cards 5 2 5 4 (with jokers) 5 6 (if 3 jokers plus bridge scoring card) 2 1 Pontoon/Blackjack etc. You could probably make up stuff for everything if you wanted. I generally just remember the digits but this method isn't suitable for everyone. e.g. to start you off 1 2 Dozen 1 3 Baker('s dozen), triskadekaphobia etc. 1 4 Valentine and so forth.

2188. Re: Blindfold cubing
From: "Yuri Pertsovski <yurip@...>" <yurip@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 20 Dec 2002 15:25:02 -0000

When I began cubing, about 10 months ago, I was also interested in
mnemonics and I searched the net for memory techniques. I found a
great site that explains many systems for different purposes. Using
these I was able to memorise a pack of playing cards (suit and
number by order).

I didn't get any further, but theses systems can be great for speed-
blindfold-cubing. The major system is good for memorising a cube,
because encoding/decoding of information in memory can be very fast.
It requires memorising of 3 words for moving corners, 4 for moving
edges, and the same number to flip corners/edges at the worst case.
It has one major disadvantage though - it takes a lot of time to
learn.

Links:
http://www.mindtools.com/memory.html (new site)
or
http://www.demon.co.uk/mindtool/memory.html (old site)
The old site has sections that aren't on the new site and vice versa.
Another good site: http://www.happychild.org.uk/acc/tpr/index.htm

I hope this is helpful.

Yuri



2189. 5x5x5 method suggestions
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 20 Dec 2002 23:51:24 -0000

I just scrambled my new 5x5x5 for the first time. Like my new 4x4x4, I
want to try and work out a lot myself before resorting to the net for
algorithms. However, I was hoping to get a few ideas about where to
start. Nothing really specific, just general ideas, in the way that
the general ideas of solving a 3x3x3 are layer-based methods and
corners-first methods.

I'm guessing that some methods are heaps better than others so I'm
hoping to at least get started on the right track. When I started on
my 4x4x4, I tried edges first and it was a diasater. I could get all
edges + some centre pieces, but couldn't work out the rest. Once I
changed to centres first, all was fine and I had worked it out in a
few days (although I did end up grabbing 3-4 algs from Chris H's
page)



2190. Re: [Speed cubing group] F2L question
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 21 Dec 2002 00:19:33 -0000

I definitely subscribe to the idea of learning F2L by recognition + understanding, rather than blindly learning algorithms. When I first cubing, the main aim was just to solve the thing. Once I had done this, and gotten my time down to about a minute, I looked for other things to do with the cube. One was obviously to work on improving my times. Another was improving the efficiency of my solution so that I could reduce the average number of moves it takes to solve the cube (in time, this should lead to an improvement in speed). A third thing I've been getting into this year trying to get a better understanding of how the cube works. As a result, I no longer think of anything in F2L as being done by algs. Having said all this, my times are still around a minute and have gotten a little worse recently. I've been so excited by my new 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 that I've barely touched my 3x3x3 in weeks. Jasmine. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "simonl cube" <simonlcube@h...> wrote: z> But however you do it, learning f2l seems to fall into two parts: there is > the learning of the algorithms themselves, and then there is also learning > to *recognize* the patterns as they come up, improving until you start to > "look ahead", seeing what to do next while finishing up something else. > Now, as has been said many times on this forum in many different ways, > learning the actual algorithms (whichever ones you deide to do) for f2l is > not as difficult as the last layer algorithms, becuase (a) a lot of them > fall into one of only a few "groups", and (b) most of them are short enough, > or direct enough, to see how the algorithm "works", making memorization > easier. > > For that reason, I think it is the recognition part of the f2l that requires > the most attention. And that is why my tip would be yes, learn those 11 > ones first as you suggest. But once learnt try to avoid doing f2l with just > those 11 algorithms and no others for any length of time, because if you do > you may find yourself needing to "re-learn" the recognition part of the f2l, > and the re-learning may take more time then the learning itself. So I would > suggest that once you have those 11 under your fingers start on the others > as soon as you can. I promise you, if you just gird those loins, straighten > that back, bite that bullet and stiffen those lips (I'm getting a slightly > odd picture here ;-)) the 41 algorithms will quickly become about 10 > algorithms plus 30 others that all become one of about four different sorts. > Getting all 41 down as a chunk will help with the recognition part of your > f2l, plus lay a good foundation for the looking ahead part (which I am still > working on ... arrgggghh!!). > > Pretty soon after getting those 41 done you will want to start thinking > about using empty slots to cut down your number of moves, like the ones at: > http://www.oinkleburger.com/cube/f2l/ > My point above holds with the shortcuts as well: if you train your brain for > too long to see f2l with just the 41 set, you may find that under pressure > (e.g. time pressure) your mind will most annoyingly bring up only those 41, > and no others (does anyone else have that?). > > Anyway, very best with your f2l. I find practising f2l to be the most fun > part of Jessica's method. It might take a while, but at least I will enjoy > working on it. 2192. At least I had my cubes
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 21 Dec 2002 00:51:06 -0000

I accidentally got locked in the stairwell at work yesterday. I'd been
working much later than usual and didn't know that this particular
stairwell was locked up after hours *and* that my office key only
opened the other stairwell, not the one I was in. I had my mobile with
me so I was able to call someone to rescue me. I knew everything would
be fine, but it was a little distressing at the time, and I was going
to have to wait half an hour to be rescued. Fortunately, I had my new
cubes (4x4, 5x5) and my regular cube in my bag. I find cubing relaxing
and it takes my mind off other things, which is exactly what I needed,
rather than panicking about being locked in the stairwell. I made a
start on the 5x5x5 (having only just messed it up that day for the
first time). I didn't really know what I was doing so I just started
familiarising myself with how individual bits work (eg. made a face,
scrambled again, made a few centres, scrambled again). I'm so glad I
had my cubes with me otherwise I probably would have started to feel
pani

sometimes more than 3+ hours, I have been able to get my time down
to about 45 seconds. I was also able to memorize all 21
permutations for the last layer. I was wondering if someone could
give me some tips on ways to memorize the 50 orientations. I know
it is going to take time to learn, and god knows how many stickers I
will wear out, but does anyone have suggestions? Thanks in
advance! And happy speedcubing!

2197. Re: 5x5x5 method suggestions
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 21 Dec 2002 17:07:48 -0000

Solve one of the centres and then the opposite centre. Solve a third centre and then an adjacent centre. Then solve the last two centres. Join up all the edges. If one of the edges needs fixing do that before you embark on finishing with a 3x3x3 solution. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I just scrambled my new 5x5x5 for the first time. Like my new 4x4x4, I > want to try and work out a lot myself before resorting to the net for > algorithms. However, I was hoping to get a few ideas about where to > start. Nothing really specific, just general ideas, in the way that > the general ideas of solving a 3x3x3 are layer-based methods and > corners-first methods. > > I'm guessing that some methods are heaps better than others so I'm > hoping to at least get started on the right track. When I started on > my 4x4x4, I tried edges first and it was a diasater. I could get all > edges + some centre pieces, but couldn't work out the rest. Once I > changed to centres first, all was fine and I had worked it out in a > few days (although I did end up grabbing 3-4 algs from Chris H's > page)
2198. Re: Learning Orientation For Last Layer
From: kyubeman <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 21 Dec 2002 20:57:11 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, eligeon <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hello! After being gone for almost 4 months because of marching > band, I have returned! :-D Since the trips to competitions were > sometimes more than 3+ hours, I have been able to get my time down > to about 45 seconds. I was also able to memorize all 21 > permutations for the last layer. I was wondering if someone could > give me some tips on ways to memorize the 50 orientations. I know > it is going to take time to learn, and god knows how many stickers I > will wear out, but does anyone have suggestions? Thanks in > advance! And happy speedcubing! > > > Signature: "To envy can be deadly; to imitate is suicide", Self > Reliance by Ralph Waldo Emerson Hello there! Good to see you wanting to learn more! If you want to learn the orientations, first and foremost, I'd say learn the advanced 3 look LL. That is, if you already haven't. If you HAVE done this, then look on the internet for a set of algs that seems to best fit your hands. The algs that are the best triggered for your hands will be the easiest to remember as time goes on. Then, there's no other way around it: dive in. Try to learn them in pairs, 2 or 4 per day. After a month, you will be done, which is not so bad. A good place to look at at least for a reference, is Jessica Fridrich's site. She displays the probability of occurence of each orientation alg. I think you should learn the ones that come up the most frequently first, and then work your way down to the less occurring ones. Basically, just bite the bullet, and start. I don't think there is any secret to it other than to just get started, and know that it will all be over soon. The one tip that helps you learn, is ALWAYS ALWAYS ALWAYS look for fingertricks! They make moves much easier to remember! Good luck, and get crackin! -Ross
2199. This plateau is killing me
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 22 Dec 2002 03:47:36 -0000

I took an average time just now (taking into account the F2L time as
well). Here is what I came up with.

22.77 20.35 21.73 21.20 25.43 (26.31) (19.77) 22.30 24.62 25.53
24.90 26.19 = 23.50

Since none of these times were lucky cases I looked at the average of
all 12 runs for the F2L and LL and here is what I got,

F2L
13 10 14 13 15 18 12 13 17 15 16 18 = 14.5

LL
10 10 8 8 10 8 8 9 8 11 9 8 = 8.91

so sometimes I get a good F2L and a good LL, sometimes a bad F2L and
good LL, sometimes a good F2L and bad last layer,and sometimes bad
for both. Anyway where I'm confused is whether or not it's me that's
causing my plateau or my cube being 4 1/2 years old. I'm going to
get a studio cube and fix it up pretty soon and see once and for all,
but for now I'm trying to figure this out. The differences in my
times for the F2L and LL are extremely sporadic so I'm thinking that
maybe the problem is me. Also though I've noticed that LL perms and
orientations that I used to be able to do in 2.5 seconds or so every
time are now starting to get caught a lot and even the easy cases
take 4-5 seconds sometimes, so I'm thinking maybe my cube is partly
to blame. I made a video of me doing the cube several times, some
were very good times for me, I think I caught an 18 on tape, and I
also got a few bad times at 26's and I think a 27 or 28. I'm going
to try to get these onto my computer and I was wondering if you guys
could look at them and maybe give me some advice on where exactly I
need to improve.

Sometimes I get 9 or 10 second (non-lucky) F2L times and sometimes I
get 20's, sometimes I get 6 or 7 second (non-lucky) LL times and
sometimes I get 10-12 seconds. I was just wondering if anyone else
had/has this problem and how you got past it/are working past it.

*Slightly* frustrated still,
Chris

I found a > great site that explains many systems for different purposes. 2205. revenge piece question

is actually 'two' parts. All the other centres (and on every other
revenge I own) are all a single moulded piece. But this one blue piece
is kind of 'movable', because the leg is separate to the face. What is
this for?



2206. mefferts xmas east sheen
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 22 Dec 2002 19:37:27 -0000

When I opened the package that i ordered from mefferts i was shocked
at the sizes of the 4x4 and 5x5. There so dinky to what i normally
use. I was afraid to use them for fear of breaking the tiny pieces,
but after looking at the guts of em, they are well built and you can
adjust the center peice for a looser cube or tighter cube, I also
applied some silicon to them and they are incredible!!!! They are
certainly awesome cubes.

I got one question though, do they make the 4x4 and 5x5 in a bigger
size yet using their on internal design. I think a bigger cube would
be slightly more comfortable then the tiny ones.

well they both get my thumbs,
enjoy your Decemberween
jake



2207. Re: 5x5x5 method suggestions
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 23 Dec 2002 10:28:32 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cubed68 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > is this the best/easiset way to sovle the 5 x 5 I'm sure there are better ways but I don't know of them and they may not be easier. For instance, it's likely that the best way would be hard to work out in practise (like the best way to solve the ordinary cube is never really the one a person would use). I've broken 2 minutes with this method (on a java cube) and been sub 2:20 on very many occasions, so I'd say it's pretty good. > > Peter > > > Solve one of the centres and then the opposite centre. Solve a > third > > centre and then an adjacent centre. Then solve the last two > centres. > > Join up all the edges. If one of the edges needs fixing do that > > before you embark on finishing with a 3x3x3 solution.
2208. Re: 5x5x5 method suggestions
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 23 Dec 2002 11:32:51 -0000

I'll keep playing for a few days amd see if I can work it out, otherwise I may have to resort to asking advice for specific algs!
