2210. Re: This plateau is killing me
From: "stiff_hands <angela.hayden@...>" <angela.hayden@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 23 Dec 2002 17:47:03 -0000

Chris, I know what you mean. I am getting frustrated at all these people rushing past me whilst I am floundering, but then I have hardly cubed due to a bad wrist. I have swapped to a studio cube, and although I mess up a lot when on autopilot putting pieces in the wrong slow and with wrong orientation (the colour scheme is completely different) I think this will ultimately be beneficial. I was hitting the same problems of taking 5-6 seconds on a 3 second ll algorithm, but with this new cube the corners don't joggle and I not getting so many bad ll times, however my f2l is still erratic from 12- 20 which I put down to unfamiliarity with the current colour scheme. Yesterday I did a set of 12 and broke 25 seconds maybe twice and in another twenty cubes or so most of them were 27-28 seconds, whilst today I did a set: 21,28,20,*,17,25,*,22,19,24,17,22=22.0 average I reckon the answer must be more practice, a cube that doesn't joggle and familiarity with the colour scheme. - stiff_hands --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I took an average time just now (taking into account the F2L time as > well). Here is what I came up with. > > 22.77 20.35 21.73 21.20 25.43 (26.31) (19.77) 22.30 24.62 25.53 > 24.90 26.19 = 23.50 > > Since none of these times were lucky cases I looked at the average of > all 12 runs for the F2L and LL and here is what I got, > > F2L > 13 10 14 13 15 18 12 13 17 15 16 18 = 14.5 > > LL > 10 10 8 8 10 8 8 9 8 11 9 8 = 8.91 > > so sometimes I get a good F2L and a good LL, sometimes a bad F2L and > good LL, sometimes a good F2L and bad last layer,and sometimes bad > for both. Anyway where I'm confused is whether or not it's me that's > causing my plateau or my cube being 4 1/2 years old. I'm going to > get a studio cube and fix it up pretty soon and see once and for all, > but for now I'm trying to figure this out. The differences in my > times for the F2L and LL are extremely sporadic so I'm thinking that > maybe the problem is me. Also though I've noticed that LL perms and > orientations that I used to be able to do in 2.5 seconds or so every > time are now starting to get caught a lot and even the easy cases > take 4-5 seconds sometimes, so I'm thinking maybe my cube is partly > to blame. I'm going > to try to get these onto my computer and I was wondering if you guys > could look at them and maybe give me some advice on where exactly I > need to improve. > > Sometimes I get 9 or 10 second (non-lucky) F2L times and sometimes I > get 20's, sometimes I get 6 or 7 second (non-lucky) LL times and > sometimes I get 10-12 seconds. I was just wondering if anyone else > had/has this problem and how you got past it/are working past it. > > *Slightly* frustrated still, > Chris
2211. Re: This plateau is killing me
From: "Jessica Fridrich <jess340@...>" <jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 23 Dec 2002 18:26:15 -0000

Chris,

I looked at your times as you broke them up into the F2L and the LL.

> F2L
> 13 10 14 13 15 18 12 13 17 15 16 18 = 14.5

This is a pretty large variability for the F2L. It looks like if
you "see" the corner-edge pairs, you fly and can do it in 10,
however, if you have to search for them, you get an 18. A bad cube
can slow you down quite a bit, in the F2L, btw. I use two-face finger
shortcuts quite a bit in the F2L and if your cube gets stuck all the
times, you will lose a few seconds.

The same goes for the LL. Based on what you said, it seems that you
could shave off about 2 seconds and do the LL in 7-8 seconds pretty
much consistently.

Besides the cube itself, the large variance in the F2L tells me that
you still need more practice to get rid of those "outliers" and keep
the F2L in the 10-13 range to get sub-20. My guess is that you have
delays between algorithms. You can tell if you have delays by taping
the sound you make while cubing and then listening to that sound.
Ideally, the F2L should be almost without interruption (one in the
beginning is OK, but three is too many). When I race with Mirek
Goljan, we both can tell exactly when we finish the F2L and how well
we are doing just by the _sound_ we hear. I know if I hear a pretty
much continuous noise from his side that his time will be good and
that I have to do my best to win. On the other hand, if I hear a lot
of quiteness, I can relax because I know his time will be bad.

If you average F2L in 10-13 and the last layer in 7-8, you will have
a sub-20 average. This certainly seems possible, IMHO.

Good luck and do not give up! If you feel like giving up, jump onto a
car/bus/train/plane and come to Binghamton. I bet that a day here
with me and Mirek Goljan will help you quite a bit :)

Merry Christmas and Happy New Year to you!

Jessica

> LL
> 10 10 8 8 10 8 8 9 8 11 9 8 = 8.91
>
> so sometimes I get a good F2L and a good LL, sometimes a bad F2L
and
> good LL, sometimes a good F2L and bad last layer,and sometimes bad
> for both. Anyway where I'm confused is whether or not it's me
that's
> causing my plateau or my cube being 4 1/2 years old. I'm going to
> get a studio cube and fix it up pretty soon and see once and for
all,
> but for now I'm trying to figure this out. The differences in my
> times for the F2L and LL are extremely sporadic so I'm thinking
that
> maybe the problem is me. Also though I've noticed that LL perms
and
> orientations that I used to be able to do in 2.5 seconds or so
every
> time are now starting to get caught a lot and even the easy cases
> take 4-5 seconds sometimes, so I'm thinking maybe my cube is partly
> to blame. I made a video of me doing the cube several times, some
> were very good times for me, I think I caught an 18 on tape, and I
> also got a few bad times at 26's and I think a 27 or 28. I'm going
> to try to get these onto my computer and I was wondering if you
guys
> could look at them and maybe give me some advice on where exactly I
> need to improve.
>
> Sometimes I get 9 or 10 second (non-lucky) F2L times and sometimes
I
> get 20's, sometimes I get 6 or 7 second (non-lucky) LL times and
> sometimes I get 10-12 seconds. I was just wondering if anyone else
> had/has this problem and how you got past it/are working past it.

> Chris

2213. some ideas about going faster.....
From: misleadyouth86 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 23 Dec 2002 21:53:03 -0000

hey.. i recently started using the "popular" ll method... of
orienting the whole bottom layer.. and then permuting it.... at the
current time i am capable of permuting the corners and edges
serperately... some times both at once depending the case.... but
permuting doesnt take me that long anyway... and as far as orienting
goes... i just do the alg to make a cross on the bottom... and
sometimes there is more than a cross on the bottom... and i know the
orientation algs for all the possibilities that come after i make the
cross on the bottom.... should i learn more orientation algs and just
skip the cross part to make my times faster? or just learn more
permutation algs? because my times are pretty varied... my best time
ever is 43 seconds... but my average time is somewhere under 1:10 i
get lots of 1:06's and 1:12's and stuff like that and a 1:20 during
horrible cube states.... what should i work on first to speed up my
times? and another thing... i dont put f2l corners and edges in at
the same time... and couldnt learn a way that was effecting.... the
way i did it was i rotated the pieces around until that would go
together then i would put them in... and i found that this took about
the same, if not a little longer that doing corners and edges
seperately... so any pointers at all would be appreciated... thanks

casen



2214. Re: some ideas about going faster.....
From: "heretocube <rolerknight1977@...>" <rolerknight1977@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 23 Dec 2002 22:41:20 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, misleadyouth86 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > hey.. i recently started using the "popular" ll method... of > orienting the whole bottom layer.. and then permuting it.... at the > current time i am capable of permuting the corners and edges > serperately... some times both at once depending the case.... but > permuting doesnt take me that long anyway... and as far as orienting > goes... i just do the alg to make a cross on the bottom... and > sometimes there is more than a cross on the bottom... and i know the > orientation algs for all the possibilities that come after i make the > cross on the bottom.... should i learn more orientation algs and just > skip the cross part to make my times faster? or just learn more > permutation algs? because my times are pretty varied... my best time > ever is 43 seconds... but my average time is somewhere under 1:10 i > get lots of 1:06's and 1:12's and stuff like that and a 1:20 during > horrible cube states.... what should i work on first to speed up my > times? and another thing... i dont put f2l corners and edges in at > the same time... and couldnt learn a way that was effecting.... the > way i did it was i rotated the pieces around until that would go > together then i would put them in... and i found that this took about > the same, if not a little longer that doing corners and edges > seperately... so any pointers at all would be appreciated... thanks > > casen well i'm not much better than you are i only average about 45-50 seconds with a pb of 36 but i'll tell you what i have been working on... i have not worried about my LL as of yet i am learning the F2L (inserting corner and edges together) and although i have slowed down my pace because of the different stuff i am learning and i'm only half way through learning them (easier than they look)... i still get around the same times so when i get the new stuff back up to regular speed i think my times are gonna drop a lot.... i would say learn the 41 F2L algs for the F2L and that is the advice that i have been given many times.... and oh yeah i solve my LL by... orienting edges, permiating corners, orienting corners, and lastly permiating edges and with using only about ten algs i can do LL in about 10-13 seconds... hope my babbling helped you at least a little...:)
2215. Re: This plateau is killing me
From: kyubeman <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 24 Dec 2002 05:16:32 -0000

It certainly seems like you have what it takes to get below 20
seconds. I think what Olly and Jessica said is definitely very true,
and who better can you trust? ;) I wonder if maybe your "giving up
the cube" for a while has something to do? I think once you again
familiarize your brain with many cases that you haven't "warmed back
up to" yet you will see more consistency. Also, continue the search
for algorithms in the last layer that you like, though I assume you
must like the ones you have. As for f2l, really try coming into the
chat each weekend! I have learned SOOO much from our discussions on
f2l, (ie special cases, empty slot moves, non-rotation) it can be
quite helpful to get in there and discuss! As always, never put down
the cube. Ok, now that was all pretty unoriginal I guess, and you
probably think that doesn't help much, and I'm sorry, but I have
*one* more idea that helped me a lot. Try to cube as SMOOTHLY and
slowly as you can, with no pauses whatsoever. I said to myself a
month or so ago: "I wonder how EASY it is to break 30 seconds?" and
I sat down and cubed so SLOWLYYYYYYY!!!!! But it was also without
pauses, because when you go slowly and 'carefully' I guess, you can
see every single piece moving around in f2l. I was shocked to find
that not only was I EASILY getting times below 30, but also times
around 22 seconds, this is without rotating either, just going really
slowly. I guess you could call it sort of cube "zen" because it felt
SOO slow that it was ridiculous! I even showed my friend who cubes,
and during a run where I did a 20 second time going "slowly" he
couldn't believe it! He kept saying: "What are you doing?!?! GO
FASTER!!!!" Then was shocked to see that I solved it very quickly.
Likewise, my parents watched me "effortlessly" beat minh thai's old
record I have on my computer, and were amazed. Ron and Jessica have
both talked of this feeling, and I never understood it until I tried
to simply break 30 seconds as easily as I could! Give it a try, you
might be surprised to see some very good times. Anyway, just a few
thoughts. Good luck as always, and don't let your brain convince you
that you can't beat 22. I think if YOU are convinced you are
plateaued, then you are! So think positive!

-Ross



2216. Re: This plateau is killing me
From: "Jessica Fridrich <jess340@...>" <jess340@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 24 Dec 2002 12:53:52 -0000

Ross,

well put, indeed! Doesn't it feel unreal? I am glad that what Ron
and I have emphasized for a long time - you need to go "slower" to
be faster - starts to make sense. There is one more immensely
important factor why going slower means faster times. When you
say "I am going to break 30 seconds effortlessly, you not only twist
slower, but you become RELAXED. You give up that "competition" mode
in which you are nervous and try to break your neck to do it as fast
as humanly possible. Not only does that cause you to get stuck more
often, you get more pop ups, and you "cramp up". Yes, you do twist
faster, but you go suboptimal and you lose the concept of what is
going on. This is why faster twisting may give you slower times.

Has anyone ever noticed a correlation between faster times and
feeling relaxed during cubing? Why do we all (OK, most of us) get
(much) better times when nothing is in stake at home, alone, and why
do we tend to get terrible times in competitions? Because of the
psyche. You want to do so it so faaast and you want it soooo badly
that, guess what?, you screw up ... When you get down to sub 20,
everything starts to matter, including your mental composure.

Now, having said that, I have to acknowledge that this "go slower"
does not hold for the LL. You really need to pick up the speed
there. The "go slower" tactics holds only for the F2L.

Good luck everybody and may you find some nice Christmas presents in
the form of good times with the cube "under your tree".

Jessica

> It certainly seems like you have what it takes to get below 20
> seconds. I think what Olly and Jessica said is definitely very

2220. Re: Pressies?
From: kyubeman <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 Dec 2002 06:50:15 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > Hello! Did anyone get any puzzles for Christmas? Someone got me the > traffic jam game, you know? the one which is a grid lock and you've got > to move your car out. My friend has that puzzle. It's pretty good to fill the time! :) I got 2 puzzles: The Rubik's Cube solution video (just for the fun of it ;) ) and a 5x5 cube from rubiks.com. It feels like a brick it is so heavy, and for now, it is very difficult to turn. I immediately scrambled the 5x5 as soon as I got it, and made sure to get no help whatsoever in solving it. 30 minutes later, I had solved it. It took some puzzling to adapt my 4x4 techniques to the 5x5, so it proved to be a good mental excersise. I have since solved it 5 more times, and only on the SECOND time, did I come across something that truly stumped me for a while. I was pairing up the edges, and had it down to where ONE 3 piece edge had an inverted center edge. It was the only wrong edge. And I kept trying alike sequences over and over again in vain, (figuring out much along the way btw) until finally, I had pieced together some moves that eventually corrected the parity problem. The rest of the day was completely smooth sailing, as this case never came up again! It was fun to have a good challenge though, and I even used my webcam to make a time-lapse video of me solving it. It feels good. Anyway, back to the 3x3 I assume... :) -Ross
2221. Re: Pressies?
From: "Grant Tregay <Grant@...>" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 Dec 2002 15:45:10 -0000

Yes!!!

My wife got me the "X-mas Special" from Mefferts.com. The puzzles
were a bit stiff out of the box, but after a good lube, the 4x4x4 is
amazing!! My previous best time, on a 6.5cm Mefferts 4x4x4, was
around 2:15, but the second time I solved this new (EastSheen) cube,
I got a 2:06.81 with both parity problems! Triggers work now - I
actually have to worry about overspinning! I'm going to see about
tightening the centers a little more - I may have left it a little
loose.

I'd never solved a "real" 5x5x5 before (only in applet form), so I
made my first attempt on my new, stiff, EastSheen 5x5x5, and got it
in a little under 9 minutes. I don't think I'll play with it much
more until I get it taken apart and thoroughly lubed. Then it should
be good for at least sub 6 minutes. I don't anticipate coming
anywhere close to my applet times, though.

Also, she got me a new wireless, optical mouse - granted it's not a
puzzle, but I'll have to see if it improves my applet times at all on
oinkleburger.com :-D

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Robert Roue wrote:
> Hello! Did anyone get any puzzles for Christmas?

2223. EastSheen 2x2x2
From: "Grant Tregay <Grant@...>" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 Dec 2002 19:41:20 -0000

Does anyone know how to safely disassemble the EastSheen 2x2x2 cube
(part of the Mefferts X-mas Special)? I'd like to take it apart to
lube it, but don't want to break it in the process. In the package,
they included instructions for taking apart and reconstructing the
4x4x4 and 5x5x5, but not the 2x2x2. I think with proper lubing I'm
going to like all the EastSheen cubes better than Rubik's or
Meffert's equivalents.



2224. RE: [Speed cubing group] EastSheen 2x2x2
From: Tyler Robbins <sum1else@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 Dec 2002 15:33:12 -0500

You don't need to take it apart to lube it. DON'T take apart the 2x2x2. Its easy to open, but it breaks very easily, I broke mine this week Tyler Robbins http://www.thepuzzlestore.com Specializing in Custom Sequential Movement Puzzles Ebay ID: Sum1ese -----Original Message----- From: Grant Tregay <Grant@...> [mailto:Grant@...] Sent: Thursday, December 26, 2002 2:41 PM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: [Speed cubing group] EastSheen 2x2x2 Does anyone know how to safely disassemble the EastSheen 2x2x2 cube (part of the Mefferts X-mas Special)? I'd like to take it apart to lube it, but don't want to break it in the process. In the package, they included instructions for taking apart and reconstructing the 4x4x4 and 5x5x5, but not the 2x2x2. I think with proper lubing I'm going to like all the EastSheen cubes better than Rubik's or Meffert's equivalents. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/

Date: Thu, 26 Dec 2002 20:36:27 -0000

You can use that straw thingy that usually comes with the lube to get it inside of the cube. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyler Robbins <sum1else@o...> wrote: > You don't need to take it apart to lube it. > DON'T take apart the 2x2x2. 2226. Re: [Speed cubing group] EastSheen 2x2x2
From: "Grant Tregay <Grant@...>" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 Dec 2002 21:39:51 -0000

So there's no good way to take apart the EastSheen 2x2x2 either, huh? Oh well. I guess I'll just spray into it, and hope for the best. In the past, when I just sprayed into a puzzle, I've had the same experience with it feeling sticky afterwards, like what Jessica referred to a while ago (http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/1930). It doesn't seem to me that it's actually worse than before lubricating it, but I think it works better if the puzzle is taken apart for lubrication. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyler Robbins wrote: > You don't need to take it apart to lube it. > DON'T take apart the 2x2x2. Its easy to open, but it breaks very > easily, I broke mine this week > > -----Original Message----- > From: Grant Tregay <Grant@T...> [mailto:Grant@T...] > Subject: [Speed cubing group] EastSheen 2x2x2 > > Does anyone know how to safely disassemble the EastSheen 2x2x2 cube > (part of the Mefferts X-mas Special)? I'd like to take it apart to > lube it, but don't want to break it in the process.
2227. Re: [Speed cubing group] EastSheen 2x2x2
From: Robert Roue <r.roue@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 26 Dec 2002 22:19:44 +0000

> So there's no good way to take apart the EastSheen 2x2x2 either,
> huh? Oh well. I guess I'll just spray into it, and hope for the
> best. In the past, when I just sprayed into a puzzle, I've had the
> same experience with it feeling sticky afterwards, like what Jessica
> referred to a while ago
> (http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube/message/1930).
> It doesn't seem to me that it's actually worse than before
> lubricating it, but I think it works better if the puzzle is taken
> apart for lubrication.

Don't forget how we discussed that come lubes are volatile. It is
these volatile lubes that cause the cube to become sticky. There are
volatile and non-volatile silicone based lubes. It is my guess that
the runny lubes, like the ones that are in aerosols are volatile. My
silicone lube is not volatile, it is a thick silicone lube. It's is
easy to put in a syringe and squirt into small spaces, which I have
done with some 2x2x2 cubes. It is lubed and ready to go straight away
with no drying time necessary.

2229. Re: Pressies?
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Fri, 27 Dec 2002 17:10:27 -0000

I got a fondu pot for christmas!!!! mmmmmmmmmmmm fondu.......

I bought myself the xmas mefferts special and am thoroughly impressed
with the cubes. I absolutely love my 4x4 and 5x5. I think they are
the best compared to rubiks and mefferts, my only complaint is that
they could be a bit bigger, i often end up getting my finngers
tangled up in them. I like the size of the 2x2 but i think the old
old 2x2s from ideal are the best.

I might have to get myself the blind mans pyraminx, its another
mefferts special!!!!

mmmmmmmmmm fondu
Jake

2231. algs
From: "Sam Fontana <robot8387@...>" <robot8387@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 27 Dec 2002 23:58:39 -0000

how come most people do the fridrich method starting on the bottom
but sites that show the algs show them to you with the cross at the
top? what the heck is going on?




2232. Re: algs
From: addicted_2_my_rubiks_cube <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 28 Dec 2002 00:14:59 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Sam Fontana <robot8387@y...>" <robot8387@y...> wrote: > how come most people do the fridrich method starting on the bottom > but sites that show the algs show them to you with the cross at the > top? what the heck is going on? its alot easier to put the picture on the top of the cube to show you the alg. And pretty much everyone who does F2L on top (or where ever) does the last layer on the top of the cube. Its just alot easier to see which alg to use when its on the top of the cube, so thats why most everyone does the LL on the top layer.
2233. Re: algs
From: eligeon <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 28 Dec 2002 00:48:07 -0000

One word....speed. Once you learn the algs, like mentioned above, on
the top layer, you then get it to where you can get it done on the
bottom. The reason for this is that you do not need to waist
precious seconds turning the cube over. :-D

2235. DIY kits, Stickers, etc.
From: cubacca1972 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 28 Dec 2002 02:51:13 -0000

I recently emailed rubiks.com to see if they would be able to ship
their DIY 3x3x3 cubes with the center caps off so that the spring
tension can be adjusted. I received a response from Patrick Hess,
stating that this was not possible as they get their cubes fully
assembled from the factory.

I also asked if they would consider updating their vinyl stickers so
that they would be brighter, like on the studio cubes.

I also stuck this question in with my email:

Have you checked out the various video clips from the members of the
speed solving club? The cubists are amazing, but the cubes look
pretty grim. Do you think it might be a good Idea for the
participants of the upcoming world championships to be supplied with
new stickers? It would certainly make your product more appealing
from a marketing standpoint.

Patrick wrote that they would keep these suggestions in mind.
Hopefully they can supply some stickers.

I think it would be too bad if the world's best cubists were to
gather in one place, get the worlds best times, with global media
coverage, on ugly cubes.

Lucas





2236. Re: DIY kits, Stickers, etc.
From: j_rueth <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 28 Dec 2002 03:26:47 -0000

>
> I think it would be too bad if the world's best cubists were to
> gather in one place, get the worlds best times, with global media
> coverage, on ugly cubes.
>
> Lucas



You got a good point.... BUT!!!!
The ugly cube is a symbol on how good we are. It shows that the cube
also has a significant factor besides the beautiful minds twisting
them. A beat up cube is a symbol of long hours of twisting and is
also like a scrapbook. (I memorized all permutations algs on this
cube).
Although.... nothing beats the good ole vinal stickers where you
can be the fastest cuber and solve the cube hundreds of thousands of
times and the stickers are just as bright as when you first got
them. Thats what we all could use :|

jake



2237. Re: DIY kits, Stickers, etc.
From: kyubeman <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 28 Dec 2002 19:17:16 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, j_rueth <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > I think it would be too bad if the world's best cubists were to > > gather in one place, get the worlds best times, with global media > > coverage, on ugly cubes. > > > > Lucas > > Funny you should bring this up! I just got a new cube with 2 sets of replacement stickers. The colors on the new cube are so vibrant, that I was disappointed when I got it! Because I assumed that good colors meant paper stickers. But, thankfully, I was wrong! I couldn't convince myself the good stickers were actually not paper, until I had my friend show me his new paper sticker cube. The stickers on his cube have less uniform colors. I mean, they look like they are blotchy almost, or glittery. Meanwhile, mine are smooth and shiny, a uniform color. Also, the replacement sticker sets that I got have TRUE colors! The yellow is ACTUALLY yellow, the orange isn't brown, and the blue is bright! Maybe my eyes are deceiving me, but whatever vinyl stickers I have now, are certainly better (slightly thicker too) than their first attempt at vinyl last year. If anyone else has new cubes/sticker sets, maybe they can verify this? -Ross

>

Are the replacement stickers the same colour on BOTH sides? Or are
they coloured on one side and white on the other. My guess is that
they are paper if they are white on one side. PVC if they are coloured
on both sides.

2250. Re: stickers?
From: nascarjon2001 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 30 Dec 2002 03:11:21 -0000

I have been using model paint for quite a while now and I really like it. It takes a while to paint a whole cube (I used four coats of each color), but it's definitely worth the effort. I have a good looking cube and it takes a long, long time to wear off the paint. I've uploaded some pics of it to the photo section. Jon --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "James Potter <theboywholived81@y...>" <theboywholived81@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Sam Fontana > <robot8387@y...>" <robot8387@y...> wrote: > > what do you guys think is the best thing to use instead of > stickers? > > paint finger nail polish tape? what does every one use? i personaly > > use sticker becuase they still have some color on them. 2253. Nail polish was: stickers?
From: "d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@...>" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 30 Dec 2002 10:52:49 -0000

Hey Sam, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Sam Fontana <robot8387@y...>" <robot8387@y...> wrote: > what do you guys think is the best thing to use instead of stickers? > paint finger nail polish tape? what does every one use? i personaly > use sticker becuase they still have some color on them. (except for > the yellows came off and i put duct tape on them, has a nice grip > actually!) I got a DIY cube from hessport and I'm trying nail polish. Yesterday I put on a white undercoat, 2 coats; six colors, 4 coats each. After that will come a clear protective layer, either 2 or 4 coats. I roughed up the surface with some sandpaper first. The yellow is really nice and bright though it didn't go on very evenly. The green and chrome (for white) came out pretty smooth. If I can get a scan of it I'll post it. I'll tell you how well it wears in a few weeks. I think that next time I'll go for spray paint because I think that it may be possible to get it really even and smooth. For those who are interested, my average is starting to drop below a minute. David J

2259. Re: notation
From: "Grant Tregay <Grant@...>" <Grant@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 31 Dec 2002 04:48:32 -0000

Typical notation for cube rotations would include x, y, z, x', y',
and z'.

Think of a typical graph - with the origin (where the axes meet) at
the center of the cube, the x axis extends to the right (through the
R face), and the y axis extends upward (through the U face on the
cube). To add the 3rd dimension, the z axis extends "outward",
toward yourself (through the F face). The three cube rotations x, y,
and z rotate the cube in the same direction as a clockwise rotation
around the face that they extend out through. For example, x means
to rotate the cube in the direction of the move R. Likewise, y'
would mean to rotate the cube in the same direction as the move U'.

I hope this makes sense and helps to clarify things.

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Sam Fontana" wrote:
> is there an easy way to understand the natation for rotating the
> cube in your hands? i dont really understand it. thanks




2260. Re: notation
From: "James Potter <theboywholived81@...>" <theboywholived81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 31 Dec 2002 05:28:05 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Sam Fontana <robot8387@y...>" <robot8387@y...> wrote: > is there an easy way to understand the natation for rotating the cube > in your hands? i dont really understand it. thanks Me neither, I just don't use it.

2262. quick tangent

might get a kick out of this (particularly math people). I duped my
little sister into posing for this picture, she'll probably kill me
when she gets older :). Anyway here's the link,
http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/images/jade-math.jpg

Chris

2263. Re: my cube
From: "d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@...>" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 31 Dec 2002 07:48:48 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Sam Fontana <robot8387@y...>" <robot8387@y...> wrote: > my cube has screws under the caps but they dont seem to change the > tension its similar to a oddzon cube but not a new one of theirs > should it change the tension or not? Yes and no. Depends on how you define "change in tension." Yes, if the cube is assembled; no, if the cube is apart. I don't know that cube, but, in a typical set up, the turning of those screws should only change the distance from the center cubies to the center of the cube's mechanism. The center cubies should spin freely, and the screw shouldn't interfere with that. The pressure on the other cubies can change with the change in distance from the center of the mechanism, and that is the only tension change you should feel. DJ
2264. Blindfold cubing

remember everything.

back and change. Also I wasn't at all sure I'd got my centres right,
so my mind started to stray to think of better ways to tackle it the
next time but, as it turned out, the cube was OK anyway.

I can see each line adds up to doubles, whatever that's called. 1, 2,
4, 8, 16, 32. I can see each line is symmetrical and I can see that
one diagonal line is all ones, the next goes up in steps of one and
then two and then three etc, which matches the sequence of the first
diagonal... My brain is ticking...

I've put some numbers down to carry on the sequence, but I'm sure I
don't know what I'm doing. Maths was never my strong point! Is the
next line:

. 1, 6, 15, 20, 15, 6, 1 =64
. 1, 7, 21, 35, 35, 21, 7, 1 =128
. 1, 8, 28, 56, 70, 56, 28, 8, 1 =256

How am I doing? Have I got the wrong end of the stick? To summarise,
you take two numbers on a line, add them together and you get the
number that goes between them on the line below, right? What are these
useful for? Only as an exercise?



2267. Re: [Speed cubing group] quick tangent
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 31 Dec 2002 14:20:12 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Robert Roue <r.roue@b...> wrote: > > Hey this doesn't really relate to the cube but I thought you guys > > might get a kick out of this (particularly math people). I duped my > > little sister into posing for this picture, she'll probably kill me > > when she gets older :). Anyway here's the link, > > http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/images/jade-math.jpg > > > > Chris > > > > P.S. it's geeky humor but what the heck > > > > Cute picture, but is there some significance with the number layout? > Just curious :) It looks like the coefficients of x^i in (x+y)^n. So it's a sort of primer to doing the binomial theorem. In a more general instance n might not be a non-negative integer but it's a good place to start and easily yields to methods of induction in that case.
2268. Re: [Speed cubing group] quick tangent
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 31 Dec 2002 14:31:58 +0000

The numbers are binomial coefficients, and together they are the first five
lines of Pascal's Triangle. The Fibonacci sequence, with its eternal march
towards the Golden Mean, is also buried in there, if you add up the numbers
along the diagonal.
S.

2274. No Subject
From: "simonl cube" <simonlcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 31 Dec 2002 18:41:51 +0000

Hi everyone. I have started a new group! It is called
blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube, and it is for anyone interested in (guess
what?) solving the Rubik's cube blindfolded.

I have started it partly because I want to get better at blindfold solving
the cube (so, self interest ..). But also, many really useful tips on
blindfold cubing have been posted here at speedsolvingrubikscube, but they
have sort of got lost amongst the many others posts that are more
specifically on speedsolving the usual way.

I am hoping (naturally enough!) that you real blindfold pros would like to
join the group, and also that people like me, who are learning / keen to
learn blindfold cubing will also join. Having a dedicated group will I
think be really good in the lead up to the championships next year (or this
year, depending on when you read this), as the pros prepare to compete
against each other!

Anyway, I think blindfold cubing is awesome, and deserves its own forum!!

So if you want to, go to:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube/
... and join up!

S.

2277. cube rotations
From: "Hana M. Bizek <hanabizek@...>" <hanabizek@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 31 Dec 2002 20:56:22 -0000

To those who wonder about rotations of the Rubik's cube:

There are esse tially two kinds of rotations
a) rotations of faces/layers that will disturb the cube (twiddling),
and b) rotations of cube in your hands, without disturbing it
(pivoting)

Case a) is what makes the cube what it is, a fascinating puzzle. Case
b) is less known, and is used primarily for visualization purposed in
3D cube art. I imagine speedcubists don't use it, because pivoting a
cube in your hands accomplishes nothing and wastes precious seconds.
But I could be wrong. Corrections?

Assume the origin of coordinates is at the cube's center, with three
mutually orthogonal axes.Because the cube's faces are parallel to the
xy, yz and xz planes, the axes will be orthogonal to them also. You
will be rotating your faces (case a) or entire cubes (case b) about
those axis. Singmaster noyation applies to the faces. I does not
matter how you define your x, y, z coordinates as long as you stay
consistent with the definition.

There are four basic angles of rotations of a face in order for the
cube to stay a cube. They are 90 degrees (pi/2), 180 degrees (pi),
270 degrees (3*pi/2), and 360 degrees (2*pi). The rotations are
1) rotation of a face/layer or cube by any of those angles about the
axis orthogonal to the F/B face, call it x
2) rotation of a face/layer or cube by any of those angles about the
axis orthogonal to the R/L face, call it y
3) rotation of a face/layer or cube by any of those angles about the
axis orthogonal to the U/D face, call it z.

That should be clear enough. It's just a bit of trivial geometry.

Hana a kostky
